name: Preşedinte. –
text: The first item is the debate on Council and Commission Declarations on Combating Racism, Xenophobia, Homophobia and other forms of intolerance (2016/2989 (RSP)).

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, you have invited the Council to intervene on a topic of common concern: how to combat racism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance. We very much share your preoccupation. The evidence from different sources such as the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights and the Council of Europe confirms an alarming increase of intolerance and hatred in Europe. There might be several reasons explaining this worrying phenomenon, but let me be clear on this: there can be no justification for it. The EU has adopted specific legislation on combating intolerance and hatred, in particular the 2008 Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia. The Presidency is aware that the Commission is currently looking into the national laws of the Member States to assess the framework and to ensure its correct implementation. Only a few months ago, in June, the Council reminded Member States of the need to ensure the effective transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision and other relevant laws at national level to counter the plight of hate crimes. In addition, the Council asked Member States to develop effective methods to report and ensure proper recording of hate crimes. It is also worth mentioning that the Council has adopted a directive that prohibits discrimination on grounds of racial or ethnic origin. It has been in place for more than 15 years and it is an important tool in the fight against racial discrimination.  As for the future: we need to combine our actions and strengthen the existing cooperation between institutions. In this context, I would like to recall the important step made last June, when the Council responded positively to the Commission’s list of actions to advance LGBTI equality. The Council invited the Commission to promote the measures outlined in that list and report regularly on the progress achieved. The Council has likewise invited the Member States to take action to combat discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity. The Council has also consistently supported the efforts of the EU and its Member States to improve the situation of the Roma, which is Europe’s largest ethnic minority. Moreover, in the context of interinstitutional cooperation, the Council has supported the ambitious plan of the new Commission high-level group seeking to develop with Member States concrete practices and tools to improve responses to racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. We also welcome the ongoing EU-level dialogue with major IT companies, in cooperation with Member States, to address online hate speech. Last but not least, we should remember and commend the remarkable work done by the Fundamental Rights Agency in this field.  Let me stress once again that racism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance are incompatible with our common values and principles. According to the legal framework in place they can even constitute a crime that should be prosecuted. There is indeed no exception from this for politicians abusing the freedom of expression by inciting to violence or hatred. Our role – and on this I count on your support – is to remind ourselves of our responsibility for what we say. Words have power, including the power to harm. For this reason, freedom of expression has its limits. It is our common responsibility to find the right balance, and this is never an easy task. I look forward to your debates, honourable Members, and I thank you for your attention.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová sends her apologies for being unable to attend this morning. She asked me to replace her and I am glad to do so. Increasing fear and high rates of verbal and physical violence against ethnic, religious or other minorities across Europe are – and remain – a major concern. As we never get tired of reiterating, the Commission condemns all manifestations of racism, xenophobia, homophobia and all other forms of intolerance as these are incompatible with the values and principles upon which the European Union is founded. I personally believe that we all, collectively and individually, have the duty to fight against intolerance and hatred and reject all of its expressions. Political and opinion leaders bear, in this regard, a particularly important responsibility since racist, xenophobic and other attitudes of intolerance expressed by leaders are, by their very nature, incompatible with the responsibilities they are called upon to fulfil. They also contribute to a climate in which hatred and intolerance become normalised. History should have taught us to be wary. But for those who live in the here-and-now, very recent events have shown that this is not simply a theoretical issue, but a very real danger. I commend the efforts that this place, the European Parliament, makes in ensuring that incitement to hatred pronounced by its Members is taken seriously and addressed. Public condemnation of racism and xenophobia by the authorities, political parties and civil society contributes to acknowledging the seriousness of these phenomena and actively fighting against racist and xenophobic speech and behaviour. In the Commission prevention and the fight against racism, xenophobia and all other forms of intolerance are shared priorities. The fact that we devoted the first annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights to combating racism and intolerance last year reflects that commitment. The Commission appointed two Commission coordinators to contribute to combating hate crime, hate speech and intolerance by engaging and listening to the community’s concerns with regard to two particular forms of racism and xenophobia which have reared their heads: anti-Semitism and anti-Muslim hatred. To give one illustration, in 2015 Jews were the target of 40% of all racist crimes committed in France and, as the November Fundamental Rights Agency report on hate crime and the current migration situation puts it, Muslims experience increased hostility as they are often perceived as perpetrators or sympathisers of terrorist attacks or for being part of a refugee movement seen as threatening safety and security. The Commission is acutely aware of this developing narrative and will continue to speak out forcefully against such stigmatisation and incitement to hatred against certain communities. We are also working with Member States to ensure they effectively enforce the legislation criminalising illegal hate speech, with particular regard to the EU’s Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia by means of criminal law, which concerns, as you know, the public incitement to violence and hatred on grounds of race, colour, religion, descent, national or ethnic origin. This legislation applies to incitement to violence or hatred, online and offline, including statements by political and opinion leaders. In the bilateral dialogues we have with Member States to ensure the correct transposition and implementation of this instrument, we have raised a series of issues and concerns. As a result, in the past two years, six Member States have made amendments to their criminal law to bring their legislation in line with the framework decision. Commissioner Jourová strongly reiterated the importance of ensuring correct transposition and effective implementation of the instrument at the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 14 October and urged national governments to do everything possible to ensure that national provisions can be swiftly and fully aligned to the EU rules and, just as importantly, that they are applied in practice. Member States’ law enforcement authorities and courts remain competent to investigate, prosecute and try individual cases of hate speech and hate crime. So it is only through working together with the Member States and other key actors, including civil society, that we can make a real difference on the ground, supporting national efforts to ensure implementation of the rules and to set up effective policies to prevent and combat this phenomenon. It is a matter of building the necessary commitment, capacity and making available resources and tools. The EU High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance is a unique platform for the exchange of best practice, guidance, strengthening cooperation and synergies, bringing together the key actors: civil society, community representatives, EU agencies, in particular the Fundamental Rights Agency, and relevant international organisations, including the UN, OSCE and the Council of Europe. The engagement of the European Parliament Intergroup against racism with this High Level Group is very welcome. We need to join our efforts to achieve common objectives. The group is focusing on issues such as how to improve awareness, enhance the effectiveness of investigations and prosecutions, better address under-reporting and ensure adequate victims’ support. The group is discussing forms of intolerance in order to develop and improve targeted responses. One priority for the High Level Group is to help all Member States develop sound methodologies for recording and collecting data on hate crimes, which can often go unreported or get mistaken for other offences. This work is carried out by a specific sub-group led by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights and that met for the first time in October. We have also taken important steps to counter illegal hate speech on the internet. A Code of Conduct on countering illegal hate speech online was agreed by the Commission with Facebook, Twitter, Microsoft and YouTube in May this year. We will present a preliminary assessment of the work in this area on 7 December. We are also looking at how to support further the role of the media and ethical journalism in promoting fundamental rights and to ensure that a pluralistic media environment can foster political debate on crucial issues for democratic societies. These and other related issues were at the heart of the discussion at this year’s annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, which First Vice-President Frans Timmermans hosted together with Commissioners Oettinger and Jourová earlier in November. Furthermore, we have consistently supported concrete projects to prevent racism, xenophobia homophobia and other forms of intolerance under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. Through the new call for proposals, which is now open, we are making available EUR 6 million for projects in this area. In addition, the Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN) continues to support frontline practitioners and civil society actors to effectively address the challenges of radicalisation and polarisation at a local level. Practitioners are concerned about how violent, extremist, racist groups, on one hand, or Daesh, on the other, exploit the refugee crisis to promote their own poisonous narratives. Within the RAN practitioners are developing practical approaches and ways to address and prevent polarisation in schools and local communities with the objective of supporting a cohesive and inclusive society and reaching out to all communities. They will look into more effective ways of countering different types of extremist propaganda, including xenophobic propaganda, also drawing on the expertise within the European Strategic Communications network. Everybody should be able to enjoy their fundamental rights. We are all entitled to the respect of our right to non-discrimination, to human dignity, to life, to integrity of the person, and to protection from violence. That is why the High Level Group will also include exchanges on the intolerance and violence suffered by members of the LGBTI community. All that said, notwithstanding our efforts and the results we have achieved so far, we know there is a lot more to be done. We are ready to report regularly on the progress made and evaluate the need for further actions, and we count on your continued support as well as your constructive engagement.

name: Kinga Gál
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, Officer, Minister. All that causes hatred, strengthens violence, intolerance in society is unacceptable. Not only on paper, but also in practice. However, I find it regrettable that, as a rule, EU decision-makers do not condemn intolerant behaviour against traditional national minorities. I would therefore like to draw attention to the intolerant behaviour that is taking place in the Member States of the European Union against European citizens who have always lived in their homeland and have not moved. against minorities. These include discrimination in the press and incitement of hatred, banning and sanctioning the use of their national symbols, and restrictions on the use of their mother tongue. These are deeply contradicted, and the European Commission should deal with these matters. Because any such intolerant behaviour gives European citizens who belong to traditional national minorities the feeling that they were only second-class citizens in their own country.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group - Europe is facing a rise in racism, xenophobia, homophobia, transphobia and other forms of intolerance. It shocks me that almost 300 transsgender people have been killed worldwide in the last year alone, according to Transgender Europe data. Brexit and US elections, however, have further fuelled different forms of hate speech and intolerance. These and other forms of hatred heavily poison dialogue and cooperation between people, are often the product of different ideologies and histories, and mostly hit the most vulnerable groups. Even in my country — Slovenia — we are facing an increase in intolerance. I regret that individuals use the plight of people to inflate intolerance and spread untruths. Attacks on refugees, religious facilities or institutions that promote intercultural dialogue are truly discarded acts that I condemn the harshest. We need to address prejudice and fears through education and education and through effective legislative action and policies. In practice, some Member States continue to undertake Framework Decisions and do not provide adequate protection against racist and xenophobic hate speech and hate crimes. There will come a time when history will judge us by actions. Each one has to ask themselves which side of history he wants to be on and what we did for it.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, I would like to stress that all people are born free and equal and with rights. Diversity is the basis of a livable society. Europe has the task of effectively promoting and protecting these principles where and when necessary. Living free and equal should be for everyone. Some groups and individuals experience more than others that their experience of equality and freedom is under pressure. Lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual, intersex, abbreviated LGBTI, are such a vulnerable group. Ten years ago, the Jogjakarta principles were drawn up by a group of international human rights experts. They provide an overview of international principles and human rights, specifically with regard to sexual orientation and identity. After ten years, the concerns expressed in the Yogjakarta principles are still equally relevant. LGBTI is discriminated against or stigmatised in a large number of EU countries. Progress has been made, but there is still a lot of work to be done. Culture, tradition or religion can never be an excuse for discrimination, not of LGBTI, but also of other groups, such as religious minorities, ethnic minorities, persons with disabilities. Tolerance is insufficient. Inclusion must be our goal.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we all know Niemöller’s poem: that first they came for the Communists, the Socialists and the Jews, and how he lamented that he had not spoken out for them until there was no one left to speak out for him. This was Europe 65 years ago, but now we see that we must speak out again. It’s happening to those others, whoever they are. In June, the UK had the most divisive referendum campaigns. Our Equality and Human Rights Commission said that the referendum campaign had, and I quote, ‘legitimised hate’. During the campaign, a young MP doing her job was shot and stabbed to death by a man consumed with hate, and who, shockingly, on his conviction was supported by 60,000 tweets. Two months after the EU referendum, Mr Arkadiusz Jóźwik, a Polish national, was assaulted and killed by six teenagers in what was believed to be a hate crime. In the weeks following the Brexit result, reported hate crime rose by 58% compared to the year before, but it’s not just in the UK. Politicians and leaders on both sides of the Atlantic and across the Union are again peddling hate and fear. It gives permission to others, who feed on this bile and who are deranged enough to think that it’s acceptable.  Many EU citizens living in the UK are very scared, as are those seeking refuge or who have migrated elsewhere in the EU. What has the UK Government’s response been? To ask companies to report to them their foreign-born employees. What message is this sending? This is not the Britain I know. This is not the Europe that I know. The Britain I know is outward—looking, decent and tolerant. The Britain I know stands up for everyone, no matter what their skin colour, what their language, who they love or who they worship. And it was this ethos that founded the European Union as Europe recovered from the horrors that inspired Niemöller’s poem. But in this sea of rising intolerance, there are glimmers of hope. After the death of Mr Jóźwik, the Polish Centre in London was deluged with flowers and messages of sympathy. Brexit or no Brexit, racist, homophobic and hateful speech must be publicly and forcibly condemned by us all, and I, as a Liberal Democrat, will continue to do just that.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Treaty, the Charter of Rights, the 2008 Framework Decision, the Istanbul Convention, so we fight racism, xenophobia and the violence against women. It is urgent that the Framework Decision explicitly condemns today Islamophobia, anti-Semitism, anti-Ziganism, homophobia that pollute our countries and even common institutions. It is serious that Commissioner Oettinger's attacks on women, gay, Chinese, become normal. It is also a matter of language, we are not united by abstract values but by precise norms. If there is a Union demos it is because of this regulatory pact: those who violate it cannot invoke discordant national cultures. I think every free individual, especially in times of strong immigration, has more memberships, more identities. Assimilation has a unique identity, it generates violence. Better integration in compliance with norms than the word assimilation.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, members of the Commission and the Council, Mrs Bearder has referred to what has been happening in the UK, especially after Brexit. Polish workers, people who came to the UK to work, have been physically attacked. Also, during the Brexit campaign and afterwards, attacks against black UK citizens, many of them born in the UK, have increased.  We have seen all over this continent a rise in racism, anti-Semitism, homophobic violence and hate speech, Islamophobia, xenophobia and also sexism. This is something that both the Commission and Council have to tackle more urgently. I welcome both of you speaking out and welcoming the Directive against discrimination on grounds of race and ethnic origin, and also the list of actions against homophobia. But the problem is that Member States are not delivering as much as they should. When we have, in Hungary for example, a Jobbik mayor making sure with a decree that in his city there should not be any propagation of, for example, same-sex marriage, or of the family as anything other than marriage and parent-child relationships, and banning muezzins and other issues, how can we not make stronger efforts for Member States to implement everything we have?  The Commission’s promise to implement the equal treatment directive is not happening. We need it urgently in order to make sure that this continent provides its citizens with what it promises.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue Card question. — Madam Honourable Member, You mentioned Hungary, where I come from, and I see that the situation is a little worse there, because there are not only extremist mayors, but the Government itself, the Government, the Government of Hungary, the Government of Viktor Orbán's Government, often use European money to heat xenophobia, xenophobia and all the concepts covered. Do you think this document has any repercussions on these processes at all?

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr Szanyi, for giving me the opportunity to speak 30 seconds more. Yes, for sure, the example I mentioned was just one of the most recent that also the government of Mr Orbán is not doing anything against. I agree with you, and we have been addressing this issue – the way the Orbán Government is working in Hungary, not protecting people with whatever differences that they might have. So, the one thing that we have voted in this Parliament – the pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights – is something that should be implemented, because that would help in order to move governments that are not adhering to European values away from that, and get them in line again with what we have decided on together.

name: Kristina Winberg
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Mr President, There are many bark words thrown around in this chamber all too often; “Racist”, “xenophobic” and nowadays “populist” are terms that could have a clear and clear meaning in a different climate of society. But given that you have called ordinary people — who simply have other perceptions around immigration — for this, the terms have lost their meaning. When did it become racist to want a controlled immigration? When did it become racist to care about the safety of women and children? When did it become racist to love one's country and culture? Our citizens have seen enough to be very concerned about the situation. This cannot be dismissed as populism or dissenting views. You in the EU pretend to fight intolerance while inviting millions of migrants coming from intolerant cultures. How can you expect our citizens to be tolerant with intolerance? I'll gladly take a round of applause too. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (“blue card”) in accordance with Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the “blue card” procedure. — Dear colleague, ask if it is racist to protect your culture. My answer is no, but I ask you: don't you think we can promote our own cultures without prejudice to other cultures, without excluding them?

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: answer (“blue card”). — Thanks for the question! I can only see in my country Sweden how in some cases we distance ourselves from our own culture to correct ourselves after the immigrants who come. For example, we stop celebrating school closings in church because we can bump ourselves with certain groups, and so on. I see more and more how we're leaving away from our own culture to align ourselves with others.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, last weekend Mr Juncker could not resist hoisting dictator Fidel Castro on the shield as a hero of many. The EU's sympathy for dictators who silence their opponents is a sign. Because, under their leadership, the Union is also turning into a dictatorship where there is no room for divergent opinions. Freedom of expression only applies here if you say what the politically correct elite wants to hear, and the Brussels elite is again at its best today. The squandering of heavily fought freedoms by putting away anyone with an unwelcome opinion as racist, xenophobic or Islamophobic. No means is shunned in the attempts to silence the opposition. The Brussels elite continue to move patriots away as extremists, criticizing the asylum sunami to hate. But, Mr President, please explain to those millions of voters what is racist about wanting to protect your country from Islamic terrorists and illegal immigration. What's wrong with trying to stand up for your own country and its inhabitants? Mr President, we also see in the Netherlands that, in a political process, the elite are attacking freedom of expression in a way that would not be out of place for Turkey. My own party leader, leader of the Dutch opposition Geert Wilders, must answer himself to court according to millions of Dutch people. But, Mr President, he will not be silenced. We are not going to be silenced because the time of politically correct looking away is over, and citizens everywhere are showing that they are sick of it. We are stronger than this politically correct “away with our” mentality, stronger than this cultural relativism, stronger than this political elite.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, hate crime is unacceptable and each day we see an increase in these despicable actions right across the EU. In my constituency of Northern Ireland some great work is being done to combat the causes and recently I was contacted by a local skills SME, which works with employers, developing recruitment models that are fairer to migrant workers. In many cases workers may have the professional skills and experience but the qualifications they have achieved elsewhere are not recognised. This often leads them to become socially and economically isolated. It is vital that every citizen has the capacity to make their own contribution and this is critical to changing the unwanted perceptions in society.  I am saddened today to hear many in this Chamber refer to the result of the British referendum as a victory for racism or xenophobia. I, like the majority of people in the United Kingdom, was heartbroken by the death of Jo Cox. The British people are a welcoming people, our communities are some of the most diverse across the continent. Crimes like this are abhorrent to the vast and overwhelming majority of our people. In choosing Brexit we simply rededicated our commitment to be free from the unnecessary disorder of Brussels.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The issue we are discussing today is not suitable for attacking each other politically somewhere and trying to take a political advantage from it. It is a serious issue for those who are genuinely subjected to religious persecution, who are not recognized as a minority and disadvantaged, or who are severely attacked as disabled people, or who cannot live the normal life they would like to live because of their sexual orientation. Single attacks — I could mention difficulties in every country, including in countries such as the one currently governed by Mr Tsipras. The minorities are just as unprotected as is perhaps the case in Hungary. So let us take this issue seriously together and not use it as a political vehicle to bash each other in party politics. I believe that the vast majority here in this House have a great will to counter any form of exclusion, disavocation of people, unjustified humiliation of people. If we, as the ones we see ourselves as democratic parties, really respect ourselves in this and not try to use it as a political electoral dispute, so to speak, then I believe we would use the people who are marginalised the most. That is why let us really stand together on this issue!

name: Preşedinte. –
text: I appeal to colleagues to try to sign up for the time allowed, as we have a formal sitting at 11:30 and we have one item on the agenda other than this point.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is very clear from this debate that we are acknowledging that we are going through an unprecedented period in our history. Members in this Chamber will remember the very optimistic time in which the Framework Decision on Racism was created and the Race Equality Directive happened; it was a different time in Europe.  But I want to say to those colleagues who mention Brussels in the negative way that they do, that this is a union of values. It is a union of values for those who are rejecting it and for those who stay, and that binds us together in one very important way. It means that it is very legitimate for us to legislate, to regulate, to say that it is important for all of our citizens – not minorities, by the way; those who are old, disabled, of a different sexual orientation, those who are a different colour, race – these are millions of our European citizens. They deserve protection and what we do not see is enough implementation by our Member States. These values still exist today in these difficult times, and I would say that it increases our value and increases our cohesion here in the European Union if we are determined to make this happen.  This is not a time for us to retreat on these values. It is a time to do, as Ms Bearder said, what needs to be done when we see hatred on our streets. This is not anecdotal. We know, because of the legislation we have implemented, that we are calculating and seeing, because our police forces tell us what is happening on our streets. This is a time to go forward, but I would say, finally, to the Council: ensure that this horizontal anti-discrimination directive happens so that millions of our citizens can be protected, in line with the values of this European Union.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Mr President! The initiative against racism, xenophobia and hate speech is problematic because it prevents its own concerns. On the one hand, it is intended to combat racism, but at the same time culturally or religiously motivated acts are excluded from criticism You don't want to see or address social patterns. Violence against Jews and homosexuals, for example, is growing rapidly in Europe today. It is mostly perpetrators from the Islamic culture who are responsible for these acts. Should we really close our eyes in such cases and pretend that's not? Likewise, it is incomprehensible why other hate messages, such as those by Islamists vis-à-vis Christians or those of the left-wing extremists, are not equally persecuted to the police — as often in Germany. The citizens of Europe take note of these double standards, and the election results of the coming months will also reflect frustration. The agreed process, despite all the objections to the contrary, leads to censorship and thus to the restriction of freedom of expression.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we are talking here about how to combat racism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance, and the truth is that it would be good to start each one at home and our own, by the European Parliament. Because it's true that many times, when we think about racism or homophobia, what we think is a group of Nazis beating a black or gay man. But we never think of a well-educated man, in a suit and tie, making a speech here in the European Parliament, or we do not think of a minister, or we do not think of a president of the government. But it is there, in governments and institutions, that there are the most disgusting cases of hatred and intolerance. It's Cameron talking about “plague of immigrants.” It is the Lithuanian Government, liberal, against homosexuals. It's Orbán, against refugees and refugees. It is Fernández Díaz, when he was a minister, talking about the survival of the species to charge same-sex marriage. And it's Valls against gypsies and gypsies. So, you also start with your matches. (She agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. — I was very interested in what you said about starting the fight against homophobia and similar phenomena in the European Parliament and in the politics of democratic European states. I'd like to understand well, how do you imagine this? Whether the European Commission should engage in elections in other states, for example, or should we subsidise preferred parties, which should win elections, or perhaps best delegalise certain lists. Maybe it will be a good form of eliminating the phenomena you adhere to from public life.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: blue card response. — Mr Jurek, what I am saying is that many of the parties represented here — social democratic parties, conservative parties, liberal parties, European People's Party members — have leaders, presidents, ministers who are doing Homophobic speeches, who are making xenophobic speeches — we also have Commissioner Oettinger. So what I'm saying is that everyone starts looking around his house. And, of course, let the Bureau of the European Parliament not allow certain speeches in this House to be given with total impunity.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I want to start by echoing the words of Catherine Bearder and also welcoming what the Commission has said, but I would also point out to some of our colleagues that culture is not fossilised and it changes. I am sure we are very grateful that we are not living in the Middle Ages at this moment.  I would also join those who have asked the Commission, and the Council as well, to move forward on completing the horizontal anti-discrimination directives and to consider updating the Framework Decision against racism, xenophobia and anti-Semitism, to cover all groups in line with the Victims of Crime Directive. In terms of other action that we can take, I think it is important that we strengthen the role of the equality bodies in each of our Member States. My own Member State has seen its budget slashed down by about two-thirds over the last six years. The valuable work that can be done at the grassroots level is cut away because our equality bodies are not fully independent and cannot carry out their role adequately.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, violence should never be tolerated, but let’s get it into perspective. Sir Julian, you think hate crimes are under-reported. I will address that. Catherine Bearder cites misleading and anonymous statistics. Most of the so-called hate crime is reported anonymously and not subject to independent verification, including the police’s site True Vision. Other sites have been set up on social media. There are many. Anyone can log on and push up statistics, such as the hate-filled left for their own political agenda, as seen in this place. All can be anonymous and not subject to verification. It is very subjective.  The attacks on a Polish Cultural Centre in the UK were against a Polish pro-Brexit group. Get it into perspective. Other attacks were registered against Goths, punks and some misogyny. Nothing to do with post-referendum Britain, so don’t label it as such. Brexit and the election of Trump in the US demonstrate across the western world that people are tired of your political corrective multicultural lectures of the establishment. We’ve Brexited and we can get out of this place and stop listening to the hate-filled left. And you, Bearder.

name: President. –
text: This was uncalled-for. Really. That is my personal opinion. You have your own personal opinion, you have voiced it. I have my personal opinion and I am voicing it, and I go on and ask Mr Fountoulis to take the floor for one minute and 30 seconds.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask you a question: In the morning, when you leave your house, you obviously lock your door. The same applies in the evening, before going to bed. Why? Afraid a stranger might come in, a stranger? Are you xenophobic, racist and intolerant? Just as you have the right to protect your residence and choose who to accept and host, countries have the same right. It's not a matter of xenophobia but of legitim You are very willing to baptize those who do not agree with the prevailing liberal ideology as extremists and extremists, while daily with your practices you show your perception of democracy, where everyone is free to say what they want, as long as they do not disagree with your views. Moreover, I have never seen you concern yourself with systematic racism and discrimination against the indigenous people of Europe. In the name of supposedly protecting the rights of immigrants, you are characteristically bias at the expense of the majority, and in some countries you are making the lives of citizens intolerable in order to enforce your ideologies. Do you not realise how provocative it sounding to the ears of millions of homeless people in Greece to call vulnerable groups existing or non-existent minorities, at the same time when they cannot even provide the basics? Are you aware that at the moment it is clearly easier in Greece to be a refugee or an illegal immigrant than to be a Greek unemployed? For example, illegal immigrants have free access to the Health System, which is not the case for the Greek unemployed. But the peoples will soon overthrow your destructive policy with their vote. Now none of you doubt the upcoming historical changes, and you are afraid of them. You're doing well!

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner King, on 16 November, 21 years have passed on the United Nations Declaration on Tolerance, but, let us be honest, there are still many obstacles to a fully tolerant Europe. In 2015, a third of Europeans declared not feeling comfortable if their son, or daughter, had a Muslim partner or partner. A little more than a fifth considered that the LGBT community should not have the same rights as heterosexual people. Also a fifth of Europeans did not feel comfortable working with a person of gypsy origin. European women still earn 30% less than men, and many find that acceptable. All these data cannot leave us indifferent, especially at such a delicate time when populism is a little everywhere. Parliament must continue its work in the various fields by combating intolerance. Especially at a time when populist political speeches sow hatred and preach violence, we must reaffirm and make it felt that tolerance and non-discrimination have been fundamental values of the European Union since its foundation, both for the Member States and in the Union's external action. This is clear in the Treaties, in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and is reflected in numerous Community legislation.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: — Mr President, while a framework decision on combating racism has existed since 2008 and a committee was established in 2016 to combat racism, hate, racist and homophobic rhetoric are expressed more and more freely in public space. This trivialization is not acceptable. We must promote the values of the European Union, whose motto “United in diversity” is not just an abstraction. The retreat on oneself, the closure of mind, the lack of curiosity, everyone for himself, the stunted Europe is not what we want. So we must act by taking concrete, clear and exemplary measures towards anyone who makes this type of speech, whether it is a citizen, a head of state, a parliamentarian, a European Commissioner or a local elected representative. At a time when, for example, in France, some municipal elected officials censor posters on which homosexual couples appear, in order to violate good morals, it is clear that the road that remains to be done is still long. I would like to recall, however, that all forms of racism must be combated and that there is no hierarchy in racism. Indeed, combating all forms of racism also makes it possible to fight effectively against each of them. This is another way of saying that no one is more equal or unequal than the other.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, our topic today is one of the most important: the defence of the dignity and human rights of every person. We are having an ongoing debate on human rights on a global basis. We will find each other and consensus when we are condemning transgressions far away, but when the core values of the EU treaties are violated within the Union, we will start dodging. Racism, xenophobia and homophobia have only grown in several Member States, and growing inequality will only give them a further boost. Hopelessness is the kind of fuel from which prejudices mound against each other. Let's not feed that hopelessness. It is shown that the European Union is about more than just the market, the power of money and the building of walls. It is really about the values that we require, above all, of ourselves.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I spoke here last night about anti-Roma sentiment in the European Union. But this is just one of the aspects of racism and intolerance that have been taking place in recent periods on the territory of the European Union. This is despite the fact that the current Commission has been letting itself be heard for a long time that it is necessary to fight against the forms of racism, xenophobia and intolerance. I am very pleased that Věra Jourová has announced the creation of a high-level group to combat the manifestations of racism and intolerance. The EU needs to set an example for the rest of the world and put itself in a leadership role on this issue. But when I hear speeches from some MPs here, I ask: Isn't it us, MPs, politicians who are stoking this intolerance and these contradictions? Shouldn't we, MPs, think about how we give or don't give a cause for similar outings on the internet?

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: – Mr President, racism and discrimination should never be accepted or normalised because they are violations of democracy and the rule of law. Some people in this Chamber do not understand that. My message is for those who feel threatened and scared due to the normalisation of hatred. In Parliament, I will continue to fight and call out, and I will not stop until Muslims, Jews and other religious minorities can practice their religion freely, Roma people have full access to their human rights, black Europeans are protected from Afrophobia, LGBTI people can love whom they want, trans people are able to express who they are, people with disability are treated equally, refugees are no longer demonised, and violence against women is recognised as a security issue. These are the values that underpin the EU. These are my values, which I will fight for in the face of racists and populists, in the ARDI intergroup, inside the Parliament and in cooperation with the Commission.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr. President! I consider it important to combat all kinds of intolerance, all the more so as we still encounter this phenomenon quite often in the Union. For example, workers from Eastern European Member States who exercise the right to work freely and work in another state are often faced with intolerance. Or I could mention my country, where we are not only used to send national minorities to Asia, not only during elections. There is a great responsibility not only for politics, but also for the press. But we could also talk about the importance of education. Look at what the history books say. European citizens must be aware that the rights inherent in EU citizenship are for everyone. If we talk about European solidarity, then the first step is to accept each other as Europeans and not to distinguish between Europeans and Europeans, Europeans and people.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all the Member States have transposed European anti-discrimination directives into their system, yet never as today do we see a significant increase in episodes violence, racist and xenophobic, and the affirmation of new forms of discrimination, such as aphrophobia against which the Member States have not yet adopted joint law enforcement strategies. Legislation alone is not enough to ensure full equal treatment, just as social reprovation is not enough to stop the wave of hatred that is spreading across Europe. What we really need is a greater political awareness of the phenomenon to build an alternative cultural and social model, for the value of pluralism and integration to be affirmed as a common heritage. And combined with this, more decisive action against those who, while holding political and institutional offices, instigate and foment hatred and intolerance. Racism can never be a tool of political struggle and must be condemned.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: Mr President, we have the 2008 Framework Decision, directives, resolutions, the very heart of the Treaty: we all speak of the fight against intolerance, against racism, against xenophobia, appealing to equality, appealing to human rights, the rule of law, human dignity, freedom and democracy. But there is no doubt that in recent years there has been an escalation of intolerance — what I call a metastasis of intolerance — in Europe. That means that intolerance has been introduced, even, in some government political parties, has sometimes penetrated institutions; it is visible and submerged intolerance, with multiple forms: against Gypsies, Islamophobia, anti-Semitism, against disability. Against all those sectors that are vulnerable. And that is why I call on the Commission to step up its efforts, to make a comprehensive strategy, to update the Framework Decision for 2008 and to fight.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: Mr President, we cannot close our eyes to what is happening around us. Throughout Europe there are movements that have hatred for the different — because of their origin, their beliefs, their skin color, their sexual orientation — at the root of their being. Nationalism, xenophobia, racism, homophobia, the worst ghosts of a past that we thought surpassed, but once again beats us virulently. The increase in attacks on foreigners after Brexit proves that no society can be considered safe. Action is needed to combat the growth of hatred; action by the European Commission, but also on the part of the Member States, not only for justice, but also for the very survival of the European project and the values that feed it. Enough now!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: (ECR). — (EL) Mr President, historical experience has shown that economic difficulties, the long-term economic recession but especially the economic crisis and the rise in unemployment among young people, who feel deprived of any prospect of true social inclusion, are instrumental in the emergence of phenomena of racism, xenophobia and intolerance. These phenomena appear to be intensifying in the countries of Europe where migratory flows are increasing, in particular the waves of illegal immigrants. These timeless phenomena lead societies to impasse, conflict, fragmentation, disintegration and marginalization. Combating them therefore means combating those political decisions and actions that deepen poverty, which cause war conflicts and mass movements of populations. Unless we talk about austerity, the Dublin III Regulation, the need for a peace process in the Middle East and the need to build societies based on solidarity and mutual assistance rather than inhumane competition, we cannot fight xenophobia and racism.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, racism and xenophobia have raised their heads in Europe. These are nasty breezes of a past world that I already believed had been left behind us. It would be up to us politicians to set an example and a model: there should be zero tolerance for racism, xenophobia and discrimination of any kind. This principle should also apply to the way we speak here in Parliament. This, of course, requires that humanity be respected and without exceptions. You cannot exercise your own basic freedoms, such as freedom of speech, in an attempt to nullify the people and fundamental rights of another group of people. I am glad that the President of the Parliament has put in place a hard line and that MEPs are punished if they make a racist speech. Hopefully the future President will follow the same way

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Mr President, I should like to begin by congratulating Mr King on his speech and those colleagues who have moved in the same direction, because it was a speech that was drawn directly from the enlightenment. But, Mr King, our problem is that racists, xenophobes, do not listen to us. They have no contact with us. Your speech may reach the ears of those who agree with us. The rest have already built their own identity. They're stranded in a virtual camp. What can be done? We need state social. We need to get them back in touch with the whole of society. Of course, I am talking about the citizens and not the powers that promote racism. How is that possible? State social, state social, work for all, good and fast access to health systems for all, state social, education at all levels; and we still need media that does not promote populism, not depend on political powers. That's what we need, Mr. King, or they'll beat us. Politics society!

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). — (EL) Mr President, the obvious inability of political parties and of individual politicians to deal with the problems it has created in all the countries of Europe, and especially in Greece, the massive and uncontrolled turnout of millions of illegal immigrants, leads them to create new concepts, distort old ones and try in this way to say that they will deal with the issue. Thus, the reaction for example of parents of children in Greece to accept unvaccinated children of illegal immigrants who carry a multitude of diseases is called racism. The condemnation of the delinquent behaviour and crime of illegal immigrants is called xenophobia. When measures are taken against illegal immigrants, then we are extreme and intolerant. All this is intended to create a complex of guilt in the world, so that it does not react, and that is why any reaction is criminalized. But this is how the world is divided and racism is applied against the indigenous people of Europe.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on a point of order, you distributed the catch—the—eye on the basis of the groups in Parliament. Would it not be more logical to base it on the numerical strength of the groups? For instance, my group is five or six times larger numerically than other groups and, under the d’Hondt system which is often used in this Parliament, we should be given some consideration for extra speaking time under that system. That is something you may wish to answer now or reflect upon so that there will be greater equality under the d’Hondt system in catch—the—eye.

name: President. –
text: If you ask me, personally I would prefer to allow everybody to speak, and the fact that you are more than others does not mean that the others do not have the right to speak. This is my judgment. Maybe I’m wrong, we will certainly raise this with other colleagues because as far as I know there are no precise rules on who should get catch-the-eye. It is the prerogative of the President. Some other Presidents will probably have a different view but this is mine and I am trying to explain it, but thank you for your point of view. We do not want to transform this debate into another debate, but if you insist...

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - He doesn't want to take his voice in the debate. I just want to point out that between the twelve submissions and the seven votes given there is only five minutes of difference, so with such an important debate regarding the public good, free speech is really worth using the call procedure from the room and carry it out in full if it is only twelve submissions.

name: President. –
text: Yes, but sometimes we are under time pressure. I announced that we have this special session which starts at 11.30, so due to that we have to sacrifice and try to find a balance, but thank you.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Thank you for organising this important debate and thank you to all who spoke. Can I just for one moment join Ms Bearder and Ms Dodds who recalled the tragic murder of Jo Cox, a Member of the British Parliament, and can I just salute her memory and her work promoting tolerance and inclusion. As a number have said – Mr Moraes, Ms Guillaume, Ms Hohlmeier amongst others – we are bound together by our values. One of those values, a key value for me and for us all, is freedom of expression. We are not talking here about limiting freedom of expression. We’re talking about incitement to violence or hatred, which is a crime. Again, of course, we should have respect for the achievements of previous generations, our histories and our cultures. But we also need to be conscious of the lessons of history, the tendencies to intolerance, prejudice and fear, and those we must combat through promotion of tolerance and inclusion. And we need to work altogether, and with our Member States, to pursue that. There have been a number of questions about what the Commission is doing with Member States, so I’ll answer that. In the course of the last year the Commission has initiated bilateral dialogue with 24 Member States with a view to ensuring full and correct transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision on Racism and Xenophobia that we’re discussing today. In the course of those discussions, I’m glad to say, positive progress has been reported in a number of Member States. But there remains more to be done, as I said at the start of this debate. The Commission has begun pre-infringement proceedings against a number of Member States where there are still substantive gaps in their implementation of this framework decision. We’re going to continue to engage in a constructive discussion, obviously, with national authorities in line with the principle of sincere cooperation, but the Commission will not hesitate to use its power to launch infringement proceedings where these efforts prove unsuccessful. Because – as I said at the beginning, and as has been echoed throughout this debate – we are determined to ensure that everyone is able to enjoy their fundamental rights because we are all entitled to the respect of our rights to non-discrimination, to human dignity, to life, to integrity of the person and to protection from violence.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to make two points in conclusion. First, Mr Moraes and Ms Lambert referred to the proposal for a horizontal equal treatment directive. As you know, the discussions in the Council are very complex due to the proposal’s intricacies and the requirement for unanimity. Nevertheless, the Slovak Presidency has worked hard since the start of its term and our intention is to present a progress report which we will submit to the Council on 8 December. Secondly – and more importantly in my view – I would like to repeat what I said at the beginning, namely that hate crimes, racism and discrimination have no place in our societies and we have to fight them with resolve. I believe the problem that we have been discussing here this morning has two dimensions. On the one hand, we have a legal framework at EU level, the Charter of Fundamental Rights Framework Decision, and Member States of course have clear commitments that need to be implemented. But the second dimension of this is that I do not think we can be successful in fighting xenophobia and anti-Semitism successfully unless we mobilise our citizens to actively stand against those who are spreading hatred in Europe. To mobilize our citizens means, of course, raising awareness and showing courage – a civic courage – in protecting those who are victims of acts which we all know are clearly against the values we all share. I also believe that we have to bear this civic dimension in mind as well and not only focus on the role of institutions when we want to fight against these phenomena that clearly undermine our democratic societies.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – During the last year Europe has seen a rise in racist, xenophobic and homophobic views in governments and among many citizens. Hate crimes on the basis of sex, religion, and race have been increasing in numbers and little has been done to combat the situation. Many European politicians and political campaigns have been spreading fear and intolerance through the minds of European citizens, enticing groups to attack people of other races or nationalities. These tendencies have been fuelled by such events as Brexit. After the campaign against migrants and the nationalistic ideology of the Brexit movement, a Polish citizen was killed in the UK.  Cyber hate speech provides individuals with a shroud of secrecy that further prevents them from receiving any type of punishment. The European Union has to respond to this situation. In June 2016 Commissioner Jourová announced the creation of a High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance; this is a vital step in the fight against this intolerance, but the fight must be pushed further. The fight has to span through the education sector and into the daily lives of our civil societies.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — Like everyone else, I can only be indignant at racist, xenophobic, homophobic or intolerant provocations, words or acts. Unfortunately in this regard, the Commission and the Council, like most of the rulers of the Member States, are blinded by a well-thinking ideology. For example, the accusation of racism is very popular on the left as in an uncertain right towards anyone who fights against communitarianism, uncontrolled immigration, multiculturalism, dilution of identity, defence of French or European cultural heritage or the looting of social security. Professional anti-racists have used it, in an often inappropriate use, only intended to discredit the other or by knowingly forgetting to describe as racism what must be racism (anti-white racism, anti-Christian or anti-French racism, assumed anti-Semitism of certain populations...). This anti-racism is now emptied of its substance by the blessed of multiculturalism and social dumping. They use it above all to serve as a moral guarantor in order to overlook the major political-financial affairs and the real problems and aspirations of the peoples.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – Hate speech is anything but free. It a tool of oppression, of dehumanisation – and this allowed homophobic rhetoric has led to the categorical murder, including suicide, of thousands. Homophobia tries to perpetuate the idea that you are less human than others based on aspects such as who you love, rather than how you love. Europe has a problem with hate. And many may say, these are empty calls for action, but how can you say that when this year alone 295 Europeans were murdered because they were trans or gender-diverse?  We still live in a Europe where being queer is sometimes still an act of bravery, and thousands of young Europeans are still terrified to live. They experience violence on public transportation, in our schools, in bathrooms, at the gym and more. Citizens do not deserve a Europe where they must hide themselves to feel safe. This is why I wholeheartedly support, welcome and thank the Maltese Presidency, which has pledged to bring the equality directive, currently blocked in Council, to the fore during its upcoming presidency.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The contrast to incidents of incitement to hate and hate crimes based on racism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance must be a priority objective in defining European policies against discrimination and in the field of justice. In a European Union founded on the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights continue to occur both social divisions and the spread of dangerous and irrational hatred towards minorities, foreigners and generally towards who is perceived as different. Manifestations of these phenomena also concern the public sphere and the internet, both by individuals and political forces that often exploit socio-economic crises. At social, cultural, informational level, as well as criminal, Member States must have a leading role in taking appropriate measures to prevent, report and prosecute crimes and behaviour intolerant, violent and discriminatory that undermine peaceful civil coexistence and offend human dignity.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. — In recent years, several conceptual documents, strategies, charters or regulations have been devoted to reducing racism or xenophobia at different levels. Nevertheless, the spread of hatred is on the rise practically throughout the European Union. The Council and Commission statements should clearly indicate what other measures are preparing to reverse this trend. Existing regulations at EU level need to be reviewed. We need to know their effectiveness, their practical impact, as well as the consistency of their application in each Member State. Even politicians from so-called standard parties do not contribute many times to improving the situation. By abusing sensitive topics, they are trying to earn cheap political points. They do so despite the fact that they should try to fight with the rise of hate. It is, unfortunately, visible in many European countries. It is important not to allow fear and hatred to control society. Hate spreaders, whether on social networks, but also in real life, cannot feel impunity. We must respond appropriately to their actions, so that people's ability to recognise what is wrong is no longer reduced.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. - The fight against racism is about our belief in the rule of law, human dignity, and ultimately democracy. The fact that, as citizens with equal rights, we are all part of a bigger thing, a community. It is the duty of everyone to respect fundamental human rights and to take action against understanding of rights. The germ of racial discrimination is already unacceptable, so we have to take action against it when it comes to friendly conversation, political speech or legislation. Cultural diversity must be treated as a value, and we must confront any effort that would encourage our fellow human beings to divide, oppose and scapegoat. Racism, racial prejudice is the breeding ground for all the evil that man can commit against man and humanity. Let's learn from our history. The exclusion of certain groups of people worldwide is intensifying, and this can be tackled with a common will and courageous confrontation.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: in writing. — Your incantatory debate on the so-called rise of “racism of xenophobia, homophobia, intolerance in Europe” is that one more opportunity to try to blame the legitimate popular reaction. No one in Europe is racist in the etymological sense: supporters of the domination of one race over another. Some may be xenophobic, by becoming foreigners in their own country, without ever consenting to it. But this feeling is common to all peoples who feel an excessive foreign presence. In truth, you want to stop the rising discontent. You multiply liberticidal laws. In France alone: Pleven law, which prohibits criticism of immigration; Gayssot law which prohibits any criticism of official dogmas on contemporary history; Perben law which prohibits the preference of the natural family to homosexual unions; Taubira law which prohibits any relativization of slavery, but only of European origin. Your speech is filled with the usual hate poncifs. contempt for the popular classes retive to globalism. Calls for repression in the name of... tolerance! Conviction of Europeans alone. Fortunately your logorrhea has no grip on reality.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — It is strange that certain actions officially taken by the Commission and other organisations for the benefit of minorities (indifferent whether national, religious, LGBT or otherwise) result in a strong increase in negative reactions. These reactions are directed both against beneficiaries, or addressees of these support measures, and against the authorities or organisations taking those measures, indifferent whether they are local, regional, national or multinational. Perhaps the main problem is that in today's society a sense of the need to “fulfil its obligations to society” has faded at all levels. If such a feeling is absent, if citizens, in order to exercise their rights, do not consider it necessary to fulfill their obligations to society (family, region, nation) first, then necessarily there is the disintegration of society. After all, we see this in particular in the last 30 years, especially in industrialized states. That is where this negative development takes place particularly clearly. It all starts with a number of politicians confusing democracy with anarchy and that already young children in kindergarten learn about their rights as a child, but no one introduces them to the fact that they also have any obligations. The consequence of this is an increase in extreme policy directions, as we see it in recent years in virtually all EU countries. The mixing of tolerance and support, as the European Commission has presented in a number of its proposals, only makes this situation worse.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — Fighting racism and xenophobia is a challenge that requires a wider response, as unfortunately in the last period both are on the rise. I welcome Commissioner Jourova's announcement on the creation of a high-level working group to combat racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. Nevertheless, it is still alarming that racism and xenophobia are on the march, often accompanied by homophobia, sexism and other forms of hatred and intolerance. Unfortunately, political parties are increasingly resorting to racism and xenophobia and are planning to guard against asylum seekers and immigrants, including EU citizens from other Member States. That is why the EU must clearly and loudly condemn all forms of intolerance, racism and racial and other discrimination. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, on the basis of the principle that all people are born free and have equal dignity and equal rights, expressly prohibits any discrimination. A company that ignores, promotes or carries out discrimination based on racial or otherwise distinction is dysfunctional and entwined with risks. In my view, Member States should be particularly careful to avoid racial discrimination when treating foreign nationals when entering and entering national territory, by giving an example to their citizens, which must be positive rather than negative.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) Much is said about racism, xenophobia, homophobia, sexism and other forms of intolerance. But those who speak, shedding hypocritical crocodile tears, are often primarily responsible for the resurgence of these issues in Europe. Not innocently, racism, xenophobia and intolerance are mixed with religion, terrorism and fanaticism, as if social issues, unemployment and exploitation were not at the root of all these phenomena. Hence our fight for another Europe. The other Europe of workers and peoples will be born from their struggle and from the free and sovereign will of the peoples. It will defeat racism, xenophobia, reactionary theories and affirm friendship between peoples. This other Europe will be the more vivid and just the stronger the affirmation of the right to sovereign development and social progress, it will be the more united the more equal its sovereign states.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This debate is a sham debate. The EU and its institutions — including this' Parliament '— are experts with selective tolerance when it comes to combating racism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance. Here, double standards are constantly being measured. If a conservative government wants to implement its electoral programme, for which it was democratically elected, then Brussels is manipulating with “fundamental rights mechanisms”, “rule of law procedures” and “blue letters”, especially against conservative governments in Central and Eastern Europe. However, if the Socialist Interior Minister in France uses tear gas to shoot at peacefully demonstrating families with strollers, then this is a concern of the United Nations Human Rights Council, but not the centre-left European Commission. If — once again in socialist France — the parliament wants to adopt a far-reaching muzzle remission against associations that are engaged in the pregnancy counselling for women in need, then Merkel's friends of the EU Commission close their eyes. The Fundamental Rights Agency must be abolished. It is an outsourced arm of the European Commission. This tool of the LGBT lobby promotes gender ideology. Show me a single example of successful action by the Fundamental Rights Agency for the common good. Don't you find anything? Consequences should then be drawn: no EU clientele policy on public tax money.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (2016/3001 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. — (FR) Mr President, this year the European Parliament has already addressed the critical situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) twice, with its resolutions of March and July. The Council, for its part, has already adopted conclusions twice this year as well. The DRC will once again be on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council meeting on 12 December. This is a huge country with enormous challenges. At the same time, its potential is immense, from the point of view of natural resources, of course, but even more so in terms of human potential and cultural attractiveness. For many years, the European Union has shown its solidarity with the people of the east of the country. We are committing our humanitarian aid to 1.5 million displaced people, for refugees, women victims of sexual violence, used as weapons of war. For example, more than 20 humanitarian partners have invested nearly €40 million this year. We are also working to find solutions to the root causes of conflict, not only through future European regulations on conflict-related minerals, but also through support for the Kimberley Process for Transparency in Diamond Mining and by supporting the initiative of the Regional Conference of the Great Countries Lakes against illegal exploitation of natural resources. The European Union is also committed to combating impunity in eastern Congo. We support the work of Monusco and the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. I would also like to reiterate the importance of our CSDP missions, which have now been completed in the areas of police and military, namely EUPOL and EUSEC, for the governance of the country. I wanted to underline this commitment in the DRC, although the political situation has led us to review the usefulness of our partnership. Today, the only way to ensure stability in the DRC is to guarantee a democratic transition for the first time in its history. A clear calming of the situation could be achieved if President Kabila unambiguously confirmed that he will respect the mandate limit and that the current constitution will remain in force during the transitional period without amendment. Derogating from the constitutional deadline is only possible on the basis of a truly inclusive agreement, which can lead to a period of peaceful and as brief transition as possible. That is why the European Union has supported a framework for dialogue facilitated by the African Union. However, the resulting political agreement on 18 October may not satisfy this expectation. The risk of violence at the end of 19 December is significant, especially after the bloody crackdown on 19 and 20 September, which left more than 50 people dead on the streets of Kinshasa. A report by the UN Human Rights Office clearly points out the responsibility of the state's security apparatus. Together with other international partners, we have requested an independent investigation into these events. Since the Council conclusions of 23 May and 17 October, which are in line with Parliament's March resolution, the European Union has recalled the individual responsibility of the heads of justice and security institutions to act in strict respect for the rule of law and rights of man. Unfortunately, the repression of opponents and members of civil society, including largely unjustified arrests, the closure or interference of radio broadcasts, including RFI, has continued in recent weeks. In the coming days, the Council will announce its decision on the first restrictive measures. But our action will not remain there. First, we will continue to fully support the efforts of the Conference of Bishops of Congo to make the political agreement more robust and inclusive. We call on both the government and the opposition to cooperate constructively in this direction. Secondly, the European Union makes a clear appeal to the new government to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms and ensure security without repression. The European Union is also committed with its partners to work to strengthen the electoral cycle, and in particular the electoral commission. An electoral commission that enjoys neither the confidence of the Congolese actors nor that of its partners will not be able to fulfill this role. It is only in such a context, and on the basis of a truly inclusive agreement, that the European Union can consider providing financial support to the elections. The European Union will continue to work closely with the region, the African Union and the DRC's neighbours. I have met with several of these representatives recently, and I know that they share the same concern and objectives of a democratic and peaceful transition. Finally, the role of the United Nations Security Council and Monusco will remain crucial. We encourage the Government to further engage in effective collaboration on the ground between the DRC's armed forces and Monusco. The Democratic Republic of the Congo undoubtedly has a special link with Europe. It is our history, it is our interest in the stability of the entire Great Lakes region, it is the relations between our peoples that are at stake. This country has experienced violence that cannot be forgotten. Only a return to dialogue and compromise can prevent further violence. The people of the DRC simply aspire to get involved in the future of their country. Only a true democracy can respond to this request. The future of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is inseparable from that of the entire region and the continent as a whole.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, the last time we spoke about the Democratic Republic of the Congo in this House, I recall calling for the refusal of helplessness, fatalism and silence in the face of the trajectory that was becoming increasingly clear. This trajectory must change. It's time to be determined and decisive. In the joint resolution, which will be adopted, I hope by a large majority, we call for targeted sanctions to be imposed on those responsible for the violent repression and the political stalemate in the DRC. These sanctions should also serve as a warning and reminder to all political actors of their responsibilities, including participation in an exit from the crisis and the prevention of violence. The second point I wish to make is particularly concerned with political dialogue. We welcome the mediation of the African Union and CENCO's efforts to broaden consensus around a political transition. It is crucial that any agreement towards a transition include a reasonable timetable with specific deadlines for the realization of its various components. Alongside the political process, every effort must be made to reduce the potential for violence in the country. To that end, we need to continue to provide enhanced support for security sector reform. Finally, as we emphasise in the resolution, we need to increase the Union's mediation capacity and work at local level to bring pressure down and channel frustrations towards a real project for the DRC.

name: Maria Arena
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, High Representative, thank you for your commitment to Africa, particularly in the Great Lakes region. As you have said, the current political situation is dangerous, and it is especially dangerous for people who have been subjected to violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo for years. However, in recent months, this violence has only increased and the risk is that it will increase even further. Yes, the transition is important, you said. But this transition must take place on the basis of an inclusive agreement and, as you said, CENCO's work is important in order to engage in this effectively inclusive and constitutionally respectful dialogue, it should be recalled. Yes, there is a need for an independent CENI, which effectively organizes these elections. Above all, impunity must also be combated. This resolution, which we are presenting here in Parliament, with a list of names that, indeed, have been taken up by both the United States and by the NGO “Human Rights Watch”, says that targeted sanctions are needed against these people. That is what we want to convey here as a strong message.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, with its abundance of natural resources and strategic location at the heart of Africa, it’s a tragedy that the DRC is associated with little but corrupt governance, conflict and instability. Having been subjected to 32 years of Mobutu’s tyranny, in which he robbed the country of vast amounts of money, imposed an authoritarian regime and saw the country fall into a state of near—lawlessness, bequeathing to the world the term ‘kleptocracy’ for his government, we now find ourselves in 2016 faced again with the prospect of a president that refuses to be bound by constitutional term limits and stand down, which is of course is a great alarm to the European Union. Having served two terms after succeeding to the presidency at the young age of 29, Kabila Jr. is now seeking to become a Mobutu II.
