In the myriad of hotspots around the world, it’s tempting for some to dismiss the current constitutional crisis in Kinshasa as a problem that the European Union and Member States can ill afford to spend much time on. Whilst it’s right that we allow the African Union to take a lead on this and support the mediation of the former Prime Minister of Togo, Edem Kodjo, we should also remind ourselves of the deep divisions that exist within the Democratic Republic of Congo and the potential for bloody conflict that this volatile situation could lead to if left unresolved.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, 'Kabila, sache-le, ton mandie est fini! ' That is what is currently being heard in the Congo. “Kabila, realize your mandate is over!” , on manifestations, in sports stages... And you know, Mrs. Mogherini, that worries me the most. We know that those people who scare this, that the people who are now being shown with those phrases on the social media, that they will probably not be there by the end of this year. They'll be killed, they'll be locked up. The repression there is a daily cost for our Congolese. And that's why I think it's very important for you to send out a strong signal. I found your introduction very courageous, very concrete. I think our resolution is to the point. We want peace to return, we point out the responsibility of President Kabila. A president must protect people, provide security, not suppress. We, as Europe, must ensure that the people who commit misdeeds over there are not allowed to enter us. We must ensure that those responsible are brought to justice. Mrs Mogherini, I think it is very important that, before 19 December — because everything is focused on this and that date is in many agendas — we must ensure that peace is restored around that period. And how can we do that? We must ensure that the journalists and the opponents are released, we must ensure that the date of the elections is set. Colleagues, it's almost New Year. I think that each of us is almost engaged in the New Year's wishes, the New Year's cards, good intentions. I really only have one wish, and that is that we give amani to the Congolese, amani, peace, the best thing we could wish for each other on New Year's.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, I will begin by condemning the repression that is taking place in the Democratic Republic of Congo against peaceful demonstrations and people for their political militancy, or for fighting for human rights, and also condemning the responsibility of the European Union the spooling of the natural resources of the Democratic Republic of Congo. We call for the immediate and unconditional release of all arbitrarily detained persons, as well as respect for freedom of expression, assembly and demonstration. We call for an end to all violence and human rights violations, an end to the mass rape of women as a weapon of war and an end to the recruitment of children. We call on the European Union to put an end to the spoliation of resources and enable the country to develop on the basis of them. We also ask you to increase support in the form of donations to meet the urgent needs of the population. We also call for an international inquiry to investigate accusations of complicity between structural adjustment plans, financial support from international financial institutions... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, High Representative, I appreciated your speech, but I think we will have to be firmer. Indeed, President Kabila is at the end of his second term, and the Congolese constitution has forbidden him to run for a third term. In order to remain in power, he had already tried to amend the constitution in 2015, but he had been delighted at the legitimate mobilization of civil society against this institutional coup. Today, he seeks to impose his retention in power by constantly postponing the date of the elections. This is unacceptable, and it is not by appointing an opposition prime minister that he will legitimize his retention, as the repression is taking place every day more strongly against opponents of the regime, peaceful protests and journalists, at the cost of many human lives. Arbitrary arrests cause fear of a major political crisis. Chaos beats us in a country already weakened by systemic instability. That is why the Congolese government should be strongly called upon to release all political prisoners in a gesture of appeasement. Europe must help the Congolese people enforce its constitution and prevent Kabila from pursuing a fait accompli policy. We have means in our possession. We must activate Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement and adopt targeted sanctions, from the freezing of visas to the assets of relatives of power. Europe has endorsed the national dialogue, which has been a real masquerade. It is time to react and punch on the table if we want to be consistent with the agreements that bind us to the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the fourth time we have been talking about the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and beyond our resolutions I believe that our common words are still far from putting into place those efforts that we should instead make. We have not yet adopted that very important legislation on conflict minerals, which could finally allow us to exert strong pressure, even on multinational corporations who at this moment they support quasi-dictatorial de facto regimes like the one we have right now. A president who wants to carry out a constitutional coup d'état, which he does not yet agree, to return the country to free elections. And meanwhile, in the North Kivu region alone, we had 1 100 people killed and 1 500 people kidnapped. I still remember the words and teaching of Denis Mukvege, our Sakharov Prize in 2014, when he spoke of women's body, as a battlefield. What has changed? Very little yet, we must get to have incisive actions, strong and individual sanctions against the government responsible for these atrocities and above all we need to bring this country back to free elections , that they can truly bring this country back a Democratic Republic. (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, reading the resolutions, I see repeated a scenario that kills Africa. A leader doesn't like anymore, so he has to leave. A new one must take his place to serve us and serve himself. You'll say, “What about the constitution?” Of course, it was not drafted and adopted by the Congolese. That Kabila is criticized, for sure, but who will tell the truth? Who put Kabila in place? Who will show Rwanda's role in this crisis? Kagame is not condemned and Kabila should be condemned? Who will talk about the millions of deaths for diamonds, rare earths and other minerals in this region for the interests of Belgian, German and external powers? Finally, you will admit that African problems are the business of Africans and that African nations have the right to non-interference for their stability. Yes to the inclusive transition; for this it takes time.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Mr President! High Madam Representative! President Kabila has been using all possible technical and administrative means for two years to stay in power after the expiration of his constitutional mandate, at all costs. On the basis of an agreement with part of the opposition, the presidential election was shifted to April 2018. As a result of his actions, political tension has increased, anxiety among the residents, human rights are violated, everyone knows it. There is a ban on congregations in Congo, including the use of force against peaceful demonstrators, with arrests and restrictions on media freedom. Clear action must be taken to ensure that the constitution is upheld and to guarantee democratic, transparent, timely elections as soon as possible. It is important that the political actors involved in this process contribute to a peaceful and constructive dialogue in order to avoid deepening the current political crisis and to stem the tide of violence. This resolution is definitely an important political signal, so it is essential that it gets the support of the whole Parliament.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: Mr President, thank you very much, Mrs Mogherini, for your commitment and work with the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which we all value very much here. Today is World AIDS Day and there are many experts claiming that AIDS emerged in Kinshasa in 1920. Today it remains one of the leading causes of death in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, because people do not have access to either evidence or medicines. We are talking about the Democratic Republic of the Congo once again, and we are increasingly concerned that things are not moving at the speed they should take into account the enormous instability in the country, which is experiencing in the region, and the enormous suffering suffered by the citizens of the Congo. Today the European Parliament is sending a concrete message, this time very strongly, with broad support throughout the House, for sanctions to be adopted against those responsible for the brutal repression of recent times in Congo. Give me two seconds to quote their names: Kalev Mutond, John Numbi, General Kampete, Gabriel Amisi and Célestin Kanyama. These... (The Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr President, woolly language has not been spent on President Kabila. He needs clear language and clear, that sounds so: Mr Kabila, we reject your attempts to hold on to power. We reject the decision to postpone the elections until April 2018. We support the demand of civil society and opposition: elections before the end of 2017. Kabila can no longer be part of the solution. Samy Badibanga's appointment as Prime Minister is a transparent maneuver. Either Kabila resigns and organises elections for an interim president, or he starts an inclusive dialogue offering a solution. That is why we support the mediation efforts of the Episcopal Conference Cenco. Words, however, are not enough. Why not start the procedure under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement immediately? Why not apply targeted sanctions to officials and military officials for violations of their civil and human rights and, finally, of course, the bigger picture: peace and security can only be guaranteed in the Congo through dialogue between the countries of the Great Lakes region.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this year has proved to be a massive test for the viability of democracy in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). It is a crying shame that a land of such beauty, diversity and untapped wealth has become synonymous with the idea of a failed state. It is an even greater shame that the actions of one man could possibly plunge this country back into civil war. President Kabila must respect the principles set out in the Congolese Constitution and allow proper democratic elections to take place once his mandate is up.  I was heartened by last week’s UN Security Council reports on their visits to the DRC and Angola. It would appear, in particular, that their visit to the troubled eastern region has brought some political stability, and the welcome intervention of Angola in its dual role of Security Council member and Chair of the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region is to be warmly welcomed.  Of course, sanctions against individuals implicated in the atrocities is a necessary tool, as is the financial support that the international community provides to the DRC, but I strongly hope that the visit by the Security Council will encourage the Kabila administration to honour its democratic obligations and provide a peaceful and inclusive transition.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: — Mr President, in the debate on the DRC in March, I expressed my hope that President Kabila would not give in to the temptation to remain in power at all costs, thus ignoring the limits set by the constitution, and I warned that the country would fall into violence. Unfortunately, violence and repression of opposition protests are a reality, and I believe that we should not just condemn them, but to resort to sanctions, as Mrs Rivasi mentioned. Beyond this reaction, we must also think of the lessons that can be learned from the crisis in the DRC. In the framework of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, we are in the process of working on a report on the limits of presidential terms. There are three points that I would like to highlight. First, I believe that Europe supports strong institutions, not strong politicians in Africa; secondly, we must promote a consensus among political elites on the inviolability of the principle of mandate limits; and, finally, we must make better use of political dialogue within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement before these seizures do not arise.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Kalev Mutond, deputy head of the National Intelligence Agency of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, John Numbi, former Inspector General of the Congolese Police, General Ilunga Kampete, Commander of the Republican Guard, Gabriel Amisi, commander of the army in the western region of the country, Célestin Kanyama, Chief of the Kinshasa police; these men, among many others, are responsible for confiscating democracy in the DRC, violently repressing freedom to protest, and prevented a peaceful and constitutional transition of power, which justifies targeted sanctions. The holding of free, reliable and transparent elections in accordance with the Constitution and international law, as soon as possible, is the only way to put an end to the political and humanitarian crisis in the DRC. Let us give back a future to the DRC, young Congolese and Congolese must reclaim all the instruments of democracy. I thank the High Representative for her commitment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — (EL) Mr President, the human rights situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate, while Kabila's decision to extend his term of office to the Presidential House has caused a storm of opposition from the opposition. So sexual violence, the restriction of freedom of expression, is a daily occurrence, and police violence against activists and dissidents is common. At the same time, the illegal activities of some multinational companies in Congo are leading the country even further to destabilisation. If there is anything Europe can do to protect the Congolese people, it is to find a political solution that allows every citizen and any peaceful organisation of civil society to exercise the right of expression, freedom of expression, association, without there is a fear of persecution and arrests, and the illegal activities of some European multinationals in the country must be stopped and those who violate human rights should be penalised.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank this House and in particular the Members of the European Parliament who have constantly, all these months, carried the issue of the Republic Congo's democratic attention to the attention of the House, but also of the other European institutions. This, in particular, as well as other issues we work on in Africa and on our common foreign and security policy more overall, but this is an issue on which the work of the European Parliament and the Council work, the work of the Commission are going, hand in hand. And that will also be the case these weeks. I do not draw political conclusions from our exchange, I have seen your resolution, we have talked to some of you these days, you know well that the subject of the Democratic Republic of Congo will be back on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council in two weeks and this resolution of yours, this debate of ours, this work, which we are doing together, will surely inform the discussion of the Foreign Ministers and the decisions it will be up to the foreign ministers of the 28 Member States to take on that occasion as well. It will be December 12, a few days before an important date for the Democratic Republic of Congo. A decision which, of course, I cannot anticipate here, but which will certainly benefit from the discussions, the decisions that this House will take on this issue. I would like to underline one point which Mr Preda pointed out and who I am very much in agreement with, the fact that this work is part of a wider work, which we are doing with our African partners, to reinforce the vision of democracy that they themselves are trying to assert on their continent, that is, based on the strength of democratic systems more than on the strength of individual men in power. This is the path Africa itself has chosen to take, this is the path we are accompanying.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 1 December 2016, at 11.30 a. m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — The situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo is extremely serious and threatens the growth of political instability due to the delay of elections by incumbent President Kabila. Civil society organisations have repeatedly pointed out that the state of human rights and freedom of expression has deteriorated, and that the rate of violence has risen. I believe that political instability is harmful primarily to the population, and that it is thus exacerbating the state of extreme poverty that has been characterizing Congo for a long time. I believe that it is necessary to develop dialogue and find a peaceful joint solution of government and opposition, and to abide by international standards and agreements when it comes to fundamental rights. The European Union can certainly provide appropriate tools and instruments to drive pro-democracy processes and support human rights fighters.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, the political situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) continues to be unstable due to increasing political tensions in the country. Less than three weeks before the 19 December deadline marking the end of President Joseph Kabila’s constitutionally mandated two-term limit, he still has not made any clear commitment as to when, or even if, he will step down.  Meanwhile Congolese authorities have been heavily criticised for human rights violations, a crackdown on political opponents and an onslaught on press freedoms, as illustrated by the murder of a journalist working for the state broadcaster RTNC and the blocking of the signals of radio stations such as Radio France Internationale, Voice of America, the BBC, the Belgian French-language station RTBF and the United Nations station Radio Okapi.  In this context, I call on the Congolese authorities, and particularly President Kabila, to protect and respect the rights of all citizens of the DRC in strict compliance with the country’s constitutional law and international law, and to stop immediately the ongoing bloody crackdown on political opposition and civil society. Furthermore, I call on the EU to take all necessary measures to protect the rights and freedoms of all citizens of the DRC.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Congo elections have been postponed to the benefit of the already elected President Joseph Kabila. The Constitution limits the president to two terms; Kabila has already tried to change the Constitution to extend his term of office. These delays in elections have caused commotion throughout the country. Kabila appointed a leader of the opposition as prime minister, only that this did not have much impact to remove tensions. The delayed elections triggered demonstrations that resulted in brutal repression. The UN peacekeeping operation in the DRC is preparing for a crisis. Human rights groups criticise the worsening situation in terms of freedom of expression and association. Indeed, political instability causes chaos in the country and aggravates poverty and continues the state of uncertainty. I call for President Kabila to respect the Constitution of the DRC and to resign at the end of his term of office. The elections should take place on December 19, as originally planned. Those unjustly imprisoned during the demonstrations should be released, and the government must stop using force against demonstrators. Peaceful and transparent elections will contribute to the progress and development of the DRC.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. — In Congolese DVs, the situation is increasingly strained in relation to President Kabila's unwillingness to leave power in accordance with the prescribed procedure. The unrest in recent weeks has brought casualties, media channels have been closed, people are being detained illegally, and the number of people living in poverty and needing food aid is increasing. The African Union, as well as the EU, must ensure that elections are held in a timely manner in accordance with the Congolese Constitution and the African Charter for Democracy, Elections and Governance. It is important that all political parties enter into a peaceful and constructive dialogue as soon as possible. The EU is in a position to adopt sanctions against senior officials responsible for the violent suppression of demonstrations and political stalemate - and it should do so. Financing from the European Development Fund in Congo must also be closely monitored and, if necessary, measures taken.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — (NL) I fully support this resolution on the situation in the DRC, which calls on President Kabila to honour the promises made. According to the Constitution, presidential elections are to be held in 2016 and a president cannot be held for a third term. The Congolese Government is hiding behind the so-called impossibility of creating electoral lists based on the population register and wants to postpone the election for four years. Since January 2015, hundreds of people have been killed, authorities have been acting harshly against demonstrators and opposition, and people have been wrongfully put behind bars. Media are being shortened, spontaneous strikes break out. The situation in DRC is deteriorating sharply and there are several reports of serious human rights violations. In the east of the Congo, brutality (rapes, child soldiers,...) remains rape and impact, often motivated by conflicts over natural resources and minerals. Despite various commitments and promises from the government, the results remain deplorable. This resolution makes President Kabila unambiguously responsible for the worrying situation in his country and calls on him to comply with the Constitution, to hold elections, to re-admit freedom of opinion (and manifestations) and to respect democracy and the rule of law, as agreed in the Cotonou Accords.

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr President Béji Caïd Essebsi, Madam Vice-President and High Representative Mogherini, welcome, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Minister, welcome, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, we have the great honour of welcoming today the President of the Republic of Tunisia to the European Parliament. Mr President, let me tell you the emotion of meeting you one year after our last meeting in Tunis. I would like to reiterate my gratitude to you for the warm welcome that has been extended to me in your beautiful country. Mr President, at the beginning of this meeting, I would like to congratulate you two days late on your birthday, who were born on 29 November 1926. As you asked me not to say “90th birthday”, I say nine, zero! (Hearty applause) President Béji Caïd Essebsi said to me: “President, don't say 90, say nine, zero”. That is how I said, Mr President. Mr President of the Republic, you are here among your friends and partners. Here you are surrounded by all those who carry in their hearts the democratic future of Tunisia. In five years, your country's journey towards democracy has been exceptional. Your country is now asserting itself as a model of pluralism and tolerance where the rule of law, individual freedoms and equality among all are guaranteed in the constitution. At a time when populists are waving fears and rejection, Tunisia sends us this strong message. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, during my official visit to Tunis and Sousse, I was able to realize the magnitude of the economic, social and security challenges facing democratic Tunisia on a daily basis. Nevertheless, I have returned with the firm conviction that your country, despite all these difficulties, has a great wealth: I am referring to these strong, young, trained forces, creative, ready to work for Tunisia's prosperous future. This is a considerable asset you can count on to carry out the major reforms expected. These reforms will restore confidence to Tunisian citizens, local investors and foreign partners, as the economic conference in your country showed yesterday. On this path, Tunisia is not alone. The international investment conference, held earlier this week in Tunis, clearly demonstrates this. Rest assured, Mr President, that the European Parliament will follow closely the commitments made by the European Union and its Member States. This year we are celebrating the 40th anniversary of bilateral cooperation that has made Europe your first trading partner, and we are proud of it. But we decided to go further. We have made a political commitment to build a privileged partnership with you because we believe that it is time to translate in a sustainable, tangible and diverse way the strategic and irreversible nature of our relations. It is no longer a matter of solidarity, but rather the affirmation of a common vision of our future. Mr President, young people on both sides of the Mediterranean have never been better trained. They share the same aspirations: to learn, travel, engage, live with dignity and thrive in their studies and work. We have a historical responsibility to meet their legitimate expectations. In this regard, I welcome the launch of the new European Union Youth Initiative, which demonstrates our commitment to support the development of talent, resources and mobility for young Tunisians and Tunisians. This is the best investment we can make for the well-being and cohesion of society as a whole. We can no longer afford to indulge in the deadly ideologies of young people who no longer have hope. Together, we can thwart the black scenarios of extremists from all sides. Together, we can demonstrate that universal values combine in the same way in Tunisia and Europe. Allow me, in this regard, to welcome the initiative you have taken in launching, from the magnificent Bardo Museum, Tunisia's declaration against terrorism, for tolerance and solidarity among peoples, cultures and religions. Rest assured of the fidelity of our commitment to Tunisia, its youth, its people and its authorities. I thank you once again, Mr. President, for your presence. (Vivid applause)

name: Beji Caid Essebsi
text: President of the Republic of Tunisia. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your invitation. It is an honour for my country, and it is a privilege for me to address directly to parliamentarians and, through them, to the States and peoples they represent. I would therefore like, on behalf of my country and my people, to convey to Europe, the European Union, and through you, ladies and gentlemen, to your States and your peoples, a message of friendship, solidarity and trust from Tunisia. Tunisia is presenting itself to you today under a new face because our people have struggled to engage in a democratic process in our country. You know that we now have a modern constitution, a constitution for a civil status, without religious or dogmatic reference. However, we also have a Muslim majority people, and we believe that the well-known, well-applied Islam is not incompatible with democracy. It is even a promising element to take our country in this direction. So we have a constitution, a president elected by universal suffrage, we have a plural parliament with 16 parties, this is the first time in our history in 60 years, and we have a government that is softened by a very large majority in our parliament, namely 168 votes out of 217, which is unprecedented. Thus, from this point of view, Tunisia is presenting itself under a new face and with new perspectives, but, in any case, we can only work even harder for the cohesion of our people, in order to overcome the challenges before us: the challenge of terrorism, that of underdevelopment, from representation to the exterior. We are optimistic, reasonably optimistic, and we are going to work on that. I would therefore like to take this happy opportunity to pay tribute sincere to the European Parliament for its support and solidarity with Tunisia from the first few days following the historic turning point of our revolution of 14 January 2011. The numerous visits and missions of MEPs to Tunisia, as well as the adoption of resolutions on Tunisia — particularly the last one, dated 14 September 2016 — perfectly illustrate the European Parliament's strong interest in the success of the Tunisian democratic experiment. My deep appreciation also goes to the various political groups as well as to the Members of the European Parliament who took part in election observation missions in 2011 and 2014, and who have been the privileged witnesses of the new democratic learning in Tunisia. My presence here today also shows my gratitude to all the institutions of the European Union and the peoples of Europe that you represent here, for their sincere commitment to Tunisia and its democratic process. The visit to Brussels that I am undertaking today comes at a historic and highly symbolic moment for the Tunisian-European relations, which this year marks the 40th anniversary of the first cooperation agreement of 1976, crowned by the holding of meetings at the highest level between Tunisia and the European Union. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am coming here to convey a message of friendship of the Tunisian people to all the peoples of Europe you represent. Tunisia, located in the far north of northern Africa, very close to Europe, has always considered the European continent as a natural anchor area. This proximity to Europe has profoundly marked our history for 3000 years. Tunisia's fate has always been linked to that of Europe. We have suffered the influences and sometimes even vicissitudes and occupation, but Tunisia has always maintained close and harmonious ties with Europe and its peoples, and has always looked to the future rather than looking to the past. These links must form the basis on which we must build an even stronger strategic relationship between Tunisia and Europe today, in line with current challenges and challenges. The revolution of 14 January opened a new chapter in Tunisia's history. The Tunisian people have risen peacefully and spontaneously, without any ideological or religious referent, against established order and despotism. This uprising was carried by young people in search of dignity and freedom. It would not have been possible without the sacrifices of the martyrs who paid with their lives their aspiration to freedom, respect for human dignity and better living conditions. The Tunisian people dared a break. He embarked on a process of political transition and modernization that follows the reform movement initiated in the mid-19th century by precursors such as Kheireddine Pasha, and followed in the 20th century with Moncef Bey, Tahar Haddad, Habib Bourguiba and many others. Was Tunisia not one of the first, and in any case the first Arab country, to abolish slavery in 1846 and to promulgate, with the fundamental pact, the first political constitution in Islam in 1861? Then there was the constitution of 1959, a constitution which, precisely, guaranteed freedom to human beings in Tunisia. It is therefore a constitution of human rights, ahead of its time compared to other countries. It was also the first to grant a single status to women, with the promulgation of the Personal Status Code in 1956, after independence. The place of Tunisian women is an exception today in the Arab-Muslim world. We may be criticized a bit because of this in some parts of the world, but this is our choice and our pride. Reform Tunisia relied on an informed and moderate reading of religion and opposed any rigid or extremist doctrine. This Tunisian specificity today reinforces our irreversible march towards a democratic model to which all the components of political society in our country are attached. Tunisia is determined to prove to the whole world and to all those who have the phobia of Islam, that Islam is not incompatible with democracy. In January 2014, we worked towards the adoption of this modern constitution designed for a Muslim people, and which broadly incorporates the same principles as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The free and transparent elections held that same year helped to consolidate the democratic process through the establishment, inter alia, of constitutional institutions, the most recent of which is the Higher Council of the Judiciary, which guarantees the independence of the judiciary in our country. Of course, this path has not been easy, far from it. In the aftermath of the 2011 elections, the country experienced a serious political and identity crisis, which could have created a profound schism within Tunisian society and undercut the democratic process. But the commitment of Tunisians to their societal model, as it has been shaped over our history, and the refusal of a new authoritarianism in the name of religion, have made it possible to put the democratic transition back on track. Moreover, the initiative I took in 2012 by creating a party bringing together different political sensitivities resolutely oriented towards modernity, is in line with this spirit. Divergences and divisions within the political class have been overcome thanks to a singular Tunisian approach based on dialogue, compromise and consensus as well as the involvement of forces lively of this country. This approach has been recognized by the international community and has earned an international distinction at the National Dialogue Quartet, which was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2015. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, beyond the political progress made in the field of human rights and democracy, Tunisia must respond to socio-economic and security challenges. As you know, Tunisia is the only country in the southern neighbourhood that has embarked on a profound political and economic transformation, and at the same time to fight terrorism relentlessly. The democratic transition has a cost, and it is felt in the sectors of socio-economic activity. This cost has led, in particular, to a sharp deterioration of macroeconomic indicators. Whereas, in the previous decade, Tunisia had an average annual growth of 5%, it no longer exceeds 1.5%. Finally, to enable our economy to regain its strength and speed up the pace of reforms, I took the initiative, as you indicated earlier, Mr President, to establish a government of national unity headed by competent young people, with strong female participation. The most important positions currently in Tunisia are occupied by women. This government, supported by major political parties and national organizations, is working to implement the major reforms needed to build a sustainable and inclusive growth model. Moreover, the five-year development plan 2016-2020 is largely part of this policy. The recent adoption of the Investment Code confirms our commitment to provide the Tunisian economy with a framework conducive to domestic and foreign investment. I am delighted that the “Tunisia 2020” conference that just ended yesterday has repositioned Tunisia on the international investment map. I would particularly like to express my appreciation to our European partners, who have contributed to the success of this major economic event. The contracts signed and the commitments made on this occasion demonstrate renewed confidence in Tunisia and its economic potential. Tunisia has undeniable assets capable of enabling it to emerge from this difficult economic crisis. Nevertheless, the economic transition remains fragile and subject to considerable challenges. The Tunisian exception must be supported more, just as other countries in their time have been supported in their democratic process. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Tunisia has always maintained strong and close ties with the European Union. As the first country to conclude an association agreement with the European Union in July 1995, Tunisia made its rapprochement with the Union a constant foreign policy and strategic choice. Our relations have seen a new impetus since 2011, which was realized in 2013 through a privileged partnership, which is supposed to allow for even closer rapprochement between Tunisia and the European Union, with which it now shares the same democratic values. It is therefore quite naturally that Tunisia considers the European Union, its first partner, as its main support during this delicate phase. In this regard, we welcome the important support of the European Union for the success of the early stages of the transition in Tunisia. We particularly welcome the new measures announced recently in the joint communication by the High Representative of the Union and Vice-President of the European Commission, to further strengthen this support in the coming years. However, we believe, and I apologize for saying, that traditional instruments of cooperation remain insufficient to accompany the remarkable transformations undertaken in our country. Our country, which is experiencing an unprecedented experience in its region, is entitled to aspire to differentiated treatment on the part of its first partner. In this regard, we appreciate the fact that the European Parliament has become aware of the magnitude of the support expected to consolidate the success of this experiment by proposing, in its recent resolution, meaningful support measures for Tunisia comparable to the establishment of a Marshall Plan and the conversion of debt into plans for the investments. We hope that this initiative will be echoed favourably with the other European institutions and the Member States for the mobilization of consistent support that is up to the challenges and challenges facing our country. Such support is now essential to accompany Tunisia and help it take this crucial step in its history. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our region is shaken by major crises and is being crossed by doubt and uncertainty. In this context, some are tempted by retreat, refusal of the other and violence. Security and migration issues are constant concerns and are strategic issues that require intensification of dialogue and enhanced cooperation to provide common answers. In Tunisia, we are building our democracy in a tormented regional context because of the situation in a neighbouring country, Libya, and security threats linked to border arms trafficking and attempts to infiltrate terrorist elements. Tunisia is targeted by terrorists because its democratic and sociocultural model is at the antipodes of their obscurantist vision. We are determined to face this scourge that strikes blindly, irrespective of race or religion. Tunisia is at the forefront of the fight against terrorism and deserves full support in its efforts. Our success in this fight will also contribute to the security of Europe. On my initiative, on 18 November, Tunisia adopted a manifesto entitled “Tunis Declaration against Terrorism and for Tolerance and Solidarity among Peoples, Cultures and Religions”. We announced the adoption of this text on the occasion of the inauguration at the Bardo Museum of an exhibition entitled “Shared Holy Places”, which illustrates the common Mediterranean spiritual experience. In opening this exhibition in the presence of families of victims of terrorist acts, I also wanted to recall that Tunisia is an ancestral land of tolerance, hospitality and cultural and religious plurality. It is therefore essential today to further promote the values of dialogue and tolerance and to place the human dimension at the heart of our relations. Our belonging to the common Mediterranean area requires us to remind the world of the virtues of openness and dialogue. By its vocation, its ancient history and its geography, our common sea must restore taste to the blending of cultures and civilizations and become once again the link between spaces and people, and not a boundary that separates them. This hope must be brought first and foremost by young people on both sides. In this way, we must ensure that youth are a priority in our future cooperation. In this regard, we welcome the cooperation initiatives put in place by the European Union in the field of youth, higher education and scientific research. In conclusion, I would like to stress that we prefer to speak of a Tunisian exception rather than a Tunisian model. Our democratic experience, which has gone through important milestones, is still fragile. This experience needs more than ever strong support from European partners because the success of Tunisian democracy is not only in the interest of Tunisia, but also in the interests of Europe. A strong and prosperous democratic Tunisia will help stabilize the EU's southern neighbourhood. This is the message of trust and friendship I wanted to convey here to the European Parliament. Finally, I would like to reiterate my warmest thanks to the European Parliament for giving me the opportunity to address its honourable Members and, through them, to the friendly peoples they represent and whom I invite many to come to visit free and democratic Tunisia because the security situation there is currently very similar to that of Europe. ***

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, colleagues must have seen a horrendous leaflet that has been dropped in Aleppo, saying that people should run away or be bombed because the world has forgotten them. I think we should send a clear message that we have not forgotten the people of Aleppo. I ask you to sign, before the end of today, this letter urging EU leaders to demand at the UN General Assembly that a special prosecutor be appointed to investigate war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria and specifically in Aleppo. (Applause)

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, I would like to raise a point of order under Rule 186. In the debate this morning on combating racism, xenophobia, homophobia and the rest of it, I would like to raise a complaint against Vice-President Paşcu, a Socialist, who took a personal position in applauding Catherine Bearder this morning. Under Rule 22(3), ‘The President may speak in a debate only to sum up or to call speakers to order. Should he wish to take part in a debate, he shall vacate the chair and shall not reoccupy it until the debate is over.’ He reprimanded me for facts in my speech, whereas Ms Bearder quoted subjective opinions, not facts, inciting racial hatred and hatred against others. He should step down as a Vice-President as he cannot be trusted to provide impartiality.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, 1 December is the National Day in Romania. It is the anniversary of 98 years since the Great Union Day of all Romanian provinces into a unitary Romanian state. Romania, as a responsible Member of the European Union, promotes peace, stability and cooperation. As well as this, we are looking forward to further integration within the European Union states. Please join me in wishing Romania a Happy Birthday and sending congratulations to all Romanians. (Applause)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: “President Juncker's recent mournful declarations have provoked many protests in this room in recent days. Of course I stand in solidarity with them. Given that we have the proverb “de mortuis nihil nisi bonum,” I believe that above all today — in those days when a certain dictator is so universally extolled — we should celebrate with a minute's silence the thousands of victims of Cuban communism. And I would ask your chairman to declare this minute of silence so that we can thus remind those people who have either suffered from repression or just had their lives trumpeted because of the tyranny they had to live in.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr colleague! If you wish to report a point of order now, please wait. We had a point of order here, that was Mrs Atkinson's, and that was justified. All the others are political explanations. But if you want to debate, put this on the agenda and have normal debates. But do not abuse the vote to conduct substitute debates here. (Applause) You, my colleague, are the last one now. After that, I will not allow any further procedural motions if you do not refer to the Rules of Procedure. So please say which point on the Rules of Procedure you would like to raise.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to raise the fact that today is World AIDS Day and, I wanted to pay tribute to the victims of HIV and AIDS ... (Objections from certain quarters) ... and I wanted to ask this House to show its appreciation to end the stigma for those living with HIV. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That was not in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, but was absolutely justified.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr. President. First of all I want to thank the rapporteurs and all the political groups who understood the urgency of amending Article 136 on the Customs Code, which has been applicable since 1 May 2016. That is why I hope that today, this amendment on a simplified regime, this report will be voted on. As the Commission has also reasoned, in accordance with the current form of Article 136, the relevant authorities of the Member States have no legal basis to apply the provisions relating to the notification of the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft, the transport and presentation of goods to customs when are unloaded or transported. For this reason, the absence of legal regulation, a legal basis, could lead to insecurity, non-taxation and non-application of tax measures, lack of sanitary controls and, obviously, to risks related to goods arriving in ports. Thank you and I also wish “Happy Birthday!” because I cannot be with Romanians, I am here in Parliament. Thank you and I hope the report will be voted on.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, above all those Members who usually attach so much importance to the Rules of Procedure! The Rules of Procedure expressly provide that the rapporteur may speak for two minutes before a final vote. Mrs Grapini has done that now. She spoke for exactly one minute and ten seconds. I do not know why you are so upset now about where you usually put such a point of order. (Applause)

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the following vote is on a remarkable historic breakthrough. For the first time in history, the United States of America is entering into a binding international agreement on data protection standards. This House has been asking for this for many years, and has achieved a remarkable success by getting judicial redress for the data protection rights of EU citizens in the United States. Finally, we have this agreement. I thank the shadows and the Commission very much for their persistent work towards getting the United States to agree to this step forward, and I hope that you will all give your content to this agreement.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I cordially call on everyone here to support one final technical amendment which improves our Parliament’s organigramme without actually changing it, yet enables us to enforce the decision taken by the Bureau only last week and which, in our world of rigidity, allow some small flexibility for the administration to pay attention and award promotions to those few in number who have provided excellent and diligent services to Parliament’s everyday operations and hence guaranteed the free and unlimited political decision—making for all Members of this Chamber. The amendment reads as follows: ‘Of which three ad personam promotions granted in exceptional cases to deserving officials’.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee on 17 November 2016 was approved by Parliament and the Council. The budgetary procedure was carried out in accordance with Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The budgetary procedure for the financial year 2017 is therefore closed. I hereby note that the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 has now been definitively adopted. I am going to sign this budget now. (The President signed the 2017 budget.)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That closes the voting time.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have tried to attract the President's attention before, because in the Geier dossier, my vote was negative on all three amendments, but the machine has not worked. I wanted to report this to the Presidency so that he could take it into account.

name: Presidente. –
text: Let's take note of your reporting, thank you.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report intends to amend the scope of Article 136 of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 — so-called Customs Code — thus distinguishing between Union goods and non-Union goods. At present, many goods from non-EU countries have as their first port in the European Union not the place of destination of goods, but other ports where fuel often costs less. This causes different rules and obligations to be applied to the ships and cargoes they carry, depending on the first port where the ship stops (though different from the actual one of destination). In this way, there is a risk that import duties and other charges will not be properly collected and that veterinary and phytosanitary checks will not be carried out effectively. To overcome these diphformities I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought to correct the Customs Code as it was necessary for it to be done in order for Member States to be able to do their job in checking the goods that enter the EU. It was a correction of flawed drafting Therefore, I supported it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The parliamentary committee recommended that Parliament adopt its position at first reading by endorsing the Commission's proposal. The European Regulation establishing the Union Customs Code excludes the application of certain provisions to goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by travelling between two Union ports or airports, without stopping outside the Union. The excluded provisions subject to the amendment relate to the following obligations: filing an entry summary declaration; notifying the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft; transporting the goods to specific locations and presenting them to the customs authorities at the place where they are unloaded or transshipped; and temporary storage. There is now no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods that are unloaded or transshipped at the place where the goods are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union, which makes it more difficult for customs authorities to ensure the supervision of the goods. I voted in favour of this report, which is therefore intended to fill a legal gap and makes it possible to contribute to more effective customs surveillance.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this is consistent with the principles of my mandate as an MEP who was elected to support the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on goods temporarily removed from the customs territory of the Union by sea or air, amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 laying down the Union Customs Code. The relevant authorities in the Member States under the current Article 136 have no legal basis to apply the provisions specifically in the case of goods temporarily removed by sea or air from the customs territory of the Union by direct route between two located within that territory places without stopping outside the Union. Since there is no clear legal basis for requiring these goods to be presented to the customs authorities, the effective exercise of their customs supervision duties is hindered. I therefore agree that it is necessary to remedy this shortcoming and thus to ensure a level playing field for goods, as well as to restore the legal basis established by the previous Customs Code.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — There is currently no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods which are unloaded or transshipped upon their reintroduction into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. The monitoring of goods is therefore much more complicated for customs authorities. The proposal to amend the Regulation aims to fill this legal gap and would contribute to greater efficiency of customs supervision. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — This proposal amends an article of the Union Customs Code, which has proved problematic in practice and concerns goods which have temporarily left the territory of the Union by sea or air.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it presents very good proposals on competitiveness, environmental sustainability, safety and safety, as well as quality and accessibility of services.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Grapini report on the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily exited the customs territory of the Union by sea or aerial. This is an important text which aims to fill a gap in Regulation (EU) No 952/2013. In fact, the current wording of Article 136 of this Regulation has resulted in negative consequences for the customs authorities, which have found several obstacles in the performance of their functions of vigilance. Today they are not put in the condition of being able to properly collect import duties, to properly apply non-tax measures, such as health checks, and to identify risks related to goods arriving at different EU ports and airports. Thanks to the changes made, greater effectiveness of the legislation will be ensured, equal treatment of goods will be restored and the overall action of the authorities will be strengthened.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report lays down a number of provisions to improve the Union Customs Code by providing the permanent authorities of the Member States with a legal basis for customs supervision of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. I voted in favour, as I believe that the proper functioning of the Customs Code is necessary in order for Member States to do their job in the control of goods entering the Union.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have left the customs territory of the Union by air or sea. This proposal is aimed at filling this legal gap and ensuring equal treatment for goods and restoring the legal basis already existed in the old Customs Code.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I have decided to vote in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. Today, we have no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods that are unloaded or transshipped to the place where the goods are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. Customs authorities have an insane struggle to monitor a commodity. In order to fill this legal gap, the proposed regulation amendment would allow customs officers to work more effectively.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — This measure will allow the customs authorities of the Member States to implement the necessary customs supervision activities on goods which only temporarily leave the EU territory. The text is shareable and I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal to amend an article of the Union Customs Code. The application of this Article, which concerns goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by air or sea, has proved problematic in practice and therefore simplification is necessary.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because Parliament expressed its position on amendments to the Union Customs Code concerning goods temporarily removed from the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. Following the revision of the Union Customs Code in 2016, its implementation and delegated acts showed that There are some gaps in the text of the regulation: the relevant authorities in the Member States do not have a legal basis for applying certain provisions under the current Article 136. These provisions relate to lodging an entry summary declaration, notification of arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft, delivery and presentation of goods to customs after unloading or transhipment, waiting for the authorisation to be issued, and regulating temporary storage. These amendments address the abovementioned deficiencies in the Union Customs Code.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, with my positive vote, I also supported it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the proposal to amend Regulation No 952/2013, as some deficiencies in the arrangements so far have been revealed. This amendment will now be able to levy import and other duties more easily and correctly at customs, apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary supervision and identify risks to goods arriving at their ports or airports. The current proposal to amend Article 136 will fill this gap to ensure equal treatment for goods and restore the legal basis that already existed under the old Customs Code.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this report. Since there is no clear legal basis which would allow Member States to determine that goods are presented to the customs authorities, a situation has arisen in which the performance of their duty of effective customs supervision is difficult (cannot accurately charge import duties and other duties, apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary control and identify risks to goods coming into their maritime or airports). The current proposal seeks to correct these shortcomings and ensure equal treatment of goods and re-give the legal basis that already existed in the previous Customs Code.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — To the extent that it is a matter of better control over the flow of goods entering the territory of the Union, I fully agree with this kind of control. I therefore vote in favour.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The provisions of Regulation No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Customs Code of the Union have highlighted certain shortcomings in its elaboration. For Article 136, the competent authorities of the Member States do not have a legal basis for applying provisions concerning the submission of the entry summary declaration, the notification of arrival of a ship or aircraft, the transport and presentation of goods to customs, waiting for an authorisation before unloading or transhipping the goods, temporary custody. In the absence of a clear legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods to the customs authorities, they see in fact hampered their customs supervisory functions, insofar as they are not able to correctly collect import duties and other charges, correctly apply non-tax measures, such as health checks, identify risks related to incoming goods at their ports or airports. The current proposal to amend Article 136 aims to fill this gap and ensure equal treatment of goods.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. - Until now, the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Customs Code excluded the application of certain provisions to goods which had temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. Consequently, there is no legal basis today requiring the presentation of unloaded goods at the place where they are reintroduced into the customs territory after temporarily leaving the customs territory. This proposal to amend the Regulation aims to apply all of these provisions, including goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the European Union. I voted in favour of this text, which will help to increase the effectiveness of customs surveillance, particularly in order to limit imports of counterfeit and narcotic products.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the entry into force of the provisions of the Regulation establishing the Union Customs Code, certain irregularities and lacunar rules preventing the correct implementation of this Code have been reported. The aim of this initiative is to correct those errors with a view to ensuring equal treatment of goods. The main problem identified concerns the absence of a legal basis for the competent authorities of the Member States to apply the provisions on the transport and presentation of goods to customs when unloaded, notification of the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft, provisions relating to temporary storage. In the absence of legal basis, the performance of customs supervision tasks becomes difficult to perform in optimal parameters. As a result, the authorities will be unable to correctly levy import duties and properly apply non-fiscal measures, but also to identify risks related to goods arriving at their ports or airports. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to remedy these deficiencies in order to properly carry out the duties related to customs supervision.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ With today's vote I gave my assent to the amendment of the Union Customs Code which gives the competent authorities of the Member States a legal basis for the application of provisions concerning goods which have temporarily exited the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. In the absence of a clear legal basis, customs authorities see their duties as a matter of fact hindered by not being able to properly collect import duties and others charges and not to properly apply non-tax measures, such as health checks, and to identify risks related to goods arriving at their ports or airports. The amendment is aimed at closing this gap, ensuring equal treatment of goods and restoring the legal basis established by the old Customs Code.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file, which sought to correct the Union Customs Code for Member States to be able to do their job in checking the goods that enter the EU. It was a correction of flawed drafting; therefore, I supported it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP’s voted against this legislative report. UKIP, on principle, do not support EU legislation. Moreover, UKIP oppose the Union Customs Code (UCC) on the grounds that it has added administrative and financial burdens in the supply chain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical amendment to correct the much needed legal gap to amend Article 136 of the Union Customs Code (UCC) by re-establishing the obligation to present goods which have been brought into the Customs Union at the second EU point of entry under certain circumstances. The amendment will clarify the legal situation as regards customs supervision of goods where they enter the Union through one seaport or airport but continue their way on the container to the second port in the Union where they are unloaded.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: ‒ Today it happens that many goods from outside the EU have as their first port in the Union not the place of destination of goods, but rather ports such as Malta where fuel costs less. A ship that delivers goods to Holland after stopping in Malta may therefore not be subject to the same obligations of arrival in the EU. The current text of Article 136 means that there is no clear legal basis for prescribing the submission of such goods to the customs authorities in the Netherlands after a vessel has stopped in Malta. The basis that existed before the application of the Customs Code: Regulation No 952/2013 of 9 October 2013. If the goods are not presented to the Dutch port, since there is no obligation, it may be difficult for the Dutch authorities to ensure their supervision and there is a risk that import duties and other charges are not properly levied and veterinary and phytosanitary checks are not carried out. It is therefore essential to propose an amendment to the scope of Article 136 of the Code, distinguishing between Union goods and non-Union goods. That's why I voted for it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The report, for which I felt I voted in favour, amends Article 136 of the new Union Customs Code which entered into force in 2013 in order to simplify and rationalise customs arrangements through a standardisation of controls in individual Member States. I believe that it is appropriate to amend the article in question, since it provides that certain provisions do not apply to goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by circulating in direct line between two points of that territory by sea or air without a stopover outside the Union, thereby putting at risk the effective customs supervision of these goods. It therefore seems vital to me that the customs authorities have a clear legal basis for demanding the presentation of goods and exercise their duties as fiscal and health supervision. I am convinced that the EU Customs Code should be aimed at facilitating legitimate trade while ensuring adequate supervision to tackle fraud.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code, as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air contributes to the further establishment of rules governing Europe's economic and legal structures, aimed at combating malfunctions and economic irregularities. I believe that such moves are necessary and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted positively on this report as it will allow the customs authorities of the Member States to be able to apply appropriate legal instruments for goods leaving temporarily from the customs territory of the EU.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I completely agree with the proposal to amend Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 since it, although it entered into force last May, is characterized by some deep gaps. It is considered a priority to take action as soon as possible in the light of the clear practical implications which have the goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The shortcomings referred to are generated by the lack of a solid legal basis enabling the competent authorities of the Member States to apply provisions on the presentation of summary declaration of entry, transport and presentation of goods to customs at the time of unloading or transhipment or temporary custody. This means that the authorities are unable to properly collect import duties and other charges provided for, to apply non-tax measures such as health checks and, finally, Identify risks related to incoming goods. Once these issues have been understood, it is clear that the Union Customs Code requires smoothness as soon as possible in order to operate efficiently.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 laying down the Union Customs Code, as regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure which intends to amend Article 136 of the Union Customs Code (UCC) as a response to the concerns of the customs authorities of the Member States. The measure clarifies the legal situation with regard to customs supervision of goods entering the Union through a seaport or airport, but continue their journey. The measure aims to increase the list of necessary customs control provisions regarding goods in transit.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the rapporteur that the Commission should refer the matter to Parliament again if it intends to amend its proposal substantially or replace it with another text. There are shortcomings in its drafting which need to be addressed.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposed amendments to Regulation (EU) of the European Parliament and of the Council No 952/2013 of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code (UCC). I believe that the amendments to UCC Article 136 will guarantee equal treatment of goods. The report presented does not cause controversy and is a technical report aimed only at modifying Article 136. The justification of my decision is also to provide a legal basis for the actions of the customs authorities of the Member States.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposal to amend Article 136 as it aims to close the gap and ensure equal treatment of goods while providing the legal basis which was already established through the old customs code. I believe that in the absence of a clear legal basis, customs authorities will not be able to correctly levy import duty and other charges, correctly apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary controls and identify risks on goods arriving in their ports or airports.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report correcting errors in the original Union Customs Code legislation. If a ship temporarily leaves customs union territory whilst travelling at sea it is right and common sense that whilst they should make their goods available for inspection at their destination port, a simplified customs procedure is possible.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This co-decision report follows the decision of the European Commission to amend Article 136 of the Union Customs in order to address the concerns of the customs authorities of the Member States. Under the current Article 136 of the Customs Code, a person carrying goods is not legally obliged to submit to the presentation of the goods to the customs authorities, thus calling into question the principle of customs obligation. Considering that this amendment to the Customs Code is intended to correct a legal deficiency and does not modify the substance of the text, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP, on principle, does not support EU legislation. Moreover, UKIP opposes the UCC on the grounds that it has added administrative and financial burdens in the supply chain.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Union Customs Code, as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. It was essential to fill the legal gap where goods enter the Union by sea or air but are then transported, in the same container, to a second Union port or airport where they are unloaded. By amending Article 136 of the Union Customs Code, it will now be mandatory, under certain conditions, to present the goods that have been imported into the customs union at the second point of entry.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, with my positive vote, I also supported it.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. At present, there is no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods which are unloaded or transshipped at the place where they are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. As a result, it is difficult for customs authorities to monitor the goods. The proposed amendment to Article 136 seeks to fill this legal gap in order to ensure the equal treatment of all goods and to restore the legal basis provided for in the former Customs Code.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, with my positive vote, I also supported it.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Customs Code excludes the application of certain provisions to goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by travelling between two ports or airports of the Union, without stopover outside the European Union. This proposal fills a legal gap and facilitates the customs control mission.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. The full entry into force on 1 May 2016 of the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code and its subsequent implementation of delegated acts have demonstrated certain shortcomings in its preparation. This proposal to amend Article 136 of the Union Customs Code aims to ensure equal treatment of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code in respect of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or under air.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - States must have the right to impose restrictions on the movement of goods when this is in the interests of citizens.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, with my positive vote, I also supported it.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation amending the Union Customs Code (UCC). In the UCC, there is a legal gap concerning goods that have temporarily left EU territory whilst moving between two points within the EU by sea or air. This regulation closes that gap. This issue could become more important for Wales in years to come.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote in favour: the proposed amendment of the Regulation aims to fill a legal gap and helps to contribute to more efficient customs surveillance.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following proposal because I believe it necessary to fill the gaps which accompanied the entry into force of the provisions relating to the Union Customs Code . In particular, I think it is essential to ensure equal treatment of goods and to restore the legal basis laid down in the previous Customs Code.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In this particular case, this is an amendment to Article 136 of the Customs Code of the European Union, since a detailed analysis of the current legislation concludes that the competent national authorities did not have at their disposal a clear and precise legal basis on the basis of which they could apply certain provisions concerning customs documents and documents relating to customs goods.
