The proposed proposal to amend Article 136 aims to close this gap, thereby ensuring equal treatment of goods and recreate the legal basis already available under the old Customs Code.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I vote in favour of the report to allow customs supervision, to collect duties properly, provide for health checks and carry out security checks.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code, as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air, as states must have the right to impose restrictions on the movement of goods when this is in the interests of citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal changes one Article of the Union Customs Code, which has proved to be problematic in practice and concerns goods which have temporarily left the Union territory by sea or air. In Committee, the proposal was dealt with under simplified procedure (Rule 50) and the COM proposal was adopted without amendments. I supported the report in the Plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, which I myself supported with my positive vote.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, with my positive vote, I also supported it.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind the gaps in the formulation of its text in reference to the Union Customs Code (CAU) and its corresponding implementing acts, since the current wording of Article 136 does not provide a legal basis for the competent authorities of the Member States to be empowered in order to implement the provisions relating to the presentation of the entry summary declaration, notification of the arrival of a sea vessel or aircraft, the carriage and presentation of the goods to customs at the time of unloading or transhipment, waiting to receive an authorisation before unloading or transhipment of goods, as well as the provisions governing temporary storage. This proposal to amend Article 136 is intended to fill this legal gap and thus ensure equal treatment for goods and to restore the legal basis already existed in the old Customs Code.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal to amend the Union Customs Code, which is simplified and made more suitable for cases of temporary transfer of goods leaving the EU territory by air or by sea. In order to approve this change, we have used a speed-up procedure, but I believe it is important to emphasise the importance of a measure that makes the European economy more competitive.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the amendment of the Union Customs Code. It shall improve customs supervision of goods entering the Union via a sea or airport and then transported and unloaded in the container to another maritime or airport in the Union.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Union Customs Code. There is no legal basis for requiring goods that are unloaded or transhipped to be presented at the point where they re-enter the customs territory of the European Union after having temporarily left it. Given the critical element for authorities to ensure safety, I support the essentiality that both import duty and other charges are correctly levied and suitably apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary controls. This regulation should enter into force as soon as possible in order to ensure effective supervision of goods.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it aims to heal the dysfunctions which are unfortunately evident. Assessing the implementation of the rules that the European Union imposes is crucial in correcting, where necessary, the malfunction. The Customs Union, a great success of united Europe, is not working as we would have liked and the operators tell us so. The weakest aspect is the checks and checks on goods, which are not effective and have large gaps. This is particularly serious when it comes to health checks: we don't forget how the Xylella virus that hit our olive trees came into Europe. It is at customs that they can, and should, snap up the alert mechanisms of infected or diseased products. And it is equally serious not to be able to exercise the right controls on the quantities we import. The European Union's trade policy allows imports from different third countries, often at zero duty to enter Europe, which must not mean zero control.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report lays down a number of provisions to improve the Union Customs Code by providing the permanent authorities of the Member States with a legal basis for customs supervision of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. I voted in favour, as I believe that the proper functioning of the Customs Code is necessary in order for Member States to do their job in the control of goods entering the Union.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. - As rapporteur for the IMCO Committee, I voted for this report because the Union Customs Code sets out clear rules and fair conditions for all operators in the field and clarifies the regulated procedures. The amendment of the Customs Code will ensure an increase in safety regarding the products entering Romania and a fair taxation. This report is important because the relevant authorities of the Member States do not currently have a legal basis under the current Article 136 to apply provisions relating to the presentation of the entry summary declaration; notification of the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft; the transport and presentation of goods to customs when unloaded or transhipped; awaiting authorisation before unloading or transhipment of the goods; provisions on temporary storage. These provisions apply to the specific case of goods which temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while circulating on a direct route between two points in that territory by sea or air, without any stopping outside the Union. The absence of a clear legal basis makes it difficult to carry out customs supervision tasks effectively.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 laying down the Union Customs Code, as regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the European Union by sea or air. The current proposal to amend Article 136 is aimed at ensuring equal treatment of goods and providing again the legal basis that was already established through the old customs code.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution. As regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the European Union by sea or air, there is no clear legal basis for requiring the presentation of the goods that are unloaded or transhipped at the point where the goods re-enter the customs territory of the European Union after having temporarily left it. In absence of a clear legal basis to require presentation of these goods to the customs authorities, it is more difficult for customs authorities to ensure the supervision of those goods. To recall, Article 136 of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the Union Customs Code (UCC) excludes the application of certain provisions of that Regulation to goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the European Union while moving between two EU ports or airports without stopping outside the European Union. Therefore, I believe it is necessary to close this gap and to ensure equal treatment of goods coming in and out of the European Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air, as this corrects individual deficiencies which are established during the manufacture, and equal treatment of the goods is ensured. Moreover, the amendment to Article 136 wishes to re-give the legal basis that existed in the previous Customs Code, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I welcome this report, which fills a legal vacuum allowing customs to ensure better control of goods within the territory of the Union and thus its borders. I voted in favour.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which amends Article 136 of the Union Customs Code. The initial drafting of the latter was problematic because applying to the letter of the text exempted operators from presenting certain types of goods to customs, which poses serious security risks in the control of our customs borders.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of this report. It aims to improve and more efficient customs control, which in turn will help protect consumers.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. This review proposal is to be welcomed, with my positive vote, I also supported it.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the current proposal to amend Article 136 of the Union Customs Code (UCC) in order to ensure effective application of other UCC, notably these on customs supervision. The main reason why we should modify the article is that its current text says that certain provisions do not apply to goods that have temporarily left the Union customs territory while moving by direct route between two points of that territory by sea or air without a stop outside the Union. In other words, under the current text of Article 136 UCC custom authorities have no clear legal basis through which to require presentation of Union goods and non-Union goods that have temporarily left the Union customs territory. In this context, the proposed modification to the scope of Article 136 UCC will ensure equal treatment of goods and will provide a legal basis through which customs authorities at the European Union’s ports and airports will be able to levy correctly import duty and other charges, to apply correctly non-fiscal measures (e.g. veterinary or phytosanitary controls) as well as to identify risks on goods arriving at the European Union’s ports and airports.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it aims to fill a legal gap and helps to contribute to more effective customs surveillance.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes an amendment to the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The purpose of this adaptation of the Customs Code is to clarify the legal situation of certain goods. The general framework for the regulation of goods flows in Europe was included in the Regulation on the Union Customs Code adopted in 2013, for which I had been rapporteur for the European Parliament. The objective remains the same: more effective controls on goods.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which proposes to amend an article of the Union Customs Code, which has proved problematic in practice and which concerns goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by air or sea.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that allows the effective supervision of goods.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The beginning of full application of the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code and its subsequent implementing and delegated acts has demonstrated certain shortcomings in its drafting. In accordance with Article 136, in its current form, the relevant authorities in the Member States do not have legal grounds for the application of the provisions relating to the submission of an entry shortened declaration or pending authorisation prior to unloading or transhipment of goods. Those provisions shall apply in the particular case of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while moving on a direct route between two points in that area by sea or air, without stopping outside the Union. Since there is no clear legal basis to allow Member States to determine that goods are presented to the customs authorities, a situation has arisen in which the performance of their duties is difficult. This proposal to amend Article 136 seeks to correct these shortcomings, ensure equal treatment of goods and give again the legal basis that already existed in the previous Customs Code, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. — Due to the lack of legislation, the national authorities could not implement certain provisions of the Union Customs Code relating to goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union without stopping outside the Union during transport by sea or air. The lack of legislation had an impact on the correct collection of duties and charges. Amending the provisions of Article 136 of the Customs Code will eliminate this problem.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code, as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. The proposed amendment of the Regulation aims to fill a legal gap. This vacuum concerns goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the European Union travelling between two ports or between two airports of the Member States and which have not made a stopover outside the Union. The amendment will require the presentation of goods which are unloaded at the place where they are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. This measure makes it possible to contribute to a somewhat more efficient customs surveillance, which we support.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Union Customs Code, as regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. Supporting the proposal of amending Article 136 potentially represents ensuring an equal treatment of goods as well as providing the legal basis established in the old customs code. By amending the aforementioned article, the authorities will be able to, according to the report, ‘correctly levy import duty and other charges; correctly apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary controls; and identify risks on goods arriving’.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report is aimed at amending Article 136 of the Union Customs Code, which entered into force on 1 May 2016. At present, the possibility of requiring the presentation of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the EU by sea or air is not established. Thus, the customs authorities, with regard to these goods, face difficulties in carrying out their supervisory activity because they cannot control them. With a view to ensuring equal treatment of goods and the effective application of the Union Customs Code, it is necessary to amend the content of that Article. I voted in favour.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The proposal in the Customs Code provides a clearer legal basis for customs authorities to properly adapt import duties and other charges, to apply non-fiscal measures in cases where goods were temporarily removed by sea or air from the customs territory of the Union by direct transport a route between two places within that territory without a stop outside the Union.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The parliamentary committee recommended that Parliament adopt its position at first reading in order to endorse the Commission's proposal. As a reminder, the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the EU Customs Code excludes the application of certain provisions to goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the EU while travelling between two EU ports or airports, without stopover outside the EU. Consequently, there is now no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods that are unloaded or transshipped at the place where the goods are reintroduced into the customs territory of the EU after temporarily leaving the EU customs territory. It is therefore more difficult for customs authorities to monitor goods. The proposed amendment of the Regulation is therefore intended to fill this legal gap and makes it possible to contribute to a somewhat more efficient customs surveillance. We therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) In the absence of a clear legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods to customs authorities, they see their customs supervision hampered in practice, since they cannot: ensure the correct application of import duties and other charges, ensure the correct application of import duties and other charges application of non-tax measures such as health controls and identify the risks of goods arriving at their ports or airports. The proposal to amend Article 136 aims to bridge this gap and thereby guarantee equal treatment for goods and restore the legal basis previously established by the old customs code, hence my assent.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal because it aims to reinforce existing legislation on customs by giving the relevant customs authorities in Member States what they legally require to carry out their inspections.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I voted in favour of the proposal to amend Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the Union Customs Code (CDU) as regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. This proposal will improve the effectiveness of customs surveillance. Until now, the absence of a legally binding text has not allowed the competent authorities of the SAs to implement the provisions of Article 136 of the CDU which require the presentation of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. From now on, these customs authorities will be strengthened in order to enable them to properly collect import duties and other charges, to properly apply non-tax measures such as veterinary or phytosanitary controls, and to properly identify risks relating to goods arriving at their ports or airports. These measures are important and are in line with our efforts to strengthen consumer protection.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I agree that the proposal was a much needed amendment to address an anomaly of the same Union Customs Code. The proposal changes one Article of the Union Customs Code that has proved to be problematic in practice and concerns goods which have temporarily left the European Union’s territory by sea or air. The Union Customs Code has been improved to better meet the needs of customs authorities.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Customs Code was adopted on 9 October 2013. Its provisions were fully applied on 1 May 2016, which revealed that the wording of Article 136 of the Regulation was incomplete. The draft regulation tabled by the Commission serves to correct this. In line with the recommendation contained in the report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The parliamentary committee recommended that Parliament adopt its position at first reading by endorsing the Commission's proposal. The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Customs Code excludes the application of certain provisions to goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by travelling between two ports or airports of the Union, without stopping outside the Union. The excluded provisions subject to the amendment relate to the requirements to file an entry summary declaration, to notify the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft, to transport the goods to a particular location and to present them to the customs authorities at the place where they are unloaded or transshipped, and temporary storage. Consequently, there is now no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods unloaded or transshipped at the place where the goods are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. It is therefore more difficult for customs authorities to monitor goods. The proposed amendment of the Regulation is therefore intended to fill this legal gap and makes it possible to contribute to a somewhat more efficient customs surveillance. Vote favourable.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: - The entry into force on 1 May 2016 of the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code has exposed certain patent gaps in its preparation. The current Article 136 of the Treaty does not provide the competent authorities of the Member States with the legal basis for the application of the lodging of the entry summary declaration, the notification of arrival of a sea vessel or aircraft, the forwarding and presentation of the goods to customs after their arrival unloading or transhipment, the waiting period for authorisation before unloading or transhipment of the goods and the provisions governing temporary storage. These shall apply to goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union, moving between two points of that territory by sea or air, and if the transport has been carried out by direct line without stopover outside the customs territory of the Union. The proposed amendment of Article 136 aims to bridge this gap and ensure equal treatment for goods and restore the legal basis previously established by the old customs code.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — There is currently no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods unloaded or transshipped at the place where the goods are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. It is therefore more difficult for customs authorities to monitor goods. The proposed amendment of the Regulation is therefore intended to fill this legal gap and makes it possible to contribute to a somewhat more efficient customs surveillance. I vote for.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the amendment of the Customs Code of the European Union. The aim here is to rewrite certain provisions to remedy the legal flaw that existed which exempted operators from presenting certain types of goods for customs purposes. Controls will now be more effective on these goods.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the report. The Union Customs Code must be fully aligned with the legal order of the European Union. Thus, all customs union-related provisions, such as presenting goods to customs or waiting for authorisations, must have an appropriate legal basis.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Union Customs Code (UCC) is the new framework regulation on the rules and procedures for the customs throughout the EU. I voted for this report that will put in place provisions for the case of goods that have temporarily left the EU’s customs territory while moving by direct route by air or by sea, between two points of that territory without a stop outside the EU.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report which identifies the deficiencies in Regulation (EU) No 952/2013, proposing the necessary amendments to the regulations in the field of maritime or air freight transport. According to Article 136, at this point, the relevant authorities of the Member States do not have a legal basis to apply the provisions relating to the presentation of the entry summary declaration, the transport and presentation of goods to customs when unloaded or transhipped; or provisions relating to the temporary storage of goods. They should apply to the specific case of goods which left the customs territory of the European Union for a temporary period while on a direct route between two points by sea or air, without any stopping outside the European Union. In the absence of a clear legal basis requiring the presentation of goods to the customs authorities of the transit country, the effective performance of customs supervision tasks shall be hampered. I believe that the proposal to amend Article 136, which clearly specifies this obligation, is a remedy for this deficiency and once again provides the legal basis for control, as set out in the old customs code.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – As regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by air or sea, this file sought to correct the Customs Code as it was necessary for it to be done in order for Member States to be able to do their job in checking the goods that enter the EU. It was a correction of flawed drafting. Therefore, I supported it.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I am called for better and more efficient customs control and better and more efficient protection of consumers.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. There are legal gaps in the regulation to be filled in so that customs authorities can meet their duty of customs supervision.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I support the report submitted. First of all, the existing gaps need to be eliminated and the regulation is effectively enforced. It should be noted that the customs union is the exclusive competence of the EU, and the responsibility for the implementation of customs legislation lies primarily with the Member States. At present, Member States are facing certain difficulties when applying certain customs provisions. In order to ensure the effective exercise of customs supervision duties, the relevant authorities should be given the right to apply more widely and effectively the provisions of the EU Customs Code relating to goods temporarily removed from the customs territory of the Union by sea or air.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The competent authorities in the Member States do not have a legal basis to apply the provisions relating to the lodging of the entry summary declaration, the notification of the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft, the transport and presentation of the goods to customs during the unloading or transhipment, waiting for authorisation before unloading or transhipment of the goods and provisions on temporary storage. There is a lack of a clear legal basis requiring the goods to be presented to the customs authorities. The latter see their effective customs supervision being hampered, in the sense that they are unable to properly apply import duties and other charges, properly apply non-fiscal measures, such as health controls, and identify risks in respect of goods arriving at the ports or airports concerned. The proposal to amend Article 136 aims to fill this gap and ensure equal treatment of goods.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal tabled by my colleagues because I believe that the EU Customs Code, which came fully into force with Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, it has a number of regulatory gaps. By virtue of Article 136, the competent authorities of the individual Member States do not have the legal basis on which to exercise some of the provisions laid down in the Customs Code, e.g. notification of the arrival of a sea vessel or aircraft. In my opinion as a politician, the current proposal to amend Article 136 aims to fill this gap and, at the same time, ensure equal treatment of goods. Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this, as it will clarify the legal situation as regards customs supervision of goods where they enter the European Union through one seaport or airport but continue their way on the container to the second port in the European Union where they are unloaded. According to the current Article 136 of UCC, the person bringing the goods to the second sea port or airport does not have the legal obligation to go through certain formalities such as presenting goods to custom authorities, filling in the summary declaration, etc. This situation could jeopardise customs supervision obligations foreseen in Article 134 in the UCC. To correct this legal gap the Commission proposes to amend Article 136 of the UCC by shortening the list of non-applicable provisions and thereby re-establishing the obligation to present the goods which have been brought into the Customs Union at the second point of entry under certain circumstances.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. Since the competent authorities in the Member States do not currently have a legal basis for the application of provisions relating to the submission of notification of arrival of a ship or aircraft, as well as the submission of goods to customs upon unloading or transshipment, and there is no clear legal basis allowing Member States to determine that the goods are submitted to the customs authorities, a situation has arisen in which the performance of their duty of effective customs supervision is difficult in the sense that they cannot accurately charge import duties and other duties or apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary controls, identify risks to goods that come to their seaports or airports. Those provisions shall apply in the particular case of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while moving on a direct route between two points in that area by sea or air without stopping outside the Union. The current proposal to amend Article 136 seeks to correct these shortcomings and ensure equal treatment of goods and re-give the legal basis that already existed in the previous Customs Code.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text is the result of negotiation between States. France does not win it but it is a technical adjustment, so I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - This proposal seeks to ensure the effective application of the provisions of the Union Customs Code by amending Article 136. The CZU, whose wording does not provide clear legal grounds for the application for the submission of goods to the customs authorities, without which the customs supervision of goods other than Union goods and goods whose status must be proven sometimes difficult. Goods temporarily leaving customs territory while moving on a direct route between two ports or airports in the Union - without stopping outside the Union - cause problems for the customs authorities of ports and airports as they lose the possibility of full and accurate collection of import duties and the application of other non-fiscal measures such as phytosanitary or veterinary control. In its current form, the article at issue does not provide a legal basis for the relevant authorities of the Member States in the course of many procedures necessary and weakens the effectiveness of their customs supervision, since they cannot accurately collect duties, apply non-fiscal measures, or identify risks to goods which comes into their territory. By proposing to amend these shortcomings, we want to correct and ensure equal treatment of goods. It is necessary to provide an incentive to lawful trade, with the existence of adequate customs supervision and the fight against fraud.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: - Article 136 of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 concerning intra-Union air and maritime services has been amended and provides that a set of articles shall not apply to non-Union goods or EU goods if they have temporarily left the customs territory of the EU, moving between two points of that territory by sea or air, and if the transport has been carried out by direct line, without stopover outside the customs territory of the EU. The current Article 136 does not provide the competent authorities of the Member States with the legal basis for the application of a set of provisions and there is no clear legal basis for requiring the presentation of the goods to customs authorities. There is a problem that the customs authorities have limited their supervisory powers. This proposal to amend the existing regulation is intended to ensure equal treatment for goods and to restore the legal basis previously laid down in the old customs code.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The full entry into force on 1 May 2016 of Regulation (EU) of the European Parliament and of the Council No 952/2013 of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code (UCC) and its related delegated and implementing acts revealed some deficiencies in its drafting. The current proposal for amendments to UCC Article 136 aims to remove this obstacle and thereby guarantee equal treatment of goods and re-provide the legal basis that existed in the old version of the Customs Code. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — The EU does not adequately protect its customs borders, which is why I voted in favour of this report, which provides for amending the EU Customs Code to strengthen customs surveillance of goods when they enter the Union through a port or airport. This Regulation will allow for a second check when goods that first entered the EU move to another Union point of entry in order to carry out the necessary risk analyses. This strategy to combat infringements gives direction and direction to the economic world of the European Union. It is important to support this type of initiative in order to bring coherence both to the internal market, but also to our foreign trade.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative report. UKIP, on principle, does not support EU legislation. Moreover, UKIP opposes the UCC on the grounds that it has added administrative and financial burdens in the supply chain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal to amend an article of the Union Customs Code. The application of this Article, which concerns goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by air or sea, has proved problematic in practice and therefore simplification is necessary.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading on 1 December 2016 with a view to the adoption of Regulation (EU) of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily left the territory Union customs by sea or air. The amendment to Article 136 of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 makes it possible to better take account of the difference between non-Union goods and Union goods.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — We have succeeded in adopting a good legislation which ensures that goods originating from an EU Member State and travelling to an EU Member State are transported through the territory of third countries avoid unnecessary administrative constraints and taxation. In this way, we corrected the legal loophole imposed by Article 136 of the Single Customs Code, which prevented Member States from properly controlling the goods temporarily left EU territory.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: - This report deals with the need to amend Article 136 of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Customs Code, given that there are shortcomings in its content and which show the absence of a legal basis clear to require the presentation of the goods to the customs authorities. This makes it difficult for customs supervision, in particular as regards the correct application of import duties, of non-tax measures such as health checks and the identification of risks of goods arriving at their ports or airports. As this is a change in the legal basis of the regulatory framework, which will give greater certainty and legal certainty to the competent authorities of the Member States as regards the application and compliance with customs regulations, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: I supported this report, which deals with the European Commission's amendment of Article 136 of the European Union Customs Code. This amendment will improve customs surveillance of goods when they enter the Union through a port or airport and are then transported to a second Union port where they are unloaded. The aim is to clarify the legal situation of these goods and ensure proper customs supervision of goods circulating in the European Union.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it provides a technical provision for the better functioning of customs control. In particular, this delegated and implementing act seeks to provide the legal basis for action by the competent authorities of the Member States at certain times of the movement of goods at borders. Provisions relating to the transport, unloading and transshipment of goods, reporting obligations for both goods, ships or aircraft, waiting times before authorisation etc. Without these specifications Member States find it difficult to carry out collection, inspection or determination of risks. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not support EU legislation and UKIP opposes the UCC on the grounds that it has added administrative and financial burdens on the supply chain.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 laying down the Union Customs Code, as regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The current proposal to amend Article 136 is aimed at ensuring equal treatment of goods and providing again the legal basis that was already established through the old customs code.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code became fully applicable from 1 May 2016. Since some shortcomings appeared in its application, it was necessary to eliminate them. These were cases where goods temporarily left the customs territory of the Union when they were transported on a direct route between two points in that territory by sea or by air without stopping outside the Union. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — I agreed on the proposal to amend one article of the Union Customs Code, as it is a measure that has been required by practice. In the application of the Code, there were practical problems with goods which temporarily left the territory of the Union by sea or by air. The procedural procedure was a simplified procedure, as all the political groups considered the Commission's proposal to be conflict-free and therefore no amendments were tabled either. The essential interest of the proposal was to simplify the conditions for customs offices. In order for the customs authorities to correctly collect import duties, apply non-fiscal measures or identify the risks associated with incoming goods, a number of changes needed to be incorporated into the Customs Code. The provisions incorporated in Article 136 of this Code concern the presentation of the entry summary declaration, the notification of arrival of the seagoing vessel, the transport and presentation of goods after unloading or the obligation to wait before unloading or transhipment of the goods for authorisation. Since the proposal is intended only to close this gap concerning goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union, I consider it to be unproblematic. For the overall application of the Customs Code, these arrangements will mean greater legal certainty for customs offices.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The Commission proposal aims to amend Article 136 of the Union Customs Code in order to ensure the effective application of other provisions of the Union Customs Code, notably in the field of customs supervision. Article 136 states, inter alia, that certain provisions, such as the obligation to present goods to customs upon unloading, do not apply to non-Union goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union while moving by sea or air between two places in the customs territory of the Union. In its proposal, the Commission concludes that the failure to apply these provisions could jeopardise the effective customs supervision of non-Union goods, as there is no clear legal basis in the current wording of Article 136 requiring the presentation of those goods to the customs authorities. They may therefore have control difficulties as this deprives them of the possibility of fully and correctly charging import and other duties or the possibility of identifying a risk. In its proposal, the Commission tries to ensure the correct application of the other provisions of the Union Customs Code by specifying, inter alia, those provisions which do not apply where non-Union goods re-enter the customs territory of the Union and provisions which do not apply to Union goods which are maintain its status despite temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union. Parliament's report welcomes the Commission's findings and proposals, so I supported it in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is necessary to ensure equal treatment of goods that have come out of the EU without a direct stop outside the EU during transport. Following this type of transport, it is necessary to establish a legal basis on the basis of which import duties and other charges are correctly collected, the risks associated with goods coming back to EU ports or EU airports can be identified and correctly applied non-fiscal measures.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 laying down the Union Customs Code in respect of goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The competence to collect customs duties should lie with the Member States as long as the EU does not see itself as no more than one economic community.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — Taking into account the shortcomings of Article 136 of the current form of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code under which Member States do not have a legal basis for the control of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while moving on a direct route between two points in that territory by sea or by air without stopping outside the Union, I consider it expeditiously necessary to support this report in order to correct these deficiencies. I believe that this Regulation will effectively enable Member States to carry out their duties of customs control in terms of identifying the risks of goods coming into their countries, sanitary controls and charging import duties. I think this regulation is very important to prevent the smuggling of weapons, narcotics, exotic animals, food, etc.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The amendment of the regulation will clarify the legal dilemmas regarding the presentation of goods to customs authorities, resulting in improper charging of various duties, improper application of non-fiscal measures such as sanitary supervision, and risks to goods arriving at their ports; or airports. By amending the regulation, we will thus ensure equal treatment for goods.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - States must have the right to impose restrictions on the movement of goods when this is in the interests of citizens.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — An adequate level of customs regulation has a significant role to play in improving competitiveness. In order to be able to fulfil its role, the customs system must be modern and efficient. I agree with the rapporteur's position that a timely and transparent flow of information between the parties concerned should be possible. In addition, close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities should be encouraged in order to interrupt non-compliant products at the border. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to amend the Regulation establishing the Union Customs Code with regard to goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The report adopting the Commission proposal is to be supported because it rightly pointed to a deficiency in the Regulation establishing the Customs Code. Under the present Regulation, the competent authorities of the Member States have no legal basis for applying a number of provisions to goods which temporarily leave that territory during transport by sea or air between two points in the customs territory of the Union, provided that the transport is carried out directly by road, without stopping outside the customs territory of the Union. In the absence of a clear legal basis for the presentation of these goods to the customs authorities, effective customs supervision cannot be achieved since, inter alia, it is not possible to correctly establish the amount of import duties and other charges. I therefore agree with the proposal to amend Article 136 of the regulation to make up for this deficit, thereby ensuring equal treatment for goods.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - In order to facilitate trade flows, the amendment of the Union Customs Code in respect of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air is welcomed, as it clarifies the need for the proper and appropriate application of the fiscal and non-fiscal character (such as veterinary and phytosanitary checks), thus correcting the deficiencies found in the implementation of the Customs Code, applicable from 1 May 2016. For example, logically, temporary leaving the customs territory of the Union does not change the status of goods, that of Union goods, which is enshrined in the amendments made in the Union Customs Code. In the light of the findings of the Member States regarding the use of the Union Customs Code, it is clear that legal rules relating, in particular, to the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft, to the transport and presentation of goods to customs when unloaded; or transported. Moreover, amendments to the Union Customs Code ensure consistency with existing policies and objectives relevant to trade in goods brought into or removed from the customs territory of the Union definitively or temporarily.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — The full entry into force on 1 May 2016 of the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code, as well as the implementing acts and delegated acts therefrom, drew attention to certain shortcomings in the wording of the text. These provisions shall apply in a specific case where goods have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union in direct line travelling between two points in that territory by sea or air, without stopover outside the territory of the Union. In the absence of a clear legal basis for requiring the presentation of these goods to the customs authorities, it is more difficult for customs authorities to monitor the goods. The current proposal to amend Article 136 seeks to fill this legal gap in order to ensure the equal treatment of all goods and to restore the legal basis provided for in the former Customs Code.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the proposal for a resolution on the Union Customs Code in respect of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air, as it should clarify the legal situation on the entry of goods into the European Union. The current legislative solution does not know a clear legal basis which would allow Member States to determine that goods are presented to customs authorities. Consequently, there has been a situation where the performance of the duties of effective customs supervision is significantly hampered since they cannot: accurately charge import duties and other duties, accurately apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary controls, or identify risks to goods coming into their sea or airport. The proposal to amend Article 136 should provide a legal basis for correcting positive law deficiencies and ensuring equal treatment of goods.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - The beginning of full application of the provisions of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code and its subsequent acts revealed shortcomings in its drafting. In its current form, the relevant authorities in the Member States have no legal basis in accordance with Article 136 for applying the various provisions applicable in the particular case of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while moving on a direct route between two points in that territory by sea or air without stopping outside the Union. Since there is no legal basis to allow Member States to determine that the goods are presented to the customs authorities, a situation has arisen where the performance of the duty of effective customs supervision is hampered in such a way that they cannot correctly collect import duties and other duties, to apply exactly non-fiscal measures, such as sanitary control, and identify risks to goods coming to their ports or airports. The current proposal aims to correct these shortcomings and ensure equal treatment of goods and give the legal basis that already existed in the previous Customs Code, so I supported this report and voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The competent authorities in the Member States now have no legal basis to apply the provisions relating to the lodging of an entry summary declaration, the notification of the arrival of a sea or air vessel, the transport of goods to customs and the presentation to customs on unloading or transhipment, pending authorisation before unloading or transhipment of goods and provisions on temporary storage. Since there is no real legal basis, customs supervision is difficult and therefore unable to properly levy import and other duties, properly apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary supervision and identify risks to goods arriving at their ports or airports. The current proposal will change that.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report lays down a number of provisions to improve the Union Customs Code by providing the permanent authorities of the Member States with a legal basis for customs supervision of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. I voted in favour, as I believe that the proper functioning of the Customs Code is necessary in order for Member States to do their job in the control of goods entering the Union.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The Regulation of origin of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Union Customs Code excludes the application of certain provisions to goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by travelling between two ports or airports of the Union, without stopover outside the Union. The excluded provisions subject to the amendment relate to the following obligations: filing an entry summary declaration; notifying the arrival of a seagoing vessel or aircraft; transporting the goods to specific locations and presenting them to the customs authorities at the place where they are unloaded or transshipped; and temporary storage. Consequently, there is now no legal basis for requiring the presentation of goods unloaded or transshipped at the place where the goods are reintroduced into the customs territory of the Union after temporarily leaving the Union. It is therefore more difficult for customs authorities to monitor goods. The proposed amendment of the Regulation is therefore intended to fill this legal gap and makes it possible to contribute to a somewhat more efficient customs surveillance. I voted in favour.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The current proposal is technical. It makes changes that aim to remove errors and thereby guarantee equal treatment of goods and re-provide the legal basis that existed in the old version of the Customs Code. I saw the introduction of these amendments as legitimate, so I voted positive.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The full application from 1 May 2016 of the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 October 2013 establishing the Union Customs Code and its implementing and delegated acts has highlighted certain shortcomings in its wording. I supported the related proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report lays down a number of provisions to improve the Union Customs Code by providing the permanent authorities of the Member States with a legal basis for customs supervision of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union. I voted in favour, as I believe that the proper functioning of the Customs Code is necessary in order for Member States to do their job in the control of goods entering the Union.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — These provisions apply in particular where goods have been temporarily removed by sea or air from the customs territory of the Union by direct route between two points in that territory without stopping outside the Union.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 laying down the Union Customs Code, as regards goods that have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The relevant authorities in the Member States do not have a legal basis, under the current Article 136, on which to apply provisions related to lodging the entry summary declaration, notifying the arrival of a sea-going vessel or an aircraft, conveying and presenting the goods to customs upon unloading or transhipment, waiting for authorisation before unloading or transhipping the goods, as well as for the provisions on temporary storage. In the absence of a clear legal basis on which to require presentation of these goods to the customs authorities, they see their effective customs supervision duties hampered. I voted in favour because I believe that the current proposal to amend Article 136 will close this gap and thereby ensure equal treatment of goods, providing again the legal basis that was already established through the old customs code.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ By this amendment to the Customs Code, the legal situation concerning goods which have temporarily left the territory of the Union by air or sea when submitting such products to the customs authorities will be clarified. This technical amendment will solve this legal gap and bring more clarity in the application of the rule, and I therefore think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it provides a technical provision for the better functioning of customs control. In particular, this delegated and implementing act seeks to provide the legal basis for action by the competent authorities of the Member States at certain times of the movement of goods at borders. Provisions relating to the transport, unloading and transshipment of goods, reporting obligations for both goods, ships or aircraft, waiting times before authorisation etc. Without these specifications Member States find it difficult to carry out collection, inspection or determination of risk. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: - What is at issue is the amendment of Article 136 of Regulation (EU) No 952/2013, which refers to intra-Union air and maritime services and stipulates that a number of articles do not apply to non-Union goods or EU goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the EU, if they have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union, moving between two points of that territory by sea or air, and the transport has been carried out by direct line, without stopover outside the customs territory of the EU. There is no (clear) legal basis for requiring goods to be presented to customs authorities, there is a problem that the authorities have limited their supervisory powers. This proposal for a regulation is therefore intended to ensure equal treatment for goods and to restore the legal basis previously established by the old customs code.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it advocates better and more efficient customs control and also better consumer protection.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have gone out temporarily from the customs territory of the EU by sea or air. In fact, the full entry into force of the provisions of that Regulation have highlighted some shortcomings in its drafting. Under the current Article 136, the competent authorities of the Member States do not have a legal basis for applying provisions concerning the submission of the summary declaration of entry, notification of the arrival of a vessel, the transport and presentation of goods to customs at the time of unloading, the wait for an authorisation before unloading or transhipping the goods and temporary custody. In the absence of a clear legal basis for requiring the submission of goods to the customs authorities, they see in fact hampered their customs supervisory functions insofar as they are not capable of correctly collecting import duties, properly apply non-tax measures and identify risks related to goods arriving at their ports or airports. The current proposal to amend Article 136 aims to address these gaps.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted on the EP report on the EU regulation on goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The provisions apply to the specific case of goods which temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while circulating on a direct route between two points in that territory by sea or air, without any stopping outside the EU. The amendment of the regulation aims to ensure equal treatment of goods and to provide again the legal basis that had already been established in the old customs code.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: — The PVV voted in favour of the proposal so that our national customs authorities can regain the right to supervise all ships in our own ports, regardless of their origin. These rights should initially have remained in the management of the Member States.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the amendment of the regulation establishing the Union Customs Code in respect of goods which temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or by air. This Customs Code came into force only in May this year. Since then, there have been some legal loopholes that have not given Member States sufficient competence to fulfil their obligations. Thus, Member States did not have a legal basis for certain operations which were necessary in respect of goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union when they were transported on a direct route between two points in that territory by sea or by air without stopping outside the Union. The report was therefore of a predominantly technical nature and aimed exclusively at bridging these legal shortcomings. Since I think that if such legal loopholes are found in the legislation, they need to be removed as soon as possible so that the purpose and meaning of the legislation can be fulfilled without problems, I have given my vote to this amendment to the regulation.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. Since there is no clear legal basis to allow Member States to determine that goods are presented to the customs authorities, a situation has arisen in which the performance of their duty of effective customs supervision is difficult in the sense that they cannot: correctly charge import duties and other duties, exactly apply non-fiscal measures such as sanitary control, identify risks to goods coming to their ports or airports. Those provisions shall apply in the particular case of goods which have temporarily left the customs territory of the Union while moving on a direct route between two points in that area by sea or air without stopping outside the Union. The current proposal to amend Article 136 seeks to correct these deficiencies and ensure equal treatment of goods and re-give the legal basis that already existed in the previous Customs Code.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 establishing the Union Customs Code as regards goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union by sea or air. The proposed Regulation will provide a legal basis for carrying out certain customs control operations of goods temporarily leaving the customs territory of the Union while moving by sea or air between two places in that territory, directly and without a stop outside the Union. This will enable effective customs controls on the goods concerned, the correct charging of import and other duties and the proper implementation of non-fiscal measures such as veterinary and phytosanitary controls.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Today it happens that many goods from outside the EU have as the first port of port of port in the Union not the place of destination of goods, but rather ports such as Malta, where fuel costs less. In addition, a ship delivering goods to Holland, after stopping in Malta, may not be subject to the same obligations of arrival in the EU. The current text means that there is no clear legal basis for prescribing the submission of such goods to the customs authorities in the Netherlands after a vessel has stopped in Malta. If the goods are not presented to the final port as being of non-EU origin, since there is no obligation, it may be difficult for the authorities to ensure their supervision and there is a risk that the duties are not required. importation and other charges are not properly levied and, again, veterinary and plant health checks are not carried out. We at the M5S fought for the text to be amended and a clear distinction between Union goods and non-Union goods were put into place. I therefore gave my vote in favour of the document.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The objective of this report is to postpone by one year — to 1 January 2018 — the date of application of the PriIPs Regulation on documents containing the key information for products Retail investment and pre-assembled insurance, in order to reduce legal uncertainty and allow businesses to have more time to adjust to the new rules. As far as it is only a technical change, it is thus favouring businesses without providing for any benefit to consumers. For these reasons I decided to abstain.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this vote, which extends the deadline for implementation of the Regulation requiring providers of packaged retail insurance investment products (PRIIPs) to give customers a key information document (KID).  PRIIPs are the products usually offered by banks to everyday customers when they want to make an investment – e.g. buying a house. The Commission’s regulation sets the terms on which the PRIIPs industry is required to provide investors with a KID, a mandatory, standardised disclosure document that outlines potential risk, costs and future performance scenarios. This report postpones the roll-out of the KID by one year while the Commission revises the regulatory technical standards (RTS). I want the KID requirements to be implemented as soon as possible, but the entry into force of the Regulation in the absence of the RTS would be impractical.  There has not been sufficient justification for delaying the implementation of the KID by a full year. I also have concerns that the Commission has indicated its revision of the RTS will address some of the demands of the industry lobbies instead of sticking to the exact proposals for revision adopted by Parliament in the September plenary.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report concerns a proposal for a regulation postponing the date of application of Regulation 1286/2014 on key information documents for retail packaged and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs) by one year. Regulation 1286/2014 introduced a series of measures to strengthen investor protection in the financial services sector by improving the transparency of the retail investment market. It requires the initiators of retail packaged and assurance based investment products to produce a key information document called the Key Information Document (KID). This regulation empowers the European Supervisory Authorities to develop regulatory technical standards specifying the elements to be contained in the KID. On 30 June 2016, the Commission approved the draft presented by the ESAs by adopting a delegated act which was also approved by the Council. However, on 14 September 2016, the European Parliament rejected the delegated act and asked the Commission to review the provisions on multi-option PRIIPs, performance scenarios and notices indicating that a product may be difficult to understand. In order to avoid legal instability, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot vote in favour of new EU legislation in principle; however I also support the reasons behind the delay in this legislation which would otherwise have resulted in investors being misled. Being unable to either vote for or against, I abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the principal of retail investment products and insurance-based investment products, as regards the date of application information documents. The aim of the report is to identify various measures aimed at improving investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investment market.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. The report contains an amendment to Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on key information documents relating to retail investment products. The original regulation itself seeks to protect the public from misleading by investment packages offered by banks and various financial institutions. The information requirements in force for such products are uncoordinated and do not help retail investors to compare different products and understand their characteristics. For this reason, investments are often made which do not see the associated risks and costs and, consequently, sometimes, suffer unexpected losses. To eliminate this, the Regulation provides for information rules and obligations enabling retail investors to understand the main characteristics and risks of PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products and comparison. I supported the adoption of this report, but I must add an amendment. It is welcome that they want to spare the population more misleading, but on the other hand, it is just that banks and other financial institutions are speculating with the public's money. The role of banks, according to the textbooks, is to channel savings to investors, which, in turn, emerged as a result of the financial deregulation of the 1990s, is a casino capitalism, where savings have already been completely separated from productive investments.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. — This regulation empowers the European Supervisory Authorities (ESAs) to develop regulatory technical standards specifying the elements to be contained in the Key Information Documents (KID). On 30 June 2016, the Commission approved the draft presented by the ESAs by adopting a delegated act which was also approved by the Council. At that time I opposed this delegated act; today, an entry into force of the regulation without the technical standards specifying the information to be contained in Chione would result in legal instability. That is why I approved this proposal for a regulation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — The PRIIP proposal introduces a series of measures aimed at strengthening investor protection and rebuilding consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing the transparency of the retail investment market. The regulation was adopted in 2014 and was due to come into force on January 1, 2017. The Commission presented a technical regulatory information document. In September 2016, the EP roughly unanimously rejected the Commission's RTS. In order to enable the Commission to present a revised RTS and avoid uncertainty on the market, the Commission, in agreement with the EP and the Council, postponed the implementation date by one year.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Béres report on the proposal for a regulation on documents containing key information for retail and insurance investment products Preassembled with regard to the date of application. On 30 June 2016, the Commission adopted a delegated regulation setting out a series of new measures including those for the presentation, and content, of the document containing the key information for retail investment products, its standardised format, minimum frequency of review of the information contained therein and the methodology for the presentation of risk and return. The text approved today, of a highly technical nature, meets the demands of Parliament last September which proposed a twelve-month extension in the application, to give more time to the interested to comply with the new requirements. The date was then postponed to January 1, 2018.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this vote, in which it was decided to postpone the application of the new regulations on insurance-based investment products. This is a reform aimed at ensuring greater transparency of these products for consumers. However, industry has pushed through conservative groups in the ECON Commission to reopen the debate on the kind of information that companies selling these products should provide. While I understand that, given the lack of current agreement, it is not feasible for the new regulation to enter into force, I have decided to abstain from the problematic reasons for this delay.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the key data documents relating to packaged retail investment products and insurance-based investment products, as regards their date of application. This Regulation shall apply from 1 January 2018.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: Regulation 1286/2014 introduced a series of measures designed to strengthen investor protection in the financial services sector, allowing for greater transparency in the retail investment market. It requires the initiators of retail packaged and insurance based investment products (PRIIP) to produce a key information document called the Key Information Document (KID). The KIds that inform investors are not clear enough, and moreover, often too optimistic. The proposal for a regulation to decide on technical standards specifying the information to be contained in KiDS. I will not oppose it, giving preference to legal stability for investors.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — I do not totally share some of the passages of this text, so I have decided to express a vote of abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Technical report amending Article 34 of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 to apply from 1 January 2018. The report is adopted in accordance with the simplified procedure laid down in Rule 150 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament whereby any proposal for a legislative act at first reading which has been adopted in committee with less than one tenth of its members against, shall be included in Parliament's draft agenda for a vote without amendments. In turn, matters included in the final draft of the agenda for voting without amendments will also not be the subject of debate. I voted in favour of the report which was finally adopted.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because Parliament expressed its position on amending the regulation on key information documents for packages of retail investment products and insurance-based investment products. the protection of investors investing in packages of retail and insurance-based investment products. It also aims to restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector after the financial crisis. The Commission approved regulatory technical standards adopted by the European Supervisory Authorities by adopting the Delegated Regulation on the Key Information Document, but Parliament rejected it. The European Parliament and an overwhelming majority of Member States asked the Commission to postpone the date of application of the Regulation, arguing that without technical standards it would be difficult to apply that Regulation smoothly. This is what has been done in this report.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
