text: in writing. − In addition to the investor and consumer protection aspects, the economic crisis has also highlighted the need to revise the retail investment product regulation, which is different from one Member State to another and is not up-to-date. This proposal therefore aims to establish a single standard that could help retail investors to have readily transparent and comparable information on products available on the market before their investment decisions. Several years of preparatory work was born as a result of the relevant so-called. 'PriIPs Regulation', focusing on the development of uniform standards for information and sales processes for PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products. The essence of the regulation is to define the form and content elements of the key information document (or “KID”) and make it mandatory for investment products to transfer it before the contract. The PRIIPS Regulation therefore further strengthens transparency in addition to the ethical life insurance concept. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to postponement of the application of the Regulation in question, since these twelve months will provide additional time for the operators concerned to prepare and meet the new requirements.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report, which is a technical proposal to postpone the implementation date until 1 January 2018, to allow the document to be adopted with stronger safeguards clauses for investors.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ To the extent that I am rather in favour of the postponement of the date of entry into application of this regulation, which for the moment has many shortcomings, for example: the KIDs no longer present past data but only future assumptions; these KIDs are relatively opaque regarding the performance of the products and the method of their calculation; risk to the investor is not sufficiently put forward. I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal for a regulation and this report, which call for the postponement of the date of entry into force.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 introduced a number of measures to improve investor protection and to restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector, increasing transparency in the retail investment market. Requires initiators of pre-assembled retail investment products and insurance for producing a key information document. The Regulation authorizes European supervisory authorities (ESAs) to develop regulatory technical standards for specifying the elements contained in the information document. In April 2016, AES presented the Commission's draft on regulatory technical standards in the Key Information Document, and the Commission approved the project in June 2016, with the adoption of the Delegated Regulation on the text of the information document. The Council did not object to the delegated regulation but the European Parliament rejected it in September 2016, and asked the Commission to review the PriiPS provisions and performance scenarios. In addition, it requested the postponement of the date of application of that regulation. The proposal provides for a 12-month postponement, in order to ensure legal certainty in the sector and allowing new rules to be prepared.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: Regulation No 1286/2014 aims to strengthen investor protection in financial markets by improving the transparency of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP), notably through the creation of a key information document called the Key Information Document (KID). Although the idea is sound, the KID is criticized for being opaque and not sufficiently warning investors about the risk of losses that may exceed the amount of capital invested. Indeed, the initiators of PRIIP do not have the obligation to present in their KID past performances, thus giving way to a great subjectivity in the presentation of future performances. This text calls for a 12-month extension of the date of entry into application of the Regulation, scheduled for 1 January 2017, in order to obtain sufficient time to reintroduce certain information into the KID. Although we are not in favour of the regulation, we consider that its entry into force without the technical standards specifying the information to be contained in the KID, would lead to legal instability. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 aims to improve the protection of individual investors investing in structured and insurance-based individual investment products (PRIIP), as well as regaining consumer confidence in financial services, given the effects of financial crisis. In order to achieve these objectives, both the creators of these products are required to comply with the disclosure requirements and the obligation for individual investors to receive essential information documents (DIE). Given that there have been some delays in adopting the delegated regulation, it was proposed to postpone the date of application of the Regulation by 12 months in order to ensure compliance with all standards and to ensure the achievement of the objectives set out in the Regulation. I consider this 12-month delay in order to eliminate all legal uncertainties, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report to strengthen the protection of retail investors investing in retail investment products and pre-assembled insurance. Creators of pre-assembled retail and insurance investment products will have to comply with a uniform set of product disclosure requirements. The information communicated should allow retail investors to better understand the economic nature and risks of a given product and allow comparisons between the various offerings. Greater transparency and harmonisation will also benefit the internal market for financial services, creating a level playing field between the various products and distribution channels. However, I think it is essential to clarify more regulatory technical standards on the document containing key information for pre-assembled retail and insurance investment products.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I was shadow rapporteur for this report which extends the deadline for implementation of the Regulation requiring providers of packaged retail insurance investment products (PRIIPs) to give customers a key information document (KID).  PRIIPs are the products usually offered by banks to everyday customers when they want to make an investment – e.g. buying a house. The Commission’s regulation sets the terms on which the PRIIPs industry is required to provide investors with a KID, a mandatory, standardised disclosure document that outlines potential risk, costs and future performance scenarios. This report postpones the roll-out of the KID by one year while the Commission revises the regulatory technical standards (RTS). I want the KID requirements to be implemented as soon as possible, but the entry into force of the Regulation in the absence of the RTS would be impractical.  There has not been sufficient justification for delaying the implementation of the KID by a full year. I also have concerns that the Commission has indicated its revision of the RTS will address some of the demands of the industry lobbies instead of sticking to the exact proposals for revision adopted by Parliament in the September plenary. Therefore I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Voting against this proposed delay in bringing an EU Regulation into force would have resulted in rules being implemented that would mislead investors; voting in favour of the delay would nevertheless amount to an approval of EU legislation that UKIP regards as unnecessary for the UK (as the Common Law already provides for disclosure to investors of all information relevant to a reasonable person’s decision to invest). Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report for a deferral of the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014. A deferral of twelve months will give additional time for those concerned to adhere to the new requirements found in the new proposal. In the light of the exceptional circumstances, it is appropriate and justified for Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 to be amended accordingly.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to postpone one year of the date of application of the PriIPs Regulation on key retail information documents for investment products. Although this is only a technical change to the legislation, it actually results in a clear favour for manufacturers without any positive return for consumers; I therefore preferred to abstain.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ In order to renew consumer confidence in the financial services industry, following the financial crisis, I voted in favour of the report which provides for a 12-month extension of the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014. This regulation requires retail investors to receive a document containing the key information to better understand the nature and risks related to a particular product and be able to compare the various offers. I believe, however, that in order to uniform the legal framework we need to draw up technical standards specifying the presentation and content of that document. I therefore believe that the postponement of the date of application of the Regulation, in order to allow these rules to be drawn up, is essential for the effective application of the Regulation. I am convinced that in order to achieve the objective of restoring the confidence of those who invest in the market for financial services and products, it is essential to strengthen their protection, ensuring greater protection. information and transparency.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on key information documents relating to investment products for private investors and insurance based investment products as regards the date of application seeks to establish rules relating to investment activities with a view to strengthening the investor protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services industry. Although proper regulation of this area is necessary, I believe that the report focuses solely on capital regulation and inadequately on protecting citizens' interests, which is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to postpone by twelve months the date of application of the regulation on key information documents for the retail sale of investment products. It would have been more appropriate to have taken action quickly on this issue by laying down a clear and transparent regulation. Abstention vote.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I applaud the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014; given the opportunities and, jointly, the risks associated with pre-assembled retail investment and insurance products becomes nodal clear and pragmatic legislation. I also agree with the 12-month extension granted to suppliers of those products to comply in full with the new requirements. The aim of the Regulation is to allow easier, immediate and more effective information to the less educated consumer on financial products and who, as a result, need for information coordinates and comparable to understand their characteristics. In short, the underlying issue concerns improving investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector through greater market transparency. The specific features of presentation, content, format and methodology for calculating costs and risk constitute the heart of this Regulation precisely by virtue of complete protection of consumer.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products as regards the date of its application.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the Commission should refer the matter to Parliament again if it intends to amend its proposal substantially or replace it with another text. In this sense, I expect a better draft on how we will be enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the retail investment market.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support a report containing key information on retail collective investment products and insurance investment products with regard to the date of its application. In a report by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), I recognise the positive aspects of the proposed changes to regulatory technical standards (RTS). The 12-month implementation period will allow for the determination of the risk of the collective investment product and the insurance investment product (PRIIP), the withdrawal of the UCITS exemption for multioptional investment products and presentation transaction costs.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Regulation on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs) introduces a key information document covering not only collective investment schemes but also other ‘packaged’ investment products offered by banks or insurance companies. I am in favour of measures aimed at enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the retail investment market.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This report follows a proposal from the European Commission to improve investor protection measures for major investment products purchased by small investors. In this context, the European Parliament considers that small investors need to be better informed about possible costs related to investment products. I fully agree with the principle of preventing and defending the interests of small investors, through the introduction of simple and clear rules and guidelines, so I voted in favour of this text.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Voting against this proposed delay in bringing an EU Regulation into force would have resulted in rules being implemented that would mislead investors; voting in favour of the delay would nevertheless amount to an approval of EU legislation that UKIP regards as unnecessary for the UK (as the Common Law already provides for disclosure to investors of all information relevant to a reasonable person’s decision to invest). Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the report which aims to postpone the date of application of the Regulation on key information documents relating to packaged retail and insurance based investment products. Although I am in favour of producing key information documents on financial products, I consider, nevertheless, that the proper application of a regulation requires that sufficient preparation time be given to the actors concerned. The terms and conditions for the content of these information documents have only been fixed since 30 June 2016. An entry into force on 1 January 2017, as originally planned, does not leave enough time for a proper adaptation of the system. Thus, it is necessary to shift the date of application of this Regulation to 1 January 2018.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. − In addition to the investor and consumer protection aspects, the economic crisis has also highlighted the need to revise the retail investment product regulation, which is different from one Member State to another and is not up-to-date. This proposal therefore aims to establish a single standard that could help retail investors to have readily transparent and comparable information on products available on the market before their investment decisions. The result of several years of preparatory work was the development of the relevant so-called. 'PriIPs Regulation', focusing on the development of uniform standards for information and sales processes for PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products. The essence of the regulation is to define the form and content elements of the key information document (or “KID”) and make it mandatory for investment products to transfer it before the contract. The PRIIPS Regulation therefore further strengthens transparency in addition to the ethical life insurance concept. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that standardisation of product information is essential for comparability.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of postponing the introduction of a key explanatory document (KID) given by investment providers to consumers because I believe that small investors need to be better informed of the risks, costs and potential performance associated with the investment products they are likely to buy. Following the global financial crisis, the Commission had proposed improving investor protection measures for key investment products purchased by small investors. This is a good initiative, but the complementary project on regulatory technical standards which explain the format and methodology used to prepare the Key Information Document (KID) has clearly posed some problems of adequacy with the objectives pursued. For this reason, I think it is appropriate to postpone the introduction of this document, pending better proposals from the European Commission.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)

I voted in favour of this report as I believe that standardisation of product information is essential for comparability.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. Regulation 1286/2014 introduced a series of measures to strengthen investor protection. It requires the initiators of retail packaged and insurance based investment products (PRIIP) to produce a key information document called the Key Information Document (KID). On 30 June 2016, the Commission approved the draft by adopting a delegated act which was also approved by the Council. Instead of analyzing past performance, the new key information documents are built around three assumptions (unfavorable, moderate, favourable). However, these three criteria leave a great deal of subjectivity and do not take into account past crises. However, in order to avoid legal instability, I supported this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of this report. The proposal concerns the rejection of technical regulatory standards (RTS) proposed by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the Commission. In order to allow the Commission and the abovementioned European Authority time to change technical regulatory standards, a 12-month delay in submitting the application has been agreed, which is more than reasonable, and the changes should not apply without mandatory verification and analysis.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - With the adjournment of the twelve months proposed, it is attempting to give more time to interested parties (producers of packaged investment products for private investors and insurance-based investment products) to comply with the new requirements in drawing up the envisaged Basic Information Document (EIC). The application of this Regulation will lead to a postponement of transparency in the investment market for private investors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Vote in favour: the regulation introduces a series of measures designed to strengthen investor protection in the financial services sector by improving the transparency of the retail investment market.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following report because I believe that it is necessary to grant to the European Securities and Markets Authority (EMSA) and the Commission a 12-month extension to the European Securities and Markets Authority (EMSA) and the Commission purposes of implementing the Retail Regulation and the Regulation on Insured Investment Products. I consider this time interval sufficient for the bodies to make changes to the initial project, with particular reference to the allocation of risk classes for product issuers investment insured and at the presentation of transaction costs.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: ‒ I abstain, I would have preferred a more urgent application date deadline.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against this report, since the delay of the twelve months proposed attempts to give more time to interested parties (producers of packaged investment products for private investors and insurance based investment products) to comply with the new requirements when drawing up the planned Basic Information Document (EIC). The application of this Regulation will lead to a postponement of transparency in the investment market for private investors.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The PRIIPs proposal introduces a series of measures aimed at enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. It requires manufacturers of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products to produce a key information document (‘KID’).The Regulation was adopted in 2014 and was supposed to come into force on 1 January 2017. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that standardisation of product information is essential for comparability.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that producers of packaged retail investment products and insurance-based investment products need to produce a key data document on them in order to ensure that the consumer has all the relevant information.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I thank Mrs Pervenche Berès for completing this important dossier, which introduces measures aimed at improving investor protection and strengthening the confidence of consumers. Transparency is key to reviving the financial sector: with this regulatory text, European savers will know that they can count on a document containing all the essential information on investments made in the purchased product, guaranteeing proper use of its resources.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Regulation on key information documents for retail and insurance-based investment products introduces a number of measures to strengthen investor protection and consumer confidence in the financial services industry.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims at improving investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. The packaged retail insurance-based investment products’ aim is to impose disclosure requirements on future performance, risk and costs on the banks and financial services that market these products to retail investors. I support the introduction of key information documents covering not only collective investment schemes but also other packaged investment products offered by banks or insurance companies.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this vote, in which it was decided to postpone the application of the new regulations on insurance-based investment products. This is a reform aimed at ensuring greater transparency of these products for consumers. However, industry has pushed through conservative groups in the ECON Commission to reopen the debate on the kind of information that companies selling these products should provide. While I understand that, given the lack of current agreement, it is not feasible for the new regulation to enter into force, I have decided to abstain from the problematic reasons for this delay.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The PRIIPs proposal introduces a series of measures aimed at enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. This is a technical proposal to postpone the date of implementation to 1 January 2018 in order to allow a level 2 legislation on the key information document to be adopted with stronger protection clauses for investors.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. − In addition to the investor and consumer protection aspects, the economic crisis has also highlighted the need to revise the retail investment product regulation, which is different from one Member State to another and is not up-to-date. This proposal therefore aims to establish a single standard that could help retail investors to have readily transparent and comparable information on products available on the market before their investment decisions. The result of several years of preparatory work was the development of the relevant so-called. 'PriIPs Regulation', focusing on the development of uniform standards for information and sales processes for PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products. The essence of the regulation is to define the form and content elements of the key information document (or “KID”) and make it mandatory for investment products to transfer it before the contract. The PRIIPS Regulation therefore further strengthens transparency in addition to the ethical life insurance concept.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Regulation amendment. Parliament objected to the Delegated Regulation adopted by the Commission on 30 June 2016 and called, together with a large majority of Member States, for a deferral of the date of application of Regulation No 1286/2014 for twelve months to give additional time for those concerned to adhere to the new requirements. In the light of the exceptional circumstances, it is appropriate and justified for this Regulation to be amended accordingly.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I have voted in favour of a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No. 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products as regards the date of their application, as this adopts the position at first reading concerned. I support the postponement of the application of the Regulation for 1 January 2018 due to the need to reduce legal uncertainty and more time is needed for operators engaged in packaged retail investment products and investment insurance products to adapt to the application of new rules.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — Since I voted in favour of rejecting the delegated act presented by the Commission and that an entry into force of the regulation, without the technical standards specifying the information to be contained in the Key Information Document, would result in legal instability, I support this report. I voted in favour.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the call for postponing the application of this Regulation. It would have created too much uncertainty for both the industry and investors to have the Regulation entering into force without the technical clarifications the Commission has to give. I hope this one-year postponement will give the Commission and the ESAs time to address the concerns we raised, as this is not just a question of timing. Any delay will be for nothing if the EU does not put forward viable solutions for the problems, which remain to be solved. Given the importance of PRIIPS for investors in the capital market union, their protection and information, we want the upcoming technical standards (RTS) to remain in the spirit of the level 1 legislation, which is to provide clear, reliable and non-misleading information to investors.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which makes the Regulation on retail packaged and insurance-based investment products applicable from 1 January 2018.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of this proposal. The aim is to extend the transitional rules for certain financial products, the final regulation of which goes far beyond the target and implies a huge burden for ordinary commercial banks.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. − In addition to the investor and consumer protection aspects, the economic crisis has also highlighted the need to revise the retail investment product regulation, which is different from one Member State to another and is not up-to-date. This proposal therefore aims to establish a single standard that could help retail investors to have readily transparent and comparable information on products available on the market before their investment decisions. The result of several years of preparatory work was the development of the relevant so-called. 'PriIPs Regulation', focusing on the development of uniform standards for information and sales processes for PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products. The essence of the regulation is to define the form and content elements of the key information document (or “KID”) and make it mandatory for investment products to transfer it before the contract. The PRIIPS Regulation therefore further strengthens transparency in addition to the ethical life insurance concept. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that standardisation of product information is essential for comparability.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The Regulation on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs) introduces a key information document (KID – a simple document giving key facts to investors in a clear and understandable manner) covering not only collective investment schemes but also other ‘packaged’ investment products offered by banks or insurance companies. In light of this, we should sustain amendments made by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on key information documents for PRIIPs as regards the date of its application. By doing so we actually will postpone the date of entry into application of the PRIIPs Regulation, which means that it shall apply from 1 January 2018. Thus, the EU and its Member States will have more time to prepare for the application of the new rules.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because, following Parliament's rejection last September of the delegated act specifying the information to be provided to investors, which we supported, it is necessary to delay the application of the PRIIP Regulation by one year in order to avoid legal instability.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: ‒ In 2014, the Council and the European Parliament decided to introduce a standardised information sheet (the “Key Information Document” or KID) to help people decide to invest in certain investment products. Primarily insurers should submit this document to their customers from 2017. However, the European Commission had to adopt technical standards for the content and form requirements of this KID. Since the summer, the European Parliament has repeatedly pointed out to the Commission the shortcomings and gaps in the initial standards adopted by the Commission. Yet she stubbornly adhered to the original version of it. As a result, Parliament was forced to reject the standards in September. As a result, the Commission has had to establish new standards that insurers have to comply in principle under the PRIIPS Regulation from 1 January 2017. Unfortunately, the Commission's delay has prevented the timely implementation of these standards (which are not yet in place) and the PRIIIPS regulation for insurers. That is why the N-VA MEPs are voting in favour of a one-year postponement of the entry into force of this Regulation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Decree No. On 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, a number of measures were introduced to improve investor protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector. It requires the issuer of packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products to produce a key information document. On 14 September 2016, the European Parliament opposed a delegated regulation adopted by the Commission on 30 June 2016 and called, together with a large majority of Member States, to postpone the date of application of Regulation No 1286/2014 until 1 January 2016. The twelve-month delay will provide the parties involved an additional deadline to meet the new requirements, so I have supported this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards basic information documents relating to packaged investment products for private investors and insurance based investment products with respect to its date of application because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. This text validates the proposal for a one-year extension of the date of entry into force of Regulation 1286/2014 introducing a series of measures to strengthen investor protection in the financial services sector. These measures would improve the transparency of the retail investment market. Since, as it stands, this regulation does not have the technical standards specifying the information to be contained in the Key Information Document (KID), since the new KIDs are thus based on very subjective elements and overly favourable assumptions, this regulation would therefore lead to legal instability . We therefore support such a postponement.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investments products as regards the date of its application. The report proposes the production of a key information document (KID). This document will include elements such as presentation of risk and reward, the calculation of costs, the conditions for reviewing the information contained within the document, and information that will be provided to retail investors. Having said that, the adoption of the report and the KID will represent our continued efforts aiming at enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: This report is based on Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which introduces a series of measures to strengthen investor and consumer protection and restore confidence in financial services. The date set for its entry into force was 31 December 2016. However, and with the justification of increasing transparency in the financial investment market, as well as that time is required for the parties concerned to meet the new requirements, it is proposed to postpone 12 months before the Regulation enters into force. The time for postponement is excessive, as the regulation is urgent, and there is an increase in the risk that certain demands of the financial services industry will be met during this period and thus distort the resolutions of the Regulation as far as consumer protection are concerned. I abstained.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This proposal aims to speed up the entry into force of the regulation on packages of retail investment products and insurance-based investment products.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: Regulation 1286/2014 aims to strengthen investor protection in the financial services sector by improving the transparency of the retail investment market. It requires the initiators of retail packaged and insurance based investment products (PRIIP) to produce a key information document called the Key Information Document (KID). This regulation empowers the European Supervisory Authorities (ESAs) to develop regulatory technical standards specifying the elements to be contained in the KID. The Commission approved the draft presented by the ESAs by adopting a delegated act which was also approved by the Council. However, Parliament rejected the delegated act and asked the Commission to review the provisions on PRIIPs. These new KIDs are criticized for being opaque and deceptive. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favour of future performance scenarios built around assumptions that leave much room for subjectivity and do not integrate past crises. The formulas used on the wafer are not pessimistic enough. This is the purpose of the proposal for a regulation presented by the European Commission and that the Berès report validates. So I voted in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 was adopted on 26 November 2014 with the aim of strengthening the protection of retail investors in packages of retail investment products and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). In addition, it aims to restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector following the financial crisis. In order to meet these objectives, Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 requires PRIIP producers to comply with a uniform set of product information disclosure requirements and for retail investors to receive the key information document on the proposed PRIIPs. The information disclosed should enable retail investors to better understand the economic nature and risks of a particular product and allow comparison between the different products proposed. Hence my assent.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal which clarifies the date of application of previous legislation on such products and is very useful for the sector.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. — As provided for in Regulation 1286/2014, a series of measures will have to be introduced in order to strengthen investment protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector. To this end, a key information document will need to be prepared. In view of the measures to be implemented and their technical nature, we, with a very large majority, wanted to provide for a longer period for the application of this regulation. This should allow players more adequate time to comply with the new requirements.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical proposal to postpone the date of implementation to 1 January 2018 in order to allow a level 2 legislation on the key information document in order to be adopted with stronger protection clauses for investors.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposed to amend Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products, proposing that the Regulation its application shall be postponed by 12 months, in accordance with the request of Parliament or by a significant majority of Member States, given the exceptional shortage of the remaining time. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament adopt the proposal. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. — The PRIIPS Regulation is criticized for introducing new information requirements, which are opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favor of future performance scenarios built around 3 assumptions (unfavorable, moderate, favorable) that leave much room for subjectivity and which do not integrate past crises. However, the presence of past statistics is the only way to put forward probable losses and gains objectively. The formulas used on the brochure are not pessimistic enough and do not emphasize the risk of loss to the investor; and the presentation of costs is made on assumptions that are too favourable. Since we voted in favour of rejecting the delegated act presented by the Commission, and that the entry into force of the regulation without the technical standards specifying the information it should contain would lead to legal instability, we do not oppose this proposal for a regulation or the report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the EP and of the Council introduced measures to strengthen investor protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. It requires producers of retail investment product packages and insurance-based investment products to draw up a key information document. On 30 June 2016, the Commission adopted a Delegated Regulation supplementing the Regulation by specifying the presentation, the content of the key information document, its standardised format, the methodology on the basis of risk presentation and remuneration, the calculation of costs, conditions and frequency minimum revision of the document information. On 14 September 2016, the EP objected to the regulation and called, together with the vast majority of Member States, for a postponement of the date of application of the Regulation to give everyone more time to meet the new requirements. Therefore, it is relevant and timely that Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 should be amended accordingly.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting for this technical text which delays the application of the PRIIP Regulation, which is necessary following the rejection last September of a related delegated act.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on Parliament's proposal for a regulation on key information documents on packaged retail and insurance-based investment products. The purpose of this report was simply to extend the date of implementation of these regulations so that they could be better prepared when they came into force.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. -I support the report as I believe that it helps transparency in the retail investment market and thus increases investor protection. It is important to protect consumers' rights in the world of investment by appropriate legal means and to restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products with regard to the requirement to provide presentation, content, review and revision of key information documents.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the legislative report at first reading, which postpones the application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information communications relating to structured retail investment products and insurance products with an investment arm by twelve months, i.e. as of 1 January 2018. The purpose is to buy more time to develop regulatory technical standards specifying specific elements of the key information communication. Only in this way will it be possible to increase effective investor protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investment market.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this vote, which extends the deadline for implementation of the Regulation requiring the providers of packaged retail insurance investment products (PRIIPs) to give customers a key information document (KID).  PRIIPs are the products usually offered by banks to everyday customers when they want to make an investment – e.g. buying a house. The Commission’s Regulation sets the terms on which the PRIIPs industry is required to provide investors with a KID, a mandatory, standardised disclosure document that outlines potential risk, costs and future performance scenarios. This report postpones the roll-out of the KID by one year while the Commission revises the regulatory technical standards (RTS). I want the KID requirements to be implemented as soon as possible, but the entry into force of the Regulation in the absence of the RTS would be impractical.  There has not been sufficient justification for delaying the implementation of the KID by a full year. I also have concerns that the Commission has indicated its revision of the RTS will address some of the demands of the industry lobbies instead of sticking to the exact proposals for revision adopted by Parliament in the September plenary.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I also voted in favour of this report, as this involves extending the transitional rules for insurance-based financial products. The regulation, as envisaged, requires a key information document for each such product. Fast trading makes the information in such a document immediately obsolete. It is simply not possible to create a document for each individual product.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The deferral of application of the Regulation shall give the parties concerned additional time to comply with the new requirements.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The proposal introduces a series of measures aimed at strengthening investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. It will require manufacturers of packaged retail and insurance, based on investment products, to produce a basic information document.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that Regulation No 1286/ 2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council introduced important new and important direct measures, on the one hand to improve investor protection and, on the other hand, restore consumer confidence in financial services by ensuring greater transparency. This increased consumer protection is essentially supported by requiring the manufacturer of pre-assembled retail investment products and insurance products to provide a document with the relevant information. In addition, Regulation No 1286/2014 gives greater power to the European Banking Authority, the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority and the European Authority financial instruments and markets, allowing them to develop additional documents aimed at protecting the consumer. Therefore I voted positive

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the postponement of the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on documents for packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products. Small investors are increasingly offered a large selection of packaged investment products as well as investment insurance products (PRIIPs) when considering investments. Existing disclosures of information to small investors about such PRIIPs are inconsistent and often do not help small investors to be able to compare different products or understand their characteristics. Accordingly, small investors often invested without understanding the associated risks and costs, and sometimes suffered unforeseen losses. Member States have already initiated different and uncoordinated actions to address deficiencies in investor protection measures and such developments are likely to continue. Different approaches to publishing information related to PRIIPs prevent the creation of equal conditions for different PRIIP issuers and those who advise on or sell these products, thereby distorting competition and lead to unequal levels of investor protection in the Union. Such diversity is an obstacle to the establishment and smooth functioning of the internal market. Improving the transparency of PRIIPs offered to small investors is an important measure of their protection and is a prerequisite for restoring the confidence of small investors in the financial market, especially after the financial crisis.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 was adopted on 26 November 2014 to improve the protection of small investors investing in packaged investment products for small investors and investment insurance products. A series of measures have been introduced aimed at increasing market transparency and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector after the financial crisis. The issuer requires packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products to produce a key information document. It also gave authority to certain European supervisory authorities to develop regulatory technical standards setting out the elements of the key information document. Commission Delegated Regulation of June 2016 The European Parliament rejected the regulation and called on the Commission to review the provisions on multi-option PRIIPs and provisions on performance scenarios and a warning of understanding. Together with the Council, Parliament also requested a postponement of the date of application of the Regulation since a smooth application of the Regulation is not possible as long as there are no technical standards. The new date of application of the Regulation is 1 January 2018 and this one-year delay will allow the parties involved an additional period to meet the new requirements.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The EC proposal to impose more regulations on the PRIIP sector has arisen, alBEit late, as a response to the financial crisis. The suggested reforms are designed to protect retail investors in the financial sector that sells inappropriate and high-risk products without providing appropriate information in advance. This report, approved by the ECON by simplified procedure, aims to postpone by one year the date of adoption of Regulation 1286/2014 (concerning PRIIPS level one), i.e. the requirements to provide key information documents for PRIIPS to retail investors will only come into force until 1 January 2018. It would be desirable that the requirements relating to the key information document were implemented as soon as possible. However, it should be avoided from entering into force until the regulatory technical names are defined. However, this does not justify postponing the obligation to present DIF by one year. The “deadline” of the postponement may rather be related to the fact that the European Parliament and the EC have agreed to review regulatory technical standards in accordance with the interests of the sector. This is yet another act defined for the benefit of big financial and monopolistic capital to the detriment of workers and peoples.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The report follows a regulatory technical standard (RTS) rejected by Parliament proposed by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the Commission to draw up a key information document (KID) accompanying retail collective investment products and insurance investment products (PRIIP). In order to ensure that the Commission and ESMA have adequate time to modify the technical standard, a 12-month deployment delay period has been proposed. The changes are expected in particular in three areas: the assignment of risk classes to the issuer of PRIIP, the withdrawal of the exemption granted under the directive relating to undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS) for multiple investment products and presentation of transaction costs. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — The unprecedented financial crisis that has recently affected us must never happen again. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which proposes an additional 12 months for the stakeholders concerned to produce an explanatory document to guide consumers in their investment decisions. The purpose of this document is to provide investors with a simple overview of the most important details of the financial product purchased, including fees, risks and potential performance.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Voting against this proposed delay in bringing an EU Regulation into force would have resulted in rules being implemented that would mislead investors; voting in favour of the delay would nevertheless amount to an approval of EU legislation that UKIP regards as unnecessary for the UK (as the Common Law already provides for disclosure to investors of all information relevant to a reasonable person’s decision to invest). Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Technical report amending Article 34 of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 to apply from 1 January 2018. The report is adopted in accordance with the simplified procedure laid down in Rule 150 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament whereby any proposal for a legislative act at first reading which has been adopted in committee with less than one tenth of its members against, shall be included in Parliament's draft agenda for a vote without amendments. In turn, matters included in the final draft of the agenda for voting without amendments will also not be the subject of debate. I voted in favour of the report which was finally adopted.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents relating to packaged retail and insurance-based investment products as regards its date of implementation.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — A small but important step towards better protection of consumer rights. The question concerning retail investment products and insurance investment products clarifies the content of the current regulation by specifying more clearly what information the seller of the product must provide to the consumer. At the same time, Parliament has shown its will as a representative of EU citizens and demanded the Commission to present a draft legislation which obliges the creators of such financial instruments to assess the profitability of financial instruments on the basis of more pessimistic, nearer to reality scenarios. After all, now many financial institutions do not avoid drawing a rosy scenario of the future, which should be created by the proposed financial instruments, and, of course, take no responsibility when the promised gold castles fall apart.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report concerning a proposal to amend Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on key information documents for packages of retail investment products and insurance-based investment products. Indeed, the regulation envisages a set of measures aimed at strengthening and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector with a view to greater transparency in the retail investment market, enabling a number of regulatory and supervisory authorities to develop technical standards, capable of specifying the elements to be included in the documentary information, drawn up by the entities carrying out these packages of retail investment products and insurance-based investment products. However, the amendments to the Regulation in the meantime concerning the format, methodology, cost calculation, revision and other forms of formalisms to be included in the documentary information need a longer time period for interested parties to meet these new requirements. To that extent, I endorsed the proposal to postpone 12 months until the entry into force of the Regulation in order for the respective amendments to be applied from 1 January 2018.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, because although we understand the difficulties in implementing regulatory standards, we believe that small savers should be aware of real information about the risks faced by this type of investment. Despite being contrary to any delay in implementation, we intend to include truthful information about investment risks, so we try to avoid scenarios such as the preferential experience in Galiza. Developing these basic information documents before the proposed limit could lead to numerous problems in determining the financial risks of these types of products and provide excessively optimistic information about these investment products, but we need clear information for investors and savers so soon as possible. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report. The PRIIPs proposal introduces a series of measures aimed at enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. This is a technical proposal to postpone the date of implementation to 1 January 2018 in order to allow a level 2 legislation on the key information document to be adopted with stronger protection clauses for investors.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the postponement of the application of the Retail Investment Products Regulation, as I believe that its application would now impose an excessive burden on companies. Although the regulation itself was approved back in 2014, the Commission only adopted a delegated regulation in June 2016 setting out the presentation and content of so-called key information documents. The European Parliament objected to this delegated regulation in September and, together with a large majority of Member States, we demand that the regulation be put into effect only with one year's delay. This will only apply the measures from 1 January 2018, ensuring companies are better prepared for the new adaptation. The regulation aims to strengthen investor protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing the transparency of the retail investment market. We will require creators of structured retail investment products and insurance-based investment products under this regulation to produce key information documents. The Commission Delegated Regulation then laid down the presentation and content of those documents. For the smooth course of implementing these measures, I agree with the view that we should give financial companies an extra year to better prepare for their implementation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The postponement of the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 seems necessary at present. This deferral should be provided for a period of 12 months in order to allow the parties concerned additional time to comply with the new requirements. Since this Regulation should enter into force immediately, the question of whether it is justified to apply the emergency exemption provided for in Article 4 of the Protocol (No 1) on the role of national parliaments in the EU annexed to the EU Treaty, the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and the Treaty on the establishment of EURATOM.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products, as regards the I refused the date of application. It will amend a Regulation authorising EU supervisory authorities to develop draft regulatory technical standards specifying the details of the key information document. I reject the key information document. It unifies consumer protection in the EU and transfers key supervisory powers away from national authorities to EU authorities. They failed to draw up delegated regulations within the time limit laid down which were acceptable. The aim of this amendment to the ordinance is now to extend the deadline for this. I see no reason to give a delay here so that the Commission can make up for what it failed to do within the deadline, nor on a subject on which it should not have competence.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - I agree with the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 as it presents a number of measures to improve investor protection and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investor market. The recent financial crisis has pointed to shortcomings and irregularities in the financial sector that caused small investors to have the biggest loss. I believe that this regulation will increase the transparency of banks and investment funds to clients and investors. I support this regulation because it will reduce the asymmetry of information and reduce the risk for investors to get an insight into key information when making financial decisions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents on retail investment products and insurance investment products as regards the date of its application. In the wake of the financial and economic crisis, which saw breakage across Europe years ago, the European Commission proposed, among other things, a regulation in 2014 to increase protection for investors and restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector. The European Parliament opposed the delegated regulation months ago, and today's report will provide for the regulation to enter into force on 1 January 2018.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - With the adjournment of the twelve months proposed, it is attempting to give more time to interested parties (producers of packaged investment products for private investors and insurance-based investment products) to comply with the new requirements in drawing up the envisaged Basic Information Document (EIC). The application of this Regulation will lead to a postponement of transparency in the investment market for private investors.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. − In addition to the investor and consumer protection aspects, the economic crisis has also highlighted the need to revise the retail investment product regulation, which is different from one Member State to another and is not up-to-date. This proposal therefore aims to establish a single standard that could help retail investors to have readily transparent and comparable information on products available on the market before their investment decisions. The result of several years of preparatory work was the development of the relevant so-called. 'PriIPs Regulation', focusing on the development of uniform standards for information and sales processes for PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products. The essence of the regulation is to define the form and content elements of the key information document (or “KID”) and make it mandatory for investment products to transfer it before the contract. The PRIIPS Regulation therefore further strengthens transparency in addition to the ethical life insurance concept. I voted in favour of this report because, in my opinion, unifying product information is essential for comparability.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on PRIIP and insurance-based investment products. The report, in agreement with the Commission's proposal, supports the Commission's intention to improve the protection of retail investors investing in PRIIPs and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs). I consider this intention and also the effort to restore consumer confidence in the financial services sector that has been shaken after the financial crisis is right. To this end, the Regulation provides for uniform rules for PRIIP manufacturers on product leaflets and requires retail investors to receive a key information document on PRIIPs. I believe that the information published in the product leaflets prepared in this form will help retail investors to better understand the economic nature and risks of the product concerned and will allow easier comparison of products with other investment offers. In my opinion, the regulation also helps to increase transparency and harmonisation in the financial services market as a whole.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - In the current context, consumers of insurance products need transparency in the financial services sector, responsible behaviour on the part of financial service providers (creators of individual investment products structured and based on insurance), but in particular the proactive involvement of the competent authorities of the Member States and those at European level. This is because, on the one hand, the range of individual structured and insurance-based investment products is increasingly broader, some of these products being combined with insurance, and, however, they are complex and difficult to understand by investors, and, on the other hand, States Member States shall carry out divergent and uncoordinated actions to ensure investor protection. Thus, communication and transparency contribute to creating the conditions necessary for the development of constructive competitiveness in the individual investment market, regardless of the type of financial intermediary (which produces or markets them), as well as those relating to investor protection. In this context, the 12-month delay in the application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 is timely and justified, giving the necessary time for Member States to adhere to measures to increase investor protection and consumer confidence in individual investments structured and insurance-based.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — This proposal introduces a series of measures aimed at strengthening investor protection and rebuilding consumer confidence in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the investment market. The regulation in question was adopted in 2014 and should have entered into force on 1 January 2017. In order to allow for a timely review of the document and to avoid market uncertainty, in agreement with the PE and the Council, the Commission postponed the implementation date until 2018. It is a necessary measure, in particular for the protection of investors, and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text by eminent Cóllègue Beres on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents relating to packaged retail and insurance based investment products with regard to its date of implementation

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1398/2013 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for packaged investment products for small investors and investment insurers of products as regards the date of its application. I consider that the amendment proposal which proposes that in Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014, the second paragraph of Article 34 should be replaced by the following 'applicable from 1 January 2018' to allow the parties involved to meet the new requirements.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund enables the EU to respond to major natural disasters and to show solidarity with affected areas and countries and is a significant source of funding for local and regional self-governments to mitigate the effects of natural disasters. I voted positively for this report because I believe that such a fund is very necessary, especially in times of major climate change which has caused the number of natural disasters to increase significantly. As an MEP from Croatia, a country that has been granted financial assistance four times in rectifying the consequences of natural disasters, and the last time in 2014 after catastrophic floods that hit the eastern part of Slavonia, I welcome any improvement in the functioning of the EUSF that will accelerate the process of obtaining assistance and improving the means of communication and cooperation with local and regional authorities. Croatia has seen on its own example the importance and well-being of the existence of such a fund several times, especially in 2014, but on the other hand, it also faced some shortcomings of the EUSF in 2013 when approval was obtained only seven months after the submission of the application, and 18 months passed before than the funds came into the hands of users. Such situations, in which between emergency intervention and the arrival of funds from the Victims Fund feel forgotten, should be prevented at all costs in the future.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 128/2008. 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents on packaged investment products for retail investors and insurance investment products relating to the date of its application, I have supported. The Regulation introduced a series of measures aimed at increasing investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this vote, in which it was decided to postpone the application of the new regulations on insurance-based investment products. This is a reform aimed at ensuring greater transparency of these products for consumers. However, industry has pushed through conservative groups in the ECON Commission to reopen the debate on the kind of information that companies selling these products should provide. While I understand that, given the lack of current agreement, it is not feasible for the new regulation to enter into force, I have decided to abstain from the problematic reasons for this delay.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Regulation introduces a series of measures designed to strengthen investor protection in the financial services sector by improving the transparency of the retail investment market. It requires the initiators of retail packaged and insurance based investment products (PRIIP) to produce a key information document called the Key Information Document (KID). This regulation empowers the European Supervisory Authorities (ESAs) to develop regulatory technical standards specifying the elements to be contained in the KID. However, these new KIDs are criticized for being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favor of future performance scenarios built around 3 assumptions (unfavorable, moderate, favorable) that leave much room for subjectivity and which do not integrate past crises. However, the presence of past statistics is the only way to put forward probable losses and gains objectively. Since the entry into force of the regulation, without the technical standards specifying the information to be contained in the KID, would result in legal instability, I therefore vote IN FAVOUR of this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council introduced a series of measures aimed at enhancing investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. I voted in favour of the related document.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (5) sets out a range of measures aimed at improving investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. It requires package providers of retail and insurance-based investment products to draw up a key information document.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products as regards the date of its application. The Regulation introduced a series of measures aimed at enhancing investor protection and rebuilding consumer trust in the financial services industry by increasing transparency in the retail investment market. It requires manufacturers of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products to produce a key information document. A deferral of twelve months will give additional time for those concerned to adhere to the new requirements. In the light of the exceptional circumstances, I believe that it is appropriate and justified for Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 to be amended accordingly.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, because although we understand the difficulties in implementing regulatory standards, we believe that small savers should be aware of real information about the risks faced by this type of investment. Despite being contrary to any delay in implementation, we intend to include truthful information about investment risks, so we try to avoid scenarios such as the experience of preferentists in Spain. Developing these basic information documents before the proposed limit could lead to numerous problems in determining the financial risks of these types of products and provide excessively optimistic information about these investment products, but we need clear information for investors and savers as soon as possible. as possible. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The EC proposal to impose more regulations on the PRIIP sector has arisen, alBEit late, as a response to the financial crisis. The suggested reforms are designed to protect retail investors in the financial sector that sells inappropriate and high-risk products without providing appropriate information in advance. This report, approved by the ECON by simplified procedure, aims to postpone by one year the date of adoption of Regulation 1286/2014 (concerning PRIIPS level one), i.e. the requirements to provide key information documents for PRIIPS to retail investors will only come into force until 1 January 2018. For the CFP, this initiative represents another one-piece act designed to save capitalism and its financial crisis, which is structural and will only be overcome with another model of society, socialism.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products is to extend the transitional rules for insurance-based financial products. The current regulation requires a key information document for each such product. However, rapid trading makes the information in such a document equally obsolete, and in addition, a normal bank manages such products in the five-digit range, which simply does not make it possible to set up a document for each individual product. I therefore voted in favour of extending the transitional rules.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report voted today aims to postpone one year of the date of application of the PriIPS Regulation on key information documents for the retail sale of investment. On 6 April 2016, the European supervisory authorities submitted jointly to the Commission of regulatory technical standards for retail and insurance investment products pre-assembled, approved by delegated act. Later, during the review period, the Council raised no objection but, on 14 September 2016, the European Parliament objected asking the Commission to postpone the date of application of the regulation to allow industries to adapt to the new rules. The Commission therefore presented a new proposal delaying the entry into force by 12 months, until 1 January 2018, in order to reduce legal uncertainty and to give industries more time to adapt to the new rules. Although this is only a technical change to the legislation, it actually results in a clear favour for investment producers without any positive return for consumers. For this reason I preferred to abstain during the plenary vote.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the postponement of the date of application of Regulation (EU) No. 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on documents for packaged investment products for small investors and investment insurance products as regards the date of application. Small investors are increasingly being offered a large selection of packaged investment products for small investors and investment insurance products (PRIIPs) when considering investments. Existing disclosures of information to small investors about such PRIIPs are inconsistent and often do not help small investors compare different products or understand their characteristics. Accordingly, small investors often invested without understanding the associated risks and costs and, sometimes, suffered unforeseen losses.
