Member States have already initiated different and uncoordinated actions to address deficiencies in investor protection measures and such developments are likely to continue. Different approaches to publishing information related to PRIIPs prevent the creation of equal conditions for different PRIIP issuers and those who advise on or sell these products, thereby distorting competition and lead to unequal levels of investor protection in the Union. Such diversity is an obstacle to the establishment and smooth functioning of the internal market. Improving the transparency of PRIIPs offered to small investors is an important measure of their protection and is a prerequisite for restoring the confidence of small investors in the financial market, especially after the financial crisis.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No. 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents on packaged investment products for retail investors and insurance investment products relating to the date of its application. I support the postponement of application of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 for twelve months as it will provide additional time for the operators concerned to meet the new requirements laid down in Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014, enabling the effective and proper functioning of that Regulation. Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council introduces a series of measures aimed at increasing investor protection and restoring consumer confidence in the financial services sector by increasing transparency in the retail market. For this purpose, manufacturers of packaged investment products for retail investors and insurance investment products require the preparation of a key information document.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report establishes a visa waiver for Union citizens and citizens of Kiribati who travel to the other territory for a maximum period of 90 days within the territory of a 180-day period band. This exemption applies to all categories of persons making trips other than those made to carry out a paid activity. I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report calls for the approval of the European Parliament of an agreement providing for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a justification stating that this agreement is a culmination between the EU and third countries - with strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues ( human rights, fundamental freedoms...). The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. I therefore opposed this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this is consistent with the principles of my mandate as an MEP who was elected to support the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union. Such decisions on visas, visa waivers, and entry of nationals of third countries into UK territory should properly be a matter for the British Government to determine.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural ties, and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. Such a visa exemption would pose security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. Is it appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration? I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I approved this agreement, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and Kiribati nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today, I voted in favour of the Gabriel report on the EU-Kiribati agreement on short-stay visa waiver. The text lays down an exemption for Union citizens and citizens of Kiribati who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons regardless of the reason for staying, provided that this is not related to the performance of a paid activity. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including the Republic of Kiribati. The visa waiver agreement is a further demonstration of Europe's commitment to this region, for a partnership that strengthens economic relations and political dialogue balanced, regular and thorough on all issues which continue to be prioritised for the Union.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (120092/2015) and the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati (12091/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on short-stay visa waiver. The European Commission is requested to observe the evolution of the criteria that led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria cover not only clandestine immigration, public order and security, but also the Union's external relations with Kiribati, including human rights and fundamental freedoms issues.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. At a time when Europe is hit by terrorist attacks and massive illegal immigration, these exemptions do not appear on the agenda, as malignant people may one day use them. I am therefore firmly opposed to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Kiribati nationals travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The measure does not raise any particular issues and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This Agreement establishes a visa-free travel regime for short-stay stays, up to 90 days within 180 days. This agreement covers all categories of travel except for the exercise of a paid activity. The Agreement implies a greater rapprochement of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement strengthens cultural, economic relations and intensifies political dialogue. This agreement further proves the Union's commitment to this region with a view to a more strengthened partnership. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural ties, and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — Agreements providing visa-waiver for short-stay stay are generally both a success in deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance and a new tool for economic and cultural to strengthen relations and encourage political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. On mobility, the available data show that visa applicants have a high degree of reliability and few rejected applications. Such countries do not pose any threat to irregular migration, security and public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of rapproaching the population of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full, cheaper and easier use of the partnership's opportunities.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver between the EU and Kiribati. It is an act of great political importance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati and is also a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, such a visa waiver agreement brought positive effects, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitates investment and promotes tourism.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this report on the Agreement, which provides for visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and for Kiribati citizens when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of no more than 90 days in a 180-day period. A joint statement of interpretation is attached to the contract.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with countries third parties. A way of reporting that has often produced positive results for citizens of both parties and increased the range of influence of the European Union's soft power. The Republic of Kiribati is a country that has reached a democratic form of a modern type, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural deficiencies, its own internal social problems, the difficult relationship with some countries in the Pacific area. Overall, Europe can look to the Republic of Kiribati as a friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop in appropriate conditions, gradually, and to fit in progressively in the area of free trade and common cooperation, in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Cotonou Convention, the main purpose of which, expressed in Article 1, is the reduction and finally the elimination of poverty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. According to the rapporteur, this type of agreement constitutes a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations as well as intensifying dialogue on various issues including human rights and fundamental freedoms. On the other hand, we consider it absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement at a time when our Western societies are threatened by Islamic fundamentalism, which uses legal immigration channels to penetrate our territories and plan terrorist attacks. Besides, this visa waiver will strengthen criminal networks as well as illegal trafficking of all kinds. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Cotonou Agreement marks the partnership relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the relations between the Republic of Kiribati and the European Union are also regulated. The EU-Kiribati agreement on short-stay visa waiver provides for the abolition of the visa requirement for the benefit of Union citizens and Kiribati nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of not more than 90 days during any 180-day period. This visa waiver benefits all categories of persons, thus encouraging tourism and investment. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe it is a powerful instrument for strengthening economic, cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the recommendation in question supporting the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on short-stay visa waiver. This agreement is a useful tool for improving economic relations and increasing cooperation on human rights and fundamental freedoms. Kiribati's government has made significant progress thanks to the fulfillment of its international obligations. In fact, it adopted the action plan 2011-2021 which indicates a strong signal of contrast to sexual and gender violence. In the light of this, the Union has the opportunity to establish a balanced and constructive political dialogue on these issues, which underpin EU principles. It will be up to the Commission and the Kiribati authorities to ensure full reciprocity of the visa waiver.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will see citizens from Kiribati being able to travel visa-free in certain EU countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This visa waiver applies for all persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity.  As Ireland is not a member of the Schengen area, this does not apply to it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati, which has already been negotiated between the Republic of Kiribati and the European Commission. This would facilitate the issue of short-stay visas and also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement in question establishes a visa waiver for EU citizens and citizens of Kiribati who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This exemption covers all categories of persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for exercising a paid activity. My vote was in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: ‒ In recent years, the Republic of Kiribati has made considerable progress in fulfilling its international human rights obligations and achieving the objectives of Millennium development. I believe that this progress also shows the commitment of this region to deepening relations with the European Union. The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents the crowning achievement of this commitment. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the agreement is a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations between the two parties and to confirm the commitments made in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. Furthermore, I believe that simplifying travel conditions will result in positive results by facilitating investment and tourism.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on short-stay visa waiver. As this agreement will contribute to the further development of relations between the two parties, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: ‒ I applaud the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, the signing of which was signed by the Commission in Brussels last 23 June. This is how the visa waiver is made lasting for EU and Kiribati citizens who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180. The exemption includes all categories of persons regardless of the reason of stay, provided that it is not the conduct of a paid activity. The underlying issue involves strengthening economic and cultural relations by facilitating investment and tourism. To date, Kiribati's economy is predominantly based on fisheries (25% of GDP), while tourism is somewhat limited. The implementation and monitoring of the Agreement shall be entrusted to the Commission and the Kiribati authorities. In the middle of the Pacific, straddling the Equator and the line of date change, the Kiribati Islands were among the last to be discovered by European explorers, but the Union wants absolutely channel a political dialogue with them. In fact, the country does not pose a threat in terms of irregular immigration or migration flow, nor in matters of security and order.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is pursuing a visa policy, particularly with regard to the waiver of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens no longer need a visa. It is up to the European Parliament to give its approval to the agreement on its establishment, which is thus given. For all this and because this agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with the Republic of Kiribati, I am voting in favour of its conclusion.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati as the main purpose is to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas with the visa exemption for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati, who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Kiribati when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. There are positive effects by simplifying travel for business people, facilitating investment and boosting tourism.  This visa waiver agreement will have a rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and the Pacific and will enable citizens not only to derive full and tangible benefit from the ACP-EU partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, is of significance political under the Cotonou Agreement and represents an additional tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on several issues, including human rights and basic freedoms. I believe that in this way we can give momentum to the currently limited trade relations with Europe, facilitating investment and tourism. The visa waiver agreement will allow citizens not only to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling in a more economical and practical way.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati. I believe that it represents an important achievement in the process of deepening the relationship between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati. The visa waiver agreement can have positive effects by simplifying entrepreneurs' travel conditions, facilitating investment and tourism. The Visa Exemption Agreement allows citizens not only to fully and specifically benefit from the ACP-EU Partnership, but also participate in it through the ability to travel with lower costs and the associated administrative procedures simplified.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The signing of the short-stay waiver is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and the states. The visa waiver may act to boost economic investment in the area, and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in Kiribati.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this Agreement with Kiribati will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Kiribati on short-stay visa waiver. This visa-free regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati for a stay of up to 90 days over a period of 180 days should strengthen our economic and cultural relations by positively impacting both Contracting Parties.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. These agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and nationals of Kiribati, Solomon Islands, Micronesia, Tuvalu and Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. In a worrying security environment, any proposal for visa relief or exemptions seems to us inappropriate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Cotonou Agreement defines the relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States. The signed Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Kiribati when they travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of up to 90 days for any period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official/official and special passport) travelling for any purpose except for the purpose of pursuing a lucrative activity. I supported the abolition of the visa regime under the aforementioned conditions. I believe that it can have positive impacts by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs and increasing investment in tourism.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-Kiribati short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because I believe that visa-free travel for citizens of the Contracting Parties this Agreement could be a useful instrument in order to intensify the influence of European Union in the countries concerned, with particular reference to human rights, and may constitute a stimulus to their economic growth.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement in question between the European Union and Kiribati represents another important step in deepening diplomatic relations. The approval of the agreement concerned will allow citizens of the Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote in favour of the exemption of the tourist visa for periods of up to 90 days.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — The EU-Kiribati short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and of fundamental freedoms, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Kiribati when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver may act to boost economic investment in the area, and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in some areas. The signing of short-stay waivers steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation providing for a visa-free movement regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati for a maximum period of 90 days. This is an important agreement in reference to its political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a further step towards deepening economic and cultural relations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati as a basis for further developing friendly relations between the contracting parties. It will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business, as well as safeguarding the principle of equal treatment of all EU citizens.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. — Since the beginning of the mandate, this Parliament has been required to approve 18 agreements with third countries aiming to exempt EU and those nationals from visas travelling to the territory of the other party for non-professional stays of less than 3 months. I voted against each of these agreements, especially today's five. Certainly, the latter concern micro-island states in Oceania with a total population of barely one million inhabitants. The theoretical risks they pose, in terms of mass immigration, terrorism or organized crime, appear to be marginal. But on the one hand, this is part of Brussels's general desire to liberalize visa policy as much as possible with as many countries as possible, including more volatile and “criminogenic” countries. On the other hand, among the 18 states concerned, there are many countries on various lists, national, European or international, tax havens or non-cooperative countries in the fight against tax evasion or dirty money laundering. This policy contributes to the insecurity and vulnerability of our countries. She must stop urgently.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (120092/2015) and the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati (12091/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as the signing of the short-stay waivers is significant for the EU and the state in question, since it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this motion, as it deepens the growing relationship between the European Union and Kiribati. Additionally, this agreement is a way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. Accordingly, the agreement is a positive sign of support for the country, allowing us to pursue a balanced, regular and in-depth political dialogue on issues which remain priorities for the EU.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — If we take the particular case of Kiribati Islands, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the short-stay visa requirement, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of these three archipelagos of 100,000 inhabitants in the Pacific Ocean. Migration and security risks are non-existent. However, I believe that the visa waiver should not be an automatism but the result of an in-depth assessment of the political, institutional and geostrategic situation of the country concerned and the possible impact that a waiver of the visa requirement may have on European territory. This review should not only be based on the progress made in the years prior to this assessment, but also take into account the potential air intake risks that a visa-waiver may create in the medium term, as we have seen with some countries in the Western Balkans. I therefore reiterate my support for the rapid adoption of the suspension mechanism, which reminds us that visa exemption is not an “unlimited pass” but a conditioned facility that meets certain requirements.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver (12092/2015 — C8-0253/2016 — 2015/0200 (NLE)), granting consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the Agreement signed to citizens of the European Union and citizens of the European Union The Republic of Kiribati allows visa-free stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Republic of Kiribati has made great progress in respecting international human rights commitments as well as achieving the objectives established at the international level, such as the Millennium Development Goals.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report on visa exemption for citizens of Kiribati poses protean security risks. As such, it would be very imprudent for the European Union to sign an agreement that would only add its weight to the already heavily loaded balance of the migration crisis in our territories. So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation because I am in favour of broadening cooperation with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and this agreement suits my vision of it. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for any purpose other than carrying out a paid activity.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conclusion of an agreement with the Republic of Kiribati to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the proposal because I do not see the need for the introduction of visa-free short stays by Kiribati citizens, especially since the competence for this should also lie with the Member States themselves.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it is not appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the European Union has lost all control over immigration.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which allows the exemption of short-term visas, that is, for stays in the European Union of up to 90 days over a 180 day period, for nationals of the Republic of Kiribati, a micro-state Pacific archipelago.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of the visa facilitation agreement between the EU and Kiribati.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati are governed by the Cotonou Partnership Agreement. This Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any period of 180 days. The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati and has great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. Since I believe that the Republic of Kiribati does not pose any threat in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security, I supported this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Agreement with the Pacific Republic of Kiribata allows citizens of Contracting States to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. This country does not pose a danger to the Union from the point of view of migration, security or public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The agreement provides for the introduction of a visa-free travel regime for citizens of Kiribati. They will now be able to travel to the territory of the Member States of the European Union without applying for a visa. This proposal concerns short stays that do not exceed 90 days. Citizens of Member States will enjoy the same privilege when travelling to Kiribati. The visa liberalisation envisaged by the European Commission is dangerous and carries security risks. Lack of control can increase the level of organized crime, money-laundering and drug trafficking. On the other hand, it can encourage massive immigration.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Kiribati Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. Allowing nationals of Kiribati to enter the European Union and vice versa will help to enhance economic and cultural relations in the context of the bloc and the Conotou Agreement. Furthermore, the mutual visa waiver entails a number of positive   effects including, but not limited to, easier travel for different purposes, facilitation of investment, and a rise in tourism.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This agreement will contribute to strengthening economic and cultural ties and to foster political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa-free regime will make a significant contribution to bring Europeans closer together and the population of the Pacific countries.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The visa exemption for citizens of Kiribati presents potential security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the EU has lost all control over immigration. I therefore objected to this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, referred to as the 'Cotonou Agreement'. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this short-stay visa waiver because it bolsters tourism and facilitates business between Kiribati and the EU.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the visa-waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati. This agreement will certainly increase our ties with Kiribati within the framework of the ACP-EU partnership. In this regard, the political dialogue between the Union and Kiribati on issues dear to both partners is of particular importance and I would like to commend Kiribati's efforts to combat violence and discrimination against women. Finally, I would like to underline the commitment of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas, which  simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 was amended on 20 May 2014 by Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which included the Republic of Kiribati as a third country whose citizens are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently opened negotiations with a mandate of the Council with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati. The Council adopted a draft decision ratifying the agreement signed in Brussels on 23 June 2016, which should, however, obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament should agree with the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of third countries concerned who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question must be asked whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost control over mass immigration. Unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Republic of Kiribati has been transferred to Annex II, which lists third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 as amended applies to all Member States with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. Following the adoption of that Regulation, on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the above, I am in favour of concluding the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: The proposed visa waiver poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to vote on this kind of agreement, even though we see every day that the EU is unable to control migration flows. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides for reciprocal and short-term stays a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Kiribati nationals. This agreement will strengthen the economic and cultural ties that unite this country with our continent.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union has already concluded visa waiver agreements with a number of countries. Their positive impact is mainly in deepening economic and cultural relations, but they also play an important role in boosting investment and tourism. The visa waiver is valid for travel lasting up to 90 days in any 180-day period. During the December miniplenary, we approved the conclusion of agreements with five new countries, one of which is the Republic of Kiribati.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement was signed in June 2000 by EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and was concluded for a 20-year period, until 2020, making it the most comprehensive partnership agreement between developing countries and the EU. I have voted for this report on the waiver of short-stay visas for citizens of the EU and the Republic of Kiribati when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue on a wide range of issues like fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Commission and the European Union, respectively, show inconsistency on visa policy. My fellow citizens are victims of this because countries like Canada and the United States still discriminate against us when it comes to their visa-free policies. I refrained from giving my support to the agreement between the EU and Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver because I do not approve of the way in which the European Commission conducts the EU visa policy and that it ignores the judgments of the Court of Justice on certain issues obliged to do so. An example is the decision in Case C-88/14 of 16.7.2015, according to which the European Commission is obliged to propose the introduction of visas for countries that do not apply full visa reciprocity with all EU countries. The European Commission has not done so and has not proposed visas for US and Canadian citizens who continue to discriminate against my fellow citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report because I do not see any need for short-stay visa exemption. Furthermore, the competences should lie with the Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The agreement is an additional tool for intensifying economic and cultural relations and for more intense political dialogue on a range of topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement contributes decisively to the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati and constitutes a complementary instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying the political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will have a positive impact because it simplifies travel procedures for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and tourism. It should be stressed that the visa waiver is a non-negligible instrument for the mutual rapprochement of the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to take full and tangible advantage of the ACP-EU Partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at reduced financial and practical costs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that the short-stay visa waiver agreement is the crowning of an optimal relationship between European Union and the Republic of Kiribati. Moreover, this agreement is also aimed at strengthening the economic and cultural relations between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati, but the authorities in Kiribati must, in turn, ensure the reciprocity of this agreement granting and, therefore, equal treatment. Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement because it takes into account the situation of Member States which do not apply the Schengen acquis in full. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Kiribati when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the draft decision to conclude an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati with a desire to deepen relations between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati. It strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues such as human rights issues and fundamental freedoms. It is expected that this agreement will have a positive effect because it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and encourage the development of the tourism sector, which is very important because the Kiribati economy primarily rests on the services sector, which accounts for 66% of GDP and the agriculture sector. i.e. fisheries which has a share of 25% in GDP. On the political front, the Government of the Republic of Kiribati has made great progress in respecting international human rights obligations as well as achieving the objectives established at the international level, such as the Millennium Development Goals. In this regard, the Agreement represents a positive sign of support for Kiribati and enables a balanced, regular and thorough political dialogue on issues that remain priority for the Union. The visa waiver agreement not only enables citizens to benefit the full and concrete benefit from the partnership between Kiribati and the EU, but to actively participate in it and travel easier at less cost.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — This Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, and we must also bear in mind its great political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The Government of the Republic of Kiribati should be commended for the progress made in respecting international human rights obligations as well as in achieving the objectives established at the international level. Investments and trade exchange with Kiribati remain poorly developed from the point of view of value and in relative terms. The agreement will therefore have a positive economic impact as it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and development of the tourism sector. This strengthening of economic and cultural relations will further intensify political dialogue on issues that remain priority for the Union. As regards mobility, Kiribati does not pose any threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. The agreement is further evidence of our engagement in the region in order to achieve a better partnership and is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. Citizens of both regions will be able to benefit the full and concrete benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. I want to emphasize the necessity of complete reciprocity in visa waiver and thus equal treatment of all citizens.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement between the EU and Kiribati on short-stay visa waiver for European Union citizens and Kiribati citizens. This Agreement shall allow him to stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days during any period of 180 days. Kiribati is an island state in the Pacific Ocean whose economy is mainly based on the service sector (66% of GDP) and agriculture, specifically fisheries, which accounts for 25% of GDP. Tourism is limited due to the fact that about 4,000 persons annually visit Kiribati. I think this agreement can have a positive impact and simplify entrepreneurs' journeys, facilitate investment and encourage tourism. Kiribati has made important strides in meeting its international human rights obligations. I believe that visa waiver is another step towards deepening political dialogue on a number of issues, especially human rights, which I consider priority.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Visa Facilitation Agreement aims to provide visa-free travel for citizens of the Parties to the Agreement (EU and those countries) for a period not exceeding 90 days in each 180-day period. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for these five countries and increase the EU's clout, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal, as the population of these countries is small. The UK and Ireland do not participate in these agreements. I hereby supported the agreement

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on visa waiver in the territories of the EU and the Republic of Kiribati. This exemption applies to all travellers from both zones, for a period of 90 days, regardless of the reason. However, it excludes persons wishing to engage in a paid activity. Due to its remoteness and small population, the development of relations between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati does not pose any migratory and security risk for our continent.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament voted in favour of the agreement on a reciprocal visa waiver for European and Kiribatian nationals with a large majority of 567 votes in favour, 51 against and 24 abstentions. This flexible visa scheme for stays of less than 90 days, which has already been applied provisionally since the signing of the agreement on 13 June 2016, benefits all categories of persons travelling for any reason, except for exercising a paid activity. This agreement reinforces economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati already governed by the Cotonou Agreement (ACP-EU country). Another proof of their commitment and mutual good faith in the overall economic partnership between the European Union and 14 Pacific countries. It provides an additional means of continuing political dialogue with the Kiribati on priority issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to bringing together the peoples of Europe and those of the Pacific, this new visa regime encourages potential investments and the development of tourism in these Pacific archipelagos frequented by barely 4000 tourists every year.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for short-term stays, not exceeding 90 days within 180 days. This agreement covers all categories of travel except for the exercise of a paid activity. The Agreement implies a greater rapprochement of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement strengthens cultural, economic relations and intensifies political dialogue. This agreement further proves the Union's commitment to this region with a view to a more strengthened partnership. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 1 December 2016 on the draft Council decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. Having followed the work on this matter in the committee responsible, I have come to the conclusion that this short-stay visa exemption is fully justified.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The agreement with Kiribati on visa facilitation is a welcome and necessary step. This agreement facilitates travel for both EU citizens and Kiribati residents. The question is indeed not controversial, since until now the visa-free regime between the EU and Kiribati has been conducted without any major disruption, capable of putting forward arguments against the extension and extension of this agreement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This decision is intended to grant visa-free travel to citizens of the European Union and reciprocally for citizens of the Republic of Kiribati who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. The Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between both parties and is of political importance under the Cotonou Agreement and promotes strengthening economic and cultural relations. Kiribati is a democratic republic that respects human rights constitutionally. However, political dialogue on this issue is expected to intensify. Since Kiribati's economy is essentially based on the agriculture and services sector, and there is a weak development in the tourism sector, this agreement will not only enable travel for entrepreneurs but will also facilitate the travel of European citizens, thus investment and boost the economy and tourism. As I agree with the position put forward in this report on the importance of visa waiver as an element of rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and the Pacific, benefiting fully from the ACP-EU partnership, I voted in favour of it.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this agreement which will allow visa-free travel to the European Union for citizens of the Republic of Kiribati and vice versa, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted by the European Parliament today lays down new visa-free provisions for citizens of the Union and for citizens of the Republic of Kiribati who go in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. Visa exemption covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay. This agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument to strengthen economic, tourist and cultural relations and, Finally, it will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report as the signing of the short-stay waivers is significant for the EU and the state in question, as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the EU's cooperation with the Pacific countries. This Agreement, which is the subject of a resolution, allows citizens of the Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This will strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with the 14 countries of the Pacific region to which the Republic of Kiribati belongs. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — Removing visa barriers is an important step in deepening EU-Kiribati relations, which is why I supported this agreement. The legal framework for visa-free travel has been established by the Cotonou Agreement, which deals with the partnership of EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific States. The Republic of Kiribati has made progress in the area of human rights, which are a fundamental value of the EU. Specific steps include the adoption of an Action Plan to Eliminate Sexual and Gender Motioned Violence 2011-2020, and efforts to implement the provisions of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. I consider this agreement to be a proper demonstration of support for the activities of the Republic of Kiribati, which will enable us to continue achieving EU priorities in the region concerned. At the same time, the abolition of the visa requirement will positively affect the economic development of a country which has its economy based on the provision of services and fisheries. I stress that visa-free travel will only cover stays of 90 days for a period of 180 days and passengers with a reason other than the pursuit of an economic activity. Also important is the factor of high confidence in visa applicants, as well as the low level of visa refusal, or the fact that no Kiribati citizen was arrested for illegally staying in the EU in 2014 and 2015.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, or the so-called Cotonu Agreement governs relations between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati, while the Visa Waiver Agreement Short-term stay further deepens these relations and further clumps economic and cultural links and deepens political dialogue in particular in the areas of human rights and fundamental freedoms. According to the agreement, the Republic of Kiribati is one of the countries whose nationals are exempted from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. All citizens of the Republic of Kiribati may travel without a visa to the territory of a Contracting Party for a maximum of 92 days during a 180-day period, regardless of the purpose of the trip. The Parliament's recommendation notes that such an agreement can have positive effects on the rapprochement of European and Pacific nations by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, and promoting investment and tourism. In addition, the Republic of Kiribati has made progress on human rights (e.g. the adoption of an Action Plan to Eliminate Sexual Violence), and this agreement enables further in-depth political dialogue on these issues, and I supported the recommendation when voting.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the Kiribati Government has made progress in fulfilling its international commitments, particularly with regard to respect for human rights and freedoms, while Kiribati citizens do not pose any serious threat to the objectives of migration policy, security and internal order of the EU, it appears to be in place conclude a short-stay visa waiver agreement with that country. The conditions for visa-free travel set out in this document are regulated in the same way as in other agreements of the same type that the EU has concluded with other countries. This agreement should be a successful completion of one of the stages of deepening relations between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati and allow both sides to continue their further deepening.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, which is politically very important under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and to strengthen economic and cultural relations. Strengthen political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is nothing against this visa exemption. However, I reject the EU's responsibility for visa issues.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — This Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati and is of great political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The signed Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. Visas are revoked for all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official or special passports) who do not travel for the purpose of carrying out paid activities. Visa abolition is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. I accept this Agreement because it has great political significance, and it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, Kiribati citizens have not submitted any asylum applications and do not pose any threat in terms of irregular migration or migration flows either in terms of security and public order.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati will allow citizens of both signatories to travel without visas, but without the possibility of performing paid work. The agreement concluded will deepen relations between the EU and the Republic of Kiribati, both in economic and cultural and political areas.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-Kiribati short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent for the signing of an agreement by the Council, on behalf of the European Union, with the Republic of Kiribati on the reciprocal granting of a short-stay visa waiver for all categories of passports. In considering this proposal, I have taken into account that this step is in line with the intentions and objectives of the Cotonou Convention regulating the relationship between the EU and ACP countries, can promote the development of economic and trade relations, tourism and thus contribute to the development of the EU's development policy objectives in the region. I have taken into account the recent efforts made by Kiribati to improve the standard of living of the population and to enforce human rights, while also appreciating the important contribution that the EP has made through the ACP-EU parliamentary delegation to the visa waiver agreement in the process of creating it.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order to develop relations with countries from different parts of the world, the European Union has initiated, in the last two years, a comprehensive process of negotiations with a view to waiving short-stay visas. Kiribati is one of the member countries of the EU-ACP Agreement, with which the Union wishes to strengthen its political dialogue with a view to strengthening cooperation in areas of common interest. Recently, Kiribati authorities have made significant progress in terms of human rights, achieving the Millennium Development Goals, eliminating sexual violence and discrimination against women. The island state also presents important opportunities for collaboration in the areas of fisheries, agriculture and tourism. As there were no problems with the visa refusal rate for nationals of Kiribati, the short-stay visa waiver, with the exception of persons travelling for remunerated work, is a logical step in relation to the country, which will allow a intensification of investment and tourism activities, as well as strengthening the partnership between the two parties. I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: relations between the European Union and that State shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. With regard to the implementation and monitoring of the Agreement, Parliament invited the European Commission to observe possible developments with regard to the criteria that initially led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria include not only illegal immigration, public order and security, but also the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the Agreement between the European Union and Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati and has great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The signed agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. The cancellation of visas applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official or special passports) whose purpose of the trip does not involve carrying out paid activities.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati proposes the abolition of short-stay visas for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati travelling in the territory of the counterparty. Visit-free travel option applies to stay up to 90 days in any period of 180 days, and will apply to all categories of passengers. I believe that this agreement will have a positive effect on the Kiribati economy and contribute to strengthening economic and cultural relations between the European Union and Kiribati. The Republic of Kiribati has made significant progress on human rights and the Millennium Development Goals, and this agreement enables the continuation of a balanced dialogue. Given the experience of several recent years and that the citizens of this country do not pose a threat in terms of illegal migration or migration flows, even in terms of security and public order, I supported the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver, on behalf of the European Union. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati are governed by the Cotonou Agreement. In 2016, a bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati, allowing citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati to travel visa-free into the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver agreement will be able to bring positive effects, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, promotes investment and tourism. Visa abolition is an important means of converging European and Pacific nations.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (120092/2015) and the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati (12091/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a succinct justification stating that it constitutes a culmination in the deepening of bilateral relations with strong political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with that country including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and freedoms fundamental”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. I vote against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The visa facilitation agreement is designed to provide visa-free travel from the EU for up to 90 days in a 180-day period for citizens of the Republic of Kiribati. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for the country and increase cooperation with the EU, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal due to the small population of the Republic of Kiribati, which is why I supported the proposed agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part (Cotonou Agreement). I supported him with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (120092/2015) and the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati (12091/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Visa Waiver Agreement will have a positive impact by simplifying travel opportunities for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and tourism. In addition, the visa-free regime will make a significant contribution to bring Europeans closer together and the population of the Pacific countries. The Visa Waiver Agreement enables citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU Partnership, but also to participate in it in economically inexpensive and practical travel.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati are governed by the partnership agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States of the one part and the European Union and its Member States of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Kiribati when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for any purpose other than carrying out a paid activity.
