I voted in favour because I believe that the Agreement represents a culmination of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati that is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Agreement facilitates the short-stay visa waiver between the two parties. We are talking about an agreement negotiated by the European Commission and which was approved by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this agreement which will allow visa-free travel to the European Union for citizens of the Republic of Kiribati and vice versa, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations which are forcing thousands of people to flee

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU-Kiribati agreement on short-stay visa waiver because, firstly, I believe that there is no need for this exemption and, secondly, I believe that the competences of visa policy should remain with the Member States.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the Council's decisions on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on short-stay visa waiver. In this case, the European Parliament should have given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Visa waiver refers to short-term (maximum 90 day stays) and applies to all categories of persons for all purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity. These agreements are the result of intense political dialogue and deepening of political relations with countries outside the European Union and, before such an agreement is concluded, it is always carefully considered whether the country respects human rights, has a democratic regime and how many visa applications and for what reasons has been rejected in the case of citizens of the country concerned. As the Republic of Kiribata has made significant progress in fulfilling international human rights obligations and in achieving the objectives set at international level, such as the Millennium Development Goals, the visa refusal rate for its citizens is very low and does not pose any risk from point of view of illegal immigration, I had no reservations about the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the agreement to abolish the obligation to possess a short-stay visa of no more than 90 days within a 180 day period of first entry between the European Union and Kiribati. Increasing mobility from and towards the European Union must be one of the top priorities of European policy at international level. This exemption is a prerequisite for the development of future relations between the European Union and Kiribati. The abolition of short-stay visas has a positive effect for the economy and citizens. Increasing economic activity but also gaining new experiences through travel are major effects for both sides of the agreement. All countries applying and developing the Schengen acquis, not Member States of the European Union, should also conclude agreements with Kiribati in order to harmonize their visa regime with the European Union system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Kiribati on the short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union. I support the approval of the agreement because it will strengthen economic and cultural relations and deepen political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Visa abolition is an important means of converging European and Pacific nations.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report establishes a visa waiver for citizens of the Union and for citizens of the Solomon Islands who travel to the other territory for a maximum period of 90 days interior of a range of 180 days period. This exemption applies to all categories of persons making trips other than those made to carry out a paid activity. I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this proposal, as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions provided that the state in question has a solid human rights record.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report calls for the approval by the European Parliament of an agreement providing for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a justification stating that the agreement is a culmination between the EU and the Solomon Islands - with strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues ( human rights, fundamental freedoms, etc.). The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. I therefore opposed this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this is consistent with the principles of my mandate as an MEP who was elected to support the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union. Such decisions on visas, visa waivers, and the entry of nationals of third countries into UK territory should properly be a matter for the British Government to determine.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. Such a visa exemption would pose security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. Is it appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration? I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I have approved this agreement, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Gabriel report on the EU-Solomon Islands agreement on short-stay visa waiver. The text lays down an exemption for Union citizens and citizens of the Solomon Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons regardless of the reason for staying provided that this is not related to the performance of a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement is a further demonstration of Europe's commitment to this region, an action focused on promoting democracy, human rights and a reinforced political dialogue. The approved text will certainly also strengthen future reports on issues such as environmental protection, especially in relation to climate change which threatens to cause significant damage in the archipelago.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09785/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands (09783/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. The European Commission is requested to observe the evolution of the criteria that led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria cover not only clandestine immigration, public order and security but also the Union's external relations with Solomon Islands, including human rights and fundamental freedoms issues.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. At a time when Europe is hit by terrorist attacks and massive illegal immigration, these exemptions do not appear on the agenda, as malignant people may one day use them. I am therefore firmly opposed to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the EU and Solomon Islands travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The measure does not raise any problems of any kind and that is why I voted for it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement, which has already been provisionally applied since 7 October 2016, provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Solomon Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. The short-stay visa waiver is the result of further closer relations between the Union and Solomon Islands. Although the Union's trade relations with Solomon Islands are very limited, they have the capacity to develop further. This Agreement strengthens political dialogue, making it more regular, and improving economic and cultural relations between the two Territories. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - For the same reasons as before, I agree to the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and Solomon Islands. It is an act of great political importance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands and is also a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, such a visa waiver agreement brought positive effects, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitates investment and promotes tourism.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Agreement, which provides for visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of another Contracting Party for a period of no more than 90 days over a 180-day period. A joint statement of interpretation is attached to the contract.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with countries third parties. A way of reporting that has often produced positive results for citizens of both parties and increased the range of influence of the European Union's soft power. The Republic of the Solomon Islands is a country that has reached a democratic form of modern type, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural deficiencies, its own internal social problems, the difficult relationship with some countries in the Pacific area. Of particular importance for this territory is climate warming which, with the rise of the seas, threatens the very existence of the island state. Overall, Europe can look to the Republic of the Solomon Islands as a friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop in appropriate conditions, gradually, and to fit in progressively in the area of free trade and common cooperation, in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Cotonou Convention, the main purpose of which, expressed in Article 1, is the reduction and finally the elimination of poverty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. According to the rapporteur, this type of agreement constitutes a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations as well as intensifying dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. On the other hand, we consider it absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement at a time when our Western societies are threatened by Islamic fundamentalism, which uses legal immigration channels to penetrate our territories and plan terrorist attacks. Besides, this visa waiver will strengthen criminal networks as well as illegal trafficking of all kinds. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Cotonou Agreement marks the partnership relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the relations between the Solomon Islands and the European Union are also regulated. The EU-Solomon Islands agreement on the short-stay visa waiver provides for the abolition of the visa requirement for the benefit of Union citizens and Solomon Isle nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum stay 90 days during any 180-day period. This visa waiver benefits all categories of persons, thus encouraging tourism and investment. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe it is a powerful instrument for strengthening economic, cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue between the European Union and the Solomon Islands.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on short-stay visa waiver. The recommendation stresses that this agreement will simplify business travel conditions and facilitate tourism and investment. The visa waiver will bring benefits for citizens, who will be able to travel more practical and cheaply. Considering the development potential of the Solomon Islands, the agreement will be an excellent opportunity to increase cultural and economic relations and to intensify cooperation carried out by the EU in the islands, which currently focuses essentially on human resource development and sustainable rural development.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will enable citizens from the Solomon Islands to travel visa-free in certain EU countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity.  As Ireland is not a member of the Schengen area, this does not apply to it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against in this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU’s concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this agreement, which will facilitate the issue of short-stay visas and also provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for short periods of time. The agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. While European Union trade relations with the Solomon Islands are very limited, they have potential for development. The European Union is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Solomon Islands. The visa waiver agreement reaffirms the European Union’s commitment to strengthening partnership with that country.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreements in question which Parliament is called upon to approve provide visa-free travel for EU citizens and nationals of the aforementioned States who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in a period of 180 days. Visa waiver covers all categories of people who travel for all kinds of purposes, except to engage in paid activity. The file does not create any problems and I therefore voted for it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands is of strong political significance within the Cotonou Agreement and represents the concrete outcome of the deepening of relations between the two parties. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the agreement is a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands. Bilateral trade relations, although very limited at the moment, have great potential for development and I believe that the simplification of travel conditions will give positive results facilitating investment and stimulating tourism.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. As this agreement will contribute to the further development of relations between the two parties, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I can only call myself enthusiastic about what is voted today on the agreement signed between the European Union and the Solomon Islands: it will allow visa-free travel to citizens of both citizens Parties travelling to the territory of the other for a maximum period of 90 over a maximum period of 180. This exemption covers all categories of persons irrespective of their grounds for stay, except for those whose displacement is dictated by the carrying out of a paid activity. The Solomon Islands presents an economy based on agriculture and services, with them the European Union began in 1990 to carry out relations focused on cooperation for sustainable rural development and, in parallel, on the development of human resources. To date, however, trade relations are small, while presenting tempting growth scenarios. Therefore, the Union considers it important to continue a dialogue on environmental protection, especially in relation to climate change and the defence of human rights and gender issues.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is pursuing a visa policy, particularly with regard to the waiver of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens no longer need a visa. It is up to the European Parliament to give its approval to the agreement on its establishment, which is thus given. For all this and because this agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with the Solomon Islands, I am voting in favour of its conclusion.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands as its main purpose is to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas thus facilitating the issuance of short-stay visas thus facilitating the issuance of short-stay visas the procedures of entry into the country.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. I appeal, however, for caution, as the rapporteur does, since this practice is liable to reduce Parliament’s room for manoeuvre and is problematic because Parliament is not fully informed about the progress of bilateral negotiations.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents both the concrete outcome of the deepening relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands — which has a strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement — be a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on several issues, including rights humans and fundamental freedoms. I also believe that the visa waiver agreement will have a positive effect by simplifying the conditions for business travel, facilitating investment and stimulating tourism, which will be possible develop better trade relations with Europe.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands. I believe that this agreement is a concrete result of the process of deepening relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, while also being a complementary measure to enhance economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a variety of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The European Union's trade relationship with the Solomon Islands is very limited, but thus there is potential for their development. The visa waiver agreement reaffirms the European Union's commitment to strengthening its partnership with the country.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the signing of the short—stay waiver, as it steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue. The visa waiver agreement is further evidence of our commitment to the region, with a view to a strengthened partnership, and may boost economic investment in the area and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in the Solomon Islands.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships which this agreement with the Solomon Islands will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against in this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU’s concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I have supported the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver which provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party. maximum duration of 90 days over any period of 180 days. Through this agreement, we will strengthen not only political dialogue between the two parties, but also economic and cultural relations.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. These agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati, Micronesia, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. In a worrying security context, any proposal for visa relief or exemption seems to us inappropriate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. The Cotonou Agreement — the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States sets out relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Solomon Islands when they travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for up to 90 days within any 180 day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official/official and special passport) travelling for any purpose except for the purpose of pursuing a lucrative activity. I supported this proposal with the idea of future better trade relations and development. The visa waiver agreement not only allows citizens to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it, having the opportunity to travel more profitably and practically.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-N short-stay visa waiver agreement. Solomon is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe that visa-free travel for citizens of the Contracting Parties this Agreement could be a useful instrument in order to intensify the influence of European Union in the countries concerned, with particular reference to human rights, and may constitute a stimulus to their economic growth.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The agreement in question between the European Union and Solomon Islands represents another important step in deepening diplomatic relations. Approval of the agreement concerned will allow citizens of the Union and citizens of Solomon Islands to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote in favour of the exemption of the tourist visa for periods of up to 90 days.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — The EU-N short-stay visa waiver agreement. Solomon is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The signing of short-stay waivers is significant for the EU and the states in question, as it signifies greater cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and those states. The visa waiver may boost economic investment in the area concerned and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in some areas.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation providing for a visa-free movement regime for Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals. The Visa Waiver Agreement may have positive effects, as it helps to simplify the conditions of travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and boost tourism. Since the 1990s, the Union's development cooperation in Solomon Islands has focused mainly on sustainable rural development and human resources development.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a further step towards deepening economic and cultural relations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Solomon Islands, as this constitutes an important step to further develop economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09785/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands (09783/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this report, as the signing of the short-stay waivers steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Solomon Islands agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The European Union’s political dialogue with the Solomon Islands focuses on protecting its vulnerable environment, especially in relation to climate change, on the one hand and on defending human rights and gender issues on the other. The visa waiver agreement represents a significant step towards more regular and enhanced political dialogues. Accordingly I have voted in favour of the motion.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — If we take the particular case of the Solomon Islands, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the short-stay visa requirement, that is, three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this parliamentary democracy of 600,000 inhabitants in the Pacific Ocean. Migration and security risks are non-existent. However, I believe that the visa waiver should not be an automatism but the result of an in-depth assessment of the political, institutional and geostrategic situation of the country concerned and the possible impact that a waiver of the visa requirement may have on European territory. This review should not only be based on the progress made in the years prior to this assessment, but also take into account the potential air intake risks that a visa-waiver may create in the medium term, as we have seen with some countries in the Western Balkans. I therefore reiterate my support for the rapid adoption of the suspension mechanism, which reminds us that visa exemption is not an “unlimited pass” but a conditioned facility that meets certain requirements.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver (09785/2016 — C8-0422/2016 — 2016/0096 (NLE)), granting consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the Agreement signed to citizens of the European Union and citizens of the European Union Solomon Islands allows visa-free stay in the territory of the other contracting party of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The European Union is a partner of civil society in Solomon Islands in matters of democracy and human rights, implementation of the National Development Strategy and enhanced political dialogue.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — This visa waiver report for Solomon Islands citizens poses protean security risks. As such, it would be very imprudent for the European Union to sign an agreement that would only add its weight to the already heavily loaded balance of the migration crisis in our territories. So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Agreement on the abolition of short-term visas between the Solomon Islands and the European Union represents a concrete outlet of deepening relations within the framework of cooperation between the African Group of Countries, the Caribbean and the Pacific (ACP) and the EU. This is a significant step in the strengthening of political dialogue and the strengthening of mutual economic and cultural relations, which have been continuously developed since the signing of the Cotonou Agreement in 2000.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conclusion of an agreement with Solomon Islands to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the proposal because I do not see the need for the introduction of visa-free short stays by citizens of the Solomon Islands, especially since the competence for this should also lie with the Member States themselves.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it is not appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the European Union has lost all control over immigration.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which allows short-term visa waiver, that is, for stays in the European Union of up to 90 days over a 180 day period, for nationals of Solomon Islands, a micro-state Pacific archipelago.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of the visa facilitation agreement between the EU and the Solomon Islands.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands are governed by the Cotonou Agreement, and this Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver underlines its political importance. This Agreement will contribute to improving trade relations, which are currently limited but have the potential for development. The exemption from the obligation to own a visa is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens closer together in the Pacific region. I believe that the Visa Revocation Agreement will allow citizens to travel easier and at less cost, so I supported this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Solomon Islands Agreement allows citizens of Contracting States to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The agreement will also enable the development of relations in the field of tourism and investment. This country does not pose a danger to the Union from the point of view of migration, security or public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The agreement provides for the introduction of a visa-free travel regime for Solomon Islands citizens. They will now be able to travel to the territory of the Member States of the European Union without applying for a visa. This proposal concerns short stays that do not exceed 90 days. Citizens of Member States will enjoy the same privilege when travelling to Solomon Islands. The visa liberalisation envisaged by the European Commission is dangerous and carries security risks. Lack of control can increase the level of organized crime, money-laundering and drug trafficking. On the other hand, it can encourage massive immigration.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Solomon Islands agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. This visa arrangement between the EU and the Solomon Islands, economically speaking, will hasten the process of sustainable rural development and human resource development. Furthermore, there are no security threats in the country concerned.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Solomon Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Visa Waiver applies to all categories of persons traveling to the country for any purpose, except for persons going to work in paid employment. The aim of this agreement is to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to foster political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The visa waiver for Solomon Islands citizens presents potential security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to conclude visa-waiver agreements at a time when the EU has lost all control over immigration. I therefore objected to this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, referred to as the 'Cotonou Agreement'. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for citizens of the European Union and Solomon Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement because it helps to open up new markets for the tourism industry and it facilitates business links between the EU and the Solomon Islands.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the visa-waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Solomon Islands. This agreement will certainly increase our ties with Solomon Islands in the framework of the ACP-EU partnership. The protection of human rights and the protection of the environment are among the issues on which the two partners engage in a political dialogue. It should also be noted: the partnership that the European Union is undertaking with civil society in Solomon Islands in particular in the implementation of the national development strategy. Finally, I would like to underline the commitment of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas, which simultaneously represents a concrete outcome on the deepening relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands – which is highly significant politically in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 was amended on 20 May 2014 by Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which included Solomon Islands as third countries whose citizens are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently opened negotiations with a mandate of the Council with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands. The Council adopted a draft decision ratifying the agreement signed in Brussels on 7 October 2016, but it also needs to obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament should agree with the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of third countries concerned who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. Unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Solomon Islands have been transferred to Annex II, which lists the third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 as amended applies to all Member States with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. Following the adoption of that Regulation, on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and Solomon Islands. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for EU citizens and citizens of Solomon Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the above, I am in favour of concluding the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: The proposed visa waiver poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to vote on this kind of agreement, even though we see every day that the EU is unable to control migration flows. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides, on a reciprocal basis and for short-term stays, a visa-free travel regime for European Union citizens and Solomon Islands nationals. This agreement will strengthen the economic and cultural ties between these islands and our continent.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union has already concluded visa waiver agreements with a number of countries. Their positive impact is mainly in deepening economic and cultural relations, but they also play an important role in boosting investment and tourism. The visa waiver is valid for travel lasting up to 90 days in any 180-day period. During the December miniplenary, we approved the conclusion of agreements with five new countries, including Solomon Islands.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement was signed in June 2000 by EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and was concluded for a 20-year period, until 2020, making it the most comprehensive partnership agreement between developing countries and the EU. I have voted for this report on the waiver of short-stay visas for citizens of the EU and Solomon Islands when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue on a wide range of issues like fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Commission and the European Union, respectively, show inconsistency on visa policy. My fellow citizens are victims of this because some countries like Canada and the United States still discriminate against us when it comes to their visa-free policies. I refrained from giving my support to the agreement between the EU and the Solomon Islands on short-stay visa waivers because I do not approve of the way in which the European Commission conducts the EU's visa policy and that it ignores the judgments of the Court of Justice of the EU on certain issues oblige her to do so. An example is the decision in Case C-88/14 of 16.7.2015, according to which the European Commission is obliged to propose the introduction of visas for countries that do not apply full visa reciprocity with all EU countries. The European Commission has not done so and has not proposed visas for US and Canadian citizens who continue to discriminate against my fellow citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report because I do not see any need for short-stay visa exemption. Furthermore, the competences should lie with the Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The agreement is an additional tool for intensifying economic and cultural relations and for more intense political dialogue on a range of topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a tangible result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands and constitutes a complementary instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying the political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will have a positive impact by simplifying travel procedures for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and stimulating European Union tourism. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at reduced financial and practical costs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I believe that this short-stay visa waiver agreement in favour of the inhabitants of the Solomon Islands is validated from a document approved in Brussels on 7 October 2016. In addition, this agreement allows for the intensification of political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. As a politician, I believe that it is necessary, by the Commission, to monitor the criteria which allowed the movement from Annex I to II to Regulation No 509/2014. Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement because it takes into account the situation of Member States which do not apply the Schengen acquis in full. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the draft decision to conclude an agreement between the EU and Solomon Islands on visa waiver because it is important for further deepening relations between Member States and Solomon Islands. The Union's political dialogue with Solomon Islands is aimed at protecting their sensitive environment, especially in relation to climate change. It strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue, and it is expected that this agreement will have a positive effect on investment and development of the tourism sector. The economy of Solomon Islands rests on the agriculture sector, which accounts for 50% of GDP, and on a service sector that accounts for 40% of GDP, with the tourism sector in gradual development. When it comes to development cooperation, the European Union's main focus in terms of Solomon Islands since the 1990s has been on sustainable rural development and human resources development. While the EU's trade relations with Solomon Islands are very limited, there is potential for their development. The EU is currently negotiating the conclusion of a comprehensive Partnership Agreement with fourteen countries of the Pacific region, including the Solomon Islands. In this context, this agreement confirms the efforts of the European Union to strengthen its partnership with the country.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The short-stay visa waiver agreement is of great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Solomon Islands. EU trade relations with Solomon Islands are currently very limited, but the potential for their development exists. The agreement will thus have a positive economic impact because it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and development of the tourism sector. This strengthening of economic and cultural relations will further intensify political dialogue on issues that remain priority for the Union. As regards mobility, the Solomon Islands do not pose any threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. The agreement is further evidence of our engagement in the region in order to achieve a better partnership and is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. Citizens of both regions will be able to benefit the full and concrete benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. I want to emphasize the necessity of complete reciprocity in visa waiver and thus equal treatment of all citizens.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: This agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Solomon Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement between the EU and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver for European Union citizens and citizens of the Solomon Islands. This Agreement shall allow citizens to stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days during any period of 180 days. This agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands, as set under the Cotonou Agreement. I believe that the short-stay visa waiver will strengthen economic and cultural relations, but will also bring the people of Europe and the Pacific closer together and allow citizens to benefit fully from this partnership.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Visa Facilitation Agreement aims to provide visa-free travel for citizens of the Parties to the Agreement (EU and those countries) for a period not exceeding 90 days in each 180-day period. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for these five countries and increase the EU's clout, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal, as the population of these countries is small. The UK and Ireland do not participate in these agreements. I hereby supported the agreement

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on visa waiver in the territories of the EU and Solomon Islands. This exemption applies to all travellers from both zones, for a period of 90 days, regardless of the reason. However, it excludes persons wishing to engage in a paid activity. This agreement will allow us to deepen our dialogue with Solomon Islands, particularly on environmental and climate issues, which directly affect all citizens.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Agreement, which already applies as from 7 October 2016 on a provisional basis, provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Solomon Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. The short-stay visa waiver is the result of further closer relations between the Union and Solomon Islands. Although the Union's trade relations with Solomon Islands are very limited, they have the capacity to develop further. This Agreement strengthens political dialogue, making it more regular, and improving economic and cultural relations between the two Territories. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution of 1 December 2016 on the draft Council decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on short-stay visa waiver. Having followed the work on this matter in the committee responsible, I have come to the conclusion that this short-stay visa exemption is fully justified.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Visa facilitation agreement with Solomon Islands is a welcome and necessary step. This agreement facilitates travel for both EU citizens and Solomon Islands. The question is not really controversial, since until now the visa-free regime between the EU and Solomon Islands has been carried out without disturbances.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Like the report discussed today on Kiribati, this decision also aims to grant visa-free visa-free for citizens of the European Union (EU) and reciprocally for Solomon Islands citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in each period of 180 days. The Solomon Islands is a constitutional monarchy, which has been part of the Commonwealth since 1978. Political dialogues between these islands and the EU have focused on protecting their vulnerable environment and, on the other hand, on the defence of human rights and gender equality issues. This agreement will not only allow closer relations between both parties but will also represent an important step in the context of EU-ACP relations. As the Solomon Islands' economy is essentially based on the agriculture and service sector, this agreement will foster greater entry of European citizens into these islands, boosting their economy and bringing the peoples of Europe and the Pacific closer together. As a member of the delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I voted in favour of this recommendation as I recognise the importance of visa waiver as a benefit from the ACP-EU partnership.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this Agreement which will allow the citizens of Solomon Islands to travel without a visa to the European Union and vice versa, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted by the European Parliament today lays down new visa-free provisions for Union citizens and Solomon Islands citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. Visa exemption covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay. This agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument to strengthen economic, tourist and cultural relations and, Finally, it will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, as the signing of the short-stay waivers steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the EU's cooperation with the Pacific countries. This Agreement, which is the subject of a resolution, allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Solomon Islands to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This also represents significant progress in a more regular and strengthened political dialogue aimed at protecting the vulnerable environment of the islands, particularly in relation to climate change, on the one hand, and the protection of human rights on the other. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with the 14 countries of the Pacific region to which the Solomon Islands belong. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Cotonou Agreement has created a legal framework for deepening cooperation between the EU and countries in Africa, the Caribbean and Pacific. Solomon Islands, as a member of the Commonwealth, have been a participant in political dialogue with the EU since 1976. The dialogue focuses on the protection of the environment, in a period of change in climate conditions, and on the protection of human rights and gender equality. The abolition of visa requirements will support Solomon Islands' efforts to continue this dialogue, while unlocking the economic potential of cooperation. The economy of the Solomon Islands relies on agriculture and the provision of services. The European Union has been working with the country since 1990 on the sustainable development of agriculture and human resources. I consider it important to point out that visa-free travel will only cover stays of 90 days for a period of 180 days and for persons travelling for reasons other than for the purpose of carrying out an economic activity. Also important is the factor of high confidence in visa applicants, as well as the low level of visa refusal, or the fact that no citizen of Solomon Islands was arrested for illegally staying in the EU in 2014 and 2015. For these reasons, in particular, I supported the abolition of the visa requirement for short-term stays of citizens from Solomon Islands.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, or the so-called Cotonu Agreement governs relations between the EU and the Solomon Islands, while the Visa Waiver Agreement for Short-term stay further deepens these relations and further clumps economic and cultural links and deepens political dialogue in particular in the areas of human rights and fundamental freedoms. According to the Agreement, the Solomon Islands are among countries whose nationals are exempted from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. All citizens of Solomon Islands may travel without visas to the territory of a Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days during a 180-day period, without a visa. The Parliament's recommendation notes that such an agreement can play a huge role in establishing an enhanced and more frequent dialogue that focuses on protecting the sensitive environment there, particularly in relation to climate change, and on protecting human rights and gender equality, so I in voting supported. In addition, the agreement simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs and promotes investment and tourism, which is particularly important in this case as development cooperation is based on sustainable rural development and human resource development.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ By making progress by the Government of Solomon Islands in fulfilling its international obligations, particularly with regard to respect for human rights and freedoms, and at the same time the citizens of Solomon Islands do not pose any serious threat to the objectives of migration policy, security and internal order of the EU; it appears appropriate to conclude a short-stay visa waiver agreement with that country. The conditions for visa-free travel set out in this document are regulated in the same way as in other agreements of the same type that the EU has concluded with other countries. This agreement should be a successful completion of one of the stages of deepening relations between the EU and Solomon Islands and allow both sides to continue their further deepening.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a tangible result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands, which is politically very important under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations. and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is nothing against this visa exemption. However, I reject the EU's responsibility for visa issues.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — This Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands and has great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement. The Agreement signed allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Solomon Islands to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. Visas are revoked for all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official or special passports) who do not travel for the purpose of carrying out paid activities. Exemption from the obligation to own a visa is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. I accept this Agreement because it has great political significance, and it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, Solomon Islands citizens have not submitted any asylum applications and do not pose any threat in terms of irregular migration or migration flows either in terms of security and public order.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands will allow citizens of both signatories to travel without visa-free travel, but without the possibility of performing paid work. With an agreement that will bring a number of positive effects, we will, among other things, simplify travel for entrepreneurs, increase investment and boost tourism. In view of all of the above, I support the said Agreement.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-N short-stay visa waiver agreement. Solomon is not a complementary instrument of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent for the signing of an agreement by the Council, on behalf of the European Union, with Solomon Islands on the reciprocal granting of a short-stay visa waiver for all categories of passports. Considering the proposal, I took into account that this step is in line with the intentions and objectives of the Cotonou Convention governing the relationship between the EU and the ACP countries, and could promote the still modest economic and trade relations, tourism to contribute to the achievement of the Union's development policy objectives in the region. I have taken into account the recent efforts made by Solomon Islands to develop the local economy, to better lay the foundations for the forthcoming EU-ACP Economic Partnership Agreement, while also appreciating the important contribution that the EP through the ACP-EU parliamentary delegation played in the process of establishing a visa waiver agreement.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: relations between the European Union and that State shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. With regard to the implementation and monitoring of the Agreement, Parliament invited the European Commission to observe possible developments with regard to the criteria that initially led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria include not only illegal immigration, public order and security, but also the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the resolution on the agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands and has great political significance. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement allows visa-free travel for EU and Solomon Islands citizens when travelling to another contracted party's location for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — An agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver could have a positive effect as it would simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and encourage tourism development. This agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands in terms of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogues. As negotiations are underway to conclude a comprehensive Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the fourteen countries of the Pacific region, including the Solomon Islands, the conclusion of this agreement will confirm efforts to strengthen the EU-Solomon Islands partnership. Since there have been no cases of arrest of Solomon Islands nationals for illegally staying in the EU in recent years, and that nationals of that country have not submitted any asylum applications, it is evident that this State does not pose a threat to irregular migration, I supported cancellation of visas for a stay of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands shall be governed by the Cotonou Agreement. In 2016, a bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and Solomon Islands, allowing citizens of the European Union and Solomon Islands citizens to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The agreement is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Agreement will have positive effects on entrepreneurship, agriculture and tourism and, on the other hand, strengthen relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09785/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands (09783/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a succinct justification stating that it constitutes a culmination in the deepening of bilateral relations with strong political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with that country including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and freedoms fundamental”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. I vote against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Visa Facilitation Agreement is designed to provide visa-free travel from the EU for a maximum period of 90 days over a 180-day period. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for the country and increase cooperation with the EU, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal due to the small population of Solomon Islands, which is why I supported the proposed agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part (Cotonou Agreement). I supported the present proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09785/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands (09783/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Solomon Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Visa Waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose, except for persons going to work in paid employment.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the European Union and the Solomon Islands are governed by the partnership agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States of the one part and the European Union and its Member States of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for any purpose other than carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour because I believe that this agreement represents a concrete outcome for the relations developing between the European Union and the Solomon Islands that is highly significant politically in the context of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement facilitates the short-stay visa waiver between the two parties. We are talking about an agreement negotiated by the European Commission and which was approved by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this agreement which will allow the citizens of Solomon Islands to travel without a visa to the European Union and vice versa, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU-Solomon Islands agreement on the short-stay visa waiver because, firstly, I believe that there is no need for this and, secondly, I believe that the competences of visa policy should remain with the Member States.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the EU-Solomon Islands short-stay visa waiver agreement.
