This agreement represents both the concrete outcome of deepening relations between the EU and the Solomon Islands and a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying the political dialogue on several issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The short-stay visa waiver agreement will have positive effects by simplifying the conditions for business travel, thus facilitating investment and boosting tourism.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the Council's decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. In this case, the European Parliament should have given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Visa waiver refers to short-term (maximum 90 day stays) and applies to all categories of persons for all purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity. These agreements are the result of intense political dialogue and deepening of political relations with countries outside the European Union and, before such an agreement is concluded, it is always carefully considered whether the country respects human rights, has a democratic regime and how many visa applications and for what reasons has been rejected in the case of citizens of the country concerned. As the Solomon Islands confidence in visa applicants is high, the percentage of their refusals is low and, at the same time, in 2014 and 2015, no citizen has been arrested for illegally staying in the European Union, no citizen has been refused entry into the EU and none have been returned to Solomon Islands, I had no reservations about the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the agreement to abolish the obligation to possess a short-stay visa of no more than 90 days within a 180 day period of first entry between the European Union and Solomon Islands. Increasing mobility from and towards the European Union must be one of the top priorities of European policy at international level. This exemption is a prerequisite for the development of future relations between the European Union and Solomon Islands. The abolition of short-stay visas has a positive effect for the economy and citizens. Increasing economic activity but also gaining new experiences through travel are major effects for both sides of the agreement. All countries applying and developing the Schengen acquis, not Member States of the European Union, should also conclude agreements with the Solomon Islands State in order to harmonize their visa regime with the European Union system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Solomon Islands on the short-stay visa waiver, on behalf of the Union, I support the approval of the conclusion of the agreement because I believe it will bring positive effects, because it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, allows investment and promotes tourism. The European Union's trade relations with the Solomon Islands are currently very limited and have the potential for development.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report establishes a visa exemption for Union citizens and citizens of Micronesia who travel to the other territory for a maximum period of 90 days interior of a range of 180 days period. This exemption applies to all categories of persons making trips other than those made to carry out a paid activity. I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We supported this proposal, as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions provided that the state in question has a solid human rights record.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report calls for the approval by the European Parliament of an agreement providing for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a justification stating that the agreement is a culmination between the EU and Micronesia - with strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues ( human rights, fundamental freedoms, etc.). The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. I therefore opposed this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this is consistent with the principles of my mandate as an MEP who was elected to support the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union. Such decisions on visas, visa waivers, and the entry of nationals of third countries into UK territory should properly be a matter for the British Government to determine.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural contacts and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. Such a visa exemption would pose security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. Is it appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration? I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I have approved this agreement, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and nationals of the Federated States of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Gabriel report on the EU-Micronesia agreement on short-stay visa waiver. The text lays down an exemption for Union citizens and citizens of Micronesia who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons regardless of the reason for staying provided that this is not related to the performance of a paid activity. The agreement will give a new momentum to tourism and increase trade in the Federated States of Micronesia, while strengthening the political dialogue that today focuses on protection of the environment, especially in relation to climate change, as well as on the defence of human rights and gender issues.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09780/2015) and the EU-Micronesia agreement (09779/2015), we voted IN FAVOUR of this recommendation by finding no reason to take another decision, and we consider that decision positive. We are concerned, however, that the country appears to be a tax haven in various reports. A special monitoring of the agreement should therefore be established in order to prevent short-term visa waivers from making money laundering and tax evasion practices easy.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. The European Commission is requested to observe the evolution of the criteria that led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria cover not only clandestine immigration, public order and security but also the Union's external relations with Micronesia, including human rights and fundamental freedoms issues.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. At a time when Europe is hit by terrorist attacks and massive illegal immigration, these exemptions do not appear on the agenda, as malignant people may one day use them. I am therefore firmly opposed to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — While I have always supported the short-lived visa agreements between the EU and third countries, in this measure I have observed the steps which could open to future issues and for this reason reason I preferred to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The signed Agreement, which entered into force provisionally on 19 September 2016, provides for a visa-free movement regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Federated States of Micronesia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Although trade relations between the Union and the Federated States of Micronesia are currently very limited, they have potential development. This Agreement strengthens relations within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, to which the Federated States of Micronesia acceded in 2000, increasing political dialogue and strengthening economic and cultural relations. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural contacts and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - For the same reasons as before, I agree to the EU-Micronesia visa waiver agreement. It is an act of great political importance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and Micronesia and is also a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, such a visa waiver agreement will bring positive effects, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitates investment and promotes tourism.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Agreement, which provides for visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of no more than 90 days over a 180-day period. A joint statement of interpretation is attached to the contract.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with countries third parties. A way of reporting that has often produced positive results for citizens of both parties and increased the range of influence of the European Union's soft power. The Federated States of Micronesia are a country that has reached a democratic form of a modern type, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural deficiencies , its own internal social problems, the difficult relationship with some countries in the Pacific area. Of particular importance for this territory is climate warming which, with the rise of the seas, threatens the very existence of the island state. Overall, Europe can look to the Federated States of Micronesia as a friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop in appropriate conditions, gradually, and to fit in progressively in the area of free trade and common cooperation, in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Cotonou Convention, the main purpose of which, expressed in Article 1, is the reduction and finally the elimination of poverty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. According to the rapporteur, this type of agreement constitutes a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations as well as intensifying dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. On the other hand, we consider it absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement at a time when our Western societies are threatened by Islamic fundamentalism, which uses legal immigration channels to penetrate our territories and plan terrorist attacks. Besides, this visa waiver will strengthen criminal networks as well as illegal trafficking of all kinds. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Cotonou Agreement marks the partnership relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the relations between Micronesia and the European Union are also regulated. The EU-Micronesia agreement on short-stay visa waiver provides for the abolition of the visa requirement for the benefit of Union citizens and nationals of Federated States of Micronesia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of not more than 90 days during any 180-day period. All categories of persons benefit from this visa waiver, thus encouraging tourism and investment. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe it is a powerful instrument for strengthening economic, cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on short-stay visa waiver. The agreement adds strong political significance to the Cotonou Agreement and sets the stage for the consolidation of the dialogue on fundamental freedoms. Whereas the political relations of the European Union with the Federated States of Micronesia focus on protecting their vulnerable environment (especially in relation to climate change) and On the defence of human rights, this agreement is a step forward in promoting better cooperation. Moreover, the agreement will finally enable tourism to be activated and give a new momentum to trade.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will enable citizens from Micronesia to travel visa-free in certain EU countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all persons travelling for any purpose other than carrying out a paid activity.  As Ireland is not a member of the Schengen area, this does not apply to it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against in this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU’s concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas, which simultaneously represents a concrete outcome for the relations developing between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia – highly significant politically in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreements in question which Parliament is called upon to approve, establish a visa exemption for EU citizens and nationals of the aforementioned States who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in a period of 180 days. Visa waiver covers all categories of people who travel for all kinds of purposes, except to engage in paid activity. The file does not create any problems and I therefore voted for it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia is of strong political significance in the Cotonou Agreement and represents the concrete outcome of deepening relations between the two parties. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the agreement is a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia. Bilateral economic relations have great potential for development and I believe that simplifying travel conditions will give positive results by facilitating investment, stimulating tourism and giving momentum to trade.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. As this agreement will contribute to the further development of relations between the two parties, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I cannot but very welcome the agreement reached by the European Union with the Federated States of Micronesia, which was signed on 19 September last in Brussels. This Agreement provides for visa-free travel for European and Micronesian nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180. The exemption covers all categories of persons regardless of the reason of stay, provided that it is not one aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The Federated States of Micronesia are an island state of Oceania, whose economy is therefore focused on services with a booming tourist sector and the Union hopes to be able to facilitate them further growth facilitating mobility.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is pursuing a visa policy, particularly with regard to the waiver of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens no longer need a visa. It is up to the European Parliament to give its approval to the agreement on its establishment, which is thus given. For all this and because this agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with Micronesia, I am voting in favour of its conclusion.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Union and the Micronesia Islands as its main purpose is to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas thereby facilitating entry procedures into the country.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement will provide for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism and will make for rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. This visa waiver agreement will enable citizens not only to derive full benefit from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced economic and practical cost.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents both the concrete outcome of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia — which is of strong political significance within the Cotonou Agreement — as a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including which human rights and fundamental freedoms. I believe that in this way we can give momentum to the currently limited trade relations with Europe, facilitating investment and tourism. The visa waiver agreement will allow citizens not only to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling in a more economical and practical way.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the initiative for the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia. I am convinced that the initiative is a concrete result of the process of deepening mutual relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia, which is of great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, while also being a complementary measure for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensification of political dialogue on a variety of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement can have positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and reviving tourism.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The signing of the short stay waiver is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and the states. The visa waiver agreement may act to boost economic investment in the area, and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in the Federated States of Micronesia.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Micronesia will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP’s have voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — This short-stay visa-waiver measure is a step forward in strengthening political dialogue and economic relations between the EU Member States and the Federated States of Micronesia. While since the signing of the Cotonou Agreements by the Federated States of Micronesia, relations with the European Union have expanded, I supported this report to facilitate the movement of nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any period of 180 days.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. These agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati, Micronesia, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. In a worrying security context, any proposal for visa relief or exemption seems to us inappropriate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. The Cotonou Agreement on Partnership between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States defines relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia. The signed agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia when they travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of up to 90 days for any period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official/official and special passport) travelling for any purpose except for the purpose of pursuing a lucrative activity. I believe that the fall of the visa regime under the aforementioned conditions is a good step for the development of further relations between the two countries and the fact that the Federated States of Micronesia is a democratic state giving priority to human rights, predisposes to the desire to deepen relations. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-Micronesia short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe that visa-free travel for citizens of the Contracting Parties this Agreement could be a useful instrument in order to intensify the influence of European Union in the countries concerned, with particular reference to human rights, and may constitute a stimulus to their economic growth.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement in question between the European Union and Micronesia represents another important step in deepening diplomatic relations. Approval of the agreement concerned will allow citizens of the Union and citizens of Micronesia to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote in favour of the exemption of the tourist visa for periods of up to 90 days.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — The EU-Micronesia short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights, on that is why I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Micronesia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. A joint declaration on the interpretation of this period of 90 days in any 180-day period is attached to the agreement. The signing of the short stay waivers is significant for the EU and the states in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and those states. The visa waiver agreement may act to boost economic investment in the area, and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in some areas.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation providing for a visa-free movement regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Federated States of Micronesia for a maximum period of 90 days. This is an important agreement with regard to its political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a further step towards deepening economic and cultural relations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between EU and the Federated States of Micronesia, as this constitutes an important step to further develop economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09780/2015) and the EU-Micronesia agreement (09779/2015), we voted IN FAVOUR of this recommendation by finding no reason to take another decision, and we consider that decision positive. We are concerned, however, that the country appears to be a tax haven in various reports. A special monitoring of the agreement should therefore be established in order to prevent short-term visa waivers from making money laundering and tax evasion practices easy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the signing of the short-stay waiver agreement steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this motion. While European Union trade relations with the Federated States of Micronesia are currently very limited, they have potential for development. The European Union is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with fourteen Pacific countries, including the Federated States of Micronesia and I believe that this agreement would help strengthen the relationship between the two parties.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — If we take the special case of the Federated States of Micronesia, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the short-stay visa requirement, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this federal state of over 100,000 inhabitants in the Pacific Ocean. Migration and security risks are non-existent. However, I believe that the visa waiver should not be an automatism but the result of an in-depth assessment of the political, institutional and geostrategic situation of the country concerned and the possible impact that a waiver of the visa requirement may have on European territory. This review should not only be based on the progress made in the years prior to this assessment, but also take into account the potential air intake risks that a visa-waiver may create in the medium term, as we have seen with some countries in the Western Balkans. I therefore reiterate my support for the rapid adoption of the suspension mechanism, which reminds us that visa exemption is not an “unlimited pass” but a conditioned facility that meets certain requirements.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. − I have voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver (09780/2016 — C8-0388/2016 — 2016/0098 (NLE)) granting consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Relations between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and is signed by the Agreement to citizens of the European Union and the citizens of the European Union The Federal States of Micronesia allows visa-free stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The federal states of Micronesia are, according to political structure, a democratic republic fully committed to the protection of human rights guaranteed by their constitution. The political dialogue between the EU and the Federal States of Micronesia is aimed at protecting their sensitive environment, particularly in relation to climate change and the protection of human rights and gender issues.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report on visa waiver for citizens of Micronesia poses a number of security risks. As such, it would be very imprudent for the European Union to sign an agreement that would only add its weight to the already heavily loaded balance of the migration crisis in our territories. So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The service sector of the Federated States of Micronesia generates 74% of their GDP. I consider it important to cancel short-term visas with a period of 90 days for a maximum of 180 consecutive days between Micronesia and the EU, given that this will facilitate movement for entrepreneurs and investors. I supported this agreement because I believe that, especially in tourism, it has the potential to stimulate the economy of Micronesia.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conclusion of an agreement with the Federated States of Micronesia to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the proposal because I do not see the need for the introduction of visa-free short stays by Micronesian citizens, especially since the competence for this should also lie with the Member States themselves.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In plenary session, I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on visa abolition obligations for short stays. This Agreement establishes a visa waiver scheme for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia residing in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days during the course of any period of 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for persons travelling for the purpose of carrying out a gainful activity. This Agreement represents a concrete result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia, which are of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and is at the same time another means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues that also include human rights and fundamental freedoms. Visa waiver can have a positive impact on simplifying entrepreneurs' travel, facilitating investing and encouraging tourism.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it is not appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the European Union has lost all control over immigration.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which allows the exemption of short-term visas, that is, for stays in the European Union of up to 90 days over a 180 day period, for nationals of the Federated States of Micronesia, a micro-state Pacific archipelago.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concludes the visa facilitation agreement between the EU and Micronesia.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Relations between the EU and the Federal States of Micronesia have been strengthening since 2000, when the Cotonou Agreement was signed. This Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver may further strengthen economic and cultural relations, cooperation between entrepreneurs and trade relations between both parties. Since I consider this Agreement to be useful, I have supported this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The conclusion of the Agreement with Micronesia allows citizens of Contracting States to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The Federated States of Micronesia belong to democratic countries that respect human rights and do not pose a danger to the Union from the point of view of migration, security or public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The agreement provides for the introduction of a visa-free travel regime for the citizens of Micronesia. They will now be able to travel to the territory of the Member States of the European Union without applying for a visa. This proposal concerns short stays that do not exceed 90 days. Citizens of Member States will enjoy the same privilege when travelling to Micronesia. The visa liberalisation envisaged by the European Commission is dangerous and carries security risks. Lack of control can increase the level of organized crime, money-laundering and drug trafficking. On the other hand, it can encourage massive immigration.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU—Micronesia Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. Economically speaking, the visa waiver presents signs of intensifying economic links among businesses even when trade relations are currently limited. Politically speaking, the visa waiver also means enhanced political dialogue between the EU and Micronesia.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The signed agreement establishes a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and of the Federated States of Micronesia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. Visa Waiver applies to all categories of persons traveling to the country for any purpose, except for persons going to work in paid employment. The purpose of this agreement is of great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to foster political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The visa waiver for citizens of Micronesia presents potential security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to conclude visa-waiver agreements at a time when the EU has lost all control over immigration. I therefore objected to this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Relations between the European Union and Micronesia are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. The signed Agreement provides for a visa waiver regime for citizens of the European Union and Micronesia nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement. Such short-stay visa waiver programmes are indispensable to increase opportunities for the tourism industry for both partners and to enable business between the EU and the Federated States of Micronesia.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the visa-waiver agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia. This agreement will certainly increase our ties with the Federated States of Micronesia within the framework of the ACP-EU partnership. As with other archipelagos for which visa liberalization is now in force, this agreement should strengthen political dialogue, particularly on human rights and climate change issues. Finally, I would like to underline the commitment of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas, which simultaneously represents a concrete outcome on the deepening relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia – which is highly significant politically in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 was amended on 20 May 2014 by Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which included the Federated States of Micronesia as third countries whose citizens are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently opened negotiations with a mandate of the Council with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia. On the ratification of the agreement signed in New York on 19 September 2016, the Council adopted a draft decision, which should, however, obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament should agree with the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of third countries concerned who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. Unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Federated States of Micronesia have been transferred to Annex II, a list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements to cross borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 as amended applies to all Member States with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. Following the adoption of that Regulation, on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Federated States of Micronesia. The signed Agreement provides for a visa waiver regime for EU citizens and citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Therefore, I am in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: The proposed visa waiver poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to vote on this kind of agreement, even though we see every day that the EU is unable to control migration flows. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides, on a reciprocal basis and for short-term stays, a visa-free travel regime for European Union citizens and citizens of Micronesia. This agreement will strengthen the economic and cultural ties between these countries and our continent.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union has already concluded visa waiver agreements with a number of countries. Their positive impact is mainly in deepening economic and cultural relations, but they also play an important role in boosting investment and tourism. The visa waiver is valid for travel lasting up to 90 days in any 180-day period. During the December mini plenary, we approved the conclusion of agreements with five new countries, including the Federated States of Micronesia.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement was signed in June 2000 by EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and was concluded for a 20-year period, until 2020, making it the most comprehensive partnership agreement between developing countries and the EU. I have voted for this report on the waiver of short-stay visas for citizens of the EU and Micronesia when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue on a wide range of issues like fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Commission and the European Union, respectively, show inconsistency on visa policy. My fellow citizens are victims of this because some countries like Canada and the United States still discriminate against us when it comes to their visa-free policies. I refrained from giving my support to the EU-Micronesia short-stay visa waiver agreement because I do not endorse the way in which the European Commission conducts the EU's visa policy and that it ignores the judgments of the Court of Justice on certain issues obliged to do so. An example is the decision in Case C-88/14 of 16.7.2015, according to which the European Commission is obliged to propose the introduction of visas for countries that do not apply full visa reciprocity with all EU countries. The European Commission has not done so and has not proposed visas for US and Canadian citizens who continue to discriminate against my fellow citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report because I do not see any need for short-stay visa exemption. Furthermore, the competences should lie with the Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The agreement is an additional tool for intensifying economic and cultural relations and for more intense political dialogue on a range of topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a tangible result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia and constitutes a complementary instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is noted that the visa waiver agreement will have a positive impact, as it simplifies travel procedures for entrepreneurs, facilitates investment and strengthens tourism. The visa waiver is a non-negligible instrument for the mutual rapprochement of the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU Partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at reduced financial and practical costs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that the conclusion of the short-stay visa waiver agreement represents both the actual outcome of the deepening relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia, is a further tool for strengthening economic, cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition, this agreement also favours entrepreneurs as it simplifies their travel conditions and investment while stimulating tourism at the same time. Furthermore, as a politician I believe that the trade relationship between the EU and the Federated States of Micronesia has great potential for development. Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement because it takes into account the situation of Member States which do not apply the Schengen acquis in full. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — This short-stay visa waiver agreement further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies the political dialogue between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a concrete result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia, and has considerable political weight under the Cotonou Agreement. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogues on various issues, among others, human rights and fundamental freedoms. The economy of the Federal States of Micronesia is primarily based on the service sector, which accounts for 74% of their GDP, and the emerging tourism sector. While the European Union's trade relations with the Federal States of Micronesia are currently very limited, there is potential for their development. The European Union is currently negotiating the conclusion of a comprehensive Partnership Agreement with fourteen countries of the Pacific region, including the Federal States of Micronesia. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic ties between businesses. This agreement will also encourage the development of tourism and give a new boost to the economy as a whole.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The short-stay visa waiver agreement is of great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia. Pacific democracy is fully committed to protecting human rights and we have good communication when it comes to protecting their sensitive environment, especially in relation to climate change, but in the trade field, EU relations with the Federal States of Micronesia remain very limited and the potential for their development should be exploited. The agreement will thus have a positive economic impact because it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and development of the tourism sector. This strengthening of economic and cultural relations will further intensify political dialogue on issues prioritised for the Union. As regards mobility, the Federal States of Micronesia do not pose any threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. The agreement is further evidence of our engagement in the region in order to achieve a better partnership and is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. Citizens of both regions will be able to benefit the full and concrete benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. I want to emphasize the necessity of complete reciprocity in visa waiver and thus equal treatment of all citizens.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: This agreement provides for a visa exemption regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Federated States of Micronesia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — Supported the abolition of short-stay visa requirements for European Union citizens and citizens of Micronesia. This Agreement will allow EU and Micronesian citizens to stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days during any period of 180 days. The economy of the Federated States of Micronesia is mainly based on the service sector, which shares 74% in GDP. I believe the introduction of a visa-free regime for short stays will make travel easier for entrepreneurs, make it easier to invest, boost tourism and strengthen economic links between businesses. Moreover, Micronesia emphasizes human rights that are guaranteed by the country's constitution.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Visa Facilitation Agreement aims to provide visa-free travel for citizens of the Parties to the Agreement (EU and those countries) for a period not exceeding 90 days in each 180-day period. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for these five countries and increase the EU's clout, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal, as the population of these countries is small. The UK and Ireland do not participate in these agreements. I hereby supported the agreement

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on visa waiver in the territories of the EU and the Federated States of Micronesia. This exemption applies to all travellers from both zones, for a period of 90 days, regardless of the reason. However, it excludes persons wishing to engage in a paid activity. This agreement opens a new step in our rapprochement. This remains crucial at a time when Europe is negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with the Federated States of Micronesia.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The signed Agreement, which entered into force provisionally on 19 September 2016, establishes a visa-free movement regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Federated States of Micronesia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Although trade relations between the Union and the Federated States of Micronesia are currently very limited, they have potential development. This Agreement strengthens relations within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, to which the Federated States of Micronesia acceded in 2000, increasing political dialogue and strengthening economic and cultural relations. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution of 1 December 2016 on the draft Council decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. Having followed the work on this matter in the competent Commission, I have come to the conclusion that this short-stay visa exemption is fully justified.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The agreement with Micronesia on visa facilitation is a welcome and necessary step. This agreement facilitates travel for both EU citizens and the people of Micronesia. The question is indeed not controversial, since until now the visa-free regime between the EU and Micronesia has been conducted without any major disruption, which may put forward arguments against the extension and extension of this agreement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This proposal for a recommendation aims to grant visa-free visa-free for citizens of the European Union (EU) and reciprocally for Micronesia citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in each 180-day period. The Federated States of Micronesia constitute a democratic republic committed to respect for human rights already enshrined in its Constitution. The political dialogue between the parties has focused on climate change, the defence of human rights and gender equality issues. This agreement will strengthen political and diplomatic relations between the two parties, while also developing limited trade relations and the strengthening of economic and cultural relations. Since Micronesia's economy is essentially based on the services sector (74% of its GDP), and the tourism sector has experienced a strong expansion in recent years, this agreement will enable travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investments and boosting local tourism. Like other visa-free reports adopted today with third countries, I voted in favour of this too.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this agreement which will allow citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia to travel without a visa to the European Union, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted by the European Parliament today lays down new visa-free provisions for Union citizens and citizens of the federal states of Micronesia travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. Visa exemption covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay. This agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument to strengthen economic, tourist and cultural relations and, Finally, it will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, as the signing of the short stay waivers steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the EU's cooperation with the Pacific countries. This Agreement, which is the subject of a resolution, allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Federative States of Micronesia to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This also represents significant progress in a more regular and strengthened political dialogue aimed at protecting the vulnerable environment, particularly in relation to climate change on the one hand and the protection of human rights. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Federated States of Micronesia. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A legal framework was created in 2000 in the form of the Cotonou Agreement for cooperation between EU Member States and countries in Africa, the Caribbean and Pacific. The Federated States of Micronesia participate in cooperation with the EU in the field of strengthening cultural and economic relations as well as in conducting a dialogue on the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The abolition of the visa requirement would, in my opinion, have a positive effect on the development of the EU-Micronesian Federative States partnership. I stress that visa-free travel will only cover stays of 90 days for a period of 180 days and passengers with a reason other than the pursuit of an economic activity. Also important is the factor of high confidence in visa applicants, as well as the low level of visa refusal, or the fact that in 2014 and 2015 no citizen of Federative States of Micronesia was arrested for illegally staying in the EU. For these reasons, I supported the agreement and I believe it will contribute to a greater cultural and economic exchange between the EU and Micronesia.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, or the so-called Cotonu Agreement governs relations between the EU and Micronesia, while the Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stay further deepens these relations and further strengthens ties between the parties to the agreement. According to the Agreement, Micronesia is one of the countries whose nationals are exempted from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. All citizens of Micronesia may travel without visas to the territory of a Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days during a 180-day period, unless they perform paid work. The economy of Micronesia is primarily based on services related to tourism. The agreement, however, is expected to further strengthen tourism and boost trade, according to the rapporteur. In addition, the conditions for business trips should be simplified and economic links between undertakings are strengthened. Since the Recommendation underlines that development cooperation may also be an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue in the field of human rights and fundamental freedoms, I supported it in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. — As citizens of Federative States of Micronesia pose no serious threat to the objectives of migration policy, security and internal order of the EU, it seems appropriate to conclude a short-stay visa waiver agreement with that country. The conditions for visa-free travel set out in this document are regulated in the same way as in other agreements of the same type that the EU has concluded with other countries. This agreement should be a successful completion of one of the stages of deepening relations between the EU and the Federative States of Micronesia and allow both parties to continue their further deepening.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a tangible result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia — which is politically very important under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional tool for strengthening economic economic development. and cultural relations and to strengthen political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is nothing against this visa exemption. However, I reject the EU's responsibility for visa issues.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — This Short-Stay Visa Agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia and has great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement. The Agreement signed allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Federal States of Micronesia to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. Visas are revoked for all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official or special passports) who do not travel for the purpose of carrying out paid activities. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic ties between businesses. I accept this Agreement because it has great political significance, and it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, citizens of the Federal States of Micronesia have not submitted any asylum applications and do not pose any threat in terms of irregular migration or migration flows either in terms of security and public order.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federative States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed agreement between the European Union and the Federative States of Micronesia will allow citizens of both signatories to make up to 90 days of visa-free travel, but without the possibility of performing paid work. Despite the fact that trade relations between the EU and Micronesia countries already exist, only these have great potential and much room for progress. With the agreement, we will certainly move closer to progress in relations between the two signatories.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-Micronesia short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to the signing of an agreement with Micronesia on behalf of the European Union on the reciprocal granting of short-stay visa waiver for all categories of passports. In considering the proposal, I have taken into account that this step is in line with the intentions and objectives of the Cotonou Convention regulating the relationship between the EU and ACP countries, could promote the development of modest but promising economic and trade relations, tourism and thus contribute to the achievement of the Union's development policy objectives in the region. I took into account that Micronesia is a democratic state and its population fully assures human rights, and I also appreciated the important contribution that the EP has made through the ACP-EU parliamentary delegation to the creation of the visa waiver agreement process.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — On the basis of the EU-ACP Partnership Agreement signed in 2000 in Cotonou, the European Union has, in recent years, set out to step up relations with the countries in these regions. One very concrete way of this is to conduct negotiations on the abolition of short-stay visas for nationals of these countries. The Federated States of Micronesia are one of the countries with which the EU wants to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various topics. Micronesia currently has a democratic political system that respects human rights and gender equality, and the relationship with the EU generally involves cooperation in the area of combating climate change and protecting the natural environment. As the visa refusal rate for nationals of this small Pacific State is very low, there is the potential for the EU to abolish short-stay visas for Micronesian citizens. This will be beneficial for the intensification of economic relations between the two sides, in particular for the development of the tourism sector. The European Parliament is the institution that can decide in favour of strengthening this type of relationship. I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: relations between the European Union and that State shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. With regard to the implementation and monitoring of the Agreement, Parliament invited the European Commission to observe possible developments with regard to the criteria that initially led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria include not only illegal immigration, public order and security, but also the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the Agreement between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia and has great political significance. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. This allows visa-free travel for EU and Federal States of Micronesia when travelling to another contracted party's location for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — This Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Federal States of Micronesia to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180 day period for all categories of persons who do not travel for the purpose of carrying out paid activities. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic ties between businesses and intensify political dialogues on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. According to available data, no cases of arrest of nationals of the Federal States of Micronesia were recorded during 2014 and 2015 for illegally staying in the European Union and there was no ban on entry at external borders or decisions to return citizens of Micronesia. Accordingly, it is evident that the State does not pose a threat in respect of irregular migration, security and public order. Since the visa exemption is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together, I supported this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federative States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the European Union and the Federative States of Micronesia are governed by the Cotonou Agreement. A bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and the Federative States of Micronesia in 2016, allowing visa-free travel to the territory of the other Party for up to 90 days in any 180-day period period. The European Union is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Federal States of Micronesia, so that the agreement could facilitate negotiations. The agreement will bring the strengthening of economic and cultural relations. There will be more business trips, investment will be accelerated, economic links will be strengthened, tourism and trade development will be enabled.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09780/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia (09779/2015), I am voting in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive. I am concerned, however, that the country appears to be identified in various reports as a tax haven. A special monitoring of the Agreement should therefore be established to prevent short-term visa exemption from making it easy to engage in money laundering and tax evasion practices.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a succinct justification stating that it constitutes a culmination in the deepening of bilateral relations with strong political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with that country including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and freedoms fundamental”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. I vote against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The visa facilitation agreement is designed to ensure that Micronesian citizens have visa-free travel from the EU for a period of up to 90 days over a 180-day period. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for the country and increase cooperation with the EU, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal due to the small number of Micronesia's population, which is why I supported the proposed agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part (Cotonou Agreement). I supported the present proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09780/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia (09779/2015), I am voting in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive. I am concerned, however, that the country appears to be identified in various reports as a tax haven. A special monitoring of the Agreement should therefore be established to prevent short-term visa exemption from making it easy to engage in money laundering and tax evasion practices.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is a concrete result of efforts to strengthen relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia, of great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural ties and promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the EU and the Federated States of Micronesia are governed by the partnership agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States of the one part and the European Union and its Member States of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. This provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.
