The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. This agreement represents a concrete outcome on the deepening relations between the EU and the Federated States of Micronesia that is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Agreement facilitates the short-stay visa waiver between the two parties. We are talking about an agreement negotiated by the European Commission and which was approved by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. That is why we support this agreement which will allow citizens of the Federated States of Micronesia to travel without a visa to the European Union, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU-Micronesia agreement on short-stay visa waiver because, firstly, I believe there is no need for this and, secondly, I believe that visa policy should remain with the Member States.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the Council's decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia on short-stay visa waiver. In this case, the European Parliament should have given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Visa waiver refers to short-term (maximum 90 day stays), covering all categories of persons for all purposes except for the pursuit of a paid activity. These agreements are the result of intense political dialogue and deepening of political relations with countries outside the European Union and, before such an agreement is concluded, it is always carefully considered whether the country respects human rights, has a democratic regime and how many visa applications and for what reasons has been rejected in the case of citizens of the country concerned. Since, in the case of Federative States, confidence in visa applicants is high, the percentage of their refusal is low and democratic states with legally enshrined human rights protection, I had no reservations about the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the agreement to abolish the obligation to possess a short-stay visa of no more than 90 days within a 180 day period of first entry between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia. Increasing mobility from and towards the European Union must be one of the top priorities of European policy at international level. This exemption is a prerequisite for the development of future relations between the European Union and the Federal States of Micronesia. The abolition of short-stay visas has a positive effect for the economy and citizens. Increasing economic activity but also gaining new experiences through travel are major effects for both sides of the agreement. All countries applying and developing the Schengen acquis, not Member States of the European Union, should also conclude agreements with Micronesia in order to harmonize their visa regime with the European Union system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of approving the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Federative States of Micronesia on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Federative States of Micronesia to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of normal, diplomatic, official/official or special passport) who travel for any purpose other than performing paid work. I believe that visa liberalisation will simplify the conditions for business trips, investment will be accelerated and economic links between companies will be strengthened.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report establishes a visa waiver for Union citizens and citizens of Tuvalu who travel to the other territory for a maximum period of 90 days within a period of 90 days a 180-day period band. This exemption applies to all categories of persons making trips other than those made to carry out a paid activity. I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report calls for the approval by the European Parliament of an agreement providing for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and nationals of Tuvalu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a justification stating that the agreement is a culmination between the EU and Tuvalu - with strong political significance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues ( human rights, fundamental freedoms, etc.). The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. I therefore opposed this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this is consistent with the principles of my mandate as an MEP who was elected to support the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union. Such decisions on visas, visa waivers, and entry of nationals of third countries into UK territory, should properly be a matter for the British Government to determine.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the agreement between the Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Tuvalu, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Tuvalu nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. Such a visa exemption would pose security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. Is it appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration? I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I approved this agreement, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Tuvalu nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Gabriel report on the EU-Tuvalu agreement on short-stay visa waiver. The text lays down an exemption for Union citizens and citizens of Tuvalu who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons regardless of the reason for staying provided that this is not related to the performance of a paid activity. The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the EU and Tuvalu; it is of great political significance within the Agreement of Cotonou and represents an additional tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations by intensifying political dialogue on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09764/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu (09760/2015), I am voting in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. The European Commission is requested to observe the evolution of the criteria that led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria cover not only clandestine immigration, public order and security but also the Union's external relations with Tuvalu, including human rights and fundamental freedoms issues.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Tuvalu nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. At a time when Europe is hit by terrorist attacks and massive illegal immigration, these exemptions do not appear on the agenda, as malignant people may one day use them. I am therefore firmly opposed to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU citizens and Tuvalu travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The measure does not raise any problems of any kind and that is why I voted for it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu. This Agreement was already being applied provisionally since 1 July 2016 when it was signed by the European Commission and the competent authority of Tuvalu. The Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the Union and Tuvalu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days, for all persons for any reason, except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The Agreement represents a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Tuvalu within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. It is an agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations, as well as other matters such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition, with its approval, positive effects such as investment facilitation and tourism can be achieved.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on behalf of the European Union on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Tuvalu, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - For the same reasons as before, I agree to the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and Tuvu. It is an act of great political importance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and Tuvalu and is also a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, such a visa waiver agreement will bring positive effects, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitates investment and promotes tourism.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Agreement, which provides for visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Tuvalua when travelling to the territory of another Contracting Party for a period of no more than 90 days over a 180-day period. A joint statement of interpretation is attached to the contract.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with countries third parties. A way of reporting that has often produced positive results for citizens of both parties and increased the range of influence of the European Union's soft power. The Republic of Tuvalu is a country that has reached a democratic form of a modern type, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural shortcomings, its own internal social problems, the difficult relationship with some countries in the Pacific area. Of particular importance for this territory is climate warming which, with the rise of the seas, threatens the very existence of the island state. Overall, Europe can look to the Republic of Tuvalu as a friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop in appropriate conditions, gradually, and to fit in progressively in the area of free trade and common cooperation, in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Cotonou Convention, the main purpose of which, expressed in Article 1, is the reduction and finally the elimination of poverty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Tuvalu nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. According to the rapporteur, this type of agreement constitutes a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations as well as intensifying dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. On the other hand, we consider it absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement at a time when our Western societies are threatened by Islamic fundamentalism, which uses legal immigration channels to penetrate our territories and plan terrorist attacks. Besides, this visa waiver will strengthen criminal networks as well as illegal trafficking of all kinds. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Cotonou Agreement marks the partnership relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the relations between Tuvalu and the European Union are also regulated. The EU-Tuvalu agreement on short-stay visa waiver provides for the abolition of the visa requirement for the benefit of Union citizens and Tuvalu nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum stay of 90 days in the course of any period of 180 days. This visa waiver benefits all categories of persons, thus encouraging tourism and investment. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe it is a powerful instrument for strengthening economic, cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue between the European Union and Tuvalu.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. As it stands, the EU is negotiating an economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including Tuvalu. Visa exemption will be useful in order to further strengthen the common work and to carry out an in-depth political dialogue. The recommendation sets out the main topics on which political dialogue should focus: environmental protection, human rights and gender equality.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will see citizens from Tuvalu being able to travel visa-free in certain EU countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period. This visa waiver applies for all persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity. As Ireland is not a member of the Schengen area, this does not apply to it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this Agreement. Tuvalu’s economy is primarily based on services (more than 60% of GDP). Tourism is relatively limited. It remains dependent on international development assistance, and there are still major economic disparities between the islands in the archipelago. The EU is currently negotiating Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreements with 14 Pacific countries, including Tuvalu. The agreement also constitutes a positive sign of support for the country, allowing us to pursue a balanced, regular and in-depth political dialogue on these issues, which remain priorities for the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement in question establishes a visa waiver for EU citizens and citizens of Tuvalu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This exemption covers all categories of persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for exercising a paid activity. My vote was in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu is of strong political significance in the Cotonou Agreement and represents the concrete outcome the deepening of relations between the two parties. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the agreement is an effective instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the island nation. Tuvalu is one of the poorest countries in the Pacific region and is heavily dependent on international aid. I believe that the visa waiver agreement will give new momentum to the island's economy: simplifying travel conditions will bring positive results by facilitating investment and boosting tourism and trade.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. As this agreement will contribute to the further development of relations between the two parties, I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Not noting obvious criticalities, I expressed my opinion in favour of this report granting the provisional tourist visa between the EU countries and Tuvalu.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement, signed in Brussels on 1 July 2016 by the Commission with Tuvalu, will allow visa-free travel for nationals of the two Contracting Parties in the territories of the counterparty for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180. The exemption covers all categories of persons regardless of their grounds of stay, except those whose stay is aimed at carrying out a paid activity. Tuvalu is a Polynesian island nation, whose economy is based on services (60% of GDP), especially Internet ones, whose sale of licenses for the use of the .tv domain represents an important source of revenue for the country. Therefore, I welcome the signing of the agreement and endorse the regulatory achievement carried out by Parliament. In Tuvalu there is an entrenched dependence on international development aid due to the existence of major economic disparities, in fact it is one of the poorest countries in the Pacific region, as well as one of the most exposed to climate change and its consequences. In light of this, the correlation of two elements of such weight are the subject of common work and special attention.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is pursuing a visa policy, particularly with regard to the waiver of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens no longer need a visa. It is up to the European Parliament to give its approval to the agreement on its establishment, which is thus given. For all this and because this agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with Tuvalu, I am voting in favour of its conclusion.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu as its main purpose is to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas thus facilitating procedures entry into the country.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree we should step up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. As the rapporteur puts it, this visa waiver agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism – something which will furthermore encourage direct contacts between European citizens and Tuvaluans. The visa waiver agreement will enable citizens not only to derive full and tangible benefit from the ACP-EU partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and Tuvalu and is of political significance in the scope of the Cotonou Agreement, as an additional tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on several issues, including human rights and freedoms fundamentals. I believe that this agreement can enable the European institutions to carry out a balanced, regular and thorough political dialogue on issues which continue to be prioritised for the Union.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the initiative for the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu. I believe that this is an expression of strengthening the relationship between the European Union and Tuvalu governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and the European Union and its Member States. The commitment on the abolition of short-term visas is an important achievement in the process of deepening relations between the European Union and Tuvalu. It is of high political importance under the Cotonou Agreement and is also a complementary measure to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on a variety of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The signing of the short-stay waiver agreement is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and the states concerned. The agreement would allow citizens of Tuvalu 90-day short-stay waiver visa exemptions for both business and leisure travel.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Tuvalu will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver which allows visa-free travel for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. In addition to strengthening political dialogue and economic relations, this measure will have a direct positive impact on the economic costs of travelling travellers who are nationals of contracting countries.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. These agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and citizens of Kiribati, Micronesia, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. In a worrying security environment, any proposal for visa relief or exemptions seems to us inappropriate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported this proposal to withdraw the visa regime with Tuvalu because I believe that our relations have the potential to deepen and this agreement would be an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties and deepening political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The signed agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Tuvalu citizens when they travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for up to 90 days within any 180 day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official/official and special passport) travelling for any purpose except for the purpose of pursuing a lucrative activity. Relations between the European Union and Tuvalu are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, called the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-Tuvalu short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe that visa-free travel for citizens of the Contracting Parties this Agreement could be a useful instrument in order to intensify the influence of European Union in the countries concerned, with particular reference to human rights, and may constitute a stimulus to their economic growth.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement in question between the European Union and Tuvalu represents another important step in deepening diplomatic relations. Approval of the agreement concerned will allow citizens of the Union and citizens of Tuvalu to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote in favour of the exemption of the tourist visa for periods of up to 90 days.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — The EU-Tuvalu short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights, on that is why I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tuvalu when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The signing of the short—stay waiver agreement is significant for the EU and the states in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and the states. The visa waiver agreement may act to boost economic investment in the area, and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in some areas.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation providing for a visa-free movement regime for Union citizens and Tuvalu nationals for a maximum period of 90 days. This is an important Agreement with reference to its political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a further step towards deepening economic and cultural relations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and Tuvalu. I am in support of deepening the relations between the European Union and Tuvalu, as this constitutes an important step to further develop economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09764/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu (09760/2015), I am voting in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the signing of the short stay waiver agreement is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tuvalu’s economy is primarily based on services (more than 60% of GDP), including internet services, with the sale of licences to use the .tv domain name constituting a major source of government revenue. Agriculture and fishing account for more than 20% of GDP. Tourism is relatively limited. Tuvalu also remains dependent on international development assistance, and there are still major economic disparities between the islands in the archipelago. I believe that that this agreement would help deepen the relationship between the EU and Tuvalu and so I have voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — If we take the special case of the State of Tuvalu, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for short-stay visas, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this Polynesian archipelago of 12,000 inhabitants in the Pacific Ocean. Migration and security risks are non-existent. However, I believe that the visa waiver should not be an automatism but the result of an in-depth assessment of the political, institutional and geostrategic situation of the country concerned and the possible impact that a waiver of the visa requirement may have on European territory. This review should not only be based on the progress made in the years prior to this assessment, but also take into account the potential air intake risks that a visa-waiver may create in the medium term, as we have seen with some countries in the Western Balkans. I therefore reiterate my support for the rapid adoption of the suspension mechanism, which reminds us that visa exemption is not an “unlimited pass” but a conditioned facility that meets certain requirements.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalua on the short-stay visa waiver (09764/2016 — C8-0268/2016 — 2016/0100 (NLE)) giving consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Relations between the European Union and Tuvalu are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific countries, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other hand, and enables the citizens of the European Union and the citizens of Tuvalu visa-free stay in the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum of 90 days in any period of 180 days. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. Since Tuvalu is one of the poorest states of the Pacific region and is among the most exposed to the impacts of climate change, the relationship between climate change and human rights is the subject of special joint work and examination. The agreement is also a positive sign of support for Tuvalu and enables a balanced, regular and thorough political dialogue on those issues that remain priority for the EU.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report on visa waiver for citizens of Tuvalu poses protean security risks. As such, it would be very imprudent for the European Union to sign an agreement that would only add its weight to the already heavily loaded balance of the migration crisis in our territories. So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think that simplifying travel for businesspeople to Tuvalu can facilitate investment and boost tourism in general. That is why I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver between EU and Tuvalu. I hope that it will have positive effects on Tuvalu’s economy and will furthermore encourage direct contacts between European citizens and Tuvaluans.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conclusion of an agreement with Tuvalu to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the proposal because I do not see the need for the introduction of visa-free short stays by citizens of Tuvalu, especially since the competence for this should also lie with the Member States themselves.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it is not appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the European Union has lost all control over immigration.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which allows the exemption of short-term visas, that is, for stays in the European Union of up to 90 days over a 180 day period, for nationals of Tuvalu, a micro-state Pacific archipelago.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on conclusion of the visa facilitation agreement between the EU and Tuvalu.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The report notes that the Visa Revocation Agreement will have a positive effect, as it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment and development of tourism. In addition, it will encourage direct contacts between European citizens and Tuvalu citizens. The visa waiver agreement is evidence of European engagement in this region, in order to establish an even tighter partnership. This is a positive sign of support for Tuvalu that will enable political dialogue on many issues, so I supported this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Tuvalu Agreement allows citizens of Contracting Countries to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. Tuvalu is dependent on international development aid, one of the poorest countries in the Pacific region, the conclusion of the agreement will encourage economic and political dialogue. Tuvalu is a democratic parliamentary country that does not pose a danger to the Union from the point of view of migration, security or public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The agreement provides for the introduction of a visa-free travel regime for Tuvalu citizens. They will now be able to travel to the territory of the Member States of the European Union without applying for a visa. This proposal concerns short stays that do not exceed 90 days. Citizens of the Member States will enjoy the same privilege when travelling to Tuvalu. The visa liberalisation envisaged by the European Commission is dangerous and carries security risks. Lack of control can increase the level of organized crime, money-laundering and drug trafficking. On the other hand, it can encourage massive immigration.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a favourable vote for the EU-Tuvalu Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. In a social and cultural context, the visa waiver will serve to encourage direct contact between European and Tuvaluan citizens, paving the way for an increase of European tourism in the country and vice versa. In the context of the environment, further cooperation and dialogue between the country and the bloc means addressing the issues of environmental protection and climate change on one hand, and the protection of human rights and gender equality on the other one.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Tuvalu state is a stable parliamentary and democratic system belonging to the Commonwealth of Nations. This Agreement establishes a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Tuvalu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Visa Waiver applies to all categories of persons traveling to the country for any purpose, except for persons going to work in paid employment. The Visa Waiver Agreement will have a positive impact by simplifying travel opportunities for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and tourism. It will also help to encourage direct contacts between the EU and the citizens of Tuvalu.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The visa waiver for Tuvalu citizens presents potential security risks (organized crime, money-laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to conclude visa-waiver agreements at a time when the EU has lost all control over immigration. I therefore objected to this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Relations between the European Union and Tuvalu are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, known as the 'Cotonou Agreement'. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Tuvalu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this short-stay visa waiver agreement, which is important for the tourism industry for both partners and for opening up new markets for business in the EU and in Tuvalu.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu. This agreement will certainly increase our links with this archipelago within the framework of the ACP-EU partnership. In particular, this partnership should further strengthen political dialogue on human rights and climate change issues. Finally, I would like to underline the commitment of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas that simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Tuvalu - which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 was amended on 20 May 2014 by Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which included Tuvalu as a third country whose citizens are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently opened negotiations with a mandate of the Council to conclude a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the state of Tuvalu. The Council adopted a draft decision ratifying the agreement signed in Brussels on 1 July 2016, which should, however, obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament should agree with the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of third countries concerned who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. Unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, Tuvalu has been transferred to Annex II, which contains the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing the external borders of the Member States. Members. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 as amended applies to all Member States with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. Following the adoption of that Regulation, on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the EU and Tuvalu. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption regime for EU citizens and citizens of Tuvalu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Therefore, I am in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: The proposed visa waiver poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to vote on this kind of agreement, even though we see every day that the EU is unable to control migration flows. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides for reciprocal and short-term stays a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tuvalu nationals. This agreement will strengthen the economic and cultural ties that unite this country with our continent.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union has already concluded visa waiver agreements with a number of countries. Their positive impact is mainly in deepening economic and cultural relations, but they also play an important role in boosting investment and tourism. The visa waiver is valid for travel lasting up to 90 days in any 180-day period. During the December miniplenary, we approved the conclusion of agreements with five new countries, including Tuvalu.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement was signed in June 2000 by EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and was concluded for a 20-year period, until 2020, making it the most comprehensive partnership agreement between developing countries and the EU. I have voted for this report on the waiver of short-stay visas for citizens of the EU and Tuvalu when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue on a wide range of issues like fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Commission and the European Union, respectively, show inconsistency on visa policy. My fellow citizens are victims of this because some countries like Canada and the United States still discriminate against us when it comes to their visa-free policies. I refrained from giving my support to the EU-Tuvalu agreement on the short-stay visa waiver because I do not endorse the way in which the European Commission conducts the EU visa policy and that it ignores the judgments of the Court of Justice on certain issues which oblige it to do this. An example is the decision in Case C-88/14 of 16.7.2015, according to which the European Commission is obliged to propose the introduction of visas for countries that do not apply full visa reciprocity with all EU countries. The European Commission has not done so and has not proposed visas for US and Canadian citizens who continue to discriminate against my fellow citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report because I do not see any need for short-stay visa exemption. Furthermore, the competences should lie with the Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The agreement is an additional tool for intensifying economic and cultural relations and for more intense political dialogue on a range of topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement contributes decisively to the deepening of relations between the European Union and the State of Tuvalu and constitutes a complementary instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political relations. dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will have a positive impact because it simplifies travel procedures for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and tourism. In addition, it will encourage direct contacts between European citizens and Tuvalu citizens. The visa waiver is a non-negligible instrument for the mutual rapprochement of the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to take full and tangible advantage of the ACP-EU Partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at reduced financial and practical costs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I believe that the conclusion of the short-stay visa waiver agreement is a big step forward for those who wish to see inhabitants of Tuvalu, as they depend on international development aid. In fact Tuvalu benefits from just 2000 tourists a year who largely come from Pacific nations. This agreement aims, on the one hand, to protect the environment and climate change, on the other hand, the defence of human rights and gender equality. As a politician I think support towards this country is necessary because it is one of the poorest of Pacific nations and one of the most exposed to the effects of climate change. Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement because it takes into account the situation of Member States which do not apply the Schengen acquis in full. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tuvalu when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.  The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — This Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and Tuvalu, which is of great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, which further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among other things, about human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will have a positive effect because it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment and development of tourism. Tuvalua's economy is primarily based on services (more than 60% of GDP), including internet-connected services, among which is the sale of licenses to use the domain name.tv, which is an important source of income for the country. In the agriculture and fisheries sector, more than 20% of GDP is realized. The issuance of fishing permits is an important source of income for the state. Tourism is relatively limited, with fewer than 2000 tourists a year mostly coming from other Pacific states. Tuvalu also continues to depend on international development assistance, and there are still significant differences in economic development among the islands. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including Tuvalu. The visa waiver agreement is further evidence of our engagement with respect to that region to establish a tighter partnership.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The short-stay visa waiver agreement is of great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and Tuvalu. Pacific democracy is fully committed to protecting human rights and we have good communication when it comes to protecting their sensitive environment, especially in relation to climate change, but in the trade field, the EU's relations with Tuvalu remain very limited and the potential for their development needs exploit. The agreement will thus have a positive economic impact because it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and development of the tourism sector. This strengthening of economic and cultural relations will further intensify political dialogue on issues prioritised for the Union. As regards mobility, Tuvalu poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. The agreement is further evidence of our engagement in the region in order to achieve a better partnership and is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. Citizens of both regions will be able to benefit the full and concrete benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. I want to emphasize the necessity of complete reciprocity in visa waiver and thus equal treatment of all citizens.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: This agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tuvalu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement between the EU and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver for European Union citizens and citizens of Tuvalu. The objective of this Agreement is to stay in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days during any period of 180 days. I see this agreement as a further step in the deepening of relations between the EU and Tuvalu, which follows the Cotonou Agreement, in which the EU, as part of the Sustainable Development Strategy, committed to reducing; and later the eradication of poverty and the gradual deepening of cooperation and integration of African, Caribbean and Pacific states into the world economy. I believe that this agreement can also have a positive effect on the development of tourism and services, and therefore also on the overall economic development of this island state, which is still among the poorest countries of the Pacific region.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Visa Facilitation Agreement aims to provide visa-free travel for citizens of the Parties to the Agreement (EU and those countries) for a period not exceeding 90 days in each 180-day period. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for these five countries and increase the EU's clout, especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal, as the population of these countries is small. The UK and Ireland do not participate in these agreements. I hereby supported the agreement.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on visa waiver in the territories of the EU and Tuvalu. This exemption applies to all travellers from both zones, for a period of 90 days, regardless of the reason. However, it excludes persons wishing to engage in a paid activity. This agreement will facilitate the development of tourism, which is crucial for Tuvalu, which remains one of the poorest countries in the Pacific.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu. This Agreement was already being applied, on a provisional basis, since 1 July 2016 when it was signed by the European Commission and the competent authority of Tuvalu. The Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the Union and Tuvalu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days, for all persons for any reason, except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The Agreement represents a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Tuvalu within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. It is an Agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations, as well as other matters such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition, with its approval, positive effects such as investment facilitation and tourism can be achieved.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 1 December 2016 on the draft Council decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. Having followed the work on this matter in the committee responsible, I have come to the conclusion that this short-stay visa exemption is fully justified.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The agreement with Tuvalu on visa facilitation is a welcome and necessary step. This agreement facilitates travel both for EU citizens and for the residents of Tuvalu. The question is indeed not controversial, since until now the visa-free regime between the EU and Tuvalu has been conducted without any major disruption, capable of putting forward arguments against the extension and extension of this agreement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This recommendation seeks visa-free for citizens of the European Union and reciprocally for citizens of Tuvalu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in each 180-day period. This is an agreement of high political importance in relations between ACP-EU countries, which mirrors the strengthening of the economic and cultural relations permitted by this partnership. Tuvalu has a democratic and stable regime and is part of the Commonwealth. An intensification of political dialogue on issues such as the preservation of the environment, human rights and the promotion of gender equality is now awaited. Tuvalu's economy depends primarily on the services sector, particularly related to online services, the agriculture and fisheries sector. With this island a very limited tourism sector, this agreement will make it possible not only to travel for entrepreneurs as well as tourists, facilitating investments and boosting the tourism sector. As I agree with the position put forward by the honourable Member on the importance of visa waiver as an element of bringing the peoples of Europe and the Pacific closer together, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. That is why we support this agreement which will allow the citizens of Tuvalu to travel without a visa to the European Union, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted by the European Parliament today lays down new visa-free provisions for Union citizens and citizens of Tuvalu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. Visa exemption covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay. This agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument to strengthen economic, tourist and cultural relations and, Finally, it will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, as the signing of the short-stay waivers is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the EU's cooperation with the Pacific countries. This Agreement, which is the subject of a resolution, allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tuvalu to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This will strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues such as environmental protection and climate change and human rights and fundamental freedoms. This is one of the poorest countries in the Pacific region and one of the countries most exposed to climate change. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with the 14 countries of the Pacific region to which Tuvalu belongs. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — A legal framework for cooperation with the EU and Tuvalu has been established by the Cotonou Agreement, which deals with deepening cooperation between the EU and countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. Tuvalu, as a Commonwealth state, has a stable political regime, but its economy depends on international development aid because it is built on fishing and providing services. The EU is conducting a dialogue with Tuvalu on the subject of environmental protection during the change in climate conditions as well as the impact of climate change on human rights. I consider the EU's decision to abolish the visa requirement as a positive step in the development of EU-Tuvalu relations, which is why I supported it. Visa-free travel will only cover stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days and persons travelling with a reason other than the pursuit of an economic activity. Also important is the factor of high confidence in visa applicants, as well as the low level of visa refusal, or the fact that no Tuvalu citizen was arrested for illegally staying in the EU in 2014 and 2015.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, or the so-called Cotonu Agreement governs relations between the EU and Tuvu, while the Short-Term Visa Elimination Agreement staying this relationship further deepens and further clumps economic and cultural links and deepens political dialogue in particular in the areas of human rights and fundamental freedoms. According to the agreement, Tuvalu is one of the countries whose nationals are exempted from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. All citizens of Tuvalj may travel without visas to the territory of a Contracting Party for a maximum of 92 days during a 180-day period, unless they carry out paid work. While Tuvalu is one of the poorest countries in the Pacific region and among the most exposed effects of climate change, and there are significant economic differences between its islands. It therefore depends considerably on international development cooperation, which can be further deepened and strengthened by this Agreement. Parliament's recommendation welcomes this agreement and I have also supported it myself in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. — As the citizens of Tuvalu pose no serious threat to the objectives of the EU's migration policy, security and internal order, it seems appropriate to conclude a short-stay visa waiver agreement with the country. The conditions for visa-free travel set out in this document are regulated in the same way as in other agreements of the same type that the EU has concluded with other countries. This agreement should be a successful completion of one of the stages of deepening EU-Tuvalu relations and allow both sides to continue their further deepening.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Tuvalu, which is politically very important under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and strengthening economic and cultural relations. political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is nothing against this visa exemption. However, I reject the EU's responsibility for visa issues.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — A bilateral agreement between the EU and Tuvala was signed in Brussels on 1 July 2016. The Agreement has been provisionally applied as it awaits approval by the European Parliament. The Agreement signed allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tuvalua to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any period of 180 days. Visas are revoked for all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official or special passports) who do not travel for the purpose of carrying out paid activities. As regards mobility, available data show that the rate of visa applications refused to be granted to citizens of Tuvalua and other island Pacific countries is very low. I accept this Agreement because it has great political significance, and it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu will allow citizens of both signatories to travel without visas, but without the possibility of performing paid work. The visa waiver agreement will further strengthen relations between the EU and Tuvalu and improve negotiating positions in the negotiations on a global economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including Tuvall.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-Tuvalu short-stay visa waiver agreement is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to the signing of an agreement with the State of Tuvalu on behalf of the European Union on the reciprocal provision of visa waiver for short-stay for all categories of passports. Considering the proposal, I have taken into account that this step is in line with the intentions and objectives of the Cotonou Convention governing the relationship between the EU and ACP countries and can promote economic relations, tourism, local (mainly embodied in the sale of domain names) the development of the service industry and thus contribute to the achievement of the Union's development policy objectives in the region. I have taken into account the aspect of promoting dialogue with TUVALUM on human rights, women's rights and climate change, while also appreciating the important contribution that the EP has made through the ACP-EU parliamentary delegation to in the process of establishing an agreement.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the resolution on the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalua on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and Tuvalu and has great political significance. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The signed agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tuvalu to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The agreement between the European Union and Tuvalua for the abolition of short-term visas will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and encourage tourism development. Visa cancellation covers all categories of persons when traveling to the territory of the counterparty for a stay of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. The European Union is currently negotiating the conclusion of a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 countries of the Pacific region, including Tuvalu, and this agreement is another step in strengthening the partnership between the European Union and Tuvalu, particularly in terms of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues. In addition, according to available data, the rate of denied visa applications to citizens of Tuvalu and other Pacific countries is very low and the migration flows of that country are directed towards Australia and New Zealand. Likewise, with regard to irregular migration or migration flows and in terms of security and public order, Tuvalu is no threat to the European Union. That's why I supported this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on the short-stay visa waiver. The relations between the European Union and Tuvalu are governed by the Cotonou Agreement. Tuvaluj's economy is mainly based on services (more than 60% of GDP), including internet-connected services, where the sale of licenses to use the domain name “.tv” represents an important source of revenue for the country. Agriculture and fisheries contribute more than 20% of GDP.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09764/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu (09760/2015), I am voting in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The report is accompanied by a succinct justification stating that it constitutes a culmination in the deepening of bilateral relations with strong political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with that country including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and freedoms fundamental”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question is whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. I vote against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The visa facilitation agreement is designed to provide visa-free travel from the EU for a maximum of 90 days over a 180-day period of time for Tuvalu citizens. A visa-free system would cover all categories of people. The deal is expected to have positive economic effects for the country and increase cooperation with the EU especially in the area of human rights. The effects for the EU will most likely be minimal due to the small number of Tuvalu's population, which is why I supported the proposed agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the State of Tuvalu are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part (Cotonou Agreement). I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09764/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu (09760/2015), I am voting in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive.

Relations between the European Union and the Federated States of Micronesia are governed by the partnership agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States of the one part and the European Union and its Member States of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Agreement facilitates the short-stay visa waiver between the two parties. We are talking about an agreement negotiated by the European Commission and which was approved by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU-Tuvalu short-stay visa waiver agreement because, firstly, I believe that there is no need for this and, secondly, I believe that visa policy should remain with the Member States.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the Council's decisions on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Tuvalu on short-stay visa waiver. In this case, the European Parliament should have given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Visa waiver refers to short-term (maximum 90 day stays) and applies to all categories of persons for all purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity. These agreements are the result of intense political dialogue and deepening of political relations with countries outside the European Union and, before such an agreement is concluded, it is always carefully considered whether the country respects human rights, has a democratic regime and how many visa applications and for what reasons has been rejected in the case of citizens of the country concerned. As Tuvalu has a stable parliamentary and democratic regime as part of the Commonwealth, the rate of refusal to grant visas for Tuvalu citizens is very low and does not pose any risk in terms of illegal immigration, I have had no reservations about the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the agreement to abolish the obligation to possess a short-stay visa of no more than 90 days within a 180 day period of first entry between the European Union and Tuvalu. Increasing mobility from and towards the European Union must be one of the top priorities of European policy at international level. This exemption is a prerequisite for the development of future relations between the European Union and Tuvalu. The abolition of short-stay visas has a positive effect for the economy and citizens. Increasing economic activity but also gaining new experiences through travel are major effects for both sides of the agreement. All countries applying and developing the Schengen acquis, not Member States of the European Union, should also conclude agreements with Tuvalu in order to harmonize their visa regime with the European Union system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)

Tuvaluj's economy is mainly based on services, agriculture and fisheries contribute more than 20% of GDP, and an important source of revenue for the country is also the approval of fishing licences. The EU is currently negotiating a global economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including Tuvalu State. I believe that the visa waiver agreement will bring positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs and promoting investment and development of tourism.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report establishes a visa waiver for Union citizens and citizens of Marshall Islands who travel to the other territory for a maximum period of 90 days interior of a range of 180 days period. This exemption applies to all categories of persons making trips other than those made to carry out a paid activity. I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report calls for the approval by the European Parliament of an agreement providing for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and Marshall Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days.
