The report is accompanied by a justification stating that the agreement is a culmination between the EU and the Marshall Islands - with strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues ( human rights, fundamental freedoms, etc.). The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. I therefore opposed this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as this is consistent with the principles of my mandate as an MEP who was elected to support the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union. Such decisions on visas, visa waivers, and entry of nationals of third countries into UK territory should properly be a matter for the British Government to determine.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties; and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Marshall Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. Such a visa exemption would pose security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. Is it appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration? I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I have approved this agreement, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Marshall Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Gabriel report on the EU-Marshall Islands agreement on short-stay visa waiver. The text lays down an exemption for Union citizens and citizens of the Marshall Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons regardless of the reason for staying provided that this is not related to the performance of a paid activity. The EU's trade relations with the Republic of the Marshall Islands are very limited today but have a potential for development which can be greatly favoured by this instrument. The Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement, being defined between the Union and fourteen Pacific countries including the Marshall Islands, will help to strengthen this path by enhancing the political and economic dialogue.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09775/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands (09774/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive. I am concerned, however, that the country appears to be identified in various reports as a tax haven. A special monitoring of the Agreement should therefore be established to prevent short-term visa exemption from making it easy to engage in money laundering and tax evasion practices.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. The European Commission is requested to observe the evolution of the criteria that led to the transfer of Annex I to Annex II to Regulation No 509/2014. These criteria cover not only clandestine immigration, public order and security but also the Union's external relations with the Republic of the Marshall Islands, including human rights and fundamental freedoms issues.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Marshall Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. At a time when Europe is hit by terrorist attacks and massive illegal immigration, these exemptions do not appear on the agenda, as malignant people may one day use them. I am therefore firmly opposed to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the EU and Marshall Islands travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The measure does not raise any problems of any kind and that is why I voted for it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands are governed by the Association Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States with the Union and its Member States, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The Agreement signed provides for visa waiver for citizens of the Union and citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of 90 days every 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The Agreement signed implies a deepening of relations between the Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In addition, this agreement may have positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitating investment and tourism. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties; and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - For the same reasons as before, I agree to the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands. It is an act of great political importance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Marshall Islands and is also a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Also, such a visa waiver agreement will bring positive effects, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitates investment and promotes tourism.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Agreement, which provides for visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Marshall Islands when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of no more than 90 days in a 180-day period. A joint statement of interpretation is attached to the contract.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with countries third parties. A way of reporting that has often produced positive results for citizens of both parties and increased the range of influence of the European Union's soft power. The Republic of the Marshall Islands is a country that has reached a modern democratic form, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural shortcomings, its own internal social problems, the difficult relationship with some countries in the Pacific area. Of particular importance for this territory is climate warming which, with the rise of the seas, threatens the very existence of the island state. Overall, Europe can look to the Republic of the Marshall Islands as a friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop in appropriate conditions, gradually, and to fit in progressively in the area of free trade and common cooperation, in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Cotonou Convention, the main purpose of which, expressed in Article 1, is the reduction and finally the elimination of poverty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Marshall Islands nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. According to the rapporteur, this type of agreement constitutes a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations as well as intensifying dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. On the other hand, we consider it absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement at a time when our Western societies are threatened by Islamic fundamentalism, which uses legal immigration channels to penetrate our territories and plan terrorist attacks. Besides, this visa waiver will strengthen criminal networks as well as illegal trafficking of all kinds. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Cotonou Agreement marks the partnership relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, as well as the relations between the Republic of the Marshall Islands and the Union European. The EU-Marshall Islands agreement on short-stay visa waiver provides for the abolition of the visa requirement for the benefit of Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Marshall Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of not more than 90 days during any 180-day period. This visa waiver benefits all categories of persons, thus encouraging tourism and investment. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe it is a powerful instrument for strengthening economic, cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on short-stay visa waiver. Considering the economy of the abovementioned Republic, which is essentially based on the services, fisheries and agriculture sectors, the recommendation shows how trade relations with the EU, albeit limited, have good development potential to take into account. It therefore presents an opportunity to strengthen and intensify the partnership with the country, with the further possibility of creating a regular and constant political dialogue. In addition, the recommendation stresses the benefits and positive effects that the agreement can bring, not only in terms of cost reduction and improved travel conditions, but also to stimulate the tourism.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will see citizens from the Marshall Islands being able to travel visa-free in certain EU countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period. This visa waiver applies for all persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity. As Ireland is not a member of the Schengen area, this does not apply to it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this Agreement. This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a concrete outcome of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. The Republic of Marshall Islands has few natural resources and imports far exceed exports. The US is by far the largest contributor to the national budget under a Compact of Free Association. While EU trade relations with the Republic of Marshall Islands are very limited, they have potential for development, including through the eventual signing of a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreements in question which Parliament is called upon to approve provide visa-free travel for EU citizens and nationals of the aforementioned States who go to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in a period of 180 days. Visa waiver covers all categories of people who travel for all kinds of purposes, except to engage in paid activity. The file does not create any problems and I therefore voted for it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Marshall Islands is of strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement and represents the concrete outcome of the deepening of relations between the two parties. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the agreement is a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the Marshall Islands. Bilateral economic relations, albeit very limited at the moment, have great potential for development and I believe that simplification of travel conditions will give positive results facilitating investment and stimulating tourism.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. As this agreement will contribute to the further development of relations between the two parties, I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ No criticality for the measure under consideration granting a provisional tourist visa between the EU countries and the Marshall Islands. Upvote.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ An agreement resulting in the short-stay visa waiver was signed in Geneva between the European Commission and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on 27 July nationals of the two Contracting Parties intending to travel to the territory of the other Contractor for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180. All categories of persons shall be exempted regardless of their grounds of stay, except those whose stay is aimed at carrying out a paid activity. I cannot but vote in favour of an agreement which will not only lead to facilitations in international mobility, but which opens up a considerable opportunity for economic and cultural dialogue. The economy of the Marshall Islands is predominantly based on services, fisheries and agriculture; however there are structural problems given by a higher import value than exports. To date, the USA confirms itself as the first trading partner of the Islands as a result of a free association pact, in the future we hope to be able to contribute to each other and significantly to their respective economies. It is a reminder, within the cultural framework, how the Marshall Islands are the first of the island states of the Pacific to have a female President, Hilda Heine.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is pursuing a visa policy, particularly with regard to the waiver of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens no longer need a visa. It is up to the European Parliament to give its approval to the agreement on its establishment, which is thus given. For all this and because this agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with the Marshall Islands Republics, I am voting in favour of its conclusion.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Marshall Islands as its main purpose is to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas thus facilitating the issuance of short-stay visas, thus facilitating the issuance of short-stay the procedures of entry into the country.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Solomon Islands when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I agree that the visa waiver agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. This visa waiver agreement will have spill-over benefits on the rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The visa waiver agreement will enable citizens not only to derive full benefit from the ACP-EU partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced economical and practical cost.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents both the concrete outcome of the deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands — which is of strong political significance within the Cotonou Agreement — as a further tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including which human rights and fundamental freedoms. I believe that in this way we can give momentum to the currently limited trade relations with Europe, facilitating investment and tourism. The visa waiver agreement will allow citizens not only to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling in a more economical and practical way.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the initiative for the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. I believe that it represents a concrete achievement in the process of deepening the mutual relationship between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, which is of great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, and at the same time it is a complementary measure to enhance relations economic and cultural and intensification of political dialogue on a variety of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Having seen mutual benefits for both the EU and the Member States and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, I am in favour of agreeing to conclude such an agreement.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The signing of the short—stay waivers steps up Europe’s economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue and is further evidence of our commitment to the region, with a view to a strengthened partnership. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with the Marshall Islands will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Marshall Islands on short-stay visa waiver for up to 90 days over any 180 day period. This agreement will not only strengthen our economic and cultural relations by simplifying investment and tourism, but also our political dialogue, particularly on climate change issues.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. These agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Union and nationals of Kiribati, Solomon Islands, Micronesia, Tuvalu and the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. In a troubling security environment, any proposal for visa relief or exemption seems to us inappropriate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. The result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands is seen specifically in this agreement, and I support it. It is important to note that the agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Marshall Islands when they travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for up to 90 days within any 180 day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, official/official and special passport) travelling for any purpose except for the purpose of pursuing a lucrative activity. We already have a foundation on which our relationship operates, and that is the Cotonou Agreement. The abolition of the visa regime would contribute to more investment and stimulate the Marshall Islands to continue building their democratic system through support from us.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-N short-stay visa waiver agreement. Marshall is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe that visa-free travel for citizens of the Contracting Parties this Agreement could be a useful instrument in order to intensify the influence of European Union in the countries concerned, with particular reference to human rights, and may constitute a stimulus to their economic growth.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The agreement in question between the European Union and the Marshall Islands represents another important step in deepening diplomatic relations. The approval of the agreement concerned will allow citizens of the Union and citizens of the Marshall Islands to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote in favour of the exemption of the tourist visa for periods of up to 90 days.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — The EU-N short-stay visa waiver agreement. Marshall is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights, so I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Marshall Island when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The signing of the short—stay waivers is significant for the EU and the states in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding between the EU and those states. The visa waiver agreement may act to boost economic investment in the area, and facilitate travel for business and tourism, which may be very limited in some areas.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation providing for a visa-free movement regime for Union citizens and Marshall Islands nationals for a maximum period of 90 days. This is an important agreement with regard to its political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a further step towards deepening economic and cultural relations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the short—stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands, as this constitutes an important step to further develop economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogues on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09775/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands (09774/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive. I am concerned, however, that the country appears to be identified in various reports as a tax haven. A special monitoring of the Agreement should therefore be established to prevent short-term visa exemption from making it easy to engage in money laundering and tax evasion practices.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the signing of the short—stay waiver agrement is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Marshall Islands is a stable presidential democracy in free association with the U.S. The Union’s political dialogue with the Marshall Islands focuses on protecting its vulnerable environment, especially in relation to climate change on the one hand and on defending human rights and gender issues on the other hand. In this context, the agreement represents a significant step towards more regular and enhanced political dialogue. Therefore, I believe that this agreement would be beneficial to all parties involved.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — If we take the special case of the Marshall Islands, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the short-stay visa requirement, that is, three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small archipelago of just over 50,000 inhabitants in the Pacific Ocean. Migration and security risks are non-existent. However, I believe that the visa waiver should not be an automatism, but the result of an in-depth assessment of the political, institutional and geostrategic situation of the country concerned and of the possible impact that a waiver of the visa requirement may have on European territory. This review should not only be based on the progress made in the years prior to this assessment, but also take into account the potential airflow risks that a visa-waiver may create in the medium term, as we have seen with some countries in the Western Balkans. I therefore reiterate my support for the rapid adoption of the suspension mechanism, which reminds us that visa waiver is not an “unlimited pass”, but a conditioned facility that meets certain requirements.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. − I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver (09775/2016 — C8-0252/2016 — 2016/0103 (NLE)), granting consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the Agreement signed to the citizens of the European Union and the citizens of the European Union The Republic of Marshall Islands allows visa-free stay in the territory of the other contracting party of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Union's political dialogue with the Marshall Islands is aimed at protecting their sensitive environment, especially in relation to climate change on the one hand and protecting human rights and gender issues on the other.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: This report on visa waiver for citizens of the Marshall Islands poses a number of protean security risks. As such, it would be very imprudent for the European Union to sign an agreement that would only add its weight to the already heavily loaded balance of the migration crisis in our territories. So I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ EU trade relations with the Republic of Marshall Islands are very limited and they surely have the potential for development. The Republic of Marshall Islands has few natural resources, its economy is based primarily on the service sector as well as some fishing and agriculture and its imports far exceed exports. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Republic of Marshall Islands. I believe that the visa waiver agreement reaffirms the Union’s commitment to strengthen its partnership with this country and that is why I supported this recommendation.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conclusion of an agreement with the Republic of the Marshall Islands to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the proposal because I do not see the need for the introduction of visa-free short stays by citizens of the Marshall Islands, especially since the competence for this should also lie with the Member States themselves.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it is not appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the European Union has lost all control over immigration.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which allows short-term visa waiver, i.e. for stays in the European Union of up to 90 days over a 180 day period, for nationals of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, a micro-state Pacific archipelago.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of the visa facilitation agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — This agreement would simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and encourage tourism development. It revoke visas for all categories of persons who do not travel for the purpose of carrying out paid activities. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues. I believe that the Visa Revocation Agreement confirms the Union's efforts to strengthen partnership with this country, and I have therefore supported this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. — The conclusion of an agreement with the Marshall Islands allows citizens of Contracting States to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The country's economy stands on services, agriculture and fishing, and due to low natural resources, imports greatly exceed exports. The agreement will promote the development of the economy. The Marshall Islands are a stable presidential democracy that does not pose a danger to the Union from the point of view of migration, security or public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The agreement provides for the introduction of a visa-free travel regime for Marshall Islands citizens. They will now be able to travel to the territory of the Member States of the European Union without applying for a visa. This proposal concerns short stays that do not exceed 90 days. Citizens of Member States will enjoy the same privilege when travelling to the Marshall Islands. The visa liberalisation envisaged by the European Commission is dangerous and carries security risks. Lack of control can increase the level of organized crime, money-laundering and drug trafficking. On the other hand, it can encourage massive immigration.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU—Marshall Islands Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. Politically speaking, the country has committed to maintaining a stable presidential democracy, evidenced by the election of its first female president and the only one in the Pacific island states. The visa waiver agreement will allow future political dialogue. The country shows no signs of posing a threat to security and public order as well.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This short stay agreement is a concrete result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands, of great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural ties and promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The visa exemption for Marshall Islands citizens presents potential security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to conclude visa-waiver agreements at a time when the EU has lost all control over immigration. I therefore objected to this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Relations between the European Union and the Marshall Islands are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, known as the 'Cotonou Agreement'. The signed Agreement provides for a visa exemption scheme for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement because it boosts tourism while also providing new opportunities for the tourism industry and increasing business prospects.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. This agreement will certainly increase our ties with the Marshall Islands within the framework of the ACP-EU partnership. Strengthening the partnership should benefit cooperation between partners on key issues such as gender equality and climate change. Finally, I would like to underline the commitment of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas that simultaneously represents a concrete outcome of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 was amended on 20 May 2014 by Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which included the Republic of the Marshall Islands as a third country whose citizens are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently opened negotiations with a mandate of the Council with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. On 27 June 2016, the Council adopted a draft decision ratifying an agreement in Geneva, which should, however, obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament should agree with the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of third countries concerned who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and human rights. fundamental freedoms”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question must be asked whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost control over mass immigration. Unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Marshall Islands have been transferred to Annex II, which contains the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing borders external Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 as amended applies to all Member States with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. Following the adoption of that Regulation, on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluding a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands. The signed Agreement provides for a visa waiver regime for EU citizens and citizens of the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Therefore, I am in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: The proposed visa waiver poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.). It is not appropriate to vote on this kind of agreement, even though we see every day that the EU is unable to control migration flows. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides for reciprocal and short-term stays a visa-free travel regime for European Union citizens and Marshall Islanders. This agreement will strengthen the economic and cultural ties between these islands and our continent.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union has already concluded visa waiver agreements with a number of countries. Their positive impact is mainly in deepening economic and cultural relations, but they also play an important role in boosting investment and tourism. The visa waiver is valid for travel lasting up to 90 days in any 180-day period. During the December miniplenary, we approved the conclusion of agreements with five new countries, including the Republic of the Marshall Islands.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement was signed in June 2000 by EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and was concluded for a 20-year period, until 2020, making it the most comprehensive partnership agreement between developing countries and the EU. I have voted for this report on the waiver of short-stay visas for citizens of the EU and the Marshall Islands when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue on a wide range of issues like fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Commission and the European Union, respectively, show inconsistency on visa policy. My fellow citizens are victims of this because some countries like Canada and the United States still discriminate against us when it comes to their visa-free policies. I refrained from giving my support to the agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands on short-stay visa waivers, because I do not approve of the way the European Commission conducts EU visa policy and that it ignores the judgments of the Court of Justice on certain issues which oblige her to do so. An example is the decision in Case C-88/14 of 16.7.2015, according to which the European Commission is obliged to propose the introduction of visas for countries that do not apply full visa reciprocity with all EU countries. The European Commission has not done so and has not proposed visas for US and Canadian citizens who continue to discriminate against my fellow citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported this file as we support the relaxation of certain travel restrictions providing the state in question possesses a solid human rights record.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report because I do not see any need for short-stay visa exemption. Furthermore, the competences should lie with the Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The agreement is an additional tool for intensifying economic and cultural relations and for more intense political dialogue on a range of topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a tangible result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands and constitutes a complementary instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will have a positive impact because it simplifies travel procedures for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and stimulating tourism. The visa waiver is a non-negligible instrument for the mutual rapprochement of the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at reduced financial and practical costs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues proposal because I believe that the conclusion of the short-stay visa waiver agreement represents, for the inhabitants of the Islands Marshall, a great advantage, since it will facilitate travel conditions for both business and tourism. In addition, the inhabitants of the Marshall Islands benefit from a great deal of confidence because the rate of visa refusal for Europe is really low to the citizens, so they pose no threat to the Union European. The conclusion of this agreement also allows the people of the Marshall Islands to be brought closer to the Member States. Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement because it takes into account the situation of Member States which do not apply the Schengen acquis in full. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a concrete result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands and has considerable political weight under the Cotonou Agreement. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement could have a positive effect because it would streamline travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and encourage tourism development. The economy of Marshall Islands is primarily based on the service sector and to some extent on fisheries and agriculture. The Republic of Marshall Islands has few natural resources, and imports greatly exceed exports. The US contributes to the largest extent to the national budget of the Republic of Marshall Islands under the Free Association Treaty. Although the EU's trade relations with the Republic of the Marshall Islands are very limited, there is a possibility for their development. The EU is currently negotiating the conclusion of a comprehensive Partnership Agreement with fourteen countries of the Pacific region, including the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In this regard, this Agreement makes significant progress in establishing a more intensive and regular political dialogue and economic development of the Republic of the Marshall Islands.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The short-stay visa waiver agreement is of great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement and is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. The Pacific Presidential Democracy is fully committed to protecting human rights and has a constructive dialogue with the EU on protecting their sensitive environment, especially in relation to climate change. However, in the trade field, EU relations with the Republic of the Marshall Islands remain very limited. The agreement will therefore have a positive economic impact because it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and development of the tourism sector. This strengthening of economic and cultural relations will further intensify political dialogue on issues prioritised for the Union. As regards mobility, the Republic of the Marshall Islands does not pose any threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. The agreement is further evidence of our engagement in the region in order to achieve a better partnership and is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together. Citizens of both regions will be able to benefit the full and concrete benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. I want to emphasize the necessity of complete reciprocity in visa waiver and thus equal treatment of all citizens.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: This agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands. The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a visa waiver scheme for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Marshall Islands who may reside in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days during any period of 180 days. The Republic of the Marshall Islands is a stable presidential democracy within the framework of a loose association with the United States. I consider this island state to be a relevant and trusted partner and therefore see no reason for further postponement of visa waiver.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on visa waiver in the territories of the EU and the Marshall Islands. This exemption applies to all travellers from both zones, for a period of 90 days, regardless of the reason. However, it excludes persons wishing to engage in a paid activity. This agreement opens a new step in our rapprochement with this territory. This remains crucial at a time when Europe is negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with the Marshall Islands.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands are governed by the Association Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States with the Union and its Member States, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The Agreement signed provides for visa waiver for citizens of the Union and citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period of 90 days every 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except for the pursuit of a paid activity. The Agreement signed implies a deepening of relations between the Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In addition, this agreement may have positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitating investment and tourism. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution of 1 December 2016 on the draft Council decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. Having followed the work on this matter in the committee responsible, I have come to the conclusion that this short-stay visa exemption is fully justified.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The agreement with the Marshall Islands on visa facilitation is a welcome and necessary step. This agreement facilitates travel for both EU citizens and residents of the Marshall Islands. The question is indeed not controversial, since until now the visa-free regime between the EU and the Marshall Islands has been carried out without disturbances.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This proposal for a recommendation aims to grant visa-free visa-free for citizens of the European Union (EU) and reciprocally for citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in each 180-day period. The Marshall Islands are a stable presidential democracy. As with other ACP countries, political dialogue between these parties has focused on protecting their highly vulnerable environment, human rights and issues relating to the promotion of gender equality. This agreement will strengthen trade relations between the parties and will also represent an important step forward in the implementation of the principles established by the Cotonou Agreement. As the Marshall Islands' economy is essentially based on the services, livestock and agricultural sectors, this Agreement could result in a significant improvement not only for the development of these sectors, but also for the tourism sector, by facilitating travel conditions for tourists. As a member of the delegation of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation, as did other reports on the same subject voted today.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this agreement that will allow visa-free travel to the European Union for citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands and vice versa, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted by the European Parliament today lays down new visa-free provisions for Union citizens and citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. Visa exemption covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay. This agreement is the crowning achievement of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument to strengthen economic, tourist and cultural relations and, Finally, it will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative consent vote. UKIP does not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the movement of people.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, as the signing of the short-stay waivers is significant for the EU and the state in question as it signifies deeper cooperation and mutual understanding.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the EU's cooperation with the Pacific countries. This Agreement, which is the subject of a resolution, allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Marshall Islands to travel without visas to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This also represents significant progress in a more regular and strengthened political dialogue, economic and cultural relations and the intensification of political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, which also includes the Republic of the Marshall Islands. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the abolition of the visa requirement with the Marshall Islands for short stays. EU-Marshall Islands cooperation has also been given a legal framework in the form of the Coton Agreement of 2000. As a democracy within a free association with the US, the Marshall Islands elected its president as the first of the independent Pacific states, which I rate as a positive step in the pursuit of gender equality. The abolition of the visa requirement will unlock the potential for economic and social cooperation between the EU and the Marshall Islands. Visa-free travel will only cover stays of 90 days for a period of 180 days and persons travelling with a reason other than the pursuit of an economic activity. Important information is the high confidence factor in visa applicants, as well as the low visa refusal rate, or the fact that no Marshall Islands citizen was arrested for illegally staying in the EU in 2014 and 2015.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the so-called Cotonu Agreement governs relations between the EU and the Marshall Islands, while the Visa Elisagement Agreement for Short-term stay further deepens these relations and further clumps economic and cultural links and deepens political dialogue in particular in the areas of human rights and fundamental freedoms. According to the Agreement, the Marshall Islands are among countries whose nationals are exempted from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. All citizens of the Marshall Islands may travel without visas to the territory of a Contracting Party for a maximum of 92 days over a 180-day period, regardless of the purpose of the trip. The Parliament's recommendation notes that this Agreement confirms the commitment of the European Union to strengthen its partnership with the Marshall Islands and enables citizens to benefit from the ACP-EU partnership in full and have less financial costs when travelling. The rapporteur welcomes the visa waiver agreement, as it is a major improvement in establishing an enhanced and more regular political dialogue, and I have supported her recommendation in voting.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. — Since the citizens of the Marshall Islands pose no serious threat to the objectives of migration policy, security and internal order of the EU, it seems appropriate to conclude a short-stay visa waiver agreement with the country. The conditions for visa-free travel set out in this document are regulated in the same way as in other agreements of the same type that the EU has concluded with other countries. This agreement should be a successful completion of one of the stages of deepening EU-Marshall Islands relations and allow both sides to continue their further deepening.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is a tangible result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands, which is politically very important under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional tool for strengthening economic and economic development. cultural relations and to strengthen political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is nothing against this visa exemption. However, I reject the EU's responsibility for visa issues.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The bilateral agreement between the EU and the Republic of the Marshall Islands was signed in Geneva on 27 June 2016. Since then, the Agreement has been applied temporarily while it awaits approval from the European Parliament. The Agreement signed allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Marshall Islands to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days. Visas are revoked for all categories of persons (holders of normal, diplomatic, official or special passports) who do not travel for the purpose of performing paid activities.When it comes to mobility, the available data shows that the rate of rejected visa applications is very low. I accept this Agreement because it has great political significance, and it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands will allow citizens of both signatories to make up to 90 days of visa-free travel, but without the possibility of performing paid work. I support the agreement as it will lead to strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU-N short-stay visa waiver agreement. Marshall is not a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent for the signing of an agreement by the Council, on behalf of the European Union, with the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the reciprocal granting of a short-stay visa waiver for all categories of passports. In considering the proposal, I have taken into account that this step is in line with the intentions and objectives of the Cotonou Convention regulating the relationship between the EU and ACP countries, and could promote very modest economic and commercial relations, tourism to contribute to the achievement of the Union's development policy objectives in the region. I have taken into account that the Republic of the Marshall Islands, as a state (freely associated with the US), is today a stable democracy where human rights prevail, and indeed its population has chosen a female president for the first time in the region. I also appreciated the important contribution that the EP, through the ACP-EU parliamentary delegation, has made to the process of establishing a visa waiver agreement.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — The cooperation of the European Union with the countries of the ACP region was enshrined in the 2000 Cotonou Agreement. Since then, EU relations with Pacific countries have seen a steadily growing trend. One of the areas where cooperation in recent years has been fruitful is the visa regime, where nationals of the Marshall Islands have an insignificant rejection rate. The Republic of the Marshall Islands has a stable democratic presidential system in association with the United States and has made remarkable progress in the field of protection of human rights and gender equality. The island state works very well with the EU, particularly in the area of climate change and human rights, and has significant potential for development in tourism, services, fisheries and agriculture. In this context, the abolition of short-stay visas will be a natural development and will enable the cultural and economic relations between the two sides to be intensified. I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: This visa waiver agreement for short-term stays represents a concrete result of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands - of strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic relations and cultural issues and to intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and tourism. The economy of the Marshall Islands is mainly based on the services sector, as well as some fishing and agriculture. The Republic of the Marshall Islands has few natural resources and imports far exceed its exports. The United States is by far the largest contributor to the national budget under a free association agreement.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the Agreement between the European Union and the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Marshall Islands and has great political significance. It also strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The signed agreement allows citizens of the European Union and the Marshall Islands to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands abolishes visas for a stay of no more than 90 days in any period of 180 days of all persons travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party. This will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, among others, on human rights and fundamental freedoms. Pending the completion of negotiations on the conclusion of a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with the countries of the Pacific region, this agreement marks another step in strengthening the partnership between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. Since that State does not pose a threat to irregular migration, security and public order, and the exemption from the obligation to possess a visa is an essential factor in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer together, I supported this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the European Union and the Marshall Islands shall be governed by the Cotonou Agreement. A bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and the Marshall Islands in 2016, allowing citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Marshall Islands to travel visa-free into the territory of the other Party for up to 90 days in any 180-day period. The European Union is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Marshall Islands, so that the agreement could facilitate negotiations. There will be more business trips, investment will be accelerated, economic links will be strengthened, tourism and trade development will be enabled. The economy of the Marshall Islands is mainly based on the service sector and, to some extent, fisheries and agriculture. The country has few natural resources, and its imports largely outperform exports.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09775/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands (09774/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive. I am concerned, however, that the country appears to be identified in various reports as a tax haven. A special monitoring of the Agreement should therefore be established to prevent short-term visa exemption from making it easy to engage in money laundering and tax evasion practices.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — This Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days over any period of 180 days. This report is accompanied by a brief justification stating that it constitutes a culmination in the deepening of bilateral relations with strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement. The LIBE Committee, however, invites the European Commission to “observe possible developments in matters relating to illegal immigration, public order and security, the Union's external relations with that country including, in particular, considerations relating to respect for human rights and freedoms fundamental”. Visa exemption therefore poses security risks (organized crime, money laundering, drug trafficking, etc.) and immigration. The question must be asked whether it is appropriate to conclude visa waiver agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost control over mass immigration. I vote against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — I believe that first there should be more emphasis on building economic, cultural and social ties with citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands. Having reached a certain ceiling on relations, we can reflect on the agreement between the EU and that country, so I have adversely stated the agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part (Cotonou Agreement). I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the draft Council Decision (09775/2015) and the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands (09774/2015), I vote in favour of this recommendation by finding no reason for taking another decision, and considering that decision positive. I am concerned, however, that the country appears to be identified in various reports as a tax haven. A special monitoring of the Agreement should therefore be established to prevent short-term visa exemption from making it easy to engage in money laundering and tax evasion practices.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — This agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is a concrete result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands, of great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional measure to strengthen economic and cultural contacts and encourage political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement between the EU and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands are governed by the partnership agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States of the one part and the European Union and its Member States of the other part, known as the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the EU and of the Marshall Islands when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour because this agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a concrete outcome of the deepening of relations between the EU and the Republic of Marshall Islands – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement facilitates the short-stay visa waiver between the two parties. We are talking about an agreement negotiated by the European Commission and which was approved by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Freedom of movement is a fundamental right of all people who are currently not respected in a Union with an increasingly aggressive migration policy. We therefore support this agreement that will allow visa-free travel to the European Union for citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands and vice versa, an agreement that we would like to extend to other countries, particularly those in conflict situations that are forcing thousands of people to flee.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: This agreement provides for a visa exemption regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) irrespective of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the agreement between the EU and the Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver because, firstly, I believe that there is no need for this and, secondly, I believe that the competences of visa policy should remain with the Member States.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the Council's decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Marshall Islands on short-stay visa waiver. In this case, the European Parliament should have given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement. Visa waiver refers to short-term (maximum 90 day stays) and applies to all categories of persons for all purposes, except for carrying out a paid activity. These agreements are the result of intense political dialogue and deepening of political relations with countries outside the European Union and, before such an agreement is concluded, it is always carefully considered whether the country respects human rights, has a democratic regime and how many visa applications and for what reasons has been rejected in the case of citizens of the country concerned. Since the Republic of the Marshall Islands is a stable presidential democracy within a free association with the United States of America, confidence in visa applicants is high, the percentage of their rejection is low, and does not pose any risk in terms of illegal immigration, I did not no reservations to the conclusion of this Agreement.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the agreement to abolish the obligation to possess a short-stay visa of no more than 90 days within a 180 day period from the first entry between the European Union and the Marshall Islands. Increasing mobility from and towards the European Union must be one of the top priorities of European policy at international level. This exemption is a prerequisite for the development of future relations between the European Union and the Marshall Islands. The abolition of short-stay visas has a positive effect for the economy and citizens. Increasing economic activity but also gaining new experiences through travel are major effects for both sides of the agreement. All countries applying and developing the Schengen acquis, not Member States of the European Union, should also conclude agreements with the State of the Marshall Islands in order to harmonize their visa regime with the European Union system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted to approve the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands on the short-stay visa waiver. The short-stay visa liberalisation applies to all categories of persons (holders of normal, diplomatic, official/official or special passport) travelling for any purpose other than performing paid work. I believe that simplified travel conditions will strengthen economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the Republic of Marshall Islands, boost investment and tourism. The Republic of Marshall Islands is a politically stable presidential democracy and does not pose a threat, neither in terms of illicit migration nor in the field of security and public policy.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
