text: – This is an extremely important fund, and in the light of the disastrous flooding which plagued central Europe this summer, and as a concern which Irish people know only too well, I supported this report as an instrument which would enable the EU to respond to major natural disasters more effectively, and indeed efficiently. Such a development thus demonstrates the innate sense of solidarity which will continue to define our relationship with both current and accession states of the European Union and show citizens that we do care about them, and that when they are in dire need the European Union is prepared to do its very best to help them. This is what the Solidarity Fund is all about, and in my constituency we have benefited from it on a number of occasions. We may need to benefit from it again – hopefully not, but I think we probably will because of the nature of the various climatic disasters which are occurring.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report analyses several aspects of the European Commission's report on the reform of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) implemented in 2014 and underlines how, despite Improvements introduced (e.g., prepayments, eligibility of costs related to preparation and implementation of disaster and recovery operations, the introduction of a term of six weeks for the Commission's response to the Member State's questions), beneficiaries still face several difficulties related to the length of the entire procedure. Member States are also called on to optimise the use of existing EU funds in order to promote investments aimed at preventing and reducing the risk of natural disasters. The report also mentions the “budgetary entry” of the annual budget provided for in the omnibus regulation proposed by the Commission with the aim of speeding up the mobilisation procedure and to provide a more timely and effective response to citizens affected by a catastrophe. Appeals for greater transparency regarding the entire management and application phase of the EUSF are equally shared. For these reasons I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report which assessed the successes and failures of the most recent changes to the European Union’s Solidarity Fund. While the 2014 reforms did go a long way towards simplifying procedures for disaster stricken areas, there were some areas where it could go further. During the bad flooding last winter in Ireland, we consistently argued that applications should be possible jointly by regions divided by a border and to classify regions in terms of the NUTS III category. We are glad that an amendment to this aim was included in the final text as well as proposed changes regarding advanced payments and lowering the threshold for applications by peripheral areas with low socio-economic conditions.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — Created in 2002 following severe floods, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries that have suffered extraordinary natural disasters whose direct property damage amounts to more than €3 billion or more than 0.6% of the gross national income. This report simplifies the procedures for mobilizing the EUSF in order to facilitate the execution of payments. To achieve this, the report recommends raising the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15% and lowering the threshold for natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP. In addition, other indicators outside GDP, such as the Human Development Index and the Regional Development Index are also requested to be taken into account in the new methods of calculating the EUSF allocation. The EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and provides significant financial support for national and local authorities in regions affected by natural disasters. In this context, it is appropriate to simplify the operation of the EUSF and facilitate the execution of payments. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I support the principle of solidarity when it comes to disaster relief, I am unconvinced that the Solidarity Fund is fit for purpose. Money often takes months, or longer, to be approved. Member States pay for this fund, which is then redistributed amongst Member States, so the overall impact of the fund – given the administration and bureaucracy caused – may not actually provide any net benefit to disaster relief. This resolution correctly identifies some issues, however, and I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the evaluation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The report deals with several stages in the management of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The rapporteur notes the speed of intervention of the EUSF, the necessary prevention policy to be implemented in order to ensure complementarity between the EUSF and other EU instruments, in particular cohesion policy. The importance of effective cooperation between national and regional or local authorities was also emphasised. I therefore agree that effective response must be ensured at all levels of decision-making, so that financial support is provided to Member States urgently.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund is an important instrument to respond adequately to major natural and extraordinary regional disasters occurring in the EU and in the candidate countries, and to express solidarity with eligible regions and states. The instrument is one of the EU funds which is the most tangible, concrete grants to local and regional communities. The report summarises the most significant changes that the Fund has undergone in recent years in order to provide a more efficient and quicker response to disaster situations and to implement more flexible solutions. A factual description of the functioning of an EU fund fundamentally established for good purposes and changes to the fund in recent years. I supported its adoption.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: The purpose of this report is to simplify the procedures for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters. To achieve this, this text recommends raising the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15% and lowering the threshold for the eligibility of natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP. In addition, other indicators outside GDP, such as the Human Development Index and the Regional Development Index are also requested to be taken into account in the new methods of calculating the EUSF allocation. The Fund is an important financial support for regions affected by natural disasters. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal because I think it is quite appropriate to simplify the operation of the EUSF and to facilitate the execution of payments.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes that the European Solidarity Fund can help more quickly and effectively in response to natural disasters occurring within the EU. Indeed, given the scale and severity of certain disasters, it is important to be able to improve the responsiveness and effectiveness of emergency financing to Member States. Although the Fund underwent significant reform in 2014, efforts can still be made to reduce the often considered too long processing period for recipients.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund was established in 2002 as an instrument to enable action in particularly serious natural disasters. It is a good example of solidarity between the regions and the States of the Union, which has managed to mobilise nearly EUR 4 billion in recent years for the more than 70 disasters that have affected 24 countries members and accession countries. The Cicu report, which I supported with my vote today, underlines the importance of the Fund as support for local and regional governments affected by natural disasters. Thanks to the 2014 review, the EUSF has been able to improve its effectiveness through measures such as prepayments and new prevention provisions combined with improvements in the procedures of financial management. The text approved today suggests some improvements and calls on Member States to strengthen the media and cooperation with local authorities to support the damage assessment process and that of preparation of questions. The overall use of existing resources, especially ESI funds, should be encouraged by targeting investment policies dedicated to the prevention of natural disasters.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund is a tool for responding to natural disasters with a direct impact on people's lives, the natural environment or the economy of a given region and, in particular, to support public authorities in their emergency and recovery operations. Since its inception, it has mobilized a total of EUR 3.8 billion in over 70 disasters in 24 Member States and acceding countries. I voted in favour of the report because it responds to the finding that natural disasters have increased in number, severity and intensity and supports measures aimed, on the one hand, to improve the operating mechanisms of the instrument (simplifying procedures, gaining agility, raising the threshold for advance payments and increasing the transparency) and, on the other hand, improve Member States' capacities in disaster and emergency prevention and management.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur for his report on the assessment of the European Union Solidarity Fund, which I supported. This Fund has been a very important source of funding for local and regional administration, mitigating the consequences of natural disasters occurring throughout the European continent, ranging from earthquakes or forest fires to floods, and which has shown European solidarity with the affected regions. This Fund also constitutes one of the most concrete and tangible representations for citizens of the Union's support to local communities.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. — The EUSF was established in 2002 and has a budget of EUR 500 million to provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries that have suffered extraordinary natural disasters with direct property damage of more than €3 billion or more than 0.6% of gross national income. This report is intended to simplify procedures for the mobilisation of the EUSF in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters, in particular by raising the threshold for advance payments or by taking into account other indicators in addition to GDP. In response to natural disasters, financial support is always timely and welcome, and the EUSF is a significant tool for national or local authorities in the affected regions. So I decided to vote in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — The report proposing an assessment of the European Union Solidarity Fund is well structured and shareable, which is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and to bring European solidarity to the sinister regions of Europe. It was established in response to the major floods in the summer of 2002 in Central Europe. Since then, it has been used in 72 catastrophes of a wide variety of kinds, including floods, wildfires, earthquakes, storms and droughts. 24 European countries have been assisted with more than 3.8 billion euros. In view of the use of the ESF during its first years of existence and the ESF's specific situation report prepared by the Commission, I supported this own-initiative report which addresses the three specific aspects of improving the management of the fund: rapid reaction, prevention and complementarity with the Cohesion Funds; and, transparency and cooperation between the different levels of decision-making.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because Parliament expressed its position on the European Union Solidarity Fund. The European Union Solidarity Fund was established in the European Union following the tragic floods of 2002. Its purpose is to express the Union's solidarity with the countries affected by major natural disasters as a matter of urgency. Not only Member States but also candidate countries can benefit from the Fund. In 2014, the original Regulation was amended in order to respond more effectively to the problems faced by the beneficiaries, to respond more quickly to requests from the affected countries and to include drought in the scope. However, Parliament underlines that, although there is a mechanism whereby advances can be obtained faster than the normal procedure, beneficiaries still face problems with the length of the entire process, from the submission of the application to the payment of the final amount of support.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — Applications submitted under the Solidarity Fund shall be processed as quickly as possible and within a maximum of 12 weeks from the date of submission. All decision-making levels must respond quickly and efficiently so that financial support is available to the disaster area as soon as possible. It is untenable that in some cases it took more than one year to reach the beneficiaries of financial assistance. Effective action includes preventive measures and the search for synergies with the Cohesion Funds, particularly in the case of infrastructure projects, which reduces the costs associated with post-disaster actions. The parliamentary report proposes closer cooperation between decision-making levels and calls for greater transparency and better communication with stakeholders. I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the evaluation of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the report for the European Union Solidarity Fund, as it represents an important source of funding for local and regional governments and mitigates the consequences of natural disasters throughout Europe. Its use is possible in a range of natural disasters, ranging from floods to earthquakes and forest fires, expressing European solidarity with affected areas. It should also be emphasised that investment in the prevention of natural disasters is extremely important in responding to climate change.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which was established in response to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity for disaster-affected regions. Since 2002 it has been used for 72 accidents, covering a number of various catastrophic events, including floods, fires, earthquakes, storms...

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report aims to facilitate procedures for implementing the EUSF in the case of natural disasters in both regions and states. I consider that solidarity is a virtue which can very well be exercised at European level, and therefore I am not against it. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002) was established with the aim of giving a tangible sign of the Union's solidarity with the countries affected by serious natural disasters. The EUSF may provide assistance to Member States if all direct damage caused by a natural disaster exceeds €3 billion (at 2011 prices) or 0.6% of gross national income (GNI) of the country. There are also provisions to respond to smaller regional disasters (1.5% of the region's GDP and 1% for an outermost region). For its unpredictable nature, a natural disaster not only causes inconvenience for the affected populations, but it raises the question of the speed of intervention by the public authorities, which must cope with the expenditure unforeseen. We must therefore make sure that it is increasingly easy to mobilise the EUSF for those entitled to it: the availability of immediate funds and aid after a catastrophic event is of crucial importance for allow the resumption and continuation of production activities in the affected areas.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: The purpose of this report is to simplify the procedures for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters. To achieve this, the report recommends raising the advance payment threshold from 10% to 15% and lowering the threshold for natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP. In addition, other indicators outside GDP, such as the human development index or the regional development index, are requested to be taken into account in the new methods of calculating the allocation of the EUSF. We believe that the EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and constitutes significant financial support for national and local authorities in regions affected by natural disasters. In this context, it seems to us to be quite appropriate to simplify the functioning of the EUSF and to facilitate the implementation of payments on the sole condition that it is not used to finance the reception of illegal migrants in the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: The European Union Solidarity Fund is an important source of financial support for local and regional authorities and helps to alleviate them of the consequences of natural disasters occurring across the European continent. These include floods, earthquakes, forest fires or other disasters that are often unpredictable and have major social, economic and environmental consequences. Faced with these threats, European solidarity is indispensable. Unfortunately, recipients continue to face problems because of the lengthy process of applying for advance payments as a whole. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes improvements to the EUSF for rapid and effective financial assistance to victims of climate change and its most severe climatic consequences.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report calling on the Commission and the Court of Auditors to make a thorough assessment of the functioning of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) by the end of the current multiannual financial programming period. The report stresses the importance of redefining the scope of the EUSF in view of the reform in 2014, establishing clear requirements for defining regional disasters and increasing prevention strategies. Investment efforts should be multiplied to mitigate climate change and ensure maximum transparency regarding the award, management and application of the EUSF. Member States must improve cooperation and communication with local and regional authorities with a view to more effective cooperation with European Union assistance.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which assessed the successes and failures of the most recent changes to the European Union’s Solidarity Fund. While the 2014 reforms did go a long way towards simplifying procedures for disaster stricken areas, there were some areas where it could go further. During the bad flooding last winter in Ireland, I consistently argued that applications should be possible jointly by regions divided by a border and to classify regions in terms of the NUTS III category. I am glad that an amendment to this aim was included in the final text as well as proposed changes regarding advanced payments and lowering the threshold for applications by peripheral areas with low socio-economic conditions.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote. This vote concerned emergency disaster relief management, and we did not wish to stand in the way of such a scheme, even if it is under the control of the EU.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which analyses the 2014 EU Social Fund (EUSF) Annual Report by the European Commission. It focuses on the effects of the 2014 EUSF reform on the process of the mobilisation of assistance and it also formulates some recommendations for a future possible reform, which should take into consideration the possibility of redefining regional natural disasters, allowing for a single application to be submitted jointly by several eligible states at cross-border level, as well as examining the indirect damage when assessing the application.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Mr Cicu's report on the European Union Solidarity Fund. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established in 2002 as a valid instrument to enable the EU to cope with major natural disasters and regional disasters of scale extraordinary within the EU and in countries engaged in accession negotiations, as well as to show solidarity with the regions and states concerned. The Cicu report assesses several aspects of the European Commission report on the reform of the EUSF implemented in 2014 and rightly points out how, despite the major improvements introduced, beneficiaries still face difficulties as a result of the length of the entire process, from the submission of the application to the payment of the final contribution. The rapporteur also calls on Member States to optimise the use of existing EU funds and stresses the need to start a reflection on the search for new indicators that go beyond GDP such as the others, the Human Development Index and the Regional Index of Social Progress.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The report, on which I felt I voted in favour, examines the functioning of the activity of the European Union Solidarity Fund established in 2002 to support the States members where natural disasters take place. The Fund, which has already been activated for 72 natural disasters, is still in my view possible areas for improvement; in fact, it would be appropriate to improve the speed of reaction and coordination between European and national institutions so that financial support is quickly unblocked. We cannot tolerate victims of such major disasters feeling abandoned in the period between the emergency response and the arrival of funds. I also believe that the funding provided by the Union is intended for risk prevention and management actions, in particular by ensuring that the reconstruction of the works destroyed as a result of a natural disaster is carried out by putting the latter in accordance with. Finally, I think it is necessary to improve transparency regarding the use of funds through a thorough monitoring of expenditure and through the publication of reports submitted by the States members. It would also be important to improve communication with citizens throughout the entire aid process in order to enable beneficiaries to better follow the procedure for each individual application.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the evaluation of the European Union Solidarity Fund is a sound attempt to analyse and improve the activities of this Fund, which I believe contributes to its more effective operation. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Positive vote for this report on the European Social Fund intended to finance Member States' emergency situations. It is worth pointing out that with this fund, due to budgetary constraints, it is not possible to adequately finance prevention and reconstruction plans. However, the report is limited to a generic demand for more synergy between funds.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Natural disasters happen when we can least expect it; in today's world we can predict many things, but claim to be able to fully govern the dynamics of our Earth not falls within these. In the light of this certainty, I strongly vote in favour of the report evaluating the instrument which, since 2002, allows solidarity to be provided and to ensure adequate and timely assistance to citizens affected by severe cataclysms. It has a budget of EUR 500 million and, as a result of the reform adopted in 2014, it can act as quickly as a result of prepayments, with which it is made available until 10% of the amount of the planned contribution (however limited to a maximum amount of EUR 30 million). However, beneficiaries still face difficulties as a result of the length of the entire process, from the submission of the application to the payment of the final contribution. In any case it is necessary to remind the Member States that it is clearly preferable to prevent disasters through adequate investments, as obtained through the EU ESI funds, rather than having to use subsequent to the EUSF with increased charges and, likely, damages.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the European Union Solidarity Fund: an assessment.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to provide the Union with a tool for responding to major natural disasters, such as the 2002 floods in Central Europe, which led to the creation of the Fund. Over the years, around €3.8 billion has been mobilised to deal with more than 70 disasters, making it an effective symbol of solidarity within the EU. I agree with the concern about the lengthy procedures relating to the EUSF. I would stress the need to ensure greater speed and less bureaucracy in the handling of applications, mobilisation of funds and in the preparation of implementation and closure reports. I believe that the use of the EUSF should respect the strictest principles of sound financial management, so independence and transparency in the award, management and implementation of the EUSF should be guaranteed. The sharing of good practice that comes from this is essential for progressively improving this instrument. I believe that sustainable reconstruction and other post-disaster activities should be included in the Structural Funds, but that the evaluation of the implementation of the EUSF will lead to recommendations for reconstruction to meet a purpose of preventing and adapting infrastructure. I therefore support the report.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because I support the rapporteur's calls for greater transparency and better cooperation between decision-makers at different levels. With the Solidarity Fund, we have a good instrument at our disposal that can provide good assistance in the event of emergencies in the event of a wide range of disasters. But there is still a need for improvement: cooperation and procedures, particularly within individual local and regional authorities, must be improved. We need procedures that do justice to reality. The aim must be to provide assistance to those affected and not to make life more difficult for them through complex bureaucratic processes.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established to enable the EU to respond to emergency situations caused by severe natural disasters and express solidarity European to disaster-affected regions in Europe. I voted in favour of this proposal as it aims to increase the general budget of the Union for 2017 by an amount of EUR 50 million for appropriations of economic advances to be paid in a way timely and effective to affected countries.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is towards a very useful purpose that we have mobilised, in total, EUR 3.8 billion in connection with more than 70 disasters within 24 beneficiary states and accession countries. The circumstances leading to this embraced a wide range of natural phenomena, such as earthquakes, flooding, forest fires, storms and, more recently, drought; the EUSF remains one of the EU’s strongest symbols of solidarity in times of need. I agree with the rapporteur that may contribute to the grievances of these families through a faster mobilisation of funds so that the real needs on the ground may be met. We need to shorten deadlines for the processing of applications from six to four weeks and encourage effective cooperation between authorities at national level and regional and local levels.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. “In view of the need to make aid available to countries affected by natural disasters, I voted in favour of the report on the assessment of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EFSEU). Established in 2002, the fund represents a direct expression of EU solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. Amending and reviewing the Regulation is important for providing an effective response to beneficiaries and for more efficient consideration of the requests of the countries affected by the disasters. In the moment of cataclysm, efficient and rapid assistance is necessary for the State and its citizens. The appointment to the operation of this fund is undoubtedly legitimate. I believe that efforts should be repeated to strengthen strategies in this regard.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of an EU solidarity fund which has simplified procedures to ensure rapid response within six weeks of application, the introduction of an advanced payment of 10% upon application and improvements in the assessment phase, better communication while optimising the use of EU funding and transparency. The EU Solidarity Fund was set up as an answer to disastrous flooding in Central Europe (2012) as an instrument for major natural disasters and to demonstrate solidarity.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established following the disastrous floods in the summer of 2002 in Central Europe. It is an instrument for the EU to deal with major natural disasters on its territory. This European Parliament report analyses the annual report of the European Commission's EUSF and makes recommendations for future reform to redefine regional natural disasters. The report also calls on the European Commission to analyse the possibility of increasing the advance payment threshold to 15% and shortening the processing times to 4 weeks in order to increase the effectiveness of the EUSF. Considering that better responsiveness and effectiveness of the Fund will better respond to the challenges of natural disasters facing EU territories, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote. This vote concerned emergency disaster relief management, and we did not wish to stand in the way of such a scheme, even if it is under the control of the EU.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the evaluation report of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). The EUSF is a flagship tool for cooperation between Member States that provide assistance to European territories and citizens affected by natural disasters. This report highlights credible proposals to improve this important tool, such as reducing time to process requests for assistance or greater transparency in the use of funds.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the evaluation of the Solidarity Fund in the European Parliament plenary vote in Strasbourg. The processing time of applications submitted under the Solidarity Fund shall be processed as quickly as possible and within a maximum of 12 weeks from the date of submission of the application. All decision-making levels must respond quickly and efficiently so that financial support is available to the disaster area as soon as possible. It is untenable that in some cases it took more than one year to reach the beneficiaries of financial assistance. Effective action includes preventive measures and the search for synergies with the Cohesion Funds, particularly in the case of infrastructure projects, which reduces the costs associated with post-disaster actions. The parliamentary report proposes closer cooperation between decision-making levels and calls for greater transparency and better communication with stakeholders.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. Created in 2002 following severe floods, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries that have suffered extraordinary natural disasters whose direct property damage accounts for more than 0.6% of gross national income. The EUSF is an important tool for European solidarity, and we believe it is important to simplify its use and broaden access to it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. The Solidarity Fund has in a short time become a working fund, which is unfortunately used in natural disasters to help the victims. Unfortunately, however, many of the affected areas remained out of the reach of this fund because the disasters in them did not meet the aid frameworks. I therefore welcome the change — the EP's desire to reduce the threshold from 1.5% to 1%. At the same time, I am aggrieved that the Commission did not want to reduce it, but I hope we will be able to achieve this objective very soon. I hope we reduce the response time for the institutions because 12 weeks to submit the aid papers and then another 6 for approval is still a big period for people in distress. Finally, I hope there is no reason for the money from this fund to be touched, that is, I hope there are no major natural disasters in Europe, but in the world at all.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The nation states know their needs much better than the Union, so we are opposed to any requirement for mandatory national plans.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the evaluation of the Solidarity Fund in the European Parliament plenary vote in Strasbourg. The processing time of applications submitted under the Solidarity Fund shall be processed as quickly as possible and within a maximum of 12 weeks from the date of submission of the application. All decision-making levels must respond quickly and efficiently so that financial support is available to the disaster area as soon as possible. It is untenable that in some cases it took more than one year to reach the beneficiaries of financial assistance. Effective action includes preventive measures and the search for synergies with the Cohesion Funds, particularly in the case of infrastructure projects, which reduces the costs associated with post-disaster actions. The parliamentary report proposes closer cooperation between decision-making levels and calls for greater transparency and better communication with stakeholders.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on the Solidarity Fund which enables EU financial assistance to be provided in the event of natural disasters. Despite my many calls, the UK Government refuses to take advantage of the Solidarity Fund to help overcome disasters in Wales.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote in favour: this report aims to simplify the procedures for mobilizing the EUSF in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because the text, in the context of the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund, contains measures to deal with more quickly demands of countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 2002, the Solidarity Fund has been operating in the European Union, whose main objective is to respond to natural disasters in Europe and to provide financial assistance to those affected so that they can cope more flexibly and faster with the consequences of such events. After 12 years of operation, the original regulation changed in 2014 to better and more accurately reflect the real situation and to accelerate the response between the application for assistance and the factual provision of funds. However, the European Union still has room to improve the Solidarity Fund, for example in preventing and effectively managing after disaster. However, prevention must be an integral part of the post-disaster phase. It is important that the restoration of destroyed objects or the repair of infrastructure facilities is an opportunity to align them with the standards.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote in favor.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions. Since 2002, it has been used for 72 disasters, covering a range of different catastrophic events including floods, forest fires, earthquakes, storms and draughts. 24 European countries have been supported for an amount of almost EUR 4 billion. After an initial stalemate in the Council, the ESUF Regulation was overhauled in 2014. This own INI report, based on the annual Commission report from 2014, addresses few aspects of the management of the EUSF, such as: response time, prevention policy through, for instance, implementation of the ex-ante conditionalities in the EU Cohesion policy, transparency and cooperation between the different levels of decision makers.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The processing time of applications submitted under the Solidarity Fund shall be processed as quickly as possible and within a maximum of 12 weeks from the date of submission of the application. All decision-making levels must respond quickly and efficiently so that financial support is available to the disaster area as soon as possible. It is untenable that in some cases it took more than one year to reach the beneficiaries of financial assistance. The European Parliament's report on the evaluation of the Solidarity Fund proposes closer cooperation between decision-making levels and encourages greater transparency and better communication with stakeholders. For this reason, I voted in favour of the report in the plenary vote of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report considering that the EUSF can help Member States when the total direct damage caused by a natural disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's gross national income (GNI). Although it was impossible to foresee all emergencies, the management of their consequences could always be improved. We must avoid situations where victims feel abandoned between the emergency response and the arrival of ESF funds, so the speed in mobilizing such funds is of great importance.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund is a very important instrument that has served the EU very well, in total the fund has mobilised EUR 3.8 billion in connection with more than 70 disasters within 24 countries. The fund has been used to mount effective responses to several types of natural disasters, such as earthquakes, flooding, storms and forest fires. The effective use of this mechanism is still, however, hampered by the length of the overall process from application to payment of the final contribution. This can lead to unnecessary and potentially dangerous delays. There is also a need to increase and optimise the use of existing EU funding, for investing in the prevention of natural disasters. This will save money long-term as every euro invested in prevention saved between four to seven euros in disaster management later.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the excellent work that Mr Cicu has done in his report “EU Solidarity Fund: Assessment”: I fully agree with the need to intervene with timely responses, adequate and effective instruments and serious prevention policies against disastrous phenomena such as the earthquake which have repeatedly hit Italy in recent months and which continue to threaten safety of the person, artistic and cultural heritage and growth. Europe is the guarantor of the beauty and history of its places, as a promoter of business development and the labour market, Europe urges the process of rebirth of small municipalities and of the villages, wounded today by the many trials faced. Increase the current potential for intervention of the European Solidarity Funds, through processes of simplification, acceleration and increase of facilities to proceed as soon as possible with reconstruction and avert the sad threat of the abandonment of roots and territories.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. — Thanks to the Solidarity Fund (EFSEU), the European Union provides effective support to Member States or EU candidate countries in tackling the effects of natural disasters. From this fund, we allocate up to EUR 500 million annually to supplement the public expenditure incurred by the State or Member States in relation to the conduct of emergency actions. The EFSEU shall provide assistance where the total direct damage caused by a natural disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0,6% of the country's gross national income. This week's report on the assessment of the European Union Solidarity Fund notes the need for rapid intervention by the EFSEU, the necessary prevention policy in relation to other European instruments, especially cohesion policy and effective cooperation national level with regional or local authorities. In this context, since the speed of processing of applications for natural disasters is paramount, the rapporteur rightly proposed a deadline of 12 weeks from the time the full dossier was submitted. Moreover, it is proposed to introduce greater transparency, especially with regard to the various resources allocated to repair the damage caused by such a disaster.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to respond quickly to disasters. In this context, it is important that the EUSF and other EU instruments work together effectively. Efficient cooperation between national and local authorities is also crucial to success.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour for the assessment of the European Union solidarity fund enabling EU to respond to major natural disasters that have a direct impact on people’s lives, the natural environment and the economy in a given affected region.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because, after the time of the closeness demonstrations, the affected regions are calling on Europe to apply and act according to two principles: flexibility and simplification. They are two concepts that should regulate and govern all cohesion policy, but become “viable” in the face of entire countries and territories reduced to rubble. Flexibility and simplification of the Solidarity Fund therefore, which has procedures and above all too long application times. So the advance of the funds before the Commission's final decision, but there is still much to be done. The Solidarity Fund has proved to be an essential tool in many emergency occasions. Emergency that inevitably contrasts with bureaucracy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund is a tool for responding to natural disasters with a direct impact on people's lives, the natural environment or the economy of a given region and, in particular, to support public authorities in their emergency and recovery operations. Since its inception, it has mobilized a total of EUR 3.8 billion in over 70 disasters in 24 Member States and acceding countries. I voted in favour of the report because it responds to the finding that natural disasters have increased in number, severity and intensity and supports measures aimed, on the one hand, to improve the operating mechanisms of the instrument (simplifying procedures, gaining agility, raising the threshold for advance payments and increasing the transparency) and, on the other hand, improve Member States' capacities in disaster and emergency prevention and management.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The processing time of applications submitted under the Solidarity Fund shall be processed as quickly as possible and within a maximum of 12 weeks from the date of submission of the application. All decision-making levels must respond quickly and efficiently so that financial support is available as soon as possible in areas affected by disasters. It is untenable that in some cases it took more than one year to reach the beneficiaries of financial assistance. Effective action includes preventive measures and the search for synergies with the Cohesion Funds, particularly in the case of infrastructure projects, which reduces the costs associated with post-disaster actions. Parliamentary report proposes closer cooperation between decision-making levels and calls for greater transparency and better communication with stakeholders

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report. Following the tragic flooding of 2002, the European Union introduced the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) as an immediate demonstration of the Union’s solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. It was established for both Member States and Accession Countries. The EUSF may come to the aid of Member States if total direct damages caused by a natural disaster exceed EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country’s gross national income (GNI). There are also provisions to respond to smaller regional disasters (1.5% of the region’s GDP or 1% for outermost regions). Indeed, Ireland applied to the EUSF under this measure. In October 2015, the European Commission presented its report on the use of the EUSF for 2014 which focuses on the EUSF’s special circumstances in 2014. Following this report, the Regional Development Committee decided to produce this own-initiative report to examine how well this solidarity instrument works and calls on the Member States to optimise the use of existing EU funding.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour, since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the European Union Solidarity Fund Report, because this Fund is one of the most concrete and tangible manifestations of support the European Union can give to local communities. It is an important source of funding for local and regional governments, which alleviate the consequences of natural disasters. Due to its unpredictable character, natural disasters not only bring problems to the affected population, but also raises the question of the speed of action of public bodies that have to face unforeseen costs, so it is extremely important to ensure maximum transparency in the allocation of funds from European Union Solidarity Fund, management and implementation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: Any desire to simplify the operation of the European Union Solidarity Fund and to accelerate the implementation of payments is welcome. This mechanism is exemplary of European solidarity and proves to be decisive in the financial assistance it provides to communities affected by natural disasters. So I voted in favour.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which evaluates the Union Solidarity Fund, as it makes recommendations for a future reform of this solidarity fund in the face of natural disasters, which should take into account the possibility of redefining regional natural disasters, allowing a single application to be submitted jointly by several eligible States at the cross-border level, as well as the examination of indirect damage in the assessment of the claim. The Commission is also asked to analyse the possibility of increasing the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15% and to shorten the processing times for applications from 6 weeks to 4 weeks, which is quite desirable.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of this report. The Solidarity Fund was set up in the summer of 2012 as a result of the severe floods in Central Europe to allow Member States to respond more quickly to the consequences of natural disasters. I support efficiency-enhancing measures, as envisaged in this report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the evaluation of the Solidarity Fund in the European Parliament plenary vote in Strasbourg. The processing time of applications submitted under the Solidarity Fund shall be processed as quickly as possible and within a maximum of 12 weeks from the date of submission of the application. All decision-making levels must respond quickly and efficiently so that financial support is available to the disaster area as soon as possible. It is untenable that in some cases it took more than one year to reach the beneficiaries of financial assistance. Effective action includes preventive measures and the search for synergies with the Cohesion Funds, particularly in the case of infrastructure projects, which reduces the costs associated with post-disaster actions. The parliamentary report proposes closer cooperation between decision-making levels and calls for greater transparency and better communication with stakeholders.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Europe is increasingly confronted with natural disasters. The European Union Solidarity Fund is the clear expression of solidarity in times of need and that is why with the vote on this resolution we reiterate today our full support for this tool. Since its creation in 2002, it has been an important source of support for local and regional governments, mobilizing nearly €4 billion to support over 70 natural disasters in 24 Member States and on the way of accession. Parliament played a leading role in the review of the 2014 reform in particular with regard to improving the availability and effectiveness of aid, not least payments advance of 10% of the amount of the expected contribution. Funds alone are not enough to deal with natural disasters. Investment efforts should be multiplied, especially in climate change mitigation and risk prevention and management strategies. Let us not forget that many natural disasters are direct consequences of human activities. The appeal to the Commission today also concerns the possibility of increasing the payment threshold to 15%, as well as the possibility of reducing the time limits for the treatment of tomanas.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it aims to facilitate the implementation of payments from the EUSF, calling for an increase in advance payments from 10% to 15% and to lower the threshold for natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: — The Solidarity Fund is a tool to assist Member States affected by a major natural disaster. It goes without saying that the Union must be able to act as a matter of urgency in such cases. The N-VA supports the findings of this report and is convinced of the importance of this expenditure if it can help victims of natural disasters in a timely and effective manner to repair the damage and to recover the wire.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that suggests some areas of future possible reform to the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - After the tragic floods of 2002, the European Union established the Solidarity Fund, which serves to directly demonstrate the Union's solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters, and also applies to the accession countries. The Solidarity Fund can help Member States if the total damage directly caused by natural disasters exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the State's gross national income, and there are provisions for assistance in case of minor regional disasters. The aim of this report is to emphasize the importance of the speed of intervention of the Fund, the need for prevention policy and the necessity of complementarity of the Fund and other European instruments, notably cohesion policy. The Rapporteur stresses that better cooperation between different levels of decision-making can improve the transparency of the Fund. I believe that it is necessary to improve the mechanisms of cooperation and complementarity in the functioning of this Fund, and I have therefore supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. — From the Solidarity Fund established in 2002, the Union helps Member and candidate countries cope with natural elements. This is about the provision of aid vis major, the aim of which is to mitigate the consequences of disasters. The condition is that the total direct damage caused by the natural disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion (2011 prices), or 0.6% of the country's gross national income (GNI). The report highlights the need to improve the management of aid, increase flexibility, increase awareness and, at the same time, increase transparency in the provision of assistance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the European Union Solidarity Fund: evaluation, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, and because this report is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. This report aims to simplify the procedures for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). The EUSF was established in 2002 following severe flooding in several European countries. It aims to provide financial assistance to Member States that have suffered extraordinary natural disasters. We consider this fund to be a good tool for European solidarity and one of the few examples of the proper use of funds from national contributions. The simplification of the rules of its mobilization is therefore welcome.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The European Union Solidarity Fund was established after the tragic floods of 2002. Its purpose is to express the Union's solidarity with the countries affected by major natural disasters as a matter of urgency. Not only Member States but also candidate countries can benefit from the Fund. In 2014, the original Regulation was amended to respond more effectively to the problems faced by beneficiaries, to respond more quickly to requests from affected countries and to include drought in the scope. The European Court of Auditors has produced a single report on the use of the EUSF since the establishment of this Fund. This report highlights several options for improving fund management. These recommendations were taken into account during the 2014 review of the EUSF. I therefore agree with the provisions set out in the report that it is still possible to achieve greater transparency, in particular by allocating funds to compensate for damage caused by disasters.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The purpose of this report is to simplify procedures for mobilizing the EUSF in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters. To achieve this, the report recommends raising the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15% and lowering the threshold for natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP. In addition, other indicators outside GDP, such as the Human Development Index and the Regional Development Index, are requested to be taken into account in the new methods of calculating the allocation of the EUSF. We believe that the EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and constitutes significant financial support for national and local authorities in regions affected by natural disasters. In this context, it seems appropriate to simplify the operation of the EUSF and to facilitate the execution of payments. Therefore, I voted in favour of this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) Following the tragic floods of 2002, the European Union created the European Union Solidarity Fund (Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002), which represents the immediate manifestation of the Union's solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. The EUSF has been used positively and has helped many countries. However, improvements are always possible; hence the drafting of this report in order to find better solutions for the future. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the EU Solidarity Fund is an indispensable instrument in providing emergency relief to countries affected by major national disasters quickly and effectively.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — In 2002, following the tragic floods, the European Union set up the European Union Solidarity Fund. This Fund is aimed at both Member States and candidate countries to help countries affected by natural disasters. While it is impossible to predict all emergencies and disasters, it is nevertheless possible to improve the management of their consequences. Various aspects of management are highlighted in the report, such as the rapid intervention of the Solidarity Fund, a necessary preventive policy which goes hand in hand with the necessary complementarity between the EUSF and the other European instruments, in particular cohesion policy, as well as effective collaboration between the national level and regional or local authorities. The European Union Solidarity Fund is an immediate translation of the Union's solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. It is therefore essential to carry out an evaluation of this instrument with a view to continually improving the instrument. It is therefore without hesitation that I welcome this report.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which addresses several aspects of the management of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). It focuses on the response time of the EUSF and the need for a prevention policy, which goes hand in hand with the necessary complementarity between the EUSF and other European instruments, in particular cohesion policy. It is essential to emphasise effective cooperation between authorities at national level and regional and local levels.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was established after the flood disasters in 2002. The aim of the Fund is to express the Union's immediate solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. The European Commission presented its 2014 report on mobilisation of the Fund in October 2015. On this occasion, the Committee on Regional Development decided to examine the operation of the Fund and report it to Parliament in a report. The report focuses above all on the response rate of the Fund and raises the need for a prevention policy that takes advantage of the mutual complementarity between the Fund and other European Union instruments, in particular cohesion policy. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: The purpose of this report is to simplify procedures for mobilizing the EUSF in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters. To achieve this, the report recommends raising the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15% and lowering the threshold for natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP. In addition, other indicators outside GDP, such as the Human Development Index and the Regional Development Index, are requested to be taken into account in the new methods of calculating the allocation of the EUSF. We believe that the EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and constitutes significant financial support for national and local authorities in regions affected by natural disasters. In this context, it seems appropriate to simplify the operation of the EUSF and to facilitate the execution of payments.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. - The EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and provides significant financial support for national and local authorities in regions affected by natural disasters. In this context, it seems to me to be quite appropriate to simplify the operation of the EUSF and to facilitate the execution of payments. I am voting for the text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the evaluation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. This fund, set up in the wake of the 2002 floods in Eastern Europe, is a genuine instrument of solidarity designed to help countries affected by major natural disasters. This report proposes developments in this mechanism for greater efficiency. He proposed, inter alia, that the concept of regional natural disaster be redefined. It also proposed the creation of the possibility of filing a single application for joint assistance when several States were affected by a disaster.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: ‒ To make the most of the great opportunities offered by globalization, you must first know how to mitigate the effects. That is why we welcome the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. In fact, the Fund has proved to be an important instrument of solidarity for workers who are victims of mass redundancies generated by structural changes in world trade, through activities of assistance, redevelopment and reintegration, as well as promotion of business activity. In addition, the report puts black on white the need to pay attention to the impacts of trade policies and agreements on the European labour market, as well as reiterating the importance of dialogue Social and to urge the Commission to ensure that the loss of work occurs only as a last resort. The response to globalisation cannot nor should be declined in an attitude of distrust and closure, but must be seen as a great opportunity that needs an active adaptation to reap its benefits, maintaining as balances points of reference the achievements of the European social model and the protection of workers.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2002 the European Union Solidarity Fund was set up as a response to major natural disasters and to express the EU’s solidarity towards disaster struck regions within Europe. Since then it has been used for 72 disasters by 24 different countries. I have voted for this report that examined how well this solidarity instrument works and what areas need improvement, including improving the management of the impact of a disaster.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. The EU Solidarity Fund is a robust and flexible instrument providing real assistance to European citizens affected by major natural disasters. Evidence of this is the fact that the Fund, since its inception in 2002, has mobilised a total of EUR 3.8 billion in connection with over 70 disasters in 24 Member States and candidate member states, including my country Bulgaria. In order to continue to be a concrete and tangible means of EU solidarity towards communities affected by natural disasters, the Fund must continue to develop. In 2014, when the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 entered into force, the Solidarity Fund was significantly upgraded. The procedures for applying for financial assistance from the Fund have been improved and simplified so that regions victims of natural disasters can receive a response within six weeks from the date of application for assistance. In this resolution, for its part, once again, another interesting proposal is to look at the index of human development and the regional index of social progress in determining the financial assistance received from the affected regions. I think that the aforementioned successes of the Solidarity Fund, as well as its continued development, must be stimulated, and that is why I am giving my support to this resolution.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the report, which points out, among other things, the need to ensure that Member States optimize the use of existing EU funding, in particular all five European structural and investment funds, for the purpose of investments in the prevention of natural disasters. In this regard, it is important to develop synergies between individual Funds and Union policies in order to prevent as much as possible the consequences of natural disasters and where the Fund is used EU solidarity, also to ensure consolidation and long-term sustainable development of reconstruction projects. It is appropriate to add that the EU Solidarity Fund provides assistance for non-insurable damages and does not compensate for private losses, with long-term measures such as sustainable reconstruction or activity to promote economic development or prevention, they are eligible for financing from other Union instruments, in particular European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which assessed the successes and failures of the most recent changes to the European Union’s Solidarity Fund. While the 2014 reforms did go a long way towards simplifying procedures for disaster stricken areas, there were some areas where it could go further. During the bad flooding last winter in Ireland, I consistently argued that applications should be possible jointly by regions divided by a border and to classify regions in terms of the NUTS III category. I am glad that an amendment to this aim was included in the final text as well as proposed changes regarding advanced payments and lowering the threshold for applications by peripheral areas with low socio-economic conditions.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because the European Union Solidarity Fund was established by Regulation 2012/2002 following the severe floods in Central Europe in the summer of 2012 to enable the EU to respond to natural disasters. I therefore support the efficiency-enhancing measures.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The ELSF is one of Europe's best instruments of solidarity, which brings relief to regions after natural disasters and helps them restore post-crisis situations.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I support the report submitted. It should be noted that the EU Solidarity Fund is a very important tool for effectively responding to major natural disasters affecting Member States. This is one of the most specific and visible forms of support that the EU can provide to local communities. In the event of a disaster, it is necessary to provide assistance and help the people affected by the disaster as soon as possible. It is therefore essential to ensure that the fund operates efficiently, flexibly and is used for its intended purpose. It is necessary to establish a legal framework for defining the duration of the evaluation period. In addition, clear criteria for monitoring visits to beneficiary countries should be laid down in order to assess the implementation framework in place and to verify the proper use of resources.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was created to deal with major natural disasters and to show European solidarity in the affected regions of Europe. The Fund was established following the severe floods that hit Central Europe in the summer of 2002. Since then, it has been used in 72 cases to deal with disasters such as floods, forest fires, earthquakes, storms and droughts. To date, more than EUR 3.8 billion has been provided in 24 different European countries. I voted in favour of the report, which emphasises a number of recommendations for the possible improvement of the management of the Fund in areas such as speed of response, prevention and complementarity, transparency and cooperation between the different levels of decision-making.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues proposal because I believe that the management of the EU Solidarity Fund can still benefit from some improvements; for example it could be introduced greater transparency, in particular with regard to funds allocated for compensation for damage caused by a catastrophe. The level of cooperation between the various local, regional authorities and central services should be improved at the level of each Member State. I also believe, as a politician, the need to improve and speed up the disbursement of funds made available to the EU, to prevent people affected by environmental disasters feeling abandoned . Therefore I voted positive

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it formulates some recommendations for a future possible reform, which should take into consideration the possibility of redefining regional natural disasters, allowing for a single application to be submitted jointly by several eligible states at cross-border level, as well as examining the indirect damage when assessing the application. It also focuses on the effects of the 2014 EUSF reform on the process of the mobilisation of assistance. The Fund is the EU’s way to respond to major and extraordinary natural disasters inside the Union and in countries involved in accession negotiations and demonstrates solidarity with the eligible regions or States.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Since its inception in 2002, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) has proved to be a very useful and important instrument for mitigating the consequences of natural disasters by providing financial assistance to national governments and regional and local authorities of affected areas. In fourteen years, Member States have shown solidarity through this Fund, helping with 69 natural disasters of various types and proportions across Europe, with 24 countries assisted by receiving aid totaling €3.7 billion. Over time, there was a need for some adaptations and changes. The deadline for aid applications has been extended leaving Member States 18 months to use the funds from the date of payment, a 10% advance has been introduced and some vague provisions are much clearer defined, all in line with a number of requirements made over the years by the European Parliament and local authorities. As this Disaster Fund is the fastest aid to affected countries, I consider it important to take into account in the light of future reforms the possibility of increasing the advance threshold from 10% to 15%, as well as shortening the deadlines for processing applications from six to four weeks - so that the assistance needed can be reached as soon as possible affected areas.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund is one of the Union's most significant instruments of solidarity with citizens and countries affected by serious natural disasters. It is therefore important that its operation is as fast, transparent and effective as possible. The initial regulation of 2002 was amended, in this sense, in 2014. This report tries to provide some suggestions for further improvements. First of all, it is necessary that the intervention of the EUSF should be quick, that all decision-making levels from the Commission to the Member States and local authorities react promptly, to prevent victims of natural disasters feel abandoned. It is also important to condition reconstruction interventions to a prevention and sustainability policy that reduces the risks and damage related to future disasters. In this respect, cohesion policy may play a complementary role to that of the EUSF. Finally, even if strides were made with the 2014 review, more could be done about transparency in the management of the funds allocated and communicating to the public to enable the beneficiaries and persons concerned to best follow the whole procedure.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund is an instrument to finance emergency operations following major natural disasters and extraordinary regional disasters in the EU, as well as countries leading accession negotiations. It is used for various natural disasters such as earthquakes, floods, forest fires, storms and the latest drought. So far, the fund has mobilised a total of €3.8 billion for more than 70 disasters in 24 Member States and accession countries. Due to climate change, the number of natural disasters in the EU has increased significantly and is becoming an increasingly serious problem, so we should insist on a flexible instrument to provide adequate and prompt assistance to citizens affected by major natural disasters. In the light of future reforms, the Commission calls on the Commission to take into account the possibility of increasing the advance threshold from 10% to 15%, as well as shortening the deadlines for processing applications from six to four weeks. The possibility of setting an eligibility threshold for regional natural disasters of 1% of regional GDP should also be considered. We need to work on preventing possible disasters, creating opportunities for faster reactions after disasters, and for greater transparency and better cooperation between different levels of decision-making. It is important that the EP works to prevent situations like the one in Croatia in 2013, when 18 months passed before the funds came into the hands of users.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report, giving a positive assessment of the implementation of this fund and the acuity of the reform, suggests that Member States should optimise synergies with Strategic Investment Funds - as regards the development of instruments for the prevention, adaptation and mitigation of natural disasters - and that reconstruction and these prevention, adaptation and mitigation instruments always take into account the sustainability of reconstruction and resources, increasing the capacity to resist the randomness of disasters. The report also makes a number of suggestions to the Commission, which are positive: raising the threshold for advances from 10% to 15%; reducing the deadlines for processing applications from six weeks to four weeks; fixing the eligibility threshold for damage caused by regional natural disasters at 1% of the regional GDP and take into account, in the assessment of applications, the level of socioeconomic development of the affected regions; the weighting of indicators other than GDP, such as HDI or IPS, for the assessment of eligibility. We consider the report to be positive, we vote in favour of it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — In my opinion, the European Union Solidarity Fund (FSEU) is one of the most distinctive symbols of European solidarity in times of need. As a Social Democrat, I am very happy that such an institution has existed here since 2002. At the same time, it is necessary that this institute be as efficient as possible, or to be able to handle requests from entities facing different types of natural disasters as quickly as possible. The challenge is made more urgent by the fact that many natural disasters have occurred in areas most affected by the economic crisis. I would also like to remind you that, of course, there is a need to maintain maximum transparency in the allocation of allocated funds. At the same time, long-term investment needs to be made in projects that will lead to the prevention of any future disasters in the same territory, which can be supported, e.g., by introducing ex ante conditions in setting cohesion policy funding mechanisms.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — Following the tragic floods in 2002, the European Union has introduced the European Union Solidarity Fund (Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002). It represents a direct expression of EU solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. It is intended not only for Member States, but also for candidate countries to join the EU. In 2014, amendments were made to the original Regulation to address the concerns of beneficiaries more effectively and process the applications of the countries affected by disasters and to include the drought in the list of disasters covered by the provisions (Regulation (EU) No 661/2014). In October 2015, the European Commission presented a report on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EFSEU) for 2014. The “Collective Regulation” proposed by the Commission on 14 September provides for a new review of the fund to improve speed and the effectiveness of the financing system of actions carried out as a matter of urgency. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU established the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in 2002 to deal with emergencies such as natural disasters and particularly in the Member States. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the evaluation of the EUSF and envisages various options to improve its effectiveness. We plan to increase the speed of the EUSF response, enhance collaboration between national and local actors and improve the risk prevention and management strategy. Finally, we would also like to consider the possibility of allowing the submission of single and joint applications by several eligible States affected by a transboundary natural disaster.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote. This vote concerned emergency disaster relief management, and we did not wish to stand in the way of such a scheme, even if it is under the control of the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and to bring European solidarity to the sinister regions of Europe. It was established in response to the major floods in the summer of 2002 in Central Europe. Since then, it has been used in 72 catastrophes of a wide variety of kinds, including floods, wildfires, earthquakes, storms and droughts. 24 European countries have been assisted with more than 3.8 billion euros. In view of the use of the ESF during its first years of existence and the ESF's specific situation report prepared by the Commission, I supported this own-initiative report which addresses the three specific aspects of improving the management of the fund: rapid reaction; prevention and complementarity with the Cohesion Funds; and transparency and cooperation between the different levels of decision-making.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
