text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position to change the functioning of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Among the recommendations made by the European Parliament, I consider the possibility for Member States to make a joint request for aid in the event of cross-border disasters. In my view, this is a common sense amendment. The European Parliament also supported a reduction in the processing times of applications from six to four weeks and an increase in the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15%. These are important demands which I hope to see put in place as quickly as possible in European legislation.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Today we are discussing the issue of a policy on insurance against natural disasters by the Member States of the European Union, the European Solidarity Fund. It ensures the Union's ability to help in the event of natural disasters. It is equally important that the proposal also includes measures to improve operational efficiency. Therefore, I do not believe that the proposal to reserve the amount allocated annually to this fund in the EU budget next year will result in great resistance. At the same time, I want to draw the attention of colleagues to the harmful trends that have begun to emerge after the recent natural disasters. As you know, the draft resolution is currently being debated in Parliament, calling for the costs of increasing resilience from one type of natural disaster, earthquakes, to be removed from the calculation of the government deficit. And only in a geographically limited area. And why, in this case, other types of natural disasters, such as floods, are ignored? And other regions? This is dangerous. The danger is that, in addition to the aid that the European Solidarity Fund can provide, Member States will have the opportunity to pursue unsustainable financial policies, to distort the provisions of the Growth and Stability Pact. I would like to emphasise that the European Solidarity Fund is an effective aid instrument, but the aid instrument must have a defined budget and specific objectives. And, most importantly, we cannot allow some Member States to justify infringements of the rules of good economic governance, using the pretext of natural disasters.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report refers to the evaluation process of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) set up in 2002 to deal with serious natural disasters affecting the Member States of the Union, which can be extended to the candidate countries. This own-initiative report, which I voted for, follows the report presented by the European Commission in October 2015 on the use of the EUSF in the previous year. From the analysis carried out, it can be concluded that, although it is impossible to predict disaster and emergency situations, it is desirable to improve the management of the consequences caused by them at its various stages, particularly in relation to sustainable damage repair and risk management. I endorse the rapporteur's idea of the need to make the EUSF more rapid activation, greater transparency in its use and greater cooperation between the different levels of decision-making. I also support the adoption of a prevention policy that promotes complementarity between the use of the EUSF and other European instruments, with particular emphasis on Cohesion Funds, particularly when dealing with infrastructure projects (which should take into account prevention aspects risk and potentially reduce costs arising from natural disasters).

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the action of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The European Union Solidarity Fund has played a key role in the EU's response to natural disasters in Member States such as earthquakes, floods, forest fires and storms. Since its inception, €3.8 billion has been mobilized for more than 70 disasters in 24 Member States. This report calls for improving the speed of response and thus reducing the lengths of the entire process by strengthening, in particular, the advance payment mechanism. The report calls on the Member States and the Commission to strengthen the transparency of procedures as well as better cooperation within European states with local authorities. Finally, I supported this text because it underlines the essential nature of developing synergies between the various funds and Union policies in the context of preventing the effects of natural disasters.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I am generally in favour of it, since changes and improvements are proposed in relation to simplification, speed in allocation of funds, reduced processing times, implementation of greater transparency, increasing the number of advances and the reduction of thresholds. However, I believe that an important opportunity to propose real improvement for disaster-affected populations is lost. It would have been time to extend the objectives of the Solidarity Fund to include humanitarian disasters and not just natural disasters. An excellent opportunity to use community funds to alleviate the effects of the migration crisis that is causing so many deaths on our borders. Lastly, the introduction of policies on gender equality and women's rights should have been considered as eligibility criteria for proposals, since women were one of the groups that suffer most virulently the consequences of natural disasters. I voted in favour, although I am aware of the limitations in the evaluation of the merits.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — I have decided to vote in favour of the resolution on the European Union Solidarity Fund, which proved to be a valid and effective instrument to ensure EU support for countries affected by the EU severe natural disasters. Since its establishment, the Fund has mobilised €3.8 billion to repair damage caused by more than 70 natural disasters in 24 beneficiary countries. The regulation is now being revised in order to respond more quickly to requests from affected countries and to speed up the allocation of resources, which now goes from 6 to 4 weeks, and above all increase the advance threshold of funds from 10% to 15%.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. “I voted in favour of this resolution. The Solidarity Fund (established in 2002 after the tragic floods in the EU) serves to express the EU's solidarity with the countries affected by serious natural disasters. The beneficiary countries may be EU countries or candidate countries for entry. Prevention is also an important part of the post-disaster recovery period, from the point of view of avoiding damage in future disasters. Cooperation with the Cohesion Fund is important here, where the risk prevention aspect should also be taken into account for infrastructure projects.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since its establishment in 2002, the EU Solidarity Fund has been very useful because it has mobilised a total of €3.8 billion in the context of more than 70 disasters involving 24 beneficiary states and accession countries and has been used to respond to various natural phenomena, including earthquakes, floods, forest fires, storms and in the last period even drought. It continues to remain one of the strongest symbols of solidarity in times of need. States affected by any disaster are unable to mobilise sufficient financial entitlements to eliminate damage and compensate the population, so it is important that the Solidarity Fund is flexible so that states can apply for an advance payment. The new regulation introduces the possibility of granting advance payments of up to 10% of the likely amount of aid, the maximum amount of which is EUR 30 million. The Solidarity Fund should always operate, as far as possible, in conjunction with other sources of financial assistance, in particular the European Structural and Investment Funds. Many natural disasters are caused by climate change, so investment must also be made in the prevention and mitigation of climate change.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - After the tragic floods in 2002, the EU established an instrument for immediate financial assistance to countries affected by severe natural disasters. All Member States and candidate countries may apply for assistance from the Fund if their total injury exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0,6% of gross national income. In this assessment of the Solidarity Fund, the rapporteur stresses that not all emergencies can be foreseen and the management of their consequences can be improved. To this end, the rapporteur addresses several aspects of the management of the Fund in his own initiative report, in particular its response time and the urgency of preventive measures, which is strongly linked to the need to coordinate the Solidarity Fund with other financial instruments. As the report strongly highlights the key importance of rapid response from Member States who need to address roles as soon as possible so that victims of accidents do not feel abandoned during the accident and the acquisition of funds, I supported it in the vote. However, it also seems important to me that the rapporteur specifically emphasises the positive effects of preventive measures, which must be an obligatory component of the post-natural disaster phase and reminds Member States to submit their risk prevention and management strategies in advance.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the European Union, the number of natural disasters has increased significantly as a result of climate change, as well as the severity and intensity of natural disasters. The EU Solidarity Fund was set up in response to the devastating floods that affected Central Europe in the summer of 2012 and has been very useful since its founding, as it mobilised a total of €3.8 billion in the context of more than 70 disasters involving 24 beneficiary states and accession countries.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as rather than expressly using the funds for disaster relief, it seeks to expand the list of eligible expenses to include investments to prevent natural disasters from occurring. The whole purpose of having a Solidarity Fund is to provide rapid and effective support to Member States dealing with the impact of a major disaster. The costs of preparation for such disasters should be conducted and funded by each individual Member State.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established in response to catastrophic floods that hit central Europe during the summer of 2012. In the light of future reforms, the Commission calls on the possibility of increasing the advance threshold from 10% to 15%, as well as shortening the deadlines for processing applications from six weeks to four weeks. The Commission is also invited to consider the possibility of setting an eligibility threshold for regional natural disasters of 1% of regional GDP and to take into account the levels of socio-economic development of affected regions when assessing the requirements. I accept this Report because it is very important that victims in natural disasters receive assistance immediately as quickly and efficiently as possible because the first moments after the disaster are the most difficult for them.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Union Solidarity Fund Report: Evaluation. Over the years, it has often been shown that the European Union Solidarity Fund is needed when natural disasters occur in the Member States and it is in the first place to help people who have found themselves in need as quickly as possible. There is still plenty of room for improvement. In particular, there is a reflection on greater flexibility, with which we can respond to disasters faster and more efficiently. However, we can be satisfied from the perspective of budget control and transparent management of taxpayer money as significant improvements have been made towards better financial management over the years.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The nation states know their needs much better than the Union.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report. The document recalls that the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the European Union to react in the event of major natural disasters and express European solidarity with Europe's disastrous regions. A Regulation provides that, whenever necessary to ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources, the Fund may be mobilised for the purpose of payment of advances up to EUR 50 000 000, corresponding appropriations to the general budget of the Union by adding it to the The proposal of the European Parliament and the Council for the current decision, to which this report responds, was not made in the context of a specific disaster. Instead, it aims to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the EU budget for 2017 in order to pay advances on a timely and effective basis in the event of a disaster that may occur next year. I believe it is important that this EU financial assistance, in addition to strengthening the clear political message of solidarity, also provides the assistance needed urgently by the citizens concerned.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. “The European Union Solidarity Fund was established in response to the devastating floods that occurred in Central Europe in the summer of 2012. This instrument enables the Union to respond to major natural disasters and exceptional regional disasters within the Community and in countries negotiating accession. In 2014, the Fund underwent a major reform, to streamline and simplify procedures and ensure a quicker response to the disaster, even within 6 weeks after the application. Unfortunately since the foundation of the Fund, the frequency of natural disasters has increased significantly, carrying serious impacts on societies. I therefore believe that this instrument should be significantly strengthened in the coming years. It is also necessary to further simplify the procedure for receipt of prepayments and payment of the final amount, as well as to ensure that the Fund is granted, managed and implemented as much transparency as possible. The discussion of the EU Solidarity Fund is also an excellent opportunity to remind the obligation on Member States to implement investments to prevent natural disasters. Such activities may be financed by, among other things, the Structural Funds.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ After the tragic floods of 2002, the European Union set up the European Union Solidarity Fund (Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002). It is an immediate translation of the Union's solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. It is addressed not only to the Member States but also to the candidate countries. I am of the view that better communication to the public is needed throughout the process to allow recipients or interested individuals to better follow the procedure for each particular application. This could be organised at the European Commission level, provided that there is a good flow of information between the different operational levels.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), since it was established, has enabled some €3.8 billion to be mobilised, for 24 beneficiary states and candidate countries to make faced with over 70 natural phenomena such as earthquakes, floods, forest fires, storms and, most recently, drought. The report, which I agree, states that after a disaster, it is necessary to provide for a simplified mechanism for submitting requests as well as the improvement of evaluation procedures to the order to facilitate the execution of payments. This goal was partly realized when the instrument was extensively revised in 2014, to ensure a faster response, in line with the many requests made over the years by the Parliament. We call for the process to be efficient and speedy, including to respond effectively to the demands of our citizens.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the European Union Solidarity Fund. The European Union Solidarity Fund is one of the most concrete and tangible instruments of support provided by the European Union to Member States. Since its founding in 2002, the Fund has been an important funding instrument for local governments and has been providing considerable support to mitigate the consequences of natural disasters across Europe. The proposal for a resolution expects Member States to optimise the use of existing EU funding, notably European Structural and Investment Funds for the purpose of preventing natural disasters and reminds the importance of developing synergies between different Union funds and policies. In particular, I support the request referred to the countries concerned, i.e. the beneficiary countries of the Fund, to take all measures aimed at disaster prevention and sustainable restoration of affected areas.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - The European Union Solidarity Fund enables the EU to respond to major natural disasters, to show solidarity with affected areas and countries, and it is also a significant source of funding for local and regional self-governments to mitigate the effects of natural disasters. I voted positively for this report because I believe that such a fund is very necessary, especially in times of major climate change, which caused the number of natural disasters to increase significantly. As an MEP from Croatia, a country that has been granted financial assistance four times in rectifying the consequences of natural disasters, and the last time in 2014 after catastrophic floods that hit the eastern part of Slavonia, I welcome any improvement in the functioning of the EUSF that will accelerate the process of obtaining assistance and improving the means of communication and cooperation with local and regional authorities. Croatia has seen on its own example the importance and well-being of the existence of such a fund several times, especially in 2014, but also faced some shortcomings of the EUSF in 2013, when approval was obtained only seven months after the submission of the application, and 18 months passed before funds came into the hands of users. Such situations, in which between emergency intervention and the arrival of funds from the Victims Fund feel forgotten, should be prevented at all costs in the future.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the European Union Solidarity Fund: I supported the assessment. Following the tragic disasters of 2002, the European Union established the European Union Solidarity Fund (for Member States as well as candidate countries). Member States may apply for assistance from the Fund if the total damage caused directly as a result of a natural disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0,6% of GNI (there are also provisions for minor accidents). Natural disasters are difficult to prevent, so it matters how quickly and how we regain after an accident. Emergency situations require emergency procedures. Rapid response to events is important in easing matters (Croatian beneficiaries waited a year and a half for approval of funds in the event of 2013 floods). The management of the situation and recovery after the disaster is something that can be influenced and the European Union Solidarity Fund is one of the important levers of assistance.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund is a tool for responding to natural disasters with a direct impact on people's lives, the natural environment or the economy of a given region and, in particular, to support public authorities in their emergency and recovery operations. Since its inception, it has mobilized a total of EUR 3.8 billion in over 70 disasters in 24 Member States and acceding countries. I voted in favour of the report because it responds to the finding that natural disasters have increased in number, severity and intensity and supports measures aimed, on the one hand, to improve the operating mechanisms of the instrument (simplifying procedures, gaining agility, raising the threshold for advance payments and increasing the transparency) and, on the other hand, improve Member States' capacities in disaster and emergency prevention and management.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: Created in 2002 following severe floods, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries that have suffered extraordinary natural disasters whose direct property damage amounts to more than €3 billion or more than 0.6% of the gross national income. The purpose of this report is to simplify procedures for mobilizing the EUSF in order to facilitate the implementation of payments to States affected by natural disasters. To achieve this, it recommends raising the threshold for advance payments from 10% to 15% and lowering the threshold for natural disasters to 1% of regional GDP. We believe that the EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and constitutes significant financial support for national and local authorities in the affected regions. In this context, we consider it appropriate to simplify the operation of the EUSF and to facilitate the execution of payments. I voted in favour.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — As a rule, Member States should stand in solidarity to fight natural disasters around the world. It is important that the aid is directed efficiently, both to Member States and to countries that inspire confidence in the proper use of measures. Another important issue is the amount of aid. In order for EU policy to be effective, the amount of aid should be increased for the countries that need it most and are entitled to it. The report adopted in this version raises concerns that these issues will not be properly organised, which is why I voted against the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ After the tragic floods in 2002, the European Union set up the European Union Solidarity Fund. This Fund will enable the immediate expression of EU solidarity towards countries affected by major natural disasters. The Fund may support candidate countries, in addition to Member States. I supported the present proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund is a tool for responding to natural disasters with a direct impact on people's lives, the natural environment or the economy of a given region and, in particular, to support public authorities in their emergency and recovery operations. Since its inception, it has mobilized a total of EUR 3.8 billion in over 70 disasters in 24 Member States and acceding countries. I voted in favour of the report because it responds to the finding that natural disasters have increased in number, severity and intensity and supports measures aimed, on the one hand, to improve the operating mechanisms of the instrument (simplifying procedures, gaining agility, raising the threshold for advance payments and increasing the transparency) and, on the other hand, improve Member States' capacities in disaster and emergency prevention and management.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the recently tabled 'general proposal', which also includes new provisions relating to simplification and easier mobilisation of funds.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the European Union Solidarity Fund: an assessment. Following the tragic flooding of 2002, the European Union introduced the European Union Solidarity Fund. It was an immediate demonstration of the Union’s solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. Due to their unpredictable nature, natural disasters not only cause distress to the people affected but also raise the issue of response times from governments that have to meet unforeseen costs. When a disaster occurs, it is often too late for prevention but it should be an integral part of the next stage. I voted in favour because I believe it is important to seize the opportunity to comply with standards when rebuilding structures that have been destroyed or carrying out repairs on infrastructure.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this report, the rapporteur analyzes the 2014 annual report, as well as the conclusions of the 2015 report, making some recommendations for future reforms to that fund, concerning the possibility of sending a single request between several States, where they are the victim of a transnational tragedy. The proposal also calls for the European Commission to increase advance payments from 10 to 15% and reduce the time to process applications from 6 to 4 weeks. We are therefore talking about a very balanced and highly consensual report in the Regional Development Committee, and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I am generally in favour of it, since changes and improvements are proposed in relation to simplification, speed in allocation of funds, reduced processing times, implementation of greater transparency, increasing the number of advances and the reduction of thresholds. However, I believe that an important opportunity to propose real improvement for disaster-affected populations is lost. It would have been time to extend the objectives of the Solidarity Fund to include humanitarian disasters and not just natural disasters. An excellent opportunity to use community funds to alleviate the effects of the migration crisis that is causing so many deaths on our borders. Lastly, the introduction of policies on gender equality and women's rights should have been considered as eligibility criteria for proposals, since women were one of the groups that suffer most virulently the consequences of natural disasters. I voted in favour, although I am aware of the limitations in the evaluation of the merits.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report, giving a positive assessment of the implementation of this fund and the acuity of the reform, suggests that Member States should optimise synergies with Strategic Investment Funds - as regards the development of instruments for the prevention, adaptation and mitigation of natural disasters - and that reconstruction and these prevention, adaptation and mitigation instruments always take into account the sustainability of reconstruction and resources, increasing the capacity to resist the randomness of disasters. The report also makes a number of suggestions to the Commission, which are positive: raising the threshold for advances from 10% to 15%; reducing the deadlines for processing applications from six weeks to four weeks; fixing the eligibility threshold for damage caused by regional natural disasters at 1% of the regional GDP and take into account, in the assessment of applications, the level of socioeconomic development of the affected regions; the weighting of indicators other than GDP, such as HDI or IPS, for the assessment of eligibility. We consider the report to be positive and we vote in favour of it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established by Regulation 2012/2002 following the severe floods in Central Europe in the summer of 2012 to enable the EU to respond to natural disasters. Since this report is mainly concerned with efficiency-enhancing measures, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidary Fund (EUSF) has mobilised in total EUR 3.8 billion in connection with more than 70 disasters. Against this background, disasters in Romania and France, which caused serious damages in 2014, were considered to be illegible for EUSF funding. This why the new regulation from 2014 made some clarification of the rules on the eligibility of regional natural disasters setting a threshold at 1.5% of regional GDP together with the possibility of making advance payments of up to 10% of the likely amount of aid. In addition, a six-week deadline by which the Commission must respond to applications has been introduced. Nevertheless, I agree with rapporteur that if we really want to stop victims feeling abandoned between emergency intervention and the arrival of EUSF funds, further reforms are needed. Therefore, we should increase the advance payments threshold from 10 to 15%, shorten the deadlines for processing the applications from six weeks to four weeks and allow for a single application to be submitted jointly by several eligible states at cross-border level. Taking the above into account, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I continue to deplore the UK Government’s refusal to complete its application for the EU Solidarity Fund for the floods that hit the north of the UK last winter, with serious long term consequences for my constituents in North West England.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted on the own-initiative report on the European Union Solidarity Fund. This fund was created after the floods in 2002, representing the concrete manifestation of solidarity within the EU with countries affected by major natural disasters. The rapporteur considers that the 12-week deadline for submission of dossiers for compensation is reasonable, taking the view that their rapid processing is important. In his view, situations where victims feel abandoned between emergency interventions and the arrival of EUSF funds should be avoided.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support this report, which assesses the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The Fund has been operating for almost 15 years, and I think it is a great example of how money from the EU budget can directly help European citizens. It is possible to support the Member States directly in the event of huge natural disasters, but also to respond to regional disasters of a smaller scale. Going forward, I see room for improvement mainly in better alignment of the functions of the Solidarity Fund and the Cohesion Funds. It is cohesion funds that should take into account risk prevention aspects in the case of infrastructure projects, which can help reduce costs related to necessary corrections after disaster.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report on the European Union Solidarity Fund by voting because I agree with a positive assessment of its functioning. This Fund is one of the most concrete and measurable displays of support that the European Union can provide to local communities in the event of disasters and disasters. In addition to eliminating the effects of these phenomena, the fund should also be used for preventive purposes to minimise the losses incurred. It is also necessary to fully control and improve the transparency of the use of funds from the Fund. Not only does the Court of Auditors, whose results of previous inspections have indicated certain irregularities, but also Member States whose final reports on the use of aid received should be made public and widely available. I voted in favour of the resolution because it reaffirms not only the many qualities of the operation of the Fund, but also points out issues which will improve its effectiveness.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the report evaluating the European Union Solidarity Fund. This fund was established in 2002 as the European Union's response to widespread flooding in Central Europe. Since this year, the fund's legal basis has been amended several times and has undergone comprehensive reform in 2014. The report therefore provided us with statistics on the use of the fund, as well as precise information on its functioning. Last but not least, the report also gave an overview of problematic areas, such as the process of approving applications too long, or the fact that the fund cannot be used to compensate for private losses. I think that the creation and functioning of this fund shows a strong sense of solidarity between the Member States of the European Union and a guarantee that, in the event of natural disasters, the Member State will not have to fight the consequences alone. I therefore believe that the Fund will remain a valuable instrument for financial assistance in the event of natural disasters and that its upcoming review will bring about improvements in the problematic areas of its application.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the European Union Solidarity Fund Report: Evaluation. The European Union Solidarity Fund is an instrument set up to enable the EU to respond to major natural and extraordinary regional disasters in the Union and countries negotiating accession. Since its creation, the Solidarity Fund has been very useful and the resources from it have been used to total the EU 3.8 billion for 70 natural disasters in 24 eligible Member States and acceding countries. Since the foundation of the Fund in the European Union, there has been a sharp increase in the number of natural disasters, which have become more severe and more intense as a result of climate change. It is therefore important to ensure that, in the future, in the allocation, management and implementation of the Solidarity Fund, ensure the maximum transparency and overview of the use of Solidarity Fund subsidies with a view to making the aid effective and at the right time.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The umbrella agreement between the United States and the European Union operates in a very sensitive field and which is certainly not the simplest legal aspect. It is also an international agreement and as such it would take precedence over EU domestic law. Since this issue is very important, I believe the European Court of Justice's intervention is right so that it can express itself on the compatibility of the agreement envisaged with the Treaties. That is why I have decided to vote for it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution of the GUE Group and for the ALDE Group, as they call for referral to the Court of Justice to verify the compatibility of the agreement between the EU and the United States on the protection of personal data with the Treaties. These texts point out that the European Data Protection Supervisor has raised questions on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Charter and European secondary data protection law, and in particular the right to a judicial remedy, the access of law enforcement agencies to personal data, limitation of the right of access to data subjects and periods of data retention. The European Data Protection Supervisor is further concerned that the competent data protection authorities of the United States may not fulfil the requirements of the Court of Justice to be considered fully independent and have effective powers of intervention, and is concerned about whether the competent data protection authorities in the United States will not meet the requirements of the Court of Justice. data protection will be able to block transfers of personal data if they do not comply with Union legislation.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on these two resolutions. Whilst I support better protection of personal data, I do not believe that the ECJ is the best institution to make that determination.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. — The proposal notes that there is legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16 TFEU) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7 and 8 and 52 (1)) on the right to the protection of personal data and Article 47 on the the right to an effective remedy. I agree that this is not the best agreement proposed, but it is certainly the best in the current situation. Moreover, the agreement does not restrict or violate the rights of natural persons, since it does not constitute a legal basis for data transmission. I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — On the agenda of the EP is a proposal from the Green Party rapporteur Albrecht, who requests the EP's consent to the protection of personal data between the United States of America and the European Union relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences on behalf of the European Union, its report proposes approval of the draft Council decision on this matter. Albrecht's proposal looks at the relevant aspects and their equilibrium and concludes that the aspects of law enforcement, judicial cooperation and the protection of the personal rights and personal data of European citizens are both in balance. However, Albrecht's proposal does not address concerns about the framework agreements raised, inter alia, by the European Data Protection Supervisor. In the light of the foregoing, GUE and ALDE, on substantially similar grounds, suggest, in separate proposals for decisions, that the Framework Agreement should now be brought before the European Court of Justice, which should give an opinion on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: This is a motion for a resolution requesting the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposal for an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purposes of the prevention and detection of criminal offences, investigations and prosecutions in the matter. These texts point out that the European Data Protection Supervisor has raised a number of questions on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Charter and European secondary data protection law, and in particular the right to a judicial remedy, access by law enforcement agencies to data of character personal, limitation of the right of access to data subjects and periods of data retention. These issues are relevant and legitimate, so I supported this resolution and voted against the Albrecht report on the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed in criminal offences.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — Since the Legal Service of the European Parliament has expressed reservations about the compatibility of this agreement with the European Treaties, I voted in favour of requesting the opinion of the Court of Justice.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted against the two motions for resolutions, tabled by the ALDE and GUE Groups respectively, to request an opinion of the Court of Justice on compatibility with treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data for the purpose of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes. The SD Group line defines the agreement not contrary to the primary law of the Union and the fundamental charter of rights. Instead, the agreement is considered as an additional tool to safeguard the principles of data protection and the same personal data that, already today, are transferred between the EU and the US for law enforcement activities criminal offences.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of asking the Court to give its opinion on the question. It seems to me that it is a question that goes beyond being in favour or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: giving the Court its proper role and not running the risk of the entry into force of a Treaty containing an instrument which could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the alternative resolution tabled by the GUE and in favour of ALDE in the Court's Opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data in connection with the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses. Our group has tabled an alternative resolution which considers that there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the Agreement provided for with the Treaties and requests that the Court of Justice be asked for an opinion on its compatibility with the Treaties.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — On these resolutions concerning the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information Processed for the Purposes of the Prevention, Detection, Investigation and Prosecution of Criminal Offences, I have argued the ALDE resolution and voted against that of the GUE. The centrist resolution calls for the Court of Justice to verify the compatibility of the EU-US agreement on the protection of personal data and treaties. The European Data Protection Supervisor is also concerned that the competent data protection authorities in the United States may not fulfil the requirements of the Court of Justice to be considered fully independent and have effective powers of intervention, and is concerned about whether the authorities responsible for data protection may not meet the requirements of the Court of Justice. data protection will be able to block transfers of personal data if they do not comply with EU data protection legislation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — I wanted to support this text and with it the request for an opinion of conformity with the Treaties by the Court of Justice, the Agreement between the United States of America and the Union European protection of personal information for the purpose of prevention, investigation, investigation and prosecution of crimes.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I disagree with the proposals for resolutions as I believe that there is no legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I also believe further cooperation is needed in the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Agreement which aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and measures when personal data is transferred for the purpose of enforcing criminal law between EU Member States and the US. The duration of the contract is unspecified.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution of the GUE Group and for the ALDE Group, which call for the Court of Justice of the European Union to be referred to the European Court of Justice to verify the compatibility of the agreement between the EU and the United States on the protection of personal data with the Treaties. European Data Protection Supervisor is concerned that the competent data protection authorities of the United States may not fulfil the requirements of the Court of Justice to be considered fully independent and have effective powers of intervention, and is concerned about whether the data protection authorities in the United States will not fulfil the requirements of the Court of Justice data will be able to block transfers of personal data if they do not comply with EU data protection legislation. On the other hand, I voted against the Albrecht report.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This motion for a resolution calls for the Court of Justice to be consulted on the compatibility of the European Treaties with the proposal for an agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purposes of prevention, investigation and criminal prosecution. The European Supervisor had raised a number of questions about the inadequacy of data protection safeguards, including the right to judicial recourse, the limitation of the right of access to data subjects and the period of data retention. The European Supervisor also doubts the complete independence of the US data protection authorities, a prerequisite for concluding such an agreement. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this agreement which will ensure high and binding standards for the protection of personal data exchanged between the European Union and the United States for prevention purposes , detection, investigation and prosecution of offences, including terrorism. In the future there will finally be binding standards of quality and clear rights for citizens of both sides of the Atlantic in the exchange of data between the police and the enforcement authorities law. The agreement will ensure that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic will be entitled to be informed in the event of data security breaches, to correct incorrect information and to request the compensation for damages. After six years of negotiations, the EU increases data protection with the US to a new level. Citizens' fundamental rights will be better protected than the current low standard of mere mutual recognition of standards.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a motion to have this file referred to the European Court of Justice to assess compatibility with existing EU data protection legislation. However, as the majority of MEPs did not support this referral, I voted against the report as a whole. The file itself provides for some additional protections on the protection of personal data but by no means goes far enough. It differentiates between EU and non-EU citizens, it would also mean that it would become more difficult to challenge the legality of data exchange in court. It may contradict existing EU data protection legislation. It doesn’t cover the protection of information exchanged between national security agencies or private entities either. For those reasons I voted in favour of referral but against the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this non-legislative resolution. UKIP do not respect decisions that derive from the European Court of Justice so we could not support this resolution. Voting against this resolution would lead to the agreement being voted on today. UKIP do not support accelerating EU-third country agreements, so an abstention was deemed the most appropriate vote.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against both proposals which would subject the entry into force of the ‘umbrella’ agreement on the protection of personal information relating to criminal offences between the EU and the US, because I do not see any added value in postponing and obstructing the overall process. I believe that the agreement has its merits, it corresponds to what the EP asked for several years ago and it should now be implemented.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution on the request for an opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection with the processing of personal data for the purposes of prevention; investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offences is a reasonable and correct proposal. It is particularly important that we look at all aspects of these agreements in order to protect the interests and, above all, the rights of citizens. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I am not welcome to vote on the resolutions tabled on the request for an opinion to the European Court of Justice, which was undenied by the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats groups and Nordic left since the agreement with the US on the protection of personal data related to criminal offences has already undergone a complete analysis. It has now been approved by Parliament and concluded by the Commission with its counterparty and is functional to the protection of personal information for the purpose of prevention, investigation, assessment and prosecution of offences that can seriously harm. On top of that, there is the favourable opinion of Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, which certifies not only that the agreement is on a proper legal basis, but also ensures a high level of protection of fundamental rights to the protection of personal data and contribute to legal certainty as well as to more effective cooperation with the US in law enforcement activities. In these moments of unbelievable uncertainty caused by international terrorism, in order to allow the authorities to act promptly, they must first be assured that they can cooperate by exchanging sensitive data. Thus, the proposed proposal would risk slowing missions intended for intercontinental security.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties on the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offences.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. “I voted in favour of an agreement between the United States of America and the EU on the protection of personal information related to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes. I believe that the provisions in the contract contribute to building a security system, strengthen detection and downplay and facilitate investigation. The agreement makes it easier for relevant authorities to prevent terrorist activities. An important aspect on this point is that the contract itself does not provide a legal basis for the transfer of personal data, but only adds a layer of privacy protection to personal data transmitted under other contracts. The agreement also contains provisions specifying post-step procedures in the event of interference with basic data. I believe this agreement will contribute to increased security.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against asking the European Court of Justice for an opinion on compatibilities with the Treaties with regards to the EU-US Umbrella agreement as it is essential that the EU and US implement this decision as soon as possible in order to ensure and safeguard the digital rights and data protection of European citizens. Currently, bilateral agreements with inadequate data protection standards exist, and thus the implementation of the Umbrella agreement will help to protect citizens further.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this non-legislative resolution. UKIP do not respect decisions that derive from the European Court of Justice so we could not support this resolution. Voting against this resolution would lead to the agreement being voted on today. UKIP do not support accelerating EU-third country agreements, so an abstention was deemed the most appropriate vote.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I have rejected the resolutions, tabled by the political groups in the centre and the extreme left, calling for the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purpose of preventing and detecting personal information criminal offences, investigations and prosecutions in this regard. These proposals for resolutions are only a new political manoeuvre on the part of those who will remain opposed to the conclusion of this agreement in order to delay its implementation. This is irresponsible behaviour, while this agreement will undoubtedly strengthen our cooperation with the United States in the fight against terrorism, while ensuring a high framework for protecting personal data.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Although it was tabled by my group, it was without hesitation that I voted against this resolution calling for the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of the framework agreement with the European Treaties. Under the guise of rigour, it was actually nothing but a final dilatory manoeuvre to prevent the approval of the framework agreement. I am pleased that a majority in this House has rejected this text. Obviously, some are more concerned about hypothetical non-compliance, rather than increasing citizens' rights and enhancing their security.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, so I can vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of these texts. This is a motion for a resolution requesting the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposal for an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purposes of the prevention and detection of criminal offences, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences. the matter. The European Data Protection Supervisor has expressed serious reservations, including the independence of the US competent authorities and their ability to oppose the illegal transfer of personal data.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - Any cooperation between law enforcement authorities must be based on the principles of transparency and accountability.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the Court's opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection with the processing of personal data for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution criminal offences, as any cooperation between prosecution authorities must be based on the principles of transparency and accountability.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement, which aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and safeguards for when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU or the Member States and the US and supplements, where necessary, data protection safeguards in existing and future data transfer agreements or national provisions authorising such transfers. Therefore, it will bring a significant improvement to the current situation. However, I believe that there is a need to solve its main problem, the absence of sufficient rights to judicial redress for permanent residents who are non-EU citizens, as they are excluded from the protections of the Judicial Redress Act. Moreover, we must ensure that the European Data Protection Authorities keep their rights to independently assess the data protection environment, as the current wording would solidify the status for the US, regardless of what changes they would make to their internal legislation on data protection.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the motion for a resolution on the grounds that the Treaty has all the necessary safeguards mechanisms, as well as democratic controls to ensure the protection of the data of citizens of the Union.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I did not support this resolution given the fact that I have reservations regarding the compatibility of the Umbrella agreement with the Charter and secondary EU data protection legislation, especially concerning the right to judicial redress, the access of law enforcement agencies, limitation of data subject access rights and data retention periods.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: I voted in favour of the two motions for resolutions tabled today, which call for the opinion of the Court of Luxembourg on the compatibility of an international agreement with the treaties. It allegedly aims to ensure the protection of the rights of EU citizens when their personal data are transferred to the United States under other agreements, whether European or bilateral. It is known that the very definitions of “personal data” and “data processing” differ on one side and on the other side of the Atlantic, which in itself poses a problem. It is also known that rights of access, rectification and recourse are limited in the United States for foreign nationals, despite the Judicial Redress Act of February 2016. Even the European Data Protection Supervisor considers that this agreement does not provide sufficient guarantees as to the effectiveness of the possibilities of recourse. The 1974 Privacy Act, for example, has not been amended. Neither the EU nor its Member States are considered entities whose citizens can bring civil action against certain US agencies. All this should prompt the utmost caution.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of asking the Court to give its opinion on the question. It seems to me that it is a question that goes beyond being in favour or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: giving the Court its proper role and not running the risk of the entry into force of a Treaty containing an instrument which could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against seeking an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offenses. The US-EU Agreement on the protection of personal information relating to criminal offenses establishes a framework of data protection principles and safeguarding measures.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of seeking an opinion from the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offences. There is legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16 of the TFEU) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52(1) as regards the right of individuals to protection of personal data and Article 47 as regards the availability of an effective judicial remedy) therefore in my opinion, we need an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution to seek the Court's opinion on the compliance of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences with the Treaties, because this is the position of the ALDE Group which I decided to follow when this vote.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I agree with the European Data Protection Supervisor that there are shortcomings in the agreement between the European Union and the United States on the protection of personal data, to such an extent that I require the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the agreement with the Treaties. I voted in favour.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against resolutions aimed at delaying the agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purpose of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting criminal offences. The protection of personal data is ensured by this new text. In this period of significant terrorist threat, it is important to cooperate better with our partners in the criminal field.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the resolutions before us. An opinion will be obtained from the ECJ to determine whether the agreement is compatible with the EU Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. In particular, as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data, the principle of non-discrimination and the right to an effective remedy and a fairer procedure.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, so I can vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree with the European Data Protection Supervisor that there are shortcomings in the EU-US agreement on the protection of personal data. I therefore approve his request to refer the matter to the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of this agreement with the European Treaties.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The conclusion of the 2009 final report is that an international agreement that would oblige the EU and the US to apply harmonised common data protection principles for transatlantic data transfers in the field of prosecution would be the best solution. The purpose of the Agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of personal information and to strengthen cooperation between the United States and the European Union in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. In its statement of 26 October 2016, the Data Protection Task Force pointed out that some clarification may be needed to ensure that the level of personal data protection provided by the Roof Agreement is fully aligned with EU law. To this end, special attention should be paid to the definition of the terms “personal data” and “data processing”, the period of data retention, and access could be improved by establishing a mechanism for the right to indirect access. I supported the proposal for this resolution because I believe there is legal uncertainty regarding the compatibility of the Agreement with the provisions of the Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and that it is necessary to seek the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the request for an opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information on the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of these two proposals. Both texts call on the European Court of Justice (ECJ) to rule on the compatibility of such an agreement between the United States and the EU with regard to the European Treaties. The ECJ's reservations concern the issue of the independence of the competent US authorities and the real possibilities of blocking data transfers in the event of a dispute, which seems to me consistent.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted against. The proposal calls for the Court of Justice to clarify whether the US-EU agreement on the protection of personal data in relation to the prevention of criminal offences complies with EU law. On the basis of the opinion of the European Parliament's legal experts, I conclude that the agreement is compatible with EU law, and recourse to the Court would only unnecessarily delay cooperation processes.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. — These are two motions for resolutions submitted by the GUE Group and by the ALDE Group requesting that the Court of Justice issue an opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposal for an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purposes of prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences. These two resolutions raise relevant issues since the European Data Protection Supervisor is concerned that the competent authorities of the United States will not meet the requirements of the Court of Justice and are therefore not completely independent. I therefore supported these two common sense resolutions by voting for them.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because the Agreement is sufficiently clear and correct in its legal basis and does not require further confirmation of this from the Court of Justice, which will merely delay its implementation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I voted against this resolution seeking the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Treaties. Such a request would have had the effect of suspending the implementation of the agreement and, ultimately, would have risked jeopardizing its conclusion. This agreement provides the personal data of European citizens with a level of protection for which the European Union has been fighting for years. It therefore seems unacceptable to me to prevent the immediate implementation of an agreement which represents an undeniable step forward for Europeans.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Motions for a resolution have been tabled by the GUE/NGL and ALDE groups. The two motions, with different reasoning, are equally concerned whether the draft agreement indicated is in line with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights and proposes that Parliament seek the resolution of the European Court of Justice on the proposed agreement by the Treaties compatibility with it. Since, in my view, the envisaged agreement satisfactorily guarantees the protection of personal data of individuals, non-discrimination and the right to an effective remedy and to a fair trial, I considered the concerns of the two groups unfounded. So I rejected both drafts.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of referring the EU-US agreement on the protection of personal data to the Court of Justice, an agreement which suffers from many shortcomings.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution, which sought to ask the CJEU for its opinion on the compatibility with the treaties of the agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purposes of the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences. Seizing the CJEU is actually merely an artifice set up by the groups opposed to this agreement for the sole purpose of postponing its provisional execution.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution seeking an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses following the Parliament’s Legal Service opinion.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - The aim here is to obtain an opinion from the European Court of Justice on whether the agreement is agreed with the Treaties and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, in particular as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data, the principle of non-discrimination and the right to a an effective remedy and a fair procedure.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Legal certainty must be obtained as to whether the agreement is compatible with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union with regard to the rights of individuals to the protection of personal data, the principle of non-discrimination and the right to an effective remedy and a fair trial.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — In view of the existing legal uncertainties, it is appropriate to refer the Court of Justice to an opinion on the conclusion of an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences the protection of related personal information is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties. It is very important that the agreement guarantees the fundamental right to the highest level of protection and proper implementation of personal data. Cooperation between the United States of America and the European Union and its Member States in relation to the prevention, investigation, disclosure or prosecution of criminal activities, including terrorism, shall be strengthened in accordance with the provisions of the Treaties and in accordance with the provisions of the Treaties data protection principles and guarantees. It is also necessary to ensure that the provisions of the Agreement are compatible with the principle of non-discrimination and the right to an effective remedy and to a fair trial.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted against the proposal of my colleagues because, on the contrary, I believe that it is suitable for the United States and the EU to cooperate with each other in order to continue the exchange of information reciprocal regarding the personal data of citizens. I do not consider that there is any incompatibility between the Agreement, the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8, 21, 47 and 52 (1)) for as regards the right of individuals to personal data protection, the principle of non-discrimination and the right to an effective remedy and an impartial court. Therefore I expressed negative

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I consider it important to point out that the 'umbrella agreement' does not provide a legal basis for the transfer of personal data. The legal basis for data transfers is contained in existing EU-US agreements, bilateral agreements between Member States and the US or in national laws providing for the exchange of personal data (e.g. international agreements on passenger data records, monitoring programme financing of terrorist activities or on mutual legal assistance). The umbrella agreement complements the protection and safeguards laid down in these agreements and enhances and harmonises the rights of the data subjects. The Agreement does not apply to data exchanges between national security authorities, since they do not fall within the competence of the Union. It does not apply either to transatlantic transfers between private entities (e.g. governed by contractual provisions or EU-US privacy system), or subsequent access to US law enforcement authorities or US national authorities for the security of that data in the US. In view of all of the above, I consider that it is not necessary to ask the Court for an opinion on the compatibility of the agreement provided for with the Treaties, and therefore I have not supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the conclusion of this agreement with the United States in order to strengthen our cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, while ensuring a high data protection framework. I am therefore firmly opposed to any political manoeuvre aimed at postponing the implementation of this agreement, which is why I have decided to vote against the resolution asking for a legal opinion from the CJEU to verify the compatibility of this agreement with the Treaties. I would point out that the Commission, the guardian of the Treaties, is negotiating this agreement, so there is no reason to question its accounting.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this non-legislative resolution. UKIP do not respect decisions that derive from the European Court of Justice so we could not support this resolution. Voting against this resolution would lead to the agreement being voted on today. UKIP do not support accelerating EU-third country agreements, so an abstention was deemed the most appropriate vote.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — There is no doubt such an important and highly controversial issue as the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, disclosure and prosecution of criminal offences is compatible with the EU The provisions of the Treaties must be assessed and evaluated by the European Court of Justice. Standards of personal data protection in the European Union are very high, which can not always be said about US practices. Therefore, we must avoid the possibility of ambiguities.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution seeks to ask the Court of Justice to rule on the compatibility of the agreement between the US and the EU on the protection of personal data in the field of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of infringements, because it considers that there are doubts of compliance of this agreement with the Charter and EU secondary data legislation. I do not share the view that an opinion of the Court of Justice on this matter is necessary, since the Committee on Legal Affairs itself considers that the agreement is based on the correct legal basis, ensures a high degree of protection of the fundamental right to personal data, promotes legal certainty and will trigger improvements in law enforcement cooperation with the United States. To that extent, I believe that this motion for a resolution is merely a dilatory expedient which could delay the implementation of the agreement for another two years, unjustifiably. In view of the above, I voted against this motion for a resolution, because I believe that the European Parliament should give a signal of support rather than fragility to the conclusion of this agreement, so that the negotiations on its implementation are not postponed.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this agreement is to protect the right to privacy within the framework of cooperation between the United States and the European Union in the field of counter-terrorism. However, the standards of protection do not conform to the requirements set out in European law, and a number of exceptionality clauses are maintained for the United States, perpetuating an asymmetrical relationship between the Union and the US. On the other hand, it regulates rights on the basis of citizenship, because it guarantees citizens of Member States of the Union more rights than to persons residing or operating there without being citizens or citizens. Finally, by raising this type of regulation to the category of international agreement, what is being done is to impose obstacles to judicial investigations (many of which are currently being developed) on this subject, by having this text a higher character than the Treaties on which the claims are based. For all these reasons, I voted against this agreement.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to abstain from this non-legislative resolution. UKIP do not respect decisions that derive from the European Court of Justice so we could not support this resolution. Voting against this resolution would lead to the agreement being voted on today. UKIP do not support accelerating EU-third country agreements so an abstention is the most appropriate vote.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against seeking an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offenses. The US-EU Agreement on the protection of personal information relating to criminal offences establishes a framework of data protection principles and safeguarding measures.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
