text: in writing. ‒ It is highly likely, taking into account concerns and warnings from relevant EU bodies about a potential breach of EU law, that there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the agreement with the provisions of the Treaties (Art. 16 TFEU) and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights (Articles 7, 8, 21, 47 and 52 (1)) as regards the rights of individuals to the protection of personal data, Article 47 as regards the right to effective remedy, as well as the principle of non-discrimination and the right to a fair trial. It therefore appears necessary to ask the Court of Justice of the EU for an opinion on the compatibility of the forthcoming agreement with the Treaties.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - In the European Parliament resolution on obtaining an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data in the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences with the European Union. Contracts I abstained. I do not believe that there is a great deal of legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the Treaties (Article 16 TFEU) and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. However, a reliable expert opinion cannot hurt.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against a resolution to obtain the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Data in the Prevention, Investigation, Detection and Prosecution of Criminal Offences with the Treaties. I believe that all legal dilemmas regarding the TTIP Agreement have already been resolved and this requirement, according to the Court of Justice of the European Union, aims to delay the procedure and ultimately repeal an agreement that will bring many new jobs to the European Union, increase investment and raise economic growth, which is will be most familiar with the welfare of citizens and citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Any cooperation between law enforcement authorities must be based on the principles of transparency and accountability.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, and therefore I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — The signing of the Agreement on the protection of personal data transferred and processed in connection with the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences between the United States and the European Union constitutes an important step towards strengthening cooperation in order to combat terrorism and organised crime internationally. It will allow the protection of personal information in the context of exchanges of information between the two parties, regulated by other specific bilateral agreements. In this context, there is fear that the agreement will replace the provisions of the European Treaties in force, establishing rules incompatible with the acquis communautaire. I believe that these fears are unfounded, since the present agreement does not establish new legal bases, but only complements existing agreements (PNR, TFTP or MLA). That is why I reject the resolutions here, starting from the idea that we need this kind of strategic agreements in order to be able to continue to support the European project. The European Parliament is the institution which can give the necessary legitimacy for this type of approach.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: I agree with the rapporteur that there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the envisaged agreement with the provisions of the Treaties, in particular Article 16 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular Articles 7 and 8 thereof, Article 52 (1) as regards the right of natural persons to the protection of personal data, and Article 47 thereof on access to an effective judicial remedy.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I do not support the Motion for a Resolution seeking an opinion of the Court on the compliance of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences with the Treaties, nor the Motion for a Resolution on Seeking the Court's opinions on the compatibility of the proposed Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information relating to the Prevention, Investigation, Detection and Prosecution of Criminal Offences with the Treaties. I consider that seeking the opinion of the court would unnecessarily extend the procedure for concluding an agreement and that the assessment of the European Parliament's legal services was correctly assessed when it found that Article 16, combined with Article 218 (6) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) constitutes the proper legal basis of the proposal.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — This Agreement guarantees additional protection of personal data in cases where it has been transferred and processed for the purpose of prevention, investigation, detection and initiation of criminal activities such as terrorism. Also, the agreement itself does not provide a legal basis for the transfer of personal data - it simply adds a layer of privacy of personal data transferred within other agreements. I voted yes, because I believe that this agreement allows great progress in the preservation of private data, in the case where it is transferred between the European Union and the US, without interfering with the work of legal and police authorities. The above will be subject to regular controls whose results will be visible publicly.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have not supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on obtaining the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data in the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences with the Treaties. My EPP political group assessed that there was legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the proposal for an agreement with the Treaties and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and it was therefore the desire to ask the court for an opinion on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of asking the Court to give its opinion on the question. It seems to me that it is a question that goes beyond being in favour or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: giving the Court its proper role and not running the risk of the entry into force of a Treaty containing an instrument which could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution, as it is my belief that at this moment is fundamental to prioritise the improvement of our security procedures. In particular, I believe it is very important to achieve a high level of coordination with the USA.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to follow the S&D position and did not support the amendments of the other factions.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of asking the Court to give its opinion on the question. It seems to us that it is a question that goes beyond being in favour or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: giving the Court its proper role and not running the risk that a Treaty containing an instrument which could be incompatible with our legal system will enter into force.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I believe that there is legal uncertainty as to whether the draft agreement is compatible with the provisions of the Treaties (Article 16 TFEU) and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (Articles 7, 8 and 52 (1)) on the right to the protection of personal data and Article 47 on the right to an effective remedy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: on 3 December 2010, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations for an agreement between the European Union and the United States of America on the protection of personal data transferred and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism, in the context of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters (hereinafter referred to as the framework agreement). This agreement has raised doubts about its compatibility with the Charter and secondary EU data protection legislation, in particular as regards the right to judicial remedy, access by law enforcement agencies, limitation of access to data subject access and retention of data. This resolution seeks to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties. We do not recognise the legitimacy of this court, shaped to the interests of this process of capitalist integration of the EU.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to seek an opinion from the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of the Agreement with the Treaties and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular as regards the right of individuals to the protection of their personal data, the principle of the European Court of Justice. non-discrimination and the right to an effective remedy and a fair procedure. I voted in favour of this request because I believe that any critical review of this agreement should be used.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. — Proposals for Resolutions of the European Parliament B8-1304/2016 and B8-1305/2016 requiring the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data in the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences I did not support the Treaties. The conclusion of an international agreement enables more effective and closer cooperation between the EU and the US in the exchange of data related to law enforcement. I believe that the Agreement at the same time ensures the protection of personal data and privacy and does not disproportionately affect the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, such as, in particular, the right to protection of personal data, privacy and the right to effective remedy and impartial court

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The following recommendation is the subject of the draft umbrella agreement between the United States and the European Union on data protection with regard to criminal offences. This agreement presents a number of obligations and rights in relation to the United States and the EU for the protection of personal data when transferred overseas. The objective of the agreement is to put European citizens on the same footing as US citizens whose personal data can already enjoy the protection arising from existing European legislation. Although the following agreement represents a step forward in data protection, especially since personal data is still transmitted between the EU and the US, there are some points that remain not much clear. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the European Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – On Albrecht we voted against the report. We supported the referral of the file to the European Court of Justice to assess compatibility with existing EU data protection legislation. The file itself provides for some additional protections but by no means goes far enough. It differentiates between EU and non-EU citizens, it would also mean that it would become more difficult to challenge the legality of data exchange in court. It may contradict existing EU data protection legislation. It doesn’t cover the protection of information exchanged between national security agencies or private entities either. For those reasons we voted against.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this agreement is to establish a framework of data protection principles and guarantees when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, on the one hand, and the European Union or its Member States, on the other. Its aim is to ensure a high level of protection of the personal data of data subjects in the Union when they exchange them with the United States. Together with the National Front, I oppose the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data. The agreement provides for certain data protection rights and guarantees, but these are insufficient. The European Data Protection Supervisor recommends essential improvements to ensure that the provisions on judicial remedies are effective. It also states that massive transfers of sensitive data are not allowed. Furthermore, so far, the European Union or its Member States have not been declared by the United States Department of Justice as one of the countries whose citizens can bring civil actions against certain US government agencies under the 1974 Privacy Act. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Supporting better protection of personal information, yet believing that such matters should be determined between the UK and the USA, and noting that this will not impact on the UK anyway as the government is expected to opt out of this, I felt it appropriate to abstain.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences. I support this agreement, which will allow standards for the protection of all personal data, such as name, address or conviction, in cooperation between EU and US law enforcement authorities in criminal matters.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: The purpose of the agreement is to establish a framework of data protection principles and guarantees when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, of the one part, and the European Union or its Member States, of the other part. Its aim is to try to ensure adequate protection of the personal data of data subjects in the Union when they exchange them with the United States. I have always opposed the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data, especially with our American partners since their highly questionable practices were revealed by Edward Snowden and Julian Assange. The agreement provides for certain data protection rights and guarantees, but these are largely inadequate. I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. Indeed, it provides protection (right of access and correction under certain conditions in particular) to European citizens whose data are exchanged with the United States in the context of the fight against crime and terrorism. This is a breakthrough because, in some cases, this protection was weak. However, the Legal Service of the European Parliament considers that the agreement does not comply with the Treaties or the Charter of Fundamental Rights, in particular because it does not offer sufficient judicial recourse to the US authorities and that it outputs any additional safeguards that the Data Protection Directive may provide to from its entry into force in 2018. I also supported the resolutions calling for the opinion of the Court of Justice in this regard.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement approved today between the European Union and the United States is the landing point of a path begun in 2010 by Parliament to call for stronger measures in the field of protection of personal data exchanged for the purpose of countering crime. The Albrecht report, which I supported, concludes a six-year course of negotiations by defining some central points which do not form the legal basis for data transfer, but establish a Supplement of security measures aimed at the protection of those which are already legally traded between the two sides of the Atlantic today. The text allows data protection authorities to verify compliance with the new measures at any time and guarantees citizens the right to be informed in the event of violations of security, to claim damages and to be able to correct incorrect information. These provisions are also added to those which set limits for subsequent data transfers and on the retention period thereof. I am convinced that the agreement is a marked improvement in the regulatory framework.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The “Framework Agreement” is intended to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the protection of personal data when transmitted and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism, within the framework of police cooperation and judicial system in criminal matters, between the competent authorities of the European Union and the United States. However, there are serious doubts, including the European Data Protection Supervisor, about the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and with the Union's secondary data protection law, in particular as regards the right to a judicial remedy, access by police and judicial authorities, the limitation of the data subject's access rights and data retention periods, among others. Doubts requiring the intervention of the Court of Justice of the European Union. As the GUE/NGL and ALDE Motions for Resolutions requesting the ECJ's opinion on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Union Treaties were rejected, I voted against.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I abstained from voting on this recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data in connection with the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses. Our group has tabled an alternative resolution which considers that there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the Agreement provided for with the Treaties and requests that the Court of Justice be asked for an opinion on its compatibility with the Treaties. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of the agreement is to establish a framework of data protection principles and guarantees when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, on the one hand, and the European Union or its Member States, on the other, in order to ensure a high level of data protection. Treatment could only relate to the prevention and detection of criminal offences, including terrorism. I have always opposed the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data, especially since the rights and guarantees of the agreement are insufficient. The European Data Protection Supervisor even recommends essential improvements to ensure that the provisions on judicial remedies are effective. Finally, the EU or its Member States have not been declared by the US Department of Justice as one of the countries whose citizens can bring civil action against certain US government agencies under the 1974 Privacy Act. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report represents a first proposal for an Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information, which the recent development of technologies has put the center of attention, especially through the Internet network and social media. I think it is important to promote these types of bilateral agreements in order to ensure high data protection in the interests of citizens. For these reasons I supported the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the European Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences. The purpose of the agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular the right to privacy with regard to the processing of personal data, when they are transferred to the competent authorities of the European Union, its Member States and the United States for that purpose.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, and therefore I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to the conclusion of the said Agreement, since this Agreement between the European Union and the United States of America will significantly contribute to increasing the security of citizens. Thus, it talks about the protection of personal data in transmission and processing aimed at preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting crimes, including terrorism, which is currently on the rise.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Agreement which aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and measures when personal data is transferred for the purpose of enforcing criminal law between EU Member States and the US. The duration of the contract is unspecified.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. - I have always opposed the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data. The agreement provides for certain data protection rights and guarantees, but these are insufficient. Essential improvements to ensure the effectiveness of the provisions on judicial remedies have been recommended by the European Data Protection Supervisor. I therefore voted against this agreement.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement between the EU and the US on the protection of personal data during their transfer and/or processing, aims to ensure a high level of protection of fundamental rights and personal freedoms, especially the right to privacy. Such an agreement will not represent a legal basis for data transfer. It aims to improve, harmonise and provide guarantees to the rights of the persons concerned. The Agreement applies to transfers of personal data between law enforcement authorities in the Union or Member States and corresponding authorities in the United States in order to collect and prevent crime; and covers all data transfers between the above authorities, regardless of the nationality or place of residence of the person concerned. The agreement also provides that each Party implements the provisions without arbitrary or unjustified discrimination between its citizens and those of the other Contracting Party. It also includes provisions establishing the basic principles for data protection, such as limitations on use, preservation of integrity and rules for subsequent transfers. The agreement also defines individuals' rights and administrative and judicial recourse rights.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: The purpose of this agreement is to establish data protection safeguards when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. To achieve this, this agreement will set the duration of data retention. The individuals concerned would be able to avail themselves of rights with regard to any transatlantic transfer of personal data in the law enforcement field, namely the right of access to data, the right to rectify their data and the right to file an administrative or judicial appeal if the competent person does not does not accept the result of his application. We have always opposed the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data. Although this agreement is in the right direction, the data protection guarantees it provides are insufficient. This is evidenced by the report of the European Data Protection Supervisor, which recommends serious improvements to ensure that the provisions on judicial remedies are effective. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted against the resolutions in question because I believe that there is no legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the agreement in question with the provisions of the Treaty on operation of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in relation to the right of individuals to the protection of personal data. Thanks to the agreement approved today, for the first time, we will have a data protection instrument fully and consistently applicable to transatlantic data exchanges in the field of cooperation Police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. In addition, the agreement in question will confirm in the transatlantic context the general requirements on international data transfers provided for in the European Directive adopted last April on protection natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purpose of preventing, investigating, finding and prosecuting crimes or enforcement of criminal penalties. This agreement therefore represents a step in the right direction.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a motion to have this file referred to the European Court of Justice to assess compatibility with existing EU data protection legislation. However, as the majority of MEPs did not support this referral, I voted against the report as a whole. The file itself provides for some additional protections on the protection of personal data but by no means goes far enough. It differentiates between EU and non-EU citizens, it would also mean that it would become more difficult to challenge the legality of data exchange in court. It may contradict existing EU data protection legislation. It doesn’t cover the protection of information exchanged between national security agencies or private entities either. For those reasons I voted in favour of referral but against the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this legislative consent procedure vote. UKIP principally do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries. However, as this agreement is largely seeking to improve data protection safeguards and is not directly applicable to the UK, unless our sovereign government wishes to participate, it was more appropriate to abstain on this agreement.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ From the point of view of the content, the agreement, although not perfect, represents a step ahead of the status quo, especially in the light of the fact that personal data is transferred anyway between the EU and the USA. However, some important issues remain open; in particular, judicial review is excluded for certain types of data such as PNRs; being an international agreement it takes precedence over domestic law of the EU and it will be the umbrella agreement and not the relevant European legislation on this issue the framework for rights that European citizens can enjoy. Moreover, the fact that it is an agreement with the US could be a political problem in the light of possible ideological hostility to strike agreements with the US.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: I supported this agreement, which will ensure high and binding data protection standards for transatlantic data exchange between police authorities. This agreement covers the transfer of all personal data for prevention purposes and will allow criminal prosecution, especially in matters of terrorism. This will ensure strong rights for citizens on both sides of the Atlantic.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the report on the protection of personal information relating to criminal offences between the EU and the US because I am convinced there is need to have a sort of ‘umbrella’ over all the data protection clauses included in all the EU-US agreements to date. Also, and I find personally very important, the agreement brings the possibility for the citizens to seek judicial redress in case there is a breach in data protection by one of the parties concerned. Finally, I welcome that public independent oversight bodies which will ensure the data protection rules are respected are part of the agreement.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information for the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences. Although effective treatment of criminal offences should be a priority for us, I believe that this report does not adequately address the need to protect citizens' personal data, and I therefore voted against it.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Favourable opinion for this report which provides for the initiation of negotiations between the EU and the United States with regard to the protection of personal data for the purpose of prevention, investigation, assessment and prosecution of offences, including terrorism, within the framework of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ No doubt, when the negotiations for the conclusion of this Agreement were held in 2010, no one could have imagined a real disbursement of the structure then Existing: the Arab Spring and the establishment of the Islamic State, the war in Crimea and relations with Russia, so as not to address the onset of terrorism in Europe. With the hope that such strategic foresight will emerge more frequently, I am voting in favour of the measure. The content of the Agreement aims to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular the right to private life for treatment of personal data when there is a transfer to the authorities regarding the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism. The Agreement does not, in itself, form the legal basis for the exchange of data since it is provided for in others, but complements the safeguards and guarantees provided for by them and strengthens and harmonises rights of interested parties. Parties are required to set up supervisory authorities to control the implementation of the agreement, citizens' complaints and to report any violations of the agreement.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offences

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The so-called 'Framework Agreement on the Protection of Personal Data' with the United States has been debated over the past five years. The European Parliament's position has always been to ensure that European citizens saw their rights respected. I am not ignoring the fact that cooperation and the exchange of information with the United States in the fight against crime is fundamental for the European Union. However, as I have argued in a number of other areas, we cannot sacrifice everything in the name of security. That is why I am pleased that clear limits have been set on the use of the data transmitted and on the retention period. On the other hand, the US administration has agreed to create an ombudsman and to recognise European citizens the fundamental right to judicial protection. It is by acknowledging this new framework, and emphasising that this agreement does not authorise the transfer of data, but only creates the legal framework, which I am in favour of its adoption.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure because the text represents an important step forward in the protection of personal data transferred between the European Union and the United States in the context of of contrast activities. In addition, the agreement does not restrict or infringe any rights of the interested parties, as it does not form the legal basis for any data transfer, but merely complements existing frameworks relating to data transfers with new rights and protections in the context of cooperation between the European Union and the United States.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this agreement as it aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and safeguards for when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU or the Member States and the US and thus the agreement constitutes major progress for the protection of personal data when transferred between the EU and the US in the context of law enforcement activities. The current bilateral agreements in place do not have the same level of data protection safeguards as this agreement, therefore it is necessary to ensure citizen’s digital rights are secured.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of this EU-US Data Protection Agreement after many years of difficult negotiation. This Agreement will provide EU and UK citizens with greater rights of redress and higher levels of protection for their personal data and I am very supportive of the creation of a clear legal transatlantic legal framework for data protection.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report covers the approval of the agreement between the European Union and the United States of America. This agreement aims to guarantee high and binding personal data protection standards for transatlantic data exchanges between law enforcement and law enforcement authorities. Considering that in a context of security tension it is necessary to develop a common fight between the European Union and the United States against crimes and terrorism, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this legislative consent procedure vote. UKIP principally do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries. However, as this agreement is largely seeking to improve data protection safeguards and is not directly applicable to the UK, unless our sovereign government wishes to participate, it was more appropriate to abstain on this agreement.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I obviously supported the conclusion of the agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed in relation to criminal offences, the so-called 'Umbrella Agreement'. After several years of negotiations, this agreement is an important step forward in strengthening our cooperation with the United States, an indispensable partner in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, while ensuring a high framework for the protection of personal data transferred to prevent or detect criminal offences, conduct investigations and prosecutions.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, so I can vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Umbrella Agreement on the protection of personal data transferred and processed in the context of the prevention and detection of criminal offences, including terrorist acts. This was a long-standing request from the European Parliament. This historic agreement negotiated for several years between the European Commission and the United States aims to ensure a high level of protection of personal information and to strengthen cooperation between the United States and the European Union in the prevention and detection of criminal offences. The agreement does not allow any data transfer. Once in force, it will strengthen safeguards for the protection of all personal data transmitted by judicial authorities on both sides of the Atlantic on the basis of other agreements, such as the EU/US Air Passenger Data Agreement (PNR). Moreover, it will finally put European and American citizens on an equal footing with American courts, since it will allow European citizens to lodge a judicial remedy in the event of misuse of their personal data or if it is subsequently made public, a right until then reserved only to American citizens.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. The agreement aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and safeguards when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, of the one part, and the European Union or its Member States, of the other part. We have always opposed the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data. However, the guarantees provided for in this agreement are insufficient.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported my colleague Albrecht's report on the conclusion of an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes, as I believe that under this will ensure additional protection of personal data. The aim of the agreement is, above all, to create a wide range of safeguards and safeguards that will apply to the transfer of personal data for criminal enforcement purposes between the US and the EU and its member states. I believe that it guarantees a high level of protection of personal data and contributes to legal certainty. It will also contribute to improving law enforcement cooperation with the United States of America. It is important to note that the exchange of data between national security services remains outside the scope of the agreement, as they do not fall within the powers of the Union.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - Practice has shown that the numerous safeguards and guarantees do not guarantee a high level of protection of the fundamental right to the protection of personal data nor contribute to legal certainty.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, so I can vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this historic agreement on data sharing between the EU and the US for criminal law enforcement. It gives judicial redress to EU citizens, like my constituents in Wales, when their rights are infringed. Some are concerned about the legal clarification and I was also happy for this to be sent to the European Court of Justice to be examined.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Against: we are opposed to the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as I believe that the Agreement is an important step forward in the protection of personal data transferred between the European Union and the European Union U.S. In particular, this agreement aims to create a framework for the protection of personal data by helping to ensure legal certainty.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union is based on the protection of the fundamental rights and natural freedoms of persons, in particular the right to privacy in relation to the processing of personal data. This, too, is one of the reasons why the agreement on the protection of personal information in relation to criminal offences between the European Union and the US has been born for so long. It is important to recall that the agreement in question does not constitute a legal basis for transfers of personal data. This legal basis for data transfers can be found in existing EU-US agreements or bilateral agreements between Member States and the US, or in national legislation governing the exchange of personal data.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: ‒ I vote in favour of the provision for greater protection of personal data for the purpose of prevention, investigation, investigation and prosecution of crimes.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - Practice has shown that the numerous safeguards and guarantees do not guarantee a high level of protection of the fundamental right to personal data protection nor contribute to legal certainty, so I am voting against the US-EU agreement on protection personal information on criminal offences.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and safeguards for when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU or the Member States and the US and supplements, where necessary, data protection safeguards in existing and future data transfer agreements or national provisions authorising such transfers. Therefore, it will bring a significant improvement to the current situation. However, I believe that there is a need to solve its main problem, the absence of sufficient rights to judicial redress for permanent residents who are non-EU citizens, as they are excluded from the protections of the Judicial Redress Act. Moreover, we must ensure that the European Data Protection Authorities keep their rights to independently assess the data protection environment, as the current wording would solidify the status for the US, regardless of what changes they would make to their internal legislation on data protection.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as the agreement represents significant progress on the protection of personal data when transferring it between the EU and the US for the purposes of preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offences, including Terrorism. It should be emphasised that it does not limit or violate in any way the rights of data subjects as it does not constitute a legal basis for the transmission of data. The envisaged agreement contributes to legal certainty as it creates a legal framework for the protection of personal data. It also represents a solid base that can be used in negotiating future agreements between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and the United States, on the other, which provide for the transfer of personal data in the field of criminal law enforcement. The definition of common standards in this area of cooperation contributes to restoring confidence in data exchange between Europe and the US and sends a positive message on the strategic importance of strengthening and further deepening the transatlantic partnership in various areas.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. − Explanation of vote: USA-EU agreement on the protection of personal data in relation to crime: the exchange of crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential to guarantee the security of Europe's citizens. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. It is also important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States, so I can vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour considering that the Framework Agreement complements the protections and guarantees of these agreements, and strengthens and harmonizes the rights of those concerned, while assisting in the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism. Similarly, the Commission clarified that the presumption of conformity with applicable international rules on transfers is not automatic but qualified, i.e. refutable, and does not affect the powers of data protection authorities. We must bear in mind that personal data will be processed for specific authorised purposes, always preserving the rights of European citizens.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data - names, addresses or criminal records - exchanged between the European Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the European Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The proposed agreement aims to establish comprehensive safeguards and safeguards for the transfer of personal data for law enforcement purposes between the United States and the European Union or its Member States. It is important to ensure that personal data is effectively protected while improving law enforcement cooperation with the United States.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of EU-US agreement on protection of personal information relating to crime and offences given the Umbrella Agreement constitutes an important step forward compared to the existing system of data protection in the current bilateral agreements between the US and EU. The Umbrella Agreement also foresees law enforcement cooperation. In circumstances of terrorism and specifically cyber-crime for example, cooperation with the US is of the essence.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: in writing. — Compatibility of this agreement with the European treaties: it is logical that I refuse the agreement itself. The rapporteur, Mr Albrecht, considers that although imperfect, this is the best possible agreement in the current context. It also welcomes the fact that it does not in itself constitute a legal basis for data transfers and, on the contrary, that it adds new rights and protections to existing data transfer frameworks in the context of EU-US law enforcement cooperation. I have known the rapporteur who is less confident and more combating on these matters. The United States, along with the scandal of the massive collection of data of all kinds by the NSA, has largely proved that it is placing national security before any other consideration. I do not trust such an agreement to protect the rights of Europeans and I do not want it to become an alibi to multiply subsequent agreements involving transfers of personal data. Cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organised crime can be achieved without the systematic monitoring of all citizens.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The “Framework Agreement” is intended to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the protection of personal data when transmitted and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism, within the framework of police cooperation and judicial system in criminal matters, between the competent authorities of the European Union and the United States. However, there are serious doubts, including the European Data Protection Supervisor, about the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and with the Union's secondary data protection law, in particular as regards the right to a judicial remedy, access by police and judicial authorities, the limitation of the data subject's access rights and data retention periods, among others. Doubts requiring the intervention of the Court of Justice of the European Union. As the GUE/NGL and ALDE Motions for Resolutions requesting the ECJ's opinion on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Union Treaties were rejected, I voted against.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of adopting this agreement on the grounds that it establishes a framework of data protection principles and safeguards for when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU or the Member States and the US.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — To ensure the security of Europe's citizens, the exchange of data on crime prevention and law enforcement with other states is essential. At the same time, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection guarantees, thereby ensuring a high level of protection of data subjects' rights. It is also important to stress that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on this ‘Umbrella Agreement’. ALDE tabled a resolution pursuant to rule 108(6), referring the agreement to the European Court of Justice for an opinion on the EU-Canada PNR agreement before launching the consent procedure as it would relate to some similar provisions (in particular in relation to the ‘adequacy effect’). However this referral was not adopted, so I abstained on this agreement.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objection.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: I am pleased that Parliament has agreed to the implementation of the framework agreement between the European Union and the United States, which will ensure a high level of protection of personal data in the context of transfers between law enforcement authorities on both continents. We have again escaped a dilatory maneuver by the far left and some Liberals who wanted to refer the agreement to the Court of Justice in order to delay its implementation. It should be understood that this agreement is not a legal basis, since the exchange of data between authorities in criminal investigation and counter-terrorism matters is already regulated by bilateral agreements. This agreement, in fact, complements existing agreements by adding safeguards for European citizens' data, including the possibility of recourse to a court in the United States or a limited time to safeguard data. While this agreement has been negotiated for five years with widely mobilized legal services, when the majority of MEPs, including the Greens, have recognised the interest of this agreement for citizens and in the fight against terrorism, I find the practices of these Members really dishonest.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I was abstained in voting on the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information relating to the Prevention, Investigation, Disclosure and Persecution criminal offences because there are certain legal aspects that are not clear, and the level of protection provided for in the Agreement is not alleged to be fully compliant with EU regulations. Therefore, I followed the position of the ALDE Group, which is based on caution in granting consent to the conclusion of the Agreement concerned.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I regret that the safeguards offered in the protection of personal data are not sufficient, as evidenced by the possibility of transferring data from unsuspected individuals, for example flight passengers. Moreover, I oppose the very principle of systematized exchange of such data. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Umbrella Agreement establishes a framework of data protection principles and safeguards in case of transfers of personal information for criminal law purposes between the US and the EU and its Member States. It would supplement the data protection provisions in existing instruments such as bilateral Agreements as Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Treaty, Agreement on Enhancing Cooperation in Preventing and Combating Serious Crime and Terrorist Screening Information Agreement/Arrangement as well as the EU-US PNR Agreement and EU-US TFTP Agreement. The Umbrella Agreement provides a high level of personal data protection and that is why I voted in favour of it. I see it as an absolute necessity to consent to this Umbrella Agreement now. If we have agreements such as PNR where the transfer of data forms an integral part, we must have sufficient provisions to underpin how and when that data is transferred between the US and the EU.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed in relation to criminal offences, as it will increase the security of European citizens. The agreement is demanding regarding data protection when it comes to the transfer of personal data of citizens. Europeans will also have the same rights as citizens of the United States when they seek redress in American courts.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - Although some innovations are taking place in terms of better and more balanced data protection compared to the Umbrella Agreement, for example, EU citizens may file a legal objection if access to their data and the rectification of their data is refused or data is provided by the authorities of the other The Contracting Party has been unlawfully disclosed, the Agreement should be rejected. The rapporteur is also sceptical about the proposal as to how control mechanisms can work and, at the same time, compliance with the rules cannot be guaranteed. He concludes that the agreement itself should be terminated. I am abiding from the proposal because denunciation is not effective in an increasingly digitised world and the existing agreement is a viable framework.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report since I believe that the agreement does not meet the requirements of the EU Charter and EU law and fails to provide the required level of protections. Moreover, the wording within the report is ambiguous regarding core provisions (purpose limitation, onward transfer) and does not provide effective judicial redress to all individuals of the EU as the Charter requires.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement because it will have a significant impact on police and law enforcement cooperation between the European Union (EU) and the United States (US). By establishing a common and comprehensive framework of data protection rules and guarantees, this EU-US data-protection umbrella agreement will safeguard citizens’ personal information during law enforcement investigations on both sides. Thus, in a long-term perspective, this agreement will contribute significantly to restoring trust in transatlantic data flows as well as increasing anti-terrorism cooperation between the EU and the US. In general, this agreement will protect both EU and US citizens from common security challenges.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it proposes to accept the EU-US agreement on the protection of personal data. However, I believe that the guarantees offered by this agreement are not sufficient, in particular because the protection of the Judicial Review has not yet been granted by the United States to EU nationals.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report authorizing the conclusion of the “Umbrella Agreement”, an agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purpose of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting criminal offences. The agreement establishes a strengthened framework for cooperation with the United States in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, while ensuring high data protection. It represents significant progress, which must now be quickly implemented.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the European Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that covers the protection of personal information between the police and criminal justice authorities of the EU and the US.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — As part of the Roof Agreement, in 2011, the Commission opened negotiations with the US on the protection of personal information in relation to criminal offences. The purpose of this Agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of the individual, in particular the right to privacy when processing personal data. The agreement does not provide a legal basis for the transfer of personal data, which is contained in existing bilateral agreements between Member States and the United States, but complements the protection of those contracts and harmonizes the rights of the data exchange subject. It also represents a major breakthrough in the protection of personal data transmitted between the EU and the US in the context of prosecution actions. In addition, it does not restrict or infringe any right of the persons whose data are processed, since it does not constitute a legal basis for data transfers. This Agreement will apply to transfers of personal data between police authorities for the purpose of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting criminal offences, including terrorism. It covers all data transfers between those authorities, regardless of the nationality or place of residence of the data subject. The agreement does not restrict rights, but adds new legal protections to existing data transfer frameworks in the context of EU-US police cooperation, so I supported this report.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. On 1 December, the European Parliament approved the Agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information in relation to the prevention, detection and prosecution of crimes. The agreement struck a very good balance between the protection of personal data and the protection of public order and security in cases of joint action by the EU and the US. The strengthening of information exchange mechanisms is an important step towards better cooperation between the US, the EU and the Member States. The clauses of the agreement ensure the preservation of the high level of protection of the personal data of European citizens through accountability mechanisms, constant dialogue between responsible authorities, proportionate use of the data provided and effective legal remedies. I believe that this agreement will be the basis on which the US and the EU will continue to build their relations at times when dialogue and cooperation at international level are key to the detection and prosecution of crimes.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. — One of the main innovations of the umbrella agreement is that under it, citizens of each Contracting Party have the opportunity to appeal to court both refusal of access and refusal of rectification or unlawful disclosure by the authority of the other Contracting Party. This right shall be exercised in accordance with the law of the State in which the right is invoked. However, this right is not recognised for non-EU citizens but whose data has been transferred to the US. They also apply to non-citizens of Latvia. This distinction between EU citizens and non-EU citizens in the US Legal Remedies Act raises the question why non-citizens of Latvia and Estonia are not entitled to full protection of their data in the US.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement complements pre-existing US-EU data protection agreements. It sets out the rights and obligations of authorities in the processing and handling of personal data in the transfer of personal data between EU law enforcement authorities or its Member States and US law enforcement agencies. It is defined for the purposes of the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism. It also regulates the rights of individuals to information, access, rectification, erasure of data and establishes the right to administrative and judicial remedies. I consider it essential that there is high protection of personal data in this area so as to prevent their misuse.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information for the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. I voted against this text in the name of defending individual freedoms and knowing that the exchange of data could become systematic, while their effectiveness in combating criminal offences is not proven. The EU-US agreement provides for the transfer of personal information under certain specific procedures. To avoid deviations, a few guarantees of confidentiality are attached to it. However, safeguards remain inadequate because the fight against terrorism could endorse liberticidal practices. The exercise of a right of control of the persons concerned seems difficult to enforce and the possibility of recourse is not guaranteed.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: This recommendation is based on a draft agreement between the EU and the US on the protection of personal data. Indeed, the draft agreement proposes a legal basis ensuring a high level of protection of personal data, with a view to preventing, investigating, detecting and prosecuting criminal offences within the framework of police and judicial cooperation between the parties. However, there are huge doubts as to its compatibility with Community legislation and do not provide the legal certainty and certainty necessary to safeguard the fundamental right to personal data. I voted against.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The purpose of the agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular the right to privacy with regard to the processing of personal data, when they are transferred to the competent authorities of the European Union, its Member States and the United States for that purpose. This Agreement complements the protection and guarantees of personal data and extends and harmonises the rights of data subjects. This Agreement applies to the transfer of personal data by law enforcement authorities of the EU and its Member States and the US for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating or prosecuting criminal offences, including terrorism.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. — The original purpose of the agreement is to establish a framework of data protection principles and safeguards when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the US, on the one hand, and the EU or its Member States, on the other. Its objective is supposed to be the guarantee of a high level of protection of the personal data of data subjects in the EU when they exchange them with the US. They would be able to avail themselves of rights with regard to any transatlantic transfer of personal data in the law enforcement field, namely the right of access to data and the right to rectify data concerning them, the right to lodge an administrative or judicial remedy if a person does not accept the result of his request for access or rectification. As a reminder, we are opposed to the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data, and the guarantees offered by the agreement are not sufficient. I therefore opposed this file.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) The Framework Agreement establishes (for the first time) a comprehensive agreement on data protection principles and safeguards when personal data is transferred for the purposes of criminal law between the USA, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. The dual objective is to ensure a high level of data protection and thereby strengthen cooperation between the Parties. While not providing the legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the US, the Framework Agreement complements, where necessary, the data protection safeguards provided for in existing or future data transfer agreements, or national provisions authorising such transfers. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement because it guarantees a high level of protection of the fundamental right to personal data and improves the EU’s cooperation with the United States in the field of law enforcement.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I voted in favour of the Umbrella Agreement, an agreement between the European Union and the United States to strengthen the protection of the personal data of European citizens when transferred to the United States by judicial and police authorities as part of criminal cooperation. This agreement does not constitute a basis for data transfers, but adds additional safeguards to the protection of personal data already transferred on the basis of other agreements. Among other things, European citizens will now be able to take advantage of remedies in the event of misuse of their data in the United States. This is a historic victory on the part of Europeans. It was also a long-standing request from the European Parliament.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the agreement, which aims to establish a framework of data protection principles and safeguards for when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU or the Member States and the US. The agreement does not itself provide a legal basis for such transfers, but supplements, where necessary, data protection safeguards in existing and future data transfer agreements or national provisions authorising such transfers. This agreement will be in force for an indefinite period.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. − By its Decision of 3 December 2010, the Council authorised the Commission to prevent criminal offences, including terrorist offences, in the framework of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters between the European Union and the United States of America, Agreement on the protection of personal data transmitted and processed for the purpose of investigation, detection or prosecution. The text of the Agreement was initialled on 8 September 2015 after a five-year hearing. The purpose of the Agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the right to privacy with regard to the processing of personal data, where personal data are transferred between the European Union and its Member States and the United States to its competent authorities for those purposes. The Council adopted a draft decision ratifying the agreement and asked Parliament for its consent.
