In its opinion, the Committee on Legal Affairs concluded that the envisaged agreement is based on the appropriate legal basis, guarantees a high level of protection of the fundamental right to personal data and will improve law enforcement cooperation with the United States. The Committee on Foreign Affairs expressed its support in giving Parliament's consent to the envisaged agreement. Against this background, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes in its report that Parliament should agree with the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: The purpose of the agreement is to establish a framework of data protection principles and guarantees when transferring personal information for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, of the one part, and the European Union or its Member States, of the other part. Its aim is to ensure a high level of protection of the personal data of data subjects in the Union when they exchange them with the United States. We are opposed to the very principle of the systematic exchange of personal data, but the agreement provides for certain data protection rights and guarantees. Abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The guarantees offered by this agreement with regard to the protection of personal data are largely inadequate. I therefore object to this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed for the purpose of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting criminal offences. This will strengthen cooperation between the United States and Europe to fight crime, while providing citizens with protection of personal data.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the protection of personal information which will exchange personal with the scope of investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offences and acts of terrorism in the framework of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Any citizen from the two parts that considers that his data has been misused will have the access to several accessible and affordable dispute resolution mechanisms. This is the first time that personal data information is exchanged in a secured way with strong obligations on companies handling the data, clear safeguards and transparency obligations on US Government access and an effective protection of individual rights.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that human rights and freedoms must underpin any agreements and agreements that the European Union signs with its partners to combat crimes of all kinds. I firmly believe, as this document proposes, that we can strike a balance between the protection of the privacy of our citizens and the process of processing and transferring personal data between the competent authorities of the European Union and the United States. The European Parliament reiterates by its recommendation that the transfer of data of citizens and their processing must be carried out solely for the purpose for which such data was collected and cannot be used in any other action not related to this purpose. Therefore, the exchange of data under this Agreement should be done only for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, and this enumeration is extremely important. A novelty of the agreement is that it will allow citizens to have the legal opportunity to apply for a judicial remedy if they consider that their rights in access to personal information have been violated, both by the European authorities and the American.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – On Albrecht I voted against the report. I supported the referral of the file to the European Court of Justice to assess compatibility with existing EU data protection legislation. The file itself provides for some additional protections but by no means goes far enough. It differentiates between EU and non-EU citizens, it would also mean that it would become more difficult to challenge the legality of data exchange in court. It may contradict existing EU data protection legislation. It doesn’t cover the protection of information exchanged between national security agencies or private entities either. For those reasons I voted against.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained from voting on this report because, unfortunately, there is still no complete control over compliance with the provisions on data protection.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The Agreement aims to ensure a high level of protection of human fundamental rights and freedoms, in particular as regards privacy with regard to the processing of personal data, where personal data are transferred to the competent authorities of the European Union and its Member States and the United States. Given the current state in the fight against terrorism, such an agreement is necessary.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the EU-US Agreement on the protection of personal data exchanged by judicial and police authorities. The aim of the agreement is to ensure high and binding standards of data protection exchanged by police and law enforcement authorities. The agreement covers all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the EU and the US for the purpose of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting criminal offences, including terrorism. The agreement guarantees EU and US citizens: the right to administrative and judicial recourse, the right to be informed in the event of a breach of their data security and the right to request correction of their personal data in the event of inaccurate information. Thus, there will be high, binding standards and guaranteed rights for citizens in both the EU and the US when exchanging data between police and law enforcement agencies.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues proposal because I believe that the umbrella agreement (also called the framework agreement) is suitable because, on the one hand, it allows the Member States and the States United to cooperate with each other in the scope of justice and, on the other hand, to protect citizens' personal data if they are tried for criminal acts of various kinds. Furthermore, this exchange of information will not extend to that personal information unrelated to the EU's competence since it would imply its possible abuse of power. This agreement will simply complement existing data transfer frameworks with new rights and protections in the context of cooperation between the Union and the United States in the field of activities contrast. But, as a politician, on this motion for a resolution, I believe that the exercise of that power must take place by preventing nationality discrimination at the detriment of those involved. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the proposal for the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information in relation to Criminal Offences. The objective of this Agreement is to establish a framework of data protection measures and principles when personal information is transferred for criminal prosecution purposes between the United States of America, on the one hand, and the European Union or Member States, on the other. Information privacy, even in cases of prosecution enforcement must be the absolute priority of all European and United States agencies. This umbrella agreement lays down the procedure for notifying the other party of all acts which substantially affect the implementation of the Agreement, consultation in the event of disputes relating to interpretation or application, the possibility of suspension, territorial application and the unlimited duration of the agreement itself.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The EP agrees to the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the United States of America on the protection of personal data transmitted and processed for the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism, in the framework of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters issues (“Roof Agreement”). The Agreement contains provisions establishing the restriction of the purpose and use of personal data, provisions on the quality and integrity of the data and the storage period, rules on further transfers of data to third parties, the rights of individuals to legal protection, etc. One of the main novelties of the umbrella agreement is that it will allow citizens of each party to request judicial protection in case of refusal of access, refusal of correction or unlawful disclosure by the other party's body. The Agreement does not restrict or violate any right of the data subjects, since it does not constitute a legal basis for data transfers. The legal basis for data transfers is in existing EU-US agreements, bilateral agreements between Member States and the US or in national laws providing for the exchange of personal data. This agreement adds new rights and safeguards to these existing data transfer frameworks. While there are shortcomings, this agreement represents a major breakthrough in the protection of personal data transmitted between the EU and the US as part of prosecution actions.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation approves the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and the US on the protection of personal data in the field of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism. The agreement provides for a supposed guarantee of high data protection and enhanced police and judicial cooperation between the two sides of the Atlantic, and announces that 'European citizens' will have the same rights as their US counterparts, notably in appeals before US courts. However, the ambiguity of the terms in which the agreement is drawn up, and the premise that this is an international agreement that overlaps and European data protection rules and makes them shallow, leads us to believe that we are dealing with an agreement which, in fact, jeopardizes and undermines rights, freedoms and guarantees. On the other hand, it is an agreement which further deepens the attack on the sovereignty of the Member States, in a clear confrontation with the rights and interests of the peoples. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I consider the transfer and withdrawal of personal data to be a very complex topic where it is necessary to find the right measure between security and individual rights. I believe that the EU-US agreement on the protection of personal information relating to crimes is an example of how to maintain individual rights as much as possible without compromising security. I would like to stress that the Agreement merely regulates the handling of personal data already obtained by States under existing agreements, thus does not extend the range of shared information. This agreement guarantees a high level of individual freedoms without being at the expense of security. It clearly declares how personal data must be handled in order to avoid misuse. It also brings the opportunity for citizens to seek judicial redress in case of misconduct, which I personally consider very important. This Agreement does not in any way regulate the exchange of data between national authorities, as these do not fall within the EU area of action.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides additional protection for personal data transmitted and processed for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. The contract itself does not provide a legal basis for the transfer of personal data, but only increases the degree of privacy protection of personal data transmitted under other contracts. This agreement contains provisions laying down several basic principles of data protection, namely the purpose and limitations of use, the quality and integrity of data, the provisions for further transmission of data, the provisions on collective transmission of data and the right to redress on Judicial way. In order to comply with the requirements of the latter issue (the investigation of claims by court), the United States Congress adopted the Law on Judicial Appropriations in February 2016. This agreement represents significant progress in the protection of personal data transmitted between the EU and the US, without obstructing the work of law enforcement and intelligence services. It will be subject to regular monitoring and review and their findings will be made public. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the European Union and the United States. This will ensure better protection of privacy when transferring personal data between European and US police authorities, in order to combat terrorism and organised crime. It is essential to set high standards in place to protect the privacy of European citizens.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this legislative consent procedure vote. UKIP principally do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries. However, as this agreement is largely seeking to improve data protection safeguards and is not directly applicable to the UK, unless our sovereign government wishes to participate, it was more appropriate to abstain on this agreement.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement adopted with my vote in favour covers the transfer of all personal data, such as names, addresses or criminal records, exchanged between the European Union and the United States of America for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. I voted in favour because it represents a step forward in transatlantic data protection. There will henceforth be higher standards for the protection of fundamental rights binding and strong controls will be applied when data are exchanged between the police and the judicial authorities. The agreement represents the beginning of a new way of negotiating transatlantic standards on the protection of fundamental rights that will replace the fragmented and unguaranteed standards seen so far. The agreement ensures that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic shall have the right to be informed in the event that data security has been violated, that information is correct and that it can be corrected, and sets limits on data transfers and retention periods.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement between the United States and the European Union on the protection of personal information processed in relation to criminal offences, because it is essential that the European Union and the United States be on the same wavelength when it comes to protecting the data of European citizens in the United States and work hand in hand, as the EU has been hoping for years. The principles and safeguards established when personal data are to be transferred for criminal purposes will also apply to private entities, such as European aviation services, within the framework of the PNR. Another important step forward in this agreement is that it also includes bilateral agreements between Member States and the United States.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — There is no doubt that such an important and highly controversial issue as the agreement between the US and the EU on the protection of personal information in the investigation of criminal offences is compatible with the provisions of the EU Treaties must be assessed, in particular, with regard to personal data protection standards. These standards are very high in the European Union, which can not always be said about the US practice. Therefore, we must avoid the possibility of ambiguities.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This proposal for a recommendation deals with the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement with the USA on the protection of personal data transferred and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism, in the context of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The main objective, therefore, is to ensure a high level of protection of fundamental rights and individual freedoms, in particular with regard to privacy, when transferring personal data between the enforcement authorities of the EU and its Member States and the corresponding authorities North American. The provisions contained in the Agreement set out the fundamental principles of data protection and set out the rights of natural persons and the rights of administrative and judicial review. I believe that, overall, we are dealing with an agreement that will make progress for the protection of personal data transferred between the EU and the US, without restricting or violating any rights of data subjects, and for that reason I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report, which gives Parliament's approval to the agreement between the Union and the United States on the protection of personal data. This framework agreement will ensure high and binding data protection standards for transatlantic data exchanges between law enforcement authorities. The transfer of such personal data will take place in the context of the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism. On the other hand, the agreement will guarantee European and American citizens the right to be informed in the event of a breach of their data security, to request the modification of incorrect information or the right to bring legal proceedings. I therefore supported this agreement, which will allow both the exchange of personal information with the United States, while guaranteeing European citizens the protection of their rights.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — I have decided to speak in favour of the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information in the criminal field. This agreement is in fact an important step forward in the protection of personal data, such as names, addresses and criminal records that are exchanged by the judicial and police authorities of the two States to purposes of prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crimes, such as terrorism. Thanks to this agreement, citizens of the two Contracting Parties will be entitled, for example, to be informed in the event of a breach of the confidentiality of their data and to claim any compensation for Damage sustained.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the legislative consent procedure vote. UKIP principally do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries. However, as this agreement is largely seeking to improve data protection safeguards and is not directly applicable to the UK, unless our sovereign government wishes to participate, it is appropriate to abstain on this agreement.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of adopting this agreement on the grounds that it establishes a framework of data protection principles and safeguards for when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU or the Member States and the US.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Sharing of personal data has never been so widespread as nowadays. With the enormous development of information technologies also significantly rise risks of misuses of personal information. Agreement between the USA and the EU on the protection of personal information will just secure personal data. Agreement does not cause sharing any more personal data neither set any new legal base for personal data sharing. Therefore, I fully supported that agreement.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - The aim of the agreement is to create a legal framework on the principle of protection of personal data in the transfer of data between the EU and the US for the purposes of crime prevention, the needs of investigative bodies or in the framework of judicial cooperation. I supported this overarching agreement as it does not create a legal basis for the transfer of personal data, but complements the legal safeguards for the protection of personal data in contracts where necessary. The legal basis for data transmission can be found in existing US-EU agreements or bilateral agreements between the US and Member States. The agreement contains basic principles of data protection such as the restriction and use of the transferred data or the determination of the retention period. The Contracting Parties undertake to provide public supervisory authorities whose task will be to investigate and investigate citizens' complaints about breaches of legal practices in the field of personal data protection. I consider the agreement between the US and the EU on the protection of personal information in relation to crimes as an agreement based on the correct legal basis. I believe it will deepen cooperation in the field of enforcement of personal information.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement represents significant progress on the protection of personal data that is transferred between the EU and the US in law enforcement activities. The purpose is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the right to privacy, with regard to the processing of personal data in the transfer of personal data by the competent authorities of the European Union, its Member States and the United States for the purposes of preventing, investigating criminal offences, detection and prosecution.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences I agreed to it. This is not about establishing new rules for the exchange of data, but about the protection of data exchanged on the basis of and on the basis of existing other legal bases. This data is now better protected than before, since before that this data was not subject to any special protection at all. An improvement is therefore being achieved in relation to the status quo and this must therefore be agreed. It must, of course, also require that the rules adopted elsewhere, which serve as a reason and a reason for the exchange of data, need to be thoroughly revised. However, this must not result in the rejection of these first data protection rules.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The Council has requested Parliament's consent on the Agreement between the United States and the EU on the Protection of Personal Information in connection with criminal offences. The agreement talks about the protection of personal data transmitted and processed to prevent, investigate, detect and prosecute criminal offences, including terrorism, in the framework of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The purpose of the Agreement is to achieve a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the right to privacy in the processing of personal data when they are transferred to the competent authorities of the European Union and its Member States and the United States for that purpose. I agree to this Agreement because it aims to ensure a high level of protection of personal information and to strengthen cooperation between the United States of America and the European Union and its Member States in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Data in the Prevention, Investigation, Detection and Prosecution of Crimes. We need a wide range of protection and safeguards that will be applied when personal data are exchanged between the United States and the European Union for law enforcement purposes. This is exactly what the signed Agreement delivers and contributes to a sufficient extent to legal certainty, complementing the safeguards for data protection under existing and future agreements.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Practice has shown that the numerous safeguards and guarantees do not guarantee a high level of protection of the fundamental right to the protection of personal data nor contribute to legal certainty.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. “The decision to sign a data protection agreement by the US and the European Union is an extremely important step in ensuring the overall protection of our data, while respecting high standards of privacy. The agreement with the United States covers all transfers of data such as names, addresses or criminal record information. The transmission of this information is intended to support the fight against international crime, including the prevention, tracking, detection and prosecution of cross-border crimes, including terrorism. Until now, data of this type has been provided to US law enforcement agencies under bilateral union member states agreements with the US. However, they were not subject to any protection. Thanks to the agreement, this situation will change completely. Data transferred to the US to fight crime will be protected in the same way as in Europe. There will also be the same remedies and control procedures in the Union. Importantly, the agreement does not cover the exchange of data between national security authorities because such exchanges do not fall within the competence of the Union. It is also not covered by cases of transatlantic transfer of data between private entities.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I abstained in respect of the Agreement, since the legal interpretation of this Agreement is unclear. Final legal confirmation is needed before this agreement can be approved.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In response to the appeals of the European Parliament, the Council adopted a decision on 3 December 2010 authorizing the Commission to enter into negotiations for the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the United States of America on the protection of personal data upon transfer and transfer of personal data treatment for the prevention and detection of criminal offences, including terrorism, investigation and prosecution, within the framework of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters ('the Framework Agreement'). On 28 March 2011, the Commission began negotiations with the United States Department of Justice. Parliament has been kept regularly informed of developments in the negotiations, in accordance with Article 108 (10) of the FEU Treaty, and your rapporteur has prepared a series of working papers to facilitate discussions in the LIBE Committee. I finally abstained on the final text, because I have not received sufficient guarantees as to the effectiveness of the maneuver.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Information in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences for a number of reasons. In the first place, I consider that Article 16, combined with Article 218 (6) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), constitutes the proper legal basis of the proposal. Then, the envisaged agreement guarantees a high level of rights to the protection of personal data and contributes to legal certainty, and also lays the foundation for high operational cooperation between the United States and the European Union in the field of criminal prosecution. In addition, I believe that concern for the rights of individuals in a vertical relationship is essential, since the proposal for a resolution establishes access to information, its correction and deletion, as well as constitutional and judicial protection.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — This Agreement guarantees additional protection of personal data in cases where it has been transferred and processed for the purpose of prevention, investigation, detection and initiation of criminal activities such as terrorism. Also, the agreement itself does not provide a legal basis for the transfer of personal data - it simply adds a layer of privacy of personal data transferred within other agreements. I voted in favour, because I believe that this agreement allows great progress in the preservation of private data, in the case where it is transferred between the European Union and the US, without interfering with the work of legal and police authorities. The above will be subject to regular controls whose results will be visible publicly.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Data in the Prevention, Investigation, Detection and Prosecution of Crimes, on behalf of the European Union. The purpose of the Agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the right to privacy in relation to the processing of personal data when transferring personal data to the competent authorities of the European Union and its Member States and the USA for these purposes (also called the umbrella agreement). The umbrella agreement does not provide a legal basis for transfers of personal data — the basis for this is in some previous agreements (which it merely complements, coordinates). The agreement contains restrictions on the purpose and use of the transfer of personal data in order not to abuse the issuance of personal data. The agreement represents significant progress in the protection of personal data in its transfer between the EU and the US in the context of law enforcement activities. Perhaps this is not the best agreement that can be envisaged, but it is undoubtedly the best possible in the current situation. The Committee on Legal Affairs delivered its opinion on the draft and concluded that the envisaged agreement is based on an appropriate legal basis, ensures a high level of protection of fundamental rights to personal data and contributes to legal certainty and that it will improve law enforcement cooperation through The United States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The “Framework Agreement” is intended to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the protection of personal data when transmitted and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism, within the framework of police cooperation and judicial system in criminal matters, between the competent authorities of the European Union and the United States. However, there are serious doubts, including the European Data Protection Supervisor, about the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and with the Union's secondary data protection law, in particular as regards the right to a judicial remedy, access by police and judicial authorities, the limitation of the data subject's access rights and data retention periods, among others. Doubts requiring the intervention of the Court of Justice of the European Union. As the GUE/NGL and ALDE Motions for Resolutions requesting the ECJ's opinion on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Union Treaties were rejected, I voted against.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the agreement. I think it is a step forward to make our society safer.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — This agreement provides additional protection for personal data transmitted and processed for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism. It contains provisions defining several basic principles of data protection, including rules for the transmission of data, rules on transfers and the right of the individual to judicial redress. The agreement represents significant progress in protecting personal data transmitted between the EU and the US, without impeding the work of law enforcement and intelligence services. That's why I voted for the above agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. − On 3 December 2010, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to cover criminal offences in the framework of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters between the European Union and the United States of America, including terrorist acts — open negotiations on an agreement on the protection of personal data transmitted and processed for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting acts of terrorism. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The “Framework Agreement” is intended to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the protection of personal data when transmitted and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of crimes, including terrorism, within the framework of police cooperation and judicial system in criminal matters, between the competent authorities of the European Union and the United States. However, there are serious doubts, including the European Data Protection Supervisor, about the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and with the Union's secondary data protection law, in particular as regards the right to a judicial remedy, access by police and judicial authorities, the limitation of the data subject's access rights and data retention periods, among others. Doubts requiring the intervention of the Court of Justice of the European Union. As the GUE/NGL and ALDE Motions for Resolutions requesting the ECJ's opinion on the compatibility of the Framework Agreement with the Union Treaties were rejected, I voted against.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offenses. The purpose of the agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of personal information and enhance cooperation between the United States and the European Union and its Member States, in relation to the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism. The envisaged agreement is mainly devoted to establishing a wide set of protections and safeguards, which will apply to the transfers of personal data for criminal law enforcement purposes between the United States, on the one hand, and the European Union or its Member States, on the other. I voted in favour because I believe that the envisaged agreement creates a framework for the protection of personal data that contributes to legal certainty. The agreement will supplement, where necessary, data protection safeguards in existing and future data transfer agreements or national provisions authorising such transfers.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This framework agreement provides safeguards and guarantees of legality for data transfers, in order to provide protection of fundamental rights and to strengthen cooperation in criminal matters between the European Union and the United States of America. In short, we are talking about an agreement that will improve the existing regime, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this agreement is to protect the right to privacy within the framework of cooperation between the United States of America and the European Union in the field of counter-terrorism. However, the standards of protection do not conform to the requirements set out in European law, and a number of exceptionality clauses are maintained for the United States, perpetuating an asymmetrical relationship between the Union and the US. On the other hand, it regulates rights on the basis of citizenship, because it guarantees citizens of Member States of the Union more rights than to persons residing or operating there without being citizens or citizens. Finally, by raising this type of regulation to the category of international agreement, what is being done is to impose obstacles to judicial investigations (many of which are currently being developed) on this subject, by having this text a higher character than the treaties on which the claims are based. For all these reasons, I voted against this agreement.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: This agreement between the European Union and the United States of America concerns the protection of personal data transferred and processed for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes, including terrorism, in the context of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Personal data shall comprise any information relating to a person, whether it concerns his/her private, professional or public life. This could be a name, photo, email address, bank information, social media messages, medical information, or the IP address of your computer. Of course, this agreement represents a dangerous attack on freedoms and guarantees and opens the door to all kinds of abuse as regards the invasion of the personal private sphere of citizens. The idea is, under the fight against terrorism, to legitimize a security framework with all kinds of abuse, paving the way for the persecution of any annoying personality that jeopardises the established institutions and values.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - Despite some innovations in terms of better and more balanced data protection compared to the Umbrella agreement (for example, citizens of EU countries may file a judicial order if access and rectification are denied and data are unlawfully disclosed by the authorities of the other party ), I had to abstain in this vote. Firstly, the agreement is based on other very questionable agreements, such as the PNR and the Swift agreement, which the rapporteur himself considers critical and has admitted that compliance with the provisions of these agreements does not appear to be guaranteed and must therefore be adopted. Secondly, because the rapporteur confesses that the agreement between the US and the EU on the protection of personal data in the event of crime is not the best at the moment.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the current political climate, the protection of citizens’ personal information and data, either between states or in general on the internet, is a key issue that policy-makers must tackle. The EU is an instrumental platform for guaranteeing civil rights online, such as the right to privacy. As a member of the European Internet Forum I will continue to advocate for and defend these rights.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted on the EP recommendation on the EU-US Agreement on the Protection of Personal Information in connection with the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences. Following calls from the EP, on 3 December 2010, the Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations for an EU-US agreement on the protection of personal data when transferred and processed for prevention purposes, the investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, including terrorism.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the so-called 'umbrella agreement' between the European Union and the US. In this case, the European Parliament was only giving its consent to its closure. I supported the agreement in particular because it is a kind of additional layer of protection for data that is transferred from the EU to the US for the purpose of preventing, investigating and prosecuting crimes, including terrorism. It must be realised that Parliament did not consent here to the transfer of data itself, which already exists under the agreements in force, but only gave its consent to additional protection, such as introducing the principle of non-discrimination, stricter rules for consent to such transfer, and the manner and length of storage of these data. And although the agreement is not impeccable and has a number of opponents, I think that, in a situation where data is already being transmitted and used for its intended purposes, it is more than welcome to ensure maximum protection.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support this proposal for the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data in the context of prosecution of perpetrators of criminal offences. Establishing a quality framework of cooperation with strictly defined procedures for informing the other party about all acts, consultations in case of disputes, suspension, territorial application is necessary in order to define data protection measures and principles when information is transmitted for criminal purposes persecution between the United States of America, on the one hand, and the European Union or member states, on the other. Protection of information privacy must be a priority in the work of all European agencies and agencies of the Member States, but also in establishing cooperation in the field of prosecution of suspects for criminal offences.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted to approve the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the Protection of Personal Data in the Prevention, Investigation, Detection and Prosecution of Crimes, on behalf of the European Union. I support the Agreement as it seeks to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals, in particular the right to privacy in relation to the processing of personal data when transferring personal data to the competent authorities of the European Union and its Member States and the USA for prevention purposes, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Pending the signing of the EU-West African Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), Ghana ratified the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the Union in August 2016 European, signed in 2007. Through this pational instrument, it ensures provisional access to the duty-free EU market until its replacement by a regionally concluded global EPA. I believe that an interim agreement can only facilitate regional integration if the regional economic partnership agreement is reached in the temple. In this case, failure to ratify would put more than 1500 direct work at risk in the sectors they export to Europe. That's why I abstained.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana (AAEI) because፦ Improves the legal certainty of Ghanaian trade with Europe (avoiding a possible loss of tariff exemptions currently granted temporarily and unilaterally by the Union), improving the regulation of our trade (contains provisions on trade in goods, customs, trade facilitation, technical barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, while maintaining the free access exception for bananas destined for ultra-peripheral regions) - Incorporates mandatory commitments on sustainability and human rights, such as combating illegal trade in timber, corruption and child labour. - The Ghanaian Government has requested this agreement after consulting the actors concerned and its Parliament has strongly supported its ratification. - A possible rise in tariffs, in the absence of AAEI, would be very detrimental to a country that allocates more than 20 per cent of its foreign trade to the Union. - Socialists will monitor the proper monitoring of Ghana's commitments, while we continue to work towards a good regional EPA with all West Africa and demand from Ghana greater democratic progress and dialogue with civil society.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report as we believe it will disadvantage Ghana. The report was on establishing a transitional trade deal between the EU and Ghana while the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement negotiations are still underway. The trade deal voted on is an Economic Partnership Agreement. The EU has been using these EPAs with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries in order to force the liberalisation of their economies without providing any new benefit to them. The ACP countries already have access to the EU market but in recent years the EPA deals struck by Europe open access to the poorer countries to the EU without factoring in the massive inequality between the partners. This agreement will be detrimental to the majority of people of Ghana and it does not contain a sustainable development chapter.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: Ghana has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement: this agreement provides duty-free access to the EU market (pending a regional agreement that is delayed to be signed). Ghana is one of West Africa's leading agri-food exporters. It also exports wood, gold, oil, cocoa. The agreement will increase Ghana's exports to the EU, which are “liberalised”, from 35 to 80% of the total. Ghana protects its sensitive agricultural and food production. This agreement with Ghana appears to be a Trojan horse to impose on other West African states to open their markets with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign for now. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I found myself torn on this resolution: I recognise that Ghana is supportive of this Agreement, yet note the negative consequences that similar Agreements have caused for other countries around the world and the negative impacts that they have often had on poverty in certain sectors of the economy in other countries (for example EU overfishing in the Gulf of Guinea has caused a spike in onshore poverty). I therefore abstained on this resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted on the draft recommendation on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. Since more time is needed to sign the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), Ghana has decided to ratify its Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, which was concluded in 2007. However, Ghana still has significant unresolved problems due to large-scale corruption and child exploitation in the agriculture, forestry, fishing and gold sectors. In this context, I voted against this draft Economic Partnership Agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: Ghana has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement: this agreement provides duty-free access to the EU market. This agreement with Ghana seems to be a Trojan horse aimed at forcing other West African States to open their markets with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign for now. I therefore voted against this report, the objective of which seems to me to benefit only a few multinationals.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted against the conclusion of this interim bilateral agreement. It was concluded in 2007 and, in the meantime, negotiations for a regional agreement have been opened. I therefore think it is better to focus our efforts on the conclusion of a regional agreement, rather than on this obsolete bilateral agreement.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union and Ghana have been partners in different areas for years, with total bilateral trade that stood at 5.4 billion euros in 2015, comprising more than 20% of trade foreign countries of the African country. The republic is among the leading exporters of agribusiness products in the ECOWAS region, exporting cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish, and importing rice, sugar and meat. Last August, the African country decided to ratify the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, signed in 2007, to ensure a contractual safety net in awaiting the entry into force of the wider economic partnership agreement between the EU and West Africa. I voted against the Fjellner report because I believe that the newly ratified APEI is incomplete and passed. It provides for different deadlines for tariff dismantling compared to the regional programme, its provisional application could create significant differences on external tariffs within ECOWAS, undermining that principle of regional integration which underlies the new EPA.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this consent report on the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and Ghana, as it reinforces an asymmetrical logic and peripheral-centre subordination of trade relations, condemning Ghana in the long term to underdevelopment.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — With the adoption of this measure, the doors would be further open to agricultural and fishery products without duty, and I therefore have no full vote in favour of it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this recommendation on the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the European Community and its Member States, on the other hand. This interim agreement will open the doors to its provisional application. Due to the delay in signing the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) in 2016 Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire decided to proceed with the ratification of their interim EPA with the European Union in 2007. The agreement ensures a contractual safety net as it guarantees duty-free access to the EU Market until the regional agreement comes to a successful conclusion. The interim agreement shall in due course be replaced by an EPA at regional level once it enters into force.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This recommendation concerns the step agreement towards an EU-Ghana Economic Partnership Agreement. This agreement was signed in 2007 and provides duty-free access to the EU market (pending a regional agreement that is delayed to be signed). Ghana exports agri-food commodities, but also wood, gold, oil and cocoa. This agreement will increase Ghana's exports to the EU, which are “liberalised”, from 35 to 80% of the total. Finally, I believe that this agreement is intended to impose on the other West African States to open their markets, with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign for the time being. So I voted against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana (AAEI) because፦ Improves the legal certainty of Ghanaian trade with Europe (avoiding a possible loss of tariff exemptions currently granted temporarily and unilaterally by the Union), improving the regulation of our trade (contains provisions on trade in goods, customs, trade facilitation, technical barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, while maintaining the free access exception for bananas destined for ultra-peripheral regions) - Incorporates mandatory commitments on sustainability and human rights, such as combating illegal trade in timber, corruption and child labour. - The Ghanaian Government has requested this agreement after consulting the actors concerned and its Parliament has strongly supported its ratification. - A possible rise in tariffs, in the absence of AAEI, would be very detrimental to a country that allocates more than 20 per cent of its foreign trade to the Union. - Socialists will monitor the proper monitoring of Ghana's commitments, while we continue to work towards a good regional EPA with all West Africa and demand from Ghana greater democratic progress and dialogue with civil society.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the conclusion of an Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. As more time is needed to sign the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), August 2016 Ghana (and later Côte d'Ivoire) decided to ratify its Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, which was concluded in 2007. This agreement provides a contractual safeguard system that allows duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is implemented. The Interim Agreement provides for provisional application and will replace this Agreement by a comprehensive EMU concluded at regional level on the date of entry into force.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement is delayed, in August 2016 Ghana (later Côte d'Ivoire) decided to ratify the EPA with the European Union in 2007. The agreement provides a contractual safety net and guarantees duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is reached. The Interim Agreement provides for provisional application and a full EPA at regional level shall replace it on the date of its entry into force. Although Ghana's export revenues are dominated by gold, cocoa and crude oil, the Union has become the primary target of Ghana's' non-traditional 'exports, showing increasing diversification and value added creation within the country. Imports from Ghana are dominated by ships, vehicles and refined crude oil. The country is trying to stabilise its position as the transit and sea centre of landlocked countries. While Ghana excludes certain sensitive agricultural and processed products from liberalisation, the Interim EPA also introduces safeguards allowing the reintroduction of customs duties in the event of a sudden increase in imports with a distortion of the economy, threatens to threaten food security. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the EU-Ghana interim agreement, as Ghana and the EU are partners in different fields. The agreement is also important in promoting regional economic integration and investment. Ghana is one of the main exporters of agri-food products of the region of the Economic Community of West African countries, exporting cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish and imports rice, sugar and meat. All these raw materials are important for European citizens.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the transitional EU-Ghana Economic Partnership Agreement, which was agreed to avoid disruption to trade with the EU after the end of the trade provision under the Cotonou Treaty.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report, which aims to accelerate Ghana's ability to access the European market for its agri-food production, timber, oil and cocoa, is in fact only a Trojan horse to force other states to create a regional free trade area. I therefore vote against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Ghana has ratified the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, which ensures duty-free access to the EU market until the establishment of an EPA global concluded at regional level. Ghana and the EU are partners in different areas, including promoting regional economic integration and investment. The EU has become a prime destination of Ghana's exports, demonstrating increasing diversification and value-added creation in the country. On the one hand we seek to implement the global regional EPA, on the other hand, the Ghana-EU Interim EPA remains a temporary solution in accordance with WTO rules. As soon as the global regional EPA comes into force, it will replace the interim EPA. Although that agreement, dating back to 2007, does not fully reflect the reality of 2016; it guarantees Ghana, a lower-middle income country, an offer of total market access based on a contractual relationship long term, which will ensure the stability needed for new investment and job creation. The need to give new momentum to APEI came from the slowdown in the final stages of the regional EPA. APEI will allow Ghanaian exporters to preserve duty exemption preferences on the European market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: Ghana has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement, which provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market. Specifically, this agreement aims to exempt 80% of the goods exported by Ghana from customs duties, compared with 35% at present. At a time when our farmers are suffering from the drop in commodity prices and the Russian embargo, it is outrageous that the European Union continues to grant tariff concessions and ratify free trade agreements, which will increase our farmers' exposure to international competition unfair and wild globalization. Moreover, this agreement seems to be a pretext to impose on other West African States to open their markets. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — Given that the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement has not yet been completed, Ghana has decided to start the ratification procedures of its preliminary Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union concluded in 2007. Thus, given that both the Union and Ghana are making significant efforts to establish a full Regional Economic Partnership Agreement, this Interim Agreement remains a timely temporary solution. Ghana and the European Union are important partners in promoting economic integration and boosting investment, Ghana being one of the main exporters of agri-food products in the Economic Community of West African States. At the same time, the Economic Partnership Agreement will foster the creation of jobs through sustainable investments for the citizens of Ghana. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe it is an effective tool for preparing the regional economic agreement, but it also makes an important contribution to the economic relations between the EU-Ghana.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted against the Council decision on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Community and Ghana. I fully agree with the European Union's trade strategy to help countries in economic distress, but this agreement, concluded in 2007 and kept frozen until now, is essentially inadequate with respect to the changed current conditions: the absence of a regional dimension and rules on origin, as well as an incomplete institutional framework make this agreement a fallback solution pending define the partnership with the entire West African region. Furthermore, I believe that the agreements concluded with African countries tend to excessively sacrifice the interests of the agricultural sector of the EU Mediterranean countries and that the safeguards adopted are too often ineffective.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I believe it will disadvantage Ghana. The report was on establishing a transitional trade deal between the EU and Ghana while the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement negotiations are still underway. The trade deal voted on is an Economic Partnership Agreement. The EU has been using these EPAs with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries in order to force the liberalisation of their economies without providing any new benefit to them. The ACP countries already have access to the EU market but in recent years the EPA deals struck by Europe open access to the poorer countries to the EU without factoring in the massive inequality between the partners. This agreement will be detrimental to the majority of people of Ghana and it does not contain a sustainable development chapter.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote. Whilst we concede that EU deals with poor countries often exacerbate poverty, we note the desire of the Ghanaian Government to sign this deal so as to secure market access. For this reason, despite our reservations about this deal, we abstained.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Pending the signing of the EU-West African Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), Ghana (and later Ivory Coast) decided in August 2016 to proceed with ratification the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, signed in 2007. The agreement ensures a contractual safety net, as it ensures duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is implemented. The Interim Agreement provides for a provisional application and will be replaced by a regionally concluded global EPA. Although gold, cocoa and crude oil continue to be the source of Ghana's main export proceeds, the EU has become a prime destination of 'non-traditional' exports, demonstrating increasing diversification and creation of added value in the country. Among the sensitive sectors outside the agreement is dairy dairy, mainly characterized by powdered milk as a product base which in Ghana is fully produced and imported from Nestle. The non-ratification of the Treaty, in the case of Ghana, could undermine more than 1500 direct work in the sectors they export to Europe. For this reason I preferred to abstain.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The recommendation on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the European Community and its Member States does not focus on issues of developing greater cooperation for the benefit of citizens, which is why I do not think it can be positive results. I have therefore decided to vote against.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote against because the adoption of this measure would further open the doors to duty-free agricultural and fish products.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I agree to the definitive conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana pending the EPA's signature with West Africa. It is technically the ratification of an agreement already signed in 2007, whose continuity work is necessitated by the reluctance of African partners to sign the EPA, which was already approved in 2014. Total bilateral trade between Ghana and the EU amounts to 5.4 billion and includes more than 20% of Ghanaian exports, which introduces mainly cocoa, fruit, nuts and timber to the Union market. Since these are products beyond major exports, namely gold and crude oil, the attempt to diversify its economy and create added value in order to commendably emerge to establish itself as a middle-income nation. These guidelines appear as much as in line with Ghana's precise willingness to consolidate its position as a transit and maritime hub for landlocked countries. However, the country must absolutely increase its efforts against corruption and exploitation of child labour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the stepping stone Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report because I support the rapporteur's proposal to approve this interim agreement. It is not foreseeable how long it will take for the conditions for future relations under the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement to be met and Ghana will have full market access to the EU on the basis of a long-term contractual relationship. In the meantime, we need to ensure that duty-free access to the EU is maintained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as West Africa is our largest trading partner in sub-Saharan Africa. At the same time, the European Union contributes to the economic growth and development of the region and is the main export market for West African agricultural and fisheries. Agreement on the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana and Ivory Coast guarantees a contractual safety net ensuring a duty-free share in addition to free access to the EU market . In addition, the Interim Agreement contains provisions on measures for development cooperation, trade defence and the facilitation of trade between health and phytosanitary measures.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to the consent for this interim agreement which would open the door to its provisional application. The deal ensures a contractual safety net, warranting duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement comes into fruition We should seek fostering regional economic integration and investment, whereby in 2015, the total two-way trade between Ghana and the EU was worth 5.4 billion euros, comprising over 20% of Ghana’s external trade with the EU becoming a prime destination for Ghana’s ‘non-traditional’ exports, demonstrating an increasing diversification and value-addition in the country.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In my vote in favour, I wanted to support this resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, the EU and its Member States. The agreement, ratified last August, ensures a contractual safety net in favour of duty-free access to the EU market, temporarily, until the entry into force of an agreement Regional Economic Partnership between the EU and West Africa. In fact, Ghana and the EU are already partners in several areas, including promoting regional economic integration and investment. In addition, a third of exports of timber from Ghana are headed to EU states. I am convinced that the conclusion of this agreement, on the one hand, can encourage Ghana to continue its ongoing reform process which must precede authorisation for the enforcement of regulations and trade in the forestry sector. On the other hand, it can accelerate the final stages of a broader trade deal in the West African region. A development-oriented agreement, giving Ghana the option of duty refraining clauses if increased imports endanger the economy of the lower-middle-income country and industry nascent.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the preliminary Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana. I believe that an important aspect is cooperation between economic partners to ensure the best possible growth. The cooperation undertaken under this partnership guarantees security in maintaining duty-free access to the EU market. Fostering a regional partnership may ultimately result in other countries in the West African region signing an agreement. It is important to ensure that transitional provisions are replaced by definitive provisions, which will specifically contribute to the strengthening of the partnership.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Ghana agreement following recommendations from the European Parliament’s INTA Committee and a unanimous vote in the Parliament of the Republic of Ghana. I believe that this signal from Ghana’s elected representatives shows that the agreement is welcomed by the Republic of Ghana and therefore believe that this decision should be respected.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report which provides an important safety net to the Ghanaian economy. Given the delays and difficulties in signing the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement following the conclusion of negotiations, it is essential that Ghana continue to benefit from a WTO—compatible agreement for full duty and free quota free access to the European market. Any loss of market access could result in serious disruption to the Ghanaian economy and as a consequence this interim EPA is required as a temporary measure to ensure legal and economic stability. We should continue to work towards a full regional EPA as the best solution for all participants.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: ‒ I strongly support the conclusion of the EU-Ghana Interim Economic Partnership Agreement (IEPA). This instrument will allow Ghana to continue to benefit from preferential and asymmetrical access to the European market, with a view to the end of the EU's unilateral application of the Regulation on market access (MAR) to Ghana, in accordance with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules. In addition to the trade volet, which provides for the liberalisation of all tariff lines at duty and zero quotas for imports from Ghana, the agreement includes a very important chapter of cooperation development which explicitly refers to the provisions of the Cotonou Convention. Although it is an asymmetric agreement, it also contains bilateral safeguard clauses that will allow each party to react to possible market distortions while protecting their respective markets. Finally, I would like to remind you that this agreement has a purely transitional nature with a view to the entry into force of the wider Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the whole West African region (ECOWAS), of which Ghana is a part. That is why I voted strongly in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This report covers the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and West Africa, in particular with Ghana. Due to the delay in signing the agreement with West Africa, Ghana has ratified its Economic Partnership Agreement, which aims to liberalise 80% of trade with the European Union. The Interim Agreement provides for provisional application, which will be replaced by the Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with West Africa once ratified. Considering Ghana's willingness and motivation to accelerate the process of implementing the Economic Partnership Agreement and considering the interests of the European Union in ratifying the comprehensive agreement with West Africa from an economic and diplomatic point of view, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote. Whilst we concede that EU deals with poor countries often exacerbate poverty, we note the desire of the Ghanaian Government to sign this deal so as to secure market access. For this reason, despite our reservations about this deal, we abstained.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. — Given the delay in signing the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Stage Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana, which will allow its provisional application until the regional agreement takes effect. The Interim Agreement thus allows Ghanaian exporters to keep duty-free preferences on the European market. Ghana, for its part, will gradually liberalise 80% of imports from the European Union over a period of fifteen years.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement is delayed, in August 2016 Ghana (later Côte d'Ivoire) decided to ratify the EPA with the European Union in 2007. The agreement provides a contractual safety net and guarantees duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is reached. The Interim Agreement foresees provisional application and is replaced by a full EPA at regional level on the date of its entry into force. Although Ghana's export revenues are dominated by gold, cocoa and crude oil, the Union has become the primary target of Ghana's' non-traditional 'exports, showing increasing diversification and value added creation within the country. Imports from Ghana are dominated by ships, vehicles and refined crude oil. The country is trying to stabilise its position as the transit and sea centre of landlocked countries. While Ghana excludes certain sensitive agricultural and processed products from liberalisation, the Interim EPA also introduces safeguards allowing the reintroduction of customs duties in the event of a sudden increase in imports with a distortion of the economy, threatens to threaten food security. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. Ghana is the leading exporter of agri-food products and has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement, which provides duty-free access to the EU market. This new agreement will liberalize Ghana's production by 35 -80% of the total. It should be noted that other African States have refused to sign similar agreements. So this deal seems to be a Trojan horse.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the EU-Ghana Stage Economic Partnership Agreement concluded back in 2007, as it will provide safeguards and continue duty-free quotas for certain goods to the EU market. The conclusion of an agreement between the EU and West Africa, the so-called An Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), which, upon its entry into force, will replace all step-by-step agreements concluded between the EU and the individual countries of West Africa.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - It is proposed to revive an outdated 2007 agreement which, undoubtedly, cannot fully meet the conditions of 2016, in order to avoid disruption of trade for Ghana, while paving the way for a future EPA. The European policy pursued in the conclusion of bilateral preferential trade agreements should prejudge the implementation of updated and integrated solutions rather than temporary incomplete agreements.

text: in writing. — Vote against: this agreement aims to impose on other West African States to open their markets, with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign for the time being.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Recommendation because the Ghana-EU Interim Economic Partnership Agreement ensures a contractual safety net, ensuring Ghanaian products a duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is implemented.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the delay in the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and West Africa, Ghana has decided to ratify its own Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, which will ensure, inter alia, duty-free access to the European Union market. name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly welcome the fact that in August 2016 Ghana (and subsequently Côte d’Ivoire) has decided to proceed with ratification of its Stepping Stone Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) with the European Union, concluded back in 2007. The EU has become a prime destination for Ghana’s ‘non-traditional’ exports, demonstrating an increasing diversification and value-addition in the country. The IEPA is fundamental as it will allow Ghanaian exporters to preserve the duty-free preferences on the European market as Ghana moves up and consolidates its status as a middle-income country. Furthermore, if the regional EPA comes into place without excessive delays, any discrepancies in the IEPA tariff liberalisation schedules and tariff lines will be solved without a need for additional adaptation to the regional processes. I think this EPA will be a big step forward for the development of both regions, and will provide an added value for both economies.
