name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the recommendation bearing in mind that Ghana and the Union are partners in different areas, including the promotion of regional economic integration and investment. In 2015, the total two-way trade flow between Ghana and the Union amounted to EUR 5.4 billion. This agreement guarantees Ghana, a lower-middle-income country, a 100% market access offer, based on a long-term contractual relationship, which will provide the necessary stability for new investment and job creation.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana (AAEI) because፦ Improves the legal certainty of Ghanaian trade with Europe (avoiding a possible loss of tariff exemptions currently granted temporarily and unilaterally by the Union). - Improves the regulation of our trade (contains provisions on merchandise trade, customs, trade facilitation, technical barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, while maintaining the free access exception for bananas destined for ultra-peripheral regions) - Incorporates binding commitments on sustainability and human rights, such as combating illegal trade in timber, corruption and child labour. - The Ghanaian Government has requested this agreement after consulting the actors concerned and its Parliament has strongly supported its ratification. - A possible rise in tariffs, in the absence of AAEI, would be very detrimental to a country that allocates more than 20 per cent of its foreign trade to the Union. - Socialists will monitor proper monitoring of Ghana's commitments, while we continue to work towards a good regional EPA with all West Africa and demand from Ghana greater democratic progress and dialogue with civil society.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana (AAEI) because፦ Improves the legal certainty of Ghanaian trade with Europe (avoiding a possible loss of tariff exemptions currently granted temporarily and unilaterally by the Union), improving the regulation of our trade (contains provisions on trade in goods, customs, trade facilitation, technical barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, while maintaining the free access exception for bananas destined for ultra-peripheral regions) - Incorporates mandatory commitments on sustainability and human rights, such as combating illegal trade in timber, corruption and child labour. - The Ghanaian Government has requested this agreement after consulting the actors concerned and its Parliament has strongly supported its ratification. - A possible rise in tariffs, in the absence of AAEI, would be very detrimental to a country that allocates more than 20 per cent of its foreign trade to the Union. - Socialists will monitor the proper monitoring of Ghana's commitments, while we continue to work towards a good regional EPA with all West Africa and demand from Ghana greater democratic progress and dialogue with civil society.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - In order to bridge the time until the possible signing of the EU-West Africa Regional Economic Partnership Agreement, the Interim Agreement is a good transitional solution. A contractual safety net will be provided to guarantee duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market and the asymmetric and gradual opening of the Ghana market until the implementation of the regional agreement. The mutual reduction of tariff and non-tariff trade barriers promotes bilateral trade and thus also strengthens EU exports.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this consent report on the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and Ghana, as it reinforces an asymmetrical logic and peripheral-centre subordination of trade relations, condemning Ghana in the long term to underdevelopment.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Ghana’s Interim Economic Partnership Agreement in order to ensure Ghana’s duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market until the Regional EPA is achieved which would see an integrated West African Economic Community.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a transitional Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, on the other hand, because the aforementioned Agreement brings benefits for both sides. As Ghana and the EU are partners in a variety of areas, among them encouraging regional economic integration and investment, the transitional EPA will allow Ghanaian exporters to retain duty-free benefits for the European market as Ghana advances and solidifies its middle-income country position. In addition, if the regional EPA enters into force without excessive delay, any differences in the tariff liberalisation schedule and tariff paragraphs of the transitional SGP will be resolved without the need for additional adjustments to regional processes. The transitional SGP also introduces safeguards allowing the reintroduction of customs duties in cases where a sharp increase in imports threatens to distort the economic situation, harm the security of food supply or threatens industries in its infancy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — In 2007, the European Union signed an Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana, allowing Ghana duty-free access to our market. This new agreement, which I consider to be a Trojan horse, will significantly increase Ghanaian exports and will sooner or later take the form of a broader regional free trade agreement. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of a partnership agreement between the European Union and Ghana pending the implementation of the economic partnership agreement with all West Africa. This provisional application agreement provides a contractual safety net guaranteeing free access to the Union market. It aligns market access prospects, with provisions aimed at removing technical barriers to trade and assisting Ghanaian exporters to comply with sanitary and phytosanitary measures. It provides for cooperation to build capacity in tax reform and improve the business climate, competitiveness, trade facilitation and customs cooperation. It is therefore favourable to development and trade.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This agreement should be rejected for a number of reasons. On the one hand, there is a risk of significant negative effects on the country's economy with an increase in duty-free imports to Ghana from the EU, and on the other hand, the duty-free export of certain agricultural products to the EU threatens to put pressure on European producers and also to make exports more profitable than local consumption. Last but not least, there is no connection to take-back agreements. On the basis of these considerations, I reject the report.
