name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement had foreseen that the EU and the ACP countries would conclude the negotiations by the end of 2007. I voted against, since there are some contentious issues: in particular concerning the liberalisation schedule and it is also outdated. International competition with EU products on manufactured goods will also greatly affect regional integration of Ghana.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Ghana-EU Interim Economic Partnership Agreement (IEPA) because it will give both partners practical tools to strengthen capacity in fiscal reforms, improving business climate, competitiveness, trade facilitation and customs co-operation. In particular, IEPA ensures to Ghana, a lower middle-income country, a 100% market access offer based on a long-term contractual relationship, which will ensure new investments and job creation. On the other hand, IEPA will fully or nearly fully liberalize 80% of European exports into Ghana. Looking from this perspective, we should consider IEPA as a solid legal foundation, which opens new business opportunities for both partners. Last but not least, IEPA is another step forward for an upcoming regional Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) with 16 West African states.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: I voted against this report because it approves a new free trade agreement with Ghana. However, I am hostile to any CETA or TAFTA free trade agreement. Furthermore, I accuse this seemingly innocuous agreement of being a kind of Trojan horse paving the way for a larger free trade agreement with Africa.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that is an interim agreement between the EU and Ghana.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Ghana and the EU are partners in various fields, including the promotion of regional economic integration and investment. In 2015, total trade in both directions between Ghana and the EU was €5.4 billion, accounting for more than 20% of Ghana's foreign trade. Although gold, cocoa and crude oil to Ghana continue to bring most of its export revenue, the EU has become its leading destination for non-traditional exports, a sign of increasing adding value to products. Ghana is the first partner country to decide in August 2016 to ratify the transitional Economic Partnership Agreement with the EU, which provides it with a contractual safety net and allows duty-free market access. Ghanaian exporters will be able to retain duty-free privileges for the European market, and Ghana cement its position as a middle-income country. Also, Ghana is the first partner country to conclude negotiations and ratify the Voluntary Partnership Agreement with the EU, which promotes lawful trade in wood raw material. Regardless of the fact that this treaty is not the best solution because the rules of origin of that regional dimension are missing, it will certainly contribute to the prevention of trade disruptions in Ghana and thus prepare everything for the regional Economic Partnership Agreement that is yet to come. Since I agree with everything written in the report, I vote for this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The volume of bilateral trade between Ghana and the EU amounted to €5.4 billion in 2015, representing more than 20% of Ghana's foreign trade. The agreement opens up the scope for strengthening economic cooperation, trade and investment, and at the same time for political cooperation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech in plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, and because this recommendation is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. By voting in favour of this text, the European Parliament agrees to the increase in Ghana's exports to the EU from 35 to 80%. It is an economic partnership agreement that provides duty-free access to the EU market. We are concerned that Ghana, which is one of West Africa's leading agri-food exporters, will drown the European market with its agricultural products while protecting its national market with exception clauses for sensitive agricultural and food production. Furthermore, we believe that this agreement is a first step towards trade liberalisation between the EU and African countries. This liberalisation is envisaged by the Commission in a regional partnership agreement which is currently waiting to be signed and against which we are opposed.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted positively on the report of EU-Ghana Stepping Stone Economic Partnership Agreement. The ratification of SSEPA proves beneficial by granting a provisional duty-free access to the EU market. On the other hand, the agreement will pave the way to prevent trade disruption for Ghana, boosting the country’s GDP, by ensuring the stability needed for new investments and creating employment opportunities. Supporting the agreement represents a great opportunity for the country of Ghana to move up the economic ladder and strengthen ‘its status as a middle-income country’.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - Due to the threat of duty-free exports of certain agricultural products to the EU, European producers are being put under economic pressure, and exports of goods will be more profitable than local consumption. That is why I do not agree with this agreement.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. Ghana and the EU are partners in various fields. While the largest part of the export revenues in Ghana comes from sales of gold, cocoa and crude oil, the EU has become the most important objective of Ghana's non-traditional exports, which shows greater diversification and added value of the country. EUR, which amounts to more than 20%. Ghana's external trade. This interim agreement will ensure 100% placing on the market for Ghana, which will ensure long-term contractual relations and the economic stability needed to achieve new investments and job creation.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: Ghana has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement: this agreement provides duty-free access to the EU market. Ghana is one of West Africa's leading agri-food exporters. The agreement will increase Ghana's' liberalised 'exports to the EU from 35 to 80% of the total. This agreement with Ghana appears to be the first step towards imposing on other West African States to open their markets, eventually with the signing of a regional free-trade partnership agreement. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) This proposal is the legal instrument necessary for the conclusion of a stage Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Ghana, of the other part. The agreement provides a contractual safety net, ensuring duty-free access to the Union market until the entry into force of the regional agreement. The stage agreement will be applied provisionally and will be replaced by the EPA concluded at regional level on the day it enters into force. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement because it provides a stable framework to help increase the two-way flow of trade and investment between the EU and Ghana.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Ghana and the EU have important trade relations. Last year, trade between Ghana and the EU accounted for 20% of Ghana's foreign trade. Since the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement has been delayed and in order to ensure the continuity of trade relations between the EU and Ghana, it is desirable to adopt a temporary Economic Partnership Agreement. This will ensure trade between Ghana and the EU, maintain a stable framework for promoting economic investment in Ghana and maintain phytosanitary assistance to Ghanaian exporters.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the EU-Ghana Stepping Stone Economic Partnership Agreement because I agree that we must have guarantees in place to ensure that working conditions and sustainable development practices in such sectors complement our long standing calls for policy coherence for development. Therefore, it is important to push for strong and effective sustainable development chapters, which we want to see included in any type of EPA.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - An interim EPA was concluded between the European Union and Ghana in 2007, which guarantees Ghana duty-free access to the EU market. Since Ghana is a member of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and negotiations on a comprehensive regional economic partnership agreement between the EU and ECOWAS have been opened, the interim agreement has not yet been ratified. However, given that the Convention initialled on 30 June 2014 has not yet been ratified due to the hesitation of some ECOWAS Member States, Ghana decided on 3 August 2016 to ratify the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the EU pending its entry into force, which provides for provisional application and will be replaced by a full EPA at regional level on the date of its entry into force. The Council has drawn up a draft decision to ratify the EPA on behalf of the EU, but it also needs to obtain the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on International Trade proposes that Parliament should agree to the conclusion of the agreement on such terms. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: Ghana has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement: this agreement provides duty-free access to the EU market (pending a regional agreement that is delayed). Ghana is one of West Africa's leading agri-food exporters. It also exports wood, gold, oil, cocoa. The agreement will increase Ghana's liberalised exports to the EU from 35 to 80% of the total. Ghana protects its sensitive agricultural and food production. This agreement with Ghana seems to be a Trojan horse aimed at forcing other West African States to open their markets, with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign for now. Unfavourable vote.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: This agreement with Ghana seems to be a Trojan horse aimed at imposing on other West African States to open their markets, with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign at this time. I therefore object to this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the progress agreement towards an EU-Ghana Economic Partnership Agreement. This partnership will provide Ghana with preferential access to the European market. I consistently support all the texts aimed at the development of Africa, because it is by helping the development of this continent that will allow its people to have prospects for the future.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: Convinced of the great potential offered by the economic partnership agreements negotiated between the EU and the ACP countries; learning with regret of the difficulties encountered in ratifying an agreement regional with the countries of the ECOWAS community; assessed the incompatibility of the current tariff preferences regime, the MAR, with the principle of reciprocity provided for by the rules of the International Organization of trade; having regard to the bilateral ratification of the interim economic partnership agreement between the EU and the Ivory Coast; recognising the asymmetrical nature of the agreement which provides for a limited opening and gradual Ghanaian market in the face of unlimited and immediate access to the single market; recognising the democratic and sovereign nature of the Ghanaian Parliament and its Government, we vote in favour of the ratification of the interim agreement. The asymmetrical nature of the agreement protects Ghanaian interests, guaranteeing the country privileged access to the Community market and, at the same time, protecting the nascent local industrial system and economic diversification by preventing access of sensitive goods. On the other hand, the European system will benefit from imports, especially agricultural, from products not overlapping the Community market and production chain and better access to the Ghanaian market for its own machinery and equipment, products needed by the Ghanaian industry and not available locally.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU negotiated an Economic Partnership Agreement with 16 West African states making West Africa EU’s largest trading partner in sub-Saharan Africa. I have voted for this agreement between the EU and Ghana that covers goods and development cooperation. Ivory Coast, Ghana and Nigeria account for 80%of West Africa’s exports to the EU.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report as I believe it will disadvantage Ghana. The report was on establishing a transitional trade deal between the EU and Ghana while the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement negotiations are still underway. The trade deal voted on is an Economic Partnership Agreement. The EU has been using these EPAs with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries in order to force the liberalisation of their economies without providing any new benefit to them. The ACP countries already have access to the EU market but in recent years the EPA deals struck by Europe open access to the poorer countries to the EU without factoring in the massive inequality between the partners. This agreement will be detrimental to the majority of people of Ghana and it does not contain a sustainable development chapter.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this agreement because, firstly, there is a risk of significant negative effects on the country's economy with an increase in duty-free imports into the country, and secondly, duty-free exports of certain agricultural products will put pressure on European producers, thus preventing exports. will be more profitable than local consumption.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The Intermediate Economic Partnership Agreement enables Ghana to maintain duty-free concessions on the European market in a situation where Ghana is developing and securing its position as a middle-income country. In addition, if the Regional Economic Partnership Agreement is to be implemented without a long delay, any inconsistencies in the schedules for the liberalisation of customs tariffs and customs tariffs would be possible to resolve without the need for further adjustment to regional processes.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — It is essential to ensure that the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, adequately safeguards the legal interests of both parties. In order to strengthen trade and development policy instruments, it is important to respect the fundamental values of the EU, to ensure the stability needed to achieve new investment and job creation. Furthermore, the disturbance of trade in Ghana needs to be avoided and safeguard measures must be applied. Given the extremely difficult economic situation of Ghana and the fact that it is a lower-than-middle-income country, it is essential to protect its economy, ensure adequate food security and create conditions for the development of industry.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that the ratification of the Agreement (APEI), signed in 2007, between Ghana and the EU guarantees a contractual safety net, as ensure duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is implemented. In addition, this agreement is a simple interim solution to prevent the disruption of trade between the EU and Ghana, as the latter is one of the largest exporters of cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this agreement as it ensures a contractual safety net, warranting a duty-free quota free access to the EU market and asymmetric, gradual opening of Ghana’s market to EU goods until the regional agreement comes into a fruition. The IEPA will allow Ghanaian exporters to preserve the duty-free preferences on the European market as Ghana moves up and consolidates its status as a middle-income country. Furthermore, if the regional EPA comes into place without excessive delays, any discrepancies in the IEPA tariff liberalisation schedules and tariff lines would be solved without a need for additional adaptation to the regional processes.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a resolution on the transitional Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana. The transitional agreement takes into account two key changes, one of which is the accession of the Republic of Croatia into the European Union in 2013 and the introduction of a common external tariff. This agreement is useful because it creates a market for European products and outside the European Union, but also provides a greater development boost to Ghana. The purpose of this agreement is to prevent the formation of trade disruptions. Unlimited access to the European market will give Ghana the stability and predictability of future trade relations and pave the way for new investment and job creation. The advantage of this contract is that it guarantees the activation of mechanisms such as customs duty in cases where a sharp increase in imports may result in a distortion of the economic situation or harm the security of food supply or when the initial development of industries is threatened. The European Union must be consistent in implementing development policy mechanisms and instruments towards middle and lower income countries because their economic development is a prerequisite for creating a more stable political system and establishing peace across Africa.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Ghana is an important European partner in Africa, especially in promoting regional economic integration and investment, and more than 20% of Ghana's foreign trade is waste to trade with the EU. Ghana is seeking to cement its transit centre status in the region and diversify its economy - thus making the EU its leading destination for the country's new export sectors. Due to the indecision of partner countries, Ghana has decided to revive the transitional Economic Partnership Agreement, while, together with the EU, it seeks to encourage other countries to conclude a comprehensive regional development agreement. The transitional agreement will not be able to fully respond to the demands of today's age, but it gives the necessary stability until an interregional solution is established. The agreement will prevent the emergence of trade disruptions and adequately prepare Ghana for a future regional Economic Partnership Agreement. It will allow Ghanaian exporters to retain duty-free benefits for the European market as Ghana advances and solidifies its position as the middle-income country. But I note - Ghana needs to continue to make efforts to combat corruption and eradicate child labour in all sectors where it is present. The EU is also ready to help deliver meaningful fiscal reforms, improve business climate and competitiveness, and facilitate trade and customs cooperation.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Stage Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Ghana, recommends that the European Parliament approve the conclusion of this Agreement, paving the way for its implementation Provisional. Ghana and the EU are partners in different areas, notably in promoting regional economic integration and investment. In 2015, the total value of bilateral trade between Ghana and the Union amounted to €5.4 billion, representing more than 20% of Ghana's external trade. The country is one of the main agri-food exporters in the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) region, exporting cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish, and importing rice, sugar and meat. Nothing is said about the pernicious effects of free trade, the appropriation by multinationals of natural resources and biodiversity, rising unemployment and the threat to sovereignty. While rejecting this recommendation, we express our full solidarity with the people of Ghana, as well as with the other peoples of West Africa, for their right to development, sovereignty and independence. We voted against it.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the fact that the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) requires an additional period of time, Ghana (then Côte d'Ivoire) decided in August 2016 to continue the ratification of the preliminary Economic Partnership Agreement with The European Union, concluded in 2007. The agreement guarantees a contractual collateral system, continuing full access without duties and quotas to the EU market until the EPA Regional Agreement is finally signed by all countries in that West African region. The Interim Agreement provides for temporary application and will be replaced in full by the EPA agreement concluded at the regional level, on the date of the entry into force of that agreement. I hereby supported the initial Economic Partnership Agreement with the EU.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report on the EU-Ghana Economic Partnership Agreement. In view of the delay in signing the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and West Africa, Ghana has decided to proceed with the ratification of its Stage Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, concluded in 2007. I encourage the conclusion of this agreement and reiterate that our trade relations with Africa are essential and in the interests of all.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote. Whilst we concede that EU deals with poor countries often exacerbate poverty, we note the desire of the Ghanaian Government to sign this deal so as to secure market access. For this reason, despite our reservations about this deal, we abstained.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. — On Thursday, MEPs approved the interim economic agreement concluded in 2007 with Ghana, by 375 votes to 220, with 46 abstentions. Since June 2014, the EU and West Africa (comprising 16 countries) have been trying to ratify a Regional Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) for economic growth and free trade. However, this partnership still requires the approval of Nigeria, Gambia and Mauritania before being ratified, making the remaining 13 signatory countries dependent on their goodwill. A situation that could have had harmful consequences for Ghana if the current Ghana-EU economic agreement, which comes to an end at the end of the year, had remained unsuccessful. The European Parliament has therefore taken the right decision by supporting the position of its rapporteur, Mr Fjellner, in favour of free, customs free access to the European market for Ghanaian products. With more than 20% of foreign trade destined for the European Union amounting to €5.4 billion in 2015, this temporary solution was essential for Ghana's stability, development and economic growth.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana (AAEI) because፦ Improves the legal certainty of Ghanaian trade with Europe (avoiding a possible loss of tariff exemptions currently granted temporarily and unilaterally by the Union), improving the regulation of our trade (contains provisions on trade in goods, customs, trade facilitation, technical barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, while maintaining the free access exception for bananas destined for ultra-peripheral regions) - Incorporates mandatory commitments on sustainability and human rights, such as combating illegal trade in timber, corruption and child labour. - The Ghanaian Government has requested this agreement after consulting the actors concerned and its Parliament has strongly supported its ratification. - A possible rise in tariffs, in the absence of AAEI, would be very detrimental to a country that allocates more than 20 per cent of its foreign trade to the Union. - Socialists will monitor the proper monitoring of Ghana's commitments, while we continue to work towards a good regional EPA with all West Africa and demand from Ghana greater democratic progress and dialogue with civil society.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Trade — the best engine for economic development. Effective trade relations provide opportunities for sustainable development of the country and are therefore a more effective tool for development aid than development cooperation. Therefore, I fully welcome and support the recommendation discussed today on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Ghana, of the other part. By developing trade relations, sometimes using asymmetric preferential tools, we will help build a sustainable African economy, thereby strengthening our well-being and security.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This proposal for a recommendation concerns the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Ghana, of the other part, in view of the delay in the signing of the Economic Partnership Agreement EU-West Africa. Ratification of this agreement will provide Ghana with a contractual guarantee of duty-free access to the Union market until the entry into force of the regional agreement. It is therefore a stage agreement, which will be applied provisionally until the entry into force of the regional agreement, in strict compliance with WTO rules. Although it is not the ideal solution, given the lack of a regional dimension, rules of origin and a complete institutional framework, Ghana is carrying out a set of reforms and is making efforts to combat corruption and eliminate child labour, so this step agreement provides a basis is more robust than the Market Access Regulation and forms the antechamber of what will be the regional agreement. I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which constitutes the approval by the European Parliament of the interim agreement with Ghana. This agreement ensures the sensitivities of certain sectors and guarantees duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market. At the same time, it opens up the Ghana market asymmetrically and gradually to European products. It should be noted that in the event of market disruptions, the agreement also provides for safeguard clauses. It is therefore an agreement developing a gradual and asymmetrical liberalisation of trade between the EU and Ghana.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I am totally against these types of economic agreements and the impacts that result from them, both for the Union, and especially for third countries, in this case Ghana. For example, Ghana is asked to give up all the protection tools of its industry and agriculture, making it impossible for them to protect their own market. My vote was therefore negative.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — Among the areas of the partnership between Ghana and the EU, the promotion of regional economic integration and investment is of particular importance. In 2015, total bilateral trade between Ghana and the EU stood at around €5.4 billion and included more than 20% of Ghana's foreign trade, exporter of cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish. In addition, about a third of the country's timber exports are headed to the EU. Ghana imports rice, sugar and meat as well as ships, vehicles and refined oil. That country is also seeking to consolidate its position as a maritime transit hub for landlocked West African countries. The Interim Economic Partnership Agreement thus guarantees the safe continuation of the partnership between the two countries until the regional agreement can finally be signed by all the countries of the West African region. I therefore decided to speak out in favour.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the EU-Ghana Economic Partnership Agreement because it is an agreement that guarantees continued 'duty-free and quota-free 'access to the Union's internal market, thereby protecting thousands of jobs and strengthening Ghana's exports. This agreement, which has been negotiated a few years ago, is provisional and will only be in force until the regional agreement (already concluded) between the EU and the West African States (ECOWAS) has been ratified. I would like to point out that the Ghana Parliament, which is responsible for deciding on the national interest, approved the agreement unanimously. This is not a perfect agreement, but it is compatible with WTO rules and offers stability. Neither the market access regulation for ACP countries (MAR) nor the incentive scheme of the EU Generalised System of Preferences (GSP+) are satisfactory alternatives. Finally, the bilateral agreement contains safeguard measures for local industry and excludes from liberalisation the products most sensitive to the Ghanaian economy. My vote respects Ghana's national choice.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of Ghana’s Interim Economic Partnership Agreement in order to ensure Ghana’s duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market until the Regional EPA is achieved which would see an integrated West African Economic Community.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I did not support this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual quality and quantity work, efficiency and most of all the success of advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — I abstained in the vote on the agreement between the European Community and Ghana because there are some doubts about this proposal. The agreement, whose roots go back to 2007, is of a makeshift nature due to the long-awaited signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement. The signing of the regional West African agreement hampers Nigeria's missing signature. The Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the EU aims to ensure duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement enters into force. I recognise that the EU is a major trading partner of Ghana, with the total volume of bilateral trade for 2015 equal to EUR 5.4 billion, making up more than 20% of Ghana's foreign trade. I also appreciate the fact that Ghana is diversifying its industry and undergoing forest reforms, which are of major importance to the country. However, I must point out that the country should continue to fight corruption and the elimination of child labour in the agricultural, forestry or fisheries sectors. It should also be noted that the 2007 agreement does not correspond to the situation in 2016. The agreement should be set up to ensure that the country has access to the European market, which would accelerate economic development by creating new business opportunities.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: ‒ By signing the Temporary Economic Partnership Agreement (IEPA) with the EU, Ghana may avoid problems with tariffs, but at the same time it sacrifices the regional integration of Ecowas. To keep out cheap EU products, Ecowas members might raise their tariffs against Ghana. After a five-year moratorium, Ghana must release EU imports, which will only increase competition. In addition, there is a clause which makes a quick opening to the liberalisation of services and other free trade disciplines. Knowing that Ghana is a privileged partner of the UK, it is guessing the consequences of Brexit. As a result, you can not call the iEPA a stepping stone, but rather a well where the whole EPA EU-Ecowas process falls into. The Commission's Trade DG is behind this is worrying. The promising integration process is being called into question, and the agreement focuses mainly on the economic interests of the major European actors. It also runs counter to European principles such as policy coherence in development cooperation and the agreed development goals. Ghana was also able to opt for the GSP+ regime, with special preferential rates for vulnerable countries. This agreement has such far-reaching consequences that it is impossible for me to approve it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The signing of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the EU and West Africa takes longer than anticipated. The agreement aims to ensure a contractual safety net, which guarantees duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement enters into force, and assumes that the interim agreement will apply on a provisional basis until it is replaced by the full EPA concluded at regional level on the date of its entry into force. Moreover, if the regional EPA enters into force without undue delay, it is assumed that any differences between tariff liberalisation schedules and customs items within the EPA would be resolved without further adaptation to procedures at regional level.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, on the one hand, and the European Community and its Member States, on the other. While the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement takes longer, Ghana decided in August 2016 (followed by Côte d'Ivoire) to ratify its Interim Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union in 2007. The agreement provides a contractual safety net that guarantees duty-free access to the EU market until the implementation of the regional agreement. The Interim Agreement provides for its application on a provisional basis and replacing the Agreement after the entry into force of the comprehensive regional EPA. The agreement promotes trade between States and provides for full market access for Ghana, a low-income country, on the basis of a long-term contractual relationship. Interfering investment protection rules, which should be followed by a refusal, are not included.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — Given the postponement of the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement, Ghana, and then Ivory Coast, decided in August 2016 to ratify the transitional Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union, concluded back in 2007. The agreement provides a contractual safety net and allows Ghana duty-free access to the EU market. Ghana is among the leading agri-food exporters of the Economic Community of West African countries and exports cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish. I accept the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the EU-Ghana Interim Economic Partnership Agreement because the Agreement will allow Ghanaian exporters to retain duty-free benefits for the European market as Ghana progresses and strengthens its position as a middle-income country, all of which leads to greater stability of this part of Africa.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of an interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Ghana, of the other part. Before a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement enters into force between the European Union and Ghana, the Interim Agreement will be provisionally valid pending the entry into force of the Comprehensive Agreement. In the meantime, Ghana has duty-free access to the EU market. As the final negotiations on the Regional Economic Partnership Agreement are slow, we need a renewal of the interim agreement.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - It is proposed to revive an outdated 2007 agreement which, undoubtedly, cannot fully meet the conditions of 2016, in order to avoid disruption of trade for Ghana, while paving the way for a future EPA. The European policy pursued in the conclusion of bilateral preferential trade agreements should prejudge the implementation of updated and integrated solutions rather than temporary incomplete agreements.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement is delayed, in August 2016 Ghana (later Côte d'Ivoire) decided to ratify the EPA with the European Union in 2007. The agreement provides a contractual safety net and guarantees duty-free access to the EU market until the regional agreement is reached. The Interim Agreement foresees provisional application and is replaced by a full EPA at regional level on the date of its entry into force. Although Ghana's export revenues are dominated by gold, cocoa and crude oil, the Union has become the primary target of Ghana's' non-traditional 'exports, showing increasing diversification and value added creation within the country. Imports from Ghana are dominated by ships, vehicles and refined crude oil. The country is trying to stabilise its position as the transit and sea centre of landlocked countries. While Ghana excludes certain sensitive agricultural and processed products from liberalisation, the Interim EPA also introduces safeguards allowing the reintroduction of customs duties in the event of a sudden increase in imports with a distortion of the economy, threatens to threaten food security. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — I abstained on the proposal for a decision envisaging the implementation of the EPA already drawn up between the EU and Ghana, recognising the importance of the agreement and considering the specific economic content of the agreement doubts. I am aware that it is important for the Ghanaian economy to continue to provide duty-free with the EU even after the interim agreement that expired in October this year, for which this partnership could provide a framework. I also considered that Ghana is a democratic state where government and legislature unanimously agreed to sign the agreement. However, I could not dispense with the serious concerns expressed, mainly by my own group, suggesting that the Commission had asserted its superiority during the negotiation of the agreement and thus poses, on several points, an economic risk unfavourable to Ghana. Obviously, Ghana would also be more favourable to develop its European trade relations on the basis of an agreement planned with the EU under the auspices of ECOWAS, but it is a fact that this multilateral agreement is still being drawn up, does not benefit from the support of all the parties and thus does not provide short-term solution in terms of export positions in Ghana. In view of the complex and controversial situation in this matter, I decided to abstain from voting on the specific proposal for a decision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted against the Fjellner report. Indeed, I think it is time to review our way of making agreements and to consider Africa as our storage room, with the significant risk of impoverishing the local and regional population by imbalance the trade and economic flow of the targeted countries!

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a transitional Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. Ghana and the EU are partners in a variety of areas, including encouraging regional economic integration and investment. In 2015, total trade in both directions between Ghana and the EU was €5.4 billion, accounting for more than 20% of Ghana's foreign trade. Ghana is among the leading agri-food exporters of the Economic Community of West African countries and exports cocoa, fruit, nuts and fish, while importing rice, sugar and meat. Ghana has decided to revive the nine-year agreement and not wait for the remaining undecided partner countries of the Economic Partnership Agreement with West Africa to decide on the signing of the Regional Development Trade Agreement, initialed on 30 June 2014 and which are The leaders of the Economic Community of West African countries officially supported on 10 July 2014. While both Ghana and the EU continue to invest time and effort to conclude a comprehensive Regional Economic Partnership Agreement, the transitional Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana and the EU, in the absence of a comprehensive agreement, remains a tentative solution in line with WTO provisions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - A transitional Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana is necessary until a regional partnership agreement with West Africa is concluded, and its purpose is for that country to have duty-free access to the European Union market. Total trade between the EU and Ghana was 5.4 billion euros in 2015 and roughly a third of Ghanaian wood raw material exports waste to the EU. I believe that the Transitional Agreement clearly stipulates that Ghana should continue its reforms in order to continue cooperation, primarily in the areas of combating corruption and eliminating all forms of child labour in the agriculture, forestry, fisheries and gold sectors. Since the Transitional Agreement marks the ratification of the agreement signed in 2007, I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. Signing the EU-West Africa economic partnership still takes a long time, so Ghana has decided to continue ratifying the interim agreement on economic cooperation with the EU. In 2015, the value of total bilateral trade between Ghana and the EU amounted to €5.4 billion and comprised more than 20% of Ghanaian foreign trade. About a third of the timber exported by Ghana is destined for European markets (a signed agreement allowing for legal trade in wood with the EU). The 2007 Agreement undoubtedly does not fully correspond to the reality of 2016, so the interim agreement needs to be renewed. The interim agreement provides Ghana, a lower-middle-income country, 100% market access based on a long-term contractual relationship, thus the stability necessary for new investment and job creation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this consent report on the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and Ghana, as it reinforces an asymmetrical logic and peripheral-centre subordination of trade relations, condemning Ghana in the long term to underdevelopment.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: Ghana has decided to sign the 2007 Economic Partnership Agreement: this agreement provides duty-free access to the EU market. Ghana is one of West Africa's leading agri-food exporters. It also exports wood, gold, oil, cocoa. The agreement will increase Ghana's exports to the EU, which are “liberalised”, from 35 to 80% of the total. Ghana protects its sensitive agricultural and food production. This agreement with Ghana appears to be unbalanced and aims to impose on other West African States to open their markets, with the signing of a regional partnership agreement which they are refusing to sign for the time being. I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The Agreement guarantees a working system of safeguards, ensuring full access of partners without duties and quotas to the EU market until a regional agreement is finally signed by all countries in that region of West Africa. The Interim Agreement provides for temporary application and will be replaced fully by an agreement concluded at regional level on the date of entry into force of that agreement. That's why I supported the initial agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the signing of the EU-West Africa Economic Partnership Agreement is delayed, in August 2016 Ghana (later Côte d'Ivoire) decided to ratify the EPA with the European Union in 2007. In voksom, I followed the position of the faction.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this consent report on the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and Ghana, as it reinforces an asymmetrical logic and peripheral-centre subordination of trade relations, condemning Ghana in the long term to underdevelopment.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the stepping stone Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. Ghana and the EU are partners across different areas, including that of fostering regional economic integration and investment. In 2015, the total two-way trade between Ghana and the EU was worth 5.4 billion euros, comprising over 20% of Ghana’s external trade. As soon as the regional EPA enters into force, it will replace the two existing interim EPAs within the region. I voted in favour because I believe that the IEPA ensures to Ghana, a lower middle-income country, a 100% market access offer based on a long-term contractual relationship, which will ensure stability needed for new investments and job creation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I am totally against these types of economic agreements and the impacts that result from them, both for the Union, and especially for third countries, in this case Ghana. For example, Ghana is asked to give up all the protection tools of its industry and agriculture, making it impossible for them to protect their own market. My vote was therefore negative.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This EPA guarantees full market access to Ghana, middle/low-income country, which, allegedly, will ensure the stability necessary for new investments and job creation. Around 35% of the Union's exports to Ghana have already been fully or almost completely liberalised and the further reduction in customs duties will lead to a gradual increase of this proportion to 80%. The CFP maintains strong doubts about these partnership agreements based on free trade and the principle of free functioning of markets. Time will be taken to answer whether this agreement has been beneficial to the people of Ghana or contributed to disrupting the economy, jeopardising food security or compromising their emerging industry.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I could not agree with the report on an EC/Ghana Interim Economic Partnership Agreement because, on the one hand, there is a risk of significant negative effects on the country's economy when it increases duty-free imports into the country. On the other hand, duty-free exports of certain agricultural products to the EU would put pressure on European producers, making exports more profitable than local consumption.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I joined many colleagues in my Socialist and Democratic Group, including the shadow rapporteur, in voting against the EU-Ghana EPA. The agreement falls short on sustainable development and labour rights criteria, and risks to interfere with regional integration under ECOWAS. We object to the Commission’s conduct in rushing the agreement through, while we express support to our progressive colleagues in Ghana. As an advocate of the Alternative Trade Mandate (ATM) I support trade that puts people and planet ahead of profit. This is a complex and multifaceted issue, but upon listening and weighing both sides of the argument, I have concluded that a vote against would reflect these ATM principles.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: in writing. — I fully support, like our ECR Group, the conclusion of this EU-Ghana Interim Trade Agreement. Although neither Ghana nor the EU anticipated the need to conclude a bilateral agreement, the protracted pace of concluding a West African Regional Level Agreement (ECOWAS) prompted them to do so. The interim agreement will allow Ghanaian exporters to maintain the privilege of duty-free access to the European market for a period during which Ghana will grow economically and consolidate its economic situation. In this context, I would like to emphasise the development aspect of this trade agreement: the EU is an important place for exporting Ghanaian products, which is important for creating added value in the country. This is not only a benefit to European exporters (80% of EU exports should be gradually liberalised), but also to Ghana, where exports to the EU account for about 20% of the total foreign trade. The best development policy is free trade.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the provisional EU-Ghana EPA tabled. I see the adoption of this document as a logical step, as the planned EU-West Africa regional agreement must be delayed and therefore the interim agreement will allow Ghana to continue to have the privilege duty-free access to the European market. Ghana is a leading exporter of agricultural products as well as other commodities within the West African region, and the EU is an important export market for it. It is in the interest of the European Union that countries in the West African region strengthen their competitiveness, improve their business environment and enhance customs cooperation. I am confident that this agreement will clearly help this.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported my consent to the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana. Ghana has decided to take such a step, in particular, because the process of signing the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and West Africa has been taking too long and is constantly delaying. Thus, the Interim Agreement will ensure Ghana duty-free access to the European Union market until the signature of the Economic Partnership Agreement, and will automatically lose effect with the entry into force of the new Economic Partnership Agreement. I welcome the fact that Ghana and, later, Côte d'Ivoire have taken this step. It is clear that they care about trade relations with the European Union and, on the other hand, I also think that this interim agreement will help the economic situation of both countries and help strengthen relations between them and the European Union.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Fjellner report because, although I believe that the EC-Ghana Stage Economic Partnership Agreement is incomplete and outdated, I believe that a step agreement will fulfil its objective of helping to avoid trade disruption in Ghana and, at the same time, prepare the ground for a future relationship based on a regional partnership agreement. I would also like to point out that this stage Economic Partnership Agreement offers opportunities for promoting regional economic integration and investment. For example, in 2015, the total value of bilateral trade between Ghana and the Union amounted to €5.4 billion, representing more than 20% of Ghana's external trade.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on the transitional Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Ghana, which takes into account two important facts — one is the entry of the Republic of Croatia into the European Union, and the other is the introduction of a common external tariff. In addition to strengthening integration in the European market, it is necessary to expand the prospects of European businessmen towards third countries in a way that new markets are opened. Under the European Development Policy and Assistance, this transitional agreement can create certainty for Ghanaian businessmen who will be able to place their products on the European Union market. On the other hand, in addition to the opening of a new market, agreed mechanisms between the European Union and Ghana protect Ghanaian producers in the event of an increase in imports that may cause distortion of the economic situation or cause harm to food supply channels. Mechanisms also protect the development of industries in its early growth in the territory of Ghana. Development policy instruments towards middle-income and lower income countries must be targeted and tailored to each individual state in order for their economic growth to create a stable political system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. — It voted to approve the conclusion of an Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. I support the conclusion of the interim agreement as it will help to avoid disruption to trade for Ghana while serving as the basis for a future regional economic partnership agreement. The interim agreement provides Ghana, a lower-middle-income country, thus providing 100% market access on the basis of a long-term contractual relationship and thus the stability necessary for new investment and job creation.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The regulation of the Multiannual Financial Framework for the year 201-2020 established the possibility of using the margin for contingencies, up to 0.03% of national GDP. The use of a budget tool is always a fairly sensitive and controversial issue, however this case the margin for unforeseen could be used to deal with the migration crisis. In fact, it is very clear that large amounts of funds are needed to manage the huge waves of migrants from distressed territories, and this instrument could be the right means. That's why I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The contingency margins may have a positive element with regards to allocating aid which would assist migrants and refugees, however one must also take into account this also includes the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, and support for the likes of Frontex. This is because these margins are for Heading 3 ‘Security and citizenship’. For 2017 this also includes Heading 4 ‘Global Europe’ which covers programmes such as: the Common Security and Defence Policy, Guarantee Fund for external Actions, and ‘Macro-financial assistance’. It was proposed originally by the European Parliament to also use the Contingency margins for 2016 and 2017 for sustaining certain programmes which would fall under Heading 1 of the multi-financial framework for programmes that are progressive and socially orientated. However the Council did not budge and dictated that under that Heading, funds would have to be redeployed instead, which would mean cutting such programmes to fund another similar programme under that heading, as opposed to using the contingency margin which would entail not having to resort to sacrificing one programme over another. As a result we abstained on the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under Heading 3, “Security and Citizenship”, amounting to €2.578 billion, and heading 4, 'Europe in the world', to the tune of €9.432 billion. It is therefore a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, the funds mobilized will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the contingency reserve in 2016. The Commission proposed mobilising 240.1 million in 2016. the contingency reserve of EUR EUR to complement commitment appropriations related to expenditure under heading 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under Heading 3, “Security and Citizenship”, amounting to €2.578 billion, and heading 4, 'Europe in the world', to the tune of €9.432 billion. These huge sums should, in my view, be offset by a decrease in the appropriations for administration. Worse, the funds mobilized are supposed to finance the policy of asylum and the integration of illegal migrants, which is unacceptable. I therefore strongly voted against this mobilization proposal: any money mobilized in relation to the migrant crisis should be so to send them back to their countries and prevent them from (re) coming.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I endorsed this report, which proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2016 up to 240 million euros in order to meet the migration situation, the needs of migrants and the security situation.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is the mobilization of one of the loopholes in the budget in order to meet the Funds for the Integration of Persons in Asylum and Migration Situations. A technical adjustment to make, along with other flexibility instruments that are modified, to address the challenges of safety and mobility of people. This funding, which will in part be used as a financial instrument, in the style of the Juncker Plan, will be used to finance the continuation and stopperation of migration of persons in situations of forced mobility in countries bordering the Union. They will have an investment component in those areas (which will enable local and transnational authorities to do business), also humanitarian, but in turn the retention of that population. It will consist of mobilising this margin up to EUR 2 150.6 million, offset by cuts in agriculture and administration. Disguising mismanagement of resources as humanitarian aid.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this report on the mobilisation of the contingency margin in 2016 where an amount of EUR 240.1 million will be mobilised in commitment appropriations above the commitment ceiling of heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report on the mobilization of the contingency margin for 2016 proposes to mobilise in 2017 the sum of EUR 2.150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under heading 3, “Security and Citizenship”, to the tune of 2,578 billion and, under heading 4, 'Europe in the world', to the tune of 9.432 billion. This is therefore the problem of migrants, with policies that must therefore finance asylum policy and the integration of refugees. So, of course, I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — Technically the margin for unexpected situations is a tool of last resort, which is used to raise funds, if Europe faces serious and unexpected situations, if and only if they are all other sources of funding available within the MFF have been exhausted. Solving the migration crisis and the problem of citizens' safety are priorities that I share. My support for the demand for an increase in funds for these headings would therefore be granted if it were accompanied by a real and radical change in the policies in which these contributions are run over. As long as FRONTEX, EASO, FAMI are funded to encourage the invasion of migrants and not to block their flows, I am not going to vote on measures like this.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have abstained in respect of these three reports. On the one hand, I support redisposing of resources and being put into supporting refugees arriving in the EU. On the other hand, much of these resources are spent on Frontex and the further construction of Fortress Europe, as well as the shameful refugee agreement with Turkey, which I strongly oppose. As the budget is made, the different parts are not separated from each other. That is why I have chosen to abstain in these ballots.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having examined all other funding possibilities to respond to unforeseen circumstances within the commitments ceiling for 2016 under heading 3 (Security and citizenship) of the multiannual financial framework, and having mobilised the Flexibility Instrument for the total amount of EUR 1 530 million available in 2016, this Decision, which I voted in favour, mobilizes the Contingency Margin of EUR 240.1 million to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by increasing the commitment appropriations of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 above the commitment ceiling under heading 3.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it endorsed the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the contingency reserve in 2016. Together with Draft amending budget No 4/2016, the Commission proposed mobilising 240.1 million in 2016. the contingency reserve of EUR EUR to supplement commitment appropriations related to expenditure under heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Commission proposes that the contingency reserve shall be mobilised in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 in order to secure a commitment ceiling of EUR 240.1 million above the commitment ceiling of Chapter 3 of the multiannual financial framework commitment appropriations. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to the release of the security reserve to respond to the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crises. However, we will be able to respond to these needs by increasing commitments above the ceiling of Section 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. With this additional €240,1 million, we will be able to adequately address the aid needed.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the mobilisation of the contingency reserve in 2016, which was adopted by a large majority of votes on the Committee.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — Once again, the Commission proposes to allocate 240 million to meet the needs of the migration crisis, at the expense of the appropriations allocated to the administration. This measure is unacceptable, given that these sums should, in my view, be devoted exclusively to organizing the return of these migrants to their countries of origin. For all these reasons, I am voting against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ As far as programming and early management of funds is an important and efficient element of the European Union's financial strategy, it is also necessary to consider that not all events can be predicted accurately, neither in their occurrence nor in the resources that will be needed to deal with them. It is therefore necessary to provide a flexible margin, allowing the mobilisation of extraordinary resources capable of coping with unforeseen criticalities for the year 2017, in order to promptly make effective administrative action of the European Union and to be quickly supported by crisis areas.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report aims to mobilise the contingency margin for 2016 in order to provide EUR 240.1 million in commitment and payment appropriations in order to respond to the current migration crisis. The European Commission also recommends that this instrument be activated in order to finance policies for the reception of illegal migrants. These sums will also have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. It is strictly unacceptable for the European Union to use our taxes to finance the overwhelming migration to which a vast majority of our fellow citizens strongly oppose. Any funds mobilized in the context of the migration crisis should be mobilized to finance the return of illegal migrants to their countries of origin. At a time when our fellow citizens, especially young people, are faced with mass unemployment, the explosion of poverty and the increase in social inequalities, it is essential to allocate all European funds to them! Of course, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — After examining all possible variants for financing additional and unforeseen needs of commitment appropriations, the Commission proposed in its draft budget to mobilise, from the contingency margin, an amount of EUR 1 164.4 million for completing the appropriations of commitment for expenditure under heading 3, in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, above the commitment ceiling of EUR 2 578 million in current prices. Additional financial needs were envisaged in 2017 in order to respond effectively to humanitarian problems, security crises or refugee crisis. As a result, I welcome the proposal to mobilise the contingency margin in 2017, so that the necessary funds can be provided for next year's problems. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I consider it essential to mobilise this amount in order to meet the stringent financial needs of the 2017 challenges.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the decision in question because it is essential to mobilise the margin for contingencies in order to meet the needs arising from the migration crisis, Refugees and security by increasing commitment appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 beyond the limits of the ceilings set by the Multiannual Financial Framework. After examining all other financial possibilities in order to respond to unforeseen circumstances within the 2016 commitment ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework and after mobilizing the instrument of flexibility for the full amount of EUR 1 530 million available in 2016, the measure adopted appears to be the only possible. Under the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016, the contingency margin will be mobilised to provide the amount of EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations beyond the commitment ceiling under heading 3 (Security and citizenship) of the multiannual financial framework. The amount of EUR 240,1 million in commitment appropriations referred to in Article 1 shall be deducted in full from the margin within the commitment ceiling of heading 5 (Administration) of the Financial Framework multiannual year for the financial year 2016.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Contingency margins were one of the few new measures that were introduced in the multi-financial framework from 2014-20, it is essentially a last resort instrument, or to simplify; a ‘reserve fund’, to use in the event of unforeseen circumstances. The Commission must make the proposal in light of such events and the Council must adopt it. While I fully support the increase in expenditure related to the ongoing humanitarian crisis with thousands of people fleeing conflicts in Syria and Iraq, I do not support neither the proposed increase in expenditure for security measures, nor the expenses related to the EU-Turkey declaration on refugees. Therefore I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Contingency Margin is an EU financial instrument which is meant to be used as a last resort for unforeseen circumstances and amounts to 0.03% of EU GNI. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 240.1 million for 2016 to use on the migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP voted against as we oppose the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to mobilise the mechanism of additional possibilities for unforeseen needs for 2016. The existence of such mechanisms can only have positive consequences for Member States and citizens, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The contingency margin is a tool used to raise funds from EU gross national income and deal with serious and unforeseen situations in the event of exhaustion of all other sources of funding available in the EU Multiannual Financial Framework (period 2014-2020). The report is allocated EUR 240 million for the migration crisis and citizens' security for 2016. Support for these measures would be discounted, but in reality these resources are used to encourage the invasion of migrants and not to block their flows. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ As a man at the service of citizens, but especially as an Italian I can only participate favourably in the decision to mobilize the margin for unforeseen events for 2016. In fact, as much as EUR 240.1 million will be allocated to the expenditure on “Security and Citizenship” of the EU budget for 2016. This choice is made priority by the overbearing migration crisis that is going through Europe, which is accompanying that of refugees. A marasma of arduous proportions to be addressed and, even more, predicting leads to the looming of 0.03% of the EU's gross national income allocated by the Council to the margin under consideration. I therefore hope that it will see its own efficient and effective use, together with the consolidation of European security, under attack at the moment. We must never forget how the human tragedies from which hundreds of thousands of people flee must represent neither justification for cases of degradation such as those of Calais, but not even a source of dismay for citizens. Too often, indeed, we see congested suburbs and at the mercy of those who have no other places to go to the detriment, however, of the inhabitants; such a dynamic does nothing but fuel the climate of xenophobia and anger now sadly scattered throughout the Union as a whole.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2016.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Article 13 of Council Regulation 1311/2013 defined an unforeseen margin of up to 0.03% of the Union's gross national income. In accordance with Article 6 of that Regulation, the Commission calculated the absolute amount of contingency margin for 2016. Having mobilised the Flexibility Instrument for €1 530 million available for 2016, it is necessary to mobilise the contingency margin in order to meet the needs arising from the refugee, migration and security crisis by increasing the commitment appropriations of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 above the ceiling for category 3 authorisations (Security and Citizenship). Within the framework of the general budget of the Union for 2016, this report mobilises the contingency margin with the aim of making available an amount of EUR 240,1 million in commitment appropriations beyond the commitment ceiling in Category 3 of the multiannual financial framework. I therefore support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on Budgets.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to mobilise the Contingency Margin to address the needs stemming from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by increasing the commitment appropriations in the general budget for the financial year 2016, above the commitment ceiling in question.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — Addressing migration, refugees and enhancing the internal security of the Union is an extremely important issue, which absorbs not only significant resources but also human resources. Nevertheless, I believe that measures must be managed rationally and efficiently in every area of operation of the European Union, as well as looking for solutions that do not increase expenditure but provide an opportunity to achieve the objectives set. Thus, having analysed all aspects of the document, I voted against my own view that even greater efficiency can be achieved within the existing measures to resolve or reduce the costs of migration, refugees and security.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it considers that additional financial needs are likely to arise in 2017 in relation to the internal security crises and the current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges and thus acknowledges that these needs could significantly exceed the funding available.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This report constitutes one of the amending budgetary reports for 2016. In this context, it proposes a reduction of EUR 7 284 million (in surplus) in the area of economic, social and territorial cohesion, thus reducing national contributions accordingly, and proposes an increase of EUR 50 million for the instrument intended to provide emergency aid within the Union, of EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and EUR 70 million for the Internal Security Fund (ISF). Finally, this draft amending budget focuses in advance the provision of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) through a redeployment of EUR 73.9 million in commitment appropriations from the energy component of the Connecting Europe Facility (MIE-Energy). Considering that there is a need to reallocate surplus appropriations from the current emergencies, namely investment, growth, security and migration, I would like to point out the risk of non-payments at the end of the financial year on the economic, social and territorial cohesion component, which should be addressed within the framework of the forthcoming fiscal years. I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Contingency Margin is an EU financial instrument which is meant to be used as a last resort for unforeseen circumstances and amounts to 0.03% of EU GNI. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 240.1 million for 2016 to use on the migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP voted against as we oppose the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilizing the contingency margin for 2016. During 2016, we faced significant challenges in managing migration flows and the reception of refugees. This has resulted in the creation of new instruments, such as emergency aid, and higher than anticipated expenditures. Therefore, in order to finance these actions, while preserving the other programmes of the European budget, it is necessary to mobilise the margin for unforeseen events in 2016.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Commission proposes that the contingency reserve shall be mobilised in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 in order to secure a commitment ceiling of EUR 240.1 million above the commitment ceiling of Chapter 3 of the multiannual financial framework commitment appropriations. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget.
