The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2 150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under heading 3, “Security and Citizenship”, amounting to 2 578 billion, and heading 4 'Europe in the world', to the tune of 9 432 billion. These proposals aim to address the migrant crisis, while any funding should prioritize the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of this resolution. The 2013 Regulation on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) allows for the mobilisation of funds from an unforeseen margin to 0.03% of the EU-28 gross national income. Since the unforeseen margin is an instrument of 'last resort' for dealing with unforeseen circumstances and is used only when all other funding options have been exhausted, I consider the proposal to be good. The idea is to mobilise the unforeseen margin in 2017 for the amount of €1.9 billion, which concerns spending deemed necessary to tackle the immigrant and refugee crisis, including the new partnership framework announced in June. To compensate for these amounts, retained profits will be used. Furthermore, the overall ceilings of the MFF will not be exceeded by using the unforeseen margin. In general, the measures are reasonable and I reiterate — the mechanism is only “last resort”.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of the Union's resources. Financing Turkey under the supposed control of migratory flows leads to a full absorption of these funds, with the result that, in the event of unforeseen adverse situations in the future, there is not the necessary flexibility.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)

The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on the Solidarity Fund which enables EU financial assistance to be provided in the event of natural disasters. Despite my many calls, the UK Government refuses to take advantage of the Solidarity Fund to help overcome disasters in Wales.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: the Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2016 in order to provide €240.1 million in commitment appropriations to meet the needs arising from the migrant crisis.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following proposal as it ensures a easier recovery of the sums of money in the context of cross-border proceedings. The application of the European order for payment is a more economical and quicker way to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I vote against the report as long as FRONTEX, EASO, FAMI are funded to encourage the invasion of migrants and not to block their flows.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against mobilising the margin for unforeseen needs in 2016, as the EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, led to the waste of Union funds. Financing Turkey under the supposed control of migratory flows leads to a full absorption of these funds, with the result that, in the event of unforeseen adverse situations in the future, there is not the necessary flexibility.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the absence of any margin in commitments under Security and Citizenship (heading 3) in 2016, Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016 requires the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for + EUR 240,1 million with a full offsetting in 2016 against the unallocated margin of Administration (heading 5). An agreement on the contingency margin was reached in the framework of the 2017 EU Budget conciliation. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the Commission's proposal to supplement commitment appropriations related to expenditure under the heading 'Security and citizenship of the European Union” of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour for the mobilisation of the contingency Margin in 2016, given its mobilisation is necessary to address the needs stemming from the migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, given the absence of any margin in commitments under Security and Citizenship (heading 3) in 2016, Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016 requires the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for + EUR 240.1 million.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Commission proposes that the Contingency Margin shall be mobilised in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 in order to secure a commitment ceiling of EUR 240.1 million above the commitment ceiling of Chapter 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework commitment appropriations. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the Contingency Margin for 2016 for an amount of EUR 240 million so as to complement the commitment appropriations related to expenditure in ‘Security and citizenship’ in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of a proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision of Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the contingency reserve for 2016, as this allows mobilisation of €240.1 million under Title 3. Security and citizenship. I believe it is necessary to implement concrete measures and have the necessary financial resources to adequately respond to the challenges and obvious problems arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis. Therefore, I believe that these funds can positively contribute to mitigating the negative consequences of these crises, and I continue to support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I do not intend to support a project whose ambition is to finance the policies of asylum and integration of the so-called refugees, when the only obvious decision would be to mobilize these resources for the return of these populations to their countries of origin. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to mobilise the margin for contingencies in order to meet the needs arising from the migration and security crisis that we are experiencing, by increasing the commitment appropriations in the EU general budget for the financial year 2016 beyond the ceiling of initial commitments under heading security.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I reject this budget proposal. The aim is to activate the foreseen margins for unforeseen expenditure in the area of security and citizenship in relation to the migration, refugee and security crisis. This money would be better withdrawn in other areas.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Commission proposes that the contingency reserve shall be mobilised in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 in order to secure a commitment ceiling of EUR 240.1 million above the commitment ceiling of Chapter 3 of the multiannual financial framework commitment appropriations. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report in view of the absence of margin under heading 3 in 2016, Amending Budget No 4/2016 mobilizes the contingency margin by more than EUR 240,1 million with a total compensation in 2016 of the unallocated margin under heading 5 on Administration.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - In order to supplement the appropriations for commitments relating to expenditure in Title 3. “Security and Citizenship” in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016, the Commission proposed mobilising the 2016 contingency reserve of EUR 240,1 million. Once the Flexibility Instrument for the full amount of €1530 million available in 2016 has been mobilised, the contingency reserve is needed to respond to the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis. The appropriations of EUR 240.1 million will be fully beaten with a margin of up to the upper limit for commitments made in Title 5. (Administration) of the MFF for the financial year 2016, therefore I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal to mobilise the 2016 contingency reserve of EUR 240.1 million. The funds are intended to address the needs of the migration, refugee and security crisis in this calendar year.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I abstained on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to mobilise the margin for unforeseen needs in 2016 because it is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The objective of this text is to mobilize the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. This margin, amounting to €240.1 million in commitment appropriation, will finance the needs arising from the migrant crisis. However, this decision will lead to a reduction in the amounts allocated to the administration, which we find regrettable. On the other hand, there is behind this objective an integrationist will to which we oppose.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a favourable vote for the report on a decision of the EU Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2016. The mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for the full amount of EUR 240.1 million is vital to tackle the issues that arise from migration as well as the refugee and security crisis. At the same time, the mobilisation will also ‘complement the commitment appropriations related to expenditure in heading 3 Security and Citizenship’.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This proposal provides for the mobilisation of the contingency reserve to meet the needs arising from migration, refugees and the security crisis.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the 2016 contingency margin in order to provide EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations to meet the needs arising from the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is not conceivable for us. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. Consequently, I voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) Article 13 (1) of the MFF Regulation defines the margin for contingencies as an instrument of last resort to react to unforeseen circumstances. Having examined all other financial possibilities to react to unforeseen circumstances, within the ceiling of expenditure of Category 3 (Security and Citizenship) for 2016, and after proposing to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for Categories 3 and 4 for the total amount of 1 530 million EUR available in 2016, mobilisation of the contingency margin is necessary to address the needs arising from the refugee, migration and security crisis in order to increase the commitment appropriations of category 3 in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, above the ceiling of this category. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Contingency Margin for 2016 shall be tapped into to provide some EUR 240 million in commitment appropriations beyond the commitment limit stipulated in the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — It is necessary to mobilise the contingency margin in accordance with Article 13 of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 fixing a contingency margin of up to 0.03% of the Union's gross national income. This will enable the necessary and adequate actions to meet the needs arising from the migrant, refugee and security crisis, by increasing the commitment appropriations under heading 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 on 'security and citizenship' to an amount of 240.1 million EUR above the limit on commitments under this heading.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, because I agree that given the absence of any margin in commitments under Security and Citizenship (heading 3) in 2016, Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016 requires the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for + EUR 240,1 million with a full offsetting in 2016 against the unallocated margin of Administration (heading 5). An agreement on the contingency margin was reached in the framework of the 2017 EU Budget conciliation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Article 13 of Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020 established a contingency reserve of up to 0,03% of the gross national income of the Union. The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council the mobilisation of the contingency reserve in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016. The aim of the proposal is to provide for EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations above the commitment ceiling of Chapter 3 of the multiannual financial framework in order to meet the needs arising from the migration, asylum and security crisis. In its report, the Committee on Budgets proposes that Parliament approves the Commission's proposal to mobilise the contingency reserve. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2.15 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure under the heading Security and Citizenship to the tune of €2.578 billion and the heading Europe in the world to the tune of 9.432 billion. It is therefore necessary to mobilize this instrument of last resort in the face of unforeseen circumstances, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. Your unfavorable.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Commission has proposed, at the same time as Draft amending budget No 4/2016, to mobilise the contingency margin of EUR 240.1 million in 2016, with the aim of supplementing the commitment appropriations for security and citizenship expenditure (category 3) of the general budget of the EU for the financial year 2016. Given the need to address the challenges arising from the refugee, migration and security crisis, it is essential to mobilise the margin for contingencies by increasing the commitment appropriations of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 above the ceiling for commitments of the 3. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the 2016 contingency margin in order to provide EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations to meet the needs arising from the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, the funds mobilized will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on mobilizing margin for contingencies in 2016. This report proposed to mobilise this margin in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure under the budget heading on security and citizenship for the financial year 2016. The mobilization of this margin will amount to €240.1 million.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Contingency Margin is a last resort instrument to react to unforeseen circumstances. I have voted for this report on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2016 to a maximum of 0.03% of the Gross National Income of the Union.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report because the European Union has in recent years faced a series of crises, conflicting situations, both economically and politically, and the EU budget was not originally designed to support all these developments. The evaluations of the European Commission have shown that this year there is a need for access to the budgetary margin for contingencies, which I believe is the right thing to do. I support this report, which approves the use of this fund, and I believe it is a beneficial solution for responding, as a responsible Union, to the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by increasing the commitment appropriations under the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because a margin for unforeseen expenditure in the area of security and citizenship should be activated in relation to the migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The resolution agrees to approve an increase in the budget for EU security and citizenship issues. It also includes funding for the refugee crisis.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Having examined all other financial possibilities for dealing with unforeseen circumstances within the 2016 commitment ceilings for Heading 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework and having mobilised the Flexibility Instrument for the entire amount available for 2016 EUR 1530 million, it is necessary to mobilise the margin for unforeseen needs to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis by increasing the commitment appropriations in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, above the commitment ceiling of Heading 3.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal by my colleagues because I think it is necessary to mobilise the margin enshrined because it is the best tool to cope with the migration and migration crisis refugees. In addition, that resolution shall be submitted in full compliance with the conditions laid down in Article 13 (1) of Regulation No 1311/2013 (Euratom). I therefore voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the Resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the contingency reserve for 2016. Council Regulation 1311/2013 established a contingency reserve of a maximum of 0,03% of the Union's gross national income. It is established outside the financial framework ceiling for 2014-2020 as a last resort instrument enabling unforeseen circumstances to respond. The reserve can only be activated in connection with the amendment of the budget or the annual budget. This is exactly what the European Commission did when, together with draft amending budget No 4/2016, proposed mobilising the 2016 contingency reserve of EUR 240.1 million in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure in Title 3. “Security and Citizenship” in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 After mobilising the Flexible Instrument in the full amount of €1 530 million that was available in 2016, it proved necessary to mobilise this reserve to address the needs arising from resolving the migrant crisis, refugee care and the security crisis. by increasing the financial liabilities in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 and above the level of liabilities reached in that Chapter 3.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The Commission, together with draft amending budget No 4/2016, proposed a mobilisation of the 2016 contingency reserve of EUR 240.1 million in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure in Title 3. “Security and Citizenship” in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 The EP approves the proposed mobilization. The commitment appropriations of EUR 240.1 million are fully beaten by the margin up to the upper limit for commitments made in Title 5. (Administration) of the multiannual financial framework for the financial year 2016

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The mobilisation of the flexibility instrument relates to the need to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, with a view to financing commitment appropriations under Category 3 (security and citizenship), so that it can be used beyond the ceiling for this heading for the year 2016 according to the current Multiannual Financial Framework. In addition to the fact that it is not “new” money, there is insufficient value added to cope with and help to take action against the continued crisis of migrants and refugees. Once again, the MFF amounts (within their limits) fall short of what is needed to cope with repeated crises in the EU, not to mention what is necessary for an effective redistributive policy that will allow disadvantaged countries and regions to approach the richer regions.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the proposal to increase the European budget for 2016 in the field of security and citizenship, as the EU must be able to respond adequately in unforeseen events. The events of both this and last year showed us how underestimated these budget chapters were. The current amount for security and citizenship expenditure has already been exhausted from the budget as a result of the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis. It should be emphasised that this is not an increase in the budget for this year, but only a transfer of the unspent amount of EUR 240,1 million from the item to administrative reserves.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU must adapt its budget to its political priorities. Currently, additional resources are needed to meet the needs arising from the migrant and refugee crisis. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which deals with the mobilisation of the contingency margin of EUR 240.1 million, in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under the heading 'security and citizenship' of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. - Funding the European Union's asylum and migration policy has already spent too much of the European budget, with the funds originally planned for this component already outdated. The Union has created too many funds, specialised agencies and tools to support the influx of refugees and migrants. It is unacceptable to reallocate huge amounts of the budget to finance asylum policy and integrate refugees, given that in Europe, in 2015, 119 million people (23.7% of the population) were at risk of poverty. This money should be used in the interests of the Member States to increase the standard of living of the poor.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Contingency Margin is an EU financial instrument which is meant to be used as a last resort for unforeseen circumstances and amounts to 0.03% of EU GNI. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 240.1 million for 2016 to use on the migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP voted against as we oppose the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Having examined all other funding possibilities to respond to unforeseen circumstances within the commitments ceiling for 2016 under heading 3 (Security and citizenship) of the multiannual financial framework, and having mobilised the Flexibility Instrument for the total amount of EUR 1 530 million available in 2016, this Decision, which I voted in favour, mobilizes the Contingency Margin of EUR 240.1 million to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by increasing the commitment appropriations of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 above the commitment ceiling under heading 3.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilizing the margin for contingencies in 2016. Since all the other financial possibilities to deal with unforeseen circumstances within the limits of the commitments ceiling of Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2016 had been examined, it was necessary to mobilise this margin for contingencies in order to meet the needs arising from the crisis of migrants, refugees and security.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I support this technical amendment to the budget, which concerns the reallocation of unforeseen expenditure funds for such pressing purposes as border protection.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Article 13 of Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 defined an contingency margin of up to 0.03% of the Union's Gross National Income. The European Commission has calculated the absolute amount of this margin for the period in question after examining all other financial possibilities to react to unforeseen circumstances, within the ceiling of category 3 (Security and Citizenship) authorisations and after mobilising the Flexibility. In total, EUR 240.1 million was allocated to cope with unforeseen contingencies during 2016. The need to mobilise this margin for unforeseen arises from the emergency of responding to the needs arising from the refugee crisis, migration and security. In view of the fact that this is a very specific situation, I voted in favour of this report, as the Commission has proposed, with this extra funding, the commitment appropriations for expenditure under category 3 (Security and Citizenship) of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year. 2016.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite increasing the provisions for the migration crisis, it includes funds to be implemented in Turkey. Although we consider it absolutely necessary for the Union to allocate funds to solve the migrants' crisis, we cannot agree to the criminal agreement with Turkey under this justification. The Union must take care of the situation, but not through the use of mercenary governments to perform 'dirty work' in exchange for funding. That is why, despite earmarked funds to help migrants, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, given the absence of any margin in commitments under Security and Citizenship (heading 3) in 2016, Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016 requires the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for + EUR 240.1 million.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of the contingency reserve for 2016. The Commission has come up with this proposal to supplement the commitment appropriations by EUR 240.1 million. This appropriation relates to expenditure under heading 3 of the budget — Security and Citizenship. Given that this year has also been marked by the consequences of the migration, refugee and security crisis, I fully agree that we use all our budgetary options to tackle them. The budget contingency reserve, which we are hereby putting into effect, will be offset from the budget heading intended for the administration. We cannot be reckless on security issues at the moment, as evidenced by other events in the various countries of the Union. That is why I am inclined to adjust the budget and approve its reallocation to the challenges facing the Union today.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — In addition to amending budget No 4/2014, the Commission proposed, inter alia, to reduce the level of payment appropriations by around EUR 7 billion in economic, social and territorial cohesion and increase the level of commitment appropriations of EUR 50 million for the instrument for providing emergency assistance in the Union, EUR 130 million to the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and EUR 70 million to the Internal Security Fund, also proposed mobilising the 2016 Security Reserve of EUR 240 million to increase the appropriations for commitments related to expenditure in the field of Security and Citizenship for 2016. This report discusses the proposal for a decision of Parliament and of the Council, which examined the possibilities for financing the consequences of unforeseen circumstances within the ceilings of the Security and Citizenship section, and at the same time concluded that the full amount of the Flexibility Instrument for 2016 has already been used and therefore To successfully respond to the challenges of the migration, refugee and security crises, the European Union mobilise the security reserve by increasing the Security and Citizenship ceiling for 2016. As the report welcomes that conclusion and as I believe that all tools at our disposal should be used to mitigate the crisis, I supported the report in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Mobilising the contingency reserve to address the needs of the migration, refugee and security crisis is proving essential. In order to minimise the time required to mobilise the reserve, this Decision should apply from the beginning of the financial year 2017.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2016. The EU Commission proposed to mobilise the Contingency Margin for 2016 for an amount of EUR 240.1 million to cover expenses related to heading 3 ‘Security and Citizenship’. A cursory glance of heading 3 will reveal that many of the expenditures have little or nothing to do with the issue which requires the most attention, i.e. border control. Therefore, the funds will hardly do much to assist with the migration crisis, which should be dealt with by a non-EU ad hoc temporary agreement through financial and border security support.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The Commission proposes, together with draft amending budget No 4/2016, to mobilise the 2016 contingency reserve of EUR 240.1 million in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure in Title 3 (Security and Citizenship) in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 I accept this Draft Report because by this redistribution of resources within the budget, we will provide additional funds needed for the contingency costs caused by crisis situations.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2016. Over the past two years, we have witnessed the migration and refugee crisis in the European Union, as well as the security crisis reflected through terrorist attacks in the EU. Having looked at all other financial options for responding to unforeseen circumstances under the 2016 commitments ceilings, we are forced to release the security reserve to respond to the needs described above. This will increase liabilities above the ceiling of Section 3 of the EU general budget for 2016.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of the Union's resources. Financing Turkey under the supposed control of migratory flows leads to a full absorption of these funds, with the result that, in the event of unforeseen adverse situations in the future, there is not the necessary flexibility.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Commission proposes that the contingency reserve shall be mobilised in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 in order to secure a commitment ceiling of EUR 240.1 million above the commitment ceiling of Chapter 3 of the multiannual financial framework commitment appropriations. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — Given the absence of any commitment margin for the Security and Citizenship Framework in 2016, Draft Amending Budget (PBR) No 4/2016 requires the mobilisation of the reserve margin of approximately EUR 240.1 million. I express my support for the adoption of this document.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: It was just an appendix validation for which our office of policy experts in this field gave its go-ahead.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I voted in favour of a Motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the contingency reserve for 2016. I support the Commission proposal proposing the mobilisation of the 2016 contingency reserve of EUR 240.1 million in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure in Chapter 3 'Security and Citizenship' in the general budget of the European Union for financial year 2016

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The uncontrolled influx of migrants in recent years has created a migration, refugee and security crisis in the European Union. The causes of the migrant crisis are different, from fleeing war suffering, searching for a better life, leaving defunct countries and fleeing terrorism, and because of its easy accessibility, the European Union is one of the most desirable destinations. On a proposal from the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council decided to mobilise the contingency reserve of EUR 240.1 million for 2016 in order to address the needs arising from this crisis. Given the seriousness of the situation caused by the migration crisis, I believe that the decision to mobilise the contingency reserve is correct and I have supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2016. The decision of the European Parliament and of the Council was to release the security reserve under the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 in order to provide EUR 240,1 million in commitment appropriations above the commitment ceiling in Section 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework and to The amount of EUR 240,1 million in the liabilities referred to in Article 1 shall be fully offset by the difference up to the ceiling for liabilities in Section 5 (Administration) of the multiannual financial framework for the financial year 2016. The decision was published in the Official Journal of the European Union.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is the mobilization of one of the loopholes in the budget in order to meet the Funds for the Integration of Persons in Asylum and Migration Situations. A technical adjustment to make, along with other flexibility instruments that are modified, to address the challenges of safety and mobility of people. This funding, which will in part be used as a financial instrument, in the style of the Juncker Plan, will be used to finance the continuation and stopperation of migration of persons in situations of forced mobility in countries bordering the Union. They will have an investment component in those areas (which will enable local and transnational authorities to do business), also humanitarian, but in turn the retention of that population. It will consist of mobilising this margin up to EUR 2 150.6 million, offset by cuts in agriculture and administration. Disguising mismanagement of resources as humanitarian aid.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under Heading 3, “Security and Citizenship”, amounting to €2.578 billion, and heading 4, 'Europe in the world', to the tune of €9.432 billion. It is therefore a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The contingency reserve shall be mobilised in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 in order to provide the commitment appropriations of EUR 240.1 million above the commitment ceiling in Chapter 3 of the multiannual financial framework. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. In order to meet humanitarian needs and as budget cuts have become more severe, the flexibility margins of unemployed resources in 2016 are used once again, so that they can be used in migration matters once again mixed refugees, border security and agreements with Turkey so that act as an external guardian of borders, with, at the very least, dubious protection of human rights. A total of EUR 240.1 million for 2017 in payments, which will exceed the ceilings of heading 3 of the Union budget, on Security and Citizenship.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2016. The Commission proposed, together with Draft amending budget No 4/2016, to mobilise the Contingency Margin for 2016 for an amount of EUR 240,1 million so as to complement the commitment appropriations related to expenditure in heading 3 ‘Security and citizenship’ in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. For the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016, the Contingency Margin shall be mobilised to provide the amount of EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations over and above the commitment ceiling of heading 3 of the multiannual financial framework. I voted in favour because I believe that having regard to this very particular situation, the last-resort condition in Article 13(1) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 is fulfilled.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This decision ratifies the agreement reached which provides for $1.9 billion for the contingency margin and an additional 500 million package for farmers. We must be aware of the importance of this margin, especially given the agri-food crisis resulting from the Russian veto which has had so many effects on agriculture, with particular emphasis on the dairy sector. That is why it is necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this decision is to provide an additional EUR 1 906.2 million for the items “Security and Citizenship” and “Global Europe”, to be offset by the funds dedicated to “Sustainable Growth” and to a lesser extent, “Administration”. I am opposed to the overall orientation of funds devoted to the migration and refugee crisis, the so-called 'Fortress Europe', for turning European borders into open air prisons and tombs for thousands of migrants. I call for respect for the right to asylum and that a genuine development and peace strategy be put in place for the countries of origin of migratory flows, which requires a specific increase in the European budget rather than the proposed patches. That is why I voted against.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The mobilisation of the flexibility instrument relates to the need to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, with a view to financing commitment appropriations under Category 3 (Security and Citizenship), so that it will be possible to beyond the ceiling for this heading for the year 2016 in accordance with the current Multiannual Financial Framework. Apart from the fact that it is not “new” money, there is insufficient value added to cope with and help to take action against the continuing crisis of migrants and refugees. Once again, the MFF amounts (within their limits) fall short of what is needed to cope with repeated crises in the EU, not to mention what is necessary for an effective redistributive policy that will allow disadvantaged countries and regions to approach the richer regions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — I was unable to support this report because, in turn, new margins for unforeseen expenditure in the area of security and citizenship are to be activated.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: ‒ The regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-20201 (MFF), allows the use of the margin instrument for unexpected purposes, which can be up to 0.03% of EU-28 gross national income, as a last instance to respond to unforeseen circumstances, if all other options available within the MFF have been exhausted. In order to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, it was therefore decided to increase the commitment appropriations for 2016 for heading 3 by €240.1 million through the margin for contingencies, having already used the flexibility instrument for EUR 1 530 million for headings 3 and 4, and thus having exhausted all the room for manoeuvre within the QFP. It is undeniable that heading 3 is under particular pressure, mainly because of the migration and refugee crisis. It is therefore difficult to object to the request to mobilise these additional resources for the current year, even if it has been a few years that the issue of migration has been overriding, and should be assessed adequately when drafting the annual budgetary years. However, since this is the current budget, I have expressed my opinion in favour of this request.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The PVV voted against the joint text on the use of the 2016 Unforeseen Expenditure Margin. A margin is not a general budgetary buffer. Money from the margin that does not need to be used for the budget item in question should flow back to the Member States.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the 2016 contingency reserve mobilisation report in view of the full mobilisation of the flexible instrument in the 2016 budget (€1 530 million). Mobilisation of €240.1 million through the 2016 contingency allowance is the only available instrument to address the gap between Chapter 3 expenditure ceiling level and the additional contingency needs estimated for 2016. The contingency allowance is a last resort to unforeseen circumstances, and we need to provide a sufficient amount of funds to be able to adequately deal with the emerging situations. Although the migration crisis began back in 2015, we feel its impact and consequences on a daily basis. Mobilization of the contingency allowance is the only possible solution to meet budgetary needs in compulsory issues. The availability of contingency allowance in other chapters allows this mobilization to be fully neutralized in 2016.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2016. I support the release of the 2016 use of the security reserve of €240,1 million to increase the commitment funds arising from the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crises.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Changes to expenditure on both revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 are proposed with the following draft. Of particular interest are cuts in the funds allocated to cohesion policy. The reasons put forward by the European Commission are only a delay in the implementation of these funds in Eastern countries. This aspect leaves me very puzzled because if it were true that the causes of the cuts in expenditure are delays in implementation, in the following years Europe could be faced with expenses arising from commitments already made, without having the necessary resources. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought increased appropriations for Security and Citizenship, of which we are of the opinion, given the past performance of the EU in this regard, that the money will be spent furthering the EU’s imperial adventures and also into Frontex which is not fit for purpose. Thereafter, the file ties itself somewhat to migration but the reality is that the increased appropriations will be used in a nefarious way for security purposes, as well as the file reinforcing own resources to which we are opposed. Therefore, I had to abstain.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. This amount will be used to finance support for measures to manage the migrant crisis. These funds will thus finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution. Whilst it will return some money to the UK (which was owed to the UK anyway), it simultaneously increases certain EU budget lines by a total of EUR 225 and creates 5 extra posts for Frontex.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report 'Draft amending budget No 4 to the general budget 2016. Updating appropriations to take account of recent developments in migration and security issues, reduction of payments and commitment appropriations due to gross transfers, extension of EFSI activities, amendment of Frontex establishment plan and updating of revenue appropriations (own resources) '. I support an increase in appropriations under Heading 3 by mobilising the contingency reserve, as well as the early allocation of an increased amount of funds to the FRONTEX establishment plan. I also welcome the partly supplemented Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF), but still concern is that, despite the high level of budget execution, very few refugees have actually been displaced so far.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. The funds mobilized will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of illegal migrants, which is unacceptable. I voted resolutely against this mobilization proposal: any money mobilized in relation to the migrant crisis should be so to send them back to their countries and prevent them from (re) coming.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which supports a budgetary adjustment which aims, inter alia, to meet the needs in the field of migration in view of the migration situation facing the European Union. It therefore aims to increase the level of commitment appropriations, in order to be able to provide emergency aid of EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. An amount of EUR 70 million is also provided for the Internal Security Fund.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Fernandes report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. Parliament considered it necessary to mobilise the margin for unexpected incidents to meet the new needs arising from the outbreak of migration and refugee crises and the new security framework. The increase in appropriations for the financial year 2016 will therefore strain the ceiling of 0.03% of EU gross national income, as set by Article 13 of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013. This exceptional measure will be available €240.1 million more, which will have to be used to meet the new challenges.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I vote against. It modifies the European budget with an upward update of the levels of resources for security and migration, which, being insufficient, causes the need to mobilise other instruments, such as contingency funds, and reducing expenditure, for example, at the European Medicines Agency (based in London). Advance supplies to continue the Juncker Plan; reduce credits for items dedicated to Agriculture and Territorial Cohesion; and makes advances to finance Frontex staff. In total, it implies an increase of 225.4 million in credit and, more importantly, a decrease of 7 284.3 million in payments. It also leads to a decrease in Member States' contributions to the budget.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this report on updating appropriations, in order to reflect the latest developments in migration and security materials and the reduction of payment and commitment appropriations. I agree with the advance appropriation of EFSI, provided that the reallocation from the CEF is properly compensated in 2018. This advance appropriation does not prejudge the final financing plan for the new EFSI extension proposal, which must be decided in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report concerns draft amending budget No 4/2016 on updating appropriations to take account of recent developments in the field of migration and security and the reduction of payment and commitment appropriations. The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. This amount will be used to finance support for measures to manage the migrant crisis. Totally opposed to asylum and refugee integration policies and convinced that the massive arrival of migrants in Europe is rather a risk to our security, I naturally voted against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — Although the measure brings together heterogeneous operations with different political significance and implications, resulting in the last instance a tangle of interventions that are not consistent in terms of meaning, not it can be ignored that it reduces our national contribution to the EU budget 2016 by EUR 500 million, so I intended to express myself with a vote of abstention.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have voted against the budget report. The budget is too big and comprehensive. For example, in agricultural policy which costs too much and has a negative impact on the environment, climate and animal husbandry. The incalculable regional and structural funds, which are also prone to widespread fraud, should also be cut. I oppose the bets on Frontex, which involve the continued construction of Fortress Europe, forcing people fleeing war and oppression and risking their lives to get to a sanctuary. This, and initiatives for greater militarization of the EU, are absolutely the wrong way for a union that claims it defends human rights and is a peace project. Measures are required within the EU institutions that include reducing excessively high salaries, allowances and other types of privileges. These are some of the reasons that make me choose to vote no to the budget.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending budget No 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284,3 million, mainly under subheading 1b (Economic, social and territorial cohesion), and therefore decreases national contributions accordingly, all resulting from the accumulation of significant delays in the implementation of Union programmes. In addition, this amendment, which was voted in favour, increases the level of commitment appropriations under heading 3 (Security and citizenship) by EUR 50 million for the emergency aid instrument in the Union, 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and 70 million for the Internal Security Fund. which requires the mobilization of the Contingency Margin for a total amount of €240.1 million. In addition, it is advancing the allocation of the European Strategic Investment Fund by reallocating EUR 73.9 million in commitment appropriations from the energy component of the Connecting Europe Facility, to be offset in 2018.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the Council's position on amending budget No. 4/2016. It updates appropriations in order to take account of recent developments on migration and security issues, reductions in payments and commitment appropriations due to gross transfers, the extension of EFSI activities, the amendment of the FRONTEX establishment plan and revenue appropriations (own resources) update.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the draft amending budget No 4/2016, as changes are needed due to the latest developments in the field of migration and security. The pound's fall against the euro is also being known, leading to an expected revenue deficit. The Commission has ensured that this deficit will be covered by the revenue from the fines.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Draft Budget Amendments, the main effect of which is to reduce the level of payment of funds to the amount of EUR 7.2 billion. That money will be returned to member states.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — This text, which aims to adjust the budget to the tune of EUR 250 million through the mobilization of the contingency margin to meet the needs of asylum policy and the integration of migrants, is by its nature unacceptable, as these sums should be reserved exclusively, in my opinion, for the financing of the return of these migrants in their countries of origin. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Draft amending budget (PBR) No 4/2016 decreases the level of payment appropriations by €284.3 million. To be borne in mind is that it increases the level of commitment appropriations in Section 3 Security and Citizenship, by EUR 50 million to provide emergency aid in the Union; in addition to EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the €70 million for the Internal Security Fund (ISF). Also taking into account that PBR No 4/2016 focuses on the allocation of the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI) through the redistribution of €73.9 million in commitment appropriations; and that edit Frontex's array. Overpayments of €284.3 million are of concern, resulting in delays in the implementation of EU programmes under the concurrent management. The mobilization of the contingency margin and the strengthening of the Frontex table is required. In addition, partial reconstruction of the AMIF is crucial, since only a few relocations of refugees have actually been carried out. Finally, the proactive supply of EFSI is positive, provided that the redeployment from the CEF is duly compensated in 2018. Accordingly, amending budget No 4/2016 was finally adopted.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, which brings an update of appropriations in relation to recent developments in migration and security issues. The report endorses the proposed increases through the mobilization of the margin for contingencies, which is currently the only available instrument provided. It also requires the advance in 2016 of the increase in Frontex's headcount in order to strengthen repatriation operations, pre-return assistance, joint operations, risk analysis and resources common. Finally, it urges to anticipate the allocation of the European Fund for Strategic Interventions (EFSI), through a strengthening of EUR 73.9 million and the reallocation of the CEF. This advance will be duly offset in 2018 and will not damage the final financing plan of the new EFSI extension proposal.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While I fully support the increase in expenditure related to the ongoing humanitarian crisis with thousands of people fleeing conflicts in Syria and Iraq, I do not support either the proposed increase in expenditure for security measures, or the expenses related to the EU-Turkey declaration on refugees.  The increased security measures and the EU-Turkey declaration aim to bolster ‘Fortress Europe’ thereby preventing refugees from exercising their right to seek asylum as laid down in Article 18 of the Charter of Human Rights.  Therefore, I voted abstention

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this binding budgetary report. This amending budget would increase EU budget ceilings by a net total of EUR 255 million and also create 50 new posts for Frontex (the EU border force). However it also cuts the amount of payment appropriations from the EU budget by over EUR 7 billion and gives this money back to Member States. Our calculation shows that the UK would get an estimated EUR 1.6 billion back. While UKIP cannot vote in favour of increasing EU budgets, we can’t oppose getting money back for the UK – which is the reason why UKIP abstained.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on Draft Amending Budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016, namely the update of appropriations in order to reflect the most recent developments in migration and security issues, reducing payment and commitment appropriations, amending the Frontex establishment plan and updating the revenue appropriations. I think that although this report could contribute to a better distribution of Europe's resources, it does not achieve its objectives, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In Italy at the moment, a feeling of profound loneliness is prevailing: citizens feel abandoned by Europe to the fickleness of migration flows and the consequences thereof. Therefore, my vote of favour today is aimed at a European reaction, in aid of countries at the mercy of the migration crisis, which will transform the current dramatic situation into an efficient and efficient system Innovative fact of reception, but also of precise rules to adhere to. Only through concrete and joint responses can we avoid the disaffection and anti-Europeanism that now reign sovereign. I welcome, in line with what has been stated, the decision to raise the commitment appropriation levels provided for under the heading 'security and citizenship' by the EUR 250 million partly provided by the margin for the 2016 contingencies. Similarly, the advance of the allocation of the European Fund for Strategic Investment through a reallocation of EUR 73.9 million only increases expectations for improvement. However, despite the national appropriations implementation programmes made available by the EU, only a few of the initially planned refugee relocations have taken place until now. States must not afford to accept only the benefits without taking on the burdens associated with them.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Update of appropriations to reflect the latest developments on migration and security issues, reduction of payment and commitment appropriations as a result of the Global Transfer, extension of EFSI, modification of the staff establishment plan of Frontex and update of revenue appropriations.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - This amending budget reflects two distinct objectives. On the one hand, it allows the reallocation of funds in view of the budgetary implementation so far. On the other hand, it allows the budget to be adjusted to the new legislative instruments adopted in the meantime and to deal with unforeseen events. Therefore, although necessary, I support the rapporteur in his concern at the delay in implementing the Union's funding programmes, evident by the reduction of payments by some EUR 7 billion. On the other side, I am pleased to note the high implementation of the Security and Justice programmes, although this level of solidarity from the Union does not match the number of refugees relocated by the Member States. Finally, I am pleased to see the anticipation of funds for the new European Border and Coast Guard, allowing it to be fully operational.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of draft amending budget (PBR) No 4 for the year 2016 because significant increases in security are required in terms of commitment appropriations and citizenship, migration and integration, and internal security.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — Due to the need to take account of the changing situation requiring the revision of the appropriations, I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 4 to the general budget for 2016. Due to the migration and refugee crisis, the reduction of payment appropriations as a result of the migration and refugee crisis. slow implementation of regional policy programmes there is a need for updates and corrective shifts. The proposed update provides an accurate description of the mechanisms associated with offsets and proposes a specific compensation for losses.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this resolution as it grants the Union additional funds in order to adequately tackle the latest developments on migration and security within the European Union. The increase of the Instrument for emergency support can help Member States dealing with the increased inflows of arrivals in the Union, and thus acts as a support measure to Member States which are most effected by the humanitarian crisis.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This report constitutes one of the amending budgetary reports for 2016. In this context, it proposes a reduction of EUR 7 284 million (in surplus) in the area of economic, social and territorial cohesion, thus reducing national contributions accordingly, and proposes an increase of EUR 50 million for the instrument intended to provide emergency aid within the Union, of EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and EUR 70 million for the Internal Security Fund (ISF). Finally, this draft amending budget focuses in advance the provision of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) through a redeployment of EUR 73.9 million in commitment appropriations from the energy component of the Connecting Europe Facility (MIE-Energy). Considering that there is a need to reallocate surplus appropriations from the current emergencies, namely investment, growth, security and migration, I would like to point out the risk of non-payments at the end of the financial year on the economic, social and territorial cohesion component, which should be addressed within the framework of the forthcoming fiscal years. I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this binding budgetary report. This amending budget would increase EU budget ceilings by a net total of EUR 255 million and also create 50 new posts for Frontex (the EU border force). However it also cuts the amount of payment appropriations from the EU budget by over EUR 7 billion and gives this money back to Member States. Our calculation shows that the UK would get an estimated EUR 1.6 billion back. While UKIP cannot vote in favour of increasing EU budgets, we can’t oppose getting money back for the UK – which is the reason why UKIP abstained.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budget (ACB) No 4/2016. It shall update the appropriations deployed during 2016, to reflect increases in expenditure for the security of European citizens and overpayments due to significant delays in the implementation of Union programmes managed jointly with the Member States. In particular, the draft amending budget transcribes into the European budget expenditure related to the strengthening of Frontex's staff and resources, which enabled the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard Corps.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 contains a forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) and the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I obviously voted in favour of the report by José Manuel Fernandes on draft amending budget No 4/2016 which, like Amending Budgets 5 and 6, is part of the overall agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 budget. This draft amending budget in particular increases the commitment appropriations under heading 3, 'Security and Citizenship' by more than EUR 240 million, which I consider both necessary and urgent. I would be totally satisfied if, moreover, EUR 7,284 million were not disbursed to the Member States as a result of delays in the implementation of the Cohesion Funds. The payment crisis will only be harder from 2019 onwards.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 contains a forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) and the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. These are new funding for asylum policies, which we strongly oppose. On the contrary, the return of illegal persons to their countries must be promoted.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - Wrong EU manipulations in tackling illegal immigration, improper use of Frontex staff and support for the failed Junker project, in connection with the implementation of an incorrect Multiannual Financial Framework, lead to misuse of Union funds.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: this text aims to adjust the 2016 EU budget to deal with the refugee crisis by €250 million, by mobilising the margin for unforeseen events in 2016.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on draft amending budget (PBR) No 4/2016 because it contains a number of elements leading to a strengthening of 225.4 EUR million in commitment appropriations. In addition, the project proposes updating appropriations in relation to the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain, despite some positive points, I cannot but point out the inefficiencies of managing the European budget.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, the improper use of Frontex staff and the support of the failed Junker plan, in connection with the implementation of an incorrect Multiannual Financial Framework, lead to misuse of Union funds, for that I am voting against draft amending budget No. 4/2016: Updating appropriations to take account of recent migration and security developments, reduction of payment and commitment appropriations.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The main effect of Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016 is a decrease in the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7.3 billion due to under implementation. This money will go back to Member States. DAB 4/2016 also includes among others a reinforcement by +EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations for security and citizenship (heading 3) and a frontloading of the staffing for the new European Border and Coast Guard Regulation. An agreement on this amending budget was reached in the framework of the budget conciliation on 2017 EU Budget.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 includes a revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax and gross national income, as well as the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned.
