With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 contains a forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) and the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report, considering that the draft amending budget reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million. This surplus of 7 284.3 million, which is the result of significant delays in the implementation of Union programmes in shared management, is worrying and lays the basis for a significant accumulation of payment requests at the end of the existing multiannual financial framework.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft amending budget. This is a budgetary implementation of financial resources such as the redistribution of EUR 240.1 million from the contingency reserve to the heading 'Security and citizenship'.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Draft Amending Budget no 4/2016 which reflects the latest developments on migration, security, reduction of payments and commitment appropriation.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the Contingency Margin Mobilization in 2017, I vote against. On this occasion, another financial instrument, a total of 530 million over four years, is being mobilized at current prices. These instruments use economic engineering and not to make a substantial change in the Union budget, which is scarce, and has proved not to live up to the circumstances in the migration crisis. And they mix security terms with humanitarian aid. From my point of view, this type of crisis should not be militarized, nor should this kind of instrument be used to appear to be supposed aid that is not being given, but endorsing.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which has been adopted in BUDG by a broad majority. The main effect of Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016 is a decrease in the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7.3 billion due to under implementation. This money will go back to Member States. DAB 4/2016 also includes among others a reinforcement by +EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations for security and citizenship (heading 3) and a frontloading of the staffing for the new European Border and Coast Guard Regulation.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 contains a forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) and the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The fourth amending budget for the current financial year is requested to increase the commitment of EUR 225.4 million. The justification of this application is based on additional tasks to tackle the migration crisis, on the one hand, as well as on additional expenditure on the so-called Juncker Plan, i.e. the financial instrument EFSI, while at the same time requesting a reduction of EUR 7.27 billion due to the slow implementation of cohesion programmes. While the increase in the context of the migration crisis and the reduction of payments are welcome, I cannot agree to additional spending on EFSI, which is a programme with no additional positive effects. That is why I abstained.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of a proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position on draft amending budget No. 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Update of appropriations to take account of the latest developments in the migration and security domain, reduction of appropriations for payments and commitments as a result of global transfer, extension of the duration of the EFSI, amending the plan jobs in Frontex and the update of the appropriations of revenue, because I believe that the proposed redistribution is correct and will contribute to the overall efficiency of the Union budget. I believe that the funding for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund increased, mobilised the contingency reserve, and boosted EFSI funding. However, it is also necessary to stress that there are delays in the implementation of the EU programme, and that only a small number of refugees have been relocated.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I do not intend to support a project whose ambition is to finance the policies of asylum and integration of the so-called refugees, when the only obvious decision would be to mobilize these resources for the return of these populations to their countries of origin. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which increases the funds for security (EUR 70 million for the Internal Security Fund) or migration (EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund), as it helps to cope with the current worsening situation in these areas. This draft amending budget also includes the creation of 50 additional posts for Frontex or an extension of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, two desirable measures.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I reject the report presented. It advocates that the arrears can only be covered by 2020 if all margins are fully exhausted and the annual ceilings are lifted as a security measure. This amounts to a massive increase in the EU budget, despite the fact that migration and refugee issues do not fall within the Union's competences.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The fourth amending budget for the current financial year is requested to increase the commitment of EUR 225.4 million. The justification of this application is based on additional tasks to tackle the migration crisis, on the one hand, as well as on additional expenditure on the so-called Juncker Plan, i.e. the financial instrument EFSI, while at the same time requesting a reduction of EUR 7.27 billion due to the slow implementation of cohesion programmes. While the increase in the context of the migration crisis and the reduction of payments are welcome, I cannot agree to additional spending on EFSI, which is a programme with no additional positive effects. That is why I abstained.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 contains a forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) and the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that the humanitarian and migratory challenges that we face today were not accounted for when the current MFF was adopted back in 2013. Therefore, even with the systemic mobilisation of the totality of the Flexibility Instrument under heading 3 (Security and citizenship) in the coming years, the financial resources available will not be sufficient to tackle the increased needs. We need a fair distribution of funding according to priorities, in full transparency and accountability. For that reason, I welcome the proposal of the Commission in the context of the MFF mid-term revision which aims to increase the capability of the budget to react quickly and adequately to unforeseen events. In light of this, I strongly support the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to supplement the financing available in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, beyond the ceilings of heading 3 (Security and citizenship) by the amount of EUR 530 million to finance measures in the field of migration, refugees and security.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on amending budget No 4/2016, because the main effect is a decrease in the amount of payment appropriations by 7.3 billion due to low implementation. It also includes an increase of more than €240.1 million in commitment appropriations for heading 3 and an advance distribution of staffing for the new Coast Guard Regulation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - In draft amending budget No 4/2016, the amount of appropriations for payments is reduced by EUR 7 284,3 million, mainly in the budget lines under subheading 1.b Economic, social and territorial cohesion, and thus reducing national contributions accordingly. At the same time, funding for security and the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund is increasing. The report highlights concerns about the €7 284.3 million surplus of payment funds, a result of major delays in the implementation of the EU's split management programme. It highlights the necessity of enhanced EFSI funding at the beginning of its implementation period, provided that the redistribution of the Connecting Europe Facility is compensated in 2018. This report accepts the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016, and I have therefore supported it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the report on the Council's position on Draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Update of appropriations to reflect the most recent developments in migration and security, reduction of payment and commitment appropriations as a result of the overall transfer, prolongation of the EFSI, amendment of the Frontex establishment plan and update of revenue appropriations because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This report focuses on the change in the EU budget for 2016. The aim of this amendment is to use the budgetary margin of EUR 250 million to finance European immigrationist policy. We oppose this scandalous proposal.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding the report on Draft amending budget No 4/2016, I voted in favour. Supporting this report means looking forward to a more in-depth update of appropriations that can better reflect the latest developments in terms of migratory and security issues. Amending the budget represents the increase and mobilisation of funds that will be assigned to the Asylum, Migration, and Integration Fund as well as the Internal Security Fund and assist with their efforts to handle the migratory situation affecting the Member States.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This proposal provides for additional funding for measures addressing migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to adjust the 2016 EU budget to deal with the refugee crisis by €250 million, by mobilising the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which we believe is not conceivable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. Consequently, I voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) This draft amending budget No 4/2016 (POR No 4/2016) lowers the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million, mainly in the budget lines of category 1B Economic, social and territorial cohesion, and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. Overall, the net impact of POR 4/2014 on the expenditure side of the 2016 budget represents an increase of €225,4 million in commitment appropriations and a decrease of EUR 7 274.3 million in payment appropriations. On the revenue side, this POR also includes the revision of the forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) bases, as well as the budgeting of the relevant corrections of the Kingdom. United Kingdom and its funding, which affects the distribution of Member States' own resources contributions to the EU budget. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is necessary to update EU commitment appropriations on migration and security.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The situation constantly leads the European Union to take care of the budgets it grants. This is exactly what is dealt with in draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the Union for the financial year 2016. It concerns an update of appropriations to take account of recent developments in the field of migration and security, the reduction of payment and commitment appropriations resulting from the global transfer, the extension of the life of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the modification of Frontex's staffing table and updating of own resources. In particular, the amendment proposal aims to reduce the level of payment appropriations under budget lines relating to economic, social and territorial cohesion, thereby reducing national contributions. It also decreases several sustainable growth budget lines. On the other hand, this draft amending budget increases the commitment appropriations on security and citizenship and the appropriations for the emergency aid instrument within the Union. Frontex's staffing table is also strengthened. Such adjustments are necessary so that the European Union can act in a fair and adequate manner. I therefore welcome the report on draft amending budget No 4/2016.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this Draft Amending Budget (DAB) 4/2016, which will decrease in the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7.3 billion due to under implementation. This money will go back to Member States. DAB 4/2016 also includes among others a reinforcement by +EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations for security and citizenship (heading 3) and a frontloading of the staffing for the new European Border and Coast Guard Regulation. An agreement on this amending budget was reached in the framework of the budget conciliation on 2017 EU Budget.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. Draft amending budget No 4/2016 was adopted by the Commission on 30 September 2016. The draft proposes to update appropriations to take account of recent developments on migration and security issues, to reduce payment and commitment appropriations as a result of global transfers, the European Fund for Strategic Investments an extension, an amendment to the establishment plan of Frontex and an update of revenue appropriations. On 24 November 2016, the Council adopted its position on the draft and forwarded it to Parliament. Relying on the position expressed in the letter of the Committee on Regional Development and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in its report, the Committee on Budgets expresses serious concern about some of the measures envisaged, but nevertheless proposes: that Parliament approves the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 and thus adopts the amendment definitively. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to adjust the 2016 EU budget to deal with the refugee crisis by €250 million, by mobilising the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. Unfavourable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - I endorse the rapporteur's concern about the overpayment of EUR 7 284.3 million, which is the result of major delays in the implementation of EU programmes under shared management and paves the way for an important accumulation of payment requests at the end of the current MFF. I also endorse the rapporteur's position in his concern about the expected decrease in revenue, estimated at EUR 1.8 billion, as a result of the devaluation of the pound sterling against the euro. Given the need to address the challenges arising from the refugee, migration and security crisis, I advocate strengthening in Category 3 by mobilising the Contingency Margin. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to adjust the 2016 EU budget to deal with the refugee crisis by €250 million, by mobilising the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on amending budget 4/2016. In particular, the amending budget provides for a reduction in the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7284.3 million due to delays in the implementation of certain operational programmes by some Member States. It also provides for an upward change in the staffing of Frontex, with the creation of 50 posts.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on Draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the EU for the financial year 2016 that will update appropriations taking into consideration the latest developments on reduction of payment, commitment appropriations, migration and security issues.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought increased appropriations for Security and Citizenship, of which we are of the opinion, given the past performance of the EU in this regard, that the money will be spent furthering the EU’s imperial adventures and also into Frontex which is not fit for purpose. Thereafter, the file ties itself somewhat to migration but the reality is that the increased appropriations will be used in a nefarious way for security purposes, as well as the file reinforcing own resources to which we are opposed. Therefore, I had to abstain.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because it calls for a massive upward adjustment of the EU budget.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Recent developments in foreign affairs, including migration and security, the extension of the Frontex mandate, and domestic issues such as cohesion policy and delays in its implementation, require replacements in budget paths.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The main update of the draft amending budget (GPA) 4/2016 is the reduction of payment appropriations by EUR 7.3 billion. This money is returned to the Member States. Draft amending budget 4/2016 also includes, inter alia, the EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations for security and citizenship and the acceleration of staffing for the new European borders and the coast of the Guard Regulation.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues' proposal since PRB No 4/2016 anticipating the provision of the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI) through the allocation of 73.9 million of euro in order to commit to the Energy component of the Connecting Europe Mechanism (CEF-Europe), it requires approval of the proposed increases for heading 3 by mobilizing the margin for the unexpected. In addition, the advance to the EFSI through payment to the CEF will be offset in 2018. I therefore voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. — Amount of appropriations in Title 3. Security and Citizenship increases by EUR 50 million for the Instrument for Urgent Support within the Union, by EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, and by €70 million for the Internal Security Fund, which requires mobilisation of the contingency reserve totalling 240.1 million EUR. The increase in funding in Title 3 by mobilising the contingency reserve, as well as additional funding at the beginning of the period in view of the increase in the number of staff in the Frontex Job Plan, ensures the implementation of key measures aimed at facilitating the position of refugees and migrants, but also on security of the Union's external borders. In this regard, I also welcome the partial increase in funding for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. Despite this utterly necessary provision of sufficient funding for Union policies under Title 3, I am concerned about delays in the implementation of the EU's shared management programme which paves the way towards a significant build-up of payment requirements at the end of the current Multiannual Financial Frame. This issue has been problematic for some time and I believe it is necessary to finally find a solution in the framework of the review of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to adjust the 2016 EU budget to deal with the refugee crisis by €250 million, by mobilising the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. I am voting against this project.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 is adopted. In that draft, the amount of payment appropriations is reduced by EUR 7 284,3 million, and therefore national contributions are reduced accordingly. There are justified concerns about the €7 284.3 million surplus of payment funds, a result of major delays in the implementation of the EU's split management programme, paving the way for a significant build-up of payment requests at the end of the current MFF. Draft amending budget No 4/2016 also includes the mobilisation of the contingency reserve amounting to EUR 240.1 million.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This draft amending budget lowers the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million, mainly in the budget lines of category 1B Economic, social and territorial cohesion, and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. This POR increases the level of commitment appropriations under Category 3 Security and Citizenship by EUR 50 million for the Union Emergency Aid Instrument, €130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and EUR 70 million for the Internal Security Fund (ISF), which requires the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for a total amount of EUR 240,1 million. It also anticipates the provisioning of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). We have a lot of reservations about the mobilisation of this money. In the name of responding to the humanitarian crisis, the lion's share has been mobilised for the EU's security, xenophobic and racist policies. It is deplorable that refugees continue to live on the ground, subject to practices that widely violate their human rights, in a context of violation of international law by the EU and Member States. It is therefore no stranger that the report is boasting the increase in funding for FRONTEX.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which deals with amending budget No 4 to the 2016 general budget and which provides for an increase in commitment appropriations for the heading 'security and citizenship', in order to deal with this unprecedented migration crisis. I welcome the Commission's proposal to use revenue from additional fines to offset the expected decline in revenue, estimated at EUR 1.8 billion, due to the depreciation of the pound sterling vis-à-vis the euro. I would like to highlight here one of the immediate negative effects of Brexit.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this binding budgetary report. This amending budget would increase EU budget ceilings by a net total of EUR 255 million and also create 50 new posts for Frontex (the EU border force). However it also cuts the amount of payment appropriations from the EU budget by over EUR 7 billion and gives this money back to Member States. Our calculation shows that the UK would get an estimated EUR 1.6 billion back. While UKIP cannot vote in favour of increasing EU budgets, we can’t oppose getting money back for the UK – which is the reason why UKIP abstained.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284,3 million, mainly under subheading 1b (Economic, social and territorial cohesion), and therefore decreases national contributions accordingly, all resulting from the accumulation of significant delays in the implementation of Union programmes. In addition, this amendment, which was voted in favour, increases the level of commitment appropriations under heading 3 (Security and citizenship) by EUR 50 million for the emergency aid instrument in the Union, 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and 70 million for the Internal Security Fund. which requires the mobilization of the Contingency Margin for a total amount of €240.1 million. In addition, it is advancing the allocation of the European Strategic Investment Fund by reallocating EUR 73.9 million in commitment appropriations from the energy component of the Connecting Europe Facility, to be offset in 2018.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budgets No 4, 5 and 6 of the European Union for the financial year 2016. Amending budget No 4 concerns the updating of appropriations to take account of recent developments in the field of migration and security, the reduction of payment and commitment appropriations resulting from the global transfer, the extension of the life of the European Fund for Strategic Investments , the modification of Frontex's staffing table and the updating of revenue appropriations. Amending budget No 5 concerns the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU on the system of own resources following the closure of the ratification process and the entry into force of the Decision on 1 October 2016. Finally, amending budget No 6 concerns the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I support this technical amendment to the budget, which concerns the reallocation of funds to manage the crisis for migrants and refugees, which is needed because of the decreasing flows of asylum seekers.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the EU for the financial year 2016. This rectification concerns the updating of appropriations, in order to reflect, in particular, developments in addressing the new challenges arising from migration and new security needs, which are of exceptional and priority character. To this end, I endorsed the need to strengthen Category 3 by mobilising the Contingency Margin, as well as anticipating the strengthening of Frontex's establishment plan. I also agreed to anticipate EFSI (European Fund for Strategic Investments), provided that the reallocation from the Connecting Europe Facility is properly compensated in 2018 and does not undermine the final financing plan of the new proposal to extend this Fund. For this reason, it is important to stress the need to make every effort to avoid an accumulation of unpaid invoices and a further delay in payments, so a new binding payment plan for the period 2016-2020 to be developed by the three institutions could be a good suggestion to be made in account.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it approves the replacement of the funds from the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020. With this movement of funds, the Union reduces its capacity to act in the field of research and transport infrastructures. To provide EFSI, a mechanism for the financialisation of public interest projects, which ultimately benefits the private sector through the guarantees it offers. EFSI has proved to be a useless and inappropriate tool for the promotion of investment in the Union, while sacrificing those projects. Although the report specifies that its content should not influence the approval of the extension of this mechanism, it ratifies its funding, which I am opposed. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report which has been adopted in the Committee on Budgets by a broad majority. The main effect of Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 4/2016 is a decrease in the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7.3 billion due to under implementation. This money will go back to Member States. DAB 4/2016 also includes among others a reinforcement by +EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations for security and citizenship (heading 3) and a frontloading of the staffing for the new European Border and Coast Guard Regulation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending budget No 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million, in particular in the budget lines in subheading 1b economic, social and territorial cohesion and therefore reduces Member States' contributions accordingly. At the same time, draft amending budget No 4/2016 increases the level of commitment appropriations under Heading 3 Security and Citizenship by EUR 50 million for the Emergency Support Instrument within the Union by EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and by EUR 70 million for the Internal Fund security and therefore requires mobilisation of the contingency reserve totalling EUR 240,1 million, taking into account the transfer of EUR 9,9 million. Draft budget No 4/2016 takes into account the latest developments in migration and security in the European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - Proposal amending budget No 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by around EUR 7 billion mainly in economic, social and territorial cohesion, thereby reducing Member States' contributions accordingly. At the same time, it increases the level of commitment appropriations of EUR 50 million for the Emergency Assistance Facility in the Union, EUR 130 million for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and EUR 70 million for the Internal Security Fund, which will require the mobilisation of the security reserve. The proposal also provides for the redistribution of EFSI funds under the Connecting Europe Facility, and includes adjustments on the basis of the correction of traditional own resources forecasts, VAT and GNI bases and the inclusion of adjustments for budget financing by The United Kingdom. As the report highlights certain important issues and warnings, such as the issue of a high surplus of payments that could lead to excessive accumulation of payment claims towards the end of the multiannual financial framework, the urgency to replace the transferred funds under the Instrument as soon as possible Connecting Europe and the EU revenue deficit due to the decrease in the value of the British pound, estimated at €1.8 billion, I supported it in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - The fourth amending budget for the current financial year is requested to increase the commitment of EUR 225.4 million. The justification of this application is based on additional tasks to tackle the migration crisis, on the one hand, as well as on additional expenditure on the so-called Juncker Plan, i.e. the financial instrument EFSI, while at the same time requesting a reduction of EUR 7.27 billion due to the slow implementation of cohesion programmes. While the increase in the context of the migration crisis and the reduction of payments are welcome, I cannot agree to additional spending on EFSI, which is a programme with no additional positive effects. That is why I abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - The current situation in Europe requires a strong and rapid response by Europe, combining new legislative, operational and financial resources. For example, in the wake of a revenue outage due to the depreciation of the British pound against the euro by mobilising reserves, the EU must shift the centre of gravity of funding, with such a transfer due to be compensated in 2018.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution, as I cannot condone raising budget ceilings nor additional expenditure on EFSI, a highly risky EU investment plan, which subsidises private companies with public money, which leads to malinvestment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The Draft Report expresses concerns about excess payment funds of €7 284.3 million, resulting from major delays in the implementation of the EU's shared management programme, which paves the way for a significant build-up of payment requests at the end of the current MFO's. Particularly welcomed the partial increase in funding for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. The enhanced financing of the EFSI at the beginning of its implementation period is accepted, provided that the redistribution of the Connecting Europe Facility is appropriately compensated in 2018. The rapporteur agrees with the increase in headline funds by mobilising the contingency reserve, as well as additional funds at the beginning of the period given the increase in the number of staff in Frontex's jobs plan. I support the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No. 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Update of appropriations to take account of the latest developments in the migration and security domain, reduction of appropriations for payments and commitments as a result of global transfer, extension of the duration of the EFSI, amending the plan jobs in Frontex and updating the approved funds of income (own funds). I consider that the budget changes set out in the Draft Report are extremely important because they relate to current events which present challenges for the whole of the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the Council position on the draft amending the budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. I support additional funding in Section 3 through the release of the security reserve, as well as by disbursing additional funds for Frontex's HR plan early in the period and partially increasing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. However, we can all be concerned that, despite the high level of implementation of the budget under the national programmes of the Member States, only a few refugees have been transferred to date.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Wrong EU manipulations in tackling illegal immigration, improper use of Frontex staff and support for the failed Junker project, in connection with the implementation of an incorrect Multiannual Financial Framework, lead to misuse of Union funds.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget 4/2016 reduces the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7 284.3 million and therefore reduces national contributions accordingly. As regards the revenue side of the budget, draft amending budget No 4/2016 contains a forecast of traditional own resources (i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and resources based on value added tax (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) and the accounting and financing of the UK corrections concerned. According to the European Parliament, payment requests will accumulate considerably towards the end of the current financial framework, so it is important to avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework plan when the Commission was unable to pay the Member States for the projects implemented after the invoices submitted. With regard to the revision of the multiannual financial framework, we can only support any proposal if we have an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient funds in the annual budgets to pay for the already running catch-up programmes and agricultural subsidies. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the entry into force of the proposal for budgetary adjustment 2016/4, given that the proposal highlights the disparities in the usual timetable for budgetary planning, on the one hand, subsidies , the lack of reserves in this chapter, and the anomalies or lags in the management of the migration crisis and the use of resources transferred to refugees. I note that corrections under the proposal are necessary to ensure the continuity of the functioning of the Union under law, but I hope that the findings of this report will also contribute to avoiding similar deficiencies in the future.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — The main effect of Draft Amending Budget (PBR) No 4/2016 aims to lower the level of payment appropriations by EUR 7.3 billion due to reduced implementation. This money will go back to the Member States. The document also includes a consolidation of around €240.1 million in commitment appropriations for the security and citizenship framework. Taking into account the importance of these measures for the Member States, I am voting for the adoption of this draft.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support Draft amending budget No. 4/2016: Update of appropriations to take into account the latest developments in the migration and security domain, reduction of appropriations for payments and commitments. Since it is already approved, and that it is necessary to constantly and systematically monitor the financial needs of the European Union, especially when migration and security issues are taken into account in the prism of viewing, I have decided to support the proposed budget update.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - The current migration crisis has led to the need to amend the budget for the financial year 2016, namely the need to mobilise the contingency reserve and additional funds given the increase in the number of staff in the Frontex Job Plan and partial increase in funding for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. In addition, enhanced financing of the European Structural Investment Fund at the beginning of its implementation period was proposed, of course with the utmost transparency and close monitoring of expenditure. Nevertheless, I share the rapporters' concerns about the expected revenue deficit estimated at 1.8 billion euros, but I hope that the Commission will achieve its intention to cover this shortfall with revenue from additional fines. Given the ongoing pressure on the borders of the European Union and the volatile situation caused by migration flows, I consider the draft amending budget to be justified and I supported this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: modernisation of appropriations to reflect the latest developments in the areas of migration and security, reduction of payment appropriations and commitment appropriations I supported the global redistribution, the extension of the EFSI, the modification of Frontex's HR plan and the modernisation of the appropriations from revenue (own resources). Exceptional concern arose about surplus payments of EUR 7,284.3 million resulting from major delays in the implementation of EU shared management programmes and could lead to the accumulation of payment claims towards the end of the current Multiannual Financial Framework. Concern also emerged about the decline in the value of the British pound against the euro saw an expected deficit in revenue estimated at €1.8 billion. Additional funding for Frontex's personnel plan will be paid at the beginning of the period. The Asylum, Migration and Inclusion Fund has also increased, but worrying is that extraordinarily little has been done in the repositioning of migrants.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the Contingency Margin Mobilization in 2017, I vote against. On this occasion, another financial instrument, a total of 530 million over four years, is being mobilized at current prices. These instruments use economic engineering and not to make a substantial change in the Union budget, which is scarce, and has proved not to live up to the circumstances in the migration crisis. And they mix security terms with humanitarian aid. From my point of view, this type of crisis should not be militarized, nor should this kind of instrument be used to appear to be supposed aid that is not being given, but endorsing.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The draft amending budget covers a number of matters, including the update of the measures in relation to the migration and refugee crisis, as well as the annual update of revenue appropriations. I supported the above resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur agrees with the advance schedule of the EFSI if the redeployment from the CEF is properly remunerated in 2018. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I vote against. It modifies the European budget with an upward update of the levels of resources for security and migration, which, being insufficient, causes the need to mobilise other instruments, such as contingency funds, and reducing expenditure, for example, at the European Medicines Agency (based in London). Advance supplies to continue the Juncker Plan; reduce credits for items dedicated to Agriculture and Territorial Cohesion; and makes advances to finance Frontex staff. In total, it implies an increase of 225.4 million in credit and, more importantly, a decrease of 7 284.3 million in payments. It also leads to a decrease in Member States' contributions to the budget.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on Draft Amending Budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Update of appropriations to reflect the latest developments on migration and security issues, reduction of payment and commitment appropriations as a result of the Global Transfer, extension of EFSI, modification of the staff establishment plan of Frontex and update of revenue appropriations (Own resources). The report expresses serious concerns over the payment surplus of EUR 7 284.3 million, which is the result of major delays in the implementation of EU programmes under shared management and paves the way for an important accumulation of payment requests towards the end of the current MFF. It agrees with the frontloading of EFSI provided the redeployment from CEF is duly compensated in 2018. I voted in favour because I am concerned by the fact that, despite a high rate of budgetary execution based on Member States’ national programmes, only a few relocations of refugees have actually taken place to date.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it approves the replacement of the funds from the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020. With this movement of funds, the Union reduces its capacity to act in the field of research and transport infrastructures. To provide EFSI, a mechanism for the financialisation of public interest projects, which ultimately benefits the private sector through the guarantees it offers. EFSI has proved to be a useless and inappropriate tool for the promotion of investment in the Union, while sacrificing those projects. Although the report specifies that its content should not influence the approval of the extension of this mechanism, it ratifies its funding, which I am opposed. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Further this amending budget shows once again the fact that the amounts provided for in the MFF (within their limits) fall short once again than those needed to cope with repeated crises in the EU, not to mention what is necessary for an effective redistributive policy enabling countries and disadvantaged regions are approaching the richest regions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - According to the rapporteur, the arrears until 2020 can only be covered if all the margins were fully exhausted and the annual ceilings were lifted as a security measure. However, since on the whole it means a massive upward adjustment of the EU budget, I could not support this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council's position on the EU draft amending budget No 4/2016 for the financial year 2016 on updating appropriations for take into account the latest developments in relation to migration and security issues and the reduction of payment appropriations. The report expresses deep concern about the surplus payments of €7,284.3 million, which is due to severe delays in implementing EU programmes under concurrent management regime; approves the proposed increases through the mobilization of the margin for contingencies, as well as the advance of the increase in the headcount of Frontex and welcomes the partial strengthening of the AMIF, but is concerned for the fact that, despite a high rate of implementation based on the national programmes of the Member States, only certain relocations of refugees have so far been carried out.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This correction is the symbol of schizophrenia in the EU budget: on the one hand, payments by cohesion policy are reduced, on the other hand, some items in commitments are increased and recalculate national contributions with all corrections and changes to the case. With regard to the issue relating to Heading 1 b, if it really is only delays and commitments already made, we will find ourselves in the coming years faced with a large amount unpredictable payments to be made, with consequences difficult to analyze. If the states actually believed in the European budget they could have used these 'unexpected' resources to fill some priority budget lines with shortages of funds, while there has been no state. no interest in that regard. Instead, it was only proposed to increase some appropriations in commitments (not payments), for some shareable items such as heading 3, for others less sustainable, such as EFSI. Beyond the technical merit of the amending, it seemed necessary to point out these inconsistencies, which is why in the end I opted for an abstention vote in the Committee on Budgets on 24 November , which I kept for the Plenary as well.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the draft report. The PVV considers margins in budget items as instruments for catching unexpected overruns on those items. Since there is a surplus of over 7 billion euros in 2016, the PVV sees no reason to increase the margins.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016. This proposal aimed at updating the appropriations in order to take into account the latest developments in migration and security, the reduction of payment and commitment appropriations as a result of the global transfer, the extension of the EFSI, the adaptation of the Frontex establishment plan and the updating funds on the revenue side. This is one of a series of proposals seeking to adapt the European Union budget so that measures related to the migration and refugee crisis can be financed. I think that in this case the correct budgetary procedure for responding to major crises, such as the current refugee policy situation undoubtedly is, primarily by shifting funds from other unused items. At the same time, the proposal expressed serious concern about the excess payments due to delays in the implementation of EU programmes. I regard this as an area in which Slovakia also has major shortcomings, and I think that the EU should appeal even further to the proper implementation of the programmes.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Council Position Report on draft amending budget No 4/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: modernisation of approvals to reflect the latest developments in the areas of migration and security, reduction of payment appropriations and commitment appropriations due to global redistributions, renewal of EFSI, modification of Frontex's staff plan and modernisation of revenue appropriations (own resources). I support draft amending budget No 4/2016, which provides for the release of the security reserve totalling EUR 240,1 million. I believe the additional funds are justified as they will be spent on addressing the financial needs of migration, security and asylum issues.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Draft No 5 amending the general budget contains many technical measures, which cover various aspects: adjustments to the amounts made available to the Member States, but also to percentages of some rates and so on. However, what is most striking, in addition to the purely technical aspect, are the consequences that the following project has, from a political point of view, within the Member States. In fact, the countries that most of all have been the promoters of austerity, which has caused such great damage to Europe would come out sharply favored. As far as stated earlier I decided to vote against it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Five countries, the largest net contributors and recipients of rebates, are looking to receive an exemption from paying VAT towards the own resources for three years. While we have a nuanced position against own resources, we could not support this position. Therefore, I voted against.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget covers the implementation of the new Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom on the reform of the EU's own resources system, following the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of that Decision on 1 October 2016. This text is essentially technical and only endorsed decisions taken by Member States. Moreover, its budgetary impact is zero. It should be noted, however, that this neutral impact is due only to the fact that corrections granted to some Member States are compensated by the other States, which includes France, but, as it is the mere consequence of negotiations between States, I have chosen abstention.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this resolution, which will require the United Kingdom to hand over a further EUR 700 million to Brussels. I note that there is a suggestion that this is somehow offset by Draft Amending Budget No 4, which is in fact a completely separate matter.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report 'Draft amending budget No 5 for the financial year 2016. Implementation of own resources following the ratification process and following the entry into force of the Decision on 1 October 2016. ' Draft amending budget No 5 aims at 2016. The revenue of the Union budget include the impact of the adjustment of own resources related to Decision No. 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which shall apply retroactively for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: This text is mainly technical and has no budgetary impact, but it is because the corrections granted to some States would be compensated by others, including France. However, it seems unreasonable to vote against it, because it simply ratifies decisions taken by the Member States during negotiations. So I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I approved this resolution on amending budget No 5/2016, which implements minor technical changes in the system of own resources, which have no effect on the overall revenue or expenditure component of the Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Fernandes report on draft amending budget No 5 to the general budget 2016. This is a technical measure which aims to inscribe in the revenue of the Union budget for the financial year 2016 the impact of the own resources adjustments resulting from the implementation of the Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom. This decision introduced some limited amendments to current legislation such as reducing the costs of collecting traditional own resources, a new reduced rate based on VAT and gross reductions in GNI contributions for certain Member States.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. This draft amending budget represents a correction of the system of Member States' contributions to the budget which concerns the treatment of the percentage paid of VAT and the percentage of Gross National Income. This is basically a retrospective application of discounts already enjoyed by a number of countries. It reduces the Union's revenue, thereby reducing its fiscal and budgetary capacity.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported draft amending budget No 5/2016 on the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU on the system of own resources, which contains limited changes such as the reduction of expenditure on the collection of traditional own resources, a new reduced reference rate of VAT resources for some Member States and gross reductions in annual GNI contributions for Member States.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I preferred to abstain from this report on the implementation of the decision on the system of own resources, discussed in the context of the draft amending budget. Decision 2014/335/EU concerns the reform of the EU's own resources system under Euratom following the ratification and entry into force of this Decision on 1 October. Certainly, I agree that this text only endorsed decisions taken by the Member States themselves, with no budgetary impact. However, I note that this lack of budgetary impact is due only to the corrections granted to some Member States thanks to compensation provided by others, notably France.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — I cannot but vote against this measure which will allow the entry into force of new rules on the calculation of own resources which will cost Italy €900 million additional to the amount already pours.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The adoption of amending budget No 5/2016 is determined by the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which introduces changes such as the reduction of expenditure on the collection of traditional own resources, a new reduced resource reference rate VAT for some Member States and gross reductions in annual GNI contributions for some Member States. Therefore, the amendment, which I voted in favour, incorporates into the share of the revenue of the Union budget for 2016 the impact of the adjustments to own resources following the application of Decision 2014/335/EU, with retroactive effects for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016, involving the modification of contributions individual revenues of all Member States, without affecting the total revenue or part of the expenditure of the Union budget.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it approved the Council's position on amending budget No. 5/2016. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 aims at 2016. The revenue of the Union budget include the impact of the adjustment of own resources related to Decision No. 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which shall apply retroactively for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 requires adjustments to the individual contributions of all Member States, but does not affect the overall revenue and expenditure of the Union budget.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 follows from the completion and entry into force of the ratification process of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which includes limited changes, such as a reduction in the collection costs of traditional own resources, VAT reduction of the drawdown rate of budgetary resources for certain Member States and the gross reduction of the GNI-based contribution for some Member States. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 aims to incorporate into the revenue side of the 2016 Union budget the impact of the adjustment of own resources retroactive for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. The plenary session of the European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the draft amending budget. It is important to begin to implement the conclusion on our own funds. This is also influenced by the termination of the ratification procedure and the entry into force of the Euratom Decision, which includes a reduction in the cost of collecting traditional own funds and a new, lower professional rate of VAT resources for certain Member States and a gross reduction in GDP contributions for certain Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — This corrigendum is only the result of negotiation between Member States and, in this respect, I could support it. I note, however, that the lack of impact on the overall budget is in fact the result of favours granted to some States and offset by others. I am therefore abstaining from this amending budget

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Bearing in mind that amending budget No 5/2016 follows the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of Decision No 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which includes minor amendments, as lower collection expenditure on traditional own resources, the reduction in VAT call rates for certain Member States and gross reductions in annual GNI-based contributions. Whereas amending budget No 5/2016 aims at supplementing revenue from the 2016 budget of the Union and leading to a change in the contributions of individual Member States, without having any effect on the side of overall revenue and expenditure of the Union. The Council's position on PBR No 5/2016 was approved and it was finally adopted.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of correction no.5 to the 2016 budget, which aims to enter into the revenue from the Union budget for the financial year 2016 the impact of the adjustments to own resources, with Retroactive effect for exercises 2014, 2015 and 2016. This correction is the result of the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of Decision 2014/335/EU, which introduces limited amendments such as reducing the costs of collecting Traditional own resources, a new reduced rate of VAT based resource levy for certain Member States, as well as gross reductions in GNI contributions for certain Member States. The correction involves changing the individual contributions of all Member States but does not affect the total revenue and expenditure entered in the Union budget in any way.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Five countries, the largest net contributors and recipients of rebates, are looking to receive an exemption from paying VAT towards the own resources for three years. While Sinn Féin has a nuanced position against own resources, I could not support this position. Therefore, I voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This amending budget would require the UK to pay just over EUR 700 million back to the EU, retrospectively, for the years 2014 and 2015. UKIP opposes giving any taxpayer’s money to the EU as it should be used to help jobs and public services back in the UK. Asking the UK for a fresh backdated bill is doubly outrageous after the country just voted to leave the EU.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU on own resources after the conclusion of the ratification procedure and its entry into force on 1 October 2016. The report relates to the reallocation of Member States' commitments and the restructuring of EU funds. As I consider that the proposed changes not only do not address the existing problems of the European economy, but instead create additional inequalities and distortions, I decided to vote against.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Negative vote. The measure will allow the entry into force of new rules on the calculation of own resources made available by Member States which will cost Italy €900 million.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: ‒ I am voting in favour of a measure which aims to complete the ratification process on own resources. In relation to the latter, they include: levies levied on imports of agricultural products, customs duties, i.e. those of the Common Customs Tariff and other charges set by the Communities on trade with non-Member States, VAT proceeds obtained by applying a rate initially of 1% and finally contributions paid by Member States in the event that the previous resources do not were sufficient to guarantee the coverage of the Community budget. These contributions are calculated as a percentage of the gross national product of the individual Member States (the 'GNP resource' is referred to in this regard). This measure therefore introduces the reduction of the costs of collecting traditional own resources, a new reduced rate of VAT based resource levy for certain Member States combined with gross reductions in contributions based on gross national income for certain countries. There will certainly be a change in the individual contributions made by all Member States without affecting total revenue and expenditure entered in the Community budget.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Council position on Draft Amending Budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Implementation of the Own Resources Decision No 2014/335/EU further to the closing of the ratification process and its entry into force on 1 October 2016.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on Budgets.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budget (PBK) No 5 to the general budget for 2016 — implementing own resources decision No 2014/335/EU. The project has been positively reviewed by the Committee on Budgets. It contains accurate data on the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. The PBK is overwhelmingly a very complex document of a technical nature. It should be noted that the 2014 decision granted Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden and Austria a gross reduction in annual premiums based on GNI between 2014 and 2020.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the own resources system of the Union must ensure adequate resources for the orderly development of the policies of the Union, subject to the need for strict budgetary discipline. Furthermore, the development of the own resources system is also important and this should also contribute to wider budgetary consolidation efforts undertaken in Member States.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This report constitutes one of the amending budgetary reports for 2016. It aims to incorporate into the revenue component of the 2016 Union budget the effect of adjustments to own resources related to the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, with retroactive effect on the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This amending budget would require the UK to pay just over EUR 700 million back to the EU, retrospectively, for the years 2014 and 2015. UKIP opposes giving any taxpayer’s money to the EU as it should be used to help jobs and public services back in the UK. Asking the UK for a fresh backdated bill is doubly outrageous after the country just voted to leave the EU.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 5/2016. In 2014, the European institutions decided to modify the European Union's income system through a series of measures, such as the reduction of annual contributions based on the gross national income of certain Member States. This Decision has been ratified and is now in force and, although it modifies the individual contributions of Member States, it has no effect on the amounts of overall Union revenue and expenditure. However, it remains imperative to amend the budget so that it takes account of changes in each Member State's contributions to the European budget.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 follows from the completion and entry into force of the ratification process of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which includes limited changes, such as a reduction in the collection costs of traditional own resources, VAT reduction of the drawdown rate of budgetary resources for certain Member States and the gross reduction of the GNI-based contribution for some Member States. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 aims to incorporate into the revenue side of the 2016 Union budget the impact of the adjustment of own resources retroactive for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. The plenary session of the European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU budget for 2017. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 follows from the completion and entry into force of the ratification process of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which includes limited changes, such as a reduction in the collection costs of traditional own resources, VAT reduction of the drawdown rate of budgetary resources for certain Member States and the gross reduction of the GNI-based contribution for some Member States. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 aims to incorporate into the revenue side of the 2016 Union budget the impact of the adjustment of own resources retroactive for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. The plenary session of the European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this report. This is the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom on the reform of the EU's own resources system, which entered into force on 1 October 2016. The budgetary impact of this text is zero. However, France is still in the category of net contributors. To the extent that this situation arises from negotiations between States, we abstained.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported my colleague Fernandes' report on draft amending budget No 5/2016: implementation of the own resources decision, as it results from the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which contains limited changes, such as reduction of the cost of collecting traditional own resources, a new, reduced VAT based own resource rate for certain Member States and gross reductions in annual GNI contributions for certain Member States. Its aim is to include in the revenue part of the Union budget for 2016 the impact of own resource adjustments resulting from the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, with retroactive effect for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

October 2016. name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The system of the Union's own resources must provide adequate funding for the orderly development of Union policies, provided strict budgetary discipline. Developing a system of own resources can and should also contribute to wider efforts to consolidate budgets undertaken in Member States and participate, to the fullest extent possible, in the development of Union policies. The upper limit of own funds should be equal to 1,23% of the total GNI of Member States at the market price for payment appropriations, and a ceiling of 1,29% of the total GNI of Member States should be set for commitment appropriations. In order to remain unchanged in the amount of financial resources made available to the Union, it is appropriate to adjust those ceilings expressed in percentage terms of GNI. These ceilings should be adjusted as soon as all Member States have submitted their data under the European System of National and Regional Accounts (ESA 2010). In the event of any changes to ESA 2010 implying a significant change in the level of GNI, the upper limits of own funds and commitment appropriations should be re-adjusted. This Decision should enter into force only after it has been approved by all Member States in accordance with their respective constitutional provisions, which fully respects state sovereignty.

The plenary session of the European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the entry into force of the proposal for budgetary adjustment 2016/5, given that certain tax changes have occurred in the context of the normal timetable for budgetary planning, on the one hand, in relation to direct resources based on tax (VAT) and, on the other hand, the national In the case of income-based national contributions, the validation of the reduction data resulting from a change in the relative position of some Member States does not, in fact, constitute a shift in the overall revenue expenditure balance of the EU budget, but it is necessary to make such corrections in accordance with the continuity of operation under the law.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome Draft Amending Budget No 5/2016 which results from the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of Decision No 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which contains limited changes such as the reduction of the collection costs of traditional Own Resources, a new reduced rate of call of the VAT-based resource for some Member States, and gross reductions in GNI-based contributions for some Member States. The said Draft Amending Budget aims at incorporating in the revenue side of the 2016 Union budget the impact of adjustments to the own resources stemming from the implementation of Decision No 2014/335/EU.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU on the system of own resources following the closure of the ratification process and the entry into force of the decision on 1 October 2016.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on Draft amending budget No 5/2016 for the implementation of the decision on own resources, since it concerns the implementation of the already existing decision and leads to a modification of the proposals of all Member States. Taking into account that draft budget No 5/2016 comes from the completion of the ratification procedure and the entry into force of Decision No. 2014/335/EU, Euratom, and to introduce slight changes such as reducing the cost of collecting traditional own funds, new reduced VAT holdings for one Member State and a large reduction in GNI contributions for others, I have decided to support the proposal for this Resolution.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — Under the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 on budgetary discipline, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission must cooperate on budgetary issues and sound financial governance. On the basis of a Council Decision on the system of own resources of the European Union, the Commission adopted draft amending budget No 5/2016, integrating into the revenue side of the Union budget for 2016 the impact of adjustments to the system of own resources with retroactive effect for 2014, 2015 and 2016 and the contributions of the Member States shall be amended. Since I agree with the Council's position on draft amending budget No 5/2016, I supported this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Implementation of Own Resource Decision No 5/2016 2014/335/EU, following the completion of its ratification procedure and entry into force on 1 October 2016, I supported.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.
