This draft amending budget represents a correction of the system of Member States' contributions to the budget which concerns the treatment of the percentage paid of VAT and the percentage of Gross National Income. This is basically a retrospective application of discounts already enjoyed by a number of countries. It reduces the Union's revenue, thereby reducing its fiscal and budgetary capacity.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this decision as an act of pragmatism. The EU’s own resources are insufficient for its needs.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending budget (PBK) No 5/2016 concerns the implementation of a new decision on own resources following the completion of the ratification process of the document on 1 October 2016. PBK 5/2016 provides for the effect of that Decision retroactive from 1 January 2014 and consequently, as a consequence, It recognises the adjustments relating to the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. This PBK is overwhelmingly a composite and technical document, but it is worth noting that the 2014 decision granted Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden and Austria a gross reduction in annual premiums based on data Dutch for the period 2014-2020. This amounts to EUR 130 million, EUR 695 million, EUR 185 million and EUR 30 million respectively (2011 prices). PBK also includes changes to the UK rebate for 2014 and 2015, which is why I voted for the project.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 5/2016 follows from the completion and entry into force of the ratification process of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which includes limited changes, such as reducing the collection costs of traditional own resources, reduction of the VAT-based resource drawing rate for certain Member States and a gross reduction in the GNI-based contribution for some Member States. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. This draft amending budget represents a correction of the system of Member States' contributions to the budget which concerns the treatment of the percentage paid of VAT and the percentage of Gross National Income. This is basically a retrospective application of discounts already enjoyed by a number of countries. It reduces the Union's revenue, thereby reducing its fiscal and budgetary capacity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on Draft Amending Budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Implementation of the Own Resources Decision No 2014/335/EU further to the closing of the ratification process and its entry into force on 1 October 2016. Draft amending budget No 5/2016 results from the completion of the ratification process and the entry into force of Decision No 2014/335/EU, Euratom, which contains limited changes such as the reduction of the collection costs of traditional Own Resources, a new reduced rate of call of the VAT-based resource for some Member States, and gross reductions in GNI-based contributions for some Member States. The draft aims at incorporating in the revenue side of the 2016 Union budget the impact of adjustments to the own resources stemming from the implementation of Decision No 2014/335/EU, Euratom, with retroactive effect for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016. I voted in favour because I believe that the draft leads to the modification of the individual contributions of all Member States, but affects neither the overall revenue nor expenditure side of the Union budget.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report involves the adoption of a mechanism which reduces solidarity in the allocation of contributions to the European Union budget. The report develops' reductions' in Member States' contributions which are considered to be contributing more than they should. This is an attack against the principle of solidarity and territorial redistribution that the Union budget must have. The mechanism approves these rebates retroactively, whereby the countries concerned, including the United Kingdom, Sweden, Germany, Austria, etc... will recover part of their contribution to the European budget in the financial years where the economic crisis has been toughest. We need a European budget that promotes solidarity between countries and that is precisely why I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The calculation of contributions from EU Member States remains obscure and incomprehensible to citizens as a whole. While the contribution of each State must account for about 1% of its gross income, the problem is that successive hits are made on contributions from countries such as the UK, Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden or Austria, and these arrangements are distributed among the other Member States, passing through the idea that this budget will not be as supportive as we claim. The return of part of the contributions on the basis of revenue execution (traditional own resources and fines) above anticipated is another paradox that occurs at the same time that all margins for unforeseen contingencies are mobilised.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The new basic assessment is intended to take into account the impact of the adjustments to own funds retroactively for the years 2014-2016. This means that economically stronger countries will have to pay more. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The text voted on today is essentially a technical amending budget, but which also has political implications. On the one hand it is a question of applying rules already decided and approved, but on the other it is particularly difficult to accept these rules made of exceptions and advantages only for certain countries, which then they are among the least affected by European economic difficulties. This correction lays down favourable conditions for countries such as Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, Austria and the United Kingdom, which are certainly not to be regarded as the most suffering states internal EU. The calculation of these contributions is yet another demonstration that some countries count more in the EU than others, and in fact they are champions of rigour and austerity that brought Europe to its knees. In the Committee on Budgets on 24 November I voted against it as in the House.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the draft report. The PVV considers it undesirable for the European Parliament to have control over the level of individual contributions of Member States to the EU's own resources.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016. This proposal aimed at implementing the decision on own resources once the ratification process has been completed. In my view, the proposal did not contain any significant changes, rather these were small changes, such as a reduction in the cost of collecting traditional own funds, a new reduced rate applied to VAT resources for some Member States and a gross reduction in GNI-based contributions for some Member States and the aim of the whole proposal was to incorporate these changes with retroactive effect. That is why I had no reservations about this proposal.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the implementation of the decision on my own funds. The Union's own resources system must provide adequate funding for the orderly development of Union policies, provided strict budgetary discipline. Developing a system of own resources can and should also contribute to wider efforts to consolidate budgets undertaken in Member States and participate, to the fullest extent possible, in the development of Union policies. The upper limit of own funds should be equal to 1,23% of the total GNI of Member States at the market price for payment appropriations, and a ceiling of 1,29% of the total GNI of Member States should be set for commitment appropriations. In order to remain unchanged in the amount of financial resources made available to the Union, it is appropriate to adjust those ceilings expressed in percentage terms of GNI. These ceilings should be adjusted as soon as all Member States have submitted their data on the basis of the ESA 2010. In the event of any amendments to the ESA 2010 implying a significant change in the level of GNI, the upper limits of own funds and commitment appropriations should be re-adjusted. This Decision should enter into force only after it has been approved by all Member States in accordance with their respective constitutional provisions, which fully respects state sovereignty.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Council Position Report on draft amending budget No 5/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Implementation of Own Resource Decision No. 2014/335/EU following the completion of its ratification procedure and entry into force on 1 October 2016. Proposal for amending budget No 5/2016 provides for the inclusion of the consequences of adjustments of own resources adopted on the basis of the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom and having a retroactive effect for the financial years 2014, 2015 and 2016 on the revenue side of the Union budget for 2016. The draft amending budget No 5/2016 thus amends the individual contributions of all Member States and does not affect either the total revenue or the expenditure side of the Union budget.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance following a disaster in Germany — floods that have damaged the district of Lower Bavaria — in May and June 2016. The German authorities estimated the total damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 259,005 million. The figure obtainable through the EUSF is EUR 31 475 125, by means of the approval of an amending financial statements. To help the affected populations and foster reconstruction operations, I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file was to mobilise funding from the European Solidarity Fund to Germany after the catastrophic flooding in May and June 2016. Therefore, I supported sending solidarity funding to the affected people of the affected areas.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although this type of fundraising usually poses no problem, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country that thrives on the backs of its neighbours to the south thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need. I abstained on this file.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that this fund is necessary. EU Member States contribute to a fund from which they can then reclaim money in the event of a natural disaster. However, ultimately there will be no real net benefit in terms of the levels of administration involved. Given that the fund exists, however, I see no reason to doubt that the situation in Germany is a worthwhile cause and I have no objection to the proposal. I therefore felt, overall, that it was appropriate to abstain.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide aid to Germany. The aim of the report is to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial support to Germany in the disaster in May and June 2016 (floods in Lower Bavaria, especially in Roto on-Inn County). I agree with the Commission's proposal, which proposes the application of a 2.5% total direct damage factor for all damage up to the threshold for serious damage. The total amount of the proposed aid amounts to EUR 31 475 125.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I approved this proposal to mobilise EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations for Germany under the European Union Solidarity Fund under the 2016 budget, following floods in Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. — In May and June 2016, Germany was affected by a series of sudden floods and extremely intense floods that caused the destruction of homes, installations agricultural, enterprises and caused considerable damage to various public infrastructure. The authorities estimated the damage to be around 1.2 billion euros. 47 000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected by this dramatic event, seven lost their lives while over 2000 have been affected by this dramatic event. found in the impossibility of returning to your homes after more than two months after flooding. The town of Simbach am Inn was almost entirely destroyed and remained for as much as three weeks without access to the water supply. The Hohlmeier report, which I supported today in my vote, enables the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to areas affected by this natural disaster. This measure will be provided approximately EUR 31 million in the form of commitment and payment appropriations. This is a dutiful measure to support the German population at a time of hardship.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The aim is to mobilise 500 million to deal with the floods that occurred in 2016 in the Niederbayern region of Germany.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the mobilisation of the Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany in connection with the catastrophe that occurred in floods that affected the Lower Bavaria Region in May and June 2016. They left a trace of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture. The damage was estimated at EUR 1 259,005 million and the region concerned belongs to the most developed region category covered by the European Structural and Investment Funds (2014-2020). I agree, still and all with the aid requested by Germany, of around EUR 31,400 000.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I preferred to abstain from the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in favour of Germany. While I usually support the intervention of this mechanism and I sympathize with the plight of the many Germans affected by the floods, I believe that Germany has ample means to deal with this situation without receiving EUR 31.475.125 from the EUSF. Let us recall that with approximately EUR 12 billion in budgetary surpluses and public accounts with a surplus of about 16.4 billion, I am convinced that the German authorities will be able to cope with the challenges posed by these floods in Bavaria in particular.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — Between May and June, the regions of Lower Bavaria were affected by violent flooding. With this vote, I support the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for EUR 31 475 125 to be allocated to the reconstruction and support of the affected populations. I believe that the Solidarity Fund continues to be an important instrument of support which Europe makes available to Member States affected by serious natural disasters, although I hope that It is able to make its activation faster and faster, because this will greatly increase its effectiveness.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my vote I supported the mobilisation of EUR 31 475 125 from the Union Solidarity Fund to assist the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. German authorities estimated total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 26 billion

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, in which the Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial support to Germany in the disaster in May and June 2016 (floods in Lower Bavaria, especially in Roto nad In county). There have been a number of very large short-term and sudden floods, which have damaged public and private infrastructure, as well as private houses, and have caused damage to the agricultural sector. In Lower Bavaria, seven people were killed, more than 47,000 people were affected, and two months after the floods, 2,000 people were not yet able to return to their homes. The city of Zimbach-on-Inn was almost completely destroyed and utilities were not provided for three weeks. In addition, very serious damage to enterprises and agriculture, basic infrastructure, water supply, sewerage and electricity networks has been reported. The affected region is classified in the category of more developed regions under the European Structural and Investment Funds (2014-2020).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to the use of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. The purpose is to respond quickly, efficiently and resiliently to emergencies. By doing so, we also demonstrate our solidarity with the population of the affected areas. Thus, on 19 August 2016, Germany submitted an application for the use of the Fund, following a number of short-term, extremely intense floods affecting the Lower Bavaria region in May and June 2016. However, since the scale of the natural disaster meets all the assumptions for the use of the Fund, I consider that there are no reservations in its use.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ Even the largest countries can be affected by natural disasters, by their nature unforeseen and unpredictable. This is the case of Germany that this year, in the spring, was the target of extraordinary rains that caused numerous floods and landslides. Damage to public infrastructure (schools, dams, telecommunications networks and roads), housing and private activities (hundreds of buildings were flooded) was extensive. There was also damage to the agricultural sector and forests from mud deposits, landslides and landslides. The exceptionality and seriousness of the situation necessitated the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Parliament must approve the mobilisation of the Fund for the allocation of the amounts provided by the Commission as an emergency contribution to the affected regions, in the shortest possible time, as quickly as possible the institutional response to a flood intervention is essential for the resumption of economic activities and the normal conduct of the daily activities of citizens.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report in order to mobilize the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance to Germany following its floods that affected Lower Bavaria, especially the district of Rottal-Inn, in May and June 2016. The series of extremely intense floods resulted in the destruction of public and private infrastructure, private housing and agricultural facilities. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47000 people were affected in Lower Bavaria, of whom over 2000 had not yet been able to return to their homes two months after the floods. Significant damage was reported to business and agriculture, as well as heavy damage to basic infrastructure, water supply, wastewater disposal services and power grid . Mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund is therefore essential. However, I think that it is important to revise the Fund's regulation in order to simplify existing rules, allowing contributions to be paid more quickly.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This file sought for an increase in the social fund in instances where a natural disaster has taken place and has adversely affected the economy. Given that natural disasters can adversely affect the economies of any Member state, it is important that the EU shows solidarity to those people affected and helps them to stabilise in the aftermath of tragic circumstances. Therefore, I supported it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this binding budgetary report. The EU Solidarity Fund is an EU fund used when there has been a natural disaster in an area of Europe. This specific proposal is to give Germany EUR 31 457 125 for floods in lower Bavaria where there was material destruction and loss of life. Although UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money, as this is to do with a natural disaster we decided to abstain.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany confirms the role of the Fund, since it aims to provide assistance after the floods occurred in Germany in May and June 2016. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ By virtue of what has tragically occurred in my territories of origin, namely in Piedmont and Liguria, I can only externate all my consternation as it has similarly occurred between May and June last in the region of Lower Bavaria. I therefore vote in favour of the provision of EUR 31 475 125 in commitment appropriations and payments to Germany from the Solidarity Fund of the European Union. Unfortunately, the rains were torrential generating, thus, the exondation of several rivers, which had inevitably poured into many towns, unleashing devastating floods. It is noteworthy of note the speed with which Germany has made itself able to submit the application for mobilization of the Fund since it requires completeness and accuracy in order to compile the Fund. of data not easy to translate into numbers. I hope that with the same speed and punctuality, the Italian State will be able to do the same so that we can live a more serene 2017 to those who have found themselves, in a whale, displaced by the nature of the work of a life.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund enables the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to demonstrate its solidarity with the populations of regions affected by natural disasters. On 19 August 2016, Germany made a request to mobilise the Fund following a series of extremely intense and short-lived flooding cases affecting the region of Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016 and leaving a trail of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture, with 7 people lost their lives and more than 47000 were affected. I support this report mobilising the amount of EUR 31 475 125 in commitment and payment appropriations to be granted to Germany from the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on Budgets.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — In view of the legitimacy of the proposal, I voted in favour of the draft amending budget No 6 to the general budget for 2016, accompanied by a proposal for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany, in accordance with the guarantees of financial assistance to States affected by major natural disasters or extraordinary disasters in particular regions. Germany fulfils all formal conditions for such assistance to receive. The 2016 FSEU aid relates to floods in Lower Bavaria. The cataclysm caused damage to public and private infrastructure, homes, and destruction in the agricultural sector. In the justification of the proposal, the percentage determination of damages exceeds the threshold required to qualify the effects as a “regional catastrophe”.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it grants financial assistance to Germany following the series of extremely intense, short-lived cases of flooding/flash floods that caused destruction to public and private infrastructure, private homes and agriculture in Lower Bavaria.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to authorise the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Germany, which suffered floods affecting Lower Bavaria, in particular the Rottal-Inn district in May and June 2016. This natural disaster affected more than 47,000 people. In this context, the EUSF mobilization for Germany amounts to 34 million euros. Considering the seriousness of the German situation following these floods and considering the European Union's duty to provide relief to European territories in distress following natural disasters, I have of course voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this binding budgetary report. The EU Solidarity Fund is an EU fund used when there has been a natural disaster in an area of Europe. This specific proposal is to give Germany EUR 31 457 125 for floods in lower Bavaria where there was material destruction and loss of life. Although UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money, as this is to do with a natural disaster we decided to abstain.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Germany. The Niederbayern region of Lower Bavaria was hit by heavy flooding in May and June 2016. Since the application for assistance from the Union Solidarity Fund, submitted on 19 August 2016, fulfils the conditions for granting, the European Union must rapidly mobilise the commitment and payment appropriations necessary to assist the victims of these floods.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for financial aid of EUR 31,475,125 related to flooding in Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn, which occurred in Germany in May and June 2016. In my view, it is essential to show our solidarity with the affected region. Unfortunately, the floods claimed the lives of seven people, more than 47,000 people living in Lower Bavaria were affected, and more than 2,000 people were unable to return to their homes two months after the events. They have also resulted in the destruction of public infrastructure, private infrastructure, individual dwellings and agricultural facilities.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. This intervention covers floods in Germany and aims to provide €31,475,125 funding from the European Union Solidarity Fund. We are usually in favour of granting this type of exceptional aid. However, with regard to Germany, a country that thrives thanks to the euro to the detriment of other European states, we cannot endorse additional aid.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU must show flexibility when there are grounds for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. Explanation of votes - report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for assistance to Germany A8-0352/2016 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure a rapid, effective and be able to respond to emergencies in a flexible way and express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on the Solidarity Fund which enables EU financial assistance to be provided in the event of natural disasters. Despite my many calls, the UK Government refuses to take advantage of the Solidarity Fund to help overcome disasters in Wales.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstention: the text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In this particular case, Germany asks the European Commission to release a total amount of EUR 31 475 125, which should help the Bavaria region cope more effectively with the consequences of intense short-term floods that have caused an overall estimated damage exceeding 90 million EUR, and extensive damage to public and private infrastructure, private dwellings and agriculture.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report for concrete economic aid to the more than 1470,000 German citizens affected by the flood of May/June 2016.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund to help Germany, as the EU must show flexibility when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposes to mobilise EUR 31 475 125 to help the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. The total direct damage caused by the disaster was estimated at EUR 1.26 billion by the German authorities. The Committee on Budgets recommends swift approval of the proposal in sign of solidarity with the affected German regions. The proposal is linked with Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the European Union Solidarity Fund shall be paid to Germany the amount of EUR 31.475.000 in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report considering that the draft amending budget provides for the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the Commission's proposal to use the European Union Solidarity Fund to grant financial assistance in connection with the floods in Lower Bavaria that occurred in May and June 2016.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity fund to provide assistance to Germany. Germany faced treacherous flooding in May and June of 2016, as significant damage was caused to businesses and agriculture, as well as heavy damage to the basic infrastructure, water supply, sewage services and electricity network. Therefore, it is vital to support and provide assistance to our neighbouring Member States.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the EU solidarity fund to provide assistance to Germany. The total direct damage caused by the disaster was estimated at EUR 1.26 billion by the German authorities. Cases of flooding/flash floods caused destruction to public and private infrastructure, private homes, and agriculture.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany, which experienced a disaster in May and June 2016 when major floods in Lower Bavaria, especially in Rottal-Inn district, hit population, destroyed the basic infrastructure, water supply, sewerage and electricity distribution network. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47,000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected by the disaster, while two months after the floods more than 2,000 people were still unable to return to their homes. Major damage has been caused and the total proposed aid amount is EUR 31 475 125. The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance in relation to the above, which I fully agree.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: It is quite unusual to see Germany affected by a mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Indeed, the State keeps the heads of its neighbours under the waves of the single currency and takes advantage of its advantageous position on the surface. It would then be fair for it to draw on its resources fed by budgetary surpluses and low borrowing rates to meet the needs it can meet without the unnecessary aid of European solidarity. So I abstained.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, in order to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for €31.5 million to grant financial assistance to Germany due to the floods in Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016. The latter have led to the destruction of public and private infrastructure, private housing and agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47,000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the proposal. Lower Bavaria was hit by a flood disaster in the summer of 2016 and the fund set up can cover the damage costs of a total of 2.5% of the total loss in the event of “major catastrophes”. As the estimated appropriations of EUR 541,22 million for 2015 were not spent and carried over to the following year, the remaining appropriations amount to EUR 1.09 billion, which means that sufficient resources are available.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour in order to approve the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide EUR 31 475 125 assistance to Germany, following the floods that affected Lower Bavaria, especially the district of Rottal/Inn, in May and June 2016. The proposed aid from the EUSF of EUR 31 475 125 is intended to help restore essential infrastructure, reimburse the cost of emergency measures and cover the costs of some of the clean-up operations. In justification of this decision, it is important to note that more EU solidarity means more EU, therefore we should approve the mobilisation of the EUSF for Germany.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. — Although there is usually no problem with this kind of mobilization of the solidarity fund for the unemployed, I abstained this time because, in this case, Germany is concerned. However, it is a country that thrives on the backs of its neighbours to the south thanks to the single currency and thus ruins all their industry. Germany should use its budget surpluses to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need and in which it itself participates very sparingly. Nevertheless, I am not going so far as to vote against this report out of respect for our German AfD allies.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund to assist the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. The German authorities estimated the total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 26 billion.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to assist the region of Lower Bavaria affected by flooding in 2016.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The Commission has proposed mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for financial assistance in relation to the disaster that struck Germany in May and June 2016. Numerous extremely strong and short-term floods have caused the destruction of public and private infrastructure, homes and farmland. Great damage has been caused to basic infrastructure, water supply, sewerage and electricity distribution network. The German authorities estimated total direct damage at €1,259 005 million. Given that this amount represents 3.03% of the regional GDP of the NUTS 2 Lower Bavaria region concerned, and exceeds the 1.5% regional GDP threshold, this natural disaster qualifies as a “regional disaster”. The Commission proposed to apply a rate of 2.5% of total direct damage for all damage up to the large-scale disaster threshold. The total amount of aid proposed is therefore EUR 31 475 125. This is the second mobilisation decision for 2016, and the total proposed amount of aid is in line with the EU Solidarity Fund's upper limit provisions. In a show of solidarity with the affected region, it is necessary to urgently approve this assistance, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In accordance with the rules of the Solidarity Fund, the EP approved the granting of financial assistance to Germany, which was affected by the floods in late spring 2016. Flooding in Lower Bavaria caused casualties on lives and there has been widespread damage to both public and private infrastructure, buildings and dwellings. The earmarked amount of EUR 31 475 125 will serve to remedy the damage and rebuild.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) is a financial aid tool for European countries affected by serious natural disasters. We usually support requests to mobilise this Fund in order to help the citizens of the Member States who are in difficult situations. However, this demand provokes our reservations. In this case, this is the mobilisation of EUR 31.5 million in favour of Germany, the only country in the European Union which benefits from the single currency and the single European market. Germany could use its budget surpluses to address these kinds of problems instead of asking for funding from Member States in crisis situations!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. Such a report would represent the Member States’ aim to assist fellow EU members in the event of emergencies, to show solidarity to those affected by natural disasters. The financial contribution from the Fund will enable Germany to repair the damage caused by the floods in Lower Bavaria, which included, but was not limited to, the destruction of public and private infrastructure, private homes and agriculture. Supporting the report symbolises solidarity with the affected region, shown previously towards the earthquakes in the Greek islands and Italy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. — The additional financial aid discussed here for the flood victims in Germany is to be supported. I therefore agree with the request, as the increase is appropriate in this case.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The aim of the EU Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to disasters by showing solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters. It is proposed to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial support to Germany to repair damage caused by very severe short-term floods in May and June 2016.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case, as surprising as it may seem, Germany is concerned here, whereas everyone knows that it is the country that benefits almost exclusively from the single currency. Germany could obviously avoid appealing to European solidarity. I therefore abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) This proposal deals with the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide financial assistance for a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. The series of very intense short-lived floods/sudden flooding has left a trail of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47 000 were affected in Lower Bavaria, 2 000 of them were unable to return to their homes two months after the floods. The town of Simbach am Inn was almost completely destroyed and, for three weeks, no municipal water supply. Significant damage to companies and agriculture, as well as serious damage to basic infrastructure, water supply, sewage services and the power grid were also noted. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. In May and June 2016, parts of Lower Bavaria were severely affected by floods and the EU Solidarity Fund is indispensable for Member States to be able to finance repair works in such situations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Following particularly significant floods in the Niederbayern region (Lower Bavaria) in May and June 2016, Germany submitted an application for assistance to the Solidarity Fund on 19 August 2016. The floods have caused considerable damage to public and private infrastructure, individual dwellings and agricultural facilities. In addition, more than 47,000 people were affected, and two months after the disaster, more than 2,000 people were still unable to return to their homes. Given the extent of this disaster, I have decided to vote in favour of EUR 31 475,125 in commitment and payment appropriations for the solidarity fund, because not only does the application fulfil the conditions for granting financial aid, but also because I am convinced that the damage cannot remain unechoed. The EU combines the values of solidarity and responsibility: it was therefore normal for it to act as effectively as possible in the face of such a situation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because it is essential to have a swift approval of the proposal in sign of solidarity with the affected German regions. The mobilisation of EUR 31 475 125 will help the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. The total direct damage caused by the disaster was estimated at EUR 1.26 billion by the German authorities.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Following the flood disaster in Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016, the Commission proposed to Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund. Seven people lost their lives in the disaster, two months later more than 2000 people could not return to their homes. The city of Simbach am Inn was almost completely destroyed and serious damage to the basic infrastructure: water supply, wastewater treatment and electricity grid. In their request, the German authorities estimated the total amount of damage caused directly by the disaster at EUR 1 259,005 million, representing 3,03% of the GDP of the Lower Bavaria region, i.e. 1,5% of regional GDP and thus constitutes a 'regional disaster'. The German authorities estimated the eligible costs of the necessary emergency operations at EUR 94,196 million. In line with previous practice, the Commission proposes to take into account 2.5% of total direct damage up to the 'major disaster' threshold, with the total amount of aid proposed at EUR 31 475 125. The Committee on Budgets notes in its report that Germany's application fulfils the requirements laid down for the determination of the financial contribution from the Fund and therefore proposes that Parliament approves the in order to obtain a contribution. I voted in favour of the proposal

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: The EUSF aims to provide a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. The mobilisation of the EUSF was requested to provide financial assistance following the disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. The series of very intense short-lived floods/sudden flooding has left a trail of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture. Seven people lost, their lives and more than 47 000 were affected in Lower Bavaria; 2 000 of them were unable to return to their homes two months after the floods. Significant damage to companies and agriculture, as well as serious damage to basic infrastructure, water supply, sewage services and the power grid were also noted. I advocate the mobilization of the EUSF in this case, because it fulfils the requirements, the impact on the local community and economy and the considerable damage it caused in the region, not only in relation to public infrastructure, but also to private properties and companies, as well as the agricultural sector.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country which thrives on the backs of its southern neighbours thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: ‒ We welcome the resolution in favour of greater involvement and support of regional and local authorities. They represent the institutions most close to the citizens and those able to better understand and define their needs. Their centrality is also defined at European level, thanks to the affirmation of the principle of subsidiarity, which establishes the obligation of institutions to take decisions as close as possible to the citizen. Even in the case of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the local dimension must be central: the European Commission must consider additional measures to support their action and to be able to improve the management of the Structural Funds. If the Commission were to intervene with additional arrangements, there could be positive fallout on economic growth and employment in the Member States. Finally, it is possible and desirable that the Commission should consider the launch of a public consultation on this issue in order to give voice to citizens and their requests.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Germany following the floods in lower Bavaria that occurred in May and June 2016. The German authorities estimated that the disaster caused damage of approximately EUR 1 259 million.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. In May and June 2016, the south of Germany as well as parts of France and Austria suffered flooding after heavy rainfall that developed in a short period of time. Unfortunately, this rainfall, apart from the demolition of state and private property, has also led to fatalities. Similar consequences have recently struck the Balkans region, where, over a period of less than two years, in some regions of Romania, Serbia, Croatia, Greece, as well as in my country, Bulgaria has caused numerous human tragedies. In all these cases, the Solidarity Fund was mobilised to help financially the injured population of these countries. I believe that, like the citizens of the Balkans, German citizens from the affected cities need the financial support of the fund, which, although it cannot cover the damage from the flood, will help them at least partially. For this reason, I have given my support to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide financial assistance to Germany.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file was to mobilise European Solidarity Fund to Germany after the catastrophic flooding in May and June 2016. Therefore, I supported sending solidarity funding to the affected people of the affected areas.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because this is about the flood disaster in Lower Bavaria in the summer of 2016, and in the event of a major disaster, the Solidarity Fund should be allowed to be mobilised.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Germany's Lower Bavaria region has been hit by very heavy floods, with money allocated from the Solidarity Fund helping the region cope with the consequences.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in connection with the disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria region, in particular the Province of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. The series of extremely intense and short duration/instantaneous floods caused disasters to public and private infrastructure, private homes and agriculture. Seven people died and more than 47,000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected, and more than 2,000 people were unable to return home two months after the floods. Simbach am Inn was almost completely destroyed and left for three weeks without water supply. Significant damage was also reported to businesses and farms, as well as serious damage to basic infrastructure, water supply, sewerage services and electricity grid.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision, within the framework of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016, to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in favour of Germany for the EUR 31 475 125 in commitment and payment appropriations because I argue that Germany should have adequate financial assistance in relation to the disaster which has affected the German territory in May and June 2016. Such disasters consisted of intense, short-lived floods or intensive floods that damaged public and private infrastructure, housing and agricultural facilities, especially in Lower Bavaria. I strongly support that businesses and the agricultural sector and the infrastructure network of those seriously damaged areas should be rehabilitated with the support and solidarity of EU member countries. Therefore, I voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond in rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergencies and to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by disasters. I voted in favour of this decision, as it will grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Germany – floods affecting Lower Bavaria, especially the district of Rottal-Inn – that occurred in May and June 2016. The series of extremely intense, short-lived cases of flooding/flash floods caused destruction of public and private infrastructure, of private homes, and in agriculture.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — After numerous cases of very strong short-term floods that hit Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016, in particular Rottal-Inn district, affecting more than 47,000 people, Germany applied for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund on 19 August 2016. Having regard to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Council Regulation establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, which seeks to enable the EU to respond swiftly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to show solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters, and the fact that Germany's request qualifies for the provision of a financial contribution from the Fund, I support the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in order to provide financial assistance to Germany. The proposed aid of €31 475 125 is crucial in order to mitigate the consequences of this regional disaster. Two thousand people lost a roof over their heads. The city of Simbach am Inn is almost completely destroyed. Flooding caused massive material damage, infrastructure was destroyed, massive damage was also on farmland. Therefore, mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund is needed in order to help remediate damage and move on to reconstruction and reconstruction and to bring the population in the affected regions back to their daily life as soon as possible.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country which thrives on the backs of its southern neighbours thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to show solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters. After numerous cases of very strong short-term floods that hit Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016, Germany applied for the Fund's mobilisation in August 2016. Numerous floods and torrents have caused the destruction of public and private infrastructure, homes and farmland and human casualties. Germany's request is eligible for the provision of a financial contribution from the Fund. In line with current practice, the Commission proposes to apply a rate of 2.5% of total direct damage to all damage up to the threshold for “large-scale disasters”. The total amount of aid proposed is therefore EUR 31 475 125. Funds from the Fund should be mobilised to provide a financial contribution to Germany.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide financial assistance for a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. The series of very intense short-lived floods/sudden flooding has left a trail of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture. Seven people lost, their lives and more than 47 000 were affected in Lower Bavaria; 2 000 of them were unable to return to their homes two months after the floods. Regardless of the solidarity due to the affected populations, it is surprising that this solidarity is directed to Germany, a country which has accumulated a huge surplus in its balance of payments at the expense of other EU countries and who are asked to use this slack for a greater contribution from the consumption of the euro area.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — In May and June this year, the region of lower Bavaria was hit by a series of flash floods, it was a major natural disaster that affected tens of thousands of residents, and seven people even lost their lives. The floods also caused major property damage, primarily greatly damaging local agricultural firms, damaging local infrastructure including water and current supplies and even nearly destroying the town Simbach. I am very saddened by the fate of the people affected and I am pleased that the European Parliament has approved significant financial assistance to this stricken region, with a total of more than EUR 30 million, with The Bavarian authorities quantified the total damage at about €1.26 billion. On the other hand, I am pleased that the EU has at its disposal such an effective instrument as the Solidarity Fund, and that even in this particular case, the mobilisation of funds had wide support from all political factions.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which plans to use the EUSF to help Germany after the floods in Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016. This disaster has resulted in the death of many people and the destruction of infrastructure, housing and farms. It is essential that this aid be available as soon as possible to help the German population cope with the difficulties.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this binding budgetary report. The EU Solidarity Fund is an EU fund used when there has been a natural disaster in an area of Europe. This specific proposal is to give Germany EUR 31 457 125 for floods in lower Bavaria where there was material destruction and loss of life. Although UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money, as this is to do with a natural disaster we decided to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — With my vote I supported the mobilisation of EUR 31 475 125 from the EU Solidarity Fund to assist the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. The German authorities estimated the total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 26 billion.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Union Solidarity Fund for Germany, and more specifically Lower Bavaria, given the sudden and brutal floods that occurred in May and June 2016. This natural disaster affected more than 47,000 people, including many families who were unable to return to their homes. Indeed, the town of Simbach am Inn was almost completely destroyed and remained deprived of communal water supply for three weeks. The cost of urgent basic necessities is estimated by the German authorities at EUR 94.196 million and the total amount of aid proposed amounts to EUR 31 475,125. May German citizens turn the page of these tragic events as soon as possible.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I fully support the proposal to use the Solidarity Fund support for Germany. The principle of solidarity requires that this instrument be open to all those who need EU support in an emergency case, regardless of whether the country is a donor or recipient.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal for a report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in favour of Germany following the floods in the Lower Bavaria region in May and June of this year. This is a mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 31.475 million to deal with the total direct damage caused by the disaster, which is regarded as a 'regional disaster', in accordance with Article 2 (3) of the EUSF, in a region also classified as a 'more developed region' for the purposes of the European Structural and Investment Funds. Given the fact that this mobilisation complies with the legal criteria set out in the Regulation and complies with the annual ceiling applicable to the EUSF, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it involves the mobilisation of Union funds to help repair the damage caused by floods in Germany. During the months of May and June of this year, the German region of Niederbayern suffered heavy rains, resulting in numerous damage. The German Government has decided to request the aid of this Union solidarity fund for the reparation of the damage caused. This solidarity fund is designed for the rapid mobilization of resources in favour of areas damaged by any kind of disaster. This mobilization aims to help the inhabitants of the region to repair the damage caused and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of mobilising the EU solidarity fund to provide assistance to Germany. The total direct damage caused by the disaster was estimated at EUR 1.26 billion by the German authorities. Cases of flooding/flash floods caused destruction of public and private infrastructure, of private homes, and in agriculture.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Solidarity Fund established in 2002 (following the tragic floods in the EU) serves to express the EU's solidarity with countries affected by serious natural disasters. In May and June 2016, Germany was affected by floods. This natural disaster claimed seven human lives and more than 47,000 people from Lower Bavaria were affected, 2,000 of whom were unable to return to their homes even two months after its disappearance. The EU will help €31 475 125, which also requires a change to the 2016 budget. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the draft EP resolution on the proposal for a decision of the EP and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to provide assistance to Germany. In May and June this year, a series of extremely intense short-term floods affected the Lower Bavaria region. Following Germany's requests, an amount of EUR 31 475 125 is granted in commitment and payment appropriations to eliminate the consequences of floods. A series of particularly intense short-term floods and torrential floods have caused damage to public and private infrastructure, private dwellings and agriculture. The natural disaster claimed seven human lives and more than 47,000 people from Lower Bavaria were affected, 2000 of whom could not return to their homes even two months after the flooding. The town of Simbach am Inn was almost completely destroyed and was left without drinking water for three weeks. Indeed, there was serious damage, so the request from Germany was justified and the aid from the Solidarity Fund was agreed.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - This report addresses the decision of the Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany after the floods affecting Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016. Flooding has demolished public and private infrastructure and agricultural areas, with 7 people killed and a total of 47,000 people were affected. Some municipalities had no water supply for weeks, but they also had to face sewage failure and disruption to the power grid. The German authorities estimated total direct damage at around €1.2 billion, which significantly exceeds the 1.5% regional GDP threshold, so the accident can be considered a regional accident in accordance with the provisions of the EU Solidarity Fund Regulation. In this respect, the Commission proposes a total amount of aid of around EUR 31,5 million and the related amending budget No. 6/2016. This report welcomes the decision of Parliament and of the Council confirming the use of the Solidarity Fund funds to assist Germany. And since the Solidarity Fund is, in its essence, an instrument for rapid and effective emergency assistance, by which the European Union demonstrates solidarity with the population of affected areas, I supported it in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A series of extremely intense short-term floods and torrential floods have caused damage to public and private infrastructure, private dwellings and agriculture in Germany this year. In order to express solidarity with the affected region, it is appropriate to deal with the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to provide assistance to Germany in the form of commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. If there could be a meaningful function of the EU, then I would opt for supranational insurance against natural disasters. I therefore support the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund within the framework of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. This provides an amount of EUR 31 475 125 in payment appropriations for Germany in order to provide assistance to Germany within a short period of May and June 2016 due to exceptionally severe floodlands/flash floods in Lower Bavaria.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - This year the territory of Germany has been affected by natural disasters that have left disastrous consequences. The floods destroyed public and private infrastructure, agricultural areas and 7 human lives were lost. Following numerous cases of very strong short-term floods that hit Niederbayern in May and June 2016, Germany applied for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund on 19 August 2016. In these circumstances, it is important to demonstrate the support of the European Union and enable it to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to show solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters. I support the Draft Report as Germany's request qualifies for the grant of a financial contribution from the Fund, in accordance with Article 4. of Regulation (EC) No. 2012/2002.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. In May and June this year Germany was hit by a number of short-lived intense floods, so Germany submitted an application to use the Solidarity Fund. Germany will thus receive a good EUR 31 million in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. I voted for the report as Germany's role was complete and fully met the criteria for the application of the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU must show flexibility when there are grounds for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for financial assistance related to a natural disaster (floods in Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in Germany in May and June 2016. These brutal floods and floods have led to the destruction of public infrastructure, private infrastructure, individual dwellings and agricultural facilities. Seven people have lost their lives, more than 47,000 people living in Lower Bavaria have been affected and more than 2,000 are unable to return to their homes two months after the events. The town of Simbach am Inn was almost completely destroyed and remained deprived of communal water supply for three weeks. There have also been reports of significant damage to agricultural enterprises and facilities, as well as heavy damage to basic infrastructure, water supply, sanitation and electricity.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. I believe that the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund is necessary since 47,000 people were indirectly and/or directly affected and indirectly caused material damage, and 2000 people were unable to return to their homes 2 months after the floods. 7 people died. The German authorities must rehabilitate destroyed public and private infrastructure, and the European Union is obliged to provide financial assistance to Germany by respecting its own essential and meritory principles.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — Germany applied for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in August 2016 to repair damage caused by floods that hit Niederbayern region in May and June. The total proposed aid amount of €31 375 125 will repair direct damage caused by flooding, including the restoration of homes, public and private infrastructure and the agricultural sector. By activating the European Union Solidarity Fund, the European Union has repeatedly demonstrated its solidarity with the population affected by natural disasters. I believe that even in this case, marked as a regional disaster, the European Union should respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly. That is why I supported the Report on providing financial assistance to Germany in reparation of the damage caused.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. The purpose of the European Union Solidarity Fund ('the Fund') is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to demonstrate its solidarity with the population of areas affected by natural disasters. Germany was beset by intense short-term floods in May and June 2016, so it submitted an application to use the fund in August. Flooding has demolished public and private infrastructure, private homes and farmland. Seven people died and more than 47,000 people were affected in Lower Bavaria, with more than 2000 unable to return to homes for another two months after flooding. It is necessary to make a conclusion as quickly as possible so that people can be helped.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The aim is to mobilise 500 million to deal with the floods that occurred in 2016 in the Niederbayern region of Germany.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to grant financial assistance relating to a flood disaster in Germany. The European project is based also in solidarity in difficult moments and therefore I support this economic help to Lower Bavaria.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Solidarity Fund was established in 2002 to provide financial support for countries affected by major natural disasters or extraordinary disasters in particular regions. The proposal guarantees EUR 31,475,125 in commitments and the payment to cover the effects of severe flooding that caused damage to public and private infrastructure, homes and destruction in the agricultural sector. Damage accounts for 3.03% of regional GDP, which exceeds the threshold required to request aid under a “regional catastrophe.” I supported this resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance following the catastrophe in Germany in May and June 2016 (flooding in Lower Bavaria, in particular the Rottal-Inn region). I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The aim is to mobilise 500 million to deal with the floods that occurred in 2016 in the Niederbayern region of Germany.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — There have been a number of very large short-term and sudden floods, which have damaged public and private infrastructure, as well as private homes and have caused damage to the agricultural sector. In Lower Bavaria, seven people were killed, more than 47,000 people were affected, and two months after the floods, 2,000 people were not yet able to return to their homes. The city of Zimbach-on-Inn was almost completely destroyed and utilities were not provided for three weeks. In addition, very serious damage to enterprises and agriculture, basic infrastructure, water supply, sewerage and electricity networks has been reported.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany.
