The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, especially the district of Rottal-Inn) that occurred in May and June 2016. The series of extremely intense, short-lived cases of flooding/flash floods caused destruction of public and private infrastructure, of private homes, and in agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47 000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected. In their application, received by the Commission on 19 August 2016, the German authorities estimated total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 259.005 million. The total amount of aid proposed is therefore EUR 31 475 125 EUR.  I voted in favour because I believe that the application by Germany meets the conditions for providing a financial contribution from the Fund, as laid down in Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this action, the Union Solidarity Fund is mobilising to assist the Lower Bavaria area, especially the Rottal-Inn district, in the face of floods in May and June 2016. It is important for the Union to be able to respond to environmental disasters through this kind of action, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it involves the mobilisation of Union funds to help repair the damage caused by floods in Germany. During the months of May and June of this year, the German region of Niederbayern suffered heavy rains, resulting in numerous damage. The German Government has decided to request the aid of this Union solidarity fund for the reparation of the damage caused. This solidarity fund is designed for the rapid mobilization of resources in favour of areas damaged by any kind of disaster. This mobilization aims to help the inhabitants of the region to repair the damage caused and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide financial assistance for a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. The series of very intense short-lived floods/sudden flooding has left a trail of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47 000 were affected in Lower Bavaria; 2 000 of them were unable to return to their homes two months after the floods. Regardless of the solidarity due to the affected populations, it is surprising that this solidarity is directed to Germany, a country which has accumulated a huge surplus in its balance of payments at the expense of other EU countries and who are asked to use this slack for a greater contribution from the consumption of the euro area.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it concerns the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany for Germany due to the floods in the summer of Lower Bavaria in the summer of 2016.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Communities in my own constituency of the North-West of England are still recovering from the floods which hit them last winter, and still need support for reconstruction. EU Solidarity Funds would have provided welcome relief.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The Commission proposed mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in relation to a natural disaster in Germany during the months of May and June 2016. These phenomena caused the deaths of seven people and the involvement of nearly 50 000 people who suffered more or less direct damage. The German authorities estimated the total damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 259,005 million. The cost of the essential emergency operations eligible under the EUSF was therefore estimated at EUR 94,196 million, of which more than EUR 52,227 million for reconstruction operations in the field of transport and more than EUR 21 million cleaning measures. The figure to be obtained under EUSF aid is EUR 31 475 125, to be obtained through the approval of an amending budget which has been voted at the same time (Fernandes report, DAB 6). The ESF is for us Italians of particular importance at this time with reference to the issue of earthquakes in Central Italy. It's definitely a perfect tool, but at the moment it's the only one you have available. That's why I voted in favour of it.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the mobilisation of these funds because EU compensation for the financial consequences of the floods in Niederbayern in 2016 is not the EU's responsibility. National states may well decide for themselves when and for what amount they want to show solidarity with another State affected by a natural disaster.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for assistance to Germany. Germany applied in August this year to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to help remedy the damage caused by the widespread flooding in Lower Bavaria that affected the region in May and June this year. The floods caused damage mainly to infrastructure, homes, but also significantly affected the agricultural sector. Since the amount of damage caused has fulfilled the conditions for mobilising the Solidarity Fund, it is right that we have agreed to this mobilisation in plenary. I consider the Solidarity Fund to be an appropriate instrument to help Member States affected by natural disasters on the one hand and, on the other, demonstrates one of the main ideas of membership that the Member States are not alone, but the others will give them the necessary support if necessary.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the incentive to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. It is extremely important in situations where natural disasters occur, such as the case of floods in Germany, to help local people as soon as possible in order to repair the damage caused to homes and public and private goods as easily as possible. A large number of people in the area of Lower Bavaria have been affected by flooding, and a number of them have not returned to their homes after three weeks, which is a worrying fact. European Union solidarity and assistance to affected parts of Germany is needed because it is a prerequisite for ensuring that damage caused by natural disaster will be remedied. In addition to the importance of restoring the homes of local residents as urgently as possible, special attention should be paid to the restoration of infrastructure and agricultural land and all resources necessary for the normal life of people in the area.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. I support that the European Union Solidarity Fund allocates an amount of EUR 31 475 125 to Germany for assistance after a number of cases of short-term, extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern region in May and June 2016.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The file concerns the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund in favour of a region of Germany affected by the very strong floods that have caused disastrous damage, especially to agriculture. That's the motivation that prompted me to cast an upvote.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought for an increase in the social fund in instances where a natural disaster has taken place and has adversely affected the economy. Given that natural disasters can adversely affect the economies of any Member State, it is important that the EU shows solidarity to those people affected and helps them to stabilise in the aftermath of tragic circumstances. Therefore, I supported it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget (ACB) No 6 for the financial year 2016 covers assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country which thrives on the backs of its southern neighbours thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need. I abstained on this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I abstained upon the principle of the Solidarity Fund being used to the benefit of Germany, I cannot do the same on the proposed increase to the budget ceiling for the Solidarity Fund, which would increase the ceiling by over EUR 31 million. Consequently, whilst I might well abstain on the mobilisation of existing and available finance, it is consistent for me to vote against a proposed increase to it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on Draft amending budget No 6 of the European Union for the financial year 2016, accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. Draft amending budget No 6 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016, the Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget by increasing the budget item No. 13 06 01 'Aid to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster where living conditions, the natural environment or the economy' means EUR 31 475 125, both in commitment and in payment appropriations.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this text, because I believe that Germany could perhaps make greater use of its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it frankly does not need.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget No 6/2016 concerns the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund related to the floods that took place in Germany in May and June 2016. I approved this point.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Amendment which mobilizes the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany, due to the 2016 floods in the Lower Bavaria region, which hurt its population by a total of EUR 31,475 125.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on draft amending budget No 6/2016 on the annex to the proposal to mobilise the Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany. The Solidarity Fund is a special instrument as defined in the MFF Regulation and that the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations are entered in the budget outside the ceilings established in the MFF.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In line with the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Germany, this report concerns a draft amending budget for the financial year 2016 to cover the release of this EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. I obviously support the Germans affected by the floods in Lower Bavaria (in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. However, as I pointed out earlier, it seems to me that Germany should not be a priority for obtaining this aid. Our neighbour has, at his disposal, about EUR 12 billion in budgetary surpluses and public accounts with a surplus of about 16.4 billion. Given the tremendous economic dynamism of Germany, there is no doubt that this country will be able to cope with the consequences of the natural disasters this summer. I therefore preferred to abstain on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — Between May and June, the regions of Lower Bavaria were affected by violent flooding. With this vote, I support the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for EUR 31,475,125 to be allocated to the reconstruction and support of the affected populations. I believe that the Solidarity Fund continues to be an important instrument of support which Europe makes available to Member States affected by serious natural disasters, although I hope that It is able to make its activation faster and faster, because this will greatly increase its effectiveness.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - With my vote I supported this amending budget No 6/20016, to enable the mobilisation of EUR 31 475 125 from the Union Solidarity Fund to assist the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. German authorities estimated total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 26 billion

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which examines draft amending budget No 6/2016 covering the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in connection with the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission therefore proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase the budget 'Aid to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster where living conditions, the natural environment or the economy' are particularly affected. As defined in the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Regulation for 2014-2020, the European Union Solidarity Fund is a specific instrument and the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations are to be entered in the budget above the MFF ceilings.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the said draft amending budget, as the result of the proposed application of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to floods in Germany in May and June 2016.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this Report. The Commission proposes to mobilise €31 475 125 to help the German province of Lower Bavaria due to the May and June 2016 floods. The total direct damage estimated by the German authorities is €1.26 billion. The proposal is related to the proposal for amendments to the budget 6/2016.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: I am, of course, in favour of the release of these solidarity funds to compensate for the damage caused by floods in Germany, but I cannot help but think that the German government could have used its own budget surpluses to deal with this crisis, rather than appealing to European solidarity, as much as Germany's economic health derives largely from the single currency to the detriment of other euro area countries. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Between May and June 2016 some regions of Germany — particularly Bavaria — were affected by heavy rains, floods and landslides. These events caused extensive damage to public infrastructure (schools, dams, telecommunications networks and roads), housing and private activities (hundreds of buildings were flooded), as well as damage to the agricultural sector and forests resulting from mud deposits, landslides and landslides. The exceptionality and seriousness of the situation necessitated the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Parliament must approve the mobilisation of the Fund for the allocation of the amounts provided by the Commission as an emergency contribution to the affected regions, in the shortest possible time, as quickly as possible the institutional response to a flood intervention is essential for the resumption of economic activities and the normal conduct of the daily activities of citizens.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the call for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to make a financial contribution to Germany. Following the intense floods in May and June 2016, which destroyed infrastructure and housing, causing damage to agriculture, Germany had applied for provision of a financial contribution from the fund. I think the Commission's proposal is appropriate to provide aid to Member States affected by disasters affecting social, environmental and economic conditions. As the Solidarity Fund is a special instrument, according to the definition of the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation (MFF), the corresponding appropriations should be entered in the budget outside of the MFF ceilings.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This amending budget is taken in conjunction with a separate vote regarding Germany’s application for the EU Solidarity Fund. The EU Solidarity Fund is an EU fund used when there has been a natural disaster in an area of Europe. In order to give the money to Germany it is required to increase the budget ceiling for the Solidarity Fund. As this will increase EU budgets (as opposed to just authorising money that is already available) UKIP voted against.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany confirms the the Fund's role, since it aims to provide assistance after the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with the consent to the mobilization of the solidarity fund for Germany for the floods it suffered in Lower Bavaria in the past months of May and June, outside my favour to Draft amending budget No 6/2016. Thus, therefore, it will be possible to strengthen the Community budget under Article 13 06 01 “Assisting Member States affected by serious natural disasters with serious effects on conditions living, environmental or economy” amounting to EUR 31 475 125 in commitment and payment appropriations. The amount in question represents the figure mobilised by the Union Solidarity Fund, the annual ceiling of which is EUR 500 million.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Council position on Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Germany requested on 19 August 2016 the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund following a series of extremely intense, short-lived flooding cases affecting the Lower Bavaria region in May and June 2016 and which left a trail of destruction in the region of Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016. public and private infrastructure in housing and agriculture, with 7 people lost their lives and more than 47000 were affected. The proposed mobilisation requires the amendment of the 2016 budget, aimed at increasing Article 13 06 01 of the budget 'assistance to Member States in the event of major natural disasters with serious repercussions on living conditions, the environment and the economy'. The Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget by strengthening budget article 13 06 01 in the amount of 31 475 125 Euros, both in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations, to cover the losses suffered by Germany. This report, which I support, adopts the Council's position on amending budget No 6/2016.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergency situations and to witness solidarity to the population of the regions affected by disasters. I voted in favour of this measure granting financial assistance to Germany for the floods that hit Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to floods that occurred in Germany in May and June 2016. These had serious repercussions for the living conditions of those concerned and we are duty bound to give the devoted attention and quickly.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the Draft Amending Budget No 6 to the General Budget 2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany as it seeks to amend the 2016 budget and increase the assistance to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious repercussions.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This report constitutes one of the amending budgetary reports for 2016. It supports the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Germany, which suffered flooding in Lower Bavaria, in particular the Rottal-Inn district, in May and June 2016. This natural disaster affected more than 47,000 people. In this context, the EUSF mobilization for Germany amounts to 34 million euros. Considering the seriousness of the German situation following these floods and considering the European Union's duty to provide relief to European territories in distress following natural disasters, I have of course voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This amending budget is taken in conjunction with a separate vote regarding Germany’s application for the EU Solidarity Fund. The EU Solidarity Fund is an EU fund used when there has been a natural disaster in an area of Europe. In order to give the money to Germany it is required to increase the budget ceiling for the Solidarity Fund. As this will increase EU budgets (as opposed to just authorising money that is already available) UKIP voted against.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — Having voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to assist German flood-affected territories in May and June 2016, I also supported draft amending budget (ACB) No 6/2016, which aims to include this expenditure in the Union budget. The rules on the use of the EUSF require that its mobilisation be reflected in the Union's annual budget. Assistance to the affected regions is a priority, so is its budgeting as well.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. In this context, the European Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase its commitment and payment appropriations by EUR 31 475 125. The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. As mentioned earlier, we are generally in favour of intra-European solidarity. As far as Germany is concerned, however, we believe that Germany must be able to cope with flood expenditure alone, given the profits it derives from its participation in the European Union and, in particular, in the euro.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. -I voted for this report. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EFF) was established in 2002 to provide financial assistance to eligible countries affected by major natural disasters or exceptional regional disasters. This second proposal to mobilise the EFF in 2016 concerns flooding in Germany's Niederbayern region. The proposal is to provide assistance to the region that has been badly hit. Commitments are to cover the effects of severe flash floods that have led to the destruction of public and private infrastructure, people's homes and extinctions in the agricultural sector. The damage represented 3.03 percent of the region's GDP, exceeding the threshold needed to declare a “regional disaster.” The devastating impact on the region meets all the criteria of the EFF, and therefore the only possible solution is to support the efforts.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU must show flexibility when there are grounds for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. In this context, the European Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase its commitment and payment appropriations by EUR 31 475 125. The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstention: Draft amending budget (ACB) No 6 for the financial year 2016 covers assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on draft amending budget (PBR) No 6/2016 as it allows the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for financial assistance from countries affected by severe natural disasters. In particular, the project is an answer to the problems arose as a result of floods in Germany's Lower Bavaria region.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In this case, it is a technical change based on the granting of aid to Germany, which copes with the consequences of a series of floods in Bavaria. The European Commission has proposed to amend the budget and increase resources to help Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious consequences on living conditions, the natural environment or the economy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report because I support the need to allocate a share of the European Union Solidarity Fund, EUSF, to the German citizens of Lower Bavaria affected by the May/June this year by violent flooding.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of Draft amending budget No 6/2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund to assist Germany, as the EU must show flexibility when there are grounds for compensation for countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 6/2016 is linked to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide assistance to Germany. The EUSF mobilisation relates to floods in Germany (Lower Bavaria) and would amount to EUR 31 475 125 in commitment and payment appropriations. I supported the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund for Germany.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)

The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.
