The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to grant financial assistance in connection with the floods in Lower Bavaria, which occurred in May and June 2016.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016 accompanying the proposal for mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. I am supporting the aid proposal which favours budgeting outside the corresponding multiannual financial framework (MFF) ceiling regulation of expenditure (0.6% of GNI or EUR 3 billion). I also support the notion in the 2016 budget of increasing assistance to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious repercussions on living conditions, the natural environment or the economy, both in commitment and in payment appropriations.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The aim is to mobilise 500 million to deal with the floods that occurred in 2016 in the Niederbayern region of Germany.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016 linked to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide assistance to Germany.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. In this context, the European Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase its commitment and payment appropriations by EUR 31 475 125. The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission’s proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, especially the district of Rottal-Inn) that occurred in May and June 2016. The series of extremely intense, short-lived cases of flooding/flash floods caused destruction of public and private infrastructure, of private homes, and in agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47 000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected, with over 2 000 unable to return to their houses two months after the floods. The town of Simbach am Inn was almost entirely destroyed and was left with no municipal water supply for three weeks. Significant damage to businesses and agriculture was also reported, as well as heavy damage to the basic infrastructure, water supply, sewage services and electricity network. In their application, received by the Commission on 19 August 2016, the German authorities estimated total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 259.005 million.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The sixth amending budget for the current financial year is requesting an additional EUR 31.5 million to deal with flood costs in Lower Bavaria in spring 2016, financed by the so-called European Solidarity Fund. The total cost of this flood disaster is estimated by the German Government at EUR 1.26 billion. From my point of view, it goes without saying that the EU Member States show solidarity, as in similar cases. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of a proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position on draft amending budget No. 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 with a proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. This would help Germany after the floods that hit the country in May and June 2016. When it comes to natural or other disasters that cause serious damage and exceptional difficulties, I consider it necessary to respond as quickly and efficiently as possible to mitigate the negative consequences. I support raising the budget item by €31 475 125, and this draft amending budget.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: It is quite unusual to see Germany affected by a mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Indeed, the State keeps the heads of its neighbours under the waves of the single currency and takes advantage of its advantageous position on the surface. It would then be fair for it to draw on its resources fed by budgetary surpluses and low borrowing rates to meet the needs it can meet without the unnecessary aid of European solidarity. I abstained.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this amending budget, which accompanies the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund amounting to EUR 31 million to grant financial aid to Germany due to the floods in Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016. The latter have led to the destruction of public and private infrastructure, private housing and agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47,000 people in Lower Bavaria were affected.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The sixth amending budget for the current financial year is requesting an additional EUR 31.5 million to deal with flood costs in Lower Bavaria in spring 2016, financed by the so-called European Solidarity Fund. The total cost of this flood disaster is estimated by the German Government at EUR 1.26 billion. From my point of view, it goes without saying that the EU Member States show solidarity, as in similar cases. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. In this context, the European Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase its commitment and payment appropriations by EUR 31 475 125. The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. — Although there is usually no problem with this kind of mobilization of the solidarity fund for the unemployed, I abstained this time because, in this case, Germany is concerned. However, it is a country that thrives on the backs of its neighbours to the south thanks to the single currency and thus ruins all their industry. Germany should use its budget surpluses to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need and in which it itself participates very sparingly. Nevertheless, I am not going so far as to vote against this report, out of respect for our German AfD allies.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Amending Budget No 6/2016, because it is linked to the mobilisation of the Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany, in particular the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to assist the region of Lower Bavaria affected by flooding in 2016.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Draft budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the floods that hit Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission therefore proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase budget item 13 06 01 Assistance to Member States in the event of large-scale natural disasters with severe consequences for living conditions, the natural environment or the economy by EUR 31 475 125 in commitment appropriations and approved funds for payment. Since the European Union Solidarity Fund is a special instrument and that appropriate appropriations for commitments and payments should be entered in the budget above the MFF ceilings, I supported this report on draft amending budget No. 6/2016.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the Council's position on Draft amending budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany; because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report. This text provides for a change in the budget and aims to cover the assistance of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for an amount of almost €31.5 million. This demand causes our reservations, since it concerns Germany, a country that thrives on the backs of its neighbours to the south. Although we have feelings of sympathy for the German citizens who have suffered as a result of the floods, we believe that the German government could find resources in its own budget to address these kinds of problems, rather than looking for them at the expense of the common budget.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted positively on Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. Back in May and June of the present year, floods impacted Lower Bavaria and, more specifically, the district of Rottal-Inn, affecting more than 47 000 people. Therefore, amending the aforementioned budget represents an increase in the total amount in order to be able to assist fellow Member States.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), itself dealing with floods in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case, as surprising as it may seem, Germany is concerned here, whereas everyone knows that it is the country which benefits almost exclusively from the single currency. Germany could obviously avoid appealing to European solidarity. I therefore abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) This draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in respect of floods in Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission therefore proposes to amend the 2016 budget by strengthening budget article 13 06 01 'Assistance to Member States in the event of major natural disasters with serious repercussions on living conditions, the environment or the economy' for an amount of EUR 31 475 125, both in commitment appropriations, as in payment appropriations. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it ensures the disbursement of funds to Germany to deal with the ramifications of severe flooding that affected Lower Bavaria last spring.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 6/2016 concerns the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund related to the floods that took place in Germany in May and June 2016. In response to this series of major natural disasters, the Commission has proposed to amend the 2016 budget for assistance to Member States in the event of natural disasters that have a serious impact on living conditions, the natural environment and the economy. The amount now amounts to EUR 31.475.125, both in commitment appropriations and in payment appropriations. On that occasion, the European Parliament decided to endorse as is the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations in order to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by natural disasters. The proposed mobilisation requires an amendment to the 2016 budget and a draft amending budget (No 6/2016), aiming at increasing budget article 13 06 01 ‘Assistance to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious repercussions on living conditions, the natural environment or the economy’ by EUR 31 475 125 both in commitment and in payment appropriations. Therefore, I have voted in favour of the report, which proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, especially the district of Rottal-Inn) which occurred in May and June 2016.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — On 19 October 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for support to Germany. To cover this, it adopted at the same time Draft amending budget No 6/2016, which concerns amending the 2016 budget and increasing both commitment and payment appropriations for budget item 13 06 01 by EUR 31 475 125. The Council adopted its position on the draft on 21 November 2016 and forwarded it to the European Parliament. The Committee on Budgets notes in its report that Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016 and therefore proposes that Parliament approves the 6/ The Council's position on Draft amending budget 2016 and thus definitively adopts the amendment. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text deals with the intervention of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country which thrives on the backs of its southern neighbours thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in respect of floods in Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission therefore proposes to amend the 2016 budget by strengthening budget article 13 06 01 'Assistance to Member States in the event of major natural disasters with serious repercussions on living conditions, the environment or the economy' for an amount of EUR 31 475 125, both in commitment appropriations, as in payment appropriations. The EUSF aims to provide a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of disaster-affected regions. It is a special instrument as defined in the MFF Regulation and the corresponding appropriations should be budgeted beyond the limits MFF maximums.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget (ACB) No 6 for the financial year 2016 covers assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country which thrives on the backs of its southern neighbours thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this amending budget 6/2016 on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Germany. It is proposed to mobilize €31.475 million to help Bavaria, which was faced with major floods in May and June 2016.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report amending Draft Budget No 6/2016 that will increase the budget of the European Union Solidarity Fund by EUR 31 475 125 following the floods in lower Bavaria that occurred in Germany between May and June 2016.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought for an increase in the social fund in instances where a natural disaster has taken place and has adversely affected the economy. Given that natural disasters can adversely affect the economies of any Member State, it is important that the EU shows solidarity to those people affected and helps them to stabilise in the aftermath of tragic circumstances. Therefore, I supported it.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — This is about increasing the number of authorised funds for flood victims in Germany. I voted in favour of an increase in funding in this case.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Germany's Lower Bavaria region has been hit by very heavy floods, with money allocated from the Solidarity Fund helping the region cope with the consequences.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Whereas Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. Bearing in mind that the Commission is therefore proposing to amend the 2016 budget and increase the appropriations under Article 13 06 01 of the budget “Assistance to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious implications for living conditions, natural the environment or the economy” by EUR 31 475 125, both in commitment and payment appropriations, as well as that the European Union Solidarity Fund is a specific instrument as defined in the MFF Regulation and that the corresponding appropriations should be entered in the budget above and beyond the ceilings, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the approval, adoption and publication in the Official Journal of the European Union of draft amending budget No 6/2016 linked to the position of the Council accompanying the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to provide assistance to Germany, as I agree with the need to strengthen Article 13 06 01 “Assisting the States members affected by serious natural disasters... 'amounting to EUR 31 475 125 in both commitment and payment appropriations. Therefore, I voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Draft budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the floods that hit Germany in May and June 2016, therefore it proposes to increase budget item 13 06 01 Assistance to Member States in the event of large natural disasters scale with severe consequences for living conditions, natural environment or economy for EUR 31 475 125 in appropriations for commitment and appropriations for payment, which is the amount of aid granted by mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for Germany. The European Union Solidarity Fund is a special instrument as set out in the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation (MFF), which sets an upper limit of EUR 500 million on an annual basis. The rules also provide for the financing of the difference if the need arises. As the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund has been approved to provide assistance to Germany in which a regional disaster has been identified, I support that the budget item is increased by the amount of aid granted.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget (ACB) No 6 for the financial year 2016 covers assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), amounting to EUR 31.475.125 in commitment and payment appropriations. This intervention concerns flooding in Germany. Although usually there is no problem with this type of fundraising, it should be noted that in this case Germany is concerned here, a country which thrives on the backs of its southern neighbours thanks to the single currency and thus aspires all their industry. Perhaps Germany could use its budget surpluses and exceptionally low borrowing rates to address these kinds of problems, rather than calling for European solidarity which it does not frankly need. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The Commission proposed amending the 2016 budget and increasing budget item 13 06 01 Assistance to Member States in the event of large-scale natural disasters with severe consequences for living conditions, the natural environment or the economy by EUR 31 475 125 in appropriations for takeover liabilities and approved means for payment. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 is related to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. The Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016 is therefore accepted.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in respect of floods in Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission therefore proposes to amend the 2016 budget by strengthening budget article 13 06 01 'Assistance to Member States in the event of major natural disasters with serious repercussions on living conditions, the environment or the economy' for an amount of EUR 31 475 125, both in commitment appropriations, as in payment appropriations. The European Union Solidarity Fund is a special instrument, as defined in the MFF Regulation, and the corresponding appropriations should be budgeted beyond the MFF ceilings.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Solidarity Fund (EFSEU) was established in 2002 to provide financial support for countries affected by major natural disasters or extraordinary disasters in particular regions. This is the second proposal for the EFSEU in 2016 and it relates to flooding in Lower Bavaria, Germany. The proposal guarantees EUR 31,475,125 in commitments and the payment to cover the effects of severe flooding that caused damage to public and private infrastructure, homes and destruction in the agricultural sector. Damage accounts for 3.03% of regional GDP, exceeding the threshold required for inference under a “regional catastrophe.” The preliminary draft amending budget No 6 provides funding for this proposal. Given the serious impact on the situation in the region, I supported the proposal.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — As a follow-up to the report on the mobilisation of the EUSF to help Germany, which I supported, I voted in favour of this text, which aims to amend the 2016 budget by including the proposal to mobilize the EUSF. I would point out that this aid is essential for Germany to deal with the damage caused by the devastating floods of May and June 2016.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This amending budget is taken in conjunction with a separate vote regarding Germany’s application for the EU Solidarity Fund. The EU Solidarity Fund is an EU fund used when there has been a natural disaster in an area of Europe. In order to give the money to Germany it is required to increase the budget ceiling for the Solidarity Fund. As this will increase EU budgets (as opposed to just authorising money that is already available) UKIP voted against.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — With my vote I supported this amending budget to enable EUR 31 475 125 to be mobilised from the EU Solidarity Fund to assist the German region of Lower Bavaria, affected by floods in May and June 2016. The German authorities estimated the total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1 26 billion.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budgets No 4, 5 and 6 of the European Union for the financial year 2016. Amending budget No 4 concerns the updating of appropriations to take account of recent developments in the field of migration and security, the reduction of payment and commitment appropriations resulting from the global transfer, the extension of the life of the European Fund for Strategic Investments , the modification of Frontex's staffing table and the updating of revenue appropriations. Amending budget No 5 concerns the implementation of Decision 2014/335/EU on the system of own resources following the closure of the ratification process and the entry into force of the Decision on 1 October 2016. Finally, amending budget No 6 concerns the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I fully support the proposal to use the Solidarity Fund support for Germany. The principle of solidarity requires that this instrument be open to anyone who needs EU support in an emergency situation, regardless of whether the country is a donor or recipient.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This draft amending budget accompanies the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to assist Germany and, taking into account the amount that has been allocated to this end, it was also necessary to approve the draft amending budget covering the mobilisation of the fund, totalling €31.475 million, both in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. This proposal needs an amendment to the 2016 budget by strengthening the budget article intended to assist Member States in the event of major natural disasters, with serious repercussions on living conditions, the environment or the economy, such as serious floods occurred in Germany in May and June of this year. In view of the fact that this budget amendment meets the legal criteria, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it rectifies the Union budget to allow the mobilisation of Union funds to help repair the damage caused by floods in Germany. During the months of May and June of this year, the German region of Niederbayern suffered heavy rains and caused numerous damage. The German Government has decided to request the aid of this Union solidarity fund for the reparation of the damage caused. This solidarity fund is designed for the rapid mobilization of resources in favour of areas damaged by any kind of disaster. That is why this mobilisation aims to help the inhabitants of the region to repair the damage caused by what I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of Draft amending budget No 6/2016 linked to the Mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide assistance to Germany.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to be able to provide financial resources from the Solidarity Fund for the region of Lower Bavaria affected by the devastating floods in May and June this year, it was necessary to approve the EP Resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No. 6/2016 EU for financial year 2016. Having become acquainted with the fact of the damage caused by the floods, we supported the motion for a resolution. The draft amending budget includes the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The Commission has proposed to amend the 2016 budget and increase the appropriations to assist Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious consequences for living conditions, the environment or the economy by EUR 31 475 125 in both commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - Proposal for amending budget No 6/2016 provides the basis for implementing the proposed application of the European Union Solidarity Fund on floods in Germany in May and June 2016. In this proposal, the Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget by increasing the commitment appropriations and payment appropriations in the field of aid to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster which has serious consequences for living conditions, the natural environment or the economy by a good 31 million EUR. In this regard, the Parliament's report stresses that the European Union Solidarity Fund is a specific instrument and therefore adequate commitments and payments should be included in the budget without taking into account the relevant ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. As the report welcomes the Commission's proposal to amend the 2016 budget, I supported it in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - The sixth amending budget for the current financial year is requesting an additional EUR 31.5 million to deal with flood costs in Lower Bavaria in spring 2016, financed by the so-called European Solidarity Fund. The total cost of this flood disaster is estimated by the German Government at EUR 1.26 billion. From my point of view, it goes without saying that the EU Member States show solidarity, as in similar cases. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending budget No 6/2016 includes the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in connection with the floods that occurred in Germany in May and June 2016, and it is therefore necessary to address this matter at the European Parliament.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not endorse the European Parliament resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 on the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. The Solidarity Fund acts as a supranational insurance against natural disasters and I welcome it and disbursements from it in principle. However, there is no need to upgrade the fund above plan. Once the fund is exhausted, it will not be able to make any withdrawals.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — Draft budget No 6/2016 covers the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the floods that hit Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission proposes to amend the budget for 2016 and increase budget item 13 06 01 Assistance to Member States in the event of large-scale natural disasters with severe consequences for living conditions, the natural environment or the economy by EUR 31,475.125,00 in commitment appropriations; and approved funds for payment. The European Union Solidarity Fund constitutes a special instrument as set out in the MFF Regulation and that the corresponding appropriations for commitments and payments should be entered into the budget above the MFF ceilings. I support the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No. 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016, with a proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. I believe that solidarity is one of the fundamental values of the European Union, and for this reason, a way and means should be found in order to provide maximum assistance to any Member State in distress.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016, accompanying the proposal for the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund funds to provide assistance to Germany. Since Germany was hit by a number of short-term intense floods this May and June, only the latter submitted an application to receive funding from the European Union Solidarity Fund, thus becoming eligible for a good €31 million. I support the Commission's proposal to amend the 2016 budget and the commitment appropriations and payment appropriations in the budgetary article.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU must show flexibility when there are grounds for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Germany submitted an application on 19 August 2016 to mobilise the Fund due to a number of short-term but extremely intense floods affecting the Niederbayern (Lower Bavaria) region in May and June 2016. Germany's request fulfils the requirements laid down for determining the financial contribution from the Fund. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the sum of EUR 31 475 125 shall be paid to Germany in commitment and payment appropriations. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Germany in May and June 2016. In this context, the European Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase its commitment and payment appropriations by EUR 31 475 125. The European Parliament approved the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2016. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to floods that occurred in Germany in May and June 2016.  This is under the European Union Solidarity Fund which is a special instrument as defined in the MFF Regulation, and the corresponding commitment and payments appropriations are to be budgeted over and above the MFF ceilings. I therefore support the decision of the Commission to amend the 2016 budget and increase the budget article 13 06 01 ‘Assistance to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious repercussions on living conditions, the natural environment or the economy.’

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to amend the 2016 budget by reinforcing Article 13 06 01 'Assistance to Member States in the event of major natural disasters having a serious impact on living conditions, the natural environment and the economy' in the amount of EUR 31 475,125, both in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. The European Union Solidarity Fund is a special instrument defined in the MFF Regulation, and the commitment and payment appropriations in question must be entered in the budget beyond the MFF ceilings. We therefore voted positively.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the Council position on draft amending budget No. 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 with a proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. Since the European Union is obliged to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in the event of disasters, and since the European Union catastrophe has struck Bavaria, I consider it necessary to make an amendment to the budget in order to implement the Solidarity Fund mobilisation procedure envisaged Proposal for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the floods that hit Germany in May and June 2016. The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up in 2002 to provide financial assistance to states affected by large-scale natural disasters or extraordinary regional disasters. In recent years, several European Union member states have been affected by natural disasters - from Croatia facing flooding in 2014, this year's earthquakes in Italy and now Germany, which were hit by floods. It is evident from these experiences that a quick and appropriate reaction is very important in order to show solidarity with citizens. I consider that amending the 2016 budget to help Member States in the event of major natural disasters in this situation is essential to help that Member State rebuild homes, public and private infrastructure and the affected agricultural sector. That's why I supported this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position on draft amending budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 accompanying the proposal for the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund funds to provide assistance to Germany.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The aim is to mobilise 500 million to deal with the floods that occurred in 2016 in the Niederbayern region of Germany.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to grant financial assistance relating to a flood disaster in Germany. The European project is based also in solidarity in difficult moments and therefore I support to this draft amendment of the 2016 budget.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Solidarity Fund was established in 2002 to provide financial support for countries affected by major natural disasters or extraordinary disasters in particular regions. The proposal guarantees EUR 31,475,125 in commitments and the payment to cover the effects of severe flooding that caused damage to public and private infrastructure, homes and destruction in the agricultural sector. Damage accounts for 3.03% of regional GDP, exceeding the threshold required for inference under a “regional catastrophe.” I supported the resolution in full.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund is a special instrument set out in the MFF Regulation and the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations should be entered in the budget above the ceilings of the MFF. I followed the S&D position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this Amendment which mobilizes the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Germany, due to the 2016 floods in the Lower Bavaria region, which hurt its population by a total of EUR 31,475 125.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on Draft Amending Budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 accompanying the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. Draft amending budget No 6/2016 covers the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to floods that occurred in Germany in May and June 2016. The Commission consequently proposes to amend the 2016 budget and increase the budget article 13 06 01 ‘Assistance to Member States in the event of a major natural disaster with serious repercussions on living conditions, the natural environment or the economy’ by EUR 31 475 125 both in commitment and in payment appropriations. The European Union Solidarity Fund is a special instrument as defined in the MFF Regulation, and the corresponding commitment and payments appropriations are to be budgeted over and above the MFF ceilings. I voted in favour because I believe that the application by Germany meets the conditions for providing a financial contribution from the Fund, as laid down in Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this action, the Union Solidarity Fund is mobilising to assist the Lower Bavaria area, especially the Rottal-Inn district, in the face of floods in May and June 2016. It is important for the Union to be able to respond to environmental disasters through this kind of action, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it rectifies the Union budget to allow the mobilisation of Union funds to help repair the damage caused by floods in Germany. During the months of May and June of this year, the German region of Niederbayern suffered heavy rains and caused numerous damage. The German Government has decided to request the aid of this Union solidarity fund for the reparation of the damage caused. This solidarity fund is designed for the rapid mobilization of resources in favour of areas damaged by any kind of disaster. That is why this mobilisation aims to help the inhabitants of the region to repair the damage caused by what I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide financial assistance for a disaster in Germany (floods affecting Lower Bavaria, in particular the district of Rottal-Inn) in May and June 2016. The series of very intense short-lived floods/sudden flooding has left a trail of destruction in public and private infrastructure, housing and agriculture. Seven people lost their lives and more than 47 000 were affected in Lower Bavaria; 2 000 of them were unable to return to their homes two months after the floods. Regardless of the solidarity due to the affected populations, it is surprising that this solidarity is directed to Germany, a country which has accumulated a huge surplus in its balance of payments at the expense of other EU countries and who are asked to use this slack for a greater contribution from the consumption of the euro area.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - As this report is about increasing the eligible funds to provide aid to flood victims in Germany due to the flooding disaster in Lower Bavaria in the summer of 2016, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. The Commission proposes to mobilize the EU Solidarity Fund to provide financial assistance in relation to the floods that hit Lower Bavaria in May and June 2016 causing a total damage estimated at 1.26 billion euros. As has already been the case in the past, the Commission proposes to apply the rate of 2.5% of the total direct damage amount for all damages up to the threshold for 'major catastrophe. ' The total amount of the proposed aid is therefore EUR 31,475,125. The proposed mobilization requires an amendment to the 2016 budget and a draft amending budget.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Draft amending budget (PBR) No 6 for the financial year 2016 concerns the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in the amount of 31,475,125 euros in commitment and payment appropriations to Germany. In May and June 2016, in fact, the administrative district of Rottal-Inn, in Lower Bavaria, was affected by a series of sudden floods, extremely intense and short-lived, which have destroyed public and private infrastructure, as well as many housing, causing extensive damage also to agriculture. Since total direct damages are below the “serious catastrophe” threshold for the activation of the Solidarity Fund, the application was submitted and examined on the basis of the so-called criterion” regional catastrophe”. This correction is necessary for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund, which is an instrument other than the ordinary budgetary framework. Although I have different reservations, I always support approval for the request for these funds, also because of the fact that, unfortunately, due to the many disasters, Italy is one of the biggest beneficiaries since establishment of this Fund.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the mobilisation of these funds because EU compensation for the financial consequences of the floods in Niederbayern in 2016 is not the EU's responsibility. National states may well decide for themselves when and for what amount they want to show solidarity with another State affected by a natural disaster.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported draft amending budget No 6/2016 for the financial year 2016, tabled together with the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for assistance to Germany. The proposal was tabled in connection with the floods that hit Germany in May and June this year. Since these floods have caused major damage, Germany has requested the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund. I think that the Solidarity Fund and its purpose must be strongly supported. We must not allow a state that has been affected by natural disasters of this magnitude to have to fight the consequences alone. That is why I consider the Solidarity Fund a very good way to show that the Member States hold together in such cases.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - In line with the Commission's proposals to amend the budget and increase the budget item Assistance to Member States in the event of large-scale natural disasters with severe consequences for living conditions, the natural environment or the economy, I support this report. Since the above draft budget No. 6/2016 includes the proposed mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, which is a special instrument of the European Union, I consider it extremely important to adopt this report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 6/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016, accompanying the proposal for the use of funds of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Germany. Proposal for amending budget No 6/2016 covers the application of the European Union Solidarity Fund in respect of floods in Germany in May and June 2016. I support the use of funding from the Solidarity Fund as it is intended to help Germany because of the short-term, extremely intense floods that hit Niederbayern in May and June 2016 and have caused serious consequences for living conditions, the natural environment and the economy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The Regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF) provides for a residual instrument - the margin for contingencies, which may be up to 0, 03% of EU-28 gross national income - as an extreme ratio to cope with unforeseen circumstances, if all other options available within the MFF have been exhausted. In order to respond to the increase in the required requirements following the migration, refugee and security crisis, it was determined to increase the commitment appropriations under headings 3 and 4 of the MFF in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 beyond the limits of the ceilings set for those headings. While aware of the need for such increases in sectors that are under particular pressure at the moment, it must be remembered, however, that the use of margin for unforeseen is only one buffer solution, which does not solve the problems at the root, nor does it address the real need to rationalise the EU budget by placing emphasis on real priorities such as these. For those reasons I abstained.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The contingency margins may have a positive element with regard to allocating aid which would assist migrants and refugees; however, one must also take into account that this also includes the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, and support for the likes of Frontex. This is because these margins are for Heading 3 ‘Security and citizenship’. For 2017 this also includes Heading 4 ‘Global Europe’ which covers programmes such as the Common Security and Defence Policy, the Guarantee Fund for external Actions, and ‘Macro-financial assistance’. It was proposed originally by the European Parliament to also use the Contingency margins for 2016 and 2017 for sustaining certain programmes which would fall under Heading 1 of the multi-annual financial framework for programmes that are progressive and socially orientated. However the Council did not budge and dictated that, under that Heading, funds would have to be redeployed instead, which would mean cutting such programmes to fund another similar programme under that heading, as opposed to using the Contingency Margin which would entail not having to resort to sacrificing one programme over another.  As a result I abstained on the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure under Heading 3 'Security and Citizenship', amounting to €2.578 billion and heading 4 'Europe in the world' to the tune of €9.432 billion. It is therefore a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This budgetary instrument lies outside the normal ceilings for EU spending, and therefore I voted against its proposed mobilisation. The suggestion of applying a ‘contingency’ for 2017 before 2016 has even finished rather stretches the principle of a contingency.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the contingency reserve in 2017. In 2017, there will probably be additional financial needs related to internal security crises and the current humanitarian, migration and refugee problems. The Commission therefore proposed to mobilise 1 164.4 million in its draft budget. In order to replenish commitment appropriations for expenditure under heading 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 beyond the ceiling for commitment appropriations of 2 578 million. EUR at current prices.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The report covers the use of contingency reserves in 2017. Regulation (EU) No 1311/2013 established a contingency reserve of up to 0,03% of the gross national income of the Union. Accordingly, the Commission calculated the maximum amount of the contingency reserve for 2017. At the same time, it is foreseeable that the expenditure ceilings thus defined will not be able to be maintained in 2017, so the Commission proposed to mobilise the Contingency Reserves of EUR 1164 million above the ceiling in order to address the migratory and humanitarian challenges additional expenditure incurred may be financed. Since we are in a forced orbit here, I supported raising the ceiling.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: The aim of this text is to mobilize an instrument to deal with “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. The sums, taken from the budget initially allocated to the administration, would be used to finance the policy of asylum and integration of “refugees”, in reality illegal migrants, economic migrants who aim to return to their country of origin as soon as possible. I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I endorsed this item which proposes to allocate the contingency margin for 2017 to address the migration situation, the needs of refugees and the internal security situation.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Geier report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the margin for unexpected incidents in 2017. Parliament considered it necessary to mobilise the margin for contingencies to meet the possible new financial needs that could arise from internal security crises and challenges on the humanitarian, migration and refugee front. The Conciliation Committee, convened for the 2017 budget, therefore agreed to mobilise the margin for contingencies amounting to €1.9 billion for heading 3 and heading 4, exceeding the limits set by the ceiling provided for in the MFF.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is the mobilization of one of the loopholes in the budget in order to meet the Funds for the Integration of Persons in Asylum and Migration Situations. A technical adjustment to make, along with other flexibility instruments that are modified, to address the challenges of safety and mobility of people. This funding, which will in part be used as a financial instrument in the Juncker Plan style, will be used to finance the continuation and stopperation of migration of persons in situations of forced mobility in countries bordering the Union. They will have an investment component in those areas (which will enable local and transnational authorities to do business), also humanitarian, but in turn the retention of that population. It will consist of mobilising this margin up to EUR 2 150.6 million, offset by cuts in agriculture and administration. Disguising mismanagement of resources as humanitarian aid.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the mobilization of the contingency margin in 2017, as additional financial needs may arise in that year, in connection with the internal security crisis and the current humanitarian, migration and refugee challenges. These requirements could also exceed the funding available under heading 3.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I strongly opposed this report concerning the mobilization of the contingency margin for 2017. The “unforeseen” in question is only the modest way for the Commission to make more money available for managing the migrant crisis. Given that in this case the EU is more than complicit in organising this overwhelm, it is rather cocasse to speak of “unforeseen”. The Commission therefore proposes to use EUR 2,150 billion to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under heading 3 'Security and Citizenship'. The aim is also to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under heading 4 'Europe in the world' to the tune of EUR 9.432 billion. When we see the sums that have already been mobilized to manage this slump and, at the same time, the situation of great precariousness in which millions of Europeans find themselves, we realize the direction of the Commission's priorities. The only responsible management would be to mobilize funds to ensure the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — Technically the margin for unexpected situations is a tool of last resort, which is used to raise funds, if Europe faces serious and unexpected situations, if and only if they are all other sources of funding available within the MFF have been exhausted. Solving the migration crisis and the problem of citizens' safety are priorities that I share. My support for the demand for an increase in funds for these headings would therefore be granted if it were accompanied by a real and radical change in the policies in which these contributions are run over. As long as FRONTEX, EASO, FAMI are funded to encourage the invasion of migrants and not to block their flows, I am not going to vote on measures like this.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having examined all other financial possibilities for responding to unforeseen circumstances within the expenditure ceilings for 2017 under headings 3 (Security and citizenship) and 4 (A global Europe) established in the multiannual financial framework, and having mobilised the Flexibility Instrument for the amount total of EUR 530 million available in 2017, it is necessary to mobilise the Contingency Margin to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by increasing commitment appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 above the ceilings of headings 3 and 4. Therefore, this decision, which I voted in favour, mobilizes EUR 1 906.2 million for headings 3 and 4. This amount is offset by EUR 575 million from the unallocated margin under heading 2 (Sustainable growth) in 2017 and EUR 507.3 million in 2017, EUR 70.0 million in 2018 and EUR 253.9 million in 2019 from the unallocated margins under heading 5 (Administration).

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the decision on the mobilisation of the contingency reserve. The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's proposals for the mid-term revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to supplement the expenditure category relating to internal security crises and the current humanitarian, migration and refugee challenges for the period 2018-2020. period. This is intended to provide sufficient resources for justice and home affairs agencies, as well as to take account of recent Commission proposals in the field of security and migration. In addition, Parliament recalls the immediate need to respond to security crises, migration and refugee problems, and considers it important that all relevant actors ensure full transparency of payments and regular monitoring and reporting of expenditure. It regrets that the Commission did not use the possibility of mid-term adjustment of the MFF in order to adjust the ceiling accordingly.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. After examining all the financing options for additional and unforeseen commitment needs, the European Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin amounting to EUR 1164,4 million. in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to the expenditure of Chapter 3 of its general budget for the year year year above the payment ceiling of EUR 2578 million in current prices. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to the release of the security reserve in 2017, taking into account the use of the Flexibility Instrument for the total amount of EUR 530 million. This will be available in 2017, when the security reserve needs to be used to respond to the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, which we know has not yet ended but is expected to intensify. This approval will also require commitment in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: This margin for unforeseen circumstances to deal with serious and unforeseen circumstances will therefore be used to facilitate the EU's immigrationist policy. It is clear that this allocation, which will also be made at the expense of the appropriations allocated to the administration, is unacceptable. I am therefore voting against this Commission proposal.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ It is the responsibility of the European Parliament and each of us to mobilise all the necessary resources to deal with unforeseen criticalities for the year 2017, so as to promptly make effective administrative action of the European Union and to quickly support areas of crisis.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report aims to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2.15 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under heading 3 “Security and citizenship” and heading 4 'Europe in the world'. The European Commission recommends that this instrument be activated in order to finance reception policies for illegal migrants. These sums will also have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. It is strictly unacceptable for the European Union to use our taxes to finance the overwhelming migration to which a vast majority of our fellow citizens strongly oppose. Any funds mobilized in the context of the migration crisis should be mobilized to finance the return of illegal migrants to their countries of origin. At a time when our fellow citizens, especially young people, are faced with mass unemployment, the explosion of poverty and the increase in social inequalities, it is essential to allocate all European funds to them! Of course, I voted against this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to mobilise the margin for unforeseen to meet the needs arising from the migration crisis, of refugees and of security by increasing commitment appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 beyond the limits of the ceilings set by the Multiannual Financial Framework. Although the migration, refugee and security crisis began in 2015, its impact and consequences evolve daily. Political decisions in third countries on accepting refugees into their territory and opening and closing borders mean that it is very difficult to predict how the situation will evolve for a long time term. The changing and unpredictable nature of the crisis justifies the use of margin for unforeseen as a tool of last resort to cope with the unforeseen consequences of the migration crisis, refugees and safety on expenditure requirements.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While I fully support the increase in expenditure related to the ongoing humanitarian crisis with thousands of people fleeing conflicts in Syria and Iraq, I do not support either the proposed increase in expenditure for security measures, or the expenses related to the EU-Turkey declaration on refugees.  The increased security measures and the EU-Turkey declaration aim to bolster ‘Fortress Europe’ thereby preventing refugees from exercising their right to seek asylum as laid down in Article 18 of the Charter of Human Rights. Therefore, I voted abstention.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Contingency Margin is an EU financial instrument which is meant to be used as a last resort for unforeseen circumstances and amounts to 0.03% of EU GNI. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 1.9 billion for the EU to spend on the migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilising the margin for unforeseen needs in 2017. This is a positive report aimed at complementing the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 and especially since additional financial needs are likely to arise in relation to the crises internal security and the current challenges in terms of the humanitarian sector, immigration and refugees, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Faced with a 2016 coming to an end, the statement of the budget for the new year is certainly not optimistic and, even less, on time. Undoubtedly, we will face old and new challenges in the light of the most tumultuous global scenario. This awareness prompts me to agree to the Commission's decision to mobilise the margin for contingencies of EUR 1 164.4 million, to be shared between the heading 'Security and Citizenship' and 'Role world of Europe”. In both cases, the contributions are understood to be further compared to the levels of the respective ceilings, just as denoting how the future needs of the EU could prove significantly higher given the crisis migration, refugees and terrorism. Moreover, it would be futile to thousand less agitated geopolitical views and, therefore, a more terse internal security and, consistent with these consciousnesses, the answers can be effective not only at the level local, but also in the Mediterranean framework through the involvement of the Maghreb countries.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Having examined all the possibilities for financing the additional and unforeseen needs for commitment appropriations, the Commission proposed in its draft budget to mobilise the contingency margin of EUR 1,164.4 million, with the aim of supplementing the commitment for expenditure under Heading 3 (security and citizenship) of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. During the discussion of the Commission's proposal for a budget, the European Parliament warned of the strong likelihood of additional financial needs arising in 2017 linked to the internal security crisis and the current humanitarian, migratory and scrap challenges, calling for an increase in commitment appropriations of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 above the ceiling of headings 3 (security and citizenship) and 4 (global europe) of the multiannual financial framework. As part of letter of amendment No 1/2017, the Commission revised the proposal for mobilisation to cover also expenditure under heading 4. The conciliation committee convened agreed to mobilise the Contingency Margin for EUR 1,906.2 million for Heading 3 and 4. I therefore support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on Budgets.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree we should mobilise the Contingency Margin for an amount of EUR 1 164.4 million so as to complement the commitment appropriations related to the expenditure in question pertaining to the financial year 2017, over and above the commitment ceiling of EUR 2 578 million in current prices. Additional financial needs are likely to arise in 2017, in relation to internal security crises and the current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges.  We need to respond to the additional funding needs arising from the security crisis and the migratory and humanitarian challenges in the Union in a human way.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. “I am aware that in 2017 there are likely to be additional financial needs arising from the internal security crisis and the challenges of the current humanitarian situation, migration and refugees. Nevertheless, I believe that in every area of operation of the European Union, measures must be managed rationally and efficiently, as well as to look for solutions that, without increasing expenditure, offer an opportunity to achieve the objectives set. In view of the above, after examining all aspects of the document, I voted against, because I am assured that even greater efficiency can be achieved within the existing measures to resolve or reduce the costs of migration, refugees and security.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this amendment which mobilises the Contingency Margin for 2016 for an amount of EUR 240.1 million in order to complement the commitment appropriations related to expenditure under Security and Citizenship in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes, with a view to financing additional and unforeseen requirements for commitment appropriations for the financial year 2017, to mobilise the contingency margin of EUR 1,164.4 million in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to internal security expenditure and current challenges humanitarian, migration and refugees. Following an agreement in the Conciliation Committee, Parliament has secured that the contingency margin should be increased to EUR 1 906.2 million to cover defence expenditure as well. Considering that, in the face of current challenges, it is essential to mobilise these margins, and being reassured that the report compensates the unallocated margins of the CAP budget for the financial year 2016 and 2017 to the tune of 500 million each year, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Contingency Margin is an EU financial instrument which is meant to be used as a last resort for unforeseen circumstances and amounts to 0.03% of EU GNI. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 1.9 billion for the EU to spend on the migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilizing the margin for contingencies in 2017. The European Union and its Member States continue to face serious security, migration and hospitality issues. Mobilising the margin for contingencies in 2017 for security and citizenship as well as for Europe's action in the world is therefore essential for the Union to be able to respond to any crisis or challenge in the coming year.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. After examining all the financing options for additional and unforeseen commitment needs, the European Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin amounting to EUR 1164,4 million. in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to the expenditure of Chapter 3 of its general budget for the year year year above the payment ceiling of EUR 2578 million in current prices. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. After examining all the financing options for additional and unforeseen commitment needs, the European Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin amounting to EUR 1164,4 million. in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to the expenditure of Chapter 3 of its general budget for the year year year above the payment ceiling of EUR 2578 million in current prices. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. The Commission is proposing EUR 240 million in commitment appropriations to meet the needs arising from the migrant crisis. We believe that the funds made available for this purpose should only be made available for the purpose of returning illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of the Union's resources. Continuing funding for Turkey, in the context of the alleged control of migratory flows, leads to the forced finding of various mechanisms to mobilise the margin for unforeseen needs. However, these funds will, in the near future, be necessary to deal with other emergencies, but will no longer be available.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Vote against: it is a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the margin for contingencies in 2017 because it provides for specific measures and funding aimed at addressing the crises of the refugees and migrants at European Union level.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Commission presented the 2017 contingency mobilisation, along with the draft budget for 2017. The European Commission's proposal will amount to €1.9 billion.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting against the report as there is a need to change the policies on the migrant issue totally.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against mobilising the margin for unforeseen needs in 2017, as the EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of Union resources. Continuing funding for Turkey in the context of the alleged control of migratory flows leads to the forced finding of various mechanisms to mobilise the margin for unforeseen needs. However, these funds will, in the near future, be necessary to deal with other emergencies, but will no longer be available.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The decision on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin presented by the Commission together with the 2017 EU draft budget, and updated by Amending Letter No 1/2016, has to be aligned with the agreement reached in conciliation on the 2017 EU Budget. The Contingency Margin is mobilised at a level of EUR 1 906.2 million for security and Citizenship (heading 3) and global Europe (heading 4). It is offset for EUR 575.0 million against the unallocated margin under Sustainable Growth: Natural Resources (heading 2) in 2017 and for EUR 507.3 million in 2017, EUR 570.0 million in 2018 and EUR 253.9 million in 2019 against the unallocated margins under  Administration (heading 5).

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)

The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget.
