The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Additional financing needs are likely in 2017 due to an in increased need of funds to handle the migration crisis and the internal security struggle to combat terrorism; given this, it is important that the Commission proposed to mobilise EUR 1 164.4 million of heading 3 through the Contingency Margin in 2017. However, as there is no more margin available under the ceiling of heading 3, flexibility has been needed to solve this issue. I support the result of the Conciliation Committee as they have managed to agree to the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin at a level of EUR 1 906.2 million for heading 3 and heading 4 with relocation of unallocated funds from heading 2 and 5 in the coming years. This agreement is very important, as it will allow the EU to mobilise clearly needed funds for instruments and mechanisms needed to stabilise and combat problems that will just get more difficult and expensive to manage if left unchecked.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I support the Commission's decision, as reflected by my colleague Geier's positive opinion and the successful outcome of the conciliation on the budget, on the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen for the year 2017. I would like to emphasize the important allocation attributed to urgencies for security policies and to support the EU's role in the world: these are essential measures to meet in a concrete and incisive way, even in a framework of great emergency, to the difficult migration crisis.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. — Due to the security crisis in Europe and the current humanitarian challenges posed by migration and refugee movements, additional funding needs are expected next year. I therefore support the use of the Contingency Margin in 2017.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017. I am supporting the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for the full amount of EUR 530 million available in 2017. It is necessary to mobilise the Contingency Margin to address the needs stemming from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by expanding the commitment appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 above the ceiling of the Contingency Margin in the Gross National Income of the Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. The budget proposed by Parliament already accepted cuts, only partially compensating for Commission and Council positions, and finally after the negotiation we have one of the most austere budgets known for a long time, following the intransigence of the Council and the richest countries. The budget will remain with €157 857.8 million in Payment Authorizations (CA) and €134 490.4 million in Payments, which represents a real cut of more than 6.4% and 1.7% more in credit. The budget is more flexible to provide space and recourse to more security and migration measures. The main victims will be agriculture, the administration of institutions and decentralized agencies. Basically it involves reducing Member States' contributions to an already low budget, mobilising contingency margins and flexibility in order to be able to address additional expenditure for the treatment of migration processes, strengthening the European Sustainable Development Fund (a kind of Juncker Plan for containment migration in neighboring countries) and the Turkey Trust Fund (Refugees).

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017. The decision on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin presented by the Commission together with the 2017 EU draft budget, and updated by Amending Letter No 1/2016, has to be aligned with the agreement reached in conciliation on the 2017 EU Budget.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. After examining all financing options for further and unforeseen commitment needs, the European Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin EUR 1164,4 million, for the European Union financial year 2017 in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for the expenditure of Chapter 3 of the relevant general budget above the payment ceiling of EUR 2578 million in current prices. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of a proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision of Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the contingency reserve in 2017, as this mobilises the amount of EUR 1 164,4 million for that year. It is clear that the European Union will also face an internal security crisis in the coming year, and with migration, humanitarian and refugee challenges, and in that context I consider these additional funds more than necessary. I believe that Union funding must be used in a transparent and efficient manner, and that issuances must be in line with the political priorities of the Union. In that context, I think this mobilization of funds is realistic that I support.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I do not intend to support a project whose ambition is to finance the policies of asylum and integration of the so-called refugees, when the only obvious decision would be to mobilize these resources for the return of these populations to their countries of origin. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise the contingency margin of around EUR 1.2 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for security expenditure in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 beyond the commitment ceiling. I voted in favour of this mobilization because I am aware, like my colleagues, that the needs in these areas will increase due to the current internal security crises and current and future migration challenges.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with this report because the EU is trying to adjust the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 so that additional appropriations are made available for unforeseen expenditure, which is not necessary in view of the development of the budget. At the same time, I am in favour of improving the use of funds and compliance with budget requirements.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. After examining all the financing options for additional and unforeseen commitment needs, the European Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin amounting to EUR 1164,4 million. in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to the expenditure of Chapter 3 of its general budget for the year year year above the payment ceiling of EUR 2578 million in current prices. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in order to provide EUR 240.1 million in commitment appropriations over and above the commitment ceiling of heading 3 (Security and citizenship) of the multiannual financial framework. The main reason why we should mobilise the Contingency Margin in 2016 is related to the fact that the EU should address the unforeseen consequences of the migration crisis. For one reason or another, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin is the only possible recourse to meet the budgetary needs under commitment appropriations. In this context, it is important to note that the availability of margins in other headings allows this mobilisation to be completely offset in 2016.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it proposes to mobilise the 'margin for unforeseen unforesed' in the 2016 budget to allocate €240 million to welcome migrants! It should be noted that the LR MEPs who support François Fillon voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — In order to supplement the commitment appropriations earmarked for expenditure under Title 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 above the ceiling for commitments of EUR 2 578 million, the Commission proposed in its draft budget that the reserve for He mobilises contingency expenditure amounting to EUR 1 164.4 million. During 2017, there are likely to be additional financial needs in relation to the internal security crisis and humanitarian, migration and refugee challenges, which could exceed available funds. After considering all other financial options for responding to unforeseen circumstances within the 2017 expenditure ceilings for Title 3. (Security and Citizenship) and Title 4. (Global Europe) established by the MFF and taking into account the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to the total available amount for 2017 of EUR 530 million, mobilisation of the contingency reserve is necessary to increase the commitment appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 answered all needs. In order to minimise the time required to mobilise the contingency reserve, this Decision should apply from the beginning of the financial year 2017, I have therefore supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has allocated EUR 1 906 150 960 from the 2017 reserve for unforeseen situations related to internal security crises and humanitarian aid, migration and refugees. By earmarking early, we enable the Commission to respond more flexibly and address these problems.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilising the margin for unforeseen needs in 2017 because it is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report. Various European funds must receive additional sums from the contingency margin of the 2017 budget. All these transfers will benefit from emergency programmes designed to finance actions for the integration of refugees on European soil. However, no return assistance scheme is currently funded by the EU, which is inadmissible.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a favourable vote for the report on Mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017. Taking such a step will complement the appropriations related to expenditure highlighted in the general budget of the EU for the financial year 2017. According to the report, not much margin is left to effectively handle security crises, humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges. Therefore it is necessary to address, with the Commission, in what way additional funds could be possibly mobilised using the Contingency Margin.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The EU general budget would not require any additional resources if the use of funds were optimised. However, an attempt is being made to complement the EU's general budget for 2017. I reject this.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure under Heading 3 'Security and Citizenship' to the tune of €2.578 billion and heading 4 'Europe in the world' to the tune of €9.432 billion. It is therefore a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is undesirable. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — (PT) This proposal includes an amount of EUR 1164.4 million, for which the Commission had already made a proposal to mobilise the Contingency Margin for heading 3, which accompanies the initial draft budget for 2017, and which is now repealed and replaced by this proposal. This proposal was preceded by another Commission proposal which aims to mobilise in full the amount of the Flexibility Instrument available for 2017 (EUR 530 million), also for heading 3. Although the refugee, migration and security crisis began in 2015, its effects continue to evolve day by day. The political decisions of third countries on the acceptance of refugees within their territory, as well as the opening and closing of borders, make it very difficult to predict long-term developments in this area. The volatility and unpredictability of the crisis justify the use of the Contingency Margin as a tool of last resort to remedy the unforeseen consequences of this crisis with regard to expenditure requirements of headings 3 and 4. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Mobilising the Contingency Margin for 2017 is important to react to unforeseen circumstances as a tool of last resort.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — In order to respond to unforeseen circumstances such as the challenges relating to the migrant, refugee and security crisis, it is important to mobilise the contingency margin of EUR 1 176 030 960 in commitment appropriations exceeding the ceiling of commitments under Heading 3 'Security and Citizenship' and 730 EUR 120 000 in commitment appropriations exceeding the ceiling of commitments under heading 4 'Europe in the world' of the multiannual financial framework. This is necessary in order to fill the difference between the expenditure ceiling level of headings 3 and 4 and the estimated additional unforeseen requirements for 2017.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which acknowledges the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin, which is mobilised at a level of EUR 1 906.2 million for security and Citizenship and global Europe. The decision on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin presented by the Commission together with the 2017 EU draft budget, and updated by Amending Letter No 1/2016, has to be aligned with the agreement reached in conciliation on the 2017 EU Budget.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Article 13 of Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 established a contingency reserve of up to 0,03% of the gross national income of the Union. As additional funding needs for internal security crises and current humanitarian, migration and asylum challenges are likely to arise in 2017, the Commission presented a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of this contingency reserve in 2017 to the European Parliament and the Council. This is necessary in order to address the migration, asylum and security crisis by increasing the commitment appropriations of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 above the ceilings of Chapters 3 and 4 of the multiannual financial framework derived from the needs. In its report, the Committee on Budgets proposes, taking into account the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, that Parliament approves this proposal for a resolution. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - Given the likelihood of additional financial needs arising in 2017 related to the internal security crisis and the current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges, these needs are likely to significantly exceed the available category 3 funding. I argue that the Commission should explicitly state in what terms the mobilisation of additional funds is made using the contingency margin to meet any additional financial needs of Category 3 throughout 2017.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure under Heading 3 'Security and Citizenship' to the tune of €2.578 billion and heading 4 'Europe in the world' to the tune of €9.432 billion. It is therefore a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on mobilizing the contingency margin for the financial year 2017. This mobilization will amount to €1,906.2 million for the budget headings devoted to citizenship, freedom, security, justice and the European Union as a global player.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Contingency Margin is a last resort instrument to react to unforeseen circumstances. I have voted for this report on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017 to a maximum of 0.03% of the Gross National Income of the Union.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2016, the EU budget was extremely busy as a result of the migration, refugee and security crisis. As a result of these unforeseen circumstances, an amount of EUR 240.1 million should be provided to provide commitment appropriations under heading 3 'Security and citizenship' of the EU general budget for the financial year 2016. The contingency margin is an instrument enshrined in the Multiannual Financial Framework that allows the EU to mobilise additional funds in contingencies. It was established by Article 13 of Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 and can collect an amount corresponding to 0.03% of the Union's gross national income, which, in this case, may cover the EU's still outstanding obligations. I gave my support to mobilising the contingency margin in 2016 because I believe that the additional costs that have been formed by the migration, refugee and security crisis have been and are necessary for the EU to deal with the ridiculous situation it is in.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because the financial needs of migration and refugee movements should be met by an increase in heading 3 of the EU general budget.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The resolution agrees to approve the increase in budgetary resources related to EU security and citizenship and global Europe issues.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted against the proposal of my colleagues because I believe that mobilization of the flexibility instrument should take place in a targeted manner, for example for crises arising from migration and from security. Furthermore, as a politician I believe it is incorrect to deduct €575.0 million from the unallocated margin of heading 2 (Sustainable growth: natural resources), as environmental resources must evolve constantly and can not be abandoned. I therefore voted down.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Council Regulation 1311/2013 establishes a contingency reserve of a maximum of 0,03% of the Union's gross national income. It is established outside the financial framework ceiling for 2014-2020 as a last resort instrument enabling unforeseen circumstances to respond. Unfortunately, the Commission predicts that in 2017 there is likely to emerge additional financial needs in the face of the internal security crisis due to humanitarian, migration and refugee challenges. I think such additional financial assistance is necessary. The unpredictability of the crisis justifies the use of mobilization of the reserve for contingency expenditures. The new means of providing emergency support within the Union adopted by the Council in 2016 and which will continue to be used in 2017 for humanitarian aid, I consider an adequate response to the current influx of refugees and migrants into the Union. Therefore, I supported the Resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the contingency reserve for 2017.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the contingency margin for 2017 of EUR 2,150 billion in order to supplement the commitment appropriations for expenditure under Heading 3 'Security and Citizenship' to the tune of €2.578 billion and heading 4 'Europe in the world' to the tune of €9.432 billion. It is therefore a matter of mobilizing this instrument of last resort in the face of “unforeseen circumstances”, in this case the migrant crisis. These sums will have to be offset by a decrease in the appropriations allocated to administration. However, these funds will finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. I am therefore voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — For the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, the contingency reserve of EUR 1 176 030 960 in commitment appropriations above the upper limit of commitment appropriations under Title 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework (Security and citizenship) and EUR 730 120 000 in commitment appropriations above the upper limit of commitment appropriations under Title 4 of the Multiannual Financial Framework (Global Europe). After considering all other financial options for responding to unforeseen circumstances within the 2017 expenditure ceilings for Title 3. (Security and Citizenship) and Title 4. (Global Europe) established by the Multiannual Financial Framework and taking into account the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to the total available amount for 2017 of EUR 530 million, mobilisation of the contingency reserve seems necessary to respond to the needs arising from migration, refugee and security crises. The condition of extreme necessity referred to in Article 13. Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 has been complied with.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Council Regulation 1311/2013 of 2 December establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 provides for the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin up to 0,03% of EU-28 gross national income as a means of last resort to react to circumstances unforeseen. In the technical adjustment of the MFF for 2017, based on Article 6 of the MFF Regulation, the absolute value of Contingency Margin for the year 2017 is set at EUR 4 496,8 million. In this way, and allegedly in order to respond to the security crisis and the Union's migratory and humanitarian challenges, and having examined all the possibilities for financing additional and unforeseen commitment appropriations needs, the Commission proposes to mobilise the Contingency Margin for 2017, amounting to EUR 1 164,4 million in order to supplement heading 3 of the general budget of the European Union. We follow the need to mobilise more funds for the refugee crisis. However, in view of the EU's current policy on migration, we fear that these funds will only strengthen the repressive instruments of foreign policy, accentuating their profoundly inhuman character.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation (MFF) 2013 allows for the mobilisation of a margin for unforeseen expenditure of up to 0,03% of Gross National Income in the EU-28. The margin for unforeseen expenditure is considered to be an instrument to be used as a last resort. , in reaction to unforeseen situations, only if all other avenues of funding have been exhausted. I hereby could not support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a report which plans to mobilise, within the framework of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, the contingency margin of more than EUR 1 billion in commitment appropriations above the ceiling of commitments under the heading 'Security and Citizenship' and more than EUR 700 million in commitment appropriations beyond the ceiling of commitments under the heading 'Security and Citizenship' of the ceiling on commitments under the heading “Europe in the world”. We must anticipate the emergence of new financial needs in 2017 linked to the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Contingency Margin is an EU financial instrument which is meant to be used as a last resort for unforeseen circumstances and amounts to 0.03% of EU GNI. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 1.9 billion for the EU to spend on the migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Having examined all other financial possibilities for responding to unforeseen circumstances within the expenditure ceilings for 2017 under headings 3 (Security and citizenship) and 4 (A global Europe) established in the multiannual financial framework, and having mobilised the Flexibility Instrument for the amount total of EUR 530 million available in 2017, it is necessary to mobilise the Contingency Margin to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, by increasing commitment appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 above the ceilings of headings 3 and 4. Therefore, this decision, which I voted in favour, mobilizes EUR 1 906.2 million for headings 3 and 4. This amount is offset by EUR 575 million from the unallocated margin under heading 2 (Sustainable growth) in 2017 and EUR 507.3 million in 2017, EUR 70.0 million in 2018 and EUR 253.9 million in 2019 from the unallocated margins under heading 5 (Administration).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the contingency margin of EUR 1 164,4 million for 2017 to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to expenditure under heading 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 and beyond the commitment ceiling of EUR 2 578 million in current prices. I would like to point out that new financial needs, linked to internal security crises and current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges, could arise in 2017.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I support this technical amendment to the budget, which concerns the reallocation of unforeseen expenditure funds in line with the expected challenges of 2017.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Article 13 of Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 defined an Contingency Margin of up to 0.03% of the Union's Gross National Income. The European Commission has calculated the gross amount of this Contingency Margin for 2017 and has decided to increase the commitment appropriations of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017. Due to the increasing urgency of responses to the needs arising from the refugee crisis, migration and security, there will be an increase above the ceiling of Headings 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Global Europe) of the Multiannual Financial Framework, which will be compensated by gradual reduction in the following 3 years (2017, 2018 and 2019) of the amounts applied to areas not allocated to real EU emergencies, such as Heading 2 'Sustainable Growth - Natural Resources' and Heading 5 'Administration'. Since additional financial needs linked to the internal security crisis and the current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges are likely to arise, I voted in favour of this report because it seems logical to mobilise financial mechanisms for action for unforeseen and urgent measures in the course of 2017.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this decision is to provide an additional EUR 1 906.2 million for the items “Security and Citizenship” and “Global Europe”, to be offset by the funds devoted to “Sustainable Growth” and to a lesser extent, “Administration”. I am opposed to the overall orientation of funds devoted to the migration and refugee crisis, the so-called 'Fortress Europe', for turning European borders into open air prisons and tombs for thousands of migrants. I call for respect for the right to asylum and that a genuine development and peace strategy be put in place for the countries of origin of migratory flows, which requires a specific increase in the European budget rather than the proposed patches. That is why I voted against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017. The decision on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin presented by the Commission together with the 2017 EU draft budget, and updated by Amending Letter No 1/2016, has to be aligned with the agreement reached in conciliation on the 2017 EU Budget.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision of the EP and of the Council on mobilising the contingency reserve in 2016. For the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016, a contingency reserve of EUR 240,1 million in commitment appropriations under heading 3 of the multiannual financial framework shall be mobilised beyond the limits of the ceiling of commitment appropriations. The amount of EUR 240,1 million in commitment appropriations referred to in Article 1 shall be fully offset by a reserve within the ceiling of commitment appropriations under heading 55 (Administration) of the multiannual financial framework for the financial year 2016.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — In response to future unforeseen circumstances, the Commission has examined the financial possibilities under expenditure ceilings in the areas of security and citizenship and Europe in the world for 2017, taking full account of the use of the Flexibility Facility of EUR 530 million; concluded that the security reserve should be used to respond to migration, refugee and security crises by increasing commitment appropriations above the ceilings of the above two areas of the 2017 budget. Parliament's report addressing the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2017 agrees that new responses related to internal security crises, humanitarian issues and the migration and refugee crisis are most likely to be needed in 2017. However, it warns that these challenges could significantly exceed security and citizenship funding, as there is no longer available reserve up to the ceiling, and calls on the Commission to explain how additional resources from the security reserve could be used to respond to upcoming challenges. Despite some warnings, the report welcomes the Commission's intention and I have supported it in the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to respond to unforeseen circumstances within the specific expenditure ceilings for 2017 set out in the Multiannual Financial Framework and with a view to the mobilisation of the Flexibility Facility for 2017, mobilisation of the contingency reserve may appear necessary. It must be realised that new financial needs are likely to arise in 2017 in the context of internal security crises and the current challenges of humanitarian, migration and refugees.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017. I highly doubt that the EU Commission has access to a crystal ball through which it can peer into the future and determine with absolute certainty the need to mobilise 2017’s contingency margin when we are still in 2016. Furthermore, even if additional costs are likely, funds should be made available by making the necessary budgetary cuts now.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — Mobilisation of the 2017 contingency reserve of €1.9 billion for Title 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Title 4. (Global Europe) will be used for the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crises. That additional expenditure will be covered by a reduction in the reserve for Title 2. (Sustainable Growth — Natural Resources) of €575 million in 2017 and a reduction in the reserve for Title 5. (Administration) of €507 million in 2017, €570 million in 2018 and €254 million in 2019. I accept this Draft Report because by this redistribution of resources within the budget, we will provide additional funds needed for the contingency costs caused by crisis situations.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2017. In the European Union, we have witnessed the migrant and security crisis for the last two years. Since we are likely to assume that we will face similar challenges in 2017 and that new financial needs will arise significantly beyond the funding available in Section 3, the European Commission needs to explain how and whether it would be possible to use additional funds referred to in Section 3 in 2017.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of the Union's resources. Continuing funding for Turkey, in the context of the alleged control of migratory flows, leads to the forced finding of various mechanisms to mobilise the margin for unforeseen needs. However, these funds will, in the near future, be necessary to deal with other emergencies, but will no longer be available.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. After examining all the financing options for additional and unforeseen commitment needs, the European Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin amounting to EUR 1164,4 million. in order to supplement the commitment appropriations relating to the expenditure of Chapter 3 of its general budget for the year year year above the payment ceiling of EUR 2578 million in current prices. The European Parliament's report adopted the Commission proposal. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — This was a simple validation of an annex to which our political experts gave their green light.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I voted in favour of a Motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the contingency reserve for 2017. In line with a number of emergencies that occurred during 2016, I believe it is necessary to mobilise funding from the 2017 budget so that humanitarian, migration and refugee challenges can be met as readily as possible.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The European Union Directive on the Multiannual Budgetary Framework of 2013 allows contingency mobilisation of 0,03% of GDP for all Member States of the Union. The specified margin is considered the ultimate means of combating unforeseen situations, which is used only in the case when all other funds are exhausted. The Commission's proposal is to mobilise the margin by €1.9 trillion and is related to the spending needed to deal with the migrant crisis, which I have supported.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2017. After examining all options for financing additional and unforeseen asset needs, the Commission proposed the use of a 2017 security reserve of EUR 1 164,4 million to complement commitment appropriations. New financial needs regarding internal security crises and current humanitarian challenges and challenges in migration and refugees are likely to emerge in 2017. It is therefore necessary to know how additional resources from the security reserve could be used to respond to any additional financial needs.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is the mobilization of one of the loopholes in the budget in order to meet the Funds for the Integration of Persons in Asylum and Migration Situations. A technical adjustment to make, along with other flexibility instruments that are modified, to address the challenges of safety and mobility of people. This funding, which will in part be used as a financial instrument in the Juncker Plan style, will be used to finance the continuation and stopperation of migration of persons in situations of forced mobility in countries bordering the Union. They will have an investment component in those areas (which will enable local and transnational authorities to do business), also humanitarian, but in turn the retention of that population. It will consist of mobilising this margin up to EUR 2 150.6 million, offset by cuts in agriculture and administration. Disguising mismanagement of resources as humanitarian aid.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. —Throughout the aid procedure, there are a number of instruments designed to assist the Member State in the event of unforeseen events. It is therefore unnecessary to create another route that could raise the risk of unreasonable expenditure, which is why I voted against the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — After examining all the financing options for additional and unforeseen commitment needs, the Commission proposed, in its draft budget, the mobilisation of the contingency reserve amounting to EUR 1164,4 million. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is the mobilization of one of the loopholes in the budget in order to meet the Funds for the Integration of Persons in Asylum and Migration Situations. A technical adjustment to make, along with other flexibility instruments that are modified, to address the challenges of safety and mobility of people. This funding, which will in part be used as a financial instrument in the Juncker Plan style, will be used to finance the continuation and stopperation of migration of persons in situations of forced mobility in countries bordering the Union. They will have an investment component in those areas (which will enable local and transnational authorities to do business), also humanitarian, but in turn the retention of that population. It will consist of mobilising this margin up to EUR 2 150.6 million, offset by cuts in agriculture and administration. Disguising mismanagement of resources as humanitarian aid.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2017. The Commission proposed in the draft General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 to mobilise the Contingency Margin for an amount of EUR 1 164.4 million in commitment appropriations over and above the commitment ceiling of heading 3 to respond to the additional funding needs arising from the security crisis and the migratory and humanitarian challenges in the Union. Additional financial needs are likely to arise in 2017 in relation to the internal security crises and the current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges. The fair and transparent distribution of funding between the different objectives of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund was a priority for Parliament during the negotiations leading to the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 516/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which established the Fund. I voted in favour because I believe that response to the security crises, migratory and refugee challenges has to be immediate.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This decision ratifies the agreement reached which provides for $1.9 billion for the contingency margin and an additional 500 million package for farmers. We must be aware of the importance of this margin, especially given the agri-food crisis resulting from the Russian veto which has had so many effects on agriculture, with particular emphasis on the dairy sector. That is why it is necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Council Regulation 1311/2013 of 2 December establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 provides for the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin up to 0,03% of EU-28 gross national income as a means of last resort to react to circumstances unforeseen. In the technical adjustment of the MFF for 2017, based on Article 6 of the MFF Regulation, the absolute value of Contingency Margin for the year 2017 is set at EUR 4 496,8 million. In this way, and allegedly in order to respond to the security crisis and the migration and humanitarian challenges of the Union, and having examined all the possibilities for financing additional and unforeseen commitment appropriations needs, the Commission proposes to mobilise the Contingency Margin for 2017, amounting to EUR 1 164,4 million in order to supplement heading 3 of the general budget of the European Union. We follow the need to mobilise more funds for the refugee crisis. However, in view of the EU's current policy on migration, we fear that these funds will only strengthen the repressive instruments of foreign policy, accentuating their profoundly inhuman character.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — EUR 530 million is to be used to deal with the current migration, refugee and security crisis. That's why I couldn't support the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the margin for unforeseen events in 2016. I believe that the Commission has made a worthy choice of approval in proposing, together with draft amending budget No 4/2016, to mobilise the 2016 contingency margin for a EUR 240.1 million in order to supplement the commitment appropriations related to expenditure under the heading 'security and citizenship' of the general budget of the EU. Considing appropriate the content of the decision, I vote favourably to this proposal.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: ‒ The regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF) allows the use of the margin instrument for unexpected purposes, which can be up to 0.03% of EU-28 gross national income, as a last instance to respond to unforeseen circumstances, if all other options available within the MFF have been exhausted. In order to meet the needs arising from the migration, refugee and security crisis, it was decided to increase the commitment appropriations under headings 3 and 4 of the MFF in the general budget of the Union European for the financial year 2017 beyond the limits of the ceilings set for these headings: therefore, the mobilisation of the flexibility instruments and precisely the margin for contingencies were used. It is undeniable that heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Rubric 4 (Role of Europe of the world) are under particular pressure at this time, mainly because of the migration crisis and the refugees. It is therefore difficult to object to the request to mobilise these additional resources, but the use of margin for unforeseen is only a buffer solution, which does not solve the problems at the root, and It also does not address the real need to rationalise the EU budget by focusing on real priorities such as these.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the mobilisation of the contingency margin. The purpose of the Decision is to allocate the contingency margin to the financing of commitment appropriations relating to expenditure on migration, refugees and security. This amount of over €1.16 billion is in addition to the €350 million flexibility instrument. If this amount can be decided now, it is clearly not an “unforeseen”. The European Parliament does not appear to be able to make clear choices of policy priorities. Already granting the full margin will irrevocably lead to deficits and subsequent charges for Member States in 2017.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal for a decision on mobilising the contingency reserve for 2017. The 2014 Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation allows for the mobilisation of a reserve of up to 0,03% of the Union's gross national income as a last resort to dealing with unforeseen circumstances and should only be used when the other financing option is exhausted. This is exactly the situation in the context of the migration, refugee and security crisis. Since the necessary measures cannot be financed by transferring funds from other budget lines, it is necessary to resort to exceptional instruments such as the contingency reserve. As I am aware of the scale and gravity of the migration and refugee crisis, I consider it right to mobilise this reserve in order to mitigate it.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. — We recognise that we are facing increasing and more serious humanitarian, migration and refugee challenges and that additional financial needs will be emerging to address security issues. It is to assume that the needs during 2017 could significantly exceed the funds currently available to meet the costs caused by migration and humanitarian challenges in the Union. I agree that it is necessary that the contingency reserve be mobilised so that they can adequately respond to future potential problems posed as a threat to the security of the Union. I support a draft budget proposal that would mobilise the amount of around €1 billion during 2017 for the specific purpose of financing the measures proposed by the Commission.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the release of the security reserve in 2017. I support the release of the security reserve in 2017, given the current security and political situation, new financial needs in relation to internal security crises and current humanitarian challenges and challenges on migration and refugees will emerge in 2017.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: ‒ The Regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF) authorises the use of the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of expenditure clearly identified that they could not otherwise be financed in the framework of the available ceilings of one or more headings of the MFF. The European Commission, after considering all the possibilities for allocation of appropriations, proposes mobilizing the flexibility instrument in 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million over the ceiling, to finance measures to manage the migration crisis, refugees and security. While in favour of maximum flexibility within the MFF and I am aware of the importance of dealing with the migration crisis, I remain opposed to the fact that instead of seeking reallocations from less budgetary lines priority, the use of these “special” instruments provided for by the MFF shall be used. In the view that it is not possible to deal with the problem of the budget and the current crises in this way, I abstained.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The file sought for flexibility instruments to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure. However, it sought to use this flexibility to increase security spending under the guise of helping with migration and the refugee crisis. While I fully support the increase in expenditure related to the ongoing humanitarian crisis with thousands of people fleeing conflicts in Syria and Iraq, I do not support either the proposed increase in expenditure for security measures, or the expenses related to the EU-Turkey declaration on refugees.  The increased security measures and the EU-Turkey declaration aim to bolster ‘Fortress Europe’ thereby preventing refugees from excising their right to seek asylum as laid down in Article 18 of the Charter of Human Rights. Therefore, I voted abstention.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. This amount will be used to finance support for measures to manage the migrant crisis. These funds will thus finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. Of course, I voted against this unacceptable report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose further spending of UK taxpayers’ money on additional EU projects, and therefore voted against.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance urgent budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugee and security crisis. Examination of all possibilities for reallocating commitment appropriations under Heading 3 has shown that commitment appropriations are essential for mobilising the Flexibility Instrument. Since the ceilings in heading 3 in 2017 do not allow for the proper financing of emergency measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security, I therefore agree that 530 million should be mobilised. EUR. Amount of commitment appropriations under the Flexibility Instrument

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The report concerns the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the current migration, asylum and security crisis. As is known, the Flexibility Instrument was set up in 1999 with the aim of ensuring that, if the ceiling of a budget target (budget line) is reached and additional payments are still needed, this can be done with the help of the Flexibility Instrument, without reintroducing the budget as a whole should negotiate. The Flexibility Instrument initially amounted to EUR 200 million per year, currently EUR 471 million, but if not used, it could be carried over to the next years. In the present case, the Commission proposes the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in order to add EUR 530 million to the funds included in the general budget of the Union for 2017 in addition to the ceiling of Chapter 3 (Security and Citizenship). and to finance measures in the field of security. The report also suggests that the annual amount of the Flexibility Instrument should be increased to EUR 2 billion. Let us also support the use and increase of the Flexibility Instrument, because the management of the migrant situation requires this.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 at its maximum level, i.e. EUR 530 million. This sum would be used to finance the policy of asylum and integration of “refugees”, in reality illegal migrants, economic migrants who aim to return to their countries of origin as soon as possible. Any money spent in relation to the migrant crisis should be spent to send them home and prevent them from (re) coming. I voted against this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I endorsed this report, which supports the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures for migrants and refugees.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Geier report on the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to deal with the current migration crisis, Refugees and security. This is a technical measure which aims to approve the mobilization of the flexibility instrument amounting to EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations the challenges facing the Union. The text also underlines the need for reflection on the future of the EU budget, which should provide for greater flexibility in the future, while also providing for an increase of two billion euros on an annual basis for the Flexibility Instrument.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the Contingency Margin Mobilization in 2017, I vote against. On this occasion, another financial instrument, a total of 530 million over four years, is being mobilized at current prices. These instruments use economic engineering and not to make a substantial change in the Union budget, which is scarce, and has proved not to live up to the circumstances in the migration crisis. And they mix security terms with humanitarian aid. From my point of view, this type of crisis should not be militarized, nor should this kind of instrument be used to appear to be supposed aid that is not being given, but endorsing.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the Mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugee and security crisis. The amount will mobilise will be EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations and, we reiterate the view that without prejudice to the possibility of mobilising payment appropriations for specific budget lines, through the Flexibility Instrument without prior mobilisation of commitments, payments derived from commitments mobilised previously using the Flexibility Instrument can only be accounted for above the ceilings.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I obviously voted against this report on the Commission's proposal to mobilise the flexibility instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to deal with the current crisis of migrants, refugees and security. This tool would be used up to EUR 530 million, which is the maximum allowable ceiling. The Commission is thinking of a young person in crisis who, after spending all his pocket money on superfetious expenses, would ask for a renewal from his parents. When we are aware that, according to the 2014 report of the European Homelessness Observatory, in France, the number of homeless people has increased by 44% in 11 years, from 80,000 to 150,000 people and that these figures are no more glorious in the rest of the European Union (44% in the Czech Republic, 29% in Sweden, 21% in Germany, 17% in the Country- Low and 16% in Denmark) — in a nutshell, when we see the impoverishment of our European populations — we can only be outraged by the so-called EU migration policy.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Flexibility Instrument provides funds to deal with clearly identified expenditure, which could not be financed from the EU budget without exceeding the annual maximum ceiling of expenditure of one or more headings of the multiannual financial framework. First of all, I believe that the Commission should demonstrate unequivocally that it has meticulously assessed the possibility of sourcing funds by reallocating it from non-priority budget lines before putting your hands back in the pockets of the Member States. While the migration crisis is a priority that I share, my support for this column would be granted if it were accompanied by a real and radical change in the policies in which these contributions are invested. As long as FRONTEX, EASO, FAMI are funded to encourage the invasion of migrants and not to block their flows, I am not going to vote on measures like this.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Flexibility Instrument is intended to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure which cannot be financed within the ceilings available under one or more headings. After examining all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations within the expenditure ceiling under heading 3 (Security and citizenship), it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument in order to supplement the funding available in the general budget of the Union for the financial year by an amount of EUR 530 million 2017 exceeding the ceilings of heading 3 in order to cover measures in the field of migration, refugees and security. By this decision, which I voted in favour, the payment appropriations for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument should be distributed over several budgetary years, estimated at EUR 238.3 million in 2017, EUR 91.0 million in 2018, EUR 141.9 million in 2019 and EUR 58.8 million in 2020.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which includes the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance urgent budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugees and security crisis. The European Parliament recognises that the financial impact of current security crises and humanitarian and migration problems has not been taken into account when the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) is adopted in 2013. Furthermore, it recalls that the Flexibility Instrument must be used to finance clearly defined costs which cannot be covered within the ceilings set for one or more categories of expenditure. Parliament regrets that the Commission has not made use of the possibility of mid-term adjustment of the MFF in order to adjust the ceiling for the category of expenditure related to migration, refugees and security crises accordingly. Parliament therefore supports the Commission's proposal in the framework of the mid-term review of the MFF, which aims to increase the budgetary capacity to respond quickly and adequately to unforeseen events.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament notes that the 2017 ceilings for Chapter 3 do not provide sufficient resources to finance urgent measures on migration, refugees and security. It therefore agrees to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. This will ensure that the resources mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to the use of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures. This funding is necessary for urgent needs and significant additional amounts should be used for measures aimed at alleviating the current migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in the amount of €530 million. With this mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument, the total amount available in 2017 has been fully exhausted, and the Committee adopted the Report with a large majority of votes.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am very unfavourable to the fact that funds allocated to other objects end up financing the immigrationist policy of the European Union. I am therefore voting against this Commission proposal.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ We believe an act due, consistent with the principles of subsidiarity and solidarity on which the European Union is founded, the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to find resources necessary for the prompt financing of assistance and rescue operations related to migration and the management of refugee persons. It is a humanitarian, social and central security issue whose responsibility lies collectively with the whole European Parliament and individually on each of us: we must quickly support areas where the emergency is stronger and offer a valid collective response for 2017.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — The aim of this report is to activate the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling, for the sole purpose of financing the reception of illegal migrants. These funds will finance, in particular, asylum policy and the integration of illegal migrants in the Member States. It is strictly unacceptable for the European Union to use our taxes to finance the overwhelming migration to which a vast majority of our fellow citizens strongly oppose. Any funds mobilized in the context of the migration crisis should be mobilized to finance the return of illegal migrants to their countries of origin. At a time when our fellow citizens, especially young people, are faced with mass unemployment, the explosion of poverty and the increase in social inequalities, it is essential to allocate all European funds to them! Of course, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — After examining all possible variants for financing additional and unforeseen commitments needs, the Commission proposed in its draft budget to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to make EUR 530 million available in the form of commitment appropriations. Additional financial needs were envisaged in 2017 in order to respond effectively to the current migration, refugee and security crisis, and therefore the Union budget needs to be more flexible to meet these challenges. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I consider it essential to mobilise this amount in order to cover the stringent financial needs of the current migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report on the introduction of funding measures to tackle and manage the current migration, refugee and security crisis. The report endorses the mobilization of the flexibility instrument, which in this case amounts to EUR 530 million, and its split over the various budgetary years. The urgent needs recall the need to mobilise additional amounts to alleviate the crisis. I think it is essential that we make a fair allocation of funding taking account of absolute priorities and ensuring the necessary transparency. The report welcomes the proposal made by the Commission as part of the multiannual review which proposes a greater capacity of the budget to respond more quickly to unexpected incidents. The decision will be adopted from 1 January 2017 in order to minimise the terms of mobilization of the flexibility instrument.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The file sought for flexibility instruments to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure. However, it sought to use this flexibility to increase security spending under the guise of helping with migration and the refugee crisis. While I fully support the increase in expenditure related to the ongoing humanitarian crisis with thousands of people fleeing conflicts in Syria and Iraq, I do not support either the proposed increase in expenditure for security measures, or the expenses related to the EU-Turkey declaration on refugees.  The increased security measures and the EU-Turkey declaration aim to bolster ‘Fortress Europe’ thereby preventing refugees from excising their right to seek asylum as laid down in Article 18 of the Charter of Human Rights. Therefore, I voted abstention.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Flexibility Instrument provides funding for clearly identified expenses which cannot be covered by the normal EU budget ceilings. It has a maximum of EUR 471 million per year. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 530 million over a four-year period to be spend on the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on mobilising the Flexibility Instrument to finance direct budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugee and security crisis. It is clear that this report aims to improve the possibilities of dealing with issues that have plagued Europe in recent times and is directly linked to the refugee issue. I think it can only have positive results, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Negative vote for the resolution in question. In order to finance the current management of the migration crisis, refugees and security, the Commission proposes to use the flexibility instrument amounting to EUR 530 million. As long as we fund programmes such as Frontex, Easo and Fami with these amounts, which are used to foster migrant invasion, the problem can only get worse.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ As was easily expected, the expenditure which the Union will have to bear in 2016 to deal with migration, refugee and security crises exceed the extent of what it had been prepared for the heading of the budget relating to 'Security and Citizenship'. Consequently, the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument amounting to EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations is required. This amount reflects the costs of elephantiac mostly represented by the reception of migrants and refugees, they have often been paid directly by the States concerned and not only in monetary terms, Therefore, I can only place confidence in an implementation of flexibility. In accordance with the multiannual funding framework, mobilisation fulfil the current priority of ensuring wider room for manoeuvre on the Community budget. In fact, the increase in flexibility requires the annual amount of the instrument to be raised by at least EUR 2 billion.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the on-going migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Throughout 2016, the Union has faced numerous challenges, including the so-called refugee crisis and terrorism, with the consequent increased need for resources for these areas, requiring budgetary reinforcement throughout 2016. These needs will remain high in 2017 and so, beyond strengthening its budget lines within the Union's annual budget, Parliament — rightly — mobilises the flexibility instrument for a total of €530 million. Realistically providing with the means necessary for effective European solidarity! For example, this reinforcement will help to better empower the European Asylum Support Office. However, it should also be emphasised that it is now without any room for reinforcement for next year. This highlights the need for greater flexibility in the multiannual financial framework.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on Budgets.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: — Financing immediate budgetary measures to cope with the current migration and security crisis is a priority that the EU can no longer postpone. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution which remedies the current shortcomings. In fact, the flexibility instrument made available by the Commission has not, so far, allowed urgent measures on migration, refugees and security to be financed. The EU institutions approved the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for a total amount of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriation. In my view, this is an important step forward in the direction of a more flexible European budget management to address emergencies not covered when the framework was approved multiannual financial.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — Given the situation in which the European Union is currently in the area of eliminating the migration crisis, it seems appropriate to propose, inter alia, the flexibility instrument under Chapter 3 of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017 in the amount of 530 million EUR. Nevertheless, it should be made clear here that budgetary flexibility has its limits and can only be a short-term solution applied for unforeseen events. The main argument for this solution is that the financial effects of the current internal security crises as well as humanitarian and migration challenges were not addressed when the current MFF was adopted in 2013. I approved the Commission's proposal in the context of a mid-term revision of the MFF, which aims to increase budgetary opportunities so as to respond quickly and properly to contingencies. At the same time, it should be recalled that a fair and transparent distribution of funding for the particular objectives of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (Fund) was a priority of Parliament during the negotiations leading to the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 516/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (1) establishing the Fund. With the above in mind, I voted in favour of the project.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of adequate financing of urgent measures in the field of migration, refugees and security. Current events have proven that the European Union needs to be flexible in order to address imminent issues and circumstances which require urgent action. It is crucially important for the Union budget to be more flexible.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument to supplement the financing of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, beyond the ceiling of Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship), by an amount of EUR 530 million, in order to finance measures in the field of migration, refugees and security. Given the current challenges, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Flexibility Instrument provides funding for clearly identified expenses which cannot be covered by the normal EU budget ceilings. It has a maximum of EUR 471 million per year. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 530 million over a four-year period to be spend on the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — The expenditure of the European Union shall be fixed by a multiannual financial framework. The latter was adopted in 2013 and foresees expenditure for the period 2014-2020. When an expenditure exceeds forecasts and contingency margins, the only way to finance it is through the flexibility instrument. In order to sustain the financing of EU actions related to the management of the migration crisis and the security challenges it faces, I supported the mobilization of funds from the Flexibility Instrument, amounting to €530 million, from 2017 to 2020.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament notes that the 2017 ceilings for Chapter 3 do not provide sufficient resources to finance urgent measures on migration, refugees and security. It therefore agrees to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. This will ensure that the resources mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament notes that the 2017 ceilings for Chapter 3 do not provide sufficient resources to finance urgent measures on migration, refugees and security. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. These are new funding for asylum policies, which we strongly oppose. On the contrary, the return of illegal persons to their country must be promoted.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of the Union's resources. The financing of Turkey, in the context of the alleged control of migration flows, leads to a full absorption of these funds and, in the event of unforeseen adverse situations in the future, there is not the necessary flexibility.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to mobilise the flexibility fund for 2017 in order to support measures related to the migration crisis given its own exceptional nature which, therefore, justifies the use of the flexibility tool.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting against the report as there is a need to totally change migrant policies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance direct budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugee and security crisis, as the EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, they have led to the waste of Union resources. Financing Turkey under the supposed control of migratory flows leads to a full absorption of these available funds and, in the event of unforeseen adverse situations in the future, there is not the necessary flexibility.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The decision on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument presented by the Commission together with the 2017 EU draft budget has to be aligned with the agreement reached in conciliation on the 2017 EU Budget. The Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is mobilised in commitment appropriations for an amount of EUR 530 million for Security and Citizenship (heading 3). With this mobilisation of the flexibility instrument  the total amount available in 2017 is fully exhausted.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget.
