Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the current crisis of migration, refugees and security. It should be noted, however, that the resources made available for this purpose may not be sufficient given the challenges that the Union faces in this area, and we must therefore be prepared if additional funds are needed.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The current humanitarian challenges posed by migration and refugee movements increase the need for financing. The mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument should increase the general budget for the financial year 2017 by EUR 530 million beyond the ceiling.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crises. I support the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to complement the financing in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 beyond the ceiling of heading 3 by the amount of EUR 530 million to finance measures in the field of migration, refugees and security.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. In order to address humanitarian needs and as budget cuts have become more severe, the flexibility margins of unemployed resources in 2016 are used once again to be used for migration; refugees, border security and agreements with Turkey are once again mixed up to ensure that act as an external guardian of borders, with, at the very least, dubious protection of human rights. A total of EUR 240.1 million for 2017 in payments, which will exceed the ceilings of heading 3 of the Union budget, on Security and Citizenship.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this report adopted in the Committee on Budgets by a large majority. The Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is mobilised in commitment appropriations for an amount of EUR 530 million for Security and Citizenship (heading 3).

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament notes that the 2017 ceilings for Chapter 3 do not provide sufficient resources to finance urgent measures on migration, refugees and security. It therefore agrees to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. This will ensure that the resources mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that expresses serious concerns over the payment surplus of EUR 7 284.3 million, which is the result of major delays in the implementation of EU programmes under shared management. This paves the way for a significant accumulation of payment requests towards the end of the current MFF. It also reiterates the Commission’s conclusion that, according to the present forecasts, updated payment needs until 2020 can only be accommodated with the current ceilings if the Global Margin for Payments is fully used and if payments for special instruments are counted over and above the ceilings. It therefore asks the Commission for a definitive and unequivocal settlement of the latter issue as part of the MFF revision.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The flexibility instrument is taken into account in the 2013 Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation. It applies when expenditure is incurred in individual budgetary areas exceeding the ceilings laid down in the multiannual financial framework. Accordingly, the Commission has requested the activation of this flexibility instrument for 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million, in order to fund additional measures to address the migration crisis. Next year, it will be necessary to follow closely what specific expenditure will be spent on these additional funds and the impact of these additional activities to curb migration flows to Europe. There are still outstanding questions in this regard. Nonetheless, I decided to activate the flexibility instrument and agreed to the report accordingly.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance urgent budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis as this aid is also the flexibility of the Union budget very necessary in the current situation. This Report supports the Commission's proposal, namely the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to increase the funding in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 by €530 million above Title 3 ceiling to finance measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I do not intend to support a project whose ambition is to finance the policies of asylum and integration of the so-called refugees, when the only obvious decision would be to mobilize these means for the return of these populations to their countries of origin. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to finance budgetary measures to deal with the migration and security crisis in Europe for an amount of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. Resolving the migration crisis and ensuring the security of Europeans must be Europe's priority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with this report because it was not credible that the financial resources would not be sufficient to deal with the migration and security crisis. The EU is trying to obtain support for the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in the amount of EUR 530 million here, which I reject.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The flexibility instrument is taken into account in the 2013 Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation. It applies when expenditure is incurred in individual budgetary areas exceeding the ceilings laid down in the multiannual financial framework. Accordingly, the Commission has requested the activation of this flexibility instrument for 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million, in order to fund additional measures to address the migration crisis. Next year, it will be necessary to follow closely what specific expenditure will be spent on these additional funds and the impact of these additional activities to curb migration flows to Europe. There are still outstanding questions in this regard. Nonetheless, I decided to activate the flexibility instrument and agreed to the report accordingly.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament notes that the 2017 ceilings for Chapter 3 do not provide sufficient resources to finance urgent measures on migration, refugees and security. It therefore agrees to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. This will ensure that the resources mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it proposes to mobilise the 'margin for unforeseen unforesed' in the 2016 budget to allocate EUR 250 million to welcome migrants. It should be noted that the LR MEPs who support François Fillon voted in favour.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 because it involves the mobilisation of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 530 million for heading 3 (Security and Citizenship).

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The Commission has proposed mobilising the Flexibility Instrument to increase the funding in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 by EUR 530 million above Title 3 ceiling to finance measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security. Therefore, for the financial year 2017, the total amount available for the Flexibility Instrument was fully utilised. Since it is not possible to adequately finance emergency measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security within the limits of Title 3 in 2017, the Flexibility Instrument must be mobilised to the amount of €530 million in commitment appropriations. Mobilisation of that instrument in accordance with Article 11. The MFF Regulation once again indicates that greater flexibility of the Union budget is much needed, and I have therefore supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order to deal more effectively with the unforeseen circumstances linked to the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis, it is necessary that the Union be prepared in advance to respond appropriately to the situations that have arisen. I therefore support the proposal to mobilise for this purpose from the Flexibility Instrument of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations from the Union budget for 2017. This will allow timely response and assistance to the Member States concerned.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance direct budgetary measures to address the current crisis in the area of migration, refugees and security because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The aim of this text is to mobilise €530 million to finance measures to manage the migrant crisis, including the integration of refugees, which we oppose.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. Supporting the report means strengthening the Flexibility Instrument, which was implemented in order to ‘allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure that cannot be financed within the limits of the ceilings’. Furthermore, the mobilisation of an amount of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations will prove crucial in financing the measures to tackle the fields of migration, refugees and security.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I do not agree with the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument of €530 million to provide the insufficient financial resources to deal with the migration and security crisis.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. This amount will be used to finance support for measures to manage the migrant crisis. These funds mobilized will thus finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees. We strongly oppose it. So, I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the extent of the ongoing migration, refugee and security crises is unprecedented. The EU’s measures to resolve them must be backed by adequate financing.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The objective of the flexibility instrument is to allow the management of expenditure which could not be financed within the limits of the ceilings available for one or more headings. The objective here is to mobilise the flexibility instrument to supplement the financing of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 with an amount of EUR 530 million in order to finance measures in the field of migration, refugees and security. I have decided to vote in favour of the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for commitment appropriations, because, as things stand now, it seems to me that the Union must have the means to act to meet its responsibilities. In the name of the principle of solidarity and respect for human rights, it is humanly imperative to make progress in the management of this humanitarian crisis.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis, since I am in agreement.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — Pursuant to Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020, the Flexibility Instrument is intended to allow for the financing of clearly defined expenditure which belongs to other chapters or chapters could not be financed within the limits of ceilings. The Commission has submitted a proposal for a decision to the European Parliament and to the Council to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument in order to add EUR 530 million to the general budget of the European Union for 2017 above the ceiling of Chapter 3 to finance measures in the areas of migration, asylum and security. The Committee on Budgets notes in its report, taking into account the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, that, in order to finance the necessary measures in the fields of migration, asylum and security, the European Union general budget for 2017 it is necessary to supplement available resources beyond the ceilings of Chapter 3. It therefore proposes that Parliament agree with the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in the form of commitment appropriations of EUR 530 million, and the Commission approves its proposal for a decision on this. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - Given the likelihood of additional financial needs arising in 2017 related to the internal security crisis and the current humanitarian, migratory and refugee challenges, these needs are likely to significantly exceed the available category 3 funding. The Commission proposed mobilising the Flexibility Instrument to complement the financing of the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, beyond the ceiling of heading 3 of EUR 530 million, to finance measures in the field of migration, refugees and security. I endorse the rapporteur's position that the mobilisation of this instrument once again highlights the crucial need for greater flexibility in the Union's budget.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. This amount will be used to finance support for measures to manage the migrant crisis. These funds will thus finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the mobilisation of a Flexibility Instrument that will finance immediate budgetary measures to deal with the on-going migration, refugee and security crisis. The report will mobilise EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations for the Flexibility Instrument, to be used until 2020.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The file sought for flexibility instruments to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure. However, it sought to use this flexibility to increase security spending under the guise of helping with migration and the refugee crisis. While I fully support the increase in expenditure related to the ongoing humanitarian crisis with thousands of people fleeing conflicts in Syria and Iraq, I do not support either the proposed increase in expenditure for security measures, or the expenses related to the EU-Turkey declaration on refugees.  The increased security measures and the EU-Turkey declaration aim to bolster ‘Fortress Europe’ thereby preventing refugees from excising their right to seek asylum as laid down in Article 18 of the Charter of Human Rights. Therefore, I voted abstention.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because the money is not enough to deal with migration and security, and support would be given for the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument with an amount of EUR 530 million.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. In order to better cope with the refugee crisis, it is important to ensure financial measures that alleviate the financial burden of Member States to cope with an urgent crisis. The pre-established financial limit has been reached and it is now necessary to introduce additional funding.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that due to the increasing flow of migration, it is necessary to mobilise the flexibility instrument amounting to EUR 530 million. Moreover, this mobilisation would be carried out in full compliance with Article 11 of the MFF Regulation, which states the need to ensure greater flexibility of the EU budget. As a politician I believe that the application of this decision should take place from 1 January because of the steady increase in the percentage of migration. I therefore voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the mobilization of the Flexibility Instrument to finance urgent budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. The Flexibility Instrument is intended to finance clearly defined expenditure that cannot be financed within the available ceilings, as is currently the case. In line with urgent needs, it is essential to mobilise additional funds to mitigate the migration, refugee and security crisis. After all possibilities of redevelopment of the funds referred to in Chapter 3 (security and citizenship) have been verified, it was established that all the necessary conditions are met and it is necessary to mobilise the EUR 530 million Flexibility Instrument to complete the financing of the general budget The European Union for 2017 has provided funding for measures in the fields of migration, refugees and security. Based on the expected profit for the payment, the payment funds correspond to the mobilisation of the flexible instrument and should be redistributed over several financial years and are estimated at amounts of €238.3 million in 2017, €91 million in 2018, €141.9 million in 2019 and 58.8 million euros in 2020.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017 to the tune of EUR 530 million, the maximum allowed ceiling. This amount will be used to finance support for measures to manage the migrant crisis. These funds will thus finance the policy of asylum and the integration of refugees, which is unacceptable. Any funds mobilized should be mobilized exclusively for the return of illegal persons to their countries of origin. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Given that, within the upper limits of Title 3, 2017, it is not possible to adequately finance emergency measures in the area of migration, refugees and security, I agree that the Flexibility Instrument is mobilised to the amount of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. However, it is important to reiterate Parliament's view that greater flexibility of the Union budget is much needed and that the annual amount available for the Flexibility Instrument needs to be increased to €2 billion.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: The purpose of the Flexibility Instrument is to allow the financing of identified expenditure whether it cannot be financed within the ceilings of one or more EU budget headings. The mobilisation of the flexibility instrument relates to the need to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 with a view to financing commitment appropriations under Heading 3 — Security and Citizenship — in order to go beyond the limit maximum of this heading for the year 2017, according to the current Multiannual Financial Framework. It is therefore authorised to mobilise the total of this instrument for 2017 in the amount of €530 million. Apart from the fact that it is not 'new' money, there is insufficient value added to cope with and assist in taking action against the continuing humanitarian crisis of refugees. Once again, the MFF amounts (within their limits) fall short of what is needed to cope with repeated crises in the EU, not to mention what is necessary for an effective redistributive policy that will allow disadvantaged countries and regions to approach the richer regions.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The 2013 Regulation defining the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) provides for the possibility of launching a flexibility instrument to finance expenditure above the ceilings available in one or more divisions of the MFF. The European Commission proposes to launch EUR 530 million as part of this Flexibility Facility in 2017 to support measures related to the migration and refugee crisis. This is the maximum amount that can be launched under this instrument in 2017, which partly explains why the Commission, in a separate proposal, wishes to establish a margin for unforeseen expenditure. It recognises the unique nature of the migrant and refugee crisis and has so far supported the use of the flexibility instrument for this purpose. However, I am concerned that the full amount is due to be launched as early as 2017, as this leaves little room for manoeuvre later in the year.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: The protection of our borders and managing the migration crisis are priority issues for the European Union. I voted in favour of this report, which envisages mobilizing the flexibility instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to achieve these objectives.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. The Flexibility Instrument provides funding for clearly identified expenses which cannot be covered by the normal EU budget ceilings. It has a maximum of EUR 471 million per year. This specific proposal is to mobilise EUR 530 million over a four-year period to be spend on the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. UKIP opposes the EU spending any British taxpayer’s money.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Flexibility Instrument is intended to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure which cannot be financed within the ceilings available under one or more headings. After examining all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations within the expenditure ceiling under heading 3 (Security and citizenship), it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument in order to supplement the funding available in the general budget of the Union for the financial year by an amount of EUR 530 million 2017 exceeding the ceilings of heading 3 in order to cover measures in the field of migration, refugees and security. By this decision, which I voted in favour, the payment appropriations for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument should be distributed over several budgetary years, estimated at EUR 238,3 million in 2017, EUR 91.0 million in 2018, EUR 141.9 million in 2019 and EUR 58,8 million in 2020.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to deal with the current crisis of migrants, refugees and security. Thus, EUR 530.0 million will be allocated to finance measures to manage the current crisis of migrants, refugees and security. The breakdown will be as follows: EUR 238.3 million from 2017, EUR 91.0 million in 2018, EUR 141.9 million in 2019 and EUR 58.8 million in 2020.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I welcome this future-oriented budget change, which concerns the reallocation of funds to manage the migrant and refugee crisis, which is necessary as a result of possible changes in the flows of asylum seekers next year.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: The purpose of the Flexibility Instrument is to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure that could not be financed within the ceilings of other headings and is currently defined as the annual ceiling for this Instrument EUR 471 million. Due to the urgent and emerging needs in the European Union, it is necessary to mobilise additional amounts to those budgeted for 2017 to help finance measures to mitigate current migratory and refugee crises and enhance security. After examining all the possibilities for reallocating appropriations under the ceiling for expenditure under heading 3 (Security and Citizenship), it is therefore necessary to mobilise this Instrument in order to enable the financing of migration, refugee and security measures. Commitment appropriations are provided for an amount of 530 million. For 2017 and in terms of payment appropriations, EUR 238.3 million (which will exhaust the maximum annual amount for that year); for 2018, 91 million; in 2019, 141.9 million and 58.8 million for 2020. As I agree with this proposal and the need to act effectively and quickly, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this decision is to provide an additional 530 million to Union instruments for migration, refugees and security. I am opposed to the overall orientation of funds devoted to the migration and refugee crisis, the so-called 'Fortaleza Europe', for having turned European borders into open air prisons and tombs for thousands of migrants. I call for respect for the right to asylum and that a genuine development and peace strategy be put in place for the countries of origin of migratory flows, which requires a specific increase in the European budget rather than the proposed patches. That is why I voted against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report adopted in the Committee on Budgets by a large majority. The Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is mobilised in commitment appropriations for an amount of EUR 530 million for Security and Citizenship (heading 3).

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. “I approved the mobilisation of financial instruments to tackle the migration, refugee and security crisis because it is still an urgent issue. We use the Flexibility Instrument precisely to finance expenditure that could not be covered within the limits of the ceilings available for each chapter of expenditure. This instrument is mobilised to supplement the appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 beyond the budgetary ceilings of heading 3 with an amount of EUR 530 million to finance measures in the fields of migration, refugees and security. An example is the use of resources to finance the objectives of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, which include strengthening Fair Return Strategies, as well as more effective support for the integration of third-country citizens. The proposal envisages the reallocation of the Flexibility Facility's financial resources over the 2017-2020 horizon as follows: €238.3 million in 2017, €91 million in 2018, €141.9 million in 2019 and €58.8 million in 2020. In the financial year 2017, the total amount of the Flexibility Instrument shall be exhausted. However, I consider it important to add that, despite the systematic use of the Flexibility Instrument, it will not be able to meet the increased needs in the coming years and, therefore, in the long term, a fair reallocation of funds to these priorities is necessary.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The Parliament report discusses the decision of Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugee and security crisis, which concludes that additional funding funding needs to be used to mitigate this crisis measures under the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 530 million. Otherwise, through the Flexibility Instrument, those expenditure which cannot be financed within the ceilings of individual lines of the budget shall be financed. In this case, the ceilings of the “Security and Citizenship” section for 2017 do not allow adequate financing of emergency measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security. On this basis, the report agrees to the use of the €530 million Flexibility Instrument, which is why I supported it in the vote. Nevertheless, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs also notes that EUR 530 million is the total amount available for this instrument in 2017 and that this is a purely short-term solution to the issues that need to be addressed in the context of a regular budgetary procedure, moreover, this amount is unlikely to be sufficient to address the growing challenges in this area.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - The flexibility instrument is taken into account in the 2013 Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation. It applies when expenditure is incurred in individual budgetary areas exceeding the ceilings laid down in the multiannual financial framework. Accordingly, the Commission has requested the activation of this flexibility instrument for 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million, in order to fund additional measures to address the migration crisis. Next year, it will be necessary to follow closely what specific expenditure will be spent on these additional funds and the impact of these additional activities to curb migration flows to Europe. There are still outstanding questions in this regard. Nonetheless, I decided to activate the flexibility instrument and agreed to the report accordingly.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The ceilings on specific budgets for 2017 do not allow adequate funding for urgent measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security. After examining all options for reallocating specific commitment appropriations, it appears necessary to release from the Flexibility Instrument commitment appropriations to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. I am opposed to increasing the funding of the EU’s failed policies in this area.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — Having considered all options for redistribution of appropriations within the expenditure ceiling under Title 3. (Security and Citizenship), it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to supplement funding in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 above the upper limit under Title 3 by 530 million euros and finance measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security. Appropriations for payments under the Flexibility Instrument mobilisation should be distributed as follows: €238.3 million in 2017, €91 million in 2018, €141.9 million in 2019 and 58.8 million euros in 2020. I accept this Draft Budget Amendment because by this redistribution of resources within the budget for this and next year, we will provide additional necessary funding for the contingency costs caused by crisis situations.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. Similar to the last years, we will also witness challenges in 2017 in the areas of the migrant, refugee and security crises. I support the use of EUR 530 million commitment funds from the Flexibility Facility, since the 2017 Section 3 ceilings do not allow adequate financing of emergency measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU's misconduct in tackling illegal immigration, in connection with the implementation of a failed Multiannual Financial Framework, has led to the waste of the Union's resources. The financing of Turkey, in the context of the alleged control of migration flows, leads to a full absorption of these funds and, in the event of unforeseen adverse situations in the future, there is not the necessary flexibility.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for 2017 is part of the agreement established by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council on the 2017 EU budget. The European Parliament notes that the 2017 ceilings for Chapter 3 do not provide sufficient resources to finance urgent measures on migration, refugees and security. It therefore agrees to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. This will ensure that the resources mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - An analysis of the state of financing the immediate budgetary measures aimed at the current migration, refugee and security crisis reveals that there is a need for an additional above the funding ceilings allocated in the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017. This is because the total amount of the Flexibility Instrument for the financial year 2017 has been exhausted and the financial needs only to manage the refugee crisis are increasing, plus the financial needs for the other two problems of the community European: migration and security. As the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, provided for in Article 11 of the MFF Regulation, is possible and necessary, I voted because there is no other possibility of financing immediate budgetary measures aimed at the three phenomena affecting the socio-economic life of citizens EU.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: I therefore approved the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for an amount of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations. We also approved the proposed allocation of the corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 238,3 million for the financial year 2017, EUR 91 million for the financial year 2018, EUR 141.9 million for the financial year 2019 and EUR 58.8 million for the financial year 2020.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance urgent budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. Since the budgetary frameworks of the European Union cannot adequately respond to the urgent measures needed in the area of migration, refugees and security, I consider it necessary to mobilise flexibility instruments in order to finance urgent budgetary measures. I agree with the proposed allocation of the corresponding payment appropriations in amounts of €238.3 million in 2017, €91 million in 2018, €141.9 million in 2019 and €58.8 million in 2020.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The Multiannual Budgetary Framework Directive (MFF) of 2013 allows the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance spending above the set limit. Consequently, the Commission proposes to mobilise the €530 million Flexibility Facility for 2017 to tackle the migrant and refugee crisis. As I understand and acknowledge the gravity and complication of the emergency situation faced by the EU during the crisis, I supported this proposal from the Commission.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the current migration, refugee and security crisis. The ceilings of Section 3 of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 do not allow adequate financing of emergency measures in the areas of migration, refugees and security. Therefore, the European Parliament agrees to use commitment appropriations of EUR 530 million from the Flexibility Instrument.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the Contingency Margin Mobilization in 2017, I vote against. On this occasion, another financial instrument, a total of 530 million over four years, is being mobilized at current prices. These instruments use economic engineering and not to make a substantial change in the Union budget, which is scarce, and has proved not to live up to the circumstances in the migration crisis. And they mix security terms with humanitarian aid. From my point of view, this type of crisis should not be militarized, nor should this kind of instrument be used to appear to be supposed aid that is not being given, but endorsing.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The 2013 Regulation setting out the multiannual financial framework provides for the possibility of launching a flexibility instrument to finance expenditure above the ceilings available in one or more divisions of the multiannual financial framework. However, in my assessment, the launch of the full amount already at the very beginning of 2017 is very worrying. Such a decision will leave little room for manoeuvre later in the year and that is why I voted against the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to add €530 million to the EU general budget for 2017 measures in the areas of migration, asylum and security in addition to the ceiling of Chapter 3 to finance it. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the Contingency Margin Mobilization in 2017, I vote against. On this occasion, another financial instrument, a total of 530 million over four years, is being mobilized at current prices. These instruments use economic engineering and not to make a substantial change in the EU budget, which is scarce, and has proved not to live up to the circumstances in the migration crisis. And they mix security terms with humanitarian aid. From our point of view, this type of crisis should not be militarized, nor should this kind of instrument be used to appear supposed aid that we are not giving, but endorsing.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the on-going migration, refugee and security crisis. The proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument under Heading 3 in the draft General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 for an amount of EUR 530 million translates to the full amount available for this instrument in 2017 under the current MFF rules. However, that budgetary flexibility has its limits and can only be a short-term solution for unexpected events that then need to be addressed with ordinary budget lines. Even with the systematic mobilisation of the totality of the Flexibility Instrument under Heading 3 in the coming years, the financial resources available will not be sufficient to tackle the increased needs. I voted in favour because I believe that the fair and transparent distribution of funding between the different objectives of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund is one of Parliament’s priorities.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this decision is to provide an additional 530 million to Union instruments for migration, refugees and security. I am opposed to the overall orientation of funds devoted to the migration and refugee crisis, the so-called 'Fortress Europe', for turning European borders into open air prisons and tombs for thousands of migrants. I call for respect for the right to asylum and that a genuine development and peace strategy be put in place for the countries of origin of migratory flows, which requires a specific increase in the European budget rather than the proposed patches. That is why I voted against.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: The purpose of the flexibility instrument is to allow the financing of identified expenditure whether it cannot be financed within the ceilings of one or more headings of the EU budget. The mobilisation of the flexibility instrument relates to the need to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 with a view to financing commitment appropriations under heading 3- security and citizenship, so that it will go beyond the limit maximum of this heading for the year 2017 according to the current Multiannual Financial Framework. It is then authorised to mobilise the total since the instrument for 2017amounting to EUR 530 million. Apart from the fact that it is not “new” money, there is insufficient value added to cope with and help to take action against the continued crisis of migrants and refugees. Once again, the MFF amounts (within their limits) fall short of what is needed to cope with repeated crises in the EU, not to mention what is necessary for an effective redistributive policy that will allow disadvantaged countries and regions to approach the richer regions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — EUR 530 million is to be used to deal with the current migration, refugee and security crisis. That's why I couldn't support the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I reiterate the call for Member States to do much more to tackle the ongoing refugee crisis. While I welcome EU plans and financing of measures, it is clear that much more needs to be done, and in the most part this depends on Member State governments.   Specific measures should be taken to alleviate the plight of unaccompanied minors, as well as gender-sensitive policies to address the needs of refugee women and girls. There is an urgent humanitarian need for a common European response, and I regret the fact that the UK Government has been unwilling to cooperate.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the report on the proposal for a decision of the EP and the Council on mobilising the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures aimed at the current migration, refugee and security crisis. Thus, the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 mobilises the Flexibility Instrument to allocate EUR 530.0 million as commitment appropriations, the amount being used to finance measures to manage the current crisis on migration, refugees and security.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: ‒ The Regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF) authorises the use of the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of expenditure clearly identified that they could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings of the multiannual financial framework. The European Commission, after considering all the possibilities of reallocation of appropriations and exhausted any margin not allocated under the Security and Citizenship expenditure heading, proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument in 2017, amounting to EUR 530 million beyond the ceiling under the same heading 3, to finance measures for the management of the migration crisis, refugees and the security. I am in favour of maximum flexibility within the MFF and the issue of the migration crisis is of certain importance. However, it leaves me puzzled that we do not really want to seek reallocations from less priority budget lines, and that therefore we use these “special” instruments provided by the MFF not to dealing with the problem in a structural way. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument. The purpose of the Decision is to allocate €350 million from the Flexibility Instrument to finance commitment appropriations relating to expenditure on migration, refugees and security. This amount is in addition to the amount of over €1.16 billion taken from the contingency margin. By spending this money now, there is no longer any question of 'flexibility'. The European Parliament does not appear to be able to make clear choices of policy priorities. Already allocation of €350 million from the Flexibility Fund almost irrevocably leads to deficits in other policy areas in 2017 and additional charges for Member States.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the proposal for a decision on mobilising the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. Such a measure is in line with the multiannual financial framework and allows the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance expenditure that goes beyond the approved financial ceilings. I think that this measure is essential in the light of the current migration and refugee crisis. We all agree that this is an exceptional situation, which we should try to bridge in particular within the established budget. But at a moment when it is not possible to adequately finance urgent measures within the approved ceilings, it is necessary to reach for these extraordinary instruments. And while I share the concerns that the decision will exhaust the Flexibility Instrument for the whole next year and will not be able to cover other unforeseen events, the scale and severity of the refugee crisis has given me sufficient reason to support this decision.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the mobilisation of resources from the flexibility instrument is necessary to respond to the current migration, refugee and security crises. I would stress that with this mobilisation of its funds, the flexibility instrument exhausts the total amount available for 2017, which demonstrates the EU's commitment to solidarity with refugees, but also the lack of the Union's own resources.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - The proposed mobilisation of flexibility instruments under the General Draft Budget of the European Union, which would complement the available funds in the budget by EUR 530 million is essential. Since it has been shown that urgent measures concerning migration, refugees and security cannot be adequately funded under the current measures, I support this proposal because I believe it is necessary to minimize the time needed to mobilise flexibility instruments and welcome Commission proposals in the context of a mid-period MFF review seeking to increase budgetary capacity to respond quickly and appropriately to contingencies.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument to finance immediate budgetary measures to address the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis. I support the Commission's proposal to use the Flexibility Instrument to complement the funding from the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017 exceeding the ceiling of Section 3 of EUR 530 million to finance measures in the fields of migration, refugees and security, as the current the situation shows that additional funding of emergency measures will be needed to address this issue.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report intends to enter in the general budget of the Union for 2017 an amount of EUR 50 million in the form of commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances to title of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), in order to ensure a faster response in the event of future natural disasters. This advance - which cannot exceed 10% of the planned financial contribution and in any case EUR 30 million - is granted at the request of a Member State, following a preliminary assessment by of the Commission. The possibility of anticipation of advances is a positive change from the initial version of the EUSF Regulation. For these reasons I voted favourably.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought for the possibility of advanced payments from the EU solidarity fund of up to EUR 50 000 000 to be made available for payments in advance, but the overall maximum amount of the fund, EUR 500 000 000 could not be exceeded. As it only sought advance payments and no increase in funds I supported it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to mobilise €50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which Member States or acceding countries who are victims of natural disasters can make use of. This mobilisation is not linked to a particular disaster but will allow the EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations to be included in the general budget of the Union for 2017. This will allow, if necessary, to mobilize funds more quickly and efficiently. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst agreeing with the principle that money should be mobilised more rapidly, I likewise had certain concerns about the application of the fund and whether appropriate safeguards would be in place to ensure democratic accountability to the spending of the money. I therefore, with some reluctance, followed my Party’s position on this vote.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the purpose of 2017. allocate funds for advances in the general budget of the Union. Article 4a (4) of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 provides that, in order to ensure timely access to budgetary resources, the Fund may be mobilised to pay advances up to an amount of EUR 50 000 000 and the corresponding appropriations entered in the general budget of the Union. Therefore, in order to ensure that the year 2017 The general budget of the Union would provide sufficient budgetary resources in time, and the amount of the Fund of EUR 50 000 000 should be mobilised to pay advances.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The report concerns the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide advances from the general budget of the Union for 2017. As is known, the European Union Solidarity Fund EUSF) was established to express European solidarity with Europe's disastrous regions. The Fund provides financial support to Member States “in the event of major natural disasters, i.e. if the damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's gross national income, whichever is lower. The current proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. Instead, it aims to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the EU budget for 2017 in order to pay advances on a timely and effective basis in the event of a disaster that may occur next year. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which would make it possible to mobilize EUR 50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund, made available to Member States or in the process of accession which would suffer natural disasters. It is only a matter of entering them in commitment and payment appropriations in the general budget of the Union in 2017, which would make them mobilizable much faster.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I endorsed this proposal, which is not related to a particular disaster. Rather, it aims to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the prompt and efficient payment of advances in the event of a disaster next year. It is a direct continuation of a new provision in the amending Regulation which aims to speed up the payment of aid to the affected countries by granting an advance before the final allocation decision is taken, so as to enhance the effectiveness of the Fund.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund was established to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by serious natural disasters and to show solidarity with regions affected by such events. The Šulin report, which I supported today in my vote, calls for the mobilisation of the EUSF for the payment of advances on the general budget of the Union for 2017. This is a technical measure which aims to approve the mobilization of the flexibility instrument amounting to EUR 50 million in commitment and commitment appropriations payment to ensure faster and more efficient payment of advances should disaster occur next year. This measure represents a great victory of Parliament, which can in this way strengthen the effectiveness of the deliveries and reinforce that message of solidarity which underplies the use of the EUSF at the moment to which a Member State is suffering serious damage due to natural disasters.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Patricija Šulin's report. It is a fund dedicated to potential emergencies caused by major natural disasters, which is strengthened. It applies in cases where the disaster causes damage exceeding 3 billion euros, or exceeds 0.6 per cent of the Gross National Income of the affected country. It represents a reinforcement of EUR 50 million in authorisations and payments in order to advance expenditures on time, should such an event happen in 2017.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the mobilisation of the Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances under the general budget of the Union for 2017, which will mobilise an amount of EUR 50 000 000 000 of commitment appropriations and payment from the Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the purpose of prepayment under the general budget of the Union for 2017. The text provides EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations to the general budget of the EU, particularly in the event of an unpredictable natural disaster in a Member State. It is for this minimum of solidarity and to deal with this type of situation in an emergency, quickly and effectively, that cooperation between European nations is necessary. Recent earthquakes in Italy, for example, call for effective and concerted management of economic, social and humanitarian consequences.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund is an important instrument enabling the allocation of European funds to respond to emergency situations caused by serious natural disasters, to help affected populations and territories. The proposal for a decision in question aims to allocate 50 million appropriations of commitments and payments in order to be able to act promptly through the payment of advances if they are due verify catastrophes next year. I think this measure is shareable and that is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies, with a view to solidarity with the population of the regions affected by disasters. This Decision, which I voted in favour, provides in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations, for the timely and effective payment of advances, in the event of a catastrophe.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with disaster-struck regions in Europe. This fund can provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating membership of the European Union in the event of a major natural disaster, i.e. when the total direct damage caused by this disaster exceeds 3 billion. EUR in 2011 prices or 0,6% of the country's gross national income, whichever is lower. Its funds may also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster. It should be noted that the advance may be granted at the request of a Member State and after a preliminary assessment by the Commission of the relevant EUSF application. The amount of the advance should not exceed 10% of the estimated amount of financial support and should not exceed 30 million. EUR. The advance shall be paid without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilisation of the EUSF and the European Commission shall recover the amounts unduly paid to the Member States.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund ('the Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Whenever necessary to ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources, the Fund may be mobilised for the payment of advances up to EUR 50 000 000 by entering the corresponding appropriations in the general budget of the Union. The current proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. It aims to allocate EUR 50 million in the EU budget for 2017 in order to pay advances on a timely and effective basis in the event of a catastrophe next year. The advance may be paid at the request of a Member State after a preliminary assessment by the Commission of the application for mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund. The amount of the advance shall not exceed 10% of the expected financial contribution or EUR 30 million. The Solidarity Fund strengthens the clear political message of solidarity, while ensuring the assistance that the citizens concerned urgently need. The framework for rapid response, including the payment of the advance, will enable the Union to achieve these objectives. The EP therefore supported the inclusion of these amounts in the 2017 budget. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund, which is not related to some particular disaster, but is allocated €50 million in case of some disaster that could possibly happen in 2017.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — To the extent that this provision will make it easier to dispose of European funds, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ As is known, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by recognised natural disasters severity, as well as demonstrating the solidarity of the European institutions with the regions affected by these events. The Fund may provide financial support to Member States and countries engaged in accession negotiations which have been affected by serious natural disasters, i.e. where total direct damage caused by the catastrophe exceeds 3 billion euros. Mobilization of the fund may also be deliberated in the event of a regional disaster. To allow rapid mobilization of the EUSF means cutting down the time of economic intervention in the event of significant natural emergencies and bringing concrete aid to the affected realities. It is an act of responsibility that must see us all agree.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This report aims to facilitate the implementation of advance payments in connection with the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). Specifically, this text calls for the inclusion of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the general budget of the Union, allowing, if necessary, to release funds more quickly during an exceptional natural disaster. We believe that the EUSF embodies the expression of European solidarity and constitutes significant financial support for national and local authorities in the regions affected by this type of disaster. In this context, we consider it appropriate to simplify the functioning of the EUSF and to facilitate the implementation of payments. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the decision in question consenting to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances to the general budget 2017. In fact, the proposal aims to incorporate 50 million in the Union budget appropriations for the timely payment of advances in the event of disasters. This decision is the result of a new provision speeding up the delivery of aid to countries that can be affected. The report stresses that the advance should not exceed 10% of the planned financial contribution and must only be allowed at the request of a Member State and after preliminary assessment of the Commission on the application to the EUSF. The Council decision is fully in line with the meaning of the European Union Solidarity Fund: it represents not only a valid method of financial support, but also a clear message Community solidarity. In order to minimise the timing of mobilization of the fund, it is necessary that this decision is taken from 1 January 2017.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established to enable the Union to financially assist Member States affected by serious natural disasters and to demonstrate solidarity with the people affected by tragic and unexpected events. However, funding must be ensured by speeding up the procedures for disbursement. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the provision of an advance, before the final decision on granting the financing is taken, can improve the effectiveness of the Fund and demonstrate that Europe can move promptly from words to facts, giving concreteness to the political message of solidarity with the communities affected by serious natural disasters. My thoughts and concern are directed at this moment to the populations affected by the dramatic seismic events in Italy, a country to which prompt access to the Fund of EU solidarity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances in the general budget of the European Union for 2017 aims to achieve results faster, to improve the functioning of the European Union and to cooperate between of the Member States. I think that this is a positive proposal, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Positive vote. This proposal for a decision on mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund does not refer to any specific case of natural disaster but aims to include 50 million in the 2017 general budget appropriations, allowing us to act promptly in the event of disasters through advances.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Our Europe is increasingly accustoming to face natural disasters, as sadly known above all to us Italians, I vote convincingly in favor of mobilizing the fund solidarity. This is to ensure the timely availability of resources of EUR 50 million for the payment of advances and the entry of the corresponding appropriations in the general budget of the Union. The adoption of this measure aims to reach more quickly the citizens affected by natural disasters and the devastation that open to the eyes of them in a subitaneous and unpredictable manner. Precisely thanks to this instrument, if the Italian State could submit an application for admission to the fund in accordance with what is required, our populations affected by recent devastation could preparing to a more serene 2017. However, we must recognize how through the use of the fund's resources prevention should be implemented so that this mobilization is not lost, but can create ad hoc structures so as not to have to witness the recurrence of cataclysms. It is believed, to that effect, that this is an investment for a safer future and not just sporadic help.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide for the payment of advances in the general budget of the Union for 2017.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was created to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the affected regions of Europe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating their accession in the event of major natural disasters. I support the Šulin report, which aims to enter in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of 50 million for the payment of advances in an efficient and timely manner in the event of a disaster next year. This is the direct result of the new provision in the 2014amending regulation (Article 4a), urged insistently by the European Parliament and which aims to speed up the disbursement of aid to affected countries by paying an advance before the final decision to allocate aid is made, reinforcing, thus, the effectiveness of the fund.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) has been established to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by severe natural disasters and express the European solidarity with the regions affected by the disaster in Europe. I voted in favour of this measure which aims to speed up the delivery of aid to affected countries through the payment of an economic advance.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We want a Union which would be able to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and not just to express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe. The Fund can provide financial aid to Member States and countries involved in accession negotiations in the event of a ‘major natural disaster’, however, we need to speed up the disbursement of aid to affected countries through the payment of an advance before the final award decision has been taken. This should enhance the Fund’s effectiveness, keeping of course the amount of the advance reasonable, meaning it would not exceed 10% of the financial contribution in our budget.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of launching the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide funds for the payment of advances in the general budget of the Union for 2017. The EFSEU Regulation allows the Commission to mobilise EUR 50 million in the draft general budget for the payment of advances in the following year. Mobilization of these measures ensures the rapid provision of funds in case of natural disasters. Aid involves providing immediate budgetary support to respond to natural disasters. Beneficiaries are able to provide more effective assistance to affected citizens at the same time.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ EUSF has been a significant source of funding for local and regional governments in alleviating the consequences of natural disasters occurring across Europe from floods to earthquakes and forest fires. I agree that the EU Solidarity Fund needs to provide for payment of advances in the 2017 budget. Efforts to invest in climate change mitigation and adaptation must be stepped up. However, I call for the maximum transparency in the awarding, management and implementation of the EUSF.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: The purpose of this report is to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million for the payment of advances through appropriations entered in the general budget of the Union, in particular in connection with the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the provision of an additional EUR 50 million for the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). The EUSF is used to assist victims of natural disasters, but its mobilization is a process that can take time to deal with the urgency of the situation. As a precaution, it is therefore essential that this European financial tool be able to have sufficient funds to grant an advance to the affected territories, even before the decision to mobilise the EUSF is taken.

The aim of this text is to mobilise €50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which Member States or acceding Member States who are victims of natural disasters may have recourse. These funds have no specific purpose, but are intended to deal with a case of force majeure, which we think is useful.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - Unfortunately, natural disasters are one of the things we will never learn to deter and predict. For this reason, we must learn to overcome them as quickly and painlessly as possible. This EUR 50 million of imprest funds will help us to be faster in our actions to rebuild the affected areas.

text: in writing. ‒ I voted for an improvement in the operation of the Solidarity Fund which enables financial assistance to be provided quickly in the event of natural disasters, including paying an advance. Despite my many calls, the UK Government refuses to take advantage of the Solidarity Fund to help overcome disasters in Wales.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following proposal because I welcome the possibility of unravelling the provision of aid to countries affected by natural disasters, including regional level. To this end, I believe that it is necessary to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for a timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 2002, the Solidarity Fund has been operating in the European Union, whose main objective is to respond to natural disasters in Europe and to provide financial assistance to those affected so that they can cope more flexibly and faster with the consequences of such events. The aim of the current proposal is to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in order to allow timely and effective payment of advances in the event of a disaster over the next year. It is very important to know that the amount of the advance should not exceed 10% of the envisaged contribution or a maximum amount of EUR 30 million. Should the European Commission decide later in the process of assessing the payment of the full amount on the ineligibility of the claim, it will be able to recover from the Member State reimbursement of the unduly granted advance.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report to unveil the provision of aid to countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to pay advances to the general budget of the European Union for 2017, as the EU must use all available tools and with foresight to take the necessary steps to react promptly and effectively to the event of unforeseen disasters on its territory.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 30 June 2016 the Commission put forward a proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 50 million (in both commitment and payment appropriations). The proposal is not linked to a specific disaster. Instead, it aims at entering into the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million (in commitment and payment appropriations) to enable a timely and efficient reaction in the event of a disaster occurring next year. The Budget Committee recommends that these amounts be included in the 2017 EU Budget. Therefore this report is directly linked to the agreement on the 2017 EU Budget as a whole.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: ‒ We rightly wanted to assign great importance in this plenary session to the difficult earthquake emergency that has hit central Italy in recent weeks. I therefore find it really appropriate to the coincidence of the approval of the proposal to mobilise EUR 50 million from the outset for the Solidarity Fund for 2017. These figures will be decisive cover to respond to upcoming emergencies.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the EU solidarity fund to provide for the payment of advances in the 2017 budget. I support the Union on responding in an efficient manner to emergency situations due to natural causes.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The current proposal, released from the specific characteristics of a national case or a determined event, allows you to respond effectively and promptly to possible disasters in the first place course next year. I voted strongly in favour of this resolution because it strengthens the bond of solidarity between the peoples of Europe, at the very moment of need. And I think that we need more than anything else. In catastrophic circumstances, the European Union will be able to intervene, both by providing for greater flexibility at the budgetary level and by finding in advance more concrete and shared solutions between partners Europeans to respond to future emergencies. The Solidarity Fund is one of the most effective tools to recover citizens' credibility and trust in the European institutions. Not least, this prediction strengthens cooperation between the Commission and the Member States in the field of budget management and possible crisis situations and should certainly be supported.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion. In total, the European Union Solidarity Fund has raised more than EUR 3.8 billion in connection with more than 70 disasters within 24 beneficiary states and accession countries, and has been used in response to a wide range of natural phenomena, such as earthquakes, flooding, forest fires, storms and, more recently, drought.  I think it is important to develop synergies between the various Union funds and policies with a view to preventing the impact of natural disasters and, in cases where the EUSF is activated, to guaranteeing the consolidation and long-term sustainable development of reconstruction projects. This EUSF is vital in showing the EU’s commitment to helping our fellow humans, not only worldwide but also in the Member States.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to allow the payment of advances to the general budget of the Union for 2017 as this would ensure timely availability of budgetary funds if there is catastrophe. The general budget of the Union for 2017 seeks to bring the amount of EUR 50 million in appropriations for commitments and payments. The Union will help the affected citizens as efficiently and quickly as possible by paying down payments.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I think it is natural to support a report that will make it possible to mobilize funds from the EUSF more quickly and efficiently in the event of a natural disaster affecting a Member State. I voted in favour.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)

text: in writing. ‒ I supported the current proposal for adding EUR 50 million to the annual EU budget for 2017 in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). The EUSF was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe. In this context, the amount of EUR 50 million will definitely enhance the EUSF’s effectiveness and response capacity by speeding up the disbursement of aid to affected regions through the payment of an advance before the final award decision has been taken.
