In general, however, enhanced effectiveness and response capacity of the EUSF means more solidarity, and more solidarity means more EU. Therefore, we should support it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained because this text is essentially technical and only endorsed decisions taken by Member States. Moreover, its budgetary impact is zero.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report because it is intended to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million for the payment of advances should a disaster occur next year. As well, it is recommended that these amounts be included in the 2017 Budget.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 (Article 10) allows the Fund to be mobilised within an annual limit of EUR 500 million above the limits of the relevant financial framework titles. This proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not related to a particular disaster but seeks to introduce in the general budget of the Union for 2017 an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations, in order to pay advances in a timely and efficient way if during next year there is a disaster. This is a direct result of a new provision in the 2014 Amendment Regulation (2) (Article 4a), which seeks to accelerate the payment of aid to affected countries by paying an advance before the final award decision is taken, thereby increasing the effectiveness of the Fund. The amount of the advance should not exceed 10% of the foreseen financial contribution and EUR 30 million. The advance shall be paid without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilisation of the Fund, and the European Commission will ensure the return of unduly paid advances from the Member State. This report recommends that these amounts be entered into the 2017 budget. Since the EUSF is not only another form of EU financial support, it contributes to sending a clear political message of solidarity and at the same time providing much needed assistance to affected citizens, I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal for the European Parliament to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in order to allow for more efficient provision of early advances in the event of disasters over the next year.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to pay advances to the general budget of the Union for 2017, because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: I voted in favour of this text, which aims to mobilise EUR 50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). This fund allows Member States affected by a particular disaster to have recourse to temporary aid. In the present case, this mobilization is not linked to a disaster, but makes it possible to enter this amount in commitment and payment appropriations and, therefore, to be able to access it more quickly and efficiently when necessary.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide for payment of advances in the 2017 budget. Increasing the general budget by the amount of EUR 50 million symbolises solidarity for any Member State that falls victim to the damage caused by a natural disaster. Furthermore, mobilising the budget will contribute to the European Union Solidarity Fund’s aim to enable the Union ‘to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations’. Lastly, mobilising the budget will also ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources as well as enhancing the Fund’s effectiveness.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. — In order to make advance payments in the event of disasters and to respond more quickly, an additional €50 million is to be allocated to the budget. I agree with that.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to mobilise €50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which Member States and acceding countries who are victims of natural disasters may have recourse. This mobilization is not linked to a particular disaster but will allow the €50 million in commitment and payment appropriations to be included in the general budget of the EU for 2017. This will allow, if necessary, to mobilize funds in a more timely and efficient manner. I then voted in favour of this file.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the EU Solidarity Fund is in place to assist Member States in responding to emergency situations related to natural disasters, and advance payments enable the Fund to be mobilised rapidly and, crucially, when it is needed.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the Solidarity Fund is to enable the European Union to respond to emergency situations in order to express its solidarity with the populations affected by natural disasters. The proposal for a Decision seeks to add to the general budget of the Union for 2017 a maximum amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in order to enable rapid and efficient payment of aid advances in the event of natural disasters in 2017, ahead of the final allocation decision. The amount of this advance shall not exceed 10% of the amount of the planned financial contribution and may not exceed EUR 30 million, on the one hand, and the maximum amount granted to the Fund may not exceed EUR 500 000 000, on the other hand. I support this proposal for a decision which allows the EU to meet its responsibilities and show solidarity with countries affected by natural disasters. It seems important to me that it be able to act as quickly as possible to limit the damage and improve the safety and conditions of the affected population.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which highlights that an advance can be granted at the request of a Member State and following a preliminary assessment of the relevant EUSF application by the Commission. The proposal is not linked to a specific disaster. Instead, it aims at entering into the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million (in commitment and payment appropriations) to enable a timely and efficient reaction in the event of a disaster occurring next year.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was established after the flood disasters in 2002. The aim of the Fund is to express the Union's immediate solidarity with countries affected by major natural disasters. Article 10 of the MFF Regulation for 2014-2020 allows the mobilisation of the Fund up to an annual ceiling in 2011 prices of EUR 500 million at 2011 prices, in addition to the ceilings of the relevant headings of the financial framework. In this connection, the Commission has submitted a proposal for a decision to the European Parliament and to the Council, not to alleviate the damage caused by a specific disaster, but to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the Union budget for 2017, in order to ensure that advances can be paid in a timely and effective manner in the event of a catastrophe which may occur next year. In its report, the Committee on Budgets proposes that Parliament approves the proposal for a resolution. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was created with the aim of enabling the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the affected regions of Europe. Article 10 of the MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the mobilisation of the Fund within the annual ceiling of EUR 500 million (at 2011 prices), in addition to the corresponding headings of the financial framework. The current proposal for a decision of the EP and the Council aims to enter in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances in an efficient and timely manner in the event of a possible disaster next year. I endorse the rapporteur's position that the EUSF is not only an EU financial support mechanism, but also a clear political message of solidarity, while providing the necessary assistance to the affected citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to mobilise €50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which Member States or acceding countries who are victims of natural disasters can make use of. This mobilisation is not linked to a particular disaster but will allow the EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations to be included in the general budget of the Union for 2017. This will allow, if necessary, to mobilize funds more quickly and efficiently.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations under the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances. This Solidarity Fund enables the European Union to respond quickly and effectively to an emergency situation linked to the occurrence of a natural disaster.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2002 the European Union Solidarity Fund was set up as a response to major natural disasters and to express the EU’s solidarity towards disaster-struck regions within Europe. Since then it has been used for 72 disasters by 24 different countries. I have voted for this report that will provide payment of advances in the 2017 budget for the EUSF. The advance payment should not exceed EUR 30 million or 10% of the anticipated financial contribution.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file sought for the possibility of advanced payments from the EU solidarity fund of up to EUR 50 000 000 to be made available for payments in advance, but the overall maximum amount of the fund, EUR 500 000 000 could not be exceeded. As it only sought advance payments and no increase in funds I supported it.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because EUR 50 million is to be earmarked for possible disasters.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The Solidarity Fund is designed to cope with natural disasters and a faster system of advance payments is needed to implement it more effectively.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) has been set up to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters. The purpose of this proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is to enter in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million, in commitment and payment appropriations, for the granting of advances in a timely and effective manner in the event of a disaster next year. This is a direct result of the new provision of the 2014 Amendment Regulation, which aims to speed up the disbursement of aid to the affected countries by granting an advance before a final decision on the granting of aid is taken, in order to strengthen it in the way of this effectiveness of the Fund. The EUSF is not only another form of EU financial support, but also contributes to giving a clear political message of solidarity and at the same time providing the necessary assistance to the affected citizens. The possibility of a rapid reaction, including by granting an advance, will help the Union to achieve these objectives.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal by my colleagues because I believe that the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up by the European Union in order to deal with major disasters and offer solidarity to the affected nations. There is a further good reason for voting in favour of this proposal and it is compliance with the MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020; in fact Article 10 states the possibility of mobilization of the fund within an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million. It would also allow us to intervene in a timely manner to the occurrence of disasters to help the affected population. This fund also allows a message of solidarity to be sent to damaged populations so that they do not feel abandoned to their destiny. I therefore voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to allow payment of advances for damage caused by disasters in the territory of the European Union. Since it is likely that more and more disasters will occur in the coming period, caused by technical and technological errors, as well as by the action of nature (e.g. droughts, floods, icy rains, frost, storm winds), it is expected that it will be necessary to prepare funds to help the affected areas allow a speedy recovery and resumption of normal life. It is also likely that most future disasters will have a wider regional context and that it will be difficult to localize the volume and affected area. To this end, it is important to encourage cross-border cooperation and to incorporate a category of such disasters into the existing capacities of funds. Damage to infrastructure, particularly housing, roads and communal capacities must be removed in a short time to allow normal life after a disaster. Advances in this regard play an important role because they allow instant action, without waiting for all procedural requirements to be met in order to allow the state access to funds for recovery of damage caused by a catastrophe of a narrower or wider scale.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text aims to mobilise €50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which Member States or acceding countries who are victims of natural disasters can make use of. This mobilisation is not linked to a particular disaster but will allow the EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations to be included in the general budget of the Union for 2017. This will allow, if necessary, to mobilize funds more quickly and efficiently. I therefore vote in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Within the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, the European Union Solidarity Fund is mobilised to provide an amount of EUR 50 000 000 in commitment appropriations and appropriations for payment of advances. This is a direct result of a new provision defended by the European Parliament, which aims to accelerate the payment of aid to affected countries through advance payments before a final award decision is taken, thereby increasing the effectiveness of the Fund. At the insistence of Parliament in Regulation (EU) No 661/2014, a provision proposes to provide for up to €50 million in commitments and payments each year in the budget to ensure the timely availability of budget funds.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: - This mobilisation is not meant to respond to a specific emergency situation, or to any particular disaster, it is about mobilising EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations from the outset so that in the event of a disaster in 2017, the payment of advances in a more efficient and timely manner. This measure responds to the fair criticism of this fund of the delay in its mobilisation for solidarity aid to Member States in emergency situations.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EFSEU) was established in 2002 to provide financial assistance to countries affected by major natural disasters and regional emergency disasters. Article 4a of the provisions accompanying the inception of this instrument allows the Commission to propose a European Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 50 million in the draft general budget to pay advances in the following year. The Commission presented a proposal to launch the EFSEU totalling EUR 50 million for commitments and payments in May 2016, with a view to paying advance payments to Member States which can be used quickly and efficiently in the event of disasters and natural disasters likely to occur in 2017. I supported the proposal because it provides budgetary support for an immediate response to natural disasters.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Within the framework of the EUSF, I voted in favour of the report to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017, and for subsequent years, the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the prompt and efficient payment of advances in the event of a disaster the following year. This will accelerate the payment of aid to the affected countries by granting an advance before the final allocation decision is taken, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of the EUSF.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations with a view to solidarity with the population of the regions affected by disasters. This Decision, which I voted in favour, provides in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations, for the timely and effective payment of advances, in the event of a catastrophe.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances under the general budget of the Union for 2017. This fund is intended to deal with emergencies resulting from natural disasters. This is one of the important tools of solidarity of the European Union, without which disaster regions would not have been able to recover. This requires that bruised countries receive an advance before final allocation decision, in order to provide effective assistance to affected citizens and to be able to do so quickly. Each year, a maximum amount of EUR 50 million will be entered into the budget in commitment and payment appropriations to ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources. This is a decision that is both positive and necessary.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I support the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to be able to pay in due time from 2017. advances granted to the general budget of the Union. We cannot allow beneficiaries (many of them are municipalities, other public authorities) to fall into debts in order to implement EU-funded projects.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was created to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the affected regions of the rest of Europe. The EUSF aims to provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating their accession when the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's GNI, whichever is lower. The Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the mobilisation of the EUSF within the ceiling of EUR 500 million per year. The current proposal for a decision of the European Parliament (EP) and of the Council intends to enter in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances. This new provision aims to speed up the disbursement of the EUSF to the affected countries by paying an advance before the final decision on its allocation is taken, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of the Fund (this will only be granted after a preliminary assessment by the Commission). As I agree with the content of this report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Union Solidarity Fund provides financial assistance to Member States and candidates who have suffered a serious natural disaster (more than EUR 3 billion or 0,6% of GDP); aid which regions can also receive. In the past, I have criticized the administrative difficulties in accessing the fund and the rigidity of its implementation, as they make it difficult for the available quantities to be spent, despite the increasing frequency of natural disasters. The purpose of this decision is to ensure that 50 million of the total fund is immediately available for any emergency. I think this is a positive step, so I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund to provide for payment of advances in the 2017 budget. On 30 June 2016 the Commission put forward a proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 50 million (in both commitment and payment appropriations). The proposal is not linked to a specific disaster. Instead, it aims at entering [this amount] into the general budget of the Union for 2017 in order to enable a timely and efficient reaction in the event of a disaster occurring next year. This report is therefore directly linked to the agreement on the 2017 EU Budget as a whole.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour. I consider it necessary to ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources of the Solidarity Fund. The Solidarity Fund was established in 2002 after the tragic floods in the EU and serves to express EU solidarity with countries affected by serious natural disasters. In eliminating the consequences of a natural disaster, it is necessary to act swiftly and, therefore, to release as soon as possible the funds to help in doing so.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I approved the transfer of EUR 50 million from the Solidarity Fund to the 2017 budget. I agree with ensuring that financial resources are available in this way for contingencies that may also occur in 2017. This appropriation will be transferred from the Solidarity Fund, which aims to respond in a flexible way to emergencies. However, in order to make certain funds available directly in the budget, part of the allocation to the Solidarity Fund can be transferred. The recent earthquakes that have affected Italy are an example of the tragic events for which these resources can be exploited. However, the funds transferred are not intended for some particular catastrophe, but will represent a reserve for any disasters. In this way, it will be possible to pay advances for disasters over the next year in a timely and effective manner. The procedure chosen by Parliament here started in 2014 and since then these funds have been transferred to the budget every year under the current multiannual financial framework. An advance for contingencies can only be granted if the request is submitted by a Member State in cases of direct assistance to citizens. By making money available in the budget, advances can be paid out more quickly, even before the final decision to grant aid.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Solidarity Fund allows the European Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies, thereby demonstrating its solidarity with the population of those regions affected by natural disasters. The report on the use of the Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances under the general budget for 2017 welcomes the decision of Parliament and of the Council, which concludes that the funds of the Fund of EUR 50 million should be used to pay advances in a timely manner in order to ensure sufficient funding in due time in the general budget of the European Union for 2017. This is the maximum possible amount of use of this Fund, which can be granted in cases where rapid action is required and the appropriations must be made available in due course. This proposal is not related to a specific accident but provides for the introduction of emergency funds into the general budget of the Union so that the funds can be disposed of immediately in the event of future accidents. I supported the Parliament's report in the vote because, in addition to supporting the decision of Parliament and the Council, it contains an important message that the Solidarity Fund is not just one of the forms of EU financial support, but above all a clear political expression of solidarity towards citizens in need.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Solidarity Fund can provide assistance to Member States and countries participating in accession negotiations in the event of a “major natural disaster”. The current proposal aims to ensure that advances can be paid in a timely and effective manner in the event of a disaster during the next year. Among other things, the EUSR contributes to sending a clear political signal of solidarity, while providing the citizens with the much-needed assistance. The Union will be assisted by the ability to respond quickly in achieving these objectives, including through the payment of an advance.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not endorse the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for advances under the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017. This means that the European Union Solidarity Fund will provide for the total budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, EUR 50 000 000 for advance payments. The Solidarity Fund acts as a supranational insurance against natural disasters and I welcome it and disbursements from it in principle. However, there is no reason to make advance payments from this fund. Each State is liquid enough to advance corresponding payments from its own budget lines, in particular with regard to the usually maximum double-digit million amounts that are distributed.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was established in order to respond to emergencies caused by large-scale natural disasters and to express solidarity with the disaster-affected regions. The mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in the amount of €50 million is not related to a particular disaster, but is aimed at enabling payments of advances to the general budget of the Union for 2017. This would allow for rapid and efficient distribution of funds in the event of a disaster during the next year. This proposal is possible because Parliament persisted in 2014 to change the necessary regulations, with the aim of accelerating payments to vulnerable people. I support the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund because it is very important that victims in natural disasters receive assistance immediately in the first moments after the disaster that are the most difficult existentially.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances under the general budget of the Union for 2017. An integral part of the budget package is also a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund providing EUR 50 million to this fund for advances in the event of accidents. The European Union Solidarity Fund is more than just financial support. It is also a political message of solidarity, offering the necessary assistance to the affected citizens. Responding quickly, including through advance payments, will help the Union to achieve these objectives.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU must make use of all available tools and with anticipation to take the necessary steps to respond promptly and effectively to the event of unforeseen disasters on its territory.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund ('the Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations and to express solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters. Whenever necessary to ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources, the Fund may be mobilised for the payment of advances up to EUR 50 000 000 by entering the corresponding appropriations in the general budget of the Union. The current proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. It aims to allocate EUR 50 million in the EU budget for 2017 in order to pay advances on a timely and effective basis in the event of a catastrophe next year. The advance may be paid at the request of a Member State after a preliminary assessment by the Commission of the application for mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund. The amount of the advance shall not exceed 10% of the expected financial contribution or EUR 30 million. The Solidarity Fund strengthens the clear political message of solidarity, while ensuring the assistance that the citizens concerned urgently need. The framework for rapid response, including the payment of the advance, will enable the Union to achieve these objectives. The EP therefore supported the inclusion of these amounts in the 2017 budget. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims at entering into the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million (in commitment and payment appropriations) to enable a timely and efficient reaction in the event of a disaster occurring next year. The proposal is not linked to a specific disaster. As proposed by the Budget Committee, I support these amounts being included in the 2017 EU budget, as it is directly linked to the agreement on the 2017 EU budget as a whole, and in the light of the European Commission’s proposal from 30 June 2016 to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for this amount.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text. This proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a particular disaster. Rather, it aims to include in the general budget of the Union for 2017 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the prompt and efficient payment of advances in the event of a disaster next year.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to allow payment of advances to the general budget of the Union for 2017. The European Union Solidarity Fund established with the aim of providing financial assistance to the Member States of the European Union affected by natural disasters, in order to follow the principles of solidarity of the European Union. This proposal, however, is not related to some already occurring disaster that needs to be remedied. It seeks to introduce 50 million euros in the general budget of the European Union for 2017 with commitment appropriations for the timely payment of advances if a disaster occurs next year. I fully support such precautions, which will facilitate and accelerate the possible process of providing assistance, and I believe that the European Union sets up a quality prevention system and demonstrates a high level of disaster preparedness.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to enable the payment of advances to the general budget in 2017 mobilises EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations and appropriations for payments for advances for 2017. Countries facing major natural disasters or extraordinary regional disasters largely means the timely availability of financial support, so mobilising €50 million to pay advances provides much-needed prompt assistance to citizens. Namely, from experience with floods in Croatia I can conclude that it is extremely important to ensure timely support for citizens who have lost their roof over their heads and thus show their solidarity. As I believe that people affected by such disasters should be provided with timely support, I voted to adopt this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have endorsed the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances under the general budget of the Union for 2017. The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to enable the Union to respond quickly to emergencies caused by serious natural disasters and as an expression of European solidarity with the affected European regions. This proposal is not related to a specific accident, but is intended to bring EUR 50 million in commitments and payments into the general budget of the Union for 2017 so that advances can be made timely and efficiently in the event of an accident occurring next year. Responding quickly, including through advance payments, will help the Union to express solidarity and provide assistance to affected citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Patricija Šulin's report. It is a fund dedicated to potential emergencies caused by major natural disasters, which is strengthened. It applies in cases where the disaster causes damage exceeding 3 billion euros, or exceeds 0.6 per cent of the Gross National Income of the affected country. It represents a reinforcement of EUR 50 million in authorisations and payments in order to advance expenditures on time, should such an event happen in 2017.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The European Union Solidarity Fund has been established to provide financial assistance to countries affected by major natural disasters and extraordinary disasters of regional scope. The Commission proposed the mobilisation of EU Structural Funds totalling EUR 50 million for commitments and payments in May 2016, with a view to paying down advances to Member States which can be used quickly and efficiently in the event of disasters and natural disasters that may to take place in 2017. So I voted for the resolution above.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was established to enable the European Union to respond to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with Europe's disastrous regions. I supported the present proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Patricija Šulin's report. It is a fund dedicated to potential emergencies caused by major natural disasters, which is strengthened. It applies in cases where the disaster causes damage exceeding 3 billion euros, or exceeds 0.6 per cent of the Gross National Income of the affected country. It represents a reinforcement of EUR 50 million in authorisations and payments in order to advance expenditures on time, should such an event happen in 2017.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide for the payment of advances in the general budget of the Union for 2017.  The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe. The Fund can provide financial aid to Member States and countries involved in accession negotiations in the event of a ‘major natural disaster’. The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the mobilisation of the Fund within the annual ceiling of EUR 500 million (2011 prices), over and above the relevant headings of the financial framework. The current proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a specific disaster. I voted in favour because I believe that the EUSF is not simply another form of EU financial support, but that it also contributes to sending a clear political message of solidarity, while providing much-needed assistance to affected citizens.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this fund is to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations to natural disasters. This proposal calls for the insertion of EUR 50 million into the general budget of the Union for 2017, which is intended for payment advances in the face of any catastrophe in order to be able to act more efficiently. We are talking about a measure subject to prior assessment and which, in any event, cannot exceed 10% of the financial contribution or the maximum amount of EUR 30 million. This initiative will make it easier to act quickly, and always, subject to proportional control in the face of natural disasters, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Union Solidarity Fund provides financial assistance to Member States and candidates who have suffered a serious natural disaster (more than EUR 3 billion or 0,6% of GDP); aid which regions can also receive. In the past, I have criticized the administrative difficulties in accessing the fund and the rigidity of its implementation, as they make it difficult for the available quantities to be spent, despite the increasing frequency of natural disasters. The purpose of this decision is to ensure that 50 million of the total fund is immediately available for any emergency. I think this is a positive step, so I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We are talking about mobilising EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations so that if a disaster occurs in 2017, advances can be paid more efficiently and in a timely manner. This measure responds to the fair criticism of this fund of the delay in its mobilisation for solidarity aid to Member States in emergency situations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - As this report on mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for advance payments under the 2017 budget aims to allocate EUR 50 million for any disasters in the budget to ensure advance payments in the event of catastrophes and thus to respond more quickly in the event of disasters. can, I supported the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Solidarity Funding is an aspect of cross-border support which demonstrates the EU’s core values. This is the kind of solidarity that the UK has benefited from in its more than 40 years of EU membership.  Labour MEPs will continue to stand up for our common European values of solidarity across borders, tolerance, openness and dialogue.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the report on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to make advance payments under the 2017 budget, which provides for EUR 50 million to be entered in the general budget of the Union for 2017 in the form of commitment and payment appropriations . This amount is necessary in order to pay advances more quickly and efficiently in the event of a catastrophe that could occur in the next year. The EUSF is not only another form of EU financial assistance, but it also contributes to sending out a clear political message of solidarity, providing very necessary support to the affected citizens. A rapid response capacity, including by paying an advance, will help the Union achieve these objectives.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The aim of this proposal is to enter into the general budget of the Union for 2017 an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances under the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), to try to ensure a faster response should natural disasters occur next year. It should be noted that the advance is granted at the request of a Member State and after preliminary assessment of the relevant application to the EUSF by the Commission, and that this sum may not exceed 10% of the planned financial contribution and may not be more than EUR 30 million. It should be recalled that the MFF Regulation for 2014-2020 allows the mobilisation of the EUSF within an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million, above the limits of the relevant headings of the MFF. Surely this tool has obvious gaps, but at the moment it is what is available, and moreover the possibility of predicting advances is a positive change added later than the initial version of the EUSF Regulation.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the provision of advances from the Solidarity Fund. The Solidarity Fund is intended to provide, under conditions, assistance to countries affected by natural disasters. It is proposed to allocate €50 million to advance payments from the Fund. The PVV considers it unnecessary for the EU to make funds available for emergency aid. National states can decide for themselves how many and to which other countries they wish to provide assistance. The PVV also considers that it is unnecessary to pay advances on such aid by the EU.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a decision on mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund to ensure the payment of advances under the general budget of the Union for 2017. Since its establishment in 2002, the Solidarity Fund has been an important means of financial assistance to Member States affected by natural disasters. It is also a way to show Member States that, in the event of natural disasters, they will not be left alone to rebuild the destroyed regions, but will receive assistance and solidarity from other EU members. At the same time, the number of applications for mobilisation of this fund that have been recorded since its creation shows how much the fund is needed and valued. That is why I welcomed this proposal, which will mobilise EUR 50 000 000 from next year's budget, which will be used to pay advances. In the event of natural disasters, in particular, the speed at which the financial assistance is granted is invaluable. And it is this decision that will ensure that recovery advances will be provided in the shortest possible time.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund to pay advances under the general budget of the Union for 2017. The purpose of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to demonstrate its solidarity with the population of areas affected by natural disasters. Therefore, I consider it justified to provide for the payment of advances an amount of EUR 50 000 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations in order to enable the effective implementation of the Fund.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: in writing. — Today the European Parliament voted on the final settlement between the Council and Parliament on the EU budget for 2017. The EU needs a budget to work, and in order to show respect for the agreement agreed by the Member States, I chose to vote yes. I and the Christian Democrats highlighted the party's stance on the budget issue in the first reading of the budget in October. The Christian Democrats are clear that we need to reform the EU and focus on the core tasks. This means an ambition to gradually reduce spending on farm subsidies, industrial subsidies and regional policy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report is the subject of the final agreement for the 2017 budget, obtained at the end of the conciliation procedure on 17 November. The European Parliament has obtained the inclusion in the budget of certain increases, in particular, among others, those for Heading 1 a, for the Youth Employment Initiative, for Heading 4 (Palestine) and for the staff of certain agencies linked to heading 3 (Europol, Eurojust, EASO). We also need to point out the forecast of 76 new jobs for political groups, under pressure from the EPP and S&D, but there are several criticalities, including a lack of well-defined political priorities. and necessary cuts in order to make this budget sustainable and credible even towards the citizens of Europe. Continuous increases in administrative and bureaucratic costs (just think of a retroactive adjustment of the wages of EU staff by 3.3%) have therefore led me to vote negatively.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — If we are to address the refugee crisis seriously, encourage growth and address the still unacceptable levels of youth unemployment, we need a well-funded and flexible Community budget. The budget we are adopting today is a step in the right direction. We have managed to obtain an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, a priority for our group. This will ensure that millions of young Europeans have the opportunity to continue to study, train or find their first job. We have also managed to increase funding for programmes that drive development and address the causes of the refugee crisis: it has been agreed to add €700 million to increase aid to neighbouring and developing countries, and we have secured an increase in funding to support Palestinian refugees. For all these reasons, the Spanish Socialist delegation to the European Parliament voted in favour of the Union's budget for 2017.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – For this file, I voted against. Despite the extra financing for the EU Youth Unemployment Initiative, this remains the most draconian budget in decades and this is reflected on the basis on the volume of cuts to funding to a number of progressive and social programmes that the Council have pushed through. Despite the all efforts and requests from the European Parliament, Member States within the Council, in particular from the right-wing governments of the wealthier Member States, were lacking in solidarity towards the rest, [and this] was apparently a recurring feature of the negotiations.  The hallmark of this budget is that it indicates that austerity politics and policies driven by the Council will continue for the foreseeable future. Fundamentally there will also be cuts to tackling climate change, cuts to the European Institute for Gender Equality, social and cohesion funding which was forecast to be a 23.5 % reduction compared to 2016. All this whilst Trust funds for Turkey, Africa, etc. are to be reinforced. .

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text is a compromise text between the 2017 budget as voted by MEPs on 26 October and the Council's initial proposals. Most budget lines are thus retained. Parliament's initial ambition is being revised downwards. In detail, resources devoted to migration and security increased by 11.3% and 12% for growth and employment (including Erasmus+), which are the priorities shown in this budget. It should be noted that EUR 500 million is being mobilized to help the agricultural sectors affected by crises, particularly the dairy sector. The budget also endorses and welcomes the Trust Funds and Facility for Refugees in Turkey, which is not acceptable. In conclusion, while this budget is indeed better than that adopted by the European Parliament on 26 October, it is nevertheless excessive (the target of 5% reduction of staff in administrations decided in 2013 and whose deadline comes in 2017 is not the subject of any serious follow-up, for example) and particularly immigrationist. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose the increased spending on the European Union budget. British taxpayers, having voted to leave the European Union, would be shocked to find that we are being expected to send more money to the European Union next year.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on the allocation of the budget for 2017. In total they allocated EUR 157.86 billion for commitments. This sum has increased by almost EUR 3 billion from the 2016 commitments. The budget also leaves EUR 1.1 billion in order to be able to react to unforeseen events. The passage of this budget is extremely vital for the upcoming year. There is about 11.3% more money since 2016 dedicated to dealing with the migration and refugee crisis. The new budget also focuses on growth of the economy and youth prosperity. The Erasmus+ has been increased by 19%, [and this,] paralleled with an increase in funds to create new jobs, will boost economic growth. Youth is also aided in the employment sector by an additional EUR 500 million to help find jobs for young people. The budget also opens the doors for the Commission to be able to start their initiative that would let young people travel around Europe with ease. All in all the budget not only faces the current issues such as the refugee crisis, but it also looks into the future, both economically, socially, and culturally.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the general draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, which was approved by the Conciliation Committee during the budgetary procedure. This project provided more funding for youth employment, small and medium-sized businesses, transport infrastructure, research, as well as for the student exchange programme Erasmus+.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. The report is on the common text of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the context of the budgetary procedure. The report goes through the items agreed between the Council, the Commission and Parliament within the Conciliation Committee. The most important figures for the 2017 budget are: commitment appropriations: €157.9 billion, payment appropriations: €134.5 billion. Perhaps the most controversial issue during the conciliation was the 5% reduction in staff. In my opinion, the budget is a symbol of the EU's neoliberal economic policy, and this is, above all, in constant restrictions, such as the proposed 5% redundancy, which, by the way, makes no sense other than satisfying the completely misguided German neoliberal economic policy approach. Although a budget is obviously necessary for the Union to function, I have rejected this budget because of the neoliberal economic policy of the EU, expressing our disagreement with the Union's economic policy with tragic results.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: This budget, although better than the one adopted on October 26, 2016, is still excessive and particularly immigrationist. I voted against this text, which does not take seriously certain areas that can be the subject of real savings, sometimes already clearly identified, such as the target of 5% reduction of staff in administrations, decided in 2013 and still very little followed when the deadline will come in 2017.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I approved this report on the common draft general budget of the EU for 2017 as approved by the Conciliation Committee, which contains, inter alia, the call for the flexibility instrument for 2017 to provide the sum of EUR 530 million in commitment appropriations to address the migration and security situation.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union has faced crucial challenges in recent years which have challenged its ability to intervene effectively in an increasingly changing environment. Migration, natural disasters, investment strengthening needs for growth, jobs and security are some of the key issues that require strong capacity for action. The Geier-Tarand report, which I supported, endorses the draft budget 2017, the result of conciliation with the Council. The text focuses on a number of priorities: greater support for unemployed young people, funds to increase major initiatives for SMEs, transport infrastructure projects, research and mobility of students with Erasmus+. The commitment appropriations in the 2017 budget amounted to €157.86 billion and EUR 134.49 billion in payment appropriations. Particularly important is the EUR 500 million earmarked for YEI, the Youth Employment Initiative, a concrete sign of the EU going in the right direction and which is alongside the €728 million aimed at increasing funds for migration. The medium-term objective remains to have a more flexible budget, able to mobilise funds to meet the most important priorities.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against. The budget proposed by Parliament already accepted cuts, only partially compensating for Commission and Council positions, and finally after the negotiation we have one of the most austere budgets known for a long time, following the intransigence of the Council and the richest countries. The budget will remain with €157 857.8 million in Payment Authorizations (CA) and €134 490.4 million in Payments, which represents a real cut of more than 6.4% and 1.7% more in credit. The budget is more flexible to provide space and recourse to more security and migration measures. The main victims will be agriculture, the administration of institutions and decentralized agencies. Basically it involves reducing Member States' contributions to an already low budget, mobilising contingency margins and flexibility in order to be able to address additional expenditure for the treatment of migration processes, strengthening the European Sustainable Development Fund (a kind of Juncker Plan for containment migration in neighboring countries) and the Turkey Trust Fund (Refugees).

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - With my positive vote, I supported the agreement on the budgetary procedure for 2017, after going through the conciliation process with the Council. The approved documents are as follows: the list of unchanged budget lines with regard to the draft budget or position of the Council, the summary of the figures by heading of the financial framework, a consolidated document with an indication of the figures and the final text of all the lines which have been amended within the framework of conciliation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report on the 2017 budget and the result of the compromise reached between the positions of the European Parliament and the Council. Admittedly, Parliament's disproportionate ambitions are being revised downwards, reaching EUR 157.857 billion in commitment appropriations and an overall amount of payment appropriations of EUR 134.490 billion, compared with Parliament's initial position of 161.8 billion commitment appropriations and EUR 136.8 billion in payment appropriations. There is still a 1.9% increase in commitment appropriations compared to financial year 2016. Moreover, the resources mobilized are only intended to finance the migration slump caused by the irresponsibility of the European Commission's policy in this area. In fact, resources devoted to migration and security increased by 11.3%. The priority of European decision-makers is more in the integration of migrants than in the fight against unemployment among Europeans. Finally, where did the target of 5% reduction of staff in European administrations go? Supposed to be reached in 2017, it seems to have passed under the carpet of crazy European ambitions.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have abstained in respect of these three reports. On the one hand, I support redisposing of resources and being put into supporting refugees arriving in the EU. On the other hand, much of these resources are spent on Frontex and the further construction of Fortress Europe, as well as the shameful refugee agreement with Turkey, which I strongly oppose. As the budget is made, the different parts are not separated from each other. That is why I have chosen to abstain in these ballots.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — If we are to address the refugee crisis seriously, encourage growth and address the still unacceptable levels of youth unemployment, we need a well-funded and flexible Community budget. The budget we are adopting today is a step in the right direction. We have managed to obtain an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, a priority for our group. This will ensure that millions of young Europeans have the opportunity to continue to study, train or find their first job. We have also obtained an additional EUR 200 million for programmes aimed at boosting research and innovation, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, helping to promote cross-border infrastructure projects and to encourage aid for students to study in different Member States of the Union. In addition, we have managed to increase funding for programmes that drive development and address the causes of the refugee crisis: it has been agreed to add EUR 700 million to increase aid to neighbouring countries, and developing, we have secured an increase in funding to support Palestinian refugees. For all these reasons, the Spanish Socialist delegation to the European Parliament voted in favour of the Union's budget for 2017.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the budgetary procedure for 2017 (general draft). A comprehensive package of 78 pilot projects/preparatory actions was agreed, i.e. as proposed by the European Parliament, complementing the preparatory actions proposed by the Commission in the draft budget for 2017. Where a pilot project or preparatory action is subject to an existing legal basis, the Commission may propose that appropriations be transferred to the relevant legal basis in order to facilitate the implementation of that action. This package shall take full account of the ceilings laid down in the Financial Regulation for pilot projects and preparatory actions.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is essential to keep up with the EU budget with the implementation of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 by Member States and to have cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. The EU budget has the resources to allow the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated in implementing Member States' projects. We have also managed to ensure that the funds mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. Finally, the 2017 EU budget does not contain provisions on penalties for Member States rejecting compulsory reception quotas. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the 2017 Budget Procedure.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: This draft common budget between Parliament and the Council is certainly down from the initial budget, which is a good thing, but the part devoted to migration is up by 11.3%, total expenditure remains excessive and no follow-up to the objective of reducing the staff of the administration is specified. Therefore, I am voting against this joint project, which, moreover, supports the facilities put in place in favour of refugees from Turkey, which is totally unacceptable.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The budget of the European Union accounts for about 1% of the EU's gross national income, therefore it is complementary to national budgets. The 2017 draft budget must take into account the willingness expressed by the people of Britain to leave the European Union. The draft budget reflects and supports the political priorities set by Commission President Juncker; it also seeks to provide a European response to the challenges of migration management, combat against terrorism and organised crime, protection of the external borders of the Union and cooperation with neighbouring regions of the EU. Some of the budget's key priorities relate to jobs, growth and investment since, even as the European economy continues its recovery, growth forecasts remain subdued. There are other sectoral priorities to take into account in the budget, such as security of energy supply, research and innovation and climate action (COP21). Finally, the fight against cybercrime, effective border management and the defeat of terrorism are also crucial.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This is a compromise text from the conciliation committee between Parliament and the Council. This report sets the amount of commitment appropriations for 2017 at €157.857 billion, an increase of 1.9% compared to 2016. Payment appropriations fell by 6.5% to €134.49 billion: this is the result of the finalisation of the programmes of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2007/2013 while the 2014/2020 MFF programmes have not yet been completed. Although this joint project allocates an additional EUR 500 million to the agricultural sector, it does not address the roots of the problems faced by producers, namely the decline in commodity prices, the Russian embargo and unfair international competition exacerbated by the increase in free trade agreements. In addition, this text provides for an increase of 11.3% in the budget dedicated to the reception of illegal migrants. This is a real scandal with regard to the dramatic rise in unemployment and poverty rates, especially among young people, in the Member States of the European Union. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — In drawing up the 2017 budget, account must be taken of the main common policy priority to reduce youth unemployment by using available budgetary resources, making full use of the Youth Employment Initiative, in the best possible way. At the same time, an ordinary development of payments in relation to appropriations for commitments must be ensured, in the context of execution, in order to avoid an abnormal event of overdue factors at the end of the year. I voted in favour of the 2017 Budget Procedure: the joint draft budget because it requires a budget that is as rich as possible and divided into the main development arteries, such as reducing youth unemployment, but also to cover the needs of each Member State, which is necessary for local, but at the same time European development.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament and the Council formally adopted the budget of the European Union for 2017. The budget amounts to 157,857.8 million euros in commitments and EUR 134,490.4 million in payments. Funding for many very important programmes for European citizens has been increased. An additional 200 million euros have been added to Horizon 2020 programmes, for the Connecting Europe Facility, Erasmus+ and COSME. €500 million has been added to the Youth Employment Initiative. In addition, farmers affected by the Russian embargo will receive €500 million in aid. The resources of the new European Border and Coast Guard Agency have been significantly increased. This budget responds to the needs of the European Union in terms of growth, employment and management of agricultural and migration crises. I voted in favour of the European Union budget for 2017.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report. From the 2017 budget, there are timid signs for boosting growth, job creation - especially for young people - and tackling the migration crisis. In this direction, for example, are the additional EUR 500 million that the European Parliament has managed to obtain for the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) and the additional EUR 200 million which Projects for growth and employment (COSME, CEF, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+) will increase. However, I regret the reduction of the commitments to Mediterranean countries to EUR 332 million from the 340 originally planned and, for the postponement, due to the lack of legal basis, of financing the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) of 250 million in order to address the root causes of migration.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ For this file, I voted against. Despite the extra financing for the EU Youth Unemployment Initiative, this remains the most draconian budget in decades and this is reflected on the basis on the volume of cuts to funding to a number of progressive and social programmes that the Council have pushed through. Despite the all efforts and requests from the European Parliament, Member States within the Council, in particular from the right-wing governments of the wealthier Member States, were lacking in solidarity towards the rest, and this was apparently a recurring feature of the negotiations.  The hallmark of this budget is that it indicates that austerity politics and policies driven by the Council will continue for the foreseeable future. Fundamentally there will also be cuts to tackling climate change, cuts to the European Institute for Gender Equality, social and cohesion funding which was forecast to be a 23.5 % reduction compared to 2016. All this whilst Trust funds for Turkey, Africa, etc. are to be reinforced.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This was the final agreement on the EU budget for 2017 which would increase by 1.7% from 2016 (a EUR 2.5 billion increase) – meaning the final EU budget for 2017 would be set at just over EUR 157 billion. The UK is forecast to contribute over EUR 17.3 billion gross (after taking in to account the UK rebate). UKIP opposes this increase in the EU budget.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This is the final agreement for the 2017 budget. It has great criticalities, including a clear lack of political priorities and the necessary economies to make this European budget sustainable and credible even towards the citizens: increases in administrative and bureaucratic costs (last a retroactive adjustment of EU staff wages by 3.3%) make us understand how the reality living in Brussels is disconnected from life daily in different European countries.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. As this report does not address sufficiently issues directly affecting citizens and their rights, I do not think it will have the desired results, and I therefore voted against it.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Absolutely negative vote. We cannot support a budget that squanders citizens' money to fund bankruptcy policies.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I strongly endorse the joint draft budget because I believe it has finally taken a closer direction to the emergencies that the Member States had to find themselves to face with many difficulties, years ago are perhaps even remotely imaginable. In fact, it provides for more appropriations and widening margins on the funds needed not only by the migration crisis, but also by natural disasters which, in the year it is preparing to end, they have sapped Europe in its essence. It is therefore commendable that the project contains: a total level of commitment appropriations of EUR 158 billion and payment of EUR 134 billion, the level of the flexibility instrument will be EUR 530 million as well as that of the overall margin for commitments and contingencies will be mobilised for EUR 1.4 and 1.9 billion respectively. However, I would like to call for more attention to the eradication of youth unemployment through an increase of EUR 500 million to the Youth Employment Initiative. Equally, with regard to our agriculture, which has recently been scourged by difficult market situations, relevant budget proposals should be dealt with.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has always argued that the Union Budget for 2017 had to respond to the needs linked to the challenges of migration and the slowdown in growth following the economic crisis. To this end, following the presentation of the budget by the Commission, the European Parliament tabled a series of amendments aimed at responding to the challenges of migration and the slowdown in economic growth. This report, which I support, expresses the agreement reached by the Conciliation Committee on the Union budget, in which the European Parliament endorses its suggestions for amending the Union budget, namely 200 million new appropriations for Horizon 2020, Erasmus+, Cosimo and the Connecting Europe Facility; 500 million in new appropriations for the Youth Employment initiative, a major 530 million increase for migration issues, as well as the increase in appropriations for farmers worth 500 million. Parliament also saw the adoption of the strengthening of human and budgetary resources of various Union agencies, notably EUROJUST, EUROPOL and EASO.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure as it complies with what has already been set out in the multiannual budget and has growth and jobs as a priority. The measure also provides important support to students through an increase in funds for the Erasmus programme and SMEs. Finally, there is also a strengthening of Europol and Eurojust facilities to stem illegal immigration to Europe and manage the refugee crisis.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the overall level of commitment appropriations in the 2017 budget as well as the overall level of payment appropriations. Reducing youth unemployment remains a high and shared political priority, and to this end I reaffirm that we should be determined to make the best possible use of budgetary resources available to tackle it, in particular through the Youth Employment Initiative. I expect an orderly progression of payments in relation to the appropriations for commitments so as to avoid any abnormal level of unpaid invoices at year-end.  In this sense, I agree that the Commission should continue monitoring closely and actively the implementation of the 2014-2020 programmes, inviting the Commission to present in a timely manner updated figures concerning the state of implementation and estimates regarding payment appropriations requirements in 2017.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Common Text on the Budget Procedure for 2017 because it guarantees a balance between the implementation of current EU programmes and the provision of resources for new challenges. The budget secured the existing amount for Poland, allocated to payments under the Cohesion Fund, which means Poland's negotiating success. The budget provided funds to finance external border protection and security in the EU in accordance with Poland's postulates. The 2017 budget strengthens the actions implemented by the EU outside its borders to eliminate the causes of migration in countries of origin and transit while strengthening efforts towards the countries of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it recognises the need for a higher budget allocation to be able to tackle new realities. Thus the 3.8% addition to  the budget when compared with the 2016 allocation is a positive step in order for the European Parliament to have the financial tools needed to keep working effectively.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report covers the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017. The overall amount of commitment appropriations was set at EUR 157.86 billion. Parliament called for better employment support for young people, while adding additional funds to strengthen key initiatives for SMEs and security and migration. It has also obtained an increase in funds dedicated to managing agricultural crises. Considering that the budget is the Union's armed arm to meet the current challenges and expectations of European citizens, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This was the final agreement on the EU budget for 2017 which would increase by 1.7% from 2016 (a EUR 2.5 billion increase) – meaning the final EU budget for 2017 would be set at just over EUR 157 billion. The UK is forecast to contribute over EUR 17.3 billion gross (after taking in to account the UK rebate). UKIP opposes this increase in the EU budget.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I supported the report on the common draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure. The European Union budget for 2017 includes, inter alia, a substantial additional allocation for internal and external aspects of migration, additional posts for the European Police Office (Europol) and the European Union Judicial Cooperation Unit (Eurojust) and an increase in commitment and payment appropriations for the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). In addition to the security and migration aspects, it is essential that the available budgetary resources be used to address the problem of youth unemployment, in particular the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted globally in favour of this 2017 budget, although I have been and remain radically opposed to the creation of 76 additional posts for the political groups in the European Parliament; this indiscriminate increase in staff of the political groups leads to the elimination of an equivalent number of posts within the administration of the European Parliament, which is unjustifiable to me. Apart from that, I am delighted to include in this budget the priorities which my political group has always advocated, and in particular that for youth, thanks to the increase in funds to combat youth unemployment but also funds for the mobility of students and apprentices. We also meet our priorities to encourage initiatives for small and medium-sized enterprises, support research and infrastructure projects, and those aimed at managing the migration crisis and strengthening security within the EU's borders.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is essential to keep up with the EU budget with the implementation of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 by Member States and to have cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. The EU budget has the resources to allow the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated in implementing Member States' projects. We have also managed to ensure that the funds mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. Finally, the 2017 EU budget does not contain provisions on penalties for Member States rejecting compulsory reception quotas. The socialists and liberals have proposed a budgetary mechanism that would penalise Member States which, despite the mandatory resettlement quota system, do not accept illegal immigrants into their countries. This attack was averted during the adoption of the 2017 budget. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This is a compromise text between the Council and the European Parliament on the 2017 budget. Most budget lines are retained, with an increase in commitment appropriations of 1.9% and a decrease in payment appropriations by 6.5%. There has been an increase in the resources allocated to migration. In addition, there are no significant changes in this budget, which remains on the rise. In particular, the target of 5% reduction in staff costs has not been seriously monitored.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. -I voted against this report. As a result of the vote, Parliament's position will result in a net increase of EUR 4.07 billion for commitment appropriations and EUR 2 450 000 000 for payment appropriations, above the Commission's proposal. This represents almost 160 700,000 euros for commitments and €136 700,000 for payments. With the amount set after negotiations at EUR 157 860,000 for commitments (1.7% increase compared to 2016) and EUR 134.5 billion for payments (1.6% reduction), the Council agreed to contribute an additional EUR 200 million to Horizon 2020, COSME, the Connecting Europe Facility and Erasmus+. Another 500m euros are earmarked for the Youth Employment Initiative. I decided not to support the proposal because there were no reserves available on a number of statutes, no redistribution from wasteful budget lines to priority areas, and because this budget could deepen the gap between commitments and payments. Additional and very important: the report does not provide for the financing of anti-terrorism measures which, in light of the current political situation, must be our concern and priority.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The budget of the Union must take account of current adverse situations and seek to address them, while at the same time having as its main concern the well-being of citizens of all Member States. Its level of flexibility needs to be high enough to be able to cope with new challenges and the already emerging threats.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is essential to keep up with the EU budget with the implementation of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 by Member States and to have cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. The EU budget has the resources to allow the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated in implementing Member States' projects. We have also managed to ensure that the funds mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. Finally, the 2017 EU budget does not contain provisions on penalties for Member States rejecting compulsory reception quotas.
