The socialists and liberals have proposed a budgetary mechanism that would penalise Member States which, despite the mandatory resettlement quota system, do not accept illegal immigrants into their countries. This attack was averted during the adoption of the 2017 budget. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. I have supported an increase in the EU budget to enable us to act on climate change, build a truly sustainable economy and deal with the crises that face us. This is a missed opportunity. The final deal is very different from the original position of Parliament and I do not believe it is a good agreement for my constituents in Wales. If we say we are going to tackle climate change we must have the resources to do so.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution on the budget since the text shows the full use of available margins concerning a number of headings and since, moreover, the budget sharpens the gap between commitments and payments.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Vote against the general budget of the European Union: net of some useful intervention, there are still many squanders in failed policies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that the European Parliament managed to restore the Commission’s initial proposal on all lines cut by the Council. Furthermore, the Parliament delegation managed to ensure a large amount of fresh reinforcements for the key programmes such as growth and jobs and the Youth Employment Initiative. I also find fundamental the allocation of an additional EUR 500 million to tackle the crisis in the agriculture sector and to support milk and livestock farmers and the additional EUR 5,91 billion to tackle the migration and refugee crisis and reinforce security. Finally, I support the decision taken, in order to accommodate a large part of these reinforcements, to mobilise the special instruments available under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020 Regulation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is essential to keep up with the EU budget with the implementation of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 by Member States and to have cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources to tackle the migration crisis. The socialists and liberals have proposed the introduction of a budgetary mechanism that would have fined Member States which, despite the mandatory resettlement quota system, did not accept illegal immigrants into their countries. This attack was averted during the adoption of the 2017 budget. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2017 budget, considering that it reinforces support for unemployed young people and includes additional funds for initiatives in favour of SMEs, transport infrastructure, research and the Erasmus+ programme. We must bear in mind that Parliament has succeeded in extending the Youth Employment Initiative's funding by 500 million to help young people looking for a job, an additional 200 million to drive key initiatives for growth and jobs, such as COSME, Connecting Europe, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. — If we are to address the refugee crisis seriously, encourage growth and address the still unacceptable levels of youth unemployment, we need a well-funded and flexible Community budget. The budget we are adopting today is a step in the right direction. We have managed to obtain an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, a priority for our group. This will ensure that millions of young Europeans have the opportunity to continue to study, train or find their first job. We have also obtained an additional EUR 200 million for programmes aimed at boosting research and innovation, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, helping to promote cross-border infrastructure projects and to encourage aid for students to study in different Member States of the Union. In addition, we have managed to increase funding for programmes that drive development and address the causes of the refugee crisis: it has been agreed to add EUR 700 million to increase aid to neighbouring countries, and developing, we have secured an increase in funding to support Palestinian refugees. For all these reasons, the Spanish Socialist delegation to the European Parliament voted in favour of the Union's budget for 2017.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I congratulate the delegation of Parliament who negotiated the 2017 budget for having been able to achieve a very satisfactory result: for the first time in many years in fact In addition to a restoration of the figures allocated by the Commission, a major increase is achieved, which will all be devoted to measures to tackle unemployment. This is the sign of a change of step in Europe, which is only beginning and which will have to continue with the most sensitive budget dossier, namely the multiannual financial framework, on which the Commission and Governments They will soon have to show the political will to affect a real breakthrough for growth and solidarity in Europe.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2017 budgetary procedure.  I support the 2017 budget with the consideration of the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF), ensuring a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The 2017 budget is a very sensitive budget, I would call it a “middle budget”, trapped in the logic of the past, but with positive elements, which look at the needs of the Union European today. And it is for these elements that I voted for it. For the increase of key economic growth programmes such as Horizon and Cosme, for the increase of the Erasmus allocation. But above all, I voted in favour of the new appropriations for the Youth Employment Initiative. In my region, Sicily, youth unemployment is more than 50%, a number that makes people lose faith in the future. It is therefore crucial to insist on measures for young people and employment, to bind the use of these resources to concrete actions that create opportunities for real employment, so that they are not dispersed into internships and occasional jobs without perspective. Of course, however, we must stress that it is not a complete budget. The major absentee is again support for the migration crisis, the increase in resources for the Mediterranean countries and the fund for Africa. The 2017 budget is the European Union's first step in a new direction, which will be definitively covered with the Multiannual Financial Framework, where we will not be content.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 which was approved by the Conciliation Committee.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text that approves the joint text on budgetary procedure as agreed by the Conciliation Committee. It consists of the unmodified budget in comparison to the draft budget or the Council’s position, the summary figures by financial framework headings, line-by-line figures on all budget items, and a consolidated document showing the figures and final text of all lines modified during the conciliation.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - After 17 hours of negotiations, a compromise between Parliament, the Commission and the Council was reached on 16 November 2016 in the so-called trilogue procedure on setting the EU budget for 2017. This budget provides for commitment appropriations of EUR 157.86 billion and payments of EUR 134.5 billion. As in previous years, three quarters of this will be used for agricultural and cohesion tasks, some of which is not effective. In particular, net donors pay billions first to Brussels to recover some of these amounts. Instead, net donors should pay to Brussels only the part to the net beneficiary countries, the rest should remain in their national budgets. In addition, only activities that provide appropriate added value and can be better implemented in the European than national or regional level should be financed. This would strengthen the principle of subsidiarity and relieve the burden on the EU budget. In addition, the gap between commitments and payments is again very high, leading to unpaid invoices in the long run. For these reasons, I reject the 2017 EU budget as decided.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the common draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 adopted by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure because I consider the proposal to be balanced and consistent with the current challenges with which the Union faces. Also, this proposal includes the financing of temporary emergency support measures for milk producers, supplemented by a joint declaration for possible future needs during 2017. In addition, the European Commission undertakes to ensure transparency and improve the information provided to the budgetary authorities under current and planned funding, and therefore I support this Report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: We can see an improvement in this budget compared to the previous budget, following a downward revision of Parliament's ambition. However, it is not acceptable to vote in favour of a budget proposal with a high immigrationist dimension and still too excessive. So I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Union budget for 2017. After a first proposal in October when we reversed the Council's unjustified cuts, the definitive project that respects the priorities we had put forward by allocating more money for youth, employment, security or agriculture. We have made this 2017 budget a political tool, in line with current challenges and crises.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I have rejected this report. Funding will be provided to support various programmes (such as support for the Turkish Cypriot community) and, on the other hand, meaningful positions, such as the ESF Social Fund or the Regional Development Fund, need to be reduced.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - After 17 hours of negotiations, a compromise between Parliament, the Commission and the Council was reached on 16 November 2016 in the so-called trilogue procedure on setting the EU budget for 2017. text: in writing. — It is essential to keep up with the EU budget with the implementation of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 by Member States and to have cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the adoption of the European Parliament's 2017 budget because it is an immigrationist. On the other hand, it is unable to effectively reduce staff costs, which had been found to be excessive in 2013.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. — At the second plenary session in October, in the European Parliament, we adopted a more ambitious and voluntary vision of the draft EU budget for 2017, compared to the one originally presented by the Commission. The budgetary negotiations between Parliament and the European Council have preserved the three priorities set by my political group, the EPP: employment, youth and migration crisis. For example, an additional €15 million has been allocated to Erasmus +, a programme that supports the mobility of young Europeans in schools or for training. The budgets of agencies that play a major role in our security, such as Eurojust, Europol and the European Asylum Support Office, have also been strengthened. The same applies to the new European Coast Guard and Border Guard, since the funds previously allocated to Frontex have been doubled. An additional EUR 600 million for the milk sector has been allocated to provide an effective response to the crisis affecting our producers. I therefore voted in favour of the budget agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers, which sets the EU budget for 2017.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the 2017 budget because there are many challenges in Europe that cannot be faced without adequate funding. If we are serious about tackling the migration crisis, boosting growth and eliminating high levels of unemployment among young people, then we need a flexible EU budget. The budget we supported today is not ideal, but it is a step in the right direction. We have been able to assimilate an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, which is a priority for the S&D Group, and will give millions of young Europeans the chance to continue their education, training or get their first job. In addition, EUR 150 million will be allocated to programmes aimed at boosting research and innovation (Horizon 2020) and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME), as well as helping to fund cross-border infrastructure projects (Instrument, Connecting Europe”). It also managed to increase by EUR 50 million funding for Erasmus+, which helps young people learn and work in different member states.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: ‒ N-VA MEPs are strongly supporters of spending that respond to the migration and security crisis, but note that the 2017 budget does not place enough emphasis on this. Under 10% of the EU budget will eventually be spent on measures to strengthen security and asylum policy in 2017. That is why the N-VA delegation has also made proposals to increase funding for Europol and Frontex, the European Border and Coast Guard. Furthermore, N-VA MEPs have a lot of reservations about the unnecessary and cost-consuming issues that Europe is working on, such as the new House of European History, its own limousine service and free Interrail passes for young people. Equally incomprehensible is the accession aid to Turkey, where in recent years we have seen a clear democratic decline rather than progress. That money will once again disappear into the Turkish autocratic forgiveness pit. It is high time for the EU to focus on policies where it has a clear added value.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — If we are to address the refugee crisis seriously, encourage growth and address the still unacceptable levels of youth unemployment, we need a well-funded and flexible Community budget. The budget we are adopting today is a step in the right direction. We have managed to obtain an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, a priority for our group. This will ensure that millions of young Europeans have the opportunity to continue to study, train or find their first job. We have also obtained an additional EUR 200 million for programmes aimed at boosting research and innovation, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, helping to promote cross-border infrastructure projects and to encourage aid for students to study in different Member States of the Union. We have also managed to increase funding for programmes that drive development and address the causes of the refugee crisis: it has been agreed to add €700 million to increase aid to neighbouring and developing countries, and we have secured an increase in funding to support Palestinian refugees. For all these reasons, the Spanish Socialist delegation to the European Parliament voted in favour of the Union's budget for 2017.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is the agreement reached in conciliation with the Council on the 2017 budget.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - This report approves the joint text agreed in the Conciliation Committee, consisting of a list of lines which have not been amended in relation to the draft budget, the total amounts per the headings of the financial framework, the amounts for all budget items, the consolidated document indicating the amounts and the final the text of all lines changed during mediation. The report recalls that reducing youth unemployment remains an important common policy priority and confirms the determination to make the best use of the budget available to address the issue, particularly through the Youth Employment Initiative. The Council and the European Parliament are calling on the Commission to propose an amendment to the 2017 budget in order to provide €500 million to the Youth Employment Initiative in 2017, funded from the overall gap for commitments. It is also necessary to ensure an orderly movement of payments in relation to the appropriations for commitments, in order to avoid any unusual level of unpaid bills at the end of the year. With a view to tackling the main causes of migration, the Commission proposes to allocate €750 million to the EFOR Guarantee Fund during the period 2017 to 2020. The 2017 budget also contains a series of urgent measures to help farmers cope with recent market difficulties. I supported this report.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. With a majority of 438 votes in favour, today in plenary, we approved the European Union budget for next year. The vote on the European Union's annual budget is one of the most important votes in the European Parliament. Parliament shares budgetary powers equally with the Council. This means that MEPs can amend the draft of the Commission and even have the final say on the procedure. The European Union budget for 2017amounts to €157.86 billion. Behind the specific figures are clear political priorities: measures to support young people, create more jobs and tackle the migration crisis. The draft budget has been adjusted by €500 million more to help young people find jobs. I am pleased that, with joint efforts, we have also provided additional funding for Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - After tough negotiations, we have succeeded in putting our priorities into the 2017 EU budget and finding a consensus with the Council. Mainly managed to find EUR 500 million in support of youth employment. This project also resulted in a reduction in youth unemployment by one third in Slovakia. The evaluation of the whole project within the EU is highly positive and therefore it is essential to continue the project. We have succeeded in supporting the activities and funding of small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, who are the largest employer in Europe, for whom it is crucial that they have access to finance their activities. We also found support for research and Erasmus+, but also for infrastructure projects for transport and for tackling the migration crisis. That is why I supported the budget.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, adopted by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the European Parliament Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, as well as because the report in question is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text is a compromise text between the 2017 budget as voted by MEPs and the Council's initial proposals. Compared to 2016, commitment appropriations increased by 1.9% and payment appropriations down by 6.5%. This text welcomes the trust funds set up for refugees in Turkey, which we oppose. Moreover, this budget, although it is better than the one adopted by Parliament on 26 October, is excessive and does not implement structured monitoring in certain areas, which we regret.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on 2017 budgetary procedure: joint text. Just as the report stresses, supporting the procedure will result in ‘ensuring an orderly progression of payments in relation to the appropriations for commitments so as to avoid any abnormal level of unpaid invoices at year-end’. Furthermore, this expresses that the Council and Parliament will take the necessary steps to prevent the accumulation of excessive amount of unpaid bills.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. This proposal supports the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: This text comes from the Conciliation Committee between the European Parliament and the Council, so it is a compromise text between the 2017 budget as voted by MEPs and the Council's initial proposals. Most budget lines are thus retained. Parliament's initial ambition is therefore revised downwards, and Parliament is only able to increase these appropriations' only 'by €1.4 billion and EUR 0.7 billion compared to the Council's initial proposals. In detail, resources devoted to migration and security increased by 11.3% and 12% for growth and employment, which are the priorities of this budget. The budget also welcomes the Trust Funds and Facility for Refugees in Turkey. In conclusion, while this budget is indeed better than that adopted by the European Parliament on 26 October, it is nevertheless excessive (the target of 5% reduction in staff in administrations decided in 2013 and whose deadline comes in 2017 is not the subject of any serious follow-up, for example). Therefore, I have been unfavourable to this text.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it concludes the budgetary procedure for 2017 and confirms that the commitment will stand at EUR 157.8 billion.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In the same way as in the report on the general budget of the Union for 2017, I voted in favour of the joint draft general budget of the EU for the financial year 2017 because it fully encompasses what the Union needs to cope effectively with its challenges and responsibilities. On the one hand, this project will enable the Union to respond adequately to the challenges posed, such as migration management (for which EUR 5.3 billion is foreseen), the fight against terrorism and organised crime, the protection of the Union's external borders, and partnership with neighbouring regions of the Union and other third countries. On the other hand, we will have to be able to meet the political priorities of the Union, such as jobs, growth and investment.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the 2017 budgetary procedure since I am in agreement with the joint text.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — On 18 July 2016, the Commission adopted the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. On 12 September 2016, the Council adopted its position on this matter and forwarded it to Parliament. Parliament adopted its resolution on this matter on 26 October 2016, adding a number of budgetary amendments to the draft. The Conciliation Committee composed of delegates from Parliament, the Council and the Commission adopted the joint text. In its report, the European Parliament delegation to the Conciliation Committee proposes that Parliament approves this joint text, thereby definitively adopting the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - This report on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the framework of the budgetary procedure, deserves my vote in favour of that report. It should be stressed that the EP, the Council and the Commission maintain the reduction of youth unemployment as an important political priority and, in view of this, reaffirm their determination to make the best use of the available budgetary resources to deal with this problem, in particular through the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI). I argue that the margins that have become available below the MFF ceilings for commitment appropriations for the financial years 2014-2017 constitute a Global MFF margin for commitments, to be made available beyond the ceilings set out in the MFF for the years 2016 to 2020, having in view of policy objectives related to growth and jobs, in particular youth employment, as provided for in Article 14 (1) of Council Regulation (EU, EURATOM) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — While this budget is indeed better than the one adopted by the European Parliament on 26 October, it is nevertheless excessive (the target of 5% reduction in staff in administrations decided in 2013 and whose deadline comes in 2017 is not the subject of any serious follow-up, for example) and particularly immigrationist.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text on the 2017 budgetary procedure. The objective here is to set out the political agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the budget reached on 17 November. This budget amounts to EUR 157 857.8 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 134,490.4 million in payment appropriations. This budget will help, in particular, at a time when the European Union is facing an unprecedented migration crisis, to strengthen Frontex's workforce and resources.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report regarding the draft general budget of the EU for 2017 that was approved by the Conciliation Committee following the budgetary procedure. The 2017 budget sets, amongst other things, commitment appropriations at EU 157 857.8 million, payment appropriations at EUR 134 490.4 million, commitment appropriations for the Flexibility Instrument at EUR 530 million, commitments to the global margin for competitiveness for growth and jobs at EUR 1 439.1 million and the contingency margin at EUR 1 906.2 million.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the 2017 budget because I believe it is balanced and correctly points out the main funding directions for next year. As the document to be voted underlines, it is of paramount importance that the YEI funding for youth employment be increased, within the limits of available funds. Also, ensuring timely payment of bills and avoiding a large number of arrears at the end of the year is a very important issue for avoiding financial bottlenecks at European level.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement of the EP and the Council on the 2017 budget, knowing that most of the priorities of the EP have been defended, such as additional funds to support small and medium-sized enterprises, science and research, transport infrastructure and a youth guarantee program. In addition to this indisputable success, however, it cannot be missed that certain cuts are being made to the Global Europe chapter, namely the budget item Emergency Measures, Asylum and Migration and the European Fund for sustainable development, for which this can be explained by the fact that it has not yet been officially established. But limiting funds for asylum and migration sends an egregious political signal. I personally consider these areas a priority and, in line with the assurances that have been sounded, I anticipate that there will be a renewal of these appropriations in the next year in the form of an amending budget.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report because I cannot see that resources are being allocated, for example, to promote the participation of young people in democratic life in Europe. The report has neither a factual focus nor a task discipline.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Negotiations have resulted in a common EU budget, including funding for the refugee crisis and peace processes in the vicinity of Europe, greater support for Eurpol and also reducing poverty in the Eastern Partnership countries.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I welcome the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, which focuses on economic growth, job creation, especially for young people, and management of the migration crisis. It is welcome that the negotiations with the Council of the EU have succeeded in ensuring that more funds are allocated to critical areas, in particular youth employment, small and medium-sized businesses, transport infrastructure, research, as well as the student exchange programme Erasmus+. Given the importance and benefits of the Youth Employment Initiative, it is very important to provide it with adequate and adequate funding. I therefore believe that an additional EUR 500 million will help to implement it effectively in all Member States. Particular attention must be paid to research, which is essential for the development of innovation, and to the Connecting Europe Facility, as it is a tool for attracting investment. The additional funds will help restore the budgets trimmed by these measures and increase investment opportunities for small businesses, and provide greater support for local communities, researchers and students.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. — Thanks to the mobilisation of the Socialist MEPs, we have obtained an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, which must be a political priority of the European Union. I am also very pleased that we have been able to guarantee EUR 50 million for the ERASMUS+ programme to help students study and work in another Member State. I therefore voted in favour of this joint draft budget for 2017.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I feel that I share the proposal for the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. I therefore voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this decision as I believe it provides better support for unemployed youth. It provides additional funds to boost key initiatives supporting SMEs, transport infrastructure projects, research and Erasmus+ student mobility. Youth, investments, SMEs and entrepreneurship are my core priorities in the European Parliament.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I welcome the agreement reached on the 2017 EU budget and I would like to reiterate several priorities on which I believe that we should insist to make the lives of the citizens of the Union as better as possible. First of all, I warn of the difficult situation in agriculture and the constant crises that are destroying rural populations across Europe. European farmers pressed by the situation on the global market, the crisis in the milk sector, the crisis in the fruit and vegetables sector, faced with the increasingly frequent and increasingly severe consequences of global warming, exposed to unfair trade practices and other problems caused by policy decisions such as the Russian embargo simply can no longer cope with a difficult situation. If we want to remedy this situation, it is necessary to take active legislative measures such as simplification of the CAP, but also specific targeted budgetary measures. One such measure must be one that will ensure compensation to farmers for losses incurred due to the Russian embargo, which should continue to be implemented by means outside those intended for agriculture. Secondly, it is also necessary to provide sufficient funds to compensate for the damage caused by climate change. Sprompt assistance in cases of disasters is necessarily required. Also, measures such as the Youth Initiative are essential to help rejuvenate the agricultural sector. Without young farmers, there will soon be no sustainable farming.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. — While this budget is indeed better than the one adopted by the European Parliament on 26 October, it is nevertheless excessive (the target of 5% reduction in staff in administrations decided in 2013 and whose deadline comes in 2017 is not the subject of any serious follow-up, for example) and particularly immigrationist. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — Europe is faced with countless challenges and if they are to be addressed seriously, starting from the unacceptable level of youth unemployment, through the management of flows migratory, you need to invest. These investments are only possible if you have an adequate budget. This year the negotiations for the EU budget for next year have managed to finally bring something good and thanks to the firm position of Parliament and, within the Council, the Government Italian, we have taken a step in the right direction. An increase of 500 million is planned for the Youth Employment Initiative, another 150 million will arrive on programmes for research, SMEs and cross-border infrastructure, while another 700 million more will be allocated under the heading for development, in particular as regards the management of migration routes. These appropriations will not in themselves be decisive, but they are a very important first step and show that a Europe that is changing and closer to its citizens is still possible.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The budget for next year is not perfect, but it is definitely a step in the right direction. United Europe is a complex and proud project of our continent, and like any project, it requires bold investment and reclusive support when the environment doubts its success. This success is not possible without the support of future generations and the additional €500 million allocated for already existing means of reducing youth unemployment is the only correct message that we can, even have to, send to young people across our Union. The EU has also faced a number of other challenges such as the migrant crisis and malaise economic growth — all of them are looking to bring in a respectable and flexible budget and I am proud that S&D has shown great strength of faith in its ideals when it was crucial. In order to be able to deal with the challenges the future carries, it is necessary to lay a solid foundation for innovation in the EU. That is why an additional 150 million euros is of great importance, which is intended to support even more agile activities of SMEs, cross-border infrastructure projects and R&D programmes. Certainly, as a responsible global actor, the EU cannot think of itself alone and I therefore welcome the decision of our institutions to provide additional funding to encourage development in our neighbourhood and actively act against the root causes of the migrant crisis.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We are in the presence of a budget which cannot, no matter how much rice powder they want to disguise the profound crisis in which the European Union finds itself. On the basis of a short multiannual framework, the proposal of Parliament and the European Commission did not correspond to the real needs of a European Union that is strongly depressed and increasingly socially and economically asymmetrical. Yet the council soon made it clear that this minimalist proposal would not deserve its agreement. In this way, this agreement announced, with a small increase in funds to cope with the refugee crisis and a slight increase in funds to support youth mobility within the framework of the Erasmus programme, falls far short of possibilities and needs and even goes in the wrong direction, by reducing the burden of cohesion and support for productive activities and increasing the foreign and security policy strand, accentuating the repressive character of the EU, particularly in relation to refugees. It is also an increasingly less transparent budget, with trust funds and other financial instruments occupying a growing preponderance, making this Parliament's supervisory role even more difficult. Plenty of reasons for our vote against.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On 26 October, Parliament voted on its position on the Union budget for 2017. After Parliament took into account the amendments to the Council's position, a conciliation committee composed of representatives of the three institutions was formed, which received 21 days for the adoption of the common text. This 21-day period began the day after the plenary session vote and came to an end on November 17. Parliament has postulated an increase of EUR 4.07 billion in net commitment appropriations and EUR 2.45 billion in payments over the Commission's proposals. This means that the amount for liabilities will be close to EUR 160.7 billion and for payments EUR 136.7 billion. The Council's amendments to the Commission's proposals amounted to EUR 155.8 billion for commitments and EUR 133.4 billion for payments. On 16 November, the Conciliation Committee set the 2017 budget at EUR 157.86 billion in commitments (an increase of 1.7% compared to 2016) and EUR 134.5 billion in payments (a decrease of 1.6%). The Council agreed an additional EUR 200 million for Horizon 2020, COSME, Connecting Europe and Erasmus+. An additional EUR 500 million was also allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the budgetary procedure for 2017. The overall amount of the 2017 budget is set at EUR 157857.8 million for commitment appropriations and EUR 134490.4 million for payment appropriations. I fully support the mobilization of additional resources to stimulate growth and create jobs, especially for young people, through increased funds for key devices such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus+ or COSME. Additional posts are also planned for Europol, Eurojust and EASO (European Asylum Support Office), as well as budgetary reinforcement for migration-related funds. This will allow us to better control the migration crisis we are experiencing today.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding budgetary report. This was the final agreement on the EU budget for 2017 which would increase by 1.7% from 2016 (a EUR 2.5 billion increase) – meaning the final EU budget for 2017 would be set at just over EUR 157 billion. The UK is forecast to contribute over EUR 17.3 billion gross (after taking in to account the UK rebate). UKIP opposes this increase in the EU budget.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — If we are to address the refugee crisis seriously, encourage growth and address the still unacceptable levels of youth unemployment, we need a well-funded and flexible Community budget. The budget we are adopting today is a step in the right direction. We have managed to obtain an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, a priority for our group. This will ensure that millions of young Europeans have the opportunity to continue to study, train or find their first job. We have also obtained an additional EUR 200 million for programmes aimed at boosting research and innovation, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, helping to promote cross-border infrastructure projects and to encourage aid for students to study in different Member States of the Union. We have also managed to increase funding for programmes that drive development and address the causes of the refugee crisis: it has been agreed to add €700 million to increase aid to neighbouring and developing countries, and we have secured an increase in funding to support Palestinian refugees. For all these reasons, the Spanish socialist delegation voted in favour of the Union's budget for 2017.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the approval of the European Union budget for 2017 despite the fact that the agreement reached with the Council is far below the validated and defended position our Parliament has taken. Satisfactions include the additional €200 million for the COSME programmes, the Connecting Europe Facility, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+. Nevertheless, I regret that the Council has not shown itself more ambitious, particularly with regard to the management of migratory flows. It is essential that the European Union take on its responsibilities in order to welcome newcomers with dignity. In general, I maintain that it is necessary to increase the share of the truly own budgetary resources of the European Union and reach a maximum of 40% of the European budget dependent on national contributions.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The EU budget for the next year does not fully meet our expectations and wishes. On the other hand, I understand that his draft is the result of many compromises, and I am therefore voting in favour and hope that the other EU institutions will do their best to ensure that the support of this budget reaches its addressees as soon as possible.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal for the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, totalling EUR 157, 86 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 134.49 billion in payment appropriations. This budget confirms, in the framework of the negotiations, that the priority areas for next year should be youth employment, economic growth, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, research and innovation, student mobility, migration and security. A further EUR 200 million was included in programmes for growth and jobs, such as COSM- in the field of entrepreneurial competitiveness, the Connecting Europe Facility for cross-border mobility and energy, Horizon 2020- in the field of research and innovation and “the Erasmus +” - on student mobility.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the 2017 budget, resulting from the conciliation agreement between the Council and Parliament which sets out three priorities: stimulating growth, creating jobs, especially for young people, and better managing the refugee crisis. I supported this text because Parliament received an additional EUR 500 million over the initial project for the Youth Employment Initiative. This budget also allows the Union to strengthen its efforts to promote employment and competitiveness by providing an additional EUR 200 million for the COSME programme for SMEs, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ to encourage student mobility. On the other hand, this budget allows the Union to provide itself with an adequate level of funding to respond effectively to the refugee crisis, both in its external dimension in order to combat the root causes of migration and in its internal dimensions. Finally, this budget also gives priority to the security of the Union with the increase in the amounts allocated to Europol and Eurojust.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This decision concerns the final approval of the European budget. A vote in favour would mean, among many other things, endorsing the financialisation of investments, the austeritarian conditionality of the cohesion and development funds, the privatisation of research, the commodification of agricultural policies and the use of external funds to strengthen the strength of Europe and the militarism of the great European capital. I therefore voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become another instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 which was approved by the Conciliation Committee.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am pleased that the Slovak Presidency of the Council has managed to reach such a good compromise, which is why I supported the proposal for next year's budget. In total commitments next year, the EU budget will have €157.9 billion available, an increase of 1.7 per cent compared to last year. On the payments side, €134.5 billion is envisaged, which in turn is a decline of 1.6 per cent compared to 2016. As the greatest achievements of our Slovak team, which acted as a mediator between the various institutions, I consider the increase in the budget in the areas of narrowing our citizens. Thanks to the pressure created by the negotiators of the European Parliament, EUR 200 million for growth and jobs and up to EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative have been added to the budget. When we turn it into change, we'll send in 50 million next year. EUR 50 million more for Horizon 2020, benefiting from European research and development. EUR more will go to the Connecting Europe Facility, through which we finance infrastructure, and not least by 50 million. The EUR will receive more Erasmus+ programme, thanks to which millions of European citizens are studying in other countries. These are just a few demonstrations that show that Europe is making every effort to invest as much as possible in its development.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - After 17 hours of negotiations, a compromise between Parliament, the Commission and the Council was reached on 16 November 2016 in the so-called trilogue procedure on setting the EU budget for 2017. This budget provides for commitment appropriations of EUR 157.86 billion and payments of EUR 134.5 billion. As in previous years, three quarters of this will be used for agricultural and cohesion tasks, some of which is not effective. In particular, net donors pay billions first to Brussels to recover some of these amounts. Instead, net donors should pay to Brussels only the part to the net beneficiary countries, the rest should remain in their national budgets. In addition, only activities that provide appropriate added value and can be better implemented in the European than national or regional level should be financed. This would strengthen the principle of subsidiarity and relieve the burden on the EU budget. In addition, the gap between commitments and payments is again very high, leading to unpaid invoices in the long run. For these reasons, I reject the 2017 EU budget as decided.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is necessary to ensure a smooth running of payments in relation to commitment appropriations in order to avoid any abnormal level of unpaid invoices at the end of the year. Figures on the implementation status and estimates relating to payment appropriations requirements in 2017 must be submitted by the competent authorities in a timely manner and all necessary decisions must be taken in a timely manner for duly justified needs in order to avoid the accumulation of excess the volume of unpaid accounts and the proper payment of payment applications has been ensured.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the 2017 budget draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. Not only will the budget increase by 1.7% from 2016, but also it continues to waste billions of euros on failed wealth redistribution such as on agricultural and cohesion.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The EU budget for 2017 consists of €159.7 billion in financial commitments for payment upon fulfilment of the required conditions and €134.5 billion of commitments to cash cash or bank transactions to budget users. I support the EU budget for next year because it contains additional funding for the migrant crisis and aid for farmers.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the common draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the budgetary procedure. Through the European Parliament, the 2017 budget offers more funding for strategic items: for employment, small and medium-sized enterprises, transport infrastructure, research and innovation, Erasmus and our security. We have ahead of us an ambitious EU budget for 2017, a budget for the challenges of the present and future, which, despite limited resources, balanced all political priorities and provides synergies between different areas.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The budget of the Union must take account of current adverse situations and seek to address them, while at the same time having as its main concern the well-being of citizens of all Member States. Its level of flexibility needs to be high enough to be able to cope with new challenges and the already emerging threats.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is essential to keep up with the EU budget with the implementation of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 by Member States and to have cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. The EU budget has the resources to allow the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated in implementing Member States' projects. We have also managed to ensure that the funds mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. Finally, the 2017 EU budget does not contain provisions on penalties for Member States rejecting compulsory reception quotas. The socialists and liberals have proposed a budgetary mechanism that would penalise Member States which, despite the mandatory resettlement quota system, do not accept illegal immigrants into their countries. This attack was averted during the adoption of the 2017 budget. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, which endorses the 2017 budget figures with amendments. I think it is important to note that the final budget for this year provides for EUR 157 851.8 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 134 430,4 million in payment appropriations. This, respectively, represents an increase of 1.7% and a decrease of 1.6% compared to 2016. During the negotiations, the European Parliament has succeeded in restoring the figures proposed by the European Commission and reduced by the European Council in several places. Accordingly, two important themes, the 'Growth and Jobs Initiative' and the 'Youth Employment Initiative', have been strengthened by EUR 200 million and EUR 500 million respectively. In addition, additional funds will be given to the milk and livestock sector affected by the crisis (EUR 500 million) and the Global Europe initiative for growth and jobs — which will also address the migration and refugee crisis and its root — an additional €730 million get. I consider the proposed figures acceptable with the comment that, of course, the amount spent on sustainable jobs (including young people) is never enough.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — The 2017 budget includes a number of emergency measures to help farmers cope with the challenges currently facing the market. In this document, the Commission undertakes to monitor the market situation on a regular basis and to present, if necessary, appropriate measures to address needs not covered by appropriations authorised in the budget. I support this proposal and vote for its adoption.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I approved the text by my colleague Indrek Tarand approving the joint draft agreed upon by the Conciliation Committee, which consists of all the following documents: the list of budget lines which have not been modified in relation to the draft budget or the Council's position; the summary amounts by heading of the framework financial; line-by-line amounts of all budget items; a consolidated document showing the amounts and the final text of all lines amended during conciliation.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. — I participated in the negotiations on the 2017 budget, and despite an undersized fiscal framework since 2014, our goal has been, above all, to respond to the emergencies: jobs, growth and youth. Parliament has managed to release new resources, i.e. fresh money instead of the usual cuts and reallocations. +EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, +EUR 200 million for growth support programmes and additional resources for migration and security. It should be noted that the expenditure ceilings are met under most headings, even though the requirements to be covered remain enormous. Proof that the European Union's budgetary framework is inadequate to today's challenges and that it needs to be deeply reviewed. While this budget is a first round won by Parliament, it remains to be won the part on the revision of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020. It needs to be relaxed and flexibilized to allow for the mobilization of all unused margins in order to meet the major challenges, including jobs in sustainable growth. The fiscal battle is one of the keys to the future of the Union.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Proposal for a Resolution on the Budgetary Procedure 2017. I believe that the additional points brought by the budget, such as the extra money for Europol, the Eastern Partnership, Macro-Financial Assistance represent exceptional progress in the financial segment for the EU. In particular, I support the Joint Statement on the Youth Employment Initiative, which reminds that reducing youth unemployment remains an important common policy priority and I believe that it is necessary to confirm the Union's determination to make the best use of financial resources in order to make the most of the more qualitatively solved the issue of youth unemployment.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - In October this year, Parliament voted on its position on the Union budget. Since Parliament has significantly modified the position of the Council, a Conciliation Committee has been convened with a deadline of 21 days to agree the final text. Parliament's position is to increase the budget in relation to the Commission's initial proposal, which the Council asked for a reduction with the argument that Parliament must focus on the level of implementation of each budget item, while the Commission criticised the Council's proposal arguing that it would jeopardize implementation of a number of EU projects. I will not support the compromise that has been established between the position of the Commission and the Council because many items in the budget lack margin, and certain priority items lack funding because they are regrouped from unnecessary ones.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the common draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the budgetary procedure. The agreement was reached after budgetary reconciliation after the Council recognised and adopted the points presented by the European delegation, such as 200 million for certain priority programmes (Horizon 2020, CEF-Transport, Erasmus + and COSME) and 500 million for youth employment. The 2017 budget also includes extra money for migration and additional aid for farmers. The final agreement also contains some important points for the EPP (cash inputs for: Europol, Paralympic Games in Austria, Eastern Partnership, Macro Financial Assistance). It is divided by sections. In the first is money earmarked for competitiveness, for economic growth and jobs and economic, social and territorial cohesion. The second refers to sustainable development, natural resources - agriculture. The third section is security and citizenship. The fourth touches on global Europe (Palestine, Eastern European Partnership, Macro Financial Assistants, Turkish-Cypriot Community). The fifth section is the administration (salaries and other elements).

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. The budget proposed by Parliament already accepted cuts, only partially compensating for Commission and Council positions. Finally after the negotiation, we have one of the most austere budgets known in a long time, following the intransigence of the Council and the richest countries. The budget will remain with €157 857.8 million in Payment Authorizations (CA) and €134 490.4 million in Payments, which represents a real cut of more than 6.4% and 1.7% more in credit. The budget is more flexible to provide space and recourse to more security and migration measures. The main victims will be agriculture, the administration of institutions and decentralized agencies. Basically it involves reducing Member States' contributions to an already low budget, mobilising contingency margins and flexibility in order to be able to address additional expenditure for the treatment of migration processes, strengthening the European Sustainable Development Fund (a kind of Juncker Plan for containment migration in neighboring countries) and the Turkey Trust Fund (Refugees).

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — Parliament's position is related to an increase in the net commitment appropriations of EUR 4,07 billion and payments by EUR 2,45 billion in respect of the Commission's proposal. This means that the amount for liabilities will be close to EUR 160.7 billion and for payments EUR 136.7 billion. The Council's amendments to the Commission's proposals amounted to EUR 155.8 billion for commitments and EUR 133.4 billion for payments. The Commission believed that the Council's cuts would jeopardise the implementation of a number of EU programmes. The procedure itself was well prepared, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The total amount of commitment appropriations in the 2017 budget is EUR 157 857.8 million. A total of EUR 1100.1 million in commitment appropriations will remain below the MFF ceilings for 2017. I supported the document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. The budget proposed by Parliament already accepted cuts, only partially compensating for Commission and Council positions. Finally after the negotiation, we have one of the most austere budgets known in a long time, following the intransigence of the Council and the richest countries. The budget will remain with €157 857.8 million in Payment Authorizations (CA) and €134 490.4 million in Payments, which represents a real cut of more than 6.4% and 1.7% more in credit. The budget is more flexible to provide space and recourse to more security and migration measures. The main victims will be agriculture, the administration of institutions and decentralized agencies. Basically it involves reducing Member States' contributions to an already low budget, mobilising contingency margins and flexibility in order to be able to address additional expenditure for the treatment of migration processes, strengthening the European Sustainable Development Fund (a kind of Juncker Plan for containment migration in neighboring countries) and the Turkey Trust Fund (Refugees).

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure. The report recalls that reducing youth unemployment remains a high and shared political priority, and to this end [the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission] reaffirm their determination to make the best possible use of budgetary resources available to tackle it. In order to address the root causes of migration, the Commission launched the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) based on the establishment of an EFSD Guarantee and an EFSD Guarantee Fund. The Commission proposes to endow the EFSD Guarantee Fund with EUR 750 million over the period 2017–2020, of which EUR 400 million from the European Development Fund (EDF) over the four years. Parliament, the Council and the Commission agree that the establishment of Trust Funds and of the Facility for Refugees in Turkey should be transparent and clear. I voted in favour because I believe that those issues have to be addressed as part of the revision of the Financial Regulation in order to strike the right balance between flexibility and accountability.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This decision ratifies the agreement reached to mobilise 200 million for key programmes such as Horizon 2020, CEF, Erasmus+ or Cosme. In addition, an additional 500 million is granted for the youth employment initiative. This new agreement is in the right direction, focusing on innovation and the fight against youth unemployment, which is the basic priorities of the Union. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This decision concerns the final approval of the European budget. A vote in favour would mean endorsing the financialisation of investments, the austeritarian conditionality of the cohesion and development funds, the privatisation of research, the commodification of agricultural policies and the use of external funds to strengthen Europe's strength and militarism of big European capital. I therefore voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become another instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We are in the presence of a budget which cannot, no matter how much rice powder they want to disguise the profound crisis in which the European Union finds itself. On the basis of a short multiannual framework, the proposal of Parliament and the European Commission did not correspond to the real needs of a European Union that is strongly depressed and increasingly socially and economically asymmetrical. Yet the council soon made it clear that this minimalist proposal would not deserve its agreement. In this way, this agreement announced, with a small increase in funds to cope with the refugee crisis and a slight increase in funds to support youth mobility within the framework of the Erasmus programme, falls far short of possibilities and needs and even goes in the wrong direction, by reducing the burden of cohesion and support for productive activities and increasing the foreign and security policy strand, accentuating the repressive character of the EU, particularly in relation to refugees. It is also an increasingly less transparent budget, with trust funds and other financial instruments occupying a growing preponderance, making this Parliament's supervisory role even more difficult. Plenty of reasons for our vote against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report calls, for example, for an increase in remuneration and financial assistance to support the Turkish Cypriot community, using the scope for unforeseen expenditure for these increases. However, as meaningful positions such as the Social Fund or the Regional Development Fund are to be reduced at the same time, I voted against this report.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ To obtain the final agreement for the 2017 budget, we started from the Commission's late June proposal, to achieve a Council position which provided for many reductions, and Finally, Parliament's reading at the end of October, which proposed large increases; as expected, the solution was found in the middle. Parliament has succeeded in imposing its vision for some increments, in particular for Heading 1a and new support for the Youth Employment Initiative; there have also been increases for Heading 4 and for the staff of certain agencies linked to Heading 3. The Council was satisfied for disbonding this annual procedure from the midterm review of the MFF: in any case, any new commitments, such as those for the Employment Initiative juvenile, they will then be climbed for total computation. In my view, all the criticalities already expressed at the end of October remain, including a clear lack of political priorities and the necessary economies to make this budget sustainable and credible even in comparisons of citizens: the constant increases in administrative and bureaucratic costs make us understand how the reality that we live in Brussels is disconnected from everyday life in different European countries.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The PVV voted against the joint text on the draft budget for 2017, and the draft budget contains a number of items with major problems for the PVV. The PVV considers it unnecessary for the EU to increase funds for, for example, Palestinian terrorists, Turkish Cypriot occupying forces, migration and youth trips through Europe.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support the text of the budget agreed by the Conciliation Committee. In the budgetary procedure, there has traditionally been a conflict between the European Commission, Parliament and the Council. While the Commission sought not to increase the budget and rather reduce unnecessary spending, the European Parliament, through its amendments, has raised the budget beyond that of last year. The Conciliation Committee has managed to mitigate some of the increases, but the result is still higher than the 2016 budget. Of course, we must realise that unprecedented challenges, such as the migration and refugee crisis, or the natural disasters that repeatedly affect Europe, require higher finances, but on the other hand, I think that annual budget increases are not the right way to go. First of all, we should ask whether the missing funds in a particular area can not be obtained by transferring from another, unused budget line. We should learn how to work with the budget efficiently instead of constantly increasing it, which is not really a sustainable solution for the long term. However, despite these reservations, I appreciate the work of the Conciliation Committee in trying to reduce spending, for example, on the other hand, on the contrary, to allocate more funding to important projects such as Erasmus, Horizon 2020 or EURES.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. — The Joint Draft Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 setting an expenditure level of EUR 157 857.8 million reflects a fair and even redistribution of funds to meet all envisaged liabilities in the following year. Mobilising flexibility instruments for Security and Citizenship in the amount of €530 million provides sufficient resources to respond and address the problems caused by current migration and humanitarian crises in a timely manner. The thoroughness and systematicity of the draft budget is also reflected in ensuring sufficient funds for contingency expenditure, sustainable growth and mobilisation of flexibility instruments. I agree and support the draft of this budget because I believe that it will ensure the smooth functioning of the institutions and the fulfilment of all arising commitments.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the common draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the budgetary procedure. I support the draft general budget of the European Union because I believe it is developmentally designed as it promotes investment and regional development, inter alia, and allocates additional resources to the implementation of the Erasmus+ programme.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). — Mr President, the European Solidarity Fund is always present when it comes to repairing the damage suffered by our citizens and infrastructure in the Member States from natural disasters. I have a number of examples of how he has strengthened Greece. I would just like to say one thing: we were given EUR 16.3 million in aid for natural disasters in Greece and Bulgaria just last October, and that is what is important. But I believe that from the time of damage coverage and the healing of wounds, we must move immediately to the age of prevention, and that is why I propose that natural disaster prevention projects should be implemented, financed entirely by the Structural Funds and without national participation , especially in countries that are constantly affected, and these are examples of Greece, Bulgaria and Italy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The resolution calls on the Commission, in the light of the serious situation in which the areas affected by the earthquake are located, to consider the possibility of excluding, from the calculation of national public deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact, investments in sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention and also to consider extending the existing calculation of the Solidarity Fund, which is currently based on the effects of damage caused by a single catastrophic event, to a cumulative calculation of damage caused by several natural disasters in the same region in a year. The importance of complying with the requirements relating to the construction of earthquake-proof infrastructure and buildings is also mentioned. Taking note of the application for intervention under the European Union Solidarity Fund submitted by the Italian Government, the Commission is finally invited to take all the necessary measures to examine promptly requests for assistance under the Fund in order to ensure its rapid mobilization. For these reasons I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution accompanying an oral question. The resolution urges the Commission to take all the necessary measures to provide support and help to the Italian national and regional authorities involved in relief efforts following the recent earthquakes by simplifying procedures and shortening the time for approval and disbursement of financing from the European Solidarity Fund.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: Between August and October 2016, 3 earthquakes struck the Central Apennines, killing 290 people and wounding more than 400. This disaster has led to the destruction of historic homes and buildings, which had a major impact on the local tourism economy. In all, 130 km2 were affected by this terrible earthquake. I voted in favour of the Northern League motion for a resolution which is structured around three points: to make the use of the EUSF more efficient and less bureaucratic intervention; to amend regional operational programmes to allow the regions to use the ERDF and the ESF to cover reconstruction costs and prevention of seismic risk; exclude from the calculation of the government deficit and the scope of the State aid rules all expenditure or tax benefits incurred for the reconstruction of the affected areas. I also voted in favour of the EFDD motion for a resolution which, although less comprehensive, goes in the right direction, particularly on the possibility of reprogramming the use of European funds, as well as for the ALDE/ECR/S&D/EPPE/Greens/GUE/NGL motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The final resolution in this matter was not the subject of a roll-call vote. Therefore, in the interests of transparency and democracy, I would like to confirm that I abstained on it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy following earthquakes. In 2016, an extreme earthquake struck central Italy and three more significant earthquakes of the same wave struck the regions of central Italy. More than 400 people are injured and 290 are killed and, as a result of possible indirect consequences, 100 000 people may have to leave their place of residence. In view of the situation, I agree with the European Parliament's view that this problem needs to be given a quick and effective response in order to ensure adequate living conditions for the people who have lost their homes and other necessary assistance.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text because it corresponds more to the Europe we want in the National Front and in our group in Parliament, Europe of Nations and Freedoms: that of cooperation and mutual assistance of sovereign nations. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) covers compensation for property damage or loss of income following a natural disaster. The motion for a resolution is in the right direction since it proposes to flexibilise its use, which corresponds to France's interests: for example, floods in the south of our country typically correspond to events that could mobilise the EUSF.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for efforts to help the many victims of earthquakes in Italy and, more generally, underlines the need for further measures to better prepare institutions to deal with such disasters in the future. It asked the Commission to consider replacing the current method of calculating the Solidarity Fund with another method based on a cumulative calculation of the damage caused by several natural disasters occurring in the same region in the same year. It also stresses the importance of research and development in disaster prevention and management and calls on Member States to cooperate more closely with its institutions. Finally, it encourages its Member States to optimize the use of European funds by investing in particular in consolidation and sustainable development for reconstruction activities.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Central Italy has been affected, since August 2016, by a series of significant intensity earthquake devastating cities, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, compromised economic activities and above all destroyed a part of the great historical and cultural heritage that was preserved in the territory. The peak of seismic events occurred with the October 30 earthquake, with magnitude 6.5 on the Richter scale. Some 400 people were injured, 290 lost their lives while over 100 000 residents were forced to abandon their homes. The joint resolution adopted by Parliament today, and I strongly supported, represents an important signal of the Union's attention to our country and the areas that are tragically affected by recent earthquakes. The text calls for excluding post-earthquake reconstruction investment from the calculation of the deficit under the Stability Pact, and to use all EU funds available to help affected areas from the quakesms. The European Commission has already announced a first aid disbursement worth €30 million from the Solidarity Fund to be voted on by Parliament shortly.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses the situation in Italy after the earthquakes suffered in August 2016, followed by several aftershocks and a strong earthquake in October, the most intense in recent decades, which ravaged entire localities and caused multiple damage. It asks the Commission, given the exceptionality and seriousness of this situation, to consider excluding from the calculation of national deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact, investments related to sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention, and to take all necessary measures to analyse promptly requests for assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), with a view to ensuring their rapid mobilization.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I first supported the resolution tabled by the ENF Group on the situation in Italy, which was more comprehensive, but also voted in favour of the joint resolution of the other political groups. The ENF resolution, in my view, goes further in the common sense proposals relating to the management by national and local authorities of natural disasters. We have asked for flexibility in the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) so that it can intervene faster and more effectively. Recall that until now it can only play within six months of the natural disaster; beyond that, any subsidy from the EUSF can be considered State aid. Furthermore, we would like the regions to be allowed to use the ERDF and the ESF to cover the costs related to reconstruction and prevention of seismic risks. Finally, we believe it is essential that all expenditure or tax benefits related to the reconstruction of the affected regions should be excluded from the public deficit and the scope of the State aid regulation. Humans cannot always be regarded as a simple variable of economic adjustment!

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a motion for a resolution adopted, in the context of the debate on the Union Solidarity Fund (created to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and bring European solidarity to the sinister regions of Europe), following the devastating earthquakes that struck central Italy in August and October 2016, where about 300 people lost their lives and more than 400 others were injured, with the possible displacement of another 100,000. It is intended to answer questions as to whether the Commission has received a request from the Italian Government to receive funding from the Fund and has taken all necessary measures to assess the request and to mobilise this funding expeditiously, and whether the Commission will consider requests for changes to operational programmes national and regional levels in order to better address the issues of thematic objective 5 (“Promoting climate change adaptation and risk prevention and management”), and consider existing procedures for assessing funding requests with a view to simplifying them and shortening the required deadlines. I voted in favour of the resolution finally adopted.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament expresses its greatest solidarity with all the victims of earthquakes and their families, as well as the Italian national, regional and local authorities who are trying to provide support after the disaster, and means your deepest sympathy.
