Parliament expresses its concern about the large number of displaced persons living in extremely harsh weather as the winter season is approaching, and therefore calls on the Commission to find out all possible ways of providing assistance to the Italian authorities for all people who have lost their homes ensure proper living conditions. Parliament underlines the importance of creating synergies between all available instruments, including the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds, and ensuring that resources are used effectively for reconstruction activities and all other necessary actions, in full cooperation with Italy national and regional authorities. It also calls on the Commission to be prepared for this purpose to adopt appropriate amendments to programmes and operational programmes as soon as possible following a request from a Member State for amendments. Parliament also underlines the possibility of using the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) to support rural areas and agricultural activities affected by earthquakes.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion stresses that recent earthquakes in Italy have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity, in many cases historical and cultural heritage, and consequently significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage suffered. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response. I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion for a resolution.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the resolution identifying the severity of earthquakes in central Italy. Central Italy was hit by a devastating earthquake on August 24, 2016, which caused significant robust damage and devastated cities, severely damaging local and regional infrastructure, destroying historic and cultural heritage and damaging the economy. More than 400 people were injured in this earthquake and aftershocks and 290 died, causing up to 100,000 people to be displaced.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this question to the Commission on the situation in Italy after the earthquake, and especially since the period of harsh weather conditions is coming due to the upcoming winter season. The winter period represents one of the main concerns for large numbers of displaced people and this needs to be addressed quickly and efficiently to guarantee decent living conditions for homeless people.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — These 3 motions for resolutions are in the right direction by facilitating the use of these European solidarity funds. Nevertheless, I will remain vigilant about the drift of using these funds to finance migration policy, particularly in Italy, Greece and Cyprus. I am therefore voting in favour of the ENF resolution. I am voting for the EFDD resolution. I am voting in favour of the ALDE/ECR/S&D/EPP/Greens/Guengl resolution.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ In recent months Central Italy has been affected by several earthquakes, the most severe of which occurred on 30 October: it was the strongest quake ever recorded in the territory of the European Union since 1980. It is important that we continue to act with the speed and professionalism that we have seen in recent months also in the future: the affected territories must continue to receive all solidarity, moral and material , of the whole of the European Union. The inclusion in the budget of the annual financial envelope of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) is definitely going in the correct direction, but the Commission needs to speed up the procedures the most possible and anticipate the disbursement of support funds. The European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) will certainly be useful for supporting agricultural activities that have been damaged by earthquakes, but it is central to create synergies between all the instruments available, including the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) and to ensure that the resources are used effectively for reconstruction activities and all other necessary actions, in full cooperation with the Italian national and regional authorities. A Europe that is more humane, more supportive and closer by the citizens also passes by how it reacts to situations like this.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: Italy has been the victim of severe earthquakes in recent times, which have devastated mainly the centre of the territory, resulting in more than 400 injured and 290 deaths. These shocks have severely damaged cities, regional and local infrastructure and destroyed historical heritage properties. The European Union must assist Italy to the extent of its capabilities. We must use European instruments such as the European Union Solidarity Fund to support Italy. I give all my support to the victims of these earthquakes. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report in question which calls on the Commission to encourage the optimal use of all available resources to help Italy in rebuilding after the recent seismic catastrophes. Earthquakes that have razed entire countries and disrupted the lives of tens of thousands of people are not sporadic events, but natural phenomena intended to recur periodically. Prevention should be made, using the various existing funds, including the Structural Funds and the European Investment Fund, to provide the areas most likely to be subject to earthquake risk with appropriate measures earthquake-proof, preventing future seismic events from having the same tragic impact. The report contains the same request for Commission President Juncker and Commissioner Moscovici to exclude national deficits under the Stability Pact from calculating national deficits and growth of investments for sustainable reconstruction and earthquake protection operations. I believe, in fact, paradoxical that the flexibility clause aroused in cases of severe disasters and is not usable to prevent disasters, or to prevent such events are cause of death and devastation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution accompanying an oral question. The resolution urges the Commission to take all the necessary measures to provide support and help to the Italian national and regional authorities involved in relief efforts following the recent earthquakes by simplifying procedures and shortening the time for approval and disbursement of financing from the European Solidarity Fund.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in response to the devastating earthquakes that hit central Italy between August and October 2016.  This resulted in flattening of entire villages, seriously damaged local and regional infrastructure, ruined historical and cultural heritage, damaged economic activities, especially those of SMEs, agriculture, the landscape and the potential of the tourism and hospitality industries, a large number of displaced persons, and various indirect forms of damage in the surrounding areas. I believe that in light of this exceptional and very serious situation, the Commission should consider having sustainable reconstruction and any anti-seismic investments excluded from the calculation of national deficits in the framework of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The resolution presented on the recent earthquakes that brought central Italy to its knees is very complete, requires interventions on the territory of a wide range and not to take into account expenditure on reconstruction in order to comply with the Stability Pact. I undoubtedly voted for it.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy following the earthquakes in the past period confirms our willingness to support the citizens and the Italian State who have been badly hit and are facing major disasters. I think it is our duty to provide all possible assistance, and that is why I voted in favour of the resolution's proposals.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: ‒ “It's just words” is the mantra that is often repeated in the face of measures bearing manifestly beneficial effects resembling electoral promises. However, it is clear from the resolution that this time the EU intends to intervene as soon as possible in favour of Italy and the populations of the areas affected by the quake not only on 26 August last, but also those of 26 and 30 October. It was not merely telluric events, but real stab wounds inflicted on a land that today mourns more than 290 dead and must find, in the harsh winter, a dignified accommodation for over one hundred thousand displaced people. No, it will not be an easy Christmas, but it will certainly welcome, if it is accepted, to know that the call to the Commission to exclude national public deficits from the calculation of national public deficits under the pact of stability and growth investments in favour of sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention. Just as the possibility of extending the European Solidarity Fund to the cumulative calculation of the damage caused by different disasters in the same region in one year could only benefit areas that need to face multiple natural difficulties. We can, for now, welcome the greater flexibility given to Italy in calculating the deficit.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions on the situation in Italy after the earthquakes.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Italy has suffered in the last year 2016 a series of earthquakes and replicas of high magnitude that will have caused more than 290 deaths and 400 wounded, devastated entire villages and transformed into ruins historical and cultural heritage, causing disruption in economic activities, in particular SMEs and sector tourist. I express my solidarity with the earthquake victims and their families and with the work of the authorities and volunteers who provided emergency aid after the disaster. I share the concern that some European territories are more vulnerable to seismic activity, and research should be accelerated in order to avoid damage, manage crises and reduce the scale of the impact of disasters, in conjunction with initiatives under Horizon 2020, and should also the requirements applicable to the construction of earthquake-resistant infrastructure are complied with. On the other hand, I believe that the procedures for activating the EU Civil Protection Mechanism should be further simplified and the Commission should work together to speed up sustainable reconstruction and investment in anti-seismic infrastructure and optimise existing EU funding to prevent natural disasters.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal because it calls on the Commission, in the light of the very serious and exceptional nature of the situation in Italy after the recent earthquakes, to take into consideration Considering the possibility of excluding investments in sustainable reconstruction and prevention from the calculation of national government deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact earthquake-proof, including those co-financed with ESI funds and allocated to thematic Objective 5 (prevention, promotion of adaptation to climate change, prevention and risk management). I also believe it is positive, although not yet entirely sufficient, the advance of resources that the Commissioner has ensured in order to implement the most urgent measures.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the recent Italian earthquake disaster more than 400 people were reported to have been injured and 290 to have died.  Devastating earthquakes could accumulate in a ‘domino effect’ and lead to 100 000 displaced residents. This requires us to create synergies between all available instruments, in order to ensure that resources are used effectively for reconstruction activities and all other necessary interventions, in full cooperation with the Italian national and regional authorities. I agree on the importance of the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism in fostering cooperation among national civil protection authorities across Europe in adverse situations and in minimising the effects of exceptional occurrences. We should keep up our efforts to further simplify the procedures for the activation of the mechanism to make it available rapidly and effectively in the immediate aftermath of a disaster. I express my deepest solidarity and empathy with all the individuals affected by the earthquakes and their families, and with the Italian national, regional and local authorities involved in relief efforts following the disaster.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In the plenary in Brussels, we approved Parliament's resolution on the situation in Italy following the earthquakes. This is an absolutely positive resolution, recognising - starting with the extraordinary exceptionality of the Italian case - both the efforts the government is making, and the need to find us better Prepared in the face of the risks of extraordinary events. Certainly a step forward is the proposal to amend the Solidarity Fund Regulation, which accelerates procedures, streamlines them and makes the provision of resources more immediate than the decision hired. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it does not only meet the needs of Italian citizens, but also represents a response to the European need to allow a strategic plan for securing, facilitating and derogating from the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact. Therefore, I consider it essential to approve paragraphs 6 and 7 which call for the maximum possible flexibility and reaffirm the urgency of exclusion from the Investment Stability and Growth Pact implemented through the Structural Funds to secure the territories and areas most at risk.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — Italy has been hit by a series of highly devastating earthquakes in the last few months, during which 400 people were injured and 290 lost their lives. In the short time after these events, more than 100,000 people were displaced from their homes. As a result of these miserable events, very many towns were destroyed and local and regional infrastructure was badly damaged. Historical and cultural heritage centres have also suffered greatly. Earthquakes also had a significant impact on the operation of small and medium-sized enterprises, agriculture and tourism and hospitality industries. The draft calls on the Commission to take all necessary measures to ensure rapid and effective funding within the European Union Solidarity Fund and to consider the possibility of using the European Rural Development Fund to support areas rural and agriculture, which suffered as a result of the earthquake. Furthermore, it asks the Commission to ensure that all measures envisaged in order to improve or target the situation are actually used by the Italian Government for this particular purpose. Bearing in mind the above state of affairs, I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this resolution which looks upon the devastating earthquakes that hit central Italy in 2016 and concludes that more efforts are needed in order to tackle the EU law restrictions on budgets and state aids in situations like these. The report also highlights how it is practically impossible for earthquake-prone Member States to pursue proper programmes of investment in reconstruction work and earthquake prevention and to provide support for the economic activities affected unless they cut services or resources already earmarked for existing structural investment plans, and this must be tackled.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: ‒ The dramatic earthquake shocks that have recently hit the central regions of the Italian peninsula represent a deep wound not only for Italy, but for the whole of Europe. The European Commission's symbolic promise to rebuild the cathedral of Norcia together with the announcement of the allocation of the first tranche of funds to cope with the emergency are the first concrete signs which we appreciate; we now call for the exclusion from the Structural Investment Stability Pact for securing and rebuilding buildings according to the latest earthquake standards. I strongly hope that these tragic events will be an opportunity to show that the European Union is, first and foremost, a community of values that are attentive to the needs of citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This European Parliament resolution deals with the Italian situation following the earthquakes that struck it. The resolution, of course, takes note of the Italian government's request for aid under the European Union Solidarity Fund and calls on the European Commission to process this request swiftly with a view to acting even more effectively with the affected territories. Considering the seriousness of the Italian situation, and considering the European Union's duty to assist European territories in distress following natural disasters, I have of course voted in favour of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We first of all offer our condolences to all those affected by the earthquakes in Italy. UKIP is usually opposed to the spending of any EU money. However in light of the tragic human suffering in cases of environmental disaster we have chosen to abstain.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I supported Parliament's resolution on the situation in Italy after the earthquakes. Since 14 August 2016, Italy has been the victim of four powerful earthquakes, resulting in the deaths of 290 people, injuring 400 others and the displacement of 100,000 residents. It is necessary for the European Union to learn all the lessons from this situation in order to improve both the speed and content of the assistance it provides, as well as to optimize coordination between European-funded disputes, in order to gain efficiency. More urgently, as winter settles in, I join the call to the Commission to use all the means at its disposal to help the Italian authorities ensure accommodation for those without a home.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on earthquakes in Italy. The motion stresses that the recent Italian earthquakes have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity and, in many cases, the historical and cultural heritage and, consequently, significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage suffered. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of all these texts. Between August and October 2016, three earthquakes struck the Central Apennines, killing 290 people and wounding more than 400. The EUSF shall pay compensation for property damage caused to the assets or loss of income due to the total or partial suspension of the activity for a period not exceeding six months from the occurrence of the natural disaster. These three proposals, including one tabled by the Northern League, aim to flexibilise this fund and to allow the use, in the event of natural disasters, of the ESF and the ERDF, which we believe is useful and appropriate.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to offer my sincere condolences to those who died from the recent earthquakes in Italy. Then I would like to congratulate all those brave Italians who helped bring the living out of the ruins and rebuild cities after these many terrible earthquakes. And although difficult, after such a tragedy, we must learn lessons from these disasters and make sure that we can overcome these disasters more quickly and together.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting against, because the motion for a resolution does not really address the problems of the affected areas; on the contrary, it shows that the approach is fragmented and always under the sword of the Damocles of austerity measures.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on earthquakes in Italy. The motion stresses that the recent Italian earthquakes have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity and, in many cases, the historical and cultural heritage and, consequently, significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage suffered. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because, following the seismic events affecting Italy, the text calls on the Commission to put in place all the measures necessary for providing Italy with rapid and effective support through the European Union Solidarity Fund, also taking into consideration the possibility of using the European Fund for Rural Development to the aim to support rural areas and agricultural activities affected by earthquakes. I also believe the request made to the Commission to ensure that all the resources in question are actually used by the Italian Government for this specific purpose.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In August 2016, three huge earthquakes hit Italy, causing 400 people injuries and killing 290 people. It is possible that as a result of the devastating consequences, up to 100,000 people will lose their roof over their heads. The coming winter therefore poses a big problem for people who had to be relocated. Earthquakes destroyed cities, severely damaged regional infrastructure and destroyed cultural and historical monuments in several places as well. The European Commission must respond promptly to the situation that has arisen, and the European Union must be prepared to help Italy through the Solidarity Fund, which is designed precisely to help with similar tragic disasters.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the reports in their entirety on the situation in Italy after the earthquakes, as the motion for a resolution does not really address the problems of the affected regions. On the contrary, it shows that the approach is fragmented and always under the sword of the Damocles of austerity measures.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation is extremely hard for these citizens as the quakes have destroyed towns, seriously damaged local and regional infrastructure, ruined historic and cultural heritage, damaged economic activities especially SMEs, agriculture, as well as tourist and gastronomic potentials. The harsh weather conditions of the forthcoming winter season represent a major concern for the big number of displaced persons and it need to be addressed quickly and effectively in order to guarantee decent living conditions for the people deprived of their dwelling. I believe we have to make everything possible in order to show to the citizens that Europe stands united and backs them and that solidarity cannot remain on paper. The Commission must help the Italian authorities without hesitation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on earthquakes in Italy. The motion stresses that the recent Italian earthquakes have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity and, in many cases, the historical and cultural heritage and, consequently, significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage suffered. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, considering the devastating earthquakes that struck central Italy in 2016 and, according to various reports, caused more than 400 injuries and 290 deaths. Similarly, recent earthquakes have devastated villages, severely damaged local and regional infrastructures, destroyed historical and cultural heritage and affected economic activities, especially those of SMEs, agriculture, natural landscapes and the potential of tourism and hospitality. Therefore, the Union must be ready to assist, through the European Solidarity Fund, taking into account that it is very important that national authorities be able to have these funds as soon as possible.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the heroic efforts made by civil protection forces the earthquakes in Italy have led to the tragic loss of 290 lives and an urgent need to provide relief and reconstruction to the affected areas and to the 100 000 people displaced by the disaster. Due to the costs of this disaster, it is very important that Italy receive increased flexibility in its deficit calculations – this important issue is included in paragraph 6 of the resolution. This paragraph also rightly calls on the Italian Government to ensure that extra resources provided are used to the benefit of those affected and displaced by this tragic disaster. Another key paragraph in the resolution is paragraph 7, as it calls on the Commission to evaluate investing in sustainable reconstruction and other forms of important anti-seismic projects. These investments should be co-financed with ESI funds and excluded from the deficit calculations in regard to the Stability and Growth Pact. This is very important, as it would be wrong to restrict necessary short-term and emergency expenditure on behalf of the affected citizens and their communities.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe has the responsibility, in the face of a painful tragedy such as the earthquake that more than once painfully marked the summer of many citizens and municipalities of Central Italy, to intervene concretely and urgently so that the reconstruction of lives, historical heritage and commercial relations is reborn in a short and certain time. In order to respond effectively to this dramatic emergency, I consider it urgent to call on the Commission to establish short intervention times, measures to simplify and shorten the process bureaucratic activation of funds and consider the possibility of resorting to new lending mechanisms. Italy needs answers, timely, adequate and able to rebuild hope in the affected populations above all.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Italy after the earthquakes. I support the measures to simplify procedures and shorten the time of approval for funds.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because in particular it contains an important principle: expenditure on reconstruction must be excluded from budgetary constraints, as well as expenditure on the prevention. Because while it is true that unfortunately earthquakes, like other disasters, are not foreseeable, the inadequacy of public structures and houses in major Italian seismic areas is demonstrated. We don't know where and when the next earthquake will be, but sadly we know that it would, for the umpteenth time, be a terrible tragedy. We do not call on Europe to replace our local government or take responsibility, we call on Europe to put our government and our regions in the condition of making investment, to rebuild, to modernise, to secure, without this weighing on those budgetary constraints, which are no longer constraints, but obstacles.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses the situation in Italy after the earthquakes suffered in August 2016, followed by several aftershocks and a strong earthquake in October, the most intense in recent decades, which ravaged entire localities and caused multiple damage. It asks the Commission, given the exceptionality and seriousness of this situation, to consider excluding from the calculation of national deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact, investments related to sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention, and to take all necessary measures to analyse promptly requests for assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), with a view to ensuring their rapid mobilization.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. On 24 August 2016 a devastating earthquake hit central Italy, while three other major quakes, within a flurry of tremors, struck central Italian regions. The territories concerned suffer from a deformation that extends over an area of about 130 square km with a maximum displacement of at least 70 cm. Consequently, the quakes have destroyed towns, seriously damaged local and regional infrastructure, ruined historic and cultural heritage, damaged economic activities especially SMEs, agriculture, as well as touristic and gastronomic potentials.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion stresses that the recent earthquakes in Italy have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity and, in many cases, historical and cultural heritage. As a consequence, significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ After the devastating earthquake that hit central Italy on 24 August 2016, I feel that it is necessary to support the above motion. I believe that the reconstruction and any anti-seismic investments should be excluded from the calculation of national deficits in the framework of the Stability and Growth Pact in order to take into account the extent of the devastation.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour, since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for a joint proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Italy after the earthquake because the debate on this situation was initiated on my initiative. I believe that it is extremely important that almost all the members of Parliament have been able to unite on one such important topic. In this context, it is of great importance to simplify the procedure and shorten the time it takes to approve and withdraw funds from the EU Solidarity Fund, and to reconsider the possibilities of establishing a framework mechanism for the European Investment Bank for Loans, which would be established in the purpose of providing funds to Member States before they are disbursed from the Solidarity Fund. The resolution, among other things, appeals to the European Commission to accelerate the development of preventive measures to defend against earthquakes, crisis management and generally minimise the negative consequences caused by natural disasters. It also calls for greater synergy of all available instruments, together with the EFSI Fund, and the effective use of all resources for reconstruction and other necessary interventions in cooperation with Italy's national and regional authorities.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this balanced resolution, which expresses the Union's solidarity with Italy and the victims, following the successive earthquakes that country has experienced. This text highlights prevention and calls for the best use of the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the ENF motion for a resolution. Solidarity is expressed here with the victims of the three major earthquakes in Italy. EU Member States are also expected to promote research to reduce the impact of earthquakes.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — At the plenary session on 1 December, I voted in favour of a motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy after the earthquakes. Three devastating earthquakes hit the Central Apennines between August and October 2016, leaving behind 290 casualties, more than 400 injured and tens of thousands displaced. The last of these soil tremors, which occurred on 30 October, was the strongest earthquake on record in Italy since 1980. The series of earthquakes and the destruction it left behind are having severe economic impacts. It is therefore necessary to properly coordinate the sustainable recovery of areas in order to remedy the economic and social losses caused. This proposal will enable accelerated funding as high as possible from European Union funds and the necessary assistance to the Italian authorities to help ensure dignified living conditions for persons who have lost home. Prevention should represent an increasingly important stage in disaster management and its social importance should increase.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on earthquakes in Italy. The motion stresses that the recent Italian earthquakes have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity and, in many cases, the historical and cultural heritage and, consequently, significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage suffered. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ With today's vote we have expressed all our solidarity with the thousands of people affected by earthquakes in central Italy. The solidarity machine worked perfectly thanks to the timely mobilization of civil protection volunteer units and the coordination of local, regional and national authorities. Reconstruction will take some time and have a significant impact on national finances. Italy, as well as no other country facing a similar catastrophe in the future, can be left alone in this reconstruction effort. That is why we call on the Commission to consider excluding investment from the calculation of national government deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact in favour of sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention. The existing European funding that allows us to invest in the prevention of natural disasters, as well as to ensure the consolidation of reconstruction projects will, on our part, be used best in order to achieve long-term sustainable development of earthquake zones. However, we call on the Commission to take all the necessary steps to examine requests for assistance under the Union Solidarity Fund as soon as possible.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, the latest earthquakes in Italy have led to death of 290 people; 400 people were injured, 150 000 Italians have become homeless. Furthermore, the latest earthquakes have destroyed towns, seriously damaged local and regional infrastructure, ruined historical and cultural heritage, and done serious harm to economic activities, especially those of SMEs which are in agricultural, tourist and gastronomic sectors. Thereby, I call on the European Commission to ensure that all the available instruments within the cohesion and regional funds are effectively used for reconstruction activities in full cooperation with the Italian national and regional authorities. In addition to this, I urge the Commission to undertake all the necessary measures to allow and provide a rapid financing for Italian national and regional authorities from the European Union Solidarity Fund. Last but not least, I would like to remind the Commission and Italian national and regional authorities that sustainable reconstruction efforts need to be properly coordinated in order to fully overcome the economic and social losses from the earthquakes.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it is in the right direction by proposing to make the use of the EUSF flexible. This is indeed in line with French interests because our country will be able to take advantage of it to deal with the floods that hit the south of France.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in solidarity with the people affected by the recent earthquakes in Italy.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The earthquakes that hit Italy in the second half of this year completely destroyed villages in the area and subsequently the inhabitants of the area were brought to the brink of despair. Cities and local and regional infrastructure, historical and cultural heritage, economy, environment, agriculture and the potential of tourism and hospitality industries have been destroyed. The institutions of the European Union and the Member States have shown exceptional solidarity and mutual assistance in emergencies. At the request of the Italian government, the European Union activated emergency management service Copernicus, to obtain an assessment of damage in affected areas based on satellite imagery. The European Parliament stresses the importance of public research and development in preventing and managing disasters and calls for even better coordination and cooperation among R&D institutions in Member States, especially those facing similar risks. It is important to further note the importance of compliance with anti-earthquake construction rules when it comes to buildings and infrastructure. Buildings should comply with existing standards regarding earthquakes, so caution should be exercised when issuing building permits. I believe that in prevention it is important to create synergy among all existing instruments, including European Structural and Investment Funds, so I supported this resolution.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. - As a result of recent earthquakes, cities have been destroyed in Italy, local and regional infrastructure have been severely damaged, historical and cultural heritage have been destroyed, and economic activity has been disrupted. More than 400 victims and 290 fatalities have been reported. I believe that the Commission should take all necessary measures to provide immediate assistance to Italy through the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The inhabitants of Italy have been traumatized by earthquakes with devastating consequences since August this year. This situation requires that all financial support and assistance programmes be able to respond more flexibly and more quickly. We therefore ask the Commission to draw up a proposal without delay to amend the relevant Union standards which will strengthen the Union's belonging to the Member States. It is necessary to ensure that Member States' reconstruction work in such cases is set aside from restrictive budgetary rules and that State aid can be granted in such cases.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy after earthquakes, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, and because this joint motion for a resolution is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. The motion for a resolution aims to simplify the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to make it more efficient and less bureaucratic. This text was put to the European Parliament's vote following the earthquakes that struck Italy between August and October 2016, killing 290 dead and more than 400 injured. This disaster has also caused destruction of historic homes and buildings, which had a major impact on the local tourism sector. The rapporteurs want the use of the EUSF to be more flexible and for the EU to accept the amendment of regional operational programmes to allow regions to use the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to cover reconstruction and prevention costs in the face of seismic risk. We support this initiative.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The resolution expresses solidarity with all the victims of earthquakes in Italy and their families. It also underlines the importance of creating synergies between all available instruments, including the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds, and ensuring that the financial support provided is effectively used for reconstruction activities and for all other necessary actions.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The EUSF shall pay compensation for property damage caused to the assets or loss of income due to the total or partial suspension of the activity for a period not exceeding six months from the occurrence of the natural disaster. Beyond this period, any subsidy from the EUSF may be treated as State aid. It is the only European Fund that reflects genuine European solidarity in the face of natural disasters, hence its legitimacy. However, its raison d'être is threatened because the European Commission is looking at all costs to use the EUSF to help Member States finance migrant reception policies, particularly in Italy, Greece and Cyprus. Defending more flexibility, necessary for the flood-related tragedy in our southern regions of France, I voted in favour of the joint resolution, despite European vocabulary, and that of our allies of the Lega, which is very balanced.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution. It is an important show of solidarity with our neighbours in Italy after the series of earthquakes that struck the country. The EU Solidarity Fund further affirms the EU’s commitment to support citizens in difficult situations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — (NL) For many months, Central Italy has been in the middle of an earthquake storm. After last summer's devastating earthquake, central Italy was also affected by a series of serious earthquakes. As a result, total infrastructure in the area has been severely damaged. Residential centres and villages have been demolished, the rich cultural and historical heritage has been destroyed, economic life has been dislocated and many thousands of people have become homeless. Reconstruction will cost many billions of euros and will take a lot of time. Therefore, and given the enormous needs of the region, I endorse in this resolution the call for the Commission to rapidly mobilise funds from the European Solidarity Funds to support the costs of reconstruction in the region. With the resources from European funds, we can help to speed up the recovery of housing and infrastructure and to make it more resistant to natural disasters.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which highlights the prediction problems associated with earthquake systems and the high seismicity of the Mediterranean area and South East Europe. The report calls on Member States to speed up research with a view to preventing damage, managing crises and minimising the scale of the impact of disasters in conjunction with actions under Horizon 2020, and notes with concern that thousands of people have died and hundreds of thousands have been left homeless in the past 15 years as a result of destructive earthquakes affecting Europe. The report stresses the importance of the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism in fostering cooperation among national civil protection authorities across Europe in adverse situations and in minimising the effects of exceptional occurrences.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - All eight political groups have tabled motions for a resolution on this subject. The political groups, with the exception of the EFN faction, reached agreement and tabled a joint compromise motion. This is the motion I voted in favour of.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: Between August and October 2016, 3 earthquakes struck the Central Apennines, killing 290 people and wounding more than 400. This disaster has led to the destruction of historic homes and buildings, which had a major impact on the local tourism economy. In all, 130 km2 were affected by this terrible earthquake. The EUSF shall pay compensation for property damage caused to the assets or loss of income due to the total or partial suspension of the activity for a period not exceeding six months from the occurrence of the natural disaster. Beyond this period, any subsidy from the EUSF may be treated as State aid. It is the only European Fund that reflects genuine European solidarity in the face of natural disasters, and that is why it is legitimate. However, its raison d'être is threatened because the European Commission is looking at all costs to use the EUSF to help Member States finance migrant reception policies, particularly in Italy, Greece and Cyprus. Vote favourable.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ These proposals are common sense proposals and are structured around three points፦ to make the use of the EUSF more efficient and less bureaucratic intervention; - amend the regional operational programmes to allow the regions to use the ERDF and the ESF to cover the expenditure of the EUSF. reconstruction and prevention in the face of seismic risk; - exclude from the calculation of the public deficit and the scope of the State aid rules all expenditure or tax benefits incurred for the reconstruction of the affected areas. I vote for.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text concerning the situation in Italy after the earthquakes. This text, in addition to expressing the European Union's solidarity with Italy, emphasises the role of States in preventing the consequences of such natural disasters. It also calls for the European Union Solidarity Fund and the Structural Funds to be used more effectively to help the affected populations.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding the three devastating earthquakes in Italy between August and October 2016, killing 290 people, injuring more than 400 and displacing tens of thousands.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution with today's vote because I believe that Italy needs the support of our MEPs, representatives of all Member States, to rebuild the devastated areas and help those affected by these earthquakes. The number of citizens who have been forced to leave their homes and have been displaced is worrying high, and the economic impact of this is devastating for Italy's economy. In this respect, I think it is very important that the European Union Solidarity Fund be used as soon as possible to lend them a hand in overcoming these tragedies. I also support this resolution because it underlines the importance of preventing the impact of natural disasters by building earthquak-resistant buildings and infrastructures and by researching and implementing earthquake prediction systems.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it expresses its solidarity with the victims and is being used for reconstruction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Given the damage caused by earthquakes in Italy, comprehensive aid and support for Italy is essential. The resolution provides for more flexibility in calculating the deficit in relation to expenditure, asks the Commission to consider investment in reconstruction work and asks the Commission to urgently process aid from the European Solidarity Fund.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I support the resolution tabled. The recent earthquakes have led to an exceptional and very serious situation in Italy, which must be addressed promptly and effectively. First of all, prevention should be an increasingly important stage in disaster management and should be given greater social importance. It is necessary to strengthen disaster prevention measures and to carry out the necessary research to prevent adverse effects, to manage crises and to minimise the impact of disasters. The Commission should consider offering the Italian authorities all the aid they need to ensure adequate living conditions for those who have lost their homes. In this case, the EU Solidarity Fund plays a special role, which must be a reliable and flexible instrument for demonstrating solidarity and providing adequate and rapid assistance to those affected by major natural disasters. In this context, I think it is appropriate to consider extending the existing methods for calculating the Solidarity Fund. Furthermore, the Commission should exclude investment in sustainable recovery and anti-seismic construction from the calculation of its national deficit under the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The account of the devastating earthquake in central Italy in August this year is tragic: human losses, thousands of displaced persons, serious damage to local and regional infrastructure. All this brings a strong blow to historical and cultural heritage and economic activities. In addition, Italian national, regional and local public authorities are subject to great and strong financial pressure. It is obvious that in such exceptional situations the expression of solidarity is valuable. I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Commission and the Member States to further simplify the procedures for activating the Union's European Civil Protection Mechanism so that it is quickly and effectively available immediately after a disaster. This should be a priority, given the high seismicity of Southeast Europe. It also underlines the importance of creating synergies between all available instruments, including the European Structural and Investment Funds, to ensure that the funds are actually used for reconstruction activities and all other necessary interventions; in full cooperation with the Italian or, in the future, with the national and regional authorities concerned.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution RC-B8-1285/2016 on the situation in Italy following earthquakes since, as an Italian citizen, before acting as an Italian citizen Representative of the Italian people to the European Parliament, I was deeply and directly affected by the human drama that has invested my country. The fragility of the Italian territory has been substantiated following the latest seismic events, in the deaths, injuries of a large number of people and continues to insist on the lives of 100 000 residents who are have been forced to abandon their homes; to the unacceptable social costs should then be added to the significant economic costs which affect the stability of the affected areas; I know the power of solidarity arising in the consex of the Member States where one of them is affected and the consequent implementation of mechanisms for mutual assistance in emergency situations; comforted by this awareness and driven by the moral duty that requires me to stand next to my countrymen I welcome and ratify the content of the resolution for a mobilization towards Italy, especially with the timely intervention by the European Union Solidarity Fund. Therefore, I voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — From August to October 2016, three devastating earthquakes struck central Apennines and caused 290 dead, more than 400 injured and led to the evacuation of tens of thousands of people. In the affected areas present deformation has covered an area of about 130 square kilometres, with a maximum displacement of at least 70 centimetres, and has led to significant destruction of inhabited sites, infrastructure and historical, artistic and cultural heritage, even of world importance, as well as to complete cessation of production and tourism activities. I regret the fact that the restrictions imposed by the Union budget regulations in force and state aid make it impossible in practice for Member States at risk of earthquakes to implement harmonised investment plans for the restoration and prevention of earthquakes, as well as support plans for the affected economic activities, without those Member States having to withhold services or funds intended for other but planned structural investments. I am extremely sorry for the victims and sympathize with all citizens affected by earthquakes, and I express my admiration and congratulations for the courage in organizing and providing assistance, especially civil protection workers, volunteers, police, firefighters and municipalities chiefs. As a result, I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the situation of Italy after the earthquake.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: Between August and October 2016, three earthquakes struck the Central Apennines, killing 290 people and wounding more than 400. This disaster has led to the destruction of historic homes and buildings, which had a major impact on the local tourism economy. In all, 130 km2 were affected by this terrible earthquake. The Solidarity Fund is one of the few manifestations of genuine solidarity between the Member States of the European Union, so I am voting in favour of this legitimate aid.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The strong seismic swarm that struck central Italy, starting from the devastating earthquake of 24 August 2016, up to those of 26 and 30 October, caused the deaths of 290 people and over 400 injured. Entire towns and small countries have been razed to the ground, forcing around 100 000 people to abandon their homes. The Italian government has committed itself and is working hard to ensure decent living conditions for all people who have lost their homes, before the arrival of the winter season. It is important that the EU does its utmost to support the Italian authorities in this effort, examining the request for assistance under the Solidarity Fund as soon as possible and guaranteeing it a rapid mobilization, starting with the advances foreseen in the 2014 reform. Once the emergency has passed there will be to face reconstruction, to repair the enormous economic and social damage caused by earthquakes, without forgetting the restoration of cultural heritage. In this case, too, European support will be indispensable to promote sustainable and earthquake-proof reconstruction, through the synergistic use of its financial instruments and greater flexibility on the calculation of the deficit.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - A devastating earthquake struck Italy in August 2016, followed by three other major earthquakes and a series of smaller earthquakes in October of the same year. In these earthquakes, cities were destroyed, local and regional infrastructure was damaged, historical and cultural heritage was destroyed. Economic activities, the environment, agriculture and the potential of tourism and hospitality industries also suffered damage. According to reports, more than 400 people were injured and 290 were killed and 100,000 residents were displaced. There are justified concerns about the large number of displaced people who will be exposed to severe weather during the coming winter. S&D expresses its solidarity and sympathy with all individuals and families in earthquake-affected areas, as well as with the Italian authorities involved in providing assistance. I welcome the approval of a greater level of flexibility to Italy in calculating the deficit on the costs incurred by the earthquake, in order to enable it to respond effectively and quickly to an emergency situation. The Italian Government has submitted a request for funding from the European Solidarity Fund and I believe it is now important for the Commission to take all necessary measures to analyse this requirement and enable rapid mobilisation. It is important that advances are available to national authorities as soon as possible so that they can respond to the urgent needs associated with the situation.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Given the seriousness of the earthquake in Italy, the resolution calls on the Commission to take all necessary measures to allow and provide rapid and highest possible funding through the European Union Solidarity Fund, emphasises the role and increased responsibility of the regional and local authorities in the management and distribution of funds in their territories. It is important to mobilise all the instruments available under the regional and cohesion funds so that they are used effectively for reconstruction activities and all other necessary interventions, in full cooperation with the Italian national and regional authorities.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — In a short space of time less than three months, three devastating earthquakes struck Italy immediately, claiming hundreds dead and injured and leaving tens of thousands in their wake displaced people and huge material damage. We must remember that the European Union Solidarity Fund contributes only to expenditure related to subsequent aid and emergency, and that Member States at risk of natural disaster must beside this issue high amounts on preventive measures. I therefore supported the requirement that the Commission draw up a proposal to amend the relevant regulations so that Member States' expenditure on investments in reconstruction works and prevention measures earthquakes were not subject to Union restrictions, e.g. that tax benefits granted by Member States to citizens affected by the disaster would not be considered public aid.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the mobilization of the EUSF to help Italy after the devastating earthquake that ravaged central Italy on 24 August 2016, and the three other violent earthquakes that struck several Italian regions on 26 and 30 October 2016. We must mobilize so that Italian citizens can cope with the difficulties, as quickly as possible and with dignity, after this series of unprecedented disasters.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We first of all offer our condolences to all those affected by the earthquakes in Italy. UKIP is usually opposed to the spending of any EU money. However in light of the tragic human suffering in cases of environmental disaster we have chosen to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The motion for a resolution adopted in the context of the debate on the Union Solidarity Fund (created to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and bring European solidarity to the sinister regions of Europe) following the devastating earthquakes that struck central Italy in August and October 2016, and by which about 300 people lost their lives and more than 400 others were injured, with the possible displacement of another 100,000. It is intended to answer questions as to whether the Commission has received a request from the Italian Government to receive funding from the Fund and has taken all necessary measures to assess the request and to mobilise this funding expeditiously. And whether the Commission will consider requests for amendments to Italian national and regional operational programmes in order to better address the issues of thematic objective 5 ('Promoting climate change adaptation and risk prevention and management') and consider existing procedures for evaluating applications of funding with a view to simplifying them and shortening the required deadlines. I voted in favour of the resolution finally adopted.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Italy following the earthquakes that shook that country. Recent earthquakes in Italy have resulted in more than 400 injured and 290 deaths. I would like to stress paragraph 7 of that resolution, which calls on the Commission to consider excluding any anti-seismic investment and sustainable reconstruction from the calculation of national deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact. Proof that the Stability and Growth Pact, in its present form, can lead to difficulties in terms of investment expenditure in some Member States.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — It is nice to see that the situation in Italy is improving. The resolution under discussion today contains a number of important provisions, among which the emphasis is on increasing both the seismic resilience of buildings and the maintenance of construction. To that end, the EU also made its contribution by ensuring certain temporary exemptions from the budgetary deficit methodology. At the same time, I would like to point out that the attempt by some Italian politicians to establish the provisions that these exceptions must remain permanent, and the Member States' spending on increasing the seismic resilience of buildings must be removed from the calculation of the budget deficit will most likely lead to the opposite results — most of these costs will not reach their addressees, and trust in the EU's financial discipline policy will be completely ruined.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - In August and October 2016, a series of strong earthquakes plagued central Italy, causing injuries to more than 400 people, regrettably claimed the lives of 290, and forced 100,000 inhabitants to move as a result of the destruction caused. The impact of these earthquakes destroyed cities, caused damage to local and regional infrastructures, destroyed historical and cultural heritage and caused severe disturbances in economic, agricultural and tourist activities. The European Union Civil Protection Mechanism is absolutely essential in promoting cooperation between national civil protection authorities across Europe, so activation procedures need to be simplified for prompt, rapid and effective delivery of aid in the event of disasters like this one. There is also a need to create synergies between all available instruments, including the European Structural and Investment Funds, in order to ensure that resources are used quickly and effectively in the necessary interventions. Given that some EU territories are more vulnerable and more likely to recurrent natural disasters, I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the need to support these regions in particular more quickly and effectively.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which shows the European Parliament's solidarity with Italy, which is constantly suffering from earthquakes. These earthquakes not only damaged local and regional infrastructure and destroyed a rich cultural and historical heritage, but they also claimed the lives of Italians. First of all, this text would like to recall that the European Union stands alongside Italy and the families affected by these natural disasters. It is crucial to highlight and commend the tireless efforts made by relief units, civil protection and the numerous volunteers in Italian cities, such as the Amateur, in order to help the affected families. It should be noted that Italy has applied to the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide funds for the care of victims and the reconstruction of destroyed towns and sites. Finally, I supported this resolution, which calls for better cooperation with local authorities and optimization of European funds for the prevention of natural disasters or investment in anti-seismic structures.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which expresses its deepest solidarity and empathy with all those affected by the earthquakes in Italy, since it asks the Commission for exceptional measures, such as the possibility of extending the current method of calculating the Solidarity Fund. It also emphasizes the importance of prevention systems and compliance with requirements for the construction of earthquae-resistant buildings and infrastructures. The tragic experience of the population of central Italy, which now begins the reconstruction, shows us how the earthquake ended all the restoration works of previous earthquakes, generating great despair in the population. We therefore need more effective solidarity, and that involves increasing and making the Solidarity Fund available quickly and flexibly. As the resolution went along this line, I decided to support it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — In the earthquakes that hit Italy between 24 August and 30 October more than 400 people were injured, 290 lost their lives and as a result of these events 100,000 people were displaced from their residences. These seismic events damaged local infrastructure, ruined historical and cultural heritage, and damaged economic activities, especially SMEs, agriculture and the potential of industries of tourism and hospitality. The state of emergency must therefore be recognised and all necessary measures must be taken to provide rapid and effective financing through the European Union Solidarity Fund. The possibility of using the European Rural Development Fund to support rural areas and agricultural activities that have been affected by earthquakes should also be considered. With today's resolution we confirm our call for immediate aid and reconstruction expenditure to be outside the constraints of the Stability Pact. Our appeal now goes to the Italian state: we must work to give a future to the destroyed villages, with seriousness, security and maximum transparency!

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. On 24 August 2016 a devastating earthquake hit central Italy, while three other major quakes, within a flurry of tremors, struck central Italian regions. The territories concerned suffer from a deformation that extends over an area of about 130 square km with a maximum displacement of at least 70 cm. Consequently, the quakes have destroyed towns, seriously damaged local and regional infrastructure, ruined historic and cultural heritage, damaged economic activities especially SMEs, agriculture, as well as touristic and gastronomic potentials.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. “The situation in Italy after the devastating earthquake is very bad. Earthquakes razed whole villages with the ground, brought many residents of the affected areas to the brink of hopelessness and caused much damage. During recent earthquakes in Italy, 290 people lost their lives and more than 400 people were injured. The domino effect of subsequent upheavals caused up to 100,000 residents to lose their homes. Very badly damaged roads, transport infrastructure, historical and cultural heritage, economic activity, agriculture, the landscape changed and the travel market in the area was completely paralyzed. The affected area represents approximately 130 km2 of Italian territory. All this causes a large number of people to be displaced, and in the coming winter period it is necessary to find temporary, but acceptable forms of accommodation for a decent life for them. In this natural disaster, the importance of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism in terms of cooperation between national civil protection authorities throughout Europe should be emphasised. Following the request from the Italian Government for support from the European Solidarity Fund, it is now up to the Commission to urgently take all possible measures to analyse the aid application and to release from the Fund's budget the necessary funds to eliminate the consequences of the devastating earthquake.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The earthquake, which occurred on 30 October in Italy at a magnitude of 6.5, is considered one of the strongest earthquakes on the Apennine Peninsula since the 80s. As a result of three successive earthquakes, more than 100,000 inhabitants in the seismic area have been left without homes. Towns, villages are destroyed, local and regional infrastructure is damaged, historic and cultural buildings are destroyed, and all this has a negative impact on tourism and the economy. In the current situation, it is most important to provide assistance to the affected areas both in financial form as well as in the form of humanitarian aid. It is necessary to start rebuilding affected areas and buildings as soon as possible so that locals can return to their homes and continue their normal lives. Since the situation is very serious and given the large number of persons affected, it is necessary that the European Commission takes all necessary measures to analyse Italy's request for financial assistance from the European Solidarity Fund as quickly as possible. Italy needs to grant the financial assistance requested, while it is prudent to establish the necessary synergies between the various financial instruments for the purposes of rapid renewal and to ensure that the funds are used effectively and transparently. Because of all of the above, I voted to pass the resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Restrictions imposed by the current Union standards in relation to the budget and State aid to Member States at risk of earthquake make effective and necessary assistance impossible in practice. The whole system of measures linked to this assistance needs to be streamlined as quickly as possible. It is therefore essential that, for this purpose, a proposal to amend the relevant Union legislation should be drawn up without delay.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — For the last 15 years, the consequences of devastating earthquakes that hit Europe have seen thousands of people killed and hundreds of thousands have been left without homes. Southeast Europe is an area of strong seismic activity, which we have seen in the example of Central Italy. More than 400 people were injured and 290 were killed, according to reports. Earthquakes and subsequent soil tremors in central Italy have continued over the past months, and the earthquake that struck Italy on 30 October was the strongest recorded in the country since 1980. Members of the European Union must solidarize themselves and assist each other in emergencies of this nature. Homes, cities, historical and cultural heritage have been destroyed, and that is why I support this Resolution because I believe that we need to provide worthy living conditions for people who are left without homes, and these monetary incentives help to restore entrepreneurship, tourism and gastronomy of damaged areas strengthened as an economic branch.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy after earthquakes. Italy has been hit by earthquakes this year, followed by further aftershocks that devastated entire villages, and put many residents of the aforementioned and surrounding areas to the brink of despair. More than 400 people were injured and 290 died. I therefore support the call for the Commission to consider, in the light of the emergency and very serious situation, the possibility of excluding sustainable renewal and any anti-earthquake investments, including investments co-financed by the European Structural and Investment Funds, from the calculation of national deficits under the pact for stability and growth.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. — The motion for a resolution does not really address the problems of the affected areas; on the contrary, it shows that the approach is fragmented and always under the sword of the Damocles of austerity measures.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The dramatic events that have recently hit Central Italy require the European and national institutions a reflection on safety and prevention. I agree with the call on Member States to support research in order to prevent damage, manage crises promptly, minimising the scale of the impact of disasters. In the face of the tragedies that, over the last 15 years, has led to the deaths of thousands of people and reduced to the condition of displaced people hundreds of thousands more as a result of destructive earthquakes, we remember the importance of adhering to the requirements for the construction of earthquake-resistant buildings and infrastructure. Parliament will continue to urge national, regional and local authorities to step up their efforts to make structures comply with existing earthquake standards, paying due attention at the time of issuing construction permits. I consider the Commission's commitment to give greater flexibility in calculating the deficit on earthquake expenditure extremely positive, this will enable the current emergency to be confronted in a way Efficient and quick.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Joint Motion for a Resolution submitted pursuant to Article 128 (5) and Article 123 (4). Rules of Procedure, replacing proposals for resolutions of the following clubs: PPE (B8-1285/2016), Verts/ALE (B8-1286/2016), S&D (B8-1288/2016), EFDD (B8-1289/2016), ECR (B8-1291/2016), ALDE (B8-1294/2016), GUE/NGL (B8-1296/2016) about the situation in Italy after the earthquake. I believe that it is important to highlight the importance that the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism has in encouraging cooperation in crisis situations among national civil protection bodies across Europe and in minimising the consequences of emergency events. I also support the urging of the Commission and the Member States to further simplify the procedures for activating this mechanism so that it can be made available quickly and efficiently immediately after the disaster occurs. In particular, I consider it necessary to establish improved early warning systems in Member States and to create and strengthen links between various early warning systems in order to prevent or at least minimise damage in the event of future earthquakes as qualitatively as possible.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — Italy, one of the most seismically active countries in the world, was hit by several devastating earthquakes between 24 August and 20 October 2016. In these earthquakes, 290 people died, more than 400 people were injured, and 100 thousand citizens were forced to leave their homes. In addition, the earthquakes have destroyed cities, damaged local and regional infrastructure, historical and cultural heritage and have a negative impact on the area's agriculture, economy and tourism. With this resolution, together with the other signatories, I invited the Commission to take the necessary measures to provide effective and swift support through the European Union Solidarity Fund and to consider the possibility of activating the European Rural Development Fund and the Italian Government to use the funds obtained for the purpose of for which they are envisaged. I believe that this can greatly facilitate the situation for people affected by earthquakes and embark on the necessary recovery of economic and agricultural activities.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Italy after earthquakes. Italy was hit by a devastating earthquake in August 2016, followed by three more powerful earthquakes at the end of October. Whole villages have been completely demolished, bringing many residents of the affected areas to the brink of despair and causing major indirect damage in surrounding areas. There was a displacement of 100,000 residents. The gusts of recent earthquakes have devastated cities, severely damaging local and regional infrastructure, destroying historic and cultural heritage, and damaging economic activities, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, agriculture, the province, as well as the capacity of tourism and catering activities. It is necessary to offer immediate assistance and take measures that will ensure the relief of problems before the coming winter.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses the situation in Italy after the earthquakes suffered in August 2016, followed by several aftershocks and a strong earthquake in October, the most intense in recent decades, which ravaged entire localities and caused multiple damage. It asks the Commission, given the exceptionality and seriousness of this situation, to consider excluding from the calculation of national deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact, investments related to sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention, and to take all necessary measures to analyse promptly requests for assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), with a view to ensuring their rapid mobilization.
