name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution and vote in favour, in solidarity with the populations in Italy after the terrible earthquakes. It is not the first time the centre of Italy has been affected by tragic events in the last two years. The Solidarity Fund is there for this, and Europe has to support countries and populations which face tragic events. Only like this will Europe gain more support from EU people.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: Between August and October 2016, 3 earthquakes struck the Central Apennines, killing 290 people and wounding more than 400. This disaster has led to the destruction of historic homes and buildings, which had a major impact on the local tourism economy. In all, 130 km2 were affected by this terrible earthquake. The EU Solidarity Fund shall cover compensation for property damage caused to assets or loss of income due to the total or partial suspension of the activity for a period not exceeding six months from the occurrence of the natural disaster. Beyond this period, any subsidy from the EUSF may be treated as State aid. It is the only European Fund that reflects genuine European solidarity in the face of natural disasters and that is why it is legitimate regardless of our political position towards the European institutions. Be careful, however, in the future, because its raison d'être is threatened by the European Commission, which at all costs seeks to use the EUSF to help Member States finance policies for receiving migrants, particularly in Italy, Greece and Cyprus. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — This resolution focuses on the situation in Italy after several devastating earthquakes. More than 400 people were injured and 290 lost their lives. Following these events, 100,000 people were displaced from their homes. In addition, earthquakes destroyed towns, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, ruined historic and cultural heritage sites. Economic activity, especially agriculture and tourism and hospitality industries, suffered. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 24 August 2016, the devastating earthquake in central Italy was followed by a number of quakes in the regions of Central Italy. According to reports, more than 400 people were injured and 290 were killed as a result of the recent quakes. I voted in favour of your S&D resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which addresses the situation in Italy after the earthquakes suffered in August 2016, followed by several aftershocks and a strong earthquake in October, the most intense in recent decades, which ravaged entire localities and caused multiple damage. It asks the Commission, given the exceptionality and seriousness of this situation, to consider excluding from the calculation of national deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact, investments related to sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention, and to take all necessary measures to analyse promptly requests for assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), with a view to ensuring their rapid mobilization.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I draw attention to the predictability problems associated with earthquake systems and to the high seismic activity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy after the earthquakes. Between August and October 2016 three devastating earthquakes hit the Central Apennines region of Italy, killing 290 people, injuring more than 400 and displacing tens of thousands. The most recent quake, which occurred on 30 October, is the strongest to have been recorded in Italy since the 1980 Irpinia earthquake. The territories concerned suffer from a deformation that extends over an area of about 130 square km, with a maximum displacement of at least 70 cm. The earthquakes caused serious damage to towns, infrastructure and historic, artistic and cultural heritage assets. In order to cover reconstruction costs, Italy may be obliged to submit a request for the amendment of its national and regional operational programmes under Article 30 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 in order to be able to allocate more resources to Thematic Objective 5. The resolution underlines the serious economic effects of the successive earthquakes and the destruction left in their wake. I voted in favour because I believe that we have to show our deepest solidarity and empathy with all the individuals affected by the earthquakes and their families.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. — By this resolution the European Parliament shows its commitment to the Italian State after the terrible earthquakes it has suffered. It is at such a difficult time when the Union must be close to its citizens and, through solidarity, show its support for those affected by this terrible event. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which expresses its deepest solidarity and empathy with all those affected by the earthquakes in Italy, since it asks the Commission for exceptional measures, such as the possibility of extending the current method of calculating the Solidarity Fund. It also emphasizes the importance of prevention systems and compliance with requirements for the construction of earthquae-resistant buildings and infrastructures. The tragic experience of the population of central Italy, which now begins the reconstruction, shows us how the earthquake ended all the restoration works of previous earthquakes, generating great despair in the population. We therefore need more effective solidarity, and that involves increasing and making the Solidarity Fund available quickly and flexibly. As the resolution went along this line, I decided to support it.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: ‒ The N-VA acknowledges the emergency situation in Italy following the successive earthquakes of 24 August and 30 October 2016 and deplores the victims who claimed the natural disaster and the damage caused to infrastructure, heritage, economic activities, agriculture, tourism and industries strongly. Among other things, we call on the European Commission to take necessary measures for rapid and effective financing measures by the European Solidarity Fund and to ensure that all the resources provided to alleviate the situation are actually used by the Italian government for those purposes. However, the call for expenditure on reconstruction to be exempted from the budgetary obligations under the Stability and Growth Pact is a red line for the delegation. In order to avoid a new debt crisis in the euro area, N-VA calls for clear and simple budgetary rules that are applied unambiguously. That is why the N-VA delegation decided to vote against the resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Given the seriousness of the earthquake in Italy, the resolution calls on the Commission to take all necessary measures to allow and provide rapid and highest possible funding through the European Union Solidarity Fund, emphasises the role and increased responsibility of the regional and local authorities in the management and distribution of funds in their territories. It is important to mobilise all the instruments available under the regional and cohesion funds so that they are used effectively for reconstruction activities and all other necessary interventions, in full cooperation with the Italian national and regional authorities.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The joint motion for a resolution expresses solidarity with the victims of the three major earthquakes in Italy on 24 August, 26 October and 30 October 2016, called for an examination of the exemption from reconstruction and safeguard funding for the calculation of national deficits in the framework of the Stability and Growth Pact, and expressed the desire for Member States to promote research to reduce the impact of earthquakes. That is why I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Italy following earthquakes. Considering that, after the devastating earthquake that struck central Italy on August 24 last year, other serious telluric events linked to the same seismic swarm have hit the same areas in recent months and Considering that 100,000 people have been forced to leave their homes because they are inaccessible, the resolution calls on the Commission, in the light of the very serious and exceptional nature of the situation, to consider excluding from the calculation of national government deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact investments in favour of sustainable reconstruction and the anti-seismic prevention. It takes note of the application for intervention under the European Union Solidarity Fund submitted by the Italian Government and calls on the Commission to take all the necessary measures to to examine requests for assistance under the Fund in a timely manner in order to ensure their rapid mobilisation. The resolution also underlines the importance of advances being made available to national authorities as soon as possible, so as to enable them to meet the pressing needs imposed from the situation.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to join my colleagues in extending condolences and support for all victims and communities affected by the recent earthquakes in Italy. I hope European assistance will be able to aid in reconstruction and recovery efforts.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the resolution on the situation in Italy. Italy was hit by a series of devastating earthquakes in the second half of this year that left several hundred injured and dead, but also destroyed dwellings, infrastructure and cultural and historical monuments. Last but not least, these earthquakes had a negative impact on trade and tourism. In the resolution we therefore looked at how coordinated work should be aimed at restoring destroyed towns and municipalities, what preventive measures to choose and how reconstruction works should be financed. On this last point, we have highlighted in particular the European Union Solidarity Fund, which helps financially precisely in the event of natural disasters, but also other European funds. I think it is extremely important in such cases to express solidarity with a country affected by a natural disaster and also to show that the European Union is able to help Member States quickly and effectively.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on the situation in Italy after the earthquake. It is very important to solidarize with the inhabitants of Italy who have suffered huge losses, both human and material. At this time it is necessary to express concern as soon as possible about the large number of people left without their homes due to devastating earthquakes. There is a cold winter period ahead and it is important as urgently as possible to provide accommodation for people whose homes have been destroyed in earthquakes. From the Solidarity Fund it is necessary to send financial assistance to the vulnerable as soon as possible so that there is no situation that we have more victims of this natural disaster due to a slow reaction. In addition to clearly acting and responding to the existing situation in Italy, it is important to plan preventive actions that would minimise or at least mitigate such disasters in the future as much as possible. The importance and urgency of this situation has also demonstrated the great courage of rescue units, volunteers and authorities at all levels in Italy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The purpose of the Commissioners' declaration of interest is to ensure maximum transparency and accountability. In recent years, however, the need to evaluate several times these kinds of statements, one in all that of Arias Cañete, Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy, has highlighted several shortcomings of the regulation. I very much appreciated some of the solutions provided in the proposal such as introducing the obligation to submit the declaration also in relation to family members and the extension of three years for restrictions concerning the use of former commissioners. As far as I said earlier, I decided to vote for it.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because, following the process of appointing the Commissionarial College in 2014 and the news that subsequently appeared in relation to several Commissioners, the need for the European Commission to review its Code of Conduct is evident, to ensure that the declarations of interests of Commissioners accurately reflect their financial situation and that of their families. The financial interest statement shall include the current activities and interests of the preceding two years, Commissioners will have to declare all their interests as 'shareholders, members of boards of directors, advisors and consultants, members of foundations', as well as the interests of close relatives. In the event of a conflict of interest identified during the term of office, the President of the Commission shall follow Parliament's recommendations to resolve it, or the House may withdraw confidence in that Commissioner and, if appropriate, deprive him of his pension rights and other benefits. The resolution also provides for an extension from 18 to 36 months of the period within which Commissioners, once out of their office, should refrain from working for the private sector in the field for which they were responsible.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report and in favour of the one amendment to this report, which called to extend Commissioners’ post-office employment restrictions to a period of at least 3 years without making any changes to the transitional rules. I am happy that this amendment was passed so that unethical appointments, such as that of Former President of the Commission José Manuel Barroso to Goldman Sachs, do not happen in the future without a proper cooling-off period.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 because of the recent serious conflicts of interest concerning them. In particular, the proposal requires Commissioners to declare all their interests in companies, including their family interests, as well as their membership in NGOs or associations playing a lobby role. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As this resolution would increase transparency, and place greater accountability upon the unelected Commission, I felt it was important to vote in favour. However, as it is an own-initiative report I note that the passing of this resolution is not in any way binding.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on guidelines for declarations of interests of Commissioners. Annex XVI to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, entitled 'Guidelines for the approval of the Commission', states that 'Parliament may request any information necessary to take a decision on the suitability of the appointed members of the Commission. He hopes that all information relating to their financial interests will be disclosed. Declarations of interests of the Commissioners appointed shall be submitted to the committee responsible for legal affairs'. Unfortunately, that provision does not specifically define the scope of the investigation by the Committee on Legal Affairs, particularly as regards the question of whether this investigation requires only formal examination of the information provided or, conversely, an in-depth investigation. I therefore agree with the rapporteur, who proposes to define the scope of the examination of declarations of interest in the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The report is a European Parliament resolution on Commissioners' financial interests, in which the EP summarises its views and needs on the issue of conflicts of interest of Commissioners. The proposed proposals are eligible and clearly aimed at transparency and the exclusion of mergers with the economic sphere, whether this will be enforced in practice. I also supported Amendment No 1, extending the period of employment restrictions after the term of office of Commissioners for at least three years or for at least as long as the former Commissioner is eligible for temporary aid under the relevant regulation. Speaking of which, apparently, Jean-Claude Juncker ordered an investigation into the case of his predecessor, José Manuel Barroso, who recently started working for the American investment bank Goldman Sachs. The proposal also considers that the verification of the declaration of financial interests and, more broadly, of possible conflicts of interest involving members of the Commission should go beyond the single procedure for appointing the Commission. In this regard, it considers that any substantive modification of a Commissioner's financial interests during the term of office or the redistribution of tasks between the members of the Commission creates a new situation for the possible existence of conflicts of interest, and therefore a new parliamentary examination procedure should be the subject of.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament is considering tightening the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 following the recent serious conflicts of interest. I voted in favour of this proposal, which seeks to force Commissioners to declare all their interests in companies and their links with NGOs or lobbies.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — Barroso, Kroes, this week's case of endocrine disruptors, the multiple scandals centred on the Commission maintain a disastrous image of the European institutions and a failing ethics! Both internal procedures in the European Parliament, when the new Commission is appointed and throughout its term of office, and the transparency obligations of the members of the Commission must be addressed. The verification of the absence of a conflict of interest cannot be put to the same level as the assessment of the candidate's competencies. It must therefore be an indispensable prerequisite for the hearing. The control of statements of financial interests and, more broadly, of potential conflicts of interest concerning the members of the Commission must extend beyond the Commission's appointment procedure alone. I also expect from the Commission a series of amendments to its code of conduct and declarations of interest to ensure that these include sufficient information to assess the Commissioners' financial interests and that Parliament is informed of any changes.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Recent events involving former President of the European Commission, José Manuel Barroso, and Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete have opened a new reflection at the level Community on possible conflicts of interest that may involve EU top figures. The Durand report, which I supported in my vote, addresses this issue by asking the Commission to revise the code of conduct for commissioners. It is necessary to ensure that declarations of interest provide a complete picture of their financial situation, activities and those of their family members. In the event of an established conflict the President should follow Parliament's recommendations or allow the latter to recommend withdrawal of trust or deprive the Commissioner of Benefits and Rights to the pension. As far as the former commissioners are concerned, the text requires that the period of 'reflection' be extended from 18 to at least 36 months, the period of time which must be taken before they can fill in the roles of private sector in their areas of expertise. These are coherent measures that can broaden the role of Parliament, ensuring greater transparency of institutions and increasing the confidence of citizens.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, as its objective is to monitor Commissioners' statements of financial interests, in order to ensure that they can fulfil their mandates completely independently and to ensure maximum transparency for the Commission. Any change in the financial interests of a Commissioner during his term of office, or any reorganization of the distribution of responsibilities between the members of the Commission, constitutes a new situation as to the possible existence of a conflict of interest. The Commission is also asked to urgently review the 2011 Commissioners' Code of Conduct to take into account the recommendations made by Parliament in its recent resolutions. We believe that an institution such as the Commission should increase transparency and ensure the independence of Commissioners. That is why our vote was favourable.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: It is rare that I am so enthusiastic about a parliamentary report, but here my colleague Pascal Durand has done a remarkable job. A remarkable work in terms of its objectivity, neutrality, rationality and constructive character. While the current code of conduct applicable to Commissioners can be criticized, it is certainly not perfect, but it has at least the merit of existence. Regularly since 2004, in 2011 and now in 2016, it has been constantly improving and sticking closer to realities. Pascal Durand's proposals approved by the Committee on Legal Affairs are indeed in this direction, and I think that including the family interests referred to in point 1.6 of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct in statements of financial interest in view of Commissioner Canete's past and ambiguous situation is an excellent initiative. Don't be mistaken, this file is important. This is true of the credibility of the European Union as a whole.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on European Commissioners' declarations of interest, which calls for more comprehensive declarations of interest by European Commissioners, and calls for greater powers of control for the European Chamber. Transparency of this information must also be essential.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I supported this report, which calls for a tightening of the code of conduct governing the activities of European Commissioners. Indeed, the infamous “cases” of conflicts of interest affecting former or current Commissioners denote the urgency of establishing a minimum of transparency and ethics in the all-powerful Commission. The slipper at Goldman Sachs by José Manuel Barroso, former President of the European Commission, is just the tree that hides the forest. In 2006, a motion of censure was tabled by 77 MEPs questioning the links between José Manuel Barroso and the Latsis Group (banking, oil, real estate, shipbuilding) belonging to Greek billionaire Spiros Latsis. Dusan Sidjanski, President of the European Centre for Culture (whose mission is to promote European federalism) funded by the Latsis Group, was appointed “Special Adviser to the Commission” by José Manuel Barroso to promote the “Europe of the Regions”. It is therefore more that as long as, as advocated by this report, Commissioners are forced to declare all their interests in companies but also their potential membership in NGOs or associations engaged in lobbying the public authorities.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Durand report is balanced and shareable. I believe that the control of financial statements of interests, and more generally the potential conflicts of interest concerning the members of the Commission, must go beyond the appointment procedure alone of the Commission. I intend to support this text and call for a number of amendments to the Commission's Code of Conduct and its declarations of interests, in order to ensure that these texts include the Commission's code of conduct and its declarations of interests. sufficient information to assess the Commissioners' financial interests and that Parliament is aware of all amendments.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because, following the process of appointing the Commissionarial College in 2014 and the news that subsequently appeared in relation to several Commissioners, the need for the European Commission to review its Code of Conduct is evident, to ensure that the declarations of interests of Commissioners accurately reflect their financial situation and that of their families. The financial interest statement shall include the current activities and interests of the preceding two years, Commissioners will have to declare all their interests as 'shareholders, members of boards of directors, advisors and consultants, members of foundations', as well as the interests of close relatives. In the event of a conflict of interest identified during the term of office, the President of the Commission shall follow Parliament's recommendations to resolve it, or the House may withdraw confidence in that Commissioner and, if appropriate, deprive him of his pension rights and other benefits. The resolution also provides for an extension from 18 to 36 months of the period within which Commissioners, once out of their office, should refrain from working for the private sector in the field for which they were responsible.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which discusses guidelines on the declarations of interests of Commissioners. The European Parliament proposes to define the scope of the examination of declarations of interest within the Committee on Legal Affairs. This should include, in particular, the internal procedures of the European Parliament for the appointment of the new Commission and the transparency requirements applicable to Members of the Commission. Parliament considers that the verification of a conflict of interest cannot be equivalent to the assessment of the candidate's competences, and therefore this verification must be a prerequisite for hearing. Furthermore, it considers that the concept of a conflict of interest must include only objective and verifiable factors which can only be assessed in the light of a specific area of responsibility. Parliament therefore concludes that the Committee on Legal Affairs must both assess the possibility of a conflict of interest and, if necessary, recommend how to eliminate it. It may be recommended to waive certain financial interests or to change the scope of responsibility of a Member of the Commission. In order for the investigation to be effective, the rapporteur considers that the Committee on Legal Affairs must request additional information if the declaration raises doubts, incomplete or contradictory.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree that the requirements on the declarations of interests of the Commissioners should be tightened. Thus, by extending and improving the rules on conflicts of interest, these declarations should also include detailed information on possible contractual relations of a candidate for commissioner which could lead to conflicts of interest in the performance of his duties. It is in the interest of all, and in particular the people of the Union, to avoid possible conflicts of interest by maximising transparency.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this Report. We need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interest in the European Commission. The case of Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete shows that the current system is not enough. The European Parliament must have the ability to properly consider candidates because politicians also need to restore citizens' trust. As rapporteur for the opinion of the ENVI Committee on the procedure for the election of commissioners, I proposed similar measures.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 because of the recent serious conflicts of interest concerning them. So I voted in favour.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Rules of regulation of the European Parliament, in Annex XVI concerning the guidelines for the approval of the Commission, provides that “Parliament may request any relevant information for the adoption of a decision on the aptitudes of the appointed commissioners and exhaustive information is expected as regards their financial interests. The declarations of interest of the appointed commissioners shall be forwarded for consideration to the Committee responsible for Legal Affairs'. However, this annex does not express the exact scope of the examination by the Committee on Legal Affairs: it is unclear whether the examination should be limited to a formal analysis of the information provided or whether it should instead constitute a thorough analysis. This lack of clarity emerged great difficulties (also relevant in the appointment path of the current European Commission). Consequently, clarification is needed from the Committee on Constitutional Affairs of the European Parliament which is responsible, inter alia, for the interpretation of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The purpose of this work must be to ensure a transparent procedure and as much information as possible for citizens, who have the right to know and assess who is called to guide them.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — Taking into account Annex XVI to Parliament's Rules of Procedure on guidelines for the approval of the Commission, it is stipulated that Parliament's institution has the opportunity to request any information relevant to taking decisions on Commissioners-designate, in particular as regards the statement of interests to be sent to the committee responsible for legal matters for consideration. Unfortunately, in that annex, the exact extent of the examination by the Committee on Legal Affairs is not specified, namely whether it must be confined to a formal analysis of information or on the contrary, it must be an in-depth analysis. As a result of the difficulties involved in such a low-detailed provision, which has proven very important difficulties in the procedure for appointing the last European Commission, a classification by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, which has the necessary competence to interpretation of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. I voted in favour of the report on Commissioners' Declarations of Interest — Guidelines because I believe that there is a need for a clear specification of how to examine the Declarations of Interest of each European Commissioner.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: I welcome Jean-Claude Juncker's political will to strengthen the code of conduct for the President of the European Commission and the Commissioners. We must prove to the citizens of Europe that our institutions comply with clear ethical principles. It is important that our citizens trust the European institutions. This report recalls the importance of the declaration of financial interests of Commissioners, which aims to ensure the independence of Commissioners. The text highlights the need to improve the code of conduct to ensure the confidence of European citizens. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to amend the procedures on Commissioners’ declarations of interests which will necessitate a reform of the Commissioners’ Code of Conduct. Proposals include: an obligation to disclose all financial interests and not just those ‘likely to constitute a conflict of interest’; details of contractual relations, divestment requirements; disclosure of donations to any NGOs; regular reporting on the implementation of this code including any changes to declarations; rules in the case that Commissioners are ‘relocated’; and time frames for submission of declarations.  I also co-signed and voted in favour of the one amendment to this report, which called to extend Commissioners’ post-office employment restrictions to a period of at least three years without making any changes to the transitional rules. I am happy that this amendment was passed so that unethical appointments, such as that of Former President of the Commission José Manuel Barroso to Goldman Sachs, do not happen in the future without a proper cooling off period.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The Committee on Legal Affairs wanted to propose to Parliament the guidelines in question as a result of numerous problematic cases (most recently that of Commissioner Arias Cañete, recently examined) in which she found herself assessing the declaration of interests submitted by the Commissioners. In order to resolve this situation, two solutions are proposed: 1) an amendment to Annex XVI to RoP, including a precise reference to the fact that the JURI Committee's analysis must be made at the level substantive and of merit and 2) an amendment to the Commissioners' Code of Conduct of 2011, introducing a number of clarifications including the obligation to submit the declaration of interests also in relation to family members and the extension of 3 years for restrictions on post-term employment of commissioners. The approach of the relationship is definitely good.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this text is a thorough revision of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct to verify the total absence of a conflict of interest among Commissioners, not only when they take up their duties and throughout their tenure, but also after the latter, with a transition period for former Commissioners which has increased from 18 months to 3 years. It is essential for me that citizens be able to trust the institutions of the EU. It is simply unacceptable for commissioners to hide their personal interests or those of their family members. Recent scandals, such as the revelations in the Panama Papers case or the Barroso case, have once again demonstrated the need to react and regain the confidence of European citizens.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe there is a case for a more transparent, more efficient and better way to ensure independence of Commissioners and limit their potential conflicts of interests. As some recent cases show, there are occasions where former Commissioners can switch careers respecting fully the current code of conduct, raising at the same time some serious ethical concerns. That worries me, as it also undermines the EU’s credibility in the eyes of its citizens. We need to see this problem not only from a purely legal point of view, but to take into account a broader perspective, and that is why I think that the Code of Conduct as it stands now should be revised.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on Commissioners' declarations of financial interests represents an important step in tackling opacity and has the central idea that the scrutiny of the declarations of financial interests of Members of the European Commission should be made more thorough and rigorous. This is absolutely necessary in order to protect the credibility of the European Union itself, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Positive vote. I support any measures aimed at more detailed verification of the Commissioners' absence of conflicts of interest.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Events have led, by now too often, to the dawn of the chronicles cases of conflicts of interests within the institutions, certainly the most unbelievable ones belonged to the Commission and this urges me to vote favourably on the report. As a result, the full independence of the Commissioners' work will be ensured, as well as ensuring maximum transparency and accountability, in fact, the declarations of financial interest will be made evaluate potential conflicts based on determining, objective and relevant elements in relation to the Commissioner's portfolio. Later, it will be up to the Committee on Legal Affairs to carry out a substantial analysis of the declarations through an examination to ensure in full the authenticity and conformity of the content. If anomalies or conflicts are found, the Committee on Legal Affairs will make appropriate recommendations to resolve this situation. It is essential, within this process, that the Commissioner should inform of the updating of his financial interests of a wealth, professional, personal or family nature. I hope that a similar form of regulation will be adopted as soon as possible in Italy as regards, above all, the components of the CDM given the scandals, which have not been resolved, which have emerged recently.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on Commissioners’ declarations of interests – guidelines.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has a duty to assess the ability and suitability of European Commissioners at all times, but above all at the time of their nomination. I believe that this assessment is, above all, political and, to some extent technical, but it must also include a dimension of monitoring possible conflicts of interest. I therefore believe that the concept of conflict of interest should not be indeterminate and its verification must comply with objective and verifiable criteria. I broadly endorse the recommendations on the Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission, as they impress, once applied, greater transparency in declarations of financial interests. I would like to warn of the need to balance these transparency requirements with the privacy reserve, in particular of the families of Commissioners. I would remind you that Parliament should be given a structuring role in examining financial statements at the beginning of the Commissioners' term of office and whenever there is a substantial change in circumstances, whether it be a change of portfolio or changes in each individual's financial interests. However, this evaluation should be substantive and non-investigative, resulting in recommendations that promote and advocate transparency. I therefore support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure because important guidelines are proposed on the identification of conflicts of interest by the Committee on Legal Affairs, a reform of the Code of behaviour of the Commissioners. In general, it aims to involve the European Parliament and its powers with regard to the verification of financial statements, as well as further hearings of Commissioners in the event of portfolio change. The rapporteur also proposed that, in the event of a conflict of interest, the Committee on Legal Affairs may make a recommendation to ask the President of the Commission to withdraw confidence Commissioner in question.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Good governance entails the strengthening of ethics and transparency within the EU institutions in order to improve European citizens’ trust in our institutions, particularly in the light of the ampler political mandate entrusted to the Commission since the Lisbon Treaty. Unfortunately, the 2011 Code of Conduct failed to address all the recommendations that Commissioners should be required to declare all their financial interests or assets and not only those interests or assets ‘which might create a conflict of interest in the performance of their duties’.  As such there is no requirement to declare debts and liabilities, and dependent children are not required to produce the same information as spouses. This requires us to modify the Code of Conduct for Commissioners and look into other sensitive situations such as for example the post-office employment restriction and eligibility for a transitional allowance.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — In view of the need for transparency and clear procedures for the fulfilment of certain positions, I voted in favour of the report on the Commissioners' declaration of no conflict of interest. The introduction of clear verification criteria is a fundamental element to eliminate conflict of interest. This conflict arises as a result of obliterating the border between the public and private interest. This is due to the lack of professionalism of the clerical staff. The proposed guidelines define precisely the competence of the Commission in assessing the possible conflict of interest of the Commissioners. In addition, the resolution calls for the establishment of fair means of identifying family interests and relationships. Having postulated objective administration and transparency of decision-making processes, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interests in the European Commission.  This is why I am in favour of this report as various recent cases have shown that the current system does not suffice and that greater safeguards are required. The European Parliament needs the ability to scrutinise candidates properly and politicians need to regain the trust of citizens.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The principle of revolving doors also involves the European Commission, as demonstrated in the case of former President José Manuel Barroso, who passed to the giant Goldman Sachs a short distance from end of his term in the European institution. The conflict of interest problem is very vast. Without returning to the resignation as a bloc of the Santer Commission over the allegations of corruption involving some of its members, it is enough to remember Neelie Kroes, Vice-President of the Commission between 2004 and the 2010, who during her tenure was the administrator of an offshore company in the Bahamas. Juncker's refusal to publish at the Ombudsman's request decisions on the post-term activities of former commissioners is certainly no help. The European Parliament calls for Commissioners to declare existing or past financial interests affecting them or family members, their assets, liabilities and any affiliations to non-governmental organisations and secret societies, elements which may interfere with the exercise of their public functions. This request is made for the strengthening of the ethics and transparency of institutions, and is aimed at ensuring impartiality, integrity, diligence, honesty, accountability and discretion of the governing body of the European Union. For these reasons my vote is positive.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: The purpose of this own-initiative report is to provide guidelines for identifying potential conflicts of interest and a reform of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct. The report also proposes greater participation by the European Parliament, giving it real competence in the control of financial declarations, and proposes that the JURI committee be able to ask the President of the European Commission to withdraw his confidence in the Commissioner concerned if it considers that there is a conflict of interest. Considering that it is essential to ensure the exemplarity of European Commissioners in conflict of interest during their tenure, and to strengthen controls and the transition period following the end of their term of office, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted for this non-legislative report on Commissioners’ Declarations of Interest. We in UKIP believe that every Commissioner must face scrutiny when they are appointed to their post, whether this be at the beginning of their term or should they be replacing a Commissioner.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report on the declarations of interests of the members of the Commission establishes guidelines to facilitate the procedures for verifying such statements made by the Commissioners. In order to identify potential conflicts of interest, the report states, among other things, that the analysis of returns must be substantial and in relation to the Commissioner designate's portfolio. The European Parliament will be more involved in the process, particularly in the event of a change in the portfolio of a Commissioner. In view of recent cases involving certain Commissioners, notably Mr Barroso, and in order to raise the level of ethics and transparency, I voted in favour of this report, although some proposals are somewhat excessive.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Having been deeply shocked by the “reclassification” of Barroso to banker Goldman Sachs, it was with conviction that I voted in favour of a non-legislative resolution calling for an extension from 18 to 36 months at least the transition period before which former commissioners cannot hold positions in the private sector in their area of expertise. I also consider it appropriate to strengthen the conditions governing the Commissioners' declaration of financial interests so that it includes all interests or activities of the last two years that may lead to conflicts of interest or impartial interest.Mr. Finally, I believe that the Committee on Legal Affairs should play an increased role and have sufficient time to analyse statements of financial interest, verify that they have been properly supplemented with the right content and assess whether a conflict of interest results. It should also publish its final findings and make recommendations as appropriate.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on earthquakes in Italy. The motion stresses that the recent Italian earthquakes have removed entire villages from the face of the Earth, severely damaged local and regional infrastructure, economic activity and, in many cases, the historical and cultural heritage and, consequently, significant reconstruction efforts are needed to repair the damage suffered. The motion for a resolution draws attention to important issues, such as the fact that it is increasingly important for people who have become homeless to ensure adequate accommodation as winter approaches, to speed up related research and advance payment as possible ensure the number of areas concerned as soon as possible and make full use of synergies between existing instruments in order to ensure an effective response.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of these texts. This is a tightening of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct adopted in 2001. Commissioners should, in particular, declare all their interests in companies, including their family interests, as well as their membership in NGOs or associations playing a role as lobbies.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Recently, the European Parliament's legal committee had to analyse the alleged conflict of interest of European Commissioner for Climate and Energy Miguel Arias Cañete. The powers of our committee were not very clear and a conclusion on the subject was almost impossible to draw. Many MPs, among them myself, felt that we were not a court and we could not determine whether the commissioner was guilty or not. These guidelines, which I supported in this report, aim to clarify the competences and powers of the Law Commission in assessing the possible conflicts of interest of Commissioners. I still think that we have not reached a final text that clarifies everything, but I supported the report because I think it is a good step and gives a little more clarity and leads to a more transparent procedure.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The definition of the scope of the audit of Commissioners' declarations of financial interest, as proposed herein, presents serious legislative gaps in ensuring transparency as well as in the number of (to be declared) financial information.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The adoption of this report is intended to help clarify the role of the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) in examining declarations of interest. In addition, this report proposes to the Commission a series of amendments to its Code of Conduct and declarations of interest to ensure that the latter include sufficient information to assess the financial interests of Commissioners. The rapporteur also proposes that, in the event of a conflict of interest identified on the basis of the statement or additional information provided by the Commissioner during his term of office, the Committee on Legal Affairs may make a recommendation to request the President of the Commission to withdraw confidence in the Commissioner interested. In general, it proposes greater participation and powers of the European Parliament in relation to the control of financial declarations, in addition to additional hearings by Commissioners in the event of portfolio changes.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these guidelines which set out clear protocols for avoiding conflicts of interests of Commissioners, not only before they take office, but also during their term of office. These proposals would strengthen the power of Parliament to prevent scandals such as those we have seen recently. Parliament also wanted the cooling-off period for all former Commissioners to be at least three years. I have always promised my constituents in Wales that I would work for greater transparency and accountability.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report on the Commissioners' Statements of Interests — Guidelines has, in my view, a good approach and makes shareable recommendations, especially where it highlights the opportunity that the examination carried out by the JURI Committee is not merely formal. The proposals to prevent any conflicts of interests of the commissioners both in terms of office and at the end of the same are equally shared. For these reasons my vote was positive.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it defines more clearly the concept of conflict of interest and the procedure for controlling statements of financial interests, both before the hearings of the Commissioners, both during their term. In particular, I think it is appropriate for the reports to call on the Commission to review the Commissioners' Code of Conduct in order to expand the scope of declarations of interests and to identify a more way fair to define family interests.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The readiness and the very ability to manage an assigned resort within the European Commission must be crucial. In particular, public hearings of the candidates for the European Commissioners have also been focused on their assessment so far. However, the ability to effectively eliminate the potential conflict of interest of applicants for executive functions within the next European Commission should also become equally important. This must be a control role for the European Parliament and its committees. It is a contribution to transparency that can help increase people's confidence in the work of the European Commission. This should in particular concern the competences within the specific entrusted portfolio of the future Commissioner. Thanks to a thorough analysis of the previous actions of individual candidates, we can avoid unpleasant scandals. This, for example, is also the case of European Commission President Juncker, known as Lux Leaks, concerning tax evasion in Luxembourg.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report for a more timely verification of the absence of conflicts of interest of the Commissioners.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - The definition of the scope of the audit of Commissioners' declarations of financial interest, as proposed herein, presents serious legislative gaps in ensuring transparency as well as in the number of (to be declared) financial information and for this reason I am voting against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report underlines the need for transparency and accountability. In the absence of confirmation of the absence of a conflict of interest the procedure for appointing the Commissioner-designate shall be suspended. If the Committee on Legal Affairs identifies a conflict of interests it shall draw up recommendations aimed at resolving the conflict, including renouncing the financial interests in question, changes being made to the portfolio of the Commissioner-designate by the President of the Commission; in more serious cases and as the last resort the Committee on Legal Affairs can conclude on the inability of the Commissioner-designate to exercise his/her function according to the Treaty and to the Code of Conduct. We pushed to extend the obligation to declare financial interests of family members and any contractual relation of the Commissioners-designate, which might create a conflict of interests in the performance of their duties as much as possible in order not to leave any legal loopholes. We need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interests in the European Commission. The case of Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete shows that the current system does not suffice. The European Parliament needs the ability to scrutinise candidates properly and politicians need to regain the trust of citizens.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report, bearing in mind that it is important to have maximum transparency with regard to possible conflicts of interest among the members of the European Commission. We cannot allow the highest representatives of the European Commission to be influenced by private interests, which may go against the general interest of the citizens of the Union, so the institutions must always be vigilant, as well as to establish the maximum possible controls and transparency in order to avoid possible conflicts of interest.

text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because, following the process of appointing the Commissionarial College in 2014 and the news that subsequently appeared in relation to several Commissioners, the need for the European Commission to review its Code of Conduct is evident, to ensure that the declarations of interests of Commissioners accurately reflect their financial situation and that of their families. name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: In writing. — The reconstruction of a relationship of trust in Europe comes primarily from improving the efficiency and transparency of the Community institutions. I therefore welcome the approval of this text, which I have long followed in the Committee on Legal Affairs, and which reaffirms Parliament's strong position in favour of more impactful measures for ensure the political responsibility of the European Commissioners, in particular with regard to any conflicts of interest.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The guidelines for the declaration of interests of the members of the Commission should be improved. To this end, Parliament's internal procedures should also be reviewed when appointing the new Commission. It is also necessary to ensure transparency obligations for Commissioners during their term of office.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the process on the Commissioners’ declarations of interest in order to fulfil their mandates independently and to ensure full transparency and accountability on the part of the Commission with the Code of Conduct.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Just a few days ago in the Plenary, we found ourselves discussing the European Ombudsman's report on its fundamental activities for the benefit of the transparency of European procedures and the accessibility of citizens to the European institutions. Not least, in that case citizens can ask for explanations, as in the case of conflict of interest for former European Commissioners (and officials) who take up posts in the private sector. With the same purpose, I voted today in favour of this report because I believe, as the rapporteur has also correctly stated, that the verification of the absence of conflicts of interest cannot be placed on same plan as assessing the competences of the candidate, but rather constitutes an indispensable prerequisite for the hearing. The introduction of these guidelines can be a further step in restoring public confidence in the European institutions.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: I voted in favour of Pascal Durand's report, which aims to reinforce the constraints of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct, despite its shortcomings. For example, the non-conflict analysis is based on a statement of financial interest by the Commissioner. It therefore depends on the good faith and sincerity of the declarant. However, it was possible to measure the importance of selective amnesia that some candidates could be struck during this exercise. And Parliament has no means of investigation. The little secrets of Mrs. Neelie Kroes were thus revealed only incidentally on the occasion of the Bahamas Leaks. The extension of the reporting obligation to spouses and dependent children, as well as to non-financial interests — for example belonging to a secret organization that “profession” interfere in the performance of the functions of public bodies — will not change this construction defect. Then there is no actual sanction planned or requested in the event of a lie, not even an “ethical” requirement of resignation, and the only consequence of a conflict of interest is a change of portfolio. Finally, the Code of Conduct for Commissioners remains defined and adopted by the Commissioners themselves. Slightly like criminals were in the process of the penal code.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, as its objective is to monitor Commissioners' statements of financial interests, in order to ensure that they can fulfil their mandates completely independently and to ensure maximum transparency for the Commission. Any change in the financial interests of a Commissioner during his term of office, or any reorganization of the distribution of responsibilities between the members of the Commission, constitutes a new situation as to the possible existence of a conflict of interest. The Commission is also asked to urgently review the 2011 Commissioners' Code of Conduct to take into account the recommendations made by Parliament in its recent resolutions. We believe that an institution such as the Commission should increase transparency and ensure the independence of Commissioners. That is why our vote was favourable.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the need for transparency and accountability. We need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interests in the European Commission. The case of Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete shows that the current system does not suffice. The European Parliament needs the ability to scrutinise candidates properly and politicians need to regain the trust of citizens.

The resolution also provides for an extension from 18 to 36 months of the period within which Commissioners, once out of their office, should refrain from working for the private sector in the field for which they were responsible.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the rapporteur in his endeavour to raise accountability and transparency as regards Commissioners’ activities and potential conflicts of interests. To regain the trust of European citizens, notably in the EU institutions, it is essential to increase transparency and accountability in particular of public figures such as Commissioners. It is not acceptable if Commissioners are hiding personal or family members’ interests in taking specific decisions at EU executive level. Therefore, a thorough analysis on the basis of sufficient data to be requested from the Commissioner in question need to be undertaken on a case-by-case basis, not only before a Commissioner takes up his duties but also during and to a certain extent also after his mandate.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for a report on the Commissioners' Financial Interests Statement — Guidelines (2016/2080 (INI)), given that practice has shown that the issue should be better regulated. This defines a conflict of interest as any situation where private interests are contrary to the public interest and public interests that affect or might affect independence, impartiality and objectivity of the exercise of duty. The absence of any conflict of interest is a necessary prerequisite that must be met before a trustee's hearing. It proposes a procedure for reviewing statements of financial interests before the hearing of the nominee for the Commissioner, then the procedure for reviewing declarations of financial interests during the Commissioner's mandate, and proposes to the Commission revise and how to revise the commissioner's 2011 code of conduct. Furthermore, it is necessary to clearly and unambiguously determine the competences, the manner of operation, the necessary documentation and the manner in which the competent Committee on Legal Issues is collected in order to achieve the necessary transparency and efficiency in this matter.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — After the discovery of conflicts of interest involving Commissioners, I welcome this initiative to tighten their code of conduct by requiring them to declare all interests affecting them. I voted in favour.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I strongly support transparency in the European Union institutions and I believe that the European Commission and its Commissioners should lead by example. The report aims to facilitate a reform of the procedures relating to Commissioners’ declaration of interest to assure the maximum accountability and transparency of a Commissioner’s fully independent performance of his/her mandate. It defines conflict of interest and promotes reform of the Code of Conduct for Commissioners from 2011 to extend the post-office employment restriction to two years.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes guidelines for the determination of conflicts of interest and a reform of the code of conduct for members of the Commission. In the current context of distrust, it is important to modify certain practices in order to prevent potential conflicts of interest.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The rapporteur calls on the Commission to amend its Code of Conduct and to extend the content of its members' declarations of interests so that they contain sufficient information for the assessment of financial interests.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is more than clear that the European Commission should revise its code of conduct for Commissioners, to ensure that their declarations of interests give a complete picture of the financial situation and activities of a Commissioner and his or her family. In fact, I fully support the proposition that the absence of any conflict of interest must be an essential precondition to be met before the Commissioner’s hearings, and that the financial interest declaration forms must therefore be completed and made available before a Commissioner is heard by the relevant European Parliament committee, and that they should be reviewed at least once a year and each time there is a change to the information concerned. Thus, in this manner, we will ensure the degree of transparency which is needed for the proper functioning of the Commissioner’s appointment procedure and Parliament’s accurate assessment on it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2011. However, it is very necessary, given the many financial scandals in which commissioners or former commissioners are involved.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. — Citizens legitimately aspire to greater transparency within the institutions. While recent cases have revealed the activities of some Commissioners, sometimes inconsistent with their duties, we have dealt with this issue, with the aim of facilitating procedures for verifying their declarations of interest. This own-initiative report recalls that the analysis of statements must be substantial and related to the commissioner-designate portfolio in order to identify potential conflicts of interest. This means more involvement of Parliament in the process, particularly in the event of a change of portfolio. It is also suggested that the President of Parliament refer to the European Commission the case of a Commissioner for whom a potential conflict of interest has been identified. Finally, the report calls on the Commission to reform the Commissioners' Code of Conduct with a view to raising the level of ethics and transparency, as called for by Parliament in various resolutions. I voted in favour of this report, noting nevertheless that we must not fall into the opposite excess either, the permanent suspicion, often created by an overly aggressive policy of transparency.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: ‒ This proposal contains a number of guidelines for the review of the declarations of interests of Commissioners when they are proposed and when they are in office. In addition, the proposal also calls for a revision of the Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission. The N-VA MEPs therefore welcome this proposal. In the light of the revelations about the conduct of former Commissioners both in the course of their duties and afterwards, it is clear that there is only one way: that of clearly defined requirements and substantial consequences. For example, it is incomprehensible that there is still no clear definition of what constitutes a conflict of interest and there are no criteria attached to the solemn promise of every Commissioner to “behave honesty and discretion in accepting certain positions or benefits after the end of that term of office'. Not to mention the composition and lack of transparency of the ad hoc ethical committee responsible for monitoring the agreements reached. N-VA MEPs are calling for a swift review of the Code of Conduct and emphasise that adapting a single rule is not a solution here or there. A comprehensive policy of integrity must be pursued.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because, following the process of appointing the Commissionarial College in 2014 and the news that subsequently appeared in relation to several Commissioners, the need for the European Commission to review its Code of Conduct is evident to ensure that statements of interest by Commissioners accurately reflect their financial situation and that of their families. The financial interest statement shall include the current activities and interests of the preceding two years, Commissioners will have to declare all their interests as 'shareholders, members of boards of directors, advisors and consultants, members of foundations', as well as the interests of close relatives. In the event of a conflict of interest identified during the term of office, the President of the Commission shall follow Parliament's recommendations to resolve it, or the House may withdraw confidence in that Commissioner and, if appropriate, deprive him of his pension rights and other benefits. The resolution also provides for an extension from 18 to 36 months of the period within which Commissioners, once out of their office, should refrain from working for the private sector in the field for which they were responsible.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The purpose of the review of the statements on the financial interests of the trustees is to examine whether applicants for commissioners are capable of fulfilling their duties completely independently and to ensure maximum transparency and accountability of the Commission, in accordance with Article 17 (3). of the Treaty on European Union, Article 245. TFEU and the Code of Conduct of the Commissioners. The Committee on Legal Affairs is responsible for carrying out an extensive analysis of statements of financial interests, through a thorough review whose purpose is to establish the credibility and accuracy of the content of declarations of financial interests of applicants for trustees. The problem lies in a poorly defined provision which does not cover the exact scope of the review carried out by this Committee. Parliament insisted that the Committee issue guidelines in the form of recommendations or reports on the initiative aimed at helping reform proceedings regarding the commissioner's statements. The Rapporteur proposes that the Committee define a framework for reviewing declarations of financial interests, which would include the appointment of a new Commission and the course of its mandate and the transparency obligations to which its members are subject to. Any major change in the financial interests of the Commissioner during his term of office and any redistribution in relation to the division of responsibilities among the members of the Commission presents a new situation in relation to the possible existence of conflicts of interest and should be considered by Parliament in the context of the examination procedure. I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EP calls on the Committee on Legal Affairs to review and propose adjustments to the internal procedures for the appointment of the new Commission and for the duration of its term of office, including transparency requirements for members of the Commission. To that end, the Commission will revise the 2011 Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission and prepare amendments to the Code of Conduct and Declarations of Interest in order to ensure that they contain sufficient information to assess the financial interests of Members. Increasing transparency will prevent a possible conflict of interest from the members of the Commission. The EP shall be informed of any change.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on Commissioners' declarations of financial interests — guidelines, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. The purpose of this text is to amend the Commissioners' Code of Conduct in order to prevent them from being in a conflict of interest situation, as is the case today. In particular, this text calls for a new measure requiring Commissioners to declare all the interests they possess (business, family interests, membership of NGOs or lobby), which we approve.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The European Parliament's recommendation on guidelines for declarations of interests of Commissioners aims to ensure an open, fair and consistent assessment of all Commissioners appointed and to prevent potential conflicts of interest.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 because of the recent serious conflicts of interest concerning them. In particular, the proposal requires Commissioners to declare all their interests in companies, including their family interests, as well as their membership in NGOs or associations playing a lobby role. So, I voted for this file.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it clarifies the scope of the Parliament’s scrutiny over European Commissioners’ interests and helps avoid conflicts of interest by rendering the process more transparent.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for statements of financial interests of the Members of the Commission. By making improvements to the Commissioners' Code of Conduct adopted in 2011 (C (2011) 2904) on disinterest, integrity, transparency, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect, it is intended to send a strong political message. In an ongoing effort to strengthen the level of transparency and ethics within the Union, which is necessary to strengthen the confidence of European citizens, it is important that the Commission, as the guarantor of this value, be able to consistently improve the forms of declarations of financial interests of Commissioners. I am, moreover, fully in favour of the Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee being able to draw up recommendations to end a conflict of interest or to conclude that a commissioner appointed is unable to carry out his duties. It is important that the European Parliament be able to properly assess the existence or absence of conflicts of interest concerning Commissioners, as well as their ability to carry out their mandate.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I agree that we need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interests in the European Commission. The case of Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete shows that the current system does not suffice. The European Parliament needs the ability to scrutinise candidates properly and politicians need to regain the trust of citizens.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament's Rules of Procedure on the Commission's approval states that Parliament expects full disclosure of information on the Commissioners-designate financial interests, and their declarations should be sent for review for legal matters committee responsible. The Committee on Legal Affairs sets out the scope of this investigation in its report. It states that the verification of the absence of conflicts of interest cannot be brought to the same level as the assessment of the candidate's suitability, which should be a prerequisite for a hearing. It notes that the role of the Committee on Legal Affairs is, on the one hand, to assess possible conflicts of interest and, where appropriate, to formulate recommendations for its elimination. These may include waiving certain financial interests or changing the portfolio. Lastly, it states that the verification of possible conflicts of interest of Commissioners should not be limited to the procedure for appointing the Commission; during the term of office any substantive modification of the financial interests of a Commissioner or a new redistribution of tasks among the members of the Commission creates a situation with regard to the possible existence of conflicts of interest and should therefore be subject to a new parliamentary investigation procedure. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 because of the recent serious conflicts of interest concerning them. In particular, the proposal requires Commissioners to declare all their interests in companies, including their family interests, as well as their membership in NGOs or associations playing a lobby role. I'm in favour of it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which reminds us that the analysis of the statements of interest of the members of the Commission must be put in perspective with the Commissioner's portfolio. This will help to avoid conflicts of interest and prevent suspicions that might affect a member of the European Commission. The report also calls for Parliament's role to be strengthened in this process of transparency.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report regarding the initiative to change the legal framework for the Commissioners’ declarations of interests, representing a step forwards in fighting abuse, upholding transparency and increasing trust in the European institutions.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the report, which, inter alia, responds to the finding that the existing Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission does not adequately codify the requirement under Article 245 TFEU, which stipulates that the members of the Commission observe “during the exercise of their office and after the termination of their duty, in particular the duty of honorable and restrained conduct in the acceptance of certain functions or certain benefits after the expiry of the term. “It is unacceptable that the Commission does not report regularly on the implementation of the Code of Conduct for Commission members, in particular as regards their declarations of interest. It is necessary to consider redesigning the Code of Conduct so that it provides for the possibility of complaints or sanctions in case of serious misconduct within the meaning of Articles 245 and 247 TFEU.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the one amendment to this report, which called to extend Commissioners’ post-office employment restrictions to a period of at least three years without making any changes to the transitional rules. I am happy that this amendment was passed so that unethical appointments, such as that of Former President of the Commission José Manuel Barroso to Goldman Sachs, do not happen in the future without a proper cooling-off period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because the restriction of employment for former COM members will be extended from 2 to 3 years.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Parliament can ask the appointed Commissioners for relevant information on their economic and other activities so that Commissioners can carry out their duties entirely independently. However, the Declaration of Interest requires clarification and better rules on what and to what extent the candidates for commissioners may intervene.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. In order to ensure the independence and integrity of Commissioners, it is necessary to increase the effectiveness of the application of declarations of interest.
