The Commission should amend the code of conduct and declarations of interests of its members and ensure that they contain sufficient information. In order to increase public confidence in the EU institutions, verification of declarations of interest must be a prerequisite for hearing. It is necessary to strengthen the role of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament and to define the scope of the examination of declarations of interest. Furthermore, the concept of conflict of interest should include only objective and verifiable factors that can be assessed in the light of a specific area of responsibility. It should be noted that it is essential to extend the restrictions on post-term employment of Commissioners to a period of at least three years, which is not less than the period during which former Commissioners are entitled to the transitional allowance.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. The report underlines the need for transparency and accountability. The guidelines are a measure in the right direction since there is now a procedure for checking declarations of financial interests before the Commissioners-designate is heard, a procedure for checking declarations of financial interests during the Commissioners' term of office and, finally, a code of conduct for the Commissioners is established.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of enhanced measures to monitor the declarations of interests of European Commissioners. These measures should help to strengthen the transparency of the European institutions. Thanks to the action of the Socialist Group, we have ensured that the European Commissioners were obliged, in particular, to declare the financial interests of their family members.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I fully accept the principle of integrity and the principle of independence imposed on the members of the Commission as laid down in the Treaties, within which the two principles mentioned play a central role. It is necessary that the endowment in EU institutional roles is always consistent with the public interest, marginalising, until definitively eliminating the existence of interests that might be incompatible with the office held. Undoubting a conflict of interest only reaffirm the independence of the Commission itself and give it new strength and credibility in the face of European citizens as well as in the face of others Union institutions. It is therefore important that the verification of the absence of conflicts of interest in the Commission should be placed on a different level from the assessment of the Commissioners' powers and that this assessment does not come carried out only during appointment but also invests those cases where the substantial change in the financial interests of the Commissioner occurs in the course of office. Therefore, I voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on declarations of financial interests of the Commissioners. I recall that the purpose of the review of the Commissioners' Financial Interest Statement is to examine whether applicants for trustees are capable of fully independent exercise of their duties and to guarantee the greatest transparency and accountability of the Commission, in accordance with Article 17 (3). of the Treaty on European Union, Article 245. TFEU and the Code of Conduct of the Commissioners. Accordingly, I note that this should not be limited to the appointment of a new Commission but should also apply when filling a vacancy due to the resignation of the trustee, the compulsory retirement or death of the Commissioner, the accession of a new Member State or a substantial change of the Commissioners portfolio or its financial interests. I believe that this would give a more complete insight into the financial situation of the Commissioner, as well as a sufficient belief that the person in question will perform that responsible duty as honourable as possible. The Commissioner's Code of Conduct should include all the financial interests and activities of a candidate for a trustee and his/her spouses, and should by no means be limited to those which may cause conflicts of interest.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 because of the recent serious conflicts of interest concerning them. In particular, the proposal requires Commissioners to declare all their interests in companies, including their family interests, as well as their membership in NGOs or associations playing a lobby role. Of course, I am voting in favour of this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — With this resolution, the European Parliament strongly calls for stricter control rules on Commissioners' declarations of interests. The proposed measures are intended to increase the level of transparency and accountability of the European institutions, which are essential to maintain and strengthen the bond of trust with citizens. Designated Commissioners should also be obliged to declare each contractual relationship and the financial interests of family members. In the event that there is no certainty that there is no conflict of interest, the appointment of the Commissioner in question should be suspended. In the event that a conflict of interest occurs, the JURI Commission may indicate the measures necessary to resolve it, such as the waiver of the financial interests concerned and, in more serious cases, he may decide on the inability of the Commissioner appointed to perform his function. From Commissioner Cañete's appearance in Panama papers to the discovery that former Commissioner Kroes headed an offshore company in the Bahamas, there are too many scandals involving senior figures of the European Commission. When we talk about fighting corruption and tax evasion, we must be sure that cases like this cannot happen again and with these new rules it would be possible to prevent them.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Strengthening ethics in the EU institutions is one of the pillars of European governance to enjoy the trust of our citizens. By extending the Commission's political mandate by the Treaty of Lisbon, it became even more important to have clear criteria and respect the principle of transparency when choosing a trustee. Confirmation of the Legal Affairs Committee on the absence of conflicts of interest has become an indispensable prerequisite when hearing candidates. Commissioners must declare any financial interest and assets that could lead to conflicts of interest during the performance of their duties, including all shares held by the spouse/partner of a member of the Commission and professional activities thereof. It is necessary to provide Parliament with all requested information when deciding on candidate capacity and thus guarantee open and consistent assessments of the entire nominated Commission. I regret that the information of the present forms is limited and inadequate, without a detailed definition of conflicts of interest and does not allow Parliament to fairly and consistently assess the ability of candidates to fully independently carry out their duties and guarantee the responsibility of the Commission. The Committee should therefore be given sufficient time for an exhaustive and thus effective analysis, with the right to additional hearings and necessary clarifications where necessary. In doing so, the term “conflict of interest” must refer to objective and verifiable factors. I call for controls to be carried out as part of other procedures, not just the Commission appointment procedure.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We follow many of the considerations and proposals that the report makes, on the promiscuity between Commissioners and the economic power and their representatives, on the shortcomings of the Code of Conduct and the need for greater transparency in relations between the parties involved. We note that this initiative is a reaction to the 'scandals' of so-called 'revolving doors', in which many former members of the Commission are involved. But we also recognise the limitations of this report because much more comprehensive and incisive should be the necessary response to the problems that the report itself points out. It is pernicious that the body itself, the Commission, an unelected political appointing body, should be left to revise its own code of conduct. On the other hand, the Treaties themselves are a corset that imposes, defines and creates conditions of promiscuity with political power, by the intermediaries of lobbies and representatives of monopoly capital, who condition and dictate the legislative meanings of the EU. In other words, it is the EU's own matrix and the integration process it represents that determines this reality, which will not be changed by any Code of Conduct.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — Several current cases, such as the caucuses of former President of the European Commission Barroso, have shown us the importance that major European functionaries do not get into a clash interests. Therefore, I am pleased that the Committee on Legal Affairs is now tasked with thoroughly scrutinising the property relations of European Commissioners candidates and recommending that commissioners arrange redress by saying that propose an end to problematic property relations. Also, it is a good thing that property relations will also be controlled during the execution of the mandate, thus avoiding further potential conflicts of interest. Responsible committees should also discuss property issues far more rigorously as part of the commissioner-nominee hearings. At the same time, I am pleased that the JURI parliamentary committee will have the power to decide, in serious cases, on the impossibility of a candidate serving as European Commissioner, unless such a candidate is the power to live up to the requirements of the code of conduct.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The report defines the concept of conflict of interest and clarifies the procedure for auditing statements of property before the hearings of candidates for commissioners as well as during the office of commissioner. The Commission is invited to review the Commissioners' Code of Conduct as soon as possible in order to broaden the scope of declarations of non-conflict of interest, which could result in a more unequivocal content and facilitating the task of the EP. In addition, it calls for fair methods to determine family interests to be established. According to the conclusions of the final report, confirmation of the absence of conflict of interest cannot be equated to the assessment of the candidate's abilities and therefore must provide a necessary precondition for the hearing. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Following the particularly important practical difficulties in the appointment procedure of the last European Commission, I voted in favour of this report, which aims to facilitate procedures for verifying statements of interest by Commissioners. The Committee recalls that the analysis of statements by the competent parliamentary committee must be substantial and in relation to the portfolio of the commissioner-designate in order to identify potential conflicts of interest. We also call for a reform of the Commissioners' Code of Conduct with a view to raising the level of ethics and transparency. Finally, we supported an extension of the “transition” period from 18 to 36 months during which former Commissioners cannot hold positions in the private sector in their area of expertise.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted for this non-legislative report on Commissioners’ Declarations of Interest. We in UKIP believe that every Commissioner must face scrutiny when they are appointed to their post, whether this be at the beginning of their term or should they be replacing a Commissioner.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. — Following the affairs of Barroso, former President of the Commission who joined the Goldman Sachs business bank, and Neelie Kroes, director of an offshore company in the Bahamas when she was European Commissioner, the European Parliament sends a strong message to reform the Commissioners' code of conduct in order to prevent conflicts interests, prevent indecent behaviour and strengthen the transparency, ethics and integrity of Commissioners. Through this report, MEPs call for greater control of Commissioners' statements of financial interest through a thorough examination. MEPs wish to strengthen the role of the Committee on Legal Affairs in oversight of these statements, in particular by giving it the opportunity to develop recommendations to end a conflict of interest or to conclude that the Commissioner-designate is unable to perform his duties. Finally, to prevent indecent behaviour, MEPs call for an extension of the so-called “waiting” period to 3 years before which former commissioners who have left their office cannot join the private sector. That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's own-initiative report on the declarations of interests of Members of the Commission.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because, following the process of appointing the Commissionarial College in 2014 and the news that subsequently appeared in relation to several Commissioners, the need for the European Commission to review its Code of Conduct is evident to ensure that statements of interest by Commissioners accurately reflect their financial situation and that of their families. The financial interest statement shall include the current activities and interests of the preceding two years, Commissioners will have to declare all their interests as 'shareholders, members of boards of directors, advisors and consultants, members of foundations', as well as the interests of close relatives. In the event of a conflict of interest identified during the term of office, the President of the Commission shall follow Parliament's recommendations to resolve it, or the House may withdraw confidence in that Commissioner and, if appropriate, deprive him of his pension rights and other benefits. The resolution also provides for an extension from 18 to 36 months of the period within which Commissioners, once out of their office, should refrain from working for the private sector in the field for which they were responsible.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the declarations of interests of members of the European Commission. Faced with the recent controversy arising from the decision of former President of the European Commission, José Manuel Barroso, to join the highly contested American business bank Goldman Sachs, we cannot remain inactive. I therefore welcome the broad support given by the European Parliament for the amendment calling for the amendment to the Code of Conduct in order to extend the duration of limitations on Commissioners' post-employment activities to a period of at least three years. This is a step in the right direction but must be accompanied by other commitments in this area.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - As the example of the former President of the Commission shows, not all Commissioners tend to declare their interests in good faith or respect the requirements of fair conduct. Sadly, it seems that this club of dubious reputation has recently been supplemented by another former Commissioner who has moved to the World Bank, an institution for which, according to the media, it has recently provided significantly higher flows of EU funds. Therefore, we need to strive for more effective regulation of the activities of the most expensive paid EU officials, Commissioners. And, of course, the application of higher moral standards would also be a welcome recommendation to the Member States who put forward Commissioners.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament (EP), in particular Annex 16 thereto, provide for the request for information on Commissioners-designate, in particular their declaration of financial interests, which should be part of the assessment made by the Committee on Legal Affairs. However, the interpretation of these statements caused some doubts, and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (CCC) was requested to give an opinion on whether this examination should be limited to a formal or substantial analysis of the information contained therein. The CAC considered that the analysis should be substantive and the EP considered it important to revise these verification rules, suggesting that confirmation of no financial conflict is a prerequisite for the hearing of the Commissioner-designate. This report seeks to clarify in the Regulation the scope of the examination of declarations of interests, the verification of the absence of a conflict of interest as a prerequisite for hearing the applicant and, in the event of a finding of incompatibility, the formulation of recommendations aimed at making the applicant term. As I agree with the rapporteur's proposals and the need for the Commission to amend its code of conduct on declarations of interests for greater transparency, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European Commission to review its code of conduct for Commissioners in order to ensure that statements of interest provide a comprehensive overview of the financial situation and activities of the Commissioner and his entourage. The text also calls for an extension from one and a half years to a minimum of 3 years the “transition” period before which former Commissioners cannot hold positions in the private sector in an area related to their former portfolio. It is important that the Commissioners' statements of financial interest include all the interests of the Commissioners, over the past two years, as shareholders, board members, advisors, consultants or members of associated foundations. Finally, the text provides for an increased role for the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, in particular in analysing statements of financial interest and potential conflicts of interest cases.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it requires further clarification in the family relations of Commissioners and Commissioners, their properties and their contracts, and that the European Ombudsman's and the Ad Hoc Committee on Ethics on employment authorisations for ex-Commissioners be respected. Unfortunately, conflicts of interest are a constant in the professional career of European Commissioners, a clear example of the personal collusion between their politicians and the interests of large transnational capital. Kroes and Uber, Cañete and the properties of their family, Barroso and Goldman Sachs etc. demonstrate the structural links between high European bureaucracy and corporate power.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the need for transparency and accountability. We need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interests in the European Commission. The case of Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete shows that the current system does not suffice. The European Parliament needs the ability to scrutinise candidates properly and politicians need to regain the trust of citizens.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Conflict of interest is one of the most essential limitations for civil servants, who should focus on the public interest. Despite the existence of the Code of Conduct for Commissioners, there is still space to avoid some of its provisions. I supported this report because it contains and points out lots of recommendations and calls on the Commission to adopt them into its Code of Conduct for Commissioners.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the Declarations of Interest of Members of the Commission, because the Members of the Commission have a Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission, under which they must declare, in addition to their work activities, the work activities of their spouse or partner/partner in order to prevent any risk of conflict of interest. The Member of the Commission shall make his declaration by means of a form which must be completed before the hearing in the relevant EP Committee. The Committee on Legal Affairs shall have the authority and responsibility for carrying out a documentated analysis of declarations of financial interests through an in-depth examination to assess whether its content is true and that it complies with the criteria and principles set out in the Treaties and Code of Conduct, or whether could provoke a conflict of interest. The Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission is from 2011 and practice has shown that it needs to be revised. That is why, in the motion for a resolution, we called on the Commission to revise the Code and to take into account Parliament's recommendations on the development of general ethics and transparency standards applicable to all EU institutions.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - The objective of the Commission's declarations of financial interests under review is to ensure that the Commissioners are able to carry out their duties independently, transparently and responsibly. The assessment of a potential conflict of interest must be based on compelling, objective and relevant factors and must take into account the area of competence of the Commissioner. A detailed assessment of such a matter deserves a reasonable sufficient amount of time. The Code of Conduct for Members of the Commission must constitute a guarantee of impartiality, integrity, transparency, conscientiousness, integrity, accountability and restraint, as well as truthfulness as regards the declaration of financial interests.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The European Parliament expects all information on the financial interests of candidates for commissioners to be provided and that their declarations of interest be forwarded to the competent Legal Affairs Committee for review. In addition, the European Parliament argues that the committee of the same name should issue guidelines in the form of a recommendation or an independent report. The Commissioners' Code of Conduct dictates that they must declare any financial interest and assets that might lead to conflicts of interest during the performance of their duties and that this declaration also covers shares held by a partner of a member of the Commission that may lead to conflicts of interest. I support the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the declarations of financial interests of the Commissioners, since confirmation from the committee responsible is necessary for legal questions about the absence of conflicts of interest as a precondition for the hearing of the nominees for commissioners. I also consider that a number of recommendations from Parliament for improvement have not been taken into account, in particular with regard to the declarations of the financial interests of the members of the Commission, restrictions on employment after the expiry of the mandate of the Commission and the strengthening of the ad hoc ethics committee responsible for determining conflicts of interest, and in this context, Parliament's views on changes and improvements to the hearing process of candidates for commissioners should also be taken into account.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on the Commissioners' Declarations of Interest — Guidelines. I support the report which reminds, inter alia, that the purpose of the review of declarations of financial interests of commissioners is to ensure the ability of candidates for commissioners to perform their functions completely independently and to ensure the Commission's transparency and accountability as possible. The assessment of possible conflicts of interest should also be based on convincing, objective and relevant facts and relate to the working area of the candidate for commissioner. We therefore need to give the Legal Affairs Committee sufficient time to thoroughly examine the whole area and prepare an appropriate assessment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The definition of the scope of the audit of Commissioners' declarations of financial interest, as proposed herein, presents serious legislative gaps in ensuring transparency as well as in the number of (to be declared) financial information.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report and the proposal for a resolution because it reveals the possibility of serious misuse and offers a solution. I am convinced that the revision and enforcement of EU Commissioners' declarations of interests, the rules of conflict of interest and the code of conduct for them is necessary not only for the candidate and the already departed, but also, at least as rigorously, for the President-in-Office European Commissioners there is. In assessing this question, as a Hungarian MEP, I kept in mind the latest case concerning the government of my country, where an EU-wide questionable treaty with an external party has been accepted in the European Commission through a lobbyist, an in-office commissioner by relying on his help, influence, advice. (A Commissioner who, under the current rules of conflict of interest, did not even consider it concerned about accepting a great value favour from this lobbyist). To me, together with the case of the former private President of the Commission, this also proves that a thorough review of the European Commission's rules on conflicts of interest, transparency and public service ethics is justified, for which this EP Decision is important can give an incentive.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to increase transparency and accountability regarding the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, the implications of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and different conflicts of interest in the European Commission. As a member of the S&D group, I support this report, as we need greater parliamentary control over conflicts of interests in the European Commission. The case of Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete shows that the current system does not suffice. The European Parliament needs the ability to scrutinise candidates properly and politicians need to regain the trust of citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The verification of the absence of a conflict of interest cannot be put at the same level as the assessment of the candidate's competencies. It must therefore be an indispensable prerequisite for the hearing. The control of declarations of financial interests and, more broadly, of potential conflicts of interest concerning the members of the Commission must extend beyond the Commission's appointment procedure alone. I also expect from the Commission a series of amendments to its code of conduct and declarations of interest to ensure that these include sufficient information to assess the Commissioners' financial interests and that Parliament is informed of any changes.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the Declaration of Financial Interests of the Commissioner - Guidelines. I consider that the Committee on Legal Affairs, the committee responsible for carrying out a detailed analysis of statements of financial interests, must be provided with all adequate factual and legal mechanisms on the basis of which the analysis will be carried out. In doing so, I believe that the foreground must be making adequate time space available for the analysis to be effective. The emphasis must certainly be based on the principle of confidentiality in the course of examination of the financial statement, and upon its publication, in accordance with the principle of transparency, the results of the examination of the publication. I also consider that it is necessary to make available to the legal service mechanisms based on which, in case of any irregularities, they can conduct additional hearings and obtain additional clarifications.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - The Committee on Legal Affairs has issued a report containing guidelines for establishing clear rules in identifying possible conflicts of interests of trustees and clarifying the committee's competence. The report defines the meaning of the term 'conflict of interest' as any situation where private interests are contrary to the public interest and public interests which affect or may affect independence, impartiality and objectivity of the exercise of duties, and explains the procedure for reviewing statements on financial interests before the hearing of the nominees for trustees and during the term of the Commissioner. As I believe that the proposed procedures increase transparency and clarity of procedures, thereby reducing ambiguous situations and facilitating the task for members of the Legal Affairs Committee, I voted to adopt this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on Declarations of Interest of Commissioners - I have supported the guidelines. Annex XVI to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament on guidelines for approval by the Commission provides that Parliament 'may seek all information relevant to the adoption of a decision regarding the capacity of a candidate for commissioner. It expects full disclosure of data relating to their financial interests. Declarations of interests of candidates for commissioners shall be sent for review to the Committee responsible for legal matters”. However, this provision does not, unfortunately, specify the scope of the review by the Legal Affairs Committee. Therefore, an additional substantive review is required. It is necessary to specify the scope of the review of declarations of financial interests by the Legal Affairs Committee. The task of the Legal Affairs Committee is to assess the existence of possible conflicts of interest and, where appropriate, to make recommendations for their elimination. Control over declarations of financial interests and more broadly on possible conflicts of interest related to the members of the Commission should not be limited to the Commission's designation procedure.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, as its objective is to monitor Commissioners' statements of financial interests, in order to ensure that they can fulfil their mandates completely independently and to ensure maximum transparency for the Commission. Any change in the financial interests of a Commissioner during his term of office, or any reorganization of the distribution of responsibilities between the members of the Commission, constitutes a new situation as to the possible existence of a conflict of interest. The Commission is also asked to urgently review the 2011 Commissioners' Code of Conduct to take into account the recommendations made by Parliament in its recent resolutions. We believe that an institution such as the Commission should increase transparency and ensure the independence of Commissioners. That is why our vote was favourable.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ After the recent scandals of former Commission President Barroso and other former and present Commissioners regarding conflicts of interests and moving to the private sector after leaving the job, these guidelines for the declarations of interest of commissioners is very welcome and much needed.  I note in particular that: the Code of Conduct for Commissioners adopted on 20 April 2011 regarding impartiality, integrity, transparency, diligence, probity, responsibility and discretion presents improvements over the preceding code adopted in 2004 as regards the declaration of financial interests in that disclosure requirements are extended to Commissioners’ partners and the declaration of interests has to be revised when information changes or, at the least, every year. The credibility of the declaration of financial interests depends on the accuracy of the form presented to the Commissioner-designate; considers that the current scope of Commissioners’ declarations of interests is too limited and their explanatory content ambiguous; calls, therefore, on the Commission to revise the code of conduct as soon as possible in order to ensure that the declarations of interests provide the Committee on Legal Affairs with accurate information with which it can substantiate its decision unequivocally. The credibility of the European Commission depends on the strict applications and respect of these basic ethic rules and code of conduct.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament wishes to tighten up the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2001 because of the recent serious conflicts of interest concerning them. In particular, the proposal requires Commissioners to declare all their interests in companies, including their family interests, as well as their membership in NGOs or associations playing a lobby role. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The resolution defines the concept of conflict of interest and clarifies the procedure for the inspection of property statements prior to the hearings of candidates for commissioners as well as during the office of commissioner. The Commission is urged to review the Commissioners' Code of Conduct as soon as possible in order to broaden the scope of the declaration of no conflict of interest. Furthermore, the resolution calls for fair methods to determine family interests. I have been campaigning for transparency and clarity in EU procedures since the beginning of my work in the EP and I am pleased that Parliament has taken this important issue. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. The rapporteur intends to outline the scope of the investigation of financial interests by the Committee responsible for Legal Affairs. To this end, on the one hand, it intends to present the internal procedures of the European Parliament when appointing the new Commission and during its term of office, as well as the transparency requirements imposed on the members of the Commission. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, as its objective is to monitor Commissioners' statements of financial interests, in order to ensure that they can fulfil their mandates completely independently and to ensure maximum transparency for the Commission. Any change in the financial interests of a Commissioner during his term of office, or any reorganization of the distribution of responsibilities between the members of the Commission, constitutes a new situation as to the possible existence of a conflict of interest. The Commission is also asked to urgently review the 2011 Commissioners' Code of Conduct to take into account the recommendations made by Parliament in its recent resolutions. We believe that an institution such as the Commission should increase transparency and ensure the independence of Commissioners. That is why our vote was favourable.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Commissioners’ declarations of interests – guidelines. The aim of scrutinising Commissioners’ declarations of financial interests is to ensure that the Commissioners-designate are able to fulfil their mandates completely independently and to ensure maximum transparency and accountability on the part of the Commission. The report points out that a conflict of interests is defined as ‘any interference situation between a public interest and public and private interests that is likely to affect or that appears likely to affect the independent, impartial and objective exercise of a duty’. It equally underlines that the Committee on Legal Affairs observes the strictest confidentiality when examining questions relating to the declarations of interests of the Commissioners-designate, but also ensures, in accordance with the principle of transparency, that its conclusions are published as soon as they are available.  I voted in favour because I believe that beyond the time allocated for questions that the Committee on Legal Affairs wishes to put to the Commissioner-designate, should it note a possible conflict of interests, it should be granted the right to continue with the hearing and obtain the required clarifications.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it requires further clarification in the family relations of Commissioners, their properties and their contracts and that the resolutions of the European Ombudsman and the Ad Hoc Committee on Ethics on employment authorisations for former Commissioners be respected. Unfortunately, conflicts of interest are a constant in the professional career of European Commissioners, a clear example of the personal collusion between their politicians and the interests of large transnational capital. Kroes and Uber, Cañete and the properties of their family, Barroso and Goldman Sachs etc. demonstrate the structural links between high European bureaucracy and corporate power.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We support more transparency in terms of promiscuity between economic and political power and, of course, we support anything that might stop the current subalternization of the European institutions in general and of the European Commission in particular in the face of the big lobbies of big business. However, it must be stressed that the central problem lies in the nature of the European Union, its capitalist nature, which is not resolved by a revision of the Code of Conduct or not. The creation of a residual state, completely absent from economics and without the material means to be able to make effective its sovereignty and legitimate power transmitted to it by the people, will always be the best way to stay the same, with the European institutions serving the interests of large corporations transnational.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The rapporteur calls for a more precise description of the scope of the examination of the Declaration on Financial Interests. It rectifies that the assessment of a conflict of interest cannot be equated with the assessment of the candidate's competence and must therefore be a mandatory condition for consultation. In addition, the rapporteur calls for the examination of the statements on financial interests and conflicts of interest to extend beyond the appointment procedure, so that any significant change in the financial interests of a Commissioner during the term of office constitutes a situation to be reassessed. of a parliamentary investigation procedure. The rapporteur calls on the Commission to amend its Code of Conduct and to extend the content of its members' declarations of interests so that they contain sufficient information for the assessment of financial interests. Parliament should also be informed of any changes. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In my view, the European Parliament, as an institution with a strong democratic mandate, should address recent public opinion concerns over potential conflicts of interest regarding some former Commissioners by reassuring citizens that such situations will not happen again. This the reason why I welcome this report introducing stricter guidelines on the identification of conflicts of interest going hand in hand with a substantial reform of the Commissioners’ Code of Conduct.  Therefore, those reforms mean basically more European Parliament involvement and powers regarding the financial declarations and also some additional Commissioner hearings in case of portfolio changes. Furthermore, once a conflict is identified by the Committee on Legal Affairs, the President of the European Parliament shall formally ask the President of the European Commission what further steps are envisaged in this situation. This procedure in turn can lead even to a resignation from office of a Commissioner whose integrity is being questioned. Consequently, I think that this report is a further step towards making EU institutions more transparent and at the same time bringing them closer to the citizens, hence I voted in favour.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have been an active supporter and advocate of stricter rules on conflicts of interests of Commissioners, including a longer cooling-off period for all Commissioners, and more binding power for the Commissioners’ Ethics Committee. This is in line with the proposals made by key stakeholders like Transparency International. The recent actions by former Commission President Barroso and other similar case are a disgrace, and do not meet the standards we expect from democratic leaders. I will continue to pursue transparency, integrity, and openness in decision-making, and bringing in higher binding standards for officials and elected representatives.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I vote in favour of this report as a whole, but I still have some doubts. I completely agree that the Legal Affairs Committee is the body that should assess the presence of a potential conflict of interest and subsequently make recommendations for its removal. But I don't think this committee is competent to judge whether the information presented by the commissioner nominees is true or not. Also debatable is the extent to which conflict of interest should be limited and how it should be understood in relation to the trust portfolio. Problems with the interpretation of the little detailed provisions on the assessment of the financial interests of the EuroCommissioners proved problematic, for example, during the last appointment of the European Commission, and therefore I believe that this declaration will help clarify the whole situation and enable better consideration of Commissioner nominees.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the European Parliament's proposal on declarations of interests of the members of the Commission. This proposal contained, inter alia, guidelines on how the declarations of interests of the members of the Commission should look in order to ensure their full independence. The guidelines were drafted on the basis of the experience of the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI), which currently does not have sufficient powers and information to properly assess this independence. I think that, in functions such as a member of the European Commission or a former member of the European Commission, it is crucial that absolute independence is guaranteed, and at the same time there are legal ways to examine that independence and intervene in case of doubt. It is also necessary that this information is always up to date. Last but not least, I appreciate that the report also dealt with the revision of the Code of Conduct for Commissioners and the adoption of rules to assess the financial interests of their family members.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support this report as it calls for the full independence of the Commissioners during the performance of their duties which is important to increase the transparency and accountability of the Commission. I consider that the review of the Commissioners' financial interests declarations is necessary at each stage of completing the Commission and the new members taking office as a substitute due to the resignation or death of the Commissioner or in the case of the accession of new Member States. Conflict of interest in the performance of duties can affect independence, impartiality and objectivity during the performance of duties. The guidelines recommended in this report are a good foundation for the future framework of action of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which plays an important role in the process of verifying declarations of interests of candidates for trustees.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on the Commissioners' Declarations of Interest — Guidelines. I support the calls for the Commission to urgently revise the 2011 Code of Conduct in order to take account of the recommendations made by the European Parliament in its recent resolutions and the overall development of ethics and transparency standards applicable to all EU institutions. I believe that the full disclosure of data relating to the financial interests of candidates for commissioners contributes both to the personal integrity of candidates and strengthens the confidence of EU citizens in the independent functioning of the EU institutions.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sa tuarascáil seo agus i ndáiríre vótáil mé agus mo chomhleachtaithe leis an ngrúpa sna vótaí seo go léir inniu. Is ábhar tábhachtach é seo agus, go háirithe, caithfimid a bheith lánchinnte faoi cad a tharlóidh sna grúpaí seo amach anseo, go háirithe maidir lena mbaineann le cúrsaí airgeadais. Tar éis an cúlú eacnamaíochta ní raibh mórán tuisceana ag daoine faoi cad a bhí ag tárlu agus tháinig siad anuas go dian ar na hoibrithe go háirithe a bhí ag obair i dtionscail an airgeadais. Dar ndóigh tá sé sin ag athrú anois agus is maith sin mar ní raibh mórán baint ag na hoibrithe de ghnáth sna cinntí a bhí déanta, a tháinig agus bhí mar chúis leis an gcúlú eacnamaíochta. Ach anois tá rudaí ag feabhsú agus cabhraíonn seo leis an bhfeabhsú sin.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: ‒ The following report analyses the 2013 Directive on the safety of operations at sea. The contained analysis is fairly critical. Specifically, I agree that a definite negative aspect is the lack of clear references to the civil liability of natural and legal persons and to criminal liability for accidents at sea. In addition, another fairly controversial aspect of the directive is the lack of adequate financial guarantee for environmental disasters. Since I care very much about the protection of the environment and especially our seas, I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file seeks to harmonise on rules for liability, compensation and financial security with a view to preventing further accidents with cross border implications while making sure that those liable can be held financially and legally accountable to persons and states, particularly if the damage fishing, tourism or wildlife. It introduces the idea of a horizontal European framework for collective redress for sectors hardest hit by oil and gas spills such as fisheries and coastal tourist sectors. Although the idea of protecting both the environment by raising security standards and the idea of compensating inhabitants and workers of hard-hit areas is one I completely agree on, the usurpation of powers from Member States to the EU in this creates a subsidiarity issue. In spite of this, it also sought the harmonisation of national legislation and areas of competence for member states, therefore I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur would like the Commission to work closely with the Member States to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. Clearly, the Commission wishes to extend the scope of its scope of competence in this matter even though France considers that it does not want such an extension. I voted against it because this report awaited the sovereignty of States.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks EU-wide harmonisation, and I was elected with a mandate to oppose that. I therefore voted against.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on liability and compensation for offshore oil and gas operations and their financial security. The Maritime Safety Directive was adopted in April 2010 following the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil platform and oil spills in April 2010 in order to establish minimum levels of high requirements for preventing accidents arising from oil and gas operations in the EU and limiting the consequences of such accidents. I therefore agree with the rapporteur, who argues that the Commission must cooperate more closely with the Member States to ensure that the appropriate legal basis governing all activities at sea is applied before a serious accident occurs.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this text, which would undermine the sovereignty of States by expanding the powers of the Commission, allowing it to work closely with the Member States to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — Offshore oil and gas operations are likely to have major and devastating consequences for the environment and economy of the sea and coastal areas. I therefore supported this report, which insists in particular on compensation to third parties. Stressing that the treatment of civil liability varies considerably from one State to another, the report considers it necessary to have a European framework based on the laws of the most advanced Member States, which covers not only personal injury and property damage but also economic damage and ensures that effective compensation mechanisms for victims and sectors likely to be seriously affected (e.g. fishing and coastal tourism).

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ 90% of the oil and 60% of the gas produced in Europe come from operations at sea. These are activities that today take place in increasingly extreme environments, at a greater distance from the coast and in ever deeper waters. The greatest difficulties also lead to a possible increase in risks, which must therefore be properly assessed and averted to avoid devastating consequences for the environment, the economy of the sea and the coastal areas. The Chrysogonos report, which I supported today, deals with the issue of liabilities, compensation and financial guarantees in the event of damage occurring as a result of operations at sea in the field of hydrocarbons. The text asks the Commission to work closely with Member States to ensure the overall updating of compensation and financial guarantee schemes. In particular, it calls for the coverage of claims for the traditional damage caused by accidents, that an effective payment management scheme be set up and that ensure that operators and other responsible parties have the appropriate financial resources in order to meet the claims which may be made to them as a result of the damage.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report asks the Commission to assess the desirability of introducing new harmonised rules on liability, compensation and financial security in order to avoid new accidents with cross-border effects and consider the establishment of a legislative mechanism for compensation for maritime accidents. In addition, it calls for the establishment of countervailing regimes capable of effectively and expeditiously addressing transboundary claims and covering both primary and secondary damage caused in all affected areas. Member States are urged to develop traditional financial guarantee instruments, relating to damages, resulting from incidents involving general oil and gas activities on the high seas or the maritime transport of hydrocarbons and gas, including in the event of insolvency. I voted in favour, because I understand that strict rules on civil liability should be established for such accidents, in order to facilitate access to justice for victims.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on liability, indemnities and financial guarantees in the field of offshore oil and gas operations. The adoption of the Directives on the safety of offshore oil and gas operations is supported. In addition, Member States which have not yet transpose it are requested to do so into their national legislation as soon as possible. In addition, it is considered that stricter rules on civil liability materials for offshore accidents should be established in order to facilitate access to justice for victims affected by such accidents.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report on compensation and financial guarantee schemes for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. This case is linked to the issues of energy security, for which it is necessary to preserve France's interests and therefore to oppose the expansion of the Commission's scope of competence. Therefore, in view of liability regimes, which are the main means of applying the “polluter pays” principle and thus guarantee that companies are held liable for damage caused in the exercise of their activities, France must be able to keep all its prerogatives outside a European framework global. Finally, the failure of the directive on the safety of operations at sea is evident in this area, demonstrating that action at Member State level will make it possible to be more efficient.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Chrysogonos report on liability, compensation and financial guarantees for operations at sea in the hydrocarbons sector is balanced, it addresses this matter and proposes that the recognition of damage is also extended to the environmental impact as well as to the strictly more economical and patrimonial areas. For these reasons I voted in favour of him.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on liability, compensation and financial guarantee in offshore oil and gas operations, which clarifies the offshore safety directive, as regards the types of damage to be compensated, the liability regimes for each of the parties and the financial capacity necessary to deal with such compensation, if they are liable. This is intended to harmonise and update Member States' liability systems, ensuring the polluter pays principle. This would prevent a potential accident in European waters from adversely affecting future oil and gas operations, both in a Member State and within the Union as a whole.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which deals with responsibility and compensation for offshore oil and gas operations and their financial security. The European Parliament underlines that the effective application of the polluter pays principle to offshore oil and gas operations should not only cover the prevention and repair of environmental damage, as is currently being done to a certain extent under the Maritime Safety and Environmental Responsibility Directives, but also costs relating to the satisfaction of claims for traditional damages, as provided for in the principles of prudence and sustainable development. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to consider the possibility of establishing a legislative mechanism to compensate for damage caused by accidents at sea, similar to that provided for in the Norwegian Act on Oil Activities, which applies at least to sectors that are likely to suffer significant adverse effects, such as fisheries, coastal tourism and other sectors of the blue economy. In this context, it recommends a quantification and qualitative assessment of the problems or accidents caused by companies in the course of their operations and identifying all secondary effects of the entities involved. It also underlines the differences and weaknesses in the transposition and application of the provisions of the Environmental Liability Directive on environmental liability, as pointed out by the Commission in its second implementation report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. — I agree that further improvements to the Seas Safety Directive complementing Directive 2004/35/EC on environmental responsibility and Directive 2011/92/EU on environmental impact assessment and ratification of the Protocol on offshore activities to the Barcelona Convention are needed in the Council. These are the right steps towards protecting the environment, regulating human activities and the safety of workers. It is important to be aware of the scale of oil and natural gas pumping in the North Sea, which will also extend into the southern part of the Mediterranean Sea in the future. However, with increased scale, the chances of possible accidents increase and adequate safety should be ensured.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. — I support this Report, which deals with the types of damages that are paid, the financial capacity of the persons responsible, compensation payments and regime responsibilities. The report focuses on the importance of updating the existing system of accountability in Member States, to ensure that “polluter pay” is applied to traditional, not just environmental pollution.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — The Commission wishes to extend the scope of its scope of competence in this matter even though France considers that it does not want such an extension. This constitutes a violation of the sovereignty of the Member States. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector are carried out in deep water and some in harsh environments and areas whose main source of income is tourism. The Safety of Operations at Sea Directive was approved following the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon, with the aim of setting minimum requirements to avoid the occurrence of serious accidents and limit its consequences. However, the directive does not enter into the merits of liability for civil damage caused to natural or legal persons and does not address the issue of criminal liability. Neither the definition of offences nor the type and minimum level of sanctions are harmonised within the EU. Criminal liability should therefore be introduced at EU level, thus leading to improved environmental protection and compliance with security measures. Typically, claims for damages following an accident at sea in the hydrocarbon sector relate to purely economic losses. A close correlation is required between traditional damage liability schemes, claims management schemes and the availability of financial guarantee instruments; and therefore, Commission and Member States must cooperate in updating these schemes.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Directive on the Safety of Offshore Operations aims to establish requirements for the prevention of major accidents in offshore oil and gas operations within the EU and to limit the consequences of such accidents. Although the provisions of that directive establish that holders of authorisations to conduct offshore operations are strictly liable for the prevention and repair of all environmental damage caused by their oil and gas operations, the Directive does not governs liability for civil damage to natural persons or legal persons, nor matters relating to criminal liability for offshore accidents. Thus, this initiative proposes the establishment of mechanisms to compensate third parties for traditional damage caused by offshore oil and gas operations and the creation of an effective compensation system for the management of relevant payments. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I consider it essential to provide compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations in the EU.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report because I believe that there is no effective system of accountability and financial guarantee to cover compensation for damages caused by operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector poses a serious risk to Member States. I think that updating the liability schemes in force in the Member States could limit the outsourcing of operator responsibility for accidental pollution to the detriment to finances public. I therefore urge the Commission to encourage Member States to develop financial guarantee instruments in the field of compensation for claims for damages arising from accidents in the context of activities in sea in the hydrocarbons sector or transport thereof, including in the case of insolvency.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. It seeks to harmonise rules for liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations with a view to preventing further accidents with cross border implications while making sure that those liable can be held financially and legally accountable to persons and states, particularly if the damage fishing, tourism or wildlife. It introduces the idea of a horizontal European framework for collective redress for sectors hardest hit by oil and gas spills such as fisheries and coastal tourist sectors. Although the idea of protecting both the environment by raising security standards and the idea of compensating inhabitants and workers of hard-hit areas is one I completely agree on, the usurpation of powers from Member States to the EU in this creates a subsidiarity issue. In spite of this, it also sought the harmonisation of national legislation and areas of competence for member states, therefore I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on compensation for offshore oil and gas operations. This report is trying to harmonise the civil claims process for offshore accidents, however the  report does not even consider the fact that the international framework for each Member State differs and it cannot be harmonised on matters of this issue.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Parliament's own-initiative report proposing an analysis of the Safety of Operations at Sea Directive 2013/30/EU approved following the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon of 20 April 2010 and the consequent oil spill, which aimed at setting minimum requirements aimed at avoiding the occurrence of serious accidents within the framework of operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The report, for which I voted in favour, assesses the effects of the directive on the safety of operations at sea, which sets minimum requirements to avoid the occurrence of serious accidents in the context of operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector in the European Union and to limit the consequences of such accidents. I believe that the directive should also be updated by taking into account liability for civil damages such as personal injury, material damage and economic loss. I appreciate that the report observes how the liability schemes available in the Member States face difficulties in dealing with the majority of claims for compensation related to accidents from which Widespread pollution damage results. In this regard, it seems to me necessary for the European Union to provide itself with a legal framework allowing applicants, such as ferry companies or fishery product processing undertakings, to get a repair in case of hydrocarbon leakage from plants into the sea. I also believe that the European Union should raise the current minimum guarantee amounts and exceed the limitation of the compulsory guarantee to insurance products alone, including bank guarantees, successful guarantees, and if necessary, guarantees of the parent.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations. The proposals in this report not only affect economic activities, but also aim to support the environmental needs of the European region. Work related to oil and gas production has a significant economic impact but also high environmental hazard. It is obvious that we need to lay down certain rules for protecting the environment, both citizens and businesses located near offshore oil and gas fields. As this report contains positive proposals, I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: ‒ Positive vote for this report aimed at ensuring the updating of compensation schemes and financial guarantees for operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. As operations at sea related to the hydrocarbon sector are forced to reposition themselves in increasingly extreme and impervious areas, I think it is a priority to provide precise rules in on the liability of operators, compensation and related financial guarantees. Therefore, my agreement is outside the report, which recalls how sources of hydrocarbons are increasingly distant from the coasts and at greater sea depths, therefore accidents in these environments would cause devastating cross-border consequences. By virtue of the above, I welcome the approval of Directive 2013/30/EU on safety at sea, but I believe that it should be supplemented with precise rules on the subject of civil liability for damage to natural and legal persons. These rules must be harmonised because, to date, national legislation are applied even though they are usually transnational events. Similarly, I urge the Commission to encourage Member States to develop instruments of financial guarantees in the context of activities at sea and hydrocarbon transport even in the event of insolvency.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure because I also believe it is necessary to minimise damage from a possible accident in offshore oil and gas operations. In particular, I agree with the need to establish a compensation mechanism to protect potentially affected sectors, such as fisheries and tourism, by ensuring appropriate compensation measures.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Offshore oil and gas operations are progressively taking place in increasingly extreme environments and could potentially have major and devastating consequences for the environment and economy of the sea and coastal areas.  To address this, Member States had until 19 July to update their national legislative frameworks for offshore oil and gas operations to be in line with the Offshore Safety Directive but regrettably the deadline has long passed and the basic elements of a comprehensive EU-wide framework for preventing major accidents and limiting their consequences are not in place. We should do more to consider the special situation of workers and employees in the offshore oil and gas industry since such incidents may have particularly serious implications on their health, families and the fisheries and tourism industries.  There is no liability in many of the Member States with offshore and gas activities for most third-party claims for compensation for traditional damage caused by an accident.  There is no regime in the vast majority of Member States for compensation payments, and no assurance in many Member States that operators or liable persons would have adequate financial assets to meet claims.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — As a result of many doubts, I voted against the report on liability, compensation and financial security in relation to offshore oil and gas deposits. I believe the proposed extension of the scope of the rules is not necessary. The current rules on the issue concerned do not require proposed amendments. Regulations on these issues are sufficient to secure security matters of offshore fuel extraction activities.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as offshore oil and gas operations could have major devastating consequences for the environment and economy of our seas with these offshore facilities likely to increase in Europe over the next few years. Firms must be held accountable for any damage caused and therefore preventive measures should be put in place.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Attempting to introduce legal instruments useful to prevent and repair environmental damage caused by operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector can help you get a proper application of the principle “polluter pays”. In fact, both the activity of introspection, the settlement and the operation of the platforms can have a serious and devastating impact for marine fauna and flora, for fisheries, for coastal tourism and more generally for all activities of the blue economy. It is therefore necessary to identify compensation and repair schemes, as well as financial guarantee instruments capable of responding even in the most expensive cases, ensuring adequate restoration interventions environmental and monetization of damage to affected assets. This applies to areas already affected by extraction, since it would not make sense to expand such harmful activities, on the assumption that compensation is enough to “offset” the impact. It is necessary to avoid new drilling, abandoning any effort destined to fossil sources and instead incentivizing energy from renewable sources, better still if in the perspective of self-production. All this expressed, my vote is still positive.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report follows the directive on safety at sea, adopted with the aim of establishing minimum requirements for the prevention of major accidents in oil and gas operations in the EU. The report thus presents a list of recommendations relating to the precautionary principle and the polluter pays principle, that is, the principle that the activity that pollutes a territory must compensate that territory. Considering that oil and gas activities must exercise special precautions, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on compensation for offshore oil and gas operations. This report is trying to harmonise the civil claims process for offshore accidents, however the  report does not even consider the fact that the international framework for each Member State differs and it cannot be harmonised on matters of this issue.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — — I voted in favour of the report on liability, compensation and financial guarantees for offshore oil and gas operations. Oil and gas accidents at sea are serious environmental disasters on which the European Union must be particularly strict. While the Union has already legislated on the safety of offshore oil and gas operations, several elements of European legislation, such as the treatment of civil liability in these accidents, remain to be harmonised. This report presents several avenues, which should be evaluated by the Commission, to ensure better legal treatment of the consequences of oil or gas accidents at sea.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - Following the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil drilling platform on 20 April 2010 and oil pollution, the Directive on the safety of offshore oil and gas operations was adopted, with the aim of setting minimum requirements for EU offshore oil and to prevent major accidents involving gas operations and to limit the consequences of such accidents. Since the deadline for harmonisation has long expired, the foundations for the EU-wide regulatory framework should already be available. The Member States' liability systems are different, most civil damages claims resulting from accidents involving extensive pollution can be enforced in different procedures from one Member State to another. With a few exceptions (France, the Netherlands, Denmark), the current liability rules cover only damages that are considered to be ships and, in the event of a direct causation, they are capable of enforcing foregone profits. However, there is no such convention on compensation for damage arising from offshore oil and gas operations and in all likelihood those conventions would not cover such accidents, since offshore oil and gas installations are unlikely to be within the meaning of the Convention would be considered a “ship”. The Commission should work closely with Member States to ensure that Union compensation and financial safeguards systems for offshore oil and gas operations are modernised. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - Following the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil drilling platform on 20 April 2010 and oil pollution, the Directive on the safety of offshore oil and gas operations was adopted, with the aim of setting minimum requirements for EU offshore oil and to prevent major accidents involving gas operations and to limit the consequences of such accidents. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The objective of this report is to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. However, this extension of powers is rejected by France.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. This report largely seeks to increase the scope of responsibility for the conduct of oil and gas operations on the high seas. It calls for a framework of EU responsibility in this area, asking for harmonisation of minimum liability for civil damage, and recommends a common mechanism at EU level for dealing with incidents (i.e. another agency). It also calls on the Commission to consider establishing a legislative compensation mechanism and proposes to extend the scope to secondary damage. It further calls on the Commission to add major oil accidents to the Environmental Crime Directive (OSD). It also proposes the creation of a fund based on fees paid by the offshore industry, asking for a possible assessment by the Commission. I do not support many of these proposals and, above all, believe that, for the moment, the legislation established is quite sufficient in this area and that what is required in this report does not meet the real needs. In such cases, European legislation should not be used.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The Directive does not regulate civil liability for damage to its full extent, whether it concerns natural or legal persons, whether it is personal injury, property damage or financial loss, net or consequential. Furthermore, criminal liability for offshore accidents, possible fines or other non-custodial penalties are not regulated.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations. It calls for the full implementation of the Offshore Safety Directive, which is crucial in the event of serious accidents. Like other countries, Wales has in the past suffered from the impact of oil disasters which devastated our shores. We must do all we can to avoid this in future.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: ‒ The extension of the area of liability for damage caused by operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector constitutes a worthy objective to be pursued, together with strengthening financial guarantee instruments in respect of compensation for related damages. The report in question makes its own objectives, and also proposes a greater harmonisation of the legislative framework, which also provides for collective recourse. By sharing its contents, I declare that I vote in favour of the report.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not consider it necessary to update the compensation and financial guarantee schemes in the Member States in the context of operations at sea in the hydrocarbon industry.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report focuses on the importance of a thorough revision of existing compensation schemes in each Member State to ensure that air polluters are punishable not only for environmental damage, but also for other damages, such as physical injuries or damage property.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report for greater coordination between the EU and the Member States on compensation due to operations at sea in the hydrocarbon sector.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — I am voting against the report, as the directive does not regulate civil liability for damage to its full extent, whether it concerns natural or legal persons, whether it is personal injury, property damage, financial loss, net or consequential. Furthermore, criminal liability for offshore accidents, possible fines or other non-custodial penalties are not regulated.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In September 2015 the Commission presented a report to the EP and the Council on liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations pursuant to Article 39 of Directive 2013/30/EU (the Offshore Safety Directive or OSD). The OSD defines the elements of such a comprehensive EU-wide framework for preventing major accidents and limiting their consequences. The report  deals with what kinds of damage are being paid, financial capacity of liable parties, disbursement of compensation and liability regimes. In his report the rapporteur has focused on the importance of updating existing liability systems in the Member States to ensure the application of the polluter-pays principle not only to environmental but also to traditional damages (bodily injuries/ property damages/ pure and consequential economic losses). Incidents in European waters should not adversely affect the future of the offshore oil and gas operations of the state in question, nor that of the entire EU, were the incident to occur in an area that was largely dependent on tourism for revenue. As a result, compensation and financial security systems for offshore oil and gas operations in the EU should be brought up to speed. I supported the report in the Plenary.
