That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report, bearing in mind those affected by disasters in offshore oil and gas operations, such as those caused by the 'Castor' platform off the coast of the Terres de l'Ebre and north of Castellón. The report provides the basis for those affected by disasters due to offshore oil and gas operations, whether for direct, indirect or collateral causes, to claim liability and compensation in the future (until now, it was only possible if they were for direct causes, such as a slick tide). Likewise, if there had been this harmonisation of European legislation which we claimed from the European Parliament at the time of the events, the neighbours could now claim compensation for the damage they suffered.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. — More than 90% of the oil and 60% of the gas extracted in Europe comes from offshore activities. Such exploration and mining activities are already being carried out or planned in the territorial seas of 18 EU member states. Consequently, legislation was necessary to protect against losses caused by this type of offshore activity. The new rules were adopted by the European Parliament in November's plenary session in Brussels. The effectiveness of state systems in relation to damage resulting from pollution caused by such activity is based on systems for processing claims for compensation and the availability of financial security instruments. At present, with the exception of France, the Netherlands and Denmark, in many Member States there is little likelihood of complainants receiving compensation, especially when they are undertakings incurring indirect damage, such as fish processing plants. In this context, the European Commission should work closely with Member States in order to ensure that compensation and financial safeguards schemes for oil and natural gas activities in EU offshore areas are adapted to current requirements. They must provide compensation for claims made by third parties and for traditional damages caused by failures within such offshore activities.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is necessary to update the compensation and coverage arrangements for offshore oil and gas operations in the EU. This includes, for the first time, to provide for compensation for third-party claims for damage caused by offshore oil and gas accidents. Secondly, an effective compensation scheme must be put in place with a view to processing the relevant payments. Third, it is important to ensure that operators and other liable parties have sufficient assets to meet the claims for damages.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU framework of liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations. Effective and adequate measures need to be taken in order to compensate adequately claims on damage to victims, animals and the environment.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because Member States had until 19 July 2015 to update their national regulatory frameworks relating to operations in the field of Hydrocarbons by adapting them to the Safety of Operations at Sea Directive. Now, to protect our coasts and territories, we must improve the accountability regime in the territorial waters of the 18 Member States that are affected by exploration operations at sea and exploitation currently underway or planned. Therefore, ensuring the updating of compensation and financial guarantee schemes for hydrocarbon operations at sea in the EU is now a necessity no longer postponable. The fundamental elements of a comprehensive framework at EU level for the prevention of serious accidents and limiting their consequences must be prepared and implemented.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report asks the Commission to assess the desirability of introducing new harmonised rules on liability, compensation and financial security in order to avoid new accidents with cross-border effects and consider the establishment of a legislative mechanism for compensation for maritime accidents. In addition, it calls for the establishment of countervailing regimes capable of effectively and expeditiously addressing transboundary claims and covering both primary and secondary damage caused in all affected areas. Member States are urged to develop traditional financial guarantee instruments, relating to damages, resulting from incidents involving general oil and gas activities on the high seas or the maritime transport of hydrocarbons and gas, including in the event of insolvency. I voted in favour, because I understand that strict rules on civil liability should be established for such accidents, in order to facilitate access to justice for victims.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to keep the report as adopted in committee. The report focuses on the importance of updating existing liability systems in the Member States to ensure the application of the polluter-pays principle not only to environmental but also to traditional damages (bodily injuries/ property damages/ pure and consequential economic losses).

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given that offshore oil and gas operations are progressively taking place in increasingly extreme environments and could potentially have major and devastating consequences for the environment and economy of the sea and coastal areas, I believe that it is necessary that the providers of these operations be liable for any damage that they may cause. Therefore I supported the resolution.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour, since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted for the Report on Liability, Damage Compensation and Financial Guarantee for Authorised Oil and Gas Activities because these activities are taking place in an increasingly extreme environment, therefore potentially could have major and devastating consequences for the environment and economy of marine and coastal areas . This Report welcomes the adoption of the Authorised Safety Directive 2013/30/EU, supplementing the Environmental Accountability Directive 2004/35/EC and the Environmental Impact Assessment Directive 2011/92/EU, and the ratification of the Protocol on Approval Activities to the Barcelona Convention carried out by the Council as first steps to protect the environment, human activities and the safety of workers. Also, the Report calls on the Commission and the Member States to consider the possibility of introducing additional measures to effectively protect authorised oil and gas activities before a serious accident occurs.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing. — I oppose this report, whose purpose is to extend the scope of the Commission's competence, as is often the case, to the detriment of the sovereign power of the States, since France itself has indicated its refusal to do so. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which recommends updating existing liability systems in the Member States to ensure that, if an incident occurs in the waters of those States, it would not affect the future of offshore oil and gas operations or the entire ecosystem of the European Union and local actors.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The rapporteur calls for a revision of the directive on offshore collateral for the production of oil and gas. Offshore safety is becoming increasingly important as difficult geographical and geological conditions such as deep-sea environments are often tackled. Given the scale and characteristics of offshore oil and gas accidents and 'near accidits' recently reported worldwide and in the EU, it is essential to take measures that could reduce the likelihood of a major accident in EU waters.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The sea and oceans are considered an important element of the country's ecological stability. Unfortunately, they have become garbage dumps in a number of places as well as in recent years. Dozens of tons of plastic bring rivers around the world a year, and ocean currents concentrate these “treasures” into large floating islands. The reports speak of an area of an island of garbage in the Atlantic Ocean about the size of France. As the interests of gas and oil miners shift from land to sea, the likelihood of crashes of their equipment increases. Especially in the far north, the consequences of such a crash in nature tend to be very long visible. In the south, nature is “helping” to dispose of the crash far faster, but the losses from tourism are all the worse for the surrounding states. Fishing tends to be affected very significantly in both cases. It is good that the European Commission is trying to unify the approach to liability for compensation for the damage incurred. Only by the maximum coordination of legislation in a given area, ideally through the introduction of a globally applicable standard, can significant progress be made. The report rightly calls on the Commission to develop the necessary studies and data collection and calls for synergies by individual Member States. For the above reasons, I welcome and support the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — At the plenary session on 1 December, I voted in favour of the report on responsibility, compensation and financial security in the field of offshore oil and gas activities. More than 90% of the oil and 60% of the natural gas extracted in Europe comes from activities carried out in the sea. Currently, or are planned in territorial waters of 18 Member States. Offshore oil and gas activities are carried out in increasingly extreme conditions, so further measures need to be implemented to effectively guarantee safety before there will be an accident that would have serious and devastating consequences for the environment and economy of the marine and coastal areas. With the introduction of further harmonised rules at EU level on accountability, compensation and financial security, future accidents could be prevented on the basis of precautionary principles; and prevention, as well as on the principle of “polluter pays” and on the principles of sustainability.

The Commission should work closely with Member States to ensure that Union compensation and financial safeguards systems for offshore oil and gas operations are modernised. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In fact, over 90% of oil and 60% of gas produced in Europe (EU and Norway/Iceland) comes from offshore operations. Offshore operations (exploration and exploitation) are ongoing or planned to take place in the territorial waters of 18 Member States. In view of the liability systems available in Member States, it appears there is a crucial issue as to whether the majority of civil claims from accidents resulting in widespread pollution damage will be met by the current legislative or non-legislative and ad hoc or judicial regimes in place in these States. In this context, I fully support the rapporteur’s opinion that the Commission should work closely with the Member States and ensure that the compensation and financial security systems for offshore oil and gas operations in the EU are available. Thus, in this manner, the EU will assure its citizens that there is an effective compensation regime for offshore oil and gas operations accidents and that operators or other liable parties would have adequate financial assets to meet compensation claims.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: This implementation report follows a communication from the European Commission on civil and criminal liability of operators covered by Directive 2013/30/EU on the safety of operations at sea. In particular, the Commission examines the modalities of compensation and guarantees applicable in the event of accidents at sea. I supported this report, which proposes to clarify existing liability systems in the Member States.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, because it seeks to clarify the types of damage to be compensated in oil and gas operations on the high seas, the parties' liability regimes and their financial capacity to deal with such compensation if they are liable. The report focuses on the importance of harmonising and updating liability systems in the Member States in order to ensure the application of the polluter pays principle not only in the case of environmental damage, but also in the case of personal injury, property or net economic loss. The report is relevant to Spain because it specifically mentions the case of the “Castor” platform, which is applicable to offshore fracking operations. It also applies to cases such as the “Prestige”, since it speaks not only of damage from fixed infrastructure, but also about possible accidents during the transport process and the distribution of gas or oil.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Authorised oil and gas activities are carried out farther away from the coast and in ever deeper waters. Some of them also take place in locations whose revenues depend heavily on tourism, such as the Mediterranean. More than 90% of the oil and 60% of the gas produced in Europe comes from approved plants, and currently exploits of authorised activities are taking place or planned in the territorial waters of 18 Member States. Economic fishing and persons involved in aquaculture, entities in the tourism sector and other coastal industries can be exposed to clean economic losses due to oil spills. While the breach of authorisation security in many countries is covered by criminal law, neither the definition of a crime nor the type and degree of minimum sanctions are harmonised at EU level. The report highlights the importance of updating existing accountability systems in Member States to ensure that possible accidents in their territorial waters do not adversely affect the future of authorised oil and gas operations or the whole of the EU. It is necessary to promote a harmonised solution with regard to the requirements for a compulsory financial guarantee. This should be done so that the effectiveness of the 'polluter pay' principle is not compromised by setting too low a minimum guarantee amount or limiting compulsory insurance only to insurance products, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU declares the right of Member States to determine the conditions for the use of their energy resources, while respecting solidarity and environmental protection. The use of own resources is important for both energy security and diversity, and the issue of preventing accidents in such activities is also essential. The Maritime Safety Directive, adopted in 2010, implies the objective responsibility of holders of offshore operations permits for the prevention and elimination of any environmental damage caused by their operations. However, it does not contain provisions on civil or criminal liability for damages against natural or legal persons, whether bodily harm, property damage or economic loss. I therefore support the updating of the liability system and the harmonisation of law in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the liability, compensation and financial security of offshore oil and gas operations, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 30/11/2016, as well as because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The aim of this text is to modernise compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. This text is in favour of modifying and extending the scope of the Commission's powers even though France has voted against such an enlargement. We therefore oppose this text.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The European Parliament, in its resolution on liability and compensation for offshore oil and gas operations and their financial security calls on the Commission and the Member States to develop additional measures to ensure the safety of offshore oil and gas operations more effectively before the to a major disaster. For example, the current directive does not provide for civil liability for damage to either natural or legal persons or criminal liability for accidents at sea, possible fines and other non-custodial penalties. Although offences at sea are included in the criminal code of many countries, neither the definition of criminal offence nor the minimum nature and level of sanctions have been harmonised at EU level. The establishment of criminal liability at EU level could become another deterrent measure, which does not include civil liability, thus ensuring better protection of the environment and compliance with safety measures.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur hopes that the Commission will work closely with the Member States to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the EU. The Commission therefore wishes to extend the scope of its scope of competence in this area. Therefore, I have spoken against this resolution.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because offshore oil and gas operations are delicate and can pose risks to citizens, the natural environment and to the economy if conducted poorly. Adequate compensation and financial security are indispensable tools to prepare ourselves to deal with potential accidents.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I have decided to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution on liability, compensation and financial guarantees for offshore oil and gas operations. More than 90% of oil and 60% of the gas produced in Europe comes from offshore activities and 18 Member States see ongoing or planned operations in their waters. Accidents occurring in these offshore oil and gas operations can not only have serious impacts on the environment, the economy affecting the commercial fishing sector, tourism, tourism and coastal industries, but also jeopardize the future of operations offshore oil and gas from across the EU. It is essential to prevent these accidents but also to mitigate their consequences. To that end, the modernization of the criminal, civil and financial liability regimes, as well as the compensation and financial guarantee systems, as proposed in this resolution, seems quite adequate. This will allow us to move towards greater responsibility not only to our environment but also to our economy.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations, which defines the elements of such a comprehensive EU-wide framework for preventing major accidents and limiting their consequences. The report deals with what kinds of damage are being paid, financial capacity of liable parties, disbursement of compensation and liability regimes.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The report of the Committee on Legal Affairs concerns liability, compensation and financial safeguards for traditional damage caused by offshore oil and gas operations. The conclusions state that the Commission should cooperate closely with Member States in order to ensure that Union compensation and financial safeguards schemes for offshore oil and gas operations (i) provide for third parties for offshore oil and gas to compensate for traditional damage caused by accidents within the scope of activities; (ii) establish an effective system of compensation to deal with the relevant payments; and (iii) to ensure that economic operators and other liable parties provide for appropriate financial means necessary to meet claims for damages. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur would like the Commission to work closely with the Member States to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. Clearly, the Commission wishes to extend the scope of its scope of competence in this matter even though France considers that it does not want such an extension. I am voting against this text.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over 90% of oil and 60% of gas produced in Europe comes from offshore operations with ongoing operations planned to take place in the territorial waters of 18 Member States. I have voted for this report that will bring together EU Member States and the Commission to work and ensure that compensation and financial security systems for offshore oil and gas operations in the EU are up to date, providing for compensation of third party claims amongst others.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file seeks to harmonise on rules for liability, compensation and financial security with a view to preventing further accidents with cross-border implications while making sure that those liable can be held financially and legally accountable to persons and states, particularly if they damage fishing, tourism or wildlife. It introduces the idea of a horizontal European framework for collective redress for sectors hardest hit by oil and gas spills such as fisheries and coastal tourist sectors. Although the idea of protecting both the environment by raising security standards and the idea of compensating inhabitants and workers of hard-hit areas is one I completely agree on, the usurpation of powers from Member States to the EU in this creates a subsidiarity issue. In spite of this, it also sought the harmonisation of national legislation and areas of competence for Member States, therefore I abstained.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because criminal liability at EU level can have an additional deterrent effect. This could increase compliance with safety measures.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The Commission should work closely with Member States and ensure that offshore oil and gas extraction processes compensatory systems and financial guarantees are kept up to date in the EU and offer offsetting third party claims for offshore oil and to the traditional losses resulting from gas extraction processes, an effective compensation system would be established for handling related payments and ensuring that operators and other responsible parties have sufficient financial resources to meet compensation requirements.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — First of all, civil and criminal liability must be established at EU level for damage caused by accidents resulting from offshore exploration, investigation and extraction of oil and gas. In addition, a balanced decision on compulsory financial security must be taken and a uniform and comprehensive compensatory mechanism applied. It is necessary to provide for compensation in accordance with claims made by third parties for traditional damage, as well as an effective compensation procedure for administering the payments concerned. Responsible parties must be obliged to pay, in an appropriate and timely manner, legally owed compensation, both for damage and damage to natural or legal persons and for damage caused to the environment. It is important to ensure that operators or other responsible parties have at their disposal sufficient financial resources to satisfy claims for compensation. In order to implement the measures envisaged, the Commission should cooperate more closely with the Member States and ensure that compensation and financial security schemes applicable to offshore oil and gas operations in the EU are developed and implemented as soon as possible.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report focuses on the importance of updating existing civil liability systems in the Member States to ensure the application of the polluter pays principle, not only for environmental but also for traditional damage (bodily damage/property damage and consequent damage financial losses). The incidents in European waters must not adversely affect the future of offshore oil and gas activities of this state or of the EU as a whole.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal by my colleagues because I believe that, for greater protection of the maritime environment, we need to update the liability schemes in force in the Member States, in such a way as to ensure that, upon the occurrence of an accident in the waters of those States, it does not affect the future of maritime operations in the hydrocarbon sector or on that of the whole EU, especially when those countries living on maritime tourism are damaged. In addition, it seems appropriate to promote a balanced solution regarding mandatory financial guarantee requirements because, on the one hand, it is necessary not to remove oil companies from activities at sea in the hydrocarbon sector, on the other hand, the effectiveness of the polluter pays principle must be preserved. I therefore voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Offshore Safety Directive was adopted with the aim of establishing minimum requirements for preventing major accidents in offshore oil and gas operations in the EU and to limit the consequences of such accidents. I voted in favour as the report calls on the Commission to consider the establishment of a legislative compensation mechanism for offshore accidents at least for sectors that may be severely affected. Such sectors include fisheries and coastal tourism and other sectors of the blue economy.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Today, authorisation activities take place or plan in the territorial waters of 18 Member States, with more than 90% of oil and 60% of the EU produced gas coming from authorisation facilities. I consider that the Commission needs to work closely with Member States and ensure that the compensation and financial guarantee systems for oil and gas exploitation in the EU are brought to a satisfactory level. I point out that it is important to update existing accountability systems in Member States to ensure that a possible accident in their territorial waters does not adversely affect the future of the authorised activities of those States or the future of the whole of the EU should an accident occur in an area whose revenues largely depend on tourism. I therefore urge the Commission to reconsider the need to introduce common EU standards on the system for submitting claims for compensation and elimination of damages. The number of approved facilities is likely to increase in the future, particularly in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, which is why it is urgently necessary to fully implement Directive 2013/30/EU and provide an appropriate legal framework for managing all authorised activities. I point out that in accordance with Article 191. The Union's environmental policy must be based on the principles of caution and preventive action.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur would like the Commission to work closely with the Member States to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. Clearly, the Commission wishes to extend the scope of its scope of competence in this matter even though France considers that it does not want such an extension. I am therefore voting against this text, which undermines the sovereignty of States.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — EU action in marine and coastal areas must be aimed at achieving a high degree of protection as authorised oil and gas activities take place in an increasingly extreme environment and can potentially have major and devastating consequences for the environment and economy of these areas - and even cross-border adverse impact. Fisheries and tourism, and other sectors that rely on good conditions in the common marine environment must be protected by taking preventive measures and devising effective practices. The adoption of the Authorisation Security Directive 2013/30/EU is an important step in this direction and I appeal to Member States that have not yet - to transpose the said and all previous directives into their national legislation as soon as possible. I would also like to point out that abuse or accidents associated with the activities of companies should be assessed quantitatively and qualitatively, while covering all secondary effects. A European framework based on the legislation of the most advanced Member States is needed to provide effective compensation mechanisms for affected victims and sectors. The Commission should assess whether a horizontal European framework for collective redress would be a possible solution to this. Compensation schemes, based on common standards, can enable cross-border claims to be dealt with effectively and within a reasonable time without discriminating against applicants from different countries of the European Economic Area.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We were against the adoption of the Offshore Safety Directive, the weakening of its requirements in the negotiating process and the absence of a moratorium on the exploitation of fossil resources in the Arctic. This resolution makes a number of criticisms of this and other existing Directives on the subject, which we are following, but nothing goes forward in relation to the moratorium, but merely suggests an environmental impact assessment. It calls for the immediate ratification of the Paris COP21 Agreements, ignoring their profound limitations. It advocates the communitarization of criminal law, which, either by the indication of political objectives and goals, or by the concrete imposition of legal regimes, procedural solutions or organization of the judicial structure, which in Portugal has provided incentive and coverage to national policies contrary to the interests of workers and the people and who contribute to the discharacterization of the democratic regime also at the judicial level. It lacks greater clarity in the search for international solutions with the UN mediation on this issue, seeking greater accountability on the multinationals for the damage caused, ideas that could be exposed more clearly.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — Offshore oil and gas research and production is increasingly taking place in extreme conditions and locations and can have major to devastating impacts on marine ecosystems, environment and economy of seaside areas. It's a very sensitive subject depending on the enormous power of the mining industry. So I was happy to support the report, which calls for the guarantee of the independence of the competent authorities in the Member States, and which calls on the Commission to establish uniform rules for determining responsibility, financial security and any compensation. So far, these rules differ quite fundamentally from Member States, and I think it is necessary to establish a single European framework based on the models of the most advanced countries. Harmonised should then, of course, be the definition of offences and penalties in breaches of offshore safety rules.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. “The report calls in large part for increased liability related to offshore oil and gas deposits. It calls for an EU accountability framework in this area, seeking harmonisation of minimum liability for civil damage and recommending a common mechanism at EU level to deal with incidents (another agency). The Commission is also invited to consider the establishment of a legal compensation mechanism and it is proposed to extend its scope to secondary injury (paragraph 3). It also applies to the Commission to add major breakdowns in the oil extraction sector to the Environmental Crimes Directive, regretting that the definitions of offences in this regard have not been harmonised. Equally importantly, it calls on the Commission to consider proposals to establish a fund created from fees paid by the offshore mining sector. Nevertheless, amendments on minimum interference in national policy were ignored.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report, which deals with liability, compensation and financial guarantees for offshore oil and gas operations. The directive laying down minimum requirements for preventing serious accidents during offshore oil and gas operations does not address these issues. It is essential to establish a harmonised Union-wide liability and compensation regime, which both protects the sectors affected by these accidents but also to ensure that operators or any other responsible party have the finances necessary to deal with claims for compensation.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on compensation for offshore oil and gas operations. This report is trying to harmonise the civil claims process for offshore accidents, however the  report does not even consider the fact that the international framework for each Member State differs and it cannot be harmonised on matters of this issue.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on liability, compensation and financial security in oil and gas operations on the high seas, which clarifies the DSB as regards the types of damage to be compensated, the liability regimes of each party and the necessary financial capacity to deal with such compensation, if they are liable. This is intended to harmonise and update Member States' liability systems, ensuring the polluter pays principle. This would prevent a potential accident in European waters from adversely affecting future oil and gas operations both within the Member State and within the Union as a whole.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 1 December 2016 on liability, compensation and financial guarantees for offshore oil and gas operations. In this regard, I welcome the adoption of several directives on, inter alia, the safety of offshore oil and gas operations and environmental liability. In addition, this resolution is important because it further clarifies environmental or civil liability in the event of an incident, as well as compensation and financial guarantees resulting from accidents related to offshore oil and gas operations.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The issue of liability for accidents involving the extraction of hydrocarbons at sea is quite complex and, in my opinion, not sufficiently regulated. I therefore welcome this initiative to broaden the existing legal framework while making it clearer.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report is based on Directive 2013/30/EU on the safety of offshore operations, complemented by the Environmental Liability and Environmental Impact Assessment Directives. It advocates the establishment of minimum requirements for the prevention of major accidents in offshore oil and gas operations in the EU and the mitigation of their consequences. Indeed, Member States are failing to update their national legislative frameworks for oil and gas operations in order to be able to harmonise them in accordance with the so-called 'Offshore Safety Directive'. That is why it is extremely important to establish the basic elements of an overall EU framework. I agree with the rapporteur's proposals regarding the need for the Directive to include a chapter on liability for civil damage to natural and legal persons, as well as a chapter on criminal liability for offshore accidents. Also in terms of mandatory financial collateral requirements, a balanced solution must be reached, which does not compromise the effectiveness of the polluter pays principle. Because there is a need to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee schemes for offshore operations as proposed, I voted in favour of this.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, because I consider it essential to introduce new regulation to minimize the damage of a possible accident in offshore oil and gas operations: even more so when the Union is driving its development without taking into account its risks and impact. I share the need to establish a compensation mechanism to protect potentially affected sectors such as fishing and tourism; to facilitate victims to have recourse to justice and to ensure, through specific contributions, that the offshore industry really pays, and I call on the Commission to act in accordance with the Parliament's request. For these reasons, my vote was favourable.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to keep the report as adopted in committee. The report focuses on the importance of updating existing liability systems in the Member States to ensure the application of the polluter-pays principle not only to environmental but also to traditional damages (bodily injuries/property damages/pure and consequential economic losses).

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although there has been no major accident in the EU since 1988, accidents caused by offshore oil platforms have an increasingly serious impact on natural or legal persons, whether they are injury, property damage or economic loss. As offshore oil and gas operations take place in increasingly extreme environments and potentially have serious and devastating implications for the environment and the economy in marine and coastal areas, I agree that EU and Member State level should be set stricter rules on civil liability in accidents at sea. I supported the current resolution because I believe it is important to have effective and adequate reimbursement mechanisms and rapid and adequate mechanisms for handling claims for humans, animals and the environment as victims of damage caused by offshore exploration and oil and natural extraction operations offshore gas, as well as sufficient resources to restore major ecosystems. I regret that many Member States are still not implementing the relevant provisions of the Maritime Safety Directive; therefore, I expect the Commission to ensure that it is closely monitored and implemented in the next period.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — In order to establish minimum requirements for prevention and to limit the consequences of major accidents in offshore oil and gas operations, the European Union adopted a Sea-Safety Directive in response to a severe explosion at the Deepwater Horizon platform. The Parliament report calls for the full implementation and enforcement of this Directive and stresses the need to establish an appropriate legal framework for regulating all maritime activities before the next serious accident occurs at sea. I supported the report in the vote as it highlights two very important aspects. First, the report expresses concern that the Sea-Safety Directive identifies an accident as' major 'only if there are fatalities or serious physical injuries, but does not include any serious environmental consequences when, for example, an accident affects protected areas or protected species. Secondly, the report correctly underlines that the effective application of the polluter pays principle to offshore oil and gas operations, in accordance with the principle of sustainable development, should cover not only the costs of repairing environmental damage but also the settlement of claims. In addition, the report also highlights that strict rules on liability in offshore accidents should be introduced to make it easier for victims to access justice.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the Deepwater Horizon incident in 2010, which was a downright tragedy for the environment, the European Parliament rightly proposes that operators of offshore gas and oil operations be held liable for preventing and repairing the environmental damage that would be arise due to their activities. In addition, they must ensure that they have sufficient financial resources to compensate for the damage. I am voting in favour of the report because it indicates that it is high time to transpose these recommendations into legislation and to implement them effectively. This is a wake-up call! Recognition that an accident as a result of such activities can have serious consequences both for humans and for the environment and the process of making it easier for citizens to claim damages are some of the important green points included in the report. We also emphasise the 'polluter pays' principle. A fund, sponsored and funded by the offshore industry, is absolutely necessary, which can intervene if an operator is financially incapable of bearing and compensating for the harmful effects on people and the planet in the event of an accident caused by offshore activities.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - Depository exploration and offshore oil and gas extraction are increasingly shifting to more extreme conditions, depth or distance from the coast due to technological possibilities. Accidents on such facilities can have serious consequences for the environment, but also for tourism, for example. A European legal framework must therefore be ensured that ensures an effective compensation mechanism for affected entities.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: ‒ The N-VA delegation abstained from voting on this report on liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas activities. Although the protection of the environment and public health are absolute top priorities for N-VA, the report unfortunately opts for a wrong approach. It contains numerous calls for harmonisation both in the field of civil and criminal liability. It not only ignores the competences of the Member States, but also ignores existing regulations — European and national. The latter already ensures a very high level of protection. Moreover, existing legislation should also be given time to prove its effectiveness before being replaced by new proposals. To this end, we would like to point out, for example, the Offshore Safety Directive for which the transposition deadline expired only mid-2015. However, a vote against N-VA was not discussed. An abstention is therefore its signal that environmental interests are taking a central place in European and national policies.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on liability, damages and insurance for offshore oil and gas operations. With this report, the European Parliament is deeply involved in national affairs. Member States shall have the right to determine the conditions for the use of their energy resources themselves. Nevertheless, the resolution affects this national law on several points. The resolution also regrets that civil liability is regulated in a very different way in the Member States. On the contrary, this is not unfortunate, but to be welcomed.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The report is based on the principle of preventive action and sustainability and the principle of “pollutant pays”. The Commission is called on to reconsider the need to introduce common EU standards on the system for submitting claims for compensation and elimination of damages. The introduction of criminal liability at EU level could enhance the effect of deterrence beyond the limits of civil sanctions, which could improve environmental protection and compliance with security measures. The Commission and the Member States are encouraged to consider the establishment of a legislative damage compensation mechanism for coastal accidents for sectors that could suffer severe consequences, such as fisheries and coastal tourism and other sectors of the blue economy. I accept this Report because it is necessary to build an effective system of charging for damage caused by oil and gas plants in the coastal area. This would encourage companies to make more investments in occupational safety and accelerate compensation payments to the most affected sectors in the event of an accident.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on liability, compensation and financial guarantee for offshore oil and gas operations. I support a report urging Member States which have not yet transposed environmental responsibility directives and environmental impact assessment to do so without delay while ensuring the independence of the competent authorities and the Commission should assess whether it is appropriate to introduce additional harmonised rules on responsibility, compensation and financial security. This is the only way to prevent any further accidents with cross-border consequences.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The Directive does not regulate civil liability for damage to its full extent, whether it concerns natural or legal persons, whether it is personal injury, property damage or financial loss, net or consequential. Furthermore, criminal liability for offshore accidents, possible fines or other non-custodial penalties are not regulated.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. - Following the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil drilling platform on 20 April 2010 and oil pollution, the Directive on the safety of offshore oil and gas operations was adopted, with the aim of setting minimum requirements for EU offshore oil and to prevent major accidents involving gas operations and to limit the consequences of such accidents. Since the deadline for harmonisation has long expired, the foundations for the EU-wide regulatory framework should already be available. Member States' liability systems are different, and most civil damages claims resulting from accidents involving extensive pollution can be enforced in different procedures from one Member State to another. With a few exceptions (France, the Netherlands, Denmark), the current liability rules cover only damages that are considered to be ships and, in the event of a direct causation, they are capable of enforcing foregone profits. However, there is no such convention on compensation for damage arising from offshore oil and gas operations and in all likelihood those conventions would not cover such accidents, since offshore oil and gas installations are unlikely to be within the meaning of the Convention would be considered a “ship”. The Commission should work closely with Member States to ensure that Union compensation and financial safeguards systems for offshore oil and gas operations are modernised. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Offshore oil and gas activities have several negative effects. Although there is a chance of obvious disasters, these extraction forms and products also cause permanent damage, which can only be remedied by joint action. Of course, the Member States also have a responsibility in this. Among the recurrent problems, we can mention the emissions of harmful substances from the combustion of the finished product or the environmental impact of disposable plastic devices. I supported the report, which states that activities that harm the environment and human life must be punished by serious sanctions, the precautionary principle should be applied and remediation should be linked to collective redress. A directive on fossil marine production was already adopted in 2013, but unfortunately many countries are delaying their transposition by Member States. One of the most important means of preventing damage is the 'polluter pays principle', which has already been introduced by European legislation in other areas. With regard to Hungary, this approach was marked, for example, in the European Parliament resolution on the occasion of the 5 year anniversary of the red sludge disaster. We need a transparent and rapid compensation process and a rigorous monitoring system. Gradually, but as quickly as possible, the use of fossil and nuclear energy must be abolished.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the explosion and spill of oil from the Deepwater Horizon platform, a directive on the safety of offshore oil and gas activities has been adopted. It aims to establish minimum requirements for the prevention of serious failures within such activities and to reduce the effects of such failures. The Directive stipulates that concessionaries have absolute responsibility for the prevention of environmental damage caused by their activities and for the removal of such damage. However, the directive does not regulate civil liability for damages caused to natural or legal persons. Nor does it establish criminal liability for failures in marine areas. Accordingly, the European Commission should work more closely with Member States to ensure that compensation and financial safeguards schemes for offshore oil and gas activities in the EU enable rapid and proper handling of claims for damages. It is equally important to provide a legal framework for actions to repair environmental damage from offshore failures, in accordance with the “polluter pays” principle.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - It is known that offshore oil and gas activities for prospecting, exploration and production require a high level of protection due to the major impact on all concerned and, in particular, on the environment. EU measures in this area must necessarily be based on precautionary, prevention and sustainability principles and harmonised at international level. Obviously, the polluter pays for social and economic damage, because incidents in the oil and gas sector in the EU have serious and sustainable, direct and indirect repercussions not only on the environment but also on different sectors of activity, especially the 'blue economy' sectors (coastal tourism, fishing, etc.) and the community. As such, it becomes indispensable to implement a legislative mechanism, based on the assessment of the transposition and application of the DRM and the DSO, necessary not only adequate and effective compensation/compensation, but also to remedy traditional damage, applicable throughout the EU, for all categories of damage to the environment, persons (natural and legal), the community, the economy, society in general. Under that mechanism, Member States should include the guarantee of the existence and/or support, facilitation of adequate financial means (including financial collateral instruments) at the level of relevant operators or responsible persons necessary to cover damages; and rebuilding ecosystems.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The scope of this report is to underline the importance of updating existing liability systems in the European Union, such as the Offshore Safety Directive, to ensure the application of the polluter-pays principle not only to environmental but also to traditional damages (bodily injuries/property damage/pure and consequential economic losses). It is crucial to have effective and adequate compensation mechanisms and claims handling mechanisms for such damage, especially in areas largely dependent on tourism for revenue. Such damage would limit the arrival of tourists and reduce the total revenue in those particular areas of the European Union. Therefore, there is an urgent need for compensation and financial security systems to be brought to speed and to make up for the lost money. As an advocate of the tourism industry in the European Parliament, I support this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: The effectiveness of national liability regimes for traditional damage resulting from pollution caused by offshore oil and gas operations, claims processing regimes, availability of financial guarantee instruments and requirements for financial guarantees are closely maintained related. Compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union must be modernised, in particular to፦ provide for compensation to third parties who have suffered traditional damage resulting from accidents in the context of offshore oil and gas operations; - establish a system of effective compensation for the processing of related payments; - ensuring that operators or any other responsible party have the necessary finances to deal with claims for compensation.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ At a time when Member States lay down the conditions for the exploitation of energy resources in the hydrocarbon sector, it is important to remember the toll of many workers, who over the years have lost their lives. Considering that domestic oil and gas sources can contribute significantly to the existing energy needs in Europe, it should be borne in mind that offshore oil and gas operations are are verifying in increasingly extreme environments and could have important consequences for the environment and devastating for the economy of the sea and coastal areas. Despite oil and gas production in the North Sea being in decline in recent years, the number of offshore plants is set to increase, particularly in the Mediterranean and Black Sea. To prevent accidents caused by offshore oil and gas platforms from bringing harmful cross-border consequences with them, EU action must be aimed at prevention and prevention mitigation of the consequences of such incidents, in the maximum interest of the worker. The Union's environmental policy must also be based on the precautionary principle.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on Liability, Compensation and Financial Guarantee for Authorised Oil and Gas Activities. I consider it of great importance to update existing liability systems in all Member States of the European Union in order to ensure that possible accidents within the 12 nautical miles of Member States do not adversely affect the oil and gas activities of the whole European Union. Especially if the accident occurred in a Member State whose revenues depend on tourism. I also consider that it is correct to urge the European Commission to consider the need to introduce common Union standards in the form of a system for submitting claims for compensation and elimination of damages. I support the initiative to include victims of collateral damage associated with the operation of approved facilities and persons who meet the general requirements for obtaining compensation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — This report, on its own initiative, primarily seeks to expand the responsibilities of offshore operations related to oil and gas. In particular, the adoption of the Union Liability Framework in that segment is sought, seeking harmonisation of rules concerning minimum liability for damages resulting in the civil sector, and recommendations for common mechanisms in relation to potential incidents. Many amendments that called for more reasonable, namely minimal interference by the Commission in national policy in that segment, were ignored or rejected. So I voted against.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on liability, compensation and financial guarantee for offshore oil and gas operations. Offshore oil and gas operations are being carried out farther from land and often in much deeper water than before. Some activities take place in very relentless environments, such as the Arctic. In April 2010, an explosion occurred on the Deep Water rig and caused a spill. After that, it was clear that minimum requirements needed to prevent major accidents in offshore oil and gas operations in the EU and to limit the consequences of such accidents (the offshore safety directive was adopted after the accident). It is necessary to modernize the applicable accountability systems in Member States to ensure that incidents in Member States' waters do not adversely affect offshore oil and gas activity. The Commission needs to work closely with Member States to ensure that the system of compensation and financial guarantees for offshore oil and gas operations in the EU is updated, more specifically, to allow third party compensation claims for traditional damage resulting from oil and gas activities at sea. Therefore, it is also necessary to establish an effective compensation system.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report asks the Commission to assess the desirability of introducing new harmonised rules on liability, compensation and financial security in order to avoid new accidents with cross-border effects and consider the establishment of a legislative mechanism for compensation for maritime accidents. In addition, it calls for the establishment of countervailing regimes capable of effectively and expeditiously addressing transboundary claims and covering both primary and secondary damage caused in all affected areas. Member States are urged to develop traditional financial guarantee instruments, relating to damages, resulting from incidents involving general oil and gas activities on the high seas or the maritime transport of hydrocarbons and gas, including in the event of insolvency. I voted in favour, because I understand that strict rules on civil liability should be established for such accidents, in order to facilitate access to justice for victims.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur would like the Commission to work closely with the Member States to modernise the compensation and financial guarantee systems for offshore oil and gas operations within the Union. Clearly, the Commission wishes to extend the scope of its scope of competence in this matter even though France considers that it does not want such an extension. I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The current state of law does not require major changes. The Security Directive is positively received by the public, so it should not be amended to a greater extent. Unfortunately, the proposed legislation goes a lot further than initially supposed. In the long term, these provisions can be viewed negatively, which is why I voted against the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — Offshore oil and gas activities are moving farther from land and often in much deeper waters than in the past. Some activities are carried out in extremely difficult conditions, such as the Arctic, or in places where most of their revenue depends on tourism, such as the Mediterranean or the Aegean Sea. I supported the document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report asks the Commission to assess the desirability of introducing new harmonised rules on liability, compensation and financial security in order to avoid new accidents with cross-border effects and consider the establishment of a legislative mechanism for compensation for maritime accidents. In addition, it calls for the establishment of countervailing regimes capable of effectively and expeditiously addressing transboundary claims and covering both primary and secondary damage caused in all affected areas. Member States are urged to develop traditional financial guarantee instruments, relating to damages, resulting from incidents involving general oil and gas activities on the high seas or the maritime transport of hydrocarbons and gas, including in the event of insolvency. I voted in favour, because I understand that strict rules on civil liability should be established for such accidents, in order to facilitate access to justice for victims.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted on the report on liability, compensation and financial security for offshore oil and gas operations. Offshore oil and gas operations are being carried out further from land and often in much deeper waters than has previously been the case. Some operations are taking place in harsh environments and in locations that depend on tourism for a large part of their income. Following the explosion and oil spill from Deepwater Horizon on 20 April 2010, the Offshore Safety Directive was adopted with the aim of establishing minimum requirements for preventing major accidents in offshore oil and gas operations in the EU and to limit the consequences of such accidents. Member States had until 19 July to update their national legislative frameworks for offshore oil and gas operations to be in line with the Offshore Safety Directive. I voted in favour because I believe that it is of utmost importance to update the existing liability systems in the Member States to ensure that if an incident occurs in the waters of these states, it would not adversely affect the future of offshore oil and gas operations nor that of the entire EU.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, because I consider it essential to introduce new regulation to minimize the damage of a possible accident in offshore oil and gas operations: even more so when the Union is driving its development without taking into account its risks and impact. I share the need to establish a compensation mechanism to protect potentially affected sectors such as fishing and tourism; to facilitate victims to have recourse to justice and to ensure, through specific contributions, that the offshore industry really pays, and I call on the Commission to act in accordance with the Parliament's request. For these reasons, my vote was favourable.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report starts from a problem which is the increase in offshore gas and oil exploration on the high seas, mainly in the North Sea, but also in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean Sea. 90% of the oil produced in Europe and 60% of gas come from offshore production. 73% of Europe's oil comes from the North. The increase in farms due to energy needs could lead to accidents whose damage to people, the economy and the environment must be prevented and repaired. This is despite the fact that there has been no major accident since 1988 in Scotland. However, there have been thousands of smaller accidents with damage. It is in the sense of seeking a uniform regime in this area that this report comes up.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur deals with strict liability for environmental damage resulting from offshore activities. More than 90% of the oil produced in Europe and 60% of the extracted natural gas comes from offshore activities. In this respect, the Offshore Safety Directive was adopted in 2014, which allows licensees to be liable without fault for the prevention and remediation of all environmental damage resulting from their activities. However, the rapporteur is now calling for the directive to be revised or to list the shortcomings of the existing directive. For example, the Directive does not deal with civil liability for claims of third parties (personal injury and property damage, purely economic losses). In addition, the existing Directive does not adequately regulate criminal liability (lack of definitions of offences, no minimum sanctions for infringements of offshore safety rules). The rapporteur therefore calls for comprehensive harmonisation in the field of offshore activities, as is already the case in the directive on the protection of the environment through criminal law. In addition, the rapporteur considers that a balanced solution to the requirements for compulsory security needs needs to be found in order not to undermine the effectiveness of the polluter pays principle. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Resolution on accountability, reimbursement and financial security of offshore oil and gas operations is strongly committed to strengthening accountability in these activities. It calls for the creation of a European legal framework for liability, civil liability rules and also proposes a common European mechanism for dealing with incidents. Although there has been no major accident in the European Union since 1988, there have been thousands of minor accidents, which also leave environmental damage. It is also necessary to count on the fact that oil and gas extraction will gradually move to the Mediterranean and Black Sea areas. That is why I think that we need to talk about liability, compensation and mechanisms for recovering compensation. It is necessary to establish a legal framework before a real accident occurs, and there is no need to rely on anything serious going to happen in the future either. To this extent, I supported the report. On the other hand, however, it also contained a number of elements that I could not support, for example, a number of calls for harmonisation, which is why I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Chrysogonos report because I agree with the proposals put forward on liability, compensation and financial guarantee for oil and gas operations at sea. I would stress the importance of updating the existing liability systems in the Member States to ensure that the polluter pays principle is applied not only with regard to environmental damage but also to cover the costs of traditional claims, such as personal injury and property damage. I would remind you that I tabled in the Committee on the Environment a number of proposals to amend the report, namely urging the European Commission to rely on the principles of precautionary action and preventive action in this area, which often have a cross-border impact.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the rapporteur's proposal and believe that it is necessary to ensure that the compensation system works in the best possible way so that all injured parties can be provided with a financial guarantee for offshore oil and gas activities in the event of damage. It is necessary to raise the current accountability systems in Member States to a higher level in order to ensure that some future damages leave as little consequences as possible, for example tourism, which is a very important economic branch of the European Union, but also on the future of oil and gas activities. Establishing a clearer solution of liability and setting up an appropriate financial guarantee in the form of assets so that the injured parties can be replenished from those assets would create significantly greater certainty to meet claims for compensation for the damage suffered.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on liability, compensation and financial guarantee for offshore oil and gas operations. According to various studies, thousands of accidents have occurred in the oil and gas sector in the European Union, which have severe lasting consequences for the marine environment. I therefore consider it important that effective and appropriate compensation mechanisms and appropriate mechanisms for the rapid handling of claims are available in the event of damage caused by oil and gas activities to humans, animals and the environment. However, the compulsory financial guarantee mechanisms for payment of compensation in the event of accidents must not at the same time create a disproportionate financial burden on companies in the gas and oil industry and thus put them in a non-competitive position.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This resolution analyses the situation of increasing instability in the DRC, regretting that the government and the independent national electoral commission have failed to organise presidential elections within the terms set by the Constitution. The EU is urged to take more concrete action and immediately initiate the procedure under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement and to adopt targeted sanctions, which include a ban on issuing a visa and the asset freeze against high-level officials and armed forces agents responsible for the violent crackdown on protesters and political standoff, which prevents a passage of powers peaceful and conforming to the Constitution. Finally, it calls for a full, thorough and transparent investigation into alleged human rights violations that occurred during the protests, in order to identify those responsible and ensure that they respond of their actions. I voted for it.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths, in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a real political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this resolution. There were some very good aspects in the report on the protection and promotion of human rights, improving the legitimacy of elections, and improving the humanitarian situation in the DRC. However the resolution also included calls endorsing and promoting the Cotonou Agreement. The Cotonou Agreement includes the promotion of Economic Partnership Agreements between the EU and African, Caribbean and Pacific states. It forces the ACP countries to open their economies to the EU without receiving new benefits in return, to the detriment of the majority of the population.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This matter was not the subject of a roll-call vote. In the interests of transparency and democracy I would therefore like to confirm that I abstained on the final text. Whilst the report had much to commend it with regard to the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo, it also promoted an EU foreign policy and I could not therefore vote in favour.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The DRC is a country that has one of the biggest potentials in Africa, it has potential for a strong economy and it has the potential for nurturing democracy. But the country has been torn apart by conflict throughout the years, many ethnic minorities, homosexuals, and women are being mistreated and even persecuted. The current President Joseph Kabila’s term in office is coming to an end and this can mark a turning point in the DCR’s future. The European Union is encouraging Joseph Kabila to step down as President at the end of his second term and ensure a peaceful transition of power to the next presidency. This whole process has to take place in line with Congo’s constitution. Kabila has been in power ever since in 2001 his father was assassinated, he then was elected President in 2006 and is now reaching the end of his second term in office. If the DRC wants to prove that it is embracing democracy and that it is ready to become a full and valuable partner to Europe, it has to ensure a peaceful transition of power, but this lies in the hands of a single person – Kabila.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The European Parliament is deeply concerned that instability is increasing in the Democratic Republic of Congo due to the tense pre-election situation. The increasing violence and the increasing violations of human rights and international law, in particular targeted actions and arbitrary arrests, have a negative impact on efforts to regulate and stabilise the situation in the DRC. In this context, I agree with the European Parliament's call for the EU delegation to continue to closely monitor developments in the DRC and take all appropriate steps and measures to support human rights defenders and democratic movements.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. - Re-attempted interference in a complex regional context and already weakened by many other external interference. I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the EU to work to end the violation of human rights and international law in the DRC. Indeed, the number of victims as a result of political tensions, violence and arbitrary arrests in the country is steadily increasing, while humanitarian agencies estimate that more than 5 million people need food aid. In view of the current deterioration of the situation, the report calls for the EU to adopt sanctions under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement following non-compliance with the country's commitment to respect the principles of democracy and to organise elections in order to elect a successor to the current president. Secondly, the resolution calls on the Union to cooperate with the African Union to help citizens and stop the spread of violence. Finally, it called on all political actors to take part in a peaceful and constructive dialogue to bring stability to the country's situation.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ The Democratic Republic of the Congo is facing a particularly delicate moment. Attempts at the preservation of power by President Joseph Kabila have generated rising political tensions, unrest and violence across the country, causing an electoral deadlock. Since January 2015 repressive action by security services agents has affected activists, peacekeepers and opposition and civil society figures who opposed the many attempts put in place to allow the president to retain power beyond the constitutional limit of two terms. The joint motion for a resolution, which I supported today, expresses deep concern at the situation of increasing instability in the DRC and calls for elections to be held promptly and in a manner regular, in full compliance with the Constitution of the African Charter on Democracy. The Union must take concrete actions to facilitate dialogue and immediately initiate the procedure laid down in Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, providing for targeted sanctions against senior officials level and agents of the armed forces who have been stained with violence and violations of human rights.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted abstention in this resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, despite agreeing with certain elements of the resolution, such as its concern about the human rights situation and the growing deterioration in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, I believe that we need to address the responsibility of the Union in the crisis. In addition, I believe that the resolution will ingest significantly in the country's coming electoral process.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in which it regrets the loss of human life and expresses its solidarity with the families of the victims and the DRC people. The situation is very worrying and increasingly volatile in a pre-electoral context. The president of the country has a responsibility to protect citizens, and in particular, from abuse and crime. He has to exercise government duties strictly in compliance with the rule of law.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I opposed this joint resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, because it shows total diplomatic irresponsibility, but above all a great hypocrisy tinged with Alzheimer's. Not content with taking the risk of further destabilizing a country in an already fragile situation, MEPs are trying to forget that the Kabila regime was established thanks to the support of the Western powers. Moreover, in this resolution there is no mention of the disruptive role of Rwanda, east of the DRC, which tries to seize the mineral wealth with the guilty complicity of our dear powerful Europeans, who, for the occasion, forget their right mantras of the hommists. Finally, diplomacy was one of the regalian powers of sovereign States and must remain so, with the principle of non-interference and the right of peoples to self-determination.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — In the voting resolution there are passages which I believe are unclear and which prompted me to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a genuine political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its Member States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
