The European Parliament regrets the failure of the Government and the Independent National Electoral Commission (NNRK) to hold presidential elections within the deadline set by the Constitution. It therefore reiterates its call for successful and timely elections to be held in full compliance with the Congolese Constitution and the African Charter for Democracy, Election and Governance, and insists on the responsibility of the Congolese Government to ensure transparent, credible and inclusive elections as soon as possible favorable environment. Parliament also calls on all political actors to engage in peaceful and constructive dialogue in order to prevent the current political crisis from deepening, and urges to refrain from further violence and provocations. It welcomes the efforts of the Congolese National Conference of Bishops (CENCO) to develop a broader consensus on a political transition. Parliament calls on the authorities and the opposition to refrain from any action or statements that could further contribute to the spread of unrest and at the same time recognises the need for a transitional period during which presidential duties can only be exercised under the supervision of a transitional council in which the opposition will play an important role. Parliament also calls on the EU and its Member States to continue helping the Congolese population to improve the living conditions of the most vulnerable groups and to address the problems of resettlement, food security and the consequences of natural disasters.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the troubling situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where President Joseph Kabila clings to the presidential term and is delaying the derision of elections. Likewise, in the past two years, President Kabila has tried to delay elections by administrative and technical means, thus remaining in power after his expiration, with a restricted mandate constitution, which could turn into a dictatorship. His attempts to amend the Democratic Republic of Congo's constitution, thereby allowing him to compete for a third term, failed precisely in 2015 because of strong opposition and mobilization of civil society, clearly indicating disapproval of such changes.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the Democratic Republic of the Congo there is a risk of a new genocide. The people of the province of Beni, in eastern Congo, are victims of massacres and serious persecution on which there is still a hood of silence that we Europeans have the duty, political and moral, to raise . We call for the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, to launch an international inquiry into these massacres involving the United Nations and the International Criminal Court; for the EU to send a special representative to the Kivu area to draw up an urgent report to be submitted to the European Parliament and the highest European institutions; to France and the United Kingdom to activate itself in the UN Security Council to pass a binding resolution to halt these massacres as soon as possible. Over two thousand families have been killed and at least as many have lost track: the international community, present with the UN mission Monusco, cannot assist inert. If we do not intervene the region will be destabilized with new innocent victims and new waves of migrants fleeing to more affluent and secure countries.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — The situation of political instability in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is becoming alarming. President Joseph Kabila's second term expires on December 20, 2016. The Constitution of the Democratic Republic of the Congo limits the number of presidential terms to two. President Kabila does not want to leave power and uses all means to delay his departure. For example, he did not call elections. This uncertainty about the political future of the country leads to demonstrations and acts of violence. These disorders have resulted in many casualties. This situation must cease. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, given the difficult situation of political instability and social insecurity, which the country lives, it is absolutely necessary for Europe and the international community to activate all the processes necessary to promote the national pacification of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is necessary to favour a democratic political system that allows alternation to power, while respecting the constitutional dictate. This represents the basic and essential condition for pulling the country out of the difficult and dangerous situation in which it finds itself and avert further suffering from the civilian population.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution. There were some very good aspects in the report on the protection and promotion of human rights, improving the legitimacy of elections, and improving the humanitarian situation in the DRC. However the resolution also included calls endorsing and promoting the Cotonou Agreement. The Cotonou Agreement includes the promotion of Economic Partnership Agreements between the EU and African, Caribbean and Pacific states. It forces the ACP countries to open their economies to the EU without receiving new benefits in return, to the detriment of the majority of the population.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this oral question denouncing the serious situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. As the EU we must get to take incisive action and apply strong and individual sanctions against the government responsible for the atrocities carried out in Congo and above all we need to bring this back. country in free elections.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The report, for which I thought I was expressing a favourable opinion, expresses concern at the situation of increasing instability in the Democratic Republic of Congo in the context pre- electoral. In particular, I regret the loss of life that occurred during the demonstrations of recent weeks. In this regard, it seems necessary for international organisations to launch a full, thorough and transparent investigation into the many documented intimidations to the detriment of rights defenders human, political opponents and journalists. In the light of this escalation of violence I think it is appropriate for the European Union to adopt concrete sanctions such as a ban on the issuing of a visa and the freezing of assets against senior officials and summits military responsible for violent crackdowns against protesters. I also consider it worrying that the current government has failed to organise a presidential election within the time limits laid down in the Congolese Constitution and I hope that the electoral consultation will be able to take place quickly in a regular and peaceful context.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo promotes a series of actions on the part of the European Union to put pressure on the leadership of that State. Although I do not agree with many of the motions in the resolution, I believe that Europe should react to address imbalances that work to the detriment of citizens. I have therefore decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly endorse the resolution in the light of the serious human rights violations taking place in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, in the face of which it would be vile to remain inert. The situation is all the more magmatic since Joseph Kabila, President since 2001, would have no intention of ending his presidential status, despite the Congolese constitution providing for a maximum of two presidential terms. Therefore, it has repeatedly adopted administrative and technical tools to delay the elections planned for the end of 2016 as emerged from the signing, on 18 October last, with oppositions to postpone the elections presidential to 2018. A gesture of such calibre sparked a wave of outrage and dismay across the country by translating into demonstrations that led to a violent crackdown by authorities. In addition to expressing all my condolences for the fifty victims produced by the clashes between protesters and police, I intend to externalize the concern about the instability that is bringing the population, already exerted by repeated crises, under conditions of deeper poverty.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because it provides for sanctioning measures against those responsible for violent repression in the Congo. I also share the attempt at political dialogue to resolve problems through African Union mediation and CENCO's efforts to broaden the consensus around a political transition. Measures to support the security of the country must also not cease and the EU's capacity for mediation locally needs to be increased.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion provides for the constitution of a new census and electoral register by July 2017 and the creation of a ‘Comité de suivi’ in charge of monitoring the electoral process and reporting on its effective implementation on a monthly basis.  I agree to this towards ensuring the peaceful, transparent and timely conduct of the presidential and legislative elections to consolidate the progress that has been made in the DRC over more than a decade.  We need to advocate and assist towards a peaceful and constructive dialogue, to prevent any deepening of the current political crisis and to refrain from further violence and provocations. I also agree to a transparent investigation into the alleged human rights violations that took place during the protests to identify those responsible and hold them accountable.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The situation of increasing instability in the DRC, in a pre-election context characterised by tensions, can only cause deep concern. I recall that the DRC has committed itself under the Cotonou Agreement to respect democracy, the rule of law and human rights principles, which include freedom of expression and means of communication, good governance and transparency in political positions. To date, the dialogue established with the DRC authorities, in accordance with Article 8 of the Cotonou Agreement, with the aim of obtaining definitive clarification on the electoral process, is not going well end. Therefore, I believe it is important for the European Union to engage in a peaceful and constructive dialogue with all political actors in order to prevent the current political crisis and violence from escalating.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a resolution to initiate action to stop the undemocratic actions of the authorities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The continual drive to maintain power through the use of illegal practices leads to the challenge of fundamental democratic values. The authorities are moving to undermine the constitution unjustifiably in order to ensure their own power in another term. These actions adopt characteristics peculiar to the practices of authorities in totalitarian states, where opposition rights are destroyed and any opposition to the ruling is aggressively suppressed. I believe that such governments should be strongly protested and the respect of electoral rights as well as the rights of the opposition should be guaranteed.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The delays in the organisation of the next presidential and legislative elections in the Democratic Republic of Congo constitutes a severe violation of the Congolese Constitution. This is why I am in favour of this resolution as the EU needs to assist the people of Congo by communicating clearly and unambiguously that it would consider President Kabila staying in power beyond 2016 to be a severe violation and a threat to relations between the EU and DRC.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This resolution of the European Parliament deals with the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has been experiencing a deep political crisis since Joseph Kabila's re-election in 2011. This crisis was compounded by the inability to hold new presidential elections in a timely manner, that is, before the expiry of President Kabila's second term on 19 December 2016. This European Parliament resolution denounces this situation. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. Whilst we remain concerned at the potential further erosion of the security situation in DRC we cannot support the development of EU foreign policy or the potential use of foreign policy tools. We remain fully supportive of regional and international efforts to resolve the political situation in DRC.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In recent months, we have witnessed a worsening situation with regard to freedom of expression and human rights. Concrete sanctions must be imposed on those responsible for the violence. The European Union must open dialogue on the ground by cooperating with the African Union. In order to prevent the current political crisis from deteriorating even further, I also call for a democratic and peaceful transition to restore stability in the country.

name: Mireille D’Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This is the European Parliament's reaction to the current situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo marked by the completion of President Kabila's second term. It was following the assassination of his father, Laurent-Désiré Kabila, that President Kabila came to power. Despite the undemocratic nature of the regime, several elements are not addressed in this report, which evade Rwanda's interference in the internal affairs of the DRC.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, as what is happening in the country is very worrying. More recently, in October, authorities in Congo disclosed that, due to inaccuracies on election lists, presidential elections scheduled for December 19, 2016, were postponed until December 2018. The incumbent, Josef Kabila, took over in 2001 after his father's assassination and was re-elected twice - in 2006 and 2011. After the president's attempt to change the constitution so he can run for a third term, he is being deterred by parliament and unrest begins in the country. The authorities' decision to postpone the elections is said to be the work of President Kabila, who still wants to change the constitution and drive a third term.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting against because we do not accept the Union's interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. Especially in the case of Congo, with Western companies reaping millions from the really unacceptable situation there, we can only remember that the start of these problems in the country is rooted in Belgian 'humanitarian intervention' decades ago.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which expresses concern about the delay in calling presidential elections in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and at the worsening situation there in terms of freedom of expression and freedom of the media. It calls for free association and assembly to be restored and for the release of political prisoners. My constituents in Wales want to see the EU playing a more prominent role in achieving peace and development.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution concerning the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The resolution requires President Kabila's resignation at the end of his second term, in accordance with the Congolese constitution which provides for ineligibility as a result of the completion of two terms governmental authorities, also ensuring that elections are held on a regular basis by the competent authorities.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. “The situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo is very serious. There are constant violations of fundamental human rights by the President of the Republic and the ruling party, which refuses to resign after 19 December 2016, thereby violating the current constitution. Serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law by members of the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the National Intelligence Agency, the Republican Guard and the Congolese National Police have increased significantly in recent times, in particular as regards opposition members and representatives civil society in the electoral process, leading to a narrowing of the democratic space and political spectrum in the country. Foreign media broadcasts are subject to scrutiny in the country by government authorities. It is essential that all parties to the conflict establish a common peace dialogue and seek to resolve the tense situation in the country for the benefit of citizens and to stop all forms of violence and discrimination.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo as I do not accept the Union's interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. Especially in the case of Congo, with Western companies reaping millions from the really unacceptable situation there, I can only remember that the start of these problems in the country has its roots in Belgian 'humanitarian intervention' decades ago.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the current pre-electoral deadlock, political and security tensions are on the rise in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Worrying attempts to undermine democratic change, shrinking democratic space and a dramatic increase in human rights violations pose an acute threat to a credible and peaceful transfer of power in Congo’s young democracy. I strongly support the call for a successful and timely holding of elections, in full accordance with the Congolese Constitution and the African Charter on Democracy, Elections and Governance and insist on the Congolese government’s responsibility to guarantee an environment conducive to transparent, credible and inclusive elections as soon as possible. It is our duty to encourage strongly a credible democratic process and help prevent an escalation of violence and abuse in the DRC.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, bearing in mind that over the past two years, President Kabila has used administrative and technical means to try to delay elections and remain in power after the end of his constitutional mandate, as well as the increasing level of violence, violations of the human rights and breaches of international law in the DRC. The institutions must, under the Cotonou Agreement, respect by the DRC for the principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights, which include freedom of expression and the media, good governance and transparency of political positions.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a genuine political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its Member States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a genuine political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its Member States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution for the situation in Democratic Republic of Congo. DRC is a vast country with immense challenges in terms of poverty and security and gender based violence. Human rights groups continually report on the downward spiralling situation of human rights and freedom of expression and the use of excessive force against peaceful demonstrators, journalists, political leaders and others. A political consensus is essential to provide comprehensive and transparent elections in order to protect citizens living anywhere in the national territory, and in particular to protect them against abuse and crimes, and to exercise the task of governing with respect for the rule of law.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The political situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is particularly sensitive at the moment. President Joseph Kabila has made clear the willingness to recandidate himself or otherwise to remain in power, and the opposition reacts harshly. Added to this is the instability of the eastern regions, the richest in gold mines and resources, which border Rwanda, Kivu, the Beni, which have never been pacified in recent years. The African country faces a situation of social insecurity, as well as political, whose civilian population continues to die under the blows of militias inspired by the principles of Islamic jihadism. The next few weeks can be decisive. It serves a political national appeasement with a democratic political system that allows alternation to power. This is the basic condition for the recovery of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and that is why the International Community, including the European Union, must engage.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted abstention in this resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, despite agreeing with certain elements of the resolution, such as its concern about the human rights situation and the growing deterioration in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, I believe that we need to address the responsibility of the Union in the crisis. In addition, I believe that the resolution will ingest significantly in the country's coming electoral process.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of a motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The deteriorating human rights situation is of great concern, particularly the violence and intimidation faced by human rights defenders, political opponents and journalists in this pre-electoral context.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a genuine political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its Member States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the reports on the worsening situation of human rights and freedom of expression, assembly and demonstration in the country in the run-up to elections, including the use of excessive force against peaceful demonstrators, journalists, political leaders and others in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The extent of the loss of lives during the demonstrations over the last few weeks is particularly concerning. I support the call for transparent, credible and inclusive elections as soon as possible and therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo, given that the situation in that country is extremely serious and threatens the growth of political instability due to the delay of elections by the current President Kabila. It is especially important to emphasize the collapse of democratic standards and human rights protections in that country and the use of repression against political non-minded people. It is necessary to develop dialogue and find a peaceful joint solution of government and opposition in order to maintain stability, suppress violence and continue democratic practice and hold democratic elections. In this regard, the EU needs to cooperate with the African Union.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns violations of human rights and violations of democracy in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The text warns against President Kabila theoretically limited to two terms by the Constitution and who used means to delay the election and remain in power beyond what is allowed to him. Persistent delays in electoral preparations have led to unprecedented political tensions, unrest and violence throughout the country. Although agreement has been reached to postpone the presidential election until 2018, the entire opposition has not taken part and human rights continue to be threatened.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution. The unstable situation before the elections in the Democratic Republic of Congo is addressed. EU Member States should also work to ensure that transparent and credible elections can be held.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution because it is a new interference in a complex regional context and already weakened by multiple external interference (the United States, Rwanda, Uganda, Belgium...).

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a genuine political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its Member States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which expresses Parliament’s concern for the humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Congo elections have been postponed to the benefit of the already elected President Joseph Kabila. The Constitution limits the president to two terms; Kabila has already tried to change the constitution to extend his term of office. These delays in elections have caused commotion throughout the country. Kabila appointed a leader of the opposition as prime minister, but this did not have much impact to eliminate tensions. The delayed elections triggered demonstrations that resulted in brutal repression. The UN peacekeeping operation in the DRC is preparing for a crisis. Human rights groups criticise the worsening situation in terms of freedom of expression and association. Indeed, political instability causes chaos in the country and aggravates poverty and continues the state of uncertainty. I call for President Kabila to respect the Constitution of the DRC and to resign at the end of his term of office. The elections should take place on December 19, as originally planned. Those unjustly imprisoned during the demonstrations should be released, and the government must stop using force against demonstrators. Peaceful and transparent elections will contribute to the progress and development of the DRC.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Under the Constitution of the Democratic Republic of Congo, presidential elections will take place in 2016, although the current president, Joseph Kabila, has tried to stall those elections with various tactics. Since the Constitution stipulates that it is allowed to be in that function for two terms, it automatically means that he will no longer be able to run. The UN Security Council called on the Republic of Congo's State Election Commission to publish a calendar covering the entire election cycle, and asked the Government of the Republic of Congo to set a budget and code of conduct for elections and update the electoral list as soon as possible. In February 2016, there was a national strike over delays when organising elections. During the protests there was a brutal standoff between protesters and the defence forces. The UN, along with a number of other organisations, said human rights perpetrated by state officials were violated during the protests. The European Parliament completely blames the incumbent President Kabila and the Government for trying to delay the elections because they directly create a threat to the peace and security of the Republic of Congo and urges the authorities there to restore freedom of expression, association and assembly and freedom of the press. Since I agree with everything written in the report, I voted for this resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - Prospect implementation of democratic elections is a prerequisite for the rule of law and respect for human rights in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The Union and its Member States must use political and diplomatic dialogue to address the situation in this Central African country in order to stop the growth of another major conflict in Africa.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 1/12/2016, and because this joint motion for a resolution is sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion for a resolution. The purpose of this text is to give the European Parliament's opinion on the current situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). We consider the situation in the DRC to be extremely delicate and we find that the intervention of the European Parliament could be counterproductive with the efforts of national diplomacy. Furthermore, it could endanger the safety of nationals of the Member States.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report highlights the unstable situation before the elections in the Congo and calls on EU Member States to create a framework for transparent and credible elections in the DRC. I agree with that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The European Parliament, in its resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, expresses its concern over the restrictions on human rights, freedom of expression, assembly and demonstration, the disproportionate use of force against peaceful protesters, journalists, political leaders and others. The situation has deteriorated in particular with the recent approaching of the new presidential elections and with the emerging efforts of the existing president to postpone the elections and remain in power after the expiry of the term of mandate laid down in the Constitution. In its resolution, the European Parliament calls on the EU to respond more quickly to emerging unrest, to take concrete action and to initiate immediately the procedure under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, to adopt targeted sanctions, including visa bans and asset freezes, to apply to senior officials and representatives of the armed forces responsible for the violent suppression of demonstrations and the political impasse which impedes the peaceful and constitutional transfer of power.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The situation in the DRC is extremely fragile. It should be recalled that Joseph Kabila was placed in the presidency following the assassination of Laurent-Désiré Kabila with the support of the Western powers (USA, Belgium) who had supported the same Laurent-Désiré Kabila against Marshal Mobutu before the same. The Kabila regime is criticism, for sure, but French diplomacy recognizes, above all, states and not governments. At the same time, several elements are ignored by EU bodies, such as Rwanda's role in destabilizing the entire eastern part of the DRC to seize mineral wealth with the active complicity of Western powers. Moreover, the needs for stability and self-determination must be taken into account. Thus, the European Parliament does not have to interfere in this matter and endanger the diplomacy of the Member States or even the security of their nationals. Therefore, I voted against the joint resolution and those of the Greens, EUL/NGL and ECR. I abstained on others.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The human rights situation in the DRC is of concern. Political actors in the DRC must engage together in meaningful dialogue to begin to resolve the protracted political crisis there.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the dialogue with the DRC authorities, in the framework of Article 8 of the Cotonou Agreement with the objective of obtaining definitive clarifications on the electoral process, is failing, the current political crisis is deepening and the human rights situation is deteriorating. The Cotonou Agreement obliges respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights principles, which include freedom of expression and of the media, good governance and transparency in political office. Therefore, it is important to remain consistent in our full commitment towards the people of the DRC by requesting the EU Council put the adoption of targeted sanctions on the agenda for the next meeting on 12 December. These sanctions should include visa bans and asset freezes against the high level officials and armed forces agents responsible for the violent repression of the demonstrations, and the political impasse that prevents a peaceful and constitutional transition of power. That is why I have voted in favour

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Motions for a resolution were tabled by the Verts/ALE, EFDD, GUE/NGL, ECR, PPE, ALDE and S&D groups. With the exception of the GUE/NGL, the factions reached agreement and developed a joint compromise draft resolution. That's what I voted for.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The situation in the DRC is extremely fragile. It should be remembered that Joseph Kabila was placed in the presidency following the assassination of Laurent-Désiré Kabila with the support of the Western powers (USA, Belgium) who had previously supported the same Laurent-Désiré Kabila against Marshal Mobutu. The Kabila regime is criticism, for sure, but French diplomacy recognizes, above all, states and not governments. At the same time several elements have been ignored by the Community authorities, such as the role of Rwanda, which destabilizes the entire eastern part of the DRC to seize the mineral wealth with the active complicity of Western powers at the cost of a war that has already claimed between 4.5 and 7 million victims. Finally, the need for stability and self-determination must be taken into account; the European Parliament does not have to interfere in this matter and to put at risk seriously the diplomacy of the Member States and even the security of their nationals.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: In writing. — Taking into account the serious deterioration of the human rights situation in Congo and the accentuation of the phenomenon in the run-up to elections; the serious abuses suffered by peaceful activists, journalists, members of the opposition and civil society; we express a very strong concern for the people of Congolese and the country. The actions aimed at suppressing the most basic civil and human rights, have, in fact, affected freedom of expression, meeting and demonstration. The many serious human rights abuses have included the darkening of independent radio channels, arbitrary arrests, and physical violence. Considering the suffering inflicted on a population already experienced by years of economic, social and political crises, proven by the alarming need for food assistance of about five million people, and the catastrophic effect of postponed elections, the result of non-transparent choices and mere government instrumentalisation, we share the hope for the imposition of targeted sanctions on senior officials government responsible for the current circumstances. We also invite the parties involved to open a dialogue, to facilitate humanitarian aid and the operations of non-governmental organisations. We are also convinced that the European Union and the Member States persist in providing their humanitarian assistance, guided by the principle of maximum solidarity and trying to alleviate the suffering of citizens.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution regarding the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion because the EU is to work for the protection of human rights.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. In the DVs of Congo, the situation is increasingly strained in relation to President Kabila's unwillingness to leave power in accordance with the prescribed procedure, unrest in recent weeks has brought casualties, media channels have been closed, people are being detained illegally and people living in poverty and needing food aid the number is increasing. The African Union, as well as the EU, must ensure that elections are held in a timely manner in accordance with the Congolese Constitution and the African Charter for Democracy, Elections and Governance. It is important that all political parties enter into a peaceful and constructive dialogue as soon as possible. The EU is in a position to adopt sanctions against senior officials responsible for the violent suppression of demonstrations and political stalemate and should do so. Funding from the EU Development Fund in Congo must also be closely monitored and measures taken if necessary.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I support the resolution tabled. It should be noted that the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is constantly deteriorating, violence is increasing, and violations of human rights and international law are increasing. It is therefore necessary to take immediate action to put an end to impunity, violence, sexual violence and the plundering of useful resources. It should be noted that instability is increasing due to the tense pre-election situation. Therefore, the DRC authorities must immediately and properly implement their duty, in accordance with the rule of law, democracy and human rights, to organise transparent, credible and inclusive elections in a successful and timely manner. In addition, administrative and technical measures must be prevented in order to postpone elections and maintain power after the expiry of the term of office laid down in the Constitution.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. The political situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is particularly worrying. There is deep concern about the deteriorating security and human rights situation in the DRC, and in particular the continued reports of increasing political violence. The political crisis in the DRC can only be resolved if all parties are jointly and unequivocally committed to respect the Constitution and through a meaningful, open to all, impartial and transparent political dialogue. I voted in favour of the resolution urging the EU to adopt targeted sanctions, including the visa ban and the freezing of assets, against senior officials and officials of the armed forces responsible for the violent crackdown on demonstrators and the political stalemate preventing a peaceful and Constitution-compliant transfer of power to the DRC. Successful and timely conduct of elections before 2018 will be crucial for the long-term stability and development of the country and the whole region. Faced with the risk of instability in the country and its threat to the region, the EU remains fully mobilised.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because I find the content of it in line with my assessments and concerns about the political situation outlined in that State; the failure to organize presidential elections in compliance with constitutional terms, the marginalization of political opposition, the unequivocal deterioration of the human rights situation, the violence and distortions of the judicial system are perpetuated to the detriment of the establishment of democracy and the rule of law, objective set in the intervention of funding from the European Development Fund (national indicative programme 2014-2020 for the DRC); therefore I support the request for a survey of the abuses carried out by harm of Congolese civilians, I urge the EU to adopt all political instruments and, if necessary, sanctions against offenders of law and detractors of the democratic process in the DRC in order to bring humanitarian emergency and to lay fruitful foundations for the definitive establishment of the rule of law in the country. In accordance with these assumptions, I voted positive.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I express deep concern about the deteriorating state of human rights and the increasing restriction of political space in the DR Congo, in particular because of the instrumentalization of the judiciary and the violence and intimidation faced by human rights fighters that occurred during recent protest. It is necessary to find the culprits, prosecute and call accountable. I urge the EU delegation to continue to closely monitor developments in the DRC and to use all appropriate tools and instruments to support human rights fighters and pro-democracy movements. I also call on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to consider the possibility of strengthening the intermediary powers of the EU delegation to cooperate with the African Union and support political dialogue and prevent further political crisis and spread violence. I believe that the African Union must engage more to ensure that the Congolese Constitution is fully respected, and to ensure lasting political dialogue between the countries of the Great Lakes region to prevent any further destabilization. I remind you that peace and security of citizens are prerequisites for the stability of the state.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament has no legitimacy in dealing with foreign affairs. Its interference in situations as complex as the one in the Democratic Republic of the Congo cannot give anything good and could not bring anything positive. I am therefore voting against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — With this resolution the European Parliament reaffirms its closeness to the people of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and its commitment to respect democratic values, Rule of law and human rights. Unfortunately, the DRC government continues to violate the Constitution, the African Charter on Democracy, elections and good governance and the commitments made under the Cotonou Agreement. In particular, I subscribe to the condemnation of the violent repression against peaceful demonstrations by the opposition, of the refusal to proceed with free elections and a peaceful passage of powers, of strict limitations on freedom of expression and the media. It is clear that the European Union cannot remain silent in the face of this. That is why I agree with the call for targeted sanctions under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement against senior officials and armed forces agents responsible for the violent repression and institutional stalemate that violates the Constitution. The hope is that a firm EU stance can prompt all political actors to engage in constructive dialogue that resolves the current crisis and facilitates a quick and peaceful return to normal democratic life.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The Democratic Republic of the Congo, as a signatory to the Cotonou Agreement, has made certain commitments regarding respect for democracy, the rule of law and the principles of human rights — therefore I express concern about the move by President Kabila, who has been trying to postpone the elections envisaged for the last two years for the end of 2016 and remain in power even after the end of the mandate set by the Constitution. Such treatment with the Constitution intensified political tension, unrest and violence. The country has deteriorated the state of human rights and freedom of expression and assembly and pressure, including illegal detention, on non-violent activists, members of the opposition and civil society. I call on the EU to take concrete measures provided for in the Cotonou Agreement and to impose sanctions on top officials and members of the armed forces responsible for violent suppression of protests and paralysis of political dialogue in the country. The EU Delegation should continue to monitor developments and provide all appropriate support to human rights fighters and pro-democracy movements. I call for consideration of the possibility of strengthening the intermediary powers of the EU delegation. All political actors should start a peaceful and constructive dialogue and prevent the deepening of the current political crisis by refraining from further violence and provocations, and agree on a transitional period during which the presidential function would be exercised under the jurisdiction of the transitional councils in which the opposition would play a key role.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: It is the third resolution of the European Parliament in a year on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. There are a number of concerns, motivated by the interests of the EU, and in particular Belgium, the former colonizer of that country, and which seek to justify actions of interference and interference over a sovereign country. Nothing new, it is the usual practice of the majority of the European Parliament, which legitimizes actions of interference, destabilisation and external intervention with a view to controlling resources and regions. The practice of sanctions is advocated. Sovereignty bodies are criticized while supporting the sponsorship of organisations and movements supposedly striking for democracy. We are well aware of the aims and practices behind these to supposedly independent organisations financed to promote internal destabilisation. It values the renewal of the controversial MONUSCO mission, a UN presence that must be valued, but without impunity, and it is necessary to ensure proper scrutiny. On the contrary, the militarist and interventionist role of NATO and the strengthening of its military presence through the US military command AFRICOM is reprehensible. About the role of multinationals and their role in financing armed groups, not a word of condemnation. An undeniable attack on a sovereign country whose people, and it alone, is the task of deciding its destinies. We voted against it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns violations of human rights and violations of democratic principles in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is unacceptable for the Congolese population to suffer the burden of this electoral stalemate, which has plunged the country into chaos for more than a year and has seriously weakened the population already suffering from extreme poverty and insecurity. We call for an end to violence and arbitrary arrests. We recall that peace, security and stability are essential conditions for the successful holding of new elections.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. Whilst we remain concerned at the potential further erosion of the security situation in DRC we cannot support the development of EU foreign policy or the potential use of foreign policy tools. We remain fully supportive of regional and international efforts to resolve the political situation in DRC.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The DRC is immersed in a serious political crisis generated by the current President Kabila's intention to remain in power, running for a third term which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution. In recent months there have been dozens of deaths in the violent repression of demonstrations organized by the opposition and pro-democratic groups. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Union to react and take concrete measures of pressure on those responsible for the violence and the political blockade — through nominal sanctions — and to try to promote a genuine political dialogue in the country, including all forces and which prevents the the situation is dangerously degenerating into open conflict. This volatile political situation is added to a serious humanitarian situation, especially in the east of the country. With this text we call on the Union and its Member States to redouble their aid efforts to improve the living conditions of more than 1 500 000 internally displaced persons and hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring countries such as the CAR, Burundi or Rwanda.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 1 December 2016 on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because it underlines the increasingly worrying situation in the country due to the extremely tense pre-election climate. I deplore the violent repression of demonstrators and the loss of human lives in recent weeks and remind the authorities of the DRC that it is their responsibility to protect their citizens. Moreover, together with the European Parliament, I call for a guarantee that the elections are held smoothly and that they are held within the prescribed deadlines. I call for a peaceful solution to this political stalemate, which prevents a calm and constitutional transition of power. In this context, the European Union is also urged to take more concrete measures and impose targeted sanctions (including visa bans and asset freeze), as well as to continue its assistance to the people of the DRC.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The situation in Congo cannot give rise to free-world concerns. The ongoing conflict, human rights violations and migrant waves are all not only creating a humanitarian catastrophe, but also threatens Europe's security. We must act immediately. The main directions and objectives are set out in great detail in this resolution prepared by our colleagues.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: Joseph Kabila has been President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) since 2001, and his term of office is scheduled to end this December. In the DRC the office of President is constitutionally limited to two terms. The next presidential elections were scheduled for the end of this year. However, over the past two years, the current President has been using administrative and technical means to try to postpone its implementation, so as to remain in power beyond the end of his constitutional mandate. In recent weeks, the population has been opposed to this possibility and, as a result, there have been episodes of violence and human loss. This situation of severe social instability, and even repression, is of great concern to the European Union. As an integral country of the Cotonou Agreement, the DRC is obliged to respect democracy, the rule of law and human rights, particularly freedom of expression, good governance and transparency. The EU as a contracting party to this Agreement must take concrete measures aimed at blaming and stopping offences and violations committed. As I agree with the urgency of a peaceful and constructive dialogue that will stop the aggravation of the political crisis and further acts of violence, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have opposed Parliament's majority resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, because I think it transcends several red lines which, in my opinion, a text of this condition should never go beyond. Although I obviously oppose the violation of human rights and the repression of peaceful demonstrations and individuals because of their political militancy or for fighting in the defence of human rights, the resolution is clearly interference. It also avoids addressing the root of many of the conflicts affecting this State, and also the region, where European institutions and economic powers are involved. The European institutions' claim to give lessons on democracy and arbitrarily call for sanctions is clearly hypocritical and interested in what I have rejected this text.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of a motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The deteriorating human rights situation is of great concern, particularly the violence and intimidation faced by human rights defenders, political opponents and journalists in this pre-electoral context.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. — Although there has been some macroeconomic recovery in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) since the end of the civil war, the DRC is currently among the least developed countries, despite its wealth of natural resources. I must express my deep concern about the political situation in the DRC and, in particular, the undignified treatment and violence against children and women. I am disappointed that, despite the considerable efforts made by the EU in recent years to support the country, there has been no more significant progress in the DRC. I also find the situation in the DRC unfortunate because, on the part of the government majority and the opposition, the necessary compromises have not yet been reached, based on a broad consensus of the population. Unfortunately, fundamental elements of good governance, such as human rights and democracy, are not respected. What I find extremely worrying is that the indicators of poverty and vulnerability show little signs of improvement. Roughly 70% of the population lives below the poverty line and life expectancy is 48 years. I therefore expect the DRC to do everything possible to fulfil all conditions in accordance with the Constitution and the UN Security Council resolution.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — There are delays in organizing future presidential and parliamentary elections in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which amounts to a serious violation of the Congolese Constitution. President Kabila and the Congolese Government are responsible for this situation and delay. The aforementioned operation poses a serious threat to peace and security in the Democratic Republic of Congo. In addition, over the past two years, the situation in the area of freedom of expression and media and the rights of association in the country has deteriorated greatly. I believe that this trend is clearly linked to the government's attempts to delay elections and extend the term of office of the president, despite having already been in power for two terms, the maximum allowed in the Congolese constitution. Elections are crucial to restoring a favourable environment in the country for freely and peacefully exercising freedom of expression, association and assembly and freedom of the press. It is also important that elections are secured and that they will be held freely and fairly. In addition, the Congolese authorities should investigate, expel and adequately sanction members of the security forces and intelligence officers and other responsible persons for the violent and illegal repression of activists, opposition leaders and others who oppose President Kabila's attempts to continue to stay on area. Since this resolution addresses all the important elements of the problem facing the Democratic Republic of Congo, I voted to adopt it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - DRC President Joseph Kabila has been in office since 2001. Since the Constitutional Law does not further allow him to remain in office, it uses administrative and technical means to hold elections and remain in power even after the end of the constitutional mandate. The EU is seriously concerned about the political instability that has arisen, which is throwing the country into chaos, and should take further steps to address the constitutional and humanitarian crisis and ensure dialogue and agreement between political actors respecting the principles of democracy and legal state.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union is extremely concerned about the political situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. When we consider the risks of instability in the country and the threat this poses to the region, the EU will continue to remain involved in the situation. Member States agree that it is now necessary to agree its approach to the issue of visas for holders of diplomatic and official passports. DR Congo did not convene the electorate within constitutional deadlines to organize presidential elections. In this regard, the EU recalls its conclusions of 23 May 2016 and reiterates that the organisation of elections is the primary responsibility of the DRC authorities. The EU will use all available means, including individual measures to restrict those responsible for serious human rights violations, those who incite violence or who make it difficult to end the crisis in a consensual and peaceful manner that respects the aspirations of the Congolese people to choose their own representatives.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a joint motion for a resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Despite the constitution prohibiting him from running for a third term, the President of the Democratic Republic of Congo has tried to postpone elections by various means in the last two years, thus circumventing a very clear constitution. I join the concern about the increasingly unstable situation in the country and the warning to the authorities and the president of the country that it is their duty to protect citizens across national territory, especially from abuse and crime.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - We do not accept the Union's interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. Especially in the case of Congo, with Western companies reaping millions from the really unacceptable situation there, we can only remember that the start of these problems in the country is rooted in Belgian 'humanitarian intervention' decades ago.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported the adoption of the resolution in which the European Parliament expresses grave concern about the deterioration of the internal situation of this Democratic Republic of Congo. In my view, the EU cannot accept that, in breach of the Congolese Government's international commitments, including the Cotonou Convention, it does not guarantee the democratic rights of the opposition, acts violently against its demonstrators and provides room for the spread of street violence. I agree that the EU, through the EEAS and the High Representative, should act decisively in promoting democratisation essential for the economic and social development of this key country in the Central African region. I also expect from the current resolution of the European Parliament to contribute, in support of the work of the High Representative, to a more favourable change of political processes in the Democratic Republic of Congo and thus throughout the region.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The mandate of the President of the Democratic Republic of Congo is constitutionally limited to two terms and the next presidential and parliamentary elections were originally scheduled to take place at the end of 2016. Unfortunately, however, for the past two years, President Joseph Kabila, in power since 2001, has been using administrative and technical means to delay elections and stay in power once his mandate expires. The situation has led to unprecedented political tensions, riots and escalating violence across the country. Human rights groups are constantly reporting on the deterioration of the human rights situation and freedom of speech and assembly in the DRC, including abuse of force against peaceful demonstrators, wrongful arrests and detentions, and politically motivated trials. In this situation, it is extremely important that all political forces engage in peaceful and constructive dialogue. Otherwise, it will not be prevented from deepening the current political crisis, which will promote further violence. Another essential element of normalizing the situation in the country is the immediate release of all political prisoners and the lifting of all restrictions on the media. Nor should the European Union rule out imposing targeted sanctions on those responsible for violent repression and undermining the democratic process in the DRC. The lack of a firm response on our part is an incentive to further destabilize the situation in this country.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: This text strongly denounces the delays in the organization of the forthcoming presidential and legislative elections in the DRC, which constitute a serious violation of the Congolese constitution. Parliament appoints President Kabila and the Congolese government to be fully responsible for this situation in view of their attempts to delay the elections and considers that the actions of President Kabila and his government pose a serious threat to peace and security in the DRC. We urge the Congolese Government to respond immediately to the outstanding questions concerning the conduct of the electoral calendar and the related budget and the updating of the electoral register in order to allow for free, fair and transparent elections in the coming months.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ First of all I wish to express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims and to the people of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, who are tragically affected during the demonstrations of the victims and to last weeks. I manifest the deepest concern about the situation of increasing instability in the DRC, in a pre-election context characterised by tensions, but I want to remind the authorities, and first of all its President, that it is their primary responsibility to protect citizens living on the territory of the nation, acting in protection of the population from abuse and crimes and fulfilling their task of governing in the strictest compliance with the rule of law. It represented a dangerous precedent the failure of the government and the independent national electoral commission to have failed to organise the presidential election within the terms set by Constitution. Parliament reiterates its call for elections to be held in a regular and timely manner, in full compliance with the Constitution of the Republic and the African Charter on Democracy and recalls the responsibility of the government to ensure an environment conducive to the conduct of transparent, credible and inclusive elections.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Joint Motion for a Resolution submitted pursuant to Article 123 (2) and (4). Rules of Procedure, replacing proposals for resolutions of the following clubs: Verts/ALE (B8-1310/2016), EFDD (B8-1313/2016), ECR (B8-1316/2016), PPE (B8-1319/2016), ALDE (B8-1320/2016), S&D (B8-1324/2016) on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (2016/3001 (SP)). I support the request directed towards the main political actors, which requires them to start a peaceful and constructive dialogue, to prevent the deepening of the current political crisis and to refrain from further violence and provocations. I also support the call for the European Union and its Member States to continue to provide assistance to the people of the DRC to improve the living conditions of the most vulnerable population groups and address the consequences of displacement, food insecurity, epidemics and natural disasters.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — Authorities in Congo announced in October that presidential elections scheduled to take place in the country on 19 December this year will be postponed, leading to numerous protests by disgruntled citizens, arrests, forced imprisonments, violence and deaths of dozens of people. The current president of the DRC, Joseph Kabila, was elected twice in presidential elections, in 2006 and 2011. Although only two terms are allowed under the law, Kabila was already trying to change the constitution to get a third term as well. The current situation around the postponement of elections is believed to have something to do with this and that the current president is again trying to influence changes to the constitution, which is inadmissible. We must not allow Congo to be a hostage of one man, and we all need to influence Joseph Kabila to begin to respect the constitution of his country, not to change it according to personal interests, and to step down after the end of the second term as required by law, all for the purpose of unhindered holding elections December 19. I have voted positively on this motion for a resolution, and at the same time I urge the authorities of the DRC to stop using force to punish citizens who have legitimately protested by seeking their basic rights guaranteed by the Constitution, while those in the highest state duties do not respect the same constitution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In the past two years, President Kabila has tried to delay elections by administrative and technical means to remain in power after the end of his own, with a limited mandate constitution. President Kabila and part of the opposition signed an agreement postponing the election from 2016 to 2018. Human rights groups regularly report on the deteriorating human rights situation, freedom of expression and association, and freedom to protest in the country in the run-up to elections. The level of violence and misconduct is also growing. In Kinshasa, 50 people are believed to have been killed in September 2016, even more missing. We can express concern about the unstable affairs in Congo. The Democratic Republic of Congo and the European Union are signatories to the Cotonou Agreement, where the Democratic Republic of Congo has committed itself to respecting the principles of democracy. The deteriorating situation in the field of human rights protection and the restriction of political space is alarming. It remains necessary to monitor developments and use appropriate means to support human rights and democracy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted abstention in this resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, despite agreeing with certain elements of the resolution, such as its concern about the human rights situation and the growing deterioration in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, I believe that we need to address the responsibility of the Union in the crisis. In addition, I believe that the resolution will ingest significantly in the country's coming electoral process.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution. I deplore the loss of lives during the demonstrations over the last few weeks and I express my deepest sympathy to the families of the victims and the people of the DRC. This House is  deeply concerned at the increasingly unstable situation in the DRC in a tense pre-electoral context; reminds the authorities of the DRC, and primarily its President, that it is their responsibility to protect citizens living anywhere in the national territory, and in particular to protect them against abuse and crimes, and to exercise the task of governing with the strictest respect for the rule of law. The EP deplores the failure of the government and the CENI (Independent National Electoral Commission) to hold the presidential election within the constitutional deadline; reiterates its call for a successful and timely holding of elections, in full accordance with the Congolese Constitution and the African Charter on Democracy, Elections and Governance, and insists on the Congolese Government’s responsibility to guarantee an environment conducive to transparent, credible and inclusive elections as soon as possible.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The Congolese people's efforts to hold democratic presidential elections should be supported. The growing social dissent aimed at dignitaries manifests itself in mass demonstrations and strikes. Unfortunately, the signals coming from the DRC are troubling: the current president and his officials are admitting arrests, illegal detention of prisoners and various forms of violence. International opinion — including the United Nations and the U.S. — condemned said behaviors, imposing severe sanctions. The resolution calls on President Kabila to respect the provisions of the constitution and step down from office after the expiration of his second term, as well as to hold elections. It also calls for the release of those unjustly held and for the cessation of force against legitimate demonstrations, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In relation to the Congo, human rights groups report again and again on the deterioration of the human rights situation in the country during the pre-election period, weakening of freedom of expression, assembly and demonstration, among other things, by applying excessive force to peaceful protesters, journalists, political leaders and others. I voted in favour of his S&D resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted abstention in this resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, despite agreeing with certain elements of the resolution, such as its concern about the human rights situation and the growing deterioration in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, I believe that we need to address the responsibility of the Union in the crisis. In addition, I believe that the resolution will ingest significantly in the country's coming electoral process.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on  the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In November 2015 President Kabila announced the launch of a national dialogue. The African Union appointed former Togolese Prime Minister Edem Kodjo as national political dialogue facilitator. The African Union, the United Nations, the European Union and the International Organisation of La Francophonie have jointly underscored the importance of dialogue and the search for an agreement between political actors. Humanitarian agencies believe that political instability is plunging the country into chaos and causing its population, already weakened by the various past and present crises, to sink into extreme poverty and insecurity, with more than 5 million people currently in need of food assistance. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU has to take more concrete actions and to immediately launch the procedure under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, and to adopt targeted sanctions, including a visa ban and asset freeze, against the senior officials and armed forces agents responsible for the violent repression of demonstrations and the political impasse which is preventing a peaceful and constitutional transition of power.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have opposed Parliament's majority resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, because I think it transcends several red lines which, in my opinion, a text of this condition should never go beyond. Although I obviously oppose the violation of human rights and the repression of peaceful demonstrations and individuals because of their political militancy or for fighting in the defence of human rights, the resolution is clearly interference. It also avoids addressing the root of many of the conflicts affecting this State, and also the region, where European institutions and economic powers are involved. The European institutions' claim to give lessons on democracy and arbitrarily call for sanctions is clearly hypocritical and interested in what I have rejected this text.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: This resolution is part of a continuing process of interference and destabilization in the region aimed at restoring the power and control of the former European colonial powers over the immense natural riches that African countries have, thereby exploiting the conflicts that exist there, using -them in your favor. The majority of the political groups in the European Parliament that endorse this document conceal the destabilising role of European countries in the country, for example Belgium. We do not call responsibility or attack the multinationals and their role in financing armed groups. It does not have a single word to condemn the militarist and interventionist role of NATO and the strengthening of the military presence of this political-military bloc through the U.S. military command AFRICOM.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — As the motion for a resolution on the protection of human rights is in the Democratic Republic of Congo, I voted in favour.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I join my colleagues in expressing alarm at the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in the Congo. We call on the Commission and EEAS to do all they can to provide aid to those affected, monitor the situation, sanction those responsible, and ensure that perpetrators of war crimes are brought to justice.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the resolution on the situation in the Congo. In particular, it concerned presidential elections, when the current president has been developing activities for several years to change the constitutional order, which allows him, in its current form, only two terms. Previous efforts for change have thankfully been blocked by parliament, however the presidential election, which was due to take place in December this year, has been pushed to a later date. In response to the decision, demonstrations emerged that were suppressed, protesters were arrested and media disturbed. The human rights situation has deteriorated greatly. With the resolution, we therefore called on the Congo representatives to investigate human rights violations, for early and democratic elections and for sanctions against those officials who participated in human rights violations.
