I think it is very important to draw attention to such situations and strongly condemn them, because efforts to extend the period in power and to establish lifetime presidents are unthinkable in the 21st century and should become a thing of the past.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) because I believe that the increasing level of violence and violations and violations of human rights and international law in the DRC deserve a strong position by the European Parliament. I would like to emphasise the resolution's appeal to the DRC authorities and, first of all, its President, who is responsible for protecting citizens living throughout the country, namely to protect them from abuse and crime, and to exercise the function of governing in the strictest respect for the rule of law.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Mogherini on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Constitutional frameworks and provisions are the highest source of law and the basis for the normal functioning of society and the state in its entirety. Incumbent President Kabila is not entitled to a third term under constitutional provisions and it is imperative that the European Union insists on holding elections during 2016, or as early as 2017. The repression established after political protests in September is an inadmissible example of using excessive political force and power to suppress the people's action and freedom of expression. Since all relevant UN agencies and other organisations have previously established that there are a large number of cases of violations of human rights by the state, the European Union must insist on consistent respect for the international and national legal system and respond appropriately to the conceptual leaders and realizers of this oppressive approach.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a European Parliament resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Human rights groups regularly report on the deteriorating human rights situation, freedom of expression and association, and freedom to protest in the country in the run-up to elections, including using excessive force against peaceful protesters, journalists, political leaders and others. As a result, chaos is spreading due to political instability in the country, and the population descends into extreme poverty and insecurity, with more than 5 million people currently in need of food aid. I join the call for all political actors to engage in peaceful and constructive dialogue to prevent this political crisis from worsening. The EU must continue to monitor developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo and use all appropriate means and instruments to support human rights defenders and movements for democracy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This resolution, highlighted the high potential of renewable energy sources in developing countries - particularly in Africa - encourages their financing and use, drawing attention to the scale and implications of energy poverty in developing countries and the EU's strong involvement in efforts to reduce that poverty. For these reasons, it is also called for the phasing out of fossil fuel subsidies, allocating the funds thus released in favour of effective social policies and actions aimed at eliminating energy poverty in developing countries. I voted for it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: again proof that good intentions can lead to an indigestible resolution. It combines access to energy and drinking water, emphasis on gender specificity, traditional wood-fired cuisine versus modern and improved stoves, energy poverty, renewable and fossil energy, subsidies to the latter, construction of dams, private-public partnerships, human rights, climate justice, etc. Many of the topics discussed are important, but are in an ununderstandable disorder, as if the rapporteur had wanted to inject the maximum of good intentions into this text, but without succeeding in finding a strong and logical axis. It is consistent that the demography is rampant in Africa, without saying that this is the first of the problems of the continent. In the end, there is something indecent to ask to limit the access of fossil fuels to these populations, to ask them to change their way of life when those of the Westerners are much more expensive in energy. Nevertheless, in view of the themes discussed, I abstained, hoping for a better text to come on this topic.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this resolution, which contained such politically-correct suggestions as calling on the European Union to include a ‘gender dimension on all its energy policies’. There are further calls for EU action on a matter which should not be the business of the EU: energy policy should be decided by national governments.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on access to energy resources in developing countries. 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity, and even more people are unreliable. Half of the people who do not have access to electricity live in Africa, and this figure is growing, as the population on this continent is growing faster than expanding access to energy resources. I therefore welcome the aim of improving access to energy resources that accelerate development. It is also necessary to draw attention to the extent and consequences of energy deprivation in developing countries and to the active involvement of the EU in efforts to reduce this deprivation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. — This motion for a resolution addresses many points of interest but by stacking them all (access to energy and drinking water, women's rights, climate justice, energy poverty...) and finally arrive at a draft, barely understandable outcome, without real structure or logic. Hoping for a better text in the future, I abstained on it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which encourages the European Union to undertake initiatives to enable people in developing countries to have access to energy, which is an accelerator of human and economic development. Indeed, it is the EU's responsibility to make a major contribution to reducing energy poverty in these countries and achieving Objective 7 of the UN Sustainable Development Goals. More than 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity worldwide, and half of them live in Africa. This proposal therefore supports the provisions of the Regulation on the financing instrument for development cooperation as a solid basis for Union development assistance in the field of energy. It also calls for better coordination of international actions to improve access to energy for the implementation of the “African Clean Energy Corridor” action plan in order to meet half of total electricity demand by 2030.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ One of the goals of sustainable development is to ensure access for all to economically accessible, reliable, modern and sustainable forms of energy by 2030. Today in the world there are 1.2 billion people who do not have access to electricity, half of them live in Africa. A number in perennial increase due to population growth which is faster than the pace at which access to energy is extended. The joint resolution adopted today by Parliament and supported by me, positively assesses the Commission's Energising Development initiative to offer access to sustainable energy to more than 500 millions of people in developing countries by 2030. The creation of technical assistance instruments, the use of Union experts to develop technical skills in countries, capacity promotion and transfer of technologies are crucial means to achieve important results; which must be accompanied by investment and strengthening cooperation. Aiming access to energy for everyone, especially in rural areas, means accelerating the development of the continent, making it possible to create a system that is increasingly based on those sources of energy renewable, like solar and wind, which in Africa abound.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention in this resolution on access to energy in developing countries, for while I consider access to sustainable energy essential for the realization of various basic rights, I believe that there is a clear orientation towards the private sector. I understand that the role that the private sector can play in a strategic sector such as energy must be very limited and regulated by the State and this is an element that we lack in the resolution.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on access to energy in developing countries, which also calls for the inclusion of the gender dimension in all their energy policies. It also called for the phasing out of subsidies on fossil fuels and encourages the use of these released funds for effective social policies and actions aimed at eradicating energy poverty in developing countries.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I preferred to abstain on this resolution, which is full of good intentions but which are scattered in every way as to the challenges and possible solutions for access to energy in developing countries. The text is thus a catch-all of the challenges facing these countries: access to safe drinking water, climate justice, human rights, gender specificity or traditional wood-fired cuisine versus modern stoves. Moreover, some observations are made without the resulting consequences as in the case of the galloping demography. Finally, I am dubious about the ability of the European institutions to give moral lessons on access to fossil fuels when, moreover, the ways of life of the Westerners are not the most environmentally responsible: multiple air trips via low cost companies or public lighting with high energy consumption, especially during periods of parties. However, given that the themes discussed are of paramount importance, I hope that another text, more constructed and reasonable, will come to arm these issues.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — Although this resolution is partly shareable, I welcome some passages which take away from the text concreteness only to make entirely ideological and factious concepts, for this reason I decided to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution guaranteeing access to modern, sustainable, affordable and reliable energy for all developing countries, thereby meeting human needs and furthering human development and economic progress. The main objective of these energy access programmes in developing countries, governed by the Instrument for Development Cooperation (DCI) and the European Development Fund (EDF), should focus on access to energy and ensuring equal access to those poor in remote regions, eliminating energy and ensuring equal access to those poor in remote regions, energy poverty and the need to increase transparency and accountability. Fossil fuel subsidies must also be phased out progressively, and that funds should be applied to social policies and actions aimed at eradicating energy poverty in developing countries.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution on access to energy resources in developing countries. The European Parliament underlines that energy and potential security problems are very interrelated and believes that energy management, although difficult to implement, is crucial for the economic and human development of developing countries. Parliament supports the Commission's 'Energy Development' initiative, which aims to provide access to sustainable energy resources by 2030 to 500 million people in developing countries through programme elements such as the creation of a technical assistance instrument, the creation of EU experts to develop technical knowledge in developing countries and promote capacity building and technology transfer. In addition, he emphasizes the role of energy as a driving force in many other areas such as health, education, clean water, agriculture, as well as telecommunications and internet connectivity. Parliament calls on the Commission to report regularly on its website the progress made towards its 'Energy Development' objective and to clarify the share of total energy financing in developing countries for renewable energy, outermost regions, staff training, local know-how and skills, local and network-independent solutions.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — In my opinion, training of skilled and highly qualified local staff should be a priority in order to ensure access to energy in developing countries, and a significant share of funding should be devoted to this purpose. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the resolution, as I am aware of the importance of access to energy. This access to energy accelerates development and reduces the scale and consequences of energy poverty in developing countries. Therefore, robust and coordinated efforts by governments, civil society and other stakeholders in the relevant countries, as well as international partners, are needed in order to reduce energy poverty and achieve the objective of sustainable development in those countries. Such is Africa, the continent with the greatest potential when it comes to renewable energy, but also the continent that lags most behind others in terms of electrification, which affects its sustainable development and promotes migration of the poor population to the EU.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this issue. Sustainable access to affordable energy is of great importance for meeting basic human needs and almost all types of economic activities, and the way energy is produced and used can greatly affect progress in development.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ More than 70% of Africa's overall energy consumption comes from renewable sources, but almost all of them comes from traditional biomass uses; there are still huge opportunities to include other sources, especially solar and wind power. Considering that the demographic trend in Africa will have a strong impact on land use requirements for plant production, as well as on the requirements of firewood, a new need to be implemented development support policy, which is sustainable and supportive. We must proceed with the phasing out of fossil fuel subsidies and encourage the allocation of the funds so released in favour of effective social policies and actions aimed at eliminating poverty energy in developing countries; the only definitive measure of the success of EU action is the size of the contribution it makes to achieving universal access to energy, minimizing greenhouse gas emissions, taking into account the principle of common responsibility. Supporting the development of Africa means creating better living conditions for people, reducing crisis areas, stabilizing countries in the area and — consequently — easing flow pressure migratory over Europe.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I believe that access to energy is an accelerator for development. Access to affordable and reliable clean energy is one of the prerequisites for poverty reduction and economic development. Improving health, cooking methods, food security and access to clean water are possible only through the sustainable development of energy sources in developing countries. Goal 7 of the “Sustainable Development Goals” adopted by the United Nations aims to ensure access to all reliable and modern energy services at an affordable cost by 2030. In terms of financing, the report proposes to phase out European development financing supporting fossil fuels and stresses that blended financing operations must respect the principles of development effectiveness. As part of improving access to energy, stakeholders must participate in decision-making and project development in order to have readily usable, sustainable and culturally acceptable sources.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this resolution to draw attention to the scale and implications of energy poverty in developing countries. I think the potential of renewable energy sources in Africa is very high, particularly with reference to solar and wind power generation which could guarantee access to energy for all, especially in rural areas. I therefore urge the EU and its Member States to implement actions that facilitate the transfer of technologies so that they can actually be used in developing countries. I congratulate the various initiatives at international level to promote access to sustainable energy in developing countries, particularly in Africa, but I would stress the need to strengthen its coordination to ensure greater efficiency. In this context, lenders (bilateral aid agencies, multilateral development banks, export credit agencies and the EIB) can play a key role in tackling poverty energy in developing countries. Failure to access energy reliably is a problem that afflicts 2 billion people worldwide.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The Oral Question focused on whether the Commission is planning a strong European policy towards Africa, namely through the establishment of a Europe-Africa partnership for the electrification of the continent as well as on the state of progress and the main challenges encountered in the implementation of programmed development assistance in the energy area. It also focuses on the outlook for the Commission’s continued implementation and on the proportion of the funds engaged that goes to local renewable energy projects.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative resolution. In principle, UKIP does not support EU interference in developing countries. Moreover, UKIP does not agree with calls in this resolution to include a gender dimension in all energy policies. UKIP believe the best way to assist developing countries is via increased trade.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The strategic and operational cooperation agreement under consideration between Europol and Ukraine provides for the exchange of information, including those on personal data. By May 2018, the new Europol Regulation and the Personal Data Protection Regulation will enter into force and the directive for the exchange of data in the course of investigations into serious crimes or terrorism. Furthermore, the Agency's new regulation for the conclusion of international agreements on strategic cooperation between Europol and third countries ensures greater involvement of the Parliament, which will be called to express an opinion instead of just giving your consent or not. Waiting for that possibility, I decided to abstain.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that access to energy is one of the key drivers for development in all regions. It is necessary not only for securing a decent level of life for citizens, but also for businesses to thrive and grow. In regions where there is lack of energy infrastructure, there is a way to develop renewable sources of energy and help to shift to sustainable ways of energy production. The EU has to be able to give more financial support to those countries where access to energy is critical.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Should 20% of European citizens wake up one day, deprived of interim electricity, they should probably change their way of life in full. What is seen as a far-fetched nightmare for us is valid every day for 1.2 billion people, half of whom reside on the African continent and the worst situation is found in sub-Saharan area. We know that by 2040 Africa's electricity requirements will match those that India and Latin America had in 2010, to date it is also known as 70% of the Continent's energy Nero comes from renewable sources and there are significant development opportunities for the solar and wind sector. That access to electricity accelerates development is a certainty, but it depends on energy governance that can only be achieved through sound management of services and state capacity. Therefore, I support the Commission's Energising Development initiative to offer access to sustainable energy for another 500 million people in developing countries by 2030.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions on access to energy in developing countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure, which has as its main objective to take stock of the situation on energy poverty in developing countries, emphasising the high level number of people who do not yet have access to electricity. The resolution also pays attention to respect on climate change in achieving global access.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a strong relationship between energy and potential security issues and consider that energy governance, while also difficult to implement, is essential to economic and human development in developing countries. I welcome ElectriFI which provides a flexible and inclusive structure, allowing different partners such as the private sector, public institutions and local authorities, to participate and benefit in equal measure under the same market-based conditions. I appeal for due account to be taken of the needs and opportunities in each targeted country/region, recalling that the involvement of partners from the local private sector and civil society organisations will be instrumental in enhancing effectiveness and ownership of the actions deployed.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: ‒ Access to electricity in sub-Saharan Africa is the worst in the world, with 1.2 billion people not having access to electricity and an even greater number unable to access in a way reliable. On the other hand, Africa is the continent with the greatest potential in the world in terms of renewable energy. After all, I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that the EU should support the efforts of developing countries to get rid of energy poverty and encourage the attainment of sustainable development goals, primarily the elimination of poverty. In addition, the EU can play a crucial role in transferring technologies to developing countries, in order to ensure access to renewable energy for all by reducing high plant costs photovoltaics. In fact, I believe that energy is a key element in creating sustainable growth in many other areas, including health, drinking water, agriculture and telecommunications.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — Achieving sustainable access to energy is critical to meeting human needs and is a key driver of development. I believe it is necessary to strengthen the European policy towards Africa, namely the establishment of a Europe-Africa partnership on the electrification of the continent. The resolution highlights the EU's strong commitment to efforts to reduce energy poverty, emphasising the need for decisive and coordinated action by governments and stakeholders in the countries affected by its impact in pursuit of poverty reduction and achieving the goal sustainability. I fully support all efforts to ensure access to energy in developing countries. Systematic analysis of the situation and control of the solutions implemented are important for the effectiveness of measures in the fight against energy poverty. Unfortunately, the records that the resolution contains are not as unequivocal as I expected. Accordingly, I have taken the decision to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this resolution as it identifies the strong relationship between energy and potential security issues while it considers that energy governance is essential to economic and human development in developing countries. Africa has a high potential of renewable energy sources in terms of solar and wind production which is crucial in order to ensure access to energy for all, and more must be done to assist the development of the African community in this regard.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This resolution aims to take stock of energy poverty in developing countries with a focus on the large number of people who do not yet have access to electricity. The European Parliament commits itself to supporting the Commission's initiative “Energy for Development”, aimed at enabling an additional 500 million people in developing countries to access sustainable energy by 2030. Considering the need to provide equitable access to the first needs, including access to energy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative resolution. In principle, UKIP does not support EU interference in developing countries. Moreover, UKIP does not agree with calls in this resolution to include a gender dimension in all energy policies. UKIP believe the best way to assist developing countries is via increased trade.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the resolution on access to energy in developing countries. Today, another 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity. Access to energy is an accelerator of economic and human development and reduces potential security problems. The European Union's development assistance in the energy sector has increased significantly for the period 2014-2020, which will enable Africa, in particular, to exploit its high potential for renewable energy resources. The involvement of the private sector and local civil society organizations is also an undeniable asset on which we must build on.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. This report deals with the following points: access to energy and drinking water, insistence on the specificity of the female gender, traditional wood-burning cooking, energy poverty, renewable energy, etc. Other problems, conversely, are ignored: African demography and the difficulty of doing without fossil fuels, even though Westerners are the primary responsibility for wasting resources.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on access to energy in developing countries as it draws attention to the growing energy poverty in these regions and highlights the EU's leading role in efforts to tackle this problem. It highlights the great potential of renewables in Africa in terms of wind and solar energy production to provide access to energy for everyone, particularly in rural areas, calling on the EU and its Member States to provide support and technical assistance in implementing the action plan of the African Clean Energy Corridor Initiative, which aims to meet half of the total electricity consumption from clean, local, cost-effective renewable sources by 2030, in order to achieve a reduction in emissions of carbon dioxide.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting against because the Union must first deal with the ever-increasing energy shortage within the Member States and not intervene directly in the planning of third countries, especially when these interventions conceal neo-colonial rationals and policies. The only proposal acceptable to us would be a ban on trade with those countries that do not meet the environmental protection criteria.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as it underlines the need for concerted efforts by the EU and national governments on policy energy in developing countries. I think it is essential to commit the EU in this direction not only because access to energy results in the fulfilment of basic human rights, but also because it is a crucial element in development cheap.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The African continent has the greatest potential for renewables, but it is still lagging behind with the electrification of rural areas in particular, as well as the unbuilt infrastructure in which African countries will invest billions in future. There is plenty of evidence and broad consensus that small-scale decentralised renewable energy generation and local networks and off-grid solutions are often the most effective, that such solutions contribute most to general development progress and the most minimise or prevent adverse effects on the environment.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the motion for a resolution on access to energy in developing countries, because the Union must first deal with the ever-increasing energy shortage within the Member States and not intervene directly in the planning of third countries, especially when These interventions conceal neocolonial rationals and policies. The only proposal acceptable to us would be a ban on trade with those countries that do not meet the environmental protection criteria.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, considering that sustainable access to affordable, reliable and safe energy is essential to meeting basic human rights and needs. We must bear in mind the magnitude and consequences of energy poverty in developing countries, and vigorous and concerted efforts by Governments, civil society and other stakeholders in the affected countries, as well as international partners, must make vigorous and concerted efforts to reduce energy poverty in order to reduce energy poverty for developing countries. achieving sustainable development and poverty eradication in accordance with the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Mrs Mc Avan has carried out this text decisively, which deepens an important aspect of the EU's commitments in the fight against climate change. A neglected point of the agreements made in COP21 and COP22 concerns the effort to support developing countries to change their energy plans and consumption, just that these are the areas of the globe to be most at risk in access to energy supplies and in general to clean energy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I vote in favour of access to energy in developing countries. I support this resolution due to the sheer number of over a billion people living without electricity as this can have an effect on health, safety and education. I support this notion because access to energy can be seen as a key feature for development as well as having sustainable modern energy contributing to the present environmental issues, as firewood and charcoal currently dominate Africa’s energy consumption.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ We address with this discussion a sustainability problem of the development model fundamental to the future of relations between the European Union and the countries of development, in particular the african ones. We are talking about the continent which has the world's greatest potential in terms of renewable energy and blames the biggest delays in terms of electrification. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it essential to the promotion of sustainable access to affordable energy for those countries. In the 2014-2020 programming EU development assistance in the energy sector has increased considerably as well as international coordination for these initiatives, which must But be incremented. Finally, as rightly requested, I believe it is also essential for monitoring and the constant need to monitor progress in this field, that the Commission should verify the percentages of funds for energy in developing countries is allocated to the different expenditure chapters which, in particular, exploit renewable resources and reach the most peripheral regions.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention in this resolution on access to energy in developing countries, for while I consider access to sustainable energy essential for the realization of various basic rights, I believe that there is a clear orientation towards the private sector. I understand that the role that the private sector can play in a strategic sector such as energy must be very limited and regulated by the State and this is an element that we lack in the resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on access to energy in developing countries. Providing access to sustainable, reliable and modern energy in poor countries is a key driver of development and a goal that the EU and its Member States have committed to in signing the Sustainable Development Goals last year.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that access to energy accelerates development and that energy governance, while also difficult to implement, is essential. I am of the opinion that the EU and its Member States should provide support and technical assistance in the implementation of the Action Plan of the Africa Clean Energy Corridor initiative, which seeks to meet half of total electricity demand from clean, indigenous, cost-effective renewable resources by 2030, thereby reducing carbon dioxide emissions. Further subsidies for fossil fuels should be phased out and these freed-up funds should be allocated to efficient social policies and to actions for eradicating energy poverty in developing countries.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for a European Parliament resolution on access to energy in developing countries because I believe energy management is essential for economic and human development in the countries concerned. It is clear that access to energy accelerates development, and therefore it is necessary for the European Union to participate in efforts to reduce poverty in third countries, which of course requires an active and coordinated contribution of governments and civil society. Renewable energy sources in Africa represent enormous potential that must be exploited in a smart, balanced and responsible way. The synergy of the international community is certainly needed to ensure universal access to energy, and I continue to support this resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to take stock of energy poverty in developing countries with an emphasis on the large number of people who do not have access to electricity. It offers solutions to achieve more effective and sustainable energy access.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I reject this resolution. The report goes beyond the objective: instead of enabling developing countries to ensure their own way of achieving access to energy, the report maintains a prescriptive attitude and calls for the elimination of subsidies that certain sectors in developing countries make possible in the first place renewable energy, even though many countries are not equipped for this, and completely excludes other useful aspects such as off-grid electricity.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable access to affordable, reliable and safe energy is crucial for the satisfaction of basic human needs and rights, including access to clean water, sanitation, safe and secure environment. The resolution, calls on the EU to include a gender dimension on all its energy policies focusing on women particular needs. It also calls for the phasing out of fossil fuel subsidies. However, even if the resolution includes very positive language on sustainability and on gender issue I voted abstention since I do not believe that the access to energy in developing countries could be resolved through an EU-Africa partnership.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Access to reliable and safe energy is crucial for the satisfaction of basic human needs and rights, a key driver of development and a must for modernity. Unfortunately, nowadays 1.2 billion people lack access to electricity, half of those without access to electricity live in Africa; this number is growing, since the population on this continent is increasing at a faster pace than that at which access to energy is being extended. I supported the Commission’s ‘Energising Development’ initiative, which aims to provide access to sustainable energy for an additional 500 million people in developing countries by 2030 through programme elements such as the creation of a Technical Assistance Facility, drawing upon EU experts to develop technical expertise in developing countries, and to promote capacity building and technology transfer. In my opinion, the ‘Energising Development’ initiative must be fully aligned with the EU development policy and it should urge the EU and its Member States to facilitate technology transfer (renewable energy resources) in developing states, in Africa particularly.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained because it is a blurring resolution, but full of good feelings. It wants to eliminate the financing of fossil fuels for modern energy, which makes no sense in developing countries.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that highlights the important role that access to energy plays in accelerating development.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The population of the African continent is constantly growing, and on it half of people do not have access to electricity. An additional problem is that most people's access to electricity is unreliable. Africa has about 10% of the world's hydropower potential, and the European Parliament also recalls global warming that will pose a growing problem of access to water and food security. Many parts of Africa are already facing water shortages already now, with around one-third of arable land in Africa already qualifying as dry soil. The Paris Agreement underlines the need to promote a universal approach to sustainable energy in developing countries, especially in Africa, by strengthening the development of renewable energy sources. The African continent has the greatest potential in the world when it comes to renewable energy, but that's why it lags most when it comes to electrification. The European Parliament also notes that Africa has a great potential for renewable energy sources when it comes to solar and wind energy and that this would give everyone access to energy, especially in rural areas. I supported this resolution.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. — One of the objectives of sustainable development is to provide all people with access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy services. The EU's 'Energy for Development' initiative aims to provide access to sustainable energy for another 500 million people by 2030 and to allocate €3.5 billion for energy development aid over the 2014-2020 period. We have goals and money — it is now important that the 30 programmes envisaged work accurately and efficiently. Here, Parliament must work together with the Commission to address the challenges and coordinate our efforts to achieve the objectives. That is why it is important for MPs to get the Commission's vision and learn about the difficulties of implementing programmes in a timely manner.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - By ensuring access to affordable energy, critical environmental, air and ecosystems challenges can be tackled at the same time. The transition to modern and eco-friendly fuels will prevent unwanted felling of wood species and possible depletion of wood resources. African developing countries have a high potential for renewables. With an appropriate and effective development and social policy, it is possible to ensure affordable energy for the African population without causing further damage to the environment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - Referring to my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24/11/2016, I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution on access to energy in developing countries because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the resolution on access to energy in developing countries because sustainable access to affordable and reliable energy is a fundamental right both for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of third countries. Firstly, the EU must develop a framework to combat energy poverty within the framework of the governance of the Energy Union. The European Commission must set targets for Member States and third countries with which the EU has intergovernmental agreements on energy poverty and must set key indicators for energy poverty. I believe that, for European citizens, the EU must focus funds for energy efficiency and aid for production from its own sources in order to target consumers facing energy poverty and low incomes. Regarding the energy situation in third countries, the EU must follow the objectives of the EU's development policy in the Treaty of Lisbon and pursue potential security issues and energy governance in third countries. The Commission's 'Energizing Development' initiative is good. EU specialists in developing countries are needed to help develop technical expertise, capacity building and technology transfer. Energy development in these countries will also contribute to health, education, telecommunications and internet connectivity.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this motion for a resolution. This text deals with a wide range of themes on the development of third countries, including access to energy. If the intention is good, the proposal lacks coherence, pretending to encourage these countries to adopt a less polluting way of life than the Westerners...

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The European Parliament resolution on access to energy resources in developing countries draws attention to a number of problems for which 1.2 billion people still do not have access to electricity. Despite the fact that Africa is the continent with the greatest renewable potential on the planet, it is also the most lagging continent in terms of electrification. In this context, the European Parliament calls on the EU and its Member States to provide support and technical assistance for projects such as the African Clean Energy Corridor Action Plan, which aims to meet half of the total electricity demand by 2030 using clean local cost-effective renewable energy sources, thereby reducing carbon dioxide emissions. The European Parliament also calls on the funding bodies, the private sector and the governments of developing countries to work closely together in order to achieve these objectives faster.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The resolution mixes access to energy and drinking water, emphasis on gender specificity, traditional cuisine, energy poverty, renewable and fossil energy, subsidies to the latter, dam building, private-public partnerships, human rights, climate justice, etc. important issues addressed but in a disorder that makes the text ununderstandable. This one goes so far as to lose interest. On the other hand, it seems perfectly paradoxical to ask to limit the access of fossil fuels to these populations, to ask them to change certain ways of life, whereas in other regions there has never been so much wasted and consumed in an almost indecent way, and when demographic growth has never been more problematic. I therefore abstained.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution since access to energy is key to increasing development and can complement the EU’s other efforts to reduce energy poverty.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Access to electricity is universal except in Africa. The stability of Africa depends on the stability of Europe and the world. Although the African continent has the greatest renewable energy potential on the planet, it is experiencing the greatest delay in electrification. Access to energy is an accelerator for development. It opens up prospects for businesses, developing employment, improving economic growth. It is therefore essential that the EU, through official development assistance, and the African continent concentrate their efforts on energy, a prerequisite to health, education, access to water, women's empowerment, the agri-food industry... Access to energy for all is a guarantee of social peace, solidarity and sustainable development. A brotherly continent of Africa, the EU has a role to play in the framework of the EU-Africa Energy Partnership. Our inaction would cost 100 times the cost of action in terms of radicalization, chaos, immigration, political and social destabilization. But the impulses that do not come from the African continent are unlikely to succeed. Therefore, while it is certain that Africa's future is largely linked to that of Europe and vice versa, nothing can replace the will of Africans.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Committee on Development's report presents opportunities for people in developing countries to access energy. It covers (i) energy poverty reduction (ii) public or public authority tasks related to electrification (iii) on the initiative of the Commission to provide additional 500 million people with access to sustainable energy sources in developing countries by 2030 (iv) renewable on the huge potential of energy sources in Africa (v) on the problem of access to water and food security (vi) to improve the coordination of various international initiatives to promote access to energy (vii) fossil fuels aid and (viii) achieving universal access to energy with minimal greenhouse gas emissions. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — There is something indecent to ask to limit the access of fossil fuels to the people of developing countries, to ask them to change certain lifestyles at a time when Westerners spend more time traveling low cost around the planet and wasting energy in a shameless way at Christmas time, lighting in December representing an average of 10% of the annual energy expenditure of public lighting in a large French city. I abstain from this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text on access to energy in developing countries. The resolution takes stock of energy poverty situations in developing countries and makes proposals for improving access to energy such as the transfer of solar and wind technologies from the Union to developing countries.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: In writing. — Considering the key role of energy in ensuring the fulfillment of certain human rights, such as access to drinking water; recognizing energy as an indispensable tool for economic development; and weighed the importance of clean forms of energy in determining a sustainable nature; we support the McAvan report. These considerations are of exceptional relevance to Africa and, in particular, to the sub-Saharan one. In this region, access to energy is particularly scarce, the lowest in the world, but, on the contrary, renewable energy sources abound. We also share the emphasis on the importance of the sustainable and environmental dimension of energy. The increase in CO2 emissions, for which emanations are responsible, for 20%, deforestation, and more generally the effects of climate change increase the poverty of the most vulnerable regions that, for other, they have no responsibility in determining the phenomenon. Increasing droughts and energy poverty, moreover, aggravates and, increasingly, directly causes wars and migration. In this context, let us remember that the most affected bands are the socially most fragile ones. To this end, we share the hope for the inclusion of a gender perspective into European energy policies. We therefore hope that, by adopting an increasingly holistic approach, the Commission will pursue greater cooperation with regional partners in this area.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding access to energy in developing countries. Access to affordable, reliable and safe energy is crucial for the satisfaction of basic human needs and rights, and accelerates development.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I support the rapporteur's position on the need for developing renewable energies and ensuring access to clean energy for developing countries. Sustainable and safe energy production has implications in all areas of development of a state and is extremely important for the standard of living of all citizens, especially those with low incomes. In this context, I support the European Commission's steps to boost the development of renewable energy technology in Africa.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I believe the need to fully support the Commission's Energy for Development initiative on providing access to sustainable energy for a further 500 million people in developing countries by 2030, through the creation of technical expertise in developing countries and the promotion of capacity building and technology transfer, knowing that energy fulfills the role a necessary means for a number of other areas such as health, education, clean water, agriculture or telecommunications and internet connections. At the same time, various international initiatives aimed at promoting access to energy from sustainable sources in developing countries, particularly Africa, need to be better coordinated.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Energy availability is extremely important for all human activities, including for the purpose of meeting basic needs such as clean water, sanitation, health care, heating, etc. However, energy is not available to everyone today, and half of those who do not have electricity available live in Africa. It is therefore important that the EU contributes, for its part, to energy access in developing countries. The resolution supports the Commission's initiative to encourage the development of energy, the EU's electricity financing initiative, and also draws attention to the potential for renewable energy in Africa.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I support the resolution tabled. First of all, it is necessary to ensure better access to energy resources. It is only through joint efforts that energy deprivation can be effectively tackling and ensuring that the basic needs of people are met and human rights are respected. It should be noted that energy deprivation is a global problem, which also occurs in 11%. EU population. Access to energy resources should therefore be a key and strategic policy area for each Member State and the EU as a whole. It is necessary to remove all barriers to energy development as soon as possible. It is essential to ensure that all relevant projects are carried out in a transparent manner, taking due account of their potential impact on local populations, indigenous peoples and tribes.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. Of 1.1 billion Africans, 700 million do not have access to electricity. By 2030, if nothing is done, this figure could rise to 1.3 billion. In other words, it is the world's most populous future continent that will have the least access to electricity and light. It is high time to accompany developing countries, particularly Africa, to increase their access to energy. The stakes are enormous: education, migration, stability and security. That is what lies behind access to energy in developing countries.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The main objective of this resolution is to take stock of the energy poverty in developing countries by emphasising the large number of people who lack access to electricity. I voted in favour as I support the main objectives of the resolution. I also believe this resolution also pays attention to respect on climate change in achieving global access.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the European Parliament's resolution on access to energy in developing countries which takes into account the Sustainable Development Goals, in particular Objective No 7 on access to energy, objective 12 on sustainable consumption and production and objective No 13 on climate change. This resolution also takes into account the “Sustainable Energy for All” initiative launched by the UN in 2011. The resolution also includes the “Providing Energy to Development” initiative, launched by the European Commission in 2012 to allow an additional 500 million people in developing countries to have access to sustainable energy by 2030. Energy based on sustainable access, which is affordable, reliable and secure, is essential for meeting basic human needs and rights and is also a major driver of development. Access to energy is linked to security and geopolitical aspects, and energy issues can become the causes of conflict. The resolution calls for the phased out of fossil fuel subsidies and encourages that these freed funds be allocated to effective social policies and measures to eradicate energy poverty in developing countries.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: again proof that good intentions can lead to an indigestible resolution. It combines access to energy and drinking water, emphasis on gender specificity, traditional wood-fired cuisine versus modern and improved stoves, energy poverty, renewable and fossil energy, subsidies to the latter, construction of dams, private-public partnerships, human rights, climate justice, etc. Many of the topics discussed are important, but are in an ununderstandable disorder, as if the rapporteur had wanted to inject the maximum of good intentions into this text, but without succeeding in finding a strong and logical axis. Under these conditions, I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Sustainable access to energy, at affordable prices, is the indispensable precondition for the fulfillment of basic human needs and rights and for the development of any economic activity. In Africa, six hundred million people still have no access to electricity and that number is increasing as the pace of population growth is higher than with which access to the energy itself. The vast majority of the continent's energy consumption, moreover, comes from the use of biomass, which produces an extremely negative impact on the environment, in terms of deforestation, soil erosion and desertification, and on the lives of women, forced into huge sacrifices for wood harvesting and preparing meals using old-fashioned and inefficient methods. Yet Africa is the continent that possesses the world's greatest potential for energy generation from renewable sources, solar wind and hydro. Europe, through its development cooperation instruments and programmes and in accordance with the principles of climate justice, that is, by sharing equally and equally the burdens of environmental policies, must support the efforts of local governments, promote investment and provide technical assistance to ensure everyone has access to energy.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Sustainable access to reliable and safe energy is essential to meet basic human needs and is the main driver of development, the foundation of most economic activities. In terms of this approach, the worst is the situation in Africa, especially the sub-Saharan region, where the population is growing faster than access to energy. Demographic trends in Africa will have a huge impact on how the soil is used to produce crops and on the need for firewood. Heavy reliance on traditional biomass puts forests and shrubby areas across the African continent at risk — the continent that has the highest potential in the world when it comes to renewables. I call on the EU to support technology transfer and thus contribute to the financial accessibility of these sources. Governments, civil societies and other stakeholders should make a concerted effort to reduce energy poverty, primarily by developing young rural electricity markets until they have established themselves and become self-sustaining. I also call on the EU to include the gender dimension in all its energy policies. The example of using coal for traditional cooking can clearly identify the harm to health and the environment, whereby women bear a disproportionate part of the burden of using such materials. I welcome “Providing Energy to Development,” a Commission initiative that plans to provide access to sustainable energy for an additional 500 million people in developing countries by 2030, as well as the ElectriFi initiative.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: The resolution develops without any reference to the importance and imperative need to respect the political sovereignty of the beneficiary countries in relation to energy matters and that initiatives in this area must take into account the national context, respond to the wishes of the population and the needs of the country. On the other hand, it points out as a path to achieving the seventh objective of sustainable development — ensuring reliable, sustainable, modern and affordable access to energy for all, a greater involvement of the private sector in energy development aid programmes. We know that the logic of market and profit maximisation has had adverse consequences on access to and increase costs in access to energy, contributing to substantive energy poverty phenomena within the EU. It continues, promoting public-private partnerships, the way to finance the private sector that guarantees profits, while workers, the people and the States take on the losses of exploitation. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I believe that access to affordable, sustainable and safe energy is essential to meeting basic human needs and rights as access to drinking water, health care, education or heat. Energy is a key driver of development and is therefore also a vital security and geopolitical issue, access to energy can very easily become a reason for serious conflicts. There is a clear and very strong link between security issues and energy. The report calls on the Commission for concrete steps on improving access to energy, while monitoring and publishing their results. Further, we need to look at specific procedural innovations. For an example I would cite the potential construction of a dam Any such construction for which funds are approved must comply with the World Dam Commission Guidelines and five basic criteria: fairness, efficiency, decision-making participation of different parties, sustainability and accountability. I am a long-term promoter of the deployment of high-efficiency, sustainable and energy-efficient technologies that can be a key tool for long-term solutions in developing countries problem with access to energy sources.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: Sustainable access to reliable, safe and affordable energy, as well as access to safe drinking water, health and education, is fundamental for all human beings, but also for ensuring the economic development of countries. More than a billion people still lack access to electricity worldwide. We need to redouble our efforts in the field of energy to help protect the environment but also improve development. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which refers to the gravity of the energy situation in developing countries. It is important to stress that we will only overcome this problem by encouraging local production of renewable energy. All stakeholders, governments and international investors must be committed to achieving these goals.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative resolution. In principle, UKIP does not support EU interference in developing countries. Moreover, UKIP does not agree with calls in this resolution to include a gender dimension in all energy policies. UKIP believe the best way to assist developing countries is via increased trade.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution guaranteeing access to modern, sustainable, affordable and reliable energy for all developing countries, thereby meeting human needs and furthering human development and economic progress. The main objective of these energy access programmes in developing countries, governed by the Instrument for Development Cooperation (DCI) and the European Development Fund (EDF), should focus on access to energy and ensuring equal access to those poor in remote regions, eliminating energy and ensuring equal access to those poor in remote regions, energy poverty and the need to increase transparency and accountability. Fossil fuel subsidies must also be phased out progressively, and that funds should be applied to social policies and actions aimed at eradicating energy poverty in developing countries.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Electricity is the engine of the modern world. Therefore, ensuring access to energy should become one of the most important objectives of development cooperation and, in general, of any development. And it is here that there is a huge potential for the development of renewable energy.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution draws attention to the importance of access to energy in developing countries, as this access is a powerful tool for reducing poverty in these countries and consequently for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, in line with the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement. To this extent, a number of proposals are put forward for the EU to support improved access to energy in these countries, together with their governments, local and regional authorities, civil society and other stakeholders, inter alia, through support for the European Commission's initiative “Energy for the Development”, the implementation of the DCI Regulation and the promotion of the use of renewable energy in Africa, particularly at the level of solar and wind production in rural areas. By contrast, subsidies for fossil fuels need to be phased out. As I agree with the content of the motion for a resolution tabled, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with access to energy in developing countries. The resolution places particular emphasis on the African continent, given that currently nearly 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity and half of those deprived of electricity live in Africa. At the same time, more than 70% of Africa's total energy consumption comes from renewable sources, but there are many opportunities to diversify these sources and include new ones. It is important that the European Union, through its programmes and initiatives, be able to make available its expertise to enable capacity building and technology transfer.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution contains positive references and proposals such as recognition of the need to take particular account of the gender dimension in energy access, the importance of renewable energies and short production circuits. But this promotion of Union development policies to address energy poverty in impoverished countries remains at all, as long as current trade and economic policies are upheld. In addition, an essential element in ensuring access to energy is evident: the central role of the State and Governments in a strategic sector. Access to energy is essential to meet basic needs and human rights, but such access will never be guaranteed by promoting market logic and leaving it to private hands. Therefore, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as it promotes the current European model of privatisation of the energy sector, either in part or in part, for developing countries, in order to leave energy access into private hands by emphasizing the importance of the private sector and market conditions in ensuring access to energy.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. — Access to energy is indispensable to meet some primary needs that underpin sustainable economic development, such as, for example, access to sanitation, heating and education. In the world there are 1.2 billion people who do not have access to electricity, half of whom live in Africa, especially in the sub-Saharan area where the situation is very serious. That number is set to grow as population growth in that area does not correspond to improved access to energy. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution, sharing the need for governments and stakeholders to participate in an incisive and concentrated way in combating the reduction of this energy poverty, thanks to the contribution of the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on access to energy in developing countries. Providing access to sustainable, reliable and modern energy in poor countries is a key driver of development and a goal that the EU and its Member States have committed to in signing the Sustainable Development Goals last year.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As access to energy without any doubt accelerates development, I was happy to support this motion for a resolution. It is step forward in continuing efforts for development African countries. With its focus on sustainable energy it also takes into account the environmental point of view as well as the potential of renewable sources of energy in Africa.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. “I consider the area of access to energy as a prerequisite for economic and human development in all developing countries. In terms of access to electricity, the situation in sub-Saharan Africa is the worst worldwide. I see Africa as the continent with the greatest potential for renewable energy on the planet, but, on the other hand, it is most lagging behind with electrification. Statistical indicators tell us that 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity, and for an even higher number of people this approach is unreliable. Nearly 2.3 billion people use traditional biomass, such as charcoal, for cooking, with serious health and the environment implications. I think we could also talk about other unflattering figures that speak of lack of access to energy in developing countries, but from my point of view, it is important that cooperation between the funding authorities, the private sector and governments should be improved in order to achieve the objectives developing countries. I therefore support all initiatives at international level to promote access to energy from sustainable sources in developing countries, particularly in Africa, but at the same time I expect to improve their coordination from EU level in order to make them more effective.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — Sustainable access to affordable, reliable and secure energy is extremely important for supplying basic human needs and rights. In addition, access to energy is crucial for economic development. Unfortunately, as many as 1.2 billion people in the world do not have access to electricity, and more are grappling with unreliable access. Worrying is the fact that half of people without access to electricity live in Africa. 2.3 billion people use traditional biomass, such as charcoal for cooking, and this often has truly harmful health and environmental consequences. For this reason, programmes focusing on renewable, energy efficient, small and decentralised energy solutions should be promoted. Energy poverty is the most prevalent in rural areas, but given geographical location, connectivity and lack of infrastructure, it is also a major challenge to ensuring access to energy in ever-larger areas of rapidly growing cities. Renewables in Africa have tremendous potential, especially when it comes to producing solar and wind power and providing access to everyone, especially in rural areas. Therefore, the gradual abolition of fossil fuel subsidies and the promotion of social policies and measures to eradicate energy poverty in developing countries is important. Since all the facts written in the resolution matter, I voted to adopt it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. — One of the key factors for development is access to energy. However, the commitment and joint efforts of governments, civil society and other stakeholders in developing countries, as well as international partners, are needed for this. However, the eradication of energy poverty must be consistent with climate change and trade policies.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on access to energy in developing countries. The resolution is a peculiar hodgepodge of ideas, which is linked to the belief in man-made climate change and the desire to transfer the regulatory strangulations resulting from this belief to developing countries and to take the last chance from them to develop countries. industrialize. The resolution also calls on the EU to take gender issues into account in all energy policy measures, and in particular women with their special needs. I refuse all that.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Energy poverty is a global challenge, and it concerns Europe. Given the fact that half of people who do not have access to electricity live in Africa, and the population on that continent is growing faster than expanding access to energy, support for third world countries is indispensable because sustainable access to affordable, reliable and safe energy essential to meeting basic human needs and rights, including access to clean water, sanitation, safe environment, health care, heating and education. The Paris Agreement underlines the necessity of promoting a universal approach to sustainable energy in developing countries, especially in Africa, by strengthening the development of renewable energy sources I support this Draft Report because the availability of energy products is important for all types of economic activities and the main driver of development. In addition, access to energy is linked to security and geopolitical aspects, and since energy issues can become the causes of conflict, it is important to influence this problem.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a resolution on access to energy in developing countries. I support efforts to reduce energy poverty in developing countries. We need decisive and coordinated steps from all stakeholders: authorities, civil society and international partners. It should be remembered that access to energy accelerates development. I agree that the provisions in the Regulation establishing a Development Cooperation Instrument constitute a solid basis for European Union development assistance in the field of energy, while emphasising the importance of local and regional sources of renewable energy.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The Union must first deal with the ever-increasing energy shortage within the Member States and not intervene directly in the planning of third countries, especially when these interventions conceal neo-colonial rationals and policies. The only proposal acceptable to us would be a ban on trade with those countries that do not meet the environmental protection criteria.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to the motion for a resolution, we need to provide clean energy to developing countries. Considering the objectives of the Marrakes climate summit and the fact that climate change is the countries that are most affected by climate change, I voted in favour of the motion. I agree that sustainable access to affordable, reliable and safe energy is essential to meet basic human needs and rights and that this is one of the foundations of development. Of course, everything has security and geopolitical aspects, as energy issues can cause conflicts. I therefore agree that the energy poverty situation in developing countries must be taken into account and that the EU must play a strong role in reducing it. Clean energy that is suitable for each country should be prioritised, for example, diversified, renewable solar, water and wind energy production in African countries would be the right solution, especially in rural areas. With all this, we can only avoid eliminating energy poverty without causing an increase in emissions.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — Enduring access to affordable, reliable and safe energy is essential for meeting elementary human needs and compliance with basic rights, including access to clean water, sewerage, safe environment, health care, heating and education, as well as plays a key role in virtually all types of economic activity and is an extremely important factor of development. Unfortunately, currently 1.2bn people do not have access to electricity, and for even more people, this access is precarious. The most serious is the situation in sub-Saharan Africa, and with the demographic gain, it could get even worse. At the same time, however, the African continent holds the largest untapped potential on the entire planet in terms of renewable energy. The Paris Agreement, which assumes supporting developing countries, particularly Africa, in the development of sustainable energy, could allow for significant improvement in this area. Undoubtedly, much better coordination of many EU and international initiatives on increasing access to energy in developing countries is needed. Otherwise, it will be difficult to achieve the stated goals.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — Access to energy, especially in developing countries, is essential not only for economic activities, energy being a key driver of development, but for meeting people's basic needs. Moreover, sustainable access to affordable, reliable and secure energy is a fundamental human right and a universal objective of sustainable development. Moreover, energy poverty is a global challenge that also affects Europe, and energy security is a constant goal, because access to energy resources can give rise to conflicts, riots, armed insurrections and quickly become a security issue. international, economic or national. As such, access to renewable energy (solar and wind) is a necessity and a desideratum not only for Europe. Although energy poverty is particularly manifested in rural and semi-rural areas, the biggest challenge is to ensure access to energy in urban, highly industrialised areas. Facilitating access to energy in developing countries is possible through the viable manifestation of public-private partnership, especially since in 2015 investments in renewable sources were higher in developing countries than in developed countries.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Access to energy is an accelerator for development. Let us draw attention to the magnitude and severity of energy poverty in developing countries and to the major contribution of the European Union to efforts to stem this phenomenon and stress the need for Governments, civil society and other stakeholders in the countries concerned, as well as for their international partners, to engage in sustained and concerted efforts to reduce energy poverty and achieve SDG 7, which requires special efforts in remote rural areas, including off-grid energy regions. Let us recall that climate change strategies and trade policies must be mutually reinforcing in order to achieve sustainable development and poverty eradication in accordance with the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Access to energy is critical to the economic development of a state. Paying attention to the implications of energy poverty in developing countries and aiming for greater EU involvement in efforts to combat it must be a short-term goal pursued by the Union institutions. These programmes must also combine the fight against climate change and trade policies to achieve the goals of sustainable development and poverty eradication, in line with the agenda 2030 and with the Paris Agreement. Energy governance, although difficult to implement, is essential for economic and human development in developing countries.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on Access to Energy in developing countries. I believe it is necessary to draw attention to the range and implications of energy poverty in developing countries and to the strong participation of the European Union in efforts to reduce this poverty. Taking into account that access to energy accelerates development, strong and concerted efforts by governments, civil society and other stakeholders in affected countries and international partners are needed to reduce energy poverty and achieve the Sustainable Development Goal. In particular, I believe that it is important to bear in mind the great potential of renewable energy sources, especially when it comes to solar and wind energy in Africa whose high-quality and systematic use would provide access to energy in many rural areas. It is necessary to encourage developed countries to transfer their technologies to these underdeveloped areas in order to establish adequate infrastructure to facilitate access to energy sources.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — Governments, civil society and other stakeholders of developing countries, with the help of international partners, need to act vigorously and harmoniously to reduce energy poverty. Specifically, the key driver of development is achieving sustainable access to energy, while also achieving the eradication of poverty. There are various initiatives internationally to promote access to sustainable energy in developing countries, especially in Africa, but efficiency is not yet satisfactory.
