The European Union should provide support and technical assistance in the field of energy to use as much energy as possible from clean, local and economical renewable energy sources and reduce carbon dioxide emissions. I believe that the European Union should contribute to ensuring access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all, even for the poorest people in remote regions and reducing energy poverty. Since achieving sustainable access to energy is essential to fulfilling basic human rights and needs, I supported this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on access to energy in developing countries. Sustainable access to affordable, reliable and secure energy is extremely important to configure basic human needs and rights, including access to clean water, municipal infrastructure, safe and protected environment, nursing, heating and education, essential, so to speak all economic activities and the central driver of development, because access to energy also has security and geopolitical aspects and because energy issues can promote conflict. 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity, the largest percentage of people without electricity are African state (as many as half of people do not have electricity). Access to energy accelerates development and therefore welcome Europe's aspirations to help developing countries to electrify as quickly as possible.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention in this resolution on access to energy in developing countries, for while I consider access to sustainable energy essential for the realization of various basic rights, I believe that there is a clear orientation towards the private sector. I understand that the role that the private sector can play in a strategic sector such as energy must be very limited and regulated by the State and this is an element that we lack in the resolution.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: again proof that good intentions can lead to an indigestible resolution. It combines access to energy and drinking water, emphasis on gender specificity, traditional wood-fired cuisine versus modern and improved stoves, energy poverty, renewable and fossil energy, subsidies to the latter, construction of dams, private-public partnerships, human rights, climate justice, etc. Many of the topics discussed are important, but are in an ununderstandable disorder, as if the rapporteur had wanted to inject the maximum of good intentions into this text, but without succeeding in finding a strong and logical axis. There is something indecent about asking to limit the access of fossil fuels to these populations, to ask them to change certain lifestyles at a time when Westerners spend more time traveling low cost around the planet and wasting energy in a shameless way at Christmas time, with these lights in December averaging 10% of the annual energy expenditure of street lighting in a large French city. Nevertheless, in view of the themes discussed, I choose abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — Ensuring sustainable access to energy is essential to meet basic human needs and is a key driver of development. The growing contribution of private investment to the sector is listed as necessary for achieving affordable and safe energy for all. Such investments can be stimulated by the actions of governments. Any activity with a direct impact on energy availability in developing countries should be supported. I voted for the motion for a resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The objective of achieving universal access to energy is closely linked to the objective of achieving climate justice. I supported the Social Democratic position on this matter.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention in this resolution on access to energy in developing countries, for while I consider access to sustainable energy essential for the realization of various basic rights, I believe that there is a clear orientation towards the private sector. I understand that the role that the private sector can play in a strategic sector such as energy must be very limited and regulated by the State and this is an element that we lack in the resolution.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on access to energy in developing countries. Sustainable access to affordable, reliable and safe energy is crucial for the satisfaction of basic human needs and rights, including access to clean water, sanitation, a safe and secure environment, health care, heating and education, is essential for virtually all kinds of economic activity, and is a key driver of development. Africa is both the continent with the greatest potential for renewable energy on the planet and the one lagging furthest behind in terms of electrification. Energy poverty is most widespread in rural areas, but provision of access to energy in the expanding areas of rapidly growing cities is also a massive challenge, given the realities of geography, connectivity and lack of infrastructure. Moreover, energy poverty also has a gender dimension. The resolution stresses the strong relationship between energy and potential security issues. I voted in favour because I believe that energy governance, while also difficult to implement, is essential to economic and human development in developing countries.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution contains positive references and proposals such as recognition of the need to take particular account of the gender dimension in energy access, the importance of renewable energies and short production circuits. But this promotion of Union development policies to address energy poverty in impoverished countries remains at all, as long as current trade and economic policies are upheld. In addition, an essential element in ensuring access to energy is evident: the central role of the State and Governments in a strategic sector. Access to energy is essential to meet basic needs and human rights, but such access will never be guaranteed by promoting market logic and leaving it to private hands. Therefore, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution as it promotes the current European model of privatisation of the energy sector, either in part or in part, for developing countries, in order to leave energy access into private hands by emphasizing the importance of the private sector and market conditions in ensuring access to energy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution addresses the situation and the main challenges faced in the implementation of planned development assistance in the field of energy and the prospects for its continued implementation. However, in this resolution, there is no idea that it is important to respect the political sovereignty of the beneficiary countries in terms of energy matters and that initiatives in this area must take into account the national context, respond to the wishes of the population and the needs of the country. Overall, the resolution is very happy to see the participation of the private sector in development aid programmes in the field of energy. It is even said that an increasing contribution of private investment is needed to achieve the seventh objective of sustainable development — ensuring reliable, sustainable, modern and affordable access to energy for all. That is, nothing has been learned from the past. The right and universal access to energy will never be the work of any private interest. Only a strong public energy sector will be able to guarantee this right.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - Rather than allowing developing countries themselves to ensure how they intend to achieve access to energy, the rapporteur remains on a prescriptive tact, calls for the abolition of subsidies that certain sectors in developing countries have made possible in the first place renewable energy, even though many countries are not equipped for this at all, and completely avoids other useful aspects such as off grid solutions. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I reiterate that the EU must continue to play a leading global role in pushing for sustainable energy and the fight against climate change, particularly given the worrying political developments in the US. This must be reflected in all aspects of development, trade, and economic policy.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the resolution on access to energy with a focus on developing countries. In the resolution, we underlined the need for increased efforts by governments, as well as other stakeholders, to alleviate energy poverty. In developing countries, access to energy, water or sanitation is still not guaranteed, and up to 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity. In Africa, in particular, traditional biomass is used, which has adverse effects on human health, but also on the environment. That is why it is very important to focus on eradicating energy poverty and to ensure access to energy that accelerates development in these areas. At the same time, it is important to take into account the potential of developing countries in the field of renewable energy sources.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the resolution on access to energy in developing countries because I agree with the need to strengthen the strong link between access to energy and human and economic development. I would remind you that 1.2 billion people do not have access to electricity and that, for even more people, this access is unstable. I therefore highlight support for the initiative of the Committee on Energy for Development, which aims to grant access to sustainable energy to another 500 million people in developing countries by 2030. I would also stress the role of energy as a catalyst for many other areas, such as health, education, but also telecommunications and Internet connection, which I believe should be universal access rights.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on access to energy in developing countries as it correctly perceives the importance of energy in accelerating development and draws attention to the range and implications of energy poverty in developing countries. The European Union must make great efforts in development policy mechanisms and instruments towards third countries to help reduce poverty and to create a sustainable development framework. The latter particularly concerns rural parts of developing countries that do not have access to energy grids or corridors. Security and energy are strongly linked. Various security implications can arise if uniform economic and human development is established in developing countries. To this end, the European Union must encourage local authorities to develop renewable energy potential in Africa.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a European Parliament resolution on access to energy in developing countries. Sustainable access to affordable, reliable and secure energy is extremely important to satisfy basic human needs and rights, including access to clean water, municipal infrastructure, nursing, heating and education. Access to energy accelerates development and prevents conflicts resulting from energy issues and poverty. I therefore support the close involvement of the EU in efforts to reduce energy poverty and deliver sustainable development.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – I supported this motion for a resolution in light of its evaluation of the extent of energy poverty prevalent in developing countries. The provision of access to electricity and energy sources for developing countries should be a priority for our political agenda. Thus, I support the Commission’s energising development initiative as a means to advance progress in this field, and as one who had the privilege of representing Parliament in Marrakesh, and indeed in Paris last year, it was interesting to meet representatives from various third countries. One thing that was very notable is that the energy demands in Africa will treble over the next number of years, and in Asia it will double. So having targets to reduce emissions, and rightly so, means an awful lot of support will have to be given to them, especially through the Climate Fund of EUR 100 billion plus, and this will help towards giving them their energy requirements, but also reduce emissions.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to amend and improve the European system of payment injunction. These changes are necessary mainly because some Member States have not yet applied the regulation, causing very negative consequences for those wishing to recover a transactional claim . It is strictly necessary to standardise certain aspects of the credit injunction, such as the time in which it is granted in the various Member States, in order to be able to streamline and speed up processes. That's why I voted for it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — Regulation EC No 1896/2006 of 12 December 2006 established the European order for payment procedure. The scope of this procedure, which entered into force in December 2008 in all Member States (except Denmark), is limited to uncontested claims only. In the event of disputes, national courts shall have jurisdiction and the ordinary procedure is resumed. The report highlights the insufficient number of returns to accurately measure the effectiveness of the European order for payment procedure. The report raises delays in processing applications despite the diversion of the procedure. He therefore proposes to revitalize this procedure. I voted against this bill, which will put new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, causing them to lose their sovereignty even more. Moreover, simplicity and speed must not be sufficient reasons for sacrificing the legal certainty offered by the judge.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this report. This would require Member States to do additional work to satisfy the Commission, and there would be a potential cost implication for the United Kingdom.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the application of the European order for payment procedure. This procedure will make it easy for creditors to seek an order to recover undisputed civil and commercial claims. Moreover, this procedure can be applied in writing or often electronically, which does not require legal assistance from a lawyer and must be carried out in another Member State and no additional formalities are required.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this bill, which would undermine the sovereignty of States: this optional procedure would replace national civil and commercial law proceedings in cross-border disputes. Practically, it would not require the use of a judge or a lawyer, nor should the applicant bring evidence. Efficiency, simplicity and speed are not sufficient justifications to sacrifice the legal certainty offered by the judge.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of a more adequate application of the European order for payment procedure aimed at facilitating the recovery of sums owed in cross-border cases. In short, this procedure makes it easier for creditors to obtain an injunction to recover undisputed claims in civil and commercial matters. The European order for payment procedure is automatically issued, solely on the basis of the claim, but the debtor may file an objection within 30 days. In the event of opposition, the injunction terminates and conflicting judicial proceedings may begin.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Chrysogonos report on the application of the European payment order procedure. This is an important text which aims to provide feedback, ten years later, on the application of Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 which established a European procedure in this case matter. The report presents an overall positive framework for the application of legislation in the different Member States, but also underlines the need to make the regulation more used and known by citizens of the Union. The text asks the Commission to submit an impact assessment and, above all, to prepare a future revision of the text which aims to ensure greater harmonisation in the application of procedure and remove some of the exceptions considered today.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this report is to make an assessment of the implementation of the European Payment Order Procedure. The purpose of the European Payment Order Procedure is to enable easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims. I voted in favour of this report, as it calls on Member States to better implement the European Payment Order and to raise awareness among citizens, businesses, legal professionals and all other stakeholders about the availability, operation, application and advantages of this tool in cross-border cases.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: in writing. — As an auctioneer, I know how important it is to unify certain rules of legal and criminal procedure in cases such as trade, sales or cross-border estates. Of course, the same applies to the monitoring of orders to pay from one country to another. There are areas where Europe must be set up quickly. This is the case for cross-border recovery procedures. My colleague Chrystogonos understood this perfectly and in his report he gives us a very good analysis of the ubuesque situation facing many companies or individuals who, because of the lack of an existing European procedure, cannot claim their claim in another European country than theirs. I also fully support the possibility of allowing European orders for payment applications in electronic form in future, as well as the creation of standard forms. Europe cannot exist and really work without initiatives marked with great pragmatism. That is the case with my colleague's report, and I congratulate him on that.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this report on the implementation of the European monitoring process which I supported. We welcome the successful functioning in the Member States of this process applicable in civil and commercial matters relating to uncontested claims and the main objective of which is to simplify and expedite the procedure for the recognition and cross-border enforcement of the rights of Union creditors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report on the application of the European order for payment procedure called for a negative vote on my part. As a result of EC Regulation No 1896/2006 of 12 December 2006, this procedure attempts to replace national civil and commercial law procedures in cross-border disputes. The idea is to be able to do without a judge and a lawyer in the case of uncontested claims, since in the event of a dispute, the national courts take over. First of all, I am not sure that without a judge can guarantee full legal certainty. On the other hand, and as the report demonstrates, the effectiveness of this procedure is far from proven, with a significant proportion of requests returned. But unlike the rapporteur, I do not want this procedure to be revitalized. On the contrary, I refuse to allow new constraints and burdens to be imposed on States which should refuse to lose ever more sovereignty, here in legal matters. Finally, I am not persuaded by the relevance of a diversion of litigation proceedings.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. — The report on the application of the European order for payment is well structured and is not critical. That is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report which assesses the implementation of the European payment procedure. The European payment procedure was created in 2006 for the payment of debts not rejected by a debtor, thereby simplifying, speeding up and reducing legal costs in cases where more than one European country is involved, in addition to allowing free movement, recognition and application of payment proceedings in all Member States. The same applies to all civil and commercial matters in which one of the parties lives in a European country other than the country in which the order for payment is placed. The report gives a positive assessment to the European payment process, although it emphasizes the need to improve harmonisation as regards implementation and the need to provide.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the application of the European order for payment procedure. The purpose of the European order for payment procedure is to facilitate the recovery of sums in cross-border legal proceedings. This procedure is not mandatory: it means that in cross-border cases it can be used as an alternative to the various relevant national procedures. Simply put, this procedure will make it easy for creditors to seek the recovery of undisputed civil and commercial claims. This procedure can be applied in writing or often electronically, so there is no need for legal assistance from a lawyer and must be carried out in another Member State and no additional formalities are required. The European order for payment is issued automatically on the basis of the request alone, but the debtor may lodge a statement of objection within 30 days. In the event of such an objection, the order procedure shall be terminated and adversarial proceedings may be initiated.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree to the implementation of the European order for payment procedure and welcome the successful operation in all Member States as a procedure applicable in civil and commercial matters relating to the enforcement of uncontested claims. Its main objective is to simplify and accelerate the process of cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditors' rights in the European Union, thereby enabling the smooth functioning of the economy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure, which will simplify, accelerate and reduce litigation costs in cases involving more than one EU Member State. Likewise, the free circulation of European payment orders recognised and implemented in all countries of the European Union is possible.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. - I cannot support this project, which will put new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, causing them to lose even more sovereignty. Moreover, simplicity and speed must not be sufficient reasons for sacrificing the legal certainty offered by the judge. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The purpose of the European order for payment is to allow easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. It is an optional procedure, that is, available as an alternative to equivalent national procedures. It may be applied by mail order or electronically and is enforceable in the other Member States. Such proceedings are issued automatically, on the basis of the application, but the debtor may lodge opposition within 30 days. In the case of opposition, an end to the injunction, and prosecutions in contradictory may begin. The essential elements for the use of this procedure are how quickly the injunction must be granted, since the regulation provides that injunctions are issued within 30 days; and in Secondly, it must be possible to submit the relevant forms online. The European order for payment may be used for interest to be paid in the future, until the date of actual payment. If the defendant objects to the application, the proceedings cannot continue and may be abandoned, continue in ordinary court proceedings or continue within the framework of the European proceedings for the small claims. No forthcoming changes are needed, but more efforts must be made for review applications.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the application of the European order for payment. As statistics show, the functioning of the European injunction procedure is satisfactory, but it appears limited in Member States which already have such an instrument at national level. The report indicates as necessary the use of concrete measures and commitment to awareness campaigns in order to make citizens, businesses and stakeholders participate in the benefits it may make a clear operation of the procedure. Whereas at present in many Member States the procedure is not applied in accordance with the current regulation, the report insists that payment injunctions should be issued by greater rapidity. In fact, the regulation requires injunctions to be issued within 30 days, but in many states they are often over 6 months. The report proposes the revision of the provisions concerning the application of the proceedings and the exceptional review of the injunctions.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on a European Payment Order which will make it easier to claim payments due across borders. The report on the European Payment Order basically describes the results of an impact assessment done by the Commission and suggests some improvements. The EPO is an optional procedure, complementing (not replacing) similar national procedures.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure. This report is calling for Member States to provide to the Commission accurate and up-to-date data for effective monitoring and evaluation purposes.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of this implementation report on the state of application of Regulation 1896/2006 establishing a European order for payment procedure. The rapporteur rightly pointed out that in many Member States the regulation still has very little application, with negative consequences for those who want to recover a cross-border credit ( especially small and medium-sized enterprises). Among the problems identified are the failure to make the application for an injunction in different languages (in states where the number of requests is allowed increases substantially) and failure to implementation of the e-Codex system that allows you to file applications for injunction online.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Since late payments are one of the main causes of insolvency, putting small and medium-sized enterprises at risk, the European injunction procedure for injunction payment represents an important instrument of judicial cooperation in civil matters, necessary for the functioning of the internal market. However, an extremely low utilization rate has been recorded in some Member States. I therefore believe that more can be done by focusing on more information through awareness campaigns that highlight the benefits of the procedure, such as speed, simplification and reduction of costs, compared to similar national instruments. I believe it is also necessary to encourage the development of the e-Codex system to allow online applications to be submitted, as well as authorize the submission of applications in other languages. I therefore voted in favour of the report because I recognise the positive results resulting from the use of this procedure in all Member States, but I am convinced at the same time that much can be done. more promoting greater harmonization and removing some exceptions.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the use of the European order for payment procedure is part of the wider effort to streamline and intensify cooperation between Member States in the context of justice and civil protection. As the report highlights advantages and disadvantages recorded in the process of using the European order for payment, I think it helps to minimise the problems, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Positive vote for this report aimed at facilitating the procedure for the recovery of uncontested financial claims in the event of cross-border disputes of a civil and commercial nature.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I can only say in favour of the application of a mechanism to enable the rapid, facilitated and economic recovery of sums arising from debts enjoying certainty, are defined in amount as well as due and not disputed by the defendant. I believe that the European payment order procedure, however, needs more information towards citizens and professionals of the Member States since it is a system aimed at simplify, accelerate and reduce the costs of cross-border financial claims proceedings. It enjoys an optional nature, making it useful as an alternative to national payment injunctions. However, it should be pointed out that this report does not take into account the many different national provisions and their interoperability, so I encourage the Commission to take action to consequence. Similarly, I encourage Member States to issue injunctions within 30 days and accept applications in foreign languages.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the application of the European Order for Payment procedure

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure because the regulation in force on this issue is working satisfactorily and has managed to simplify, accelerate and improve debt collection contested cross-border crossers. I also agree with the recommendations in the text which aim to reduce the duration of the procedure for issuing European payment orders, in particular, for small and medium-sized businesses.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Late payments are often a key cause of insolvency, which threatens the survival of businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, resulting in numerous job losses. We need to keep pushing to solve bureaucratic cobwebs which are derailing the progress of our small enterprises through the development of the e-Codex system to allow the online submission of applications and encourage further measures targeting the more efficient use of the procedure. Our aim should be to simplify and speed up the procedure for the cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditors’ rights in the EU. This requires Member States to provide the Commission with accurate, comprehensive and up-to-date data for effective monitoring and evaluation purposes.  In this sense this report is a step in the right direction.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the application of the procedure on the European order of payment. I believe that the scope of regulation in this regard will facilitate the recovery of quotas in cross-border cases. The procedure is voluntary, which means that it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative solution to various equivalent national procedures. Simplified, this proceeding enables creditors to easily obtain an injunction for the return of uncontested civil and commercial claims. The issuance of such an order may be requested by letter or, often by electronic means, it does not require the assistance of a lawyer, and the order is enforceable in other Member States without the need for additional formalities. It should be noted that the current regulations in this respect in Member States work very effectively.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it simplifies and speeds up while reducing the costs of litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. This European order for payment procedure applies to all civil and commercial matters in cases where at least of the parties lives in an EU country different from the one where the application for an order is made while permitting the free circulation of European orders for payment. I agree with the rapporteur that it should be made sure that it is more known and widely used, by informing and assisting citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This vote deals with the application of the European order for payment procedure. This regulation aims to simplify, accelerate and reduce the costs of settlement in disputes involving more than one EU country, and to ensure the free movement of recognized and enforced orders for payment across all EU countries. Considering the need to approximate or even harmonise legal and administrative practices within the framework of judicial cooperation in civil matters within the European territory, I voted in favour of this application.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure. This report is calling for Member States to provide to the Commission accurate and up-to-date data for effective monitoring and evaluation purposes.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European order for payment procedure facilitates the collection of sums owed in cross-border cases. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the growing number of European orders for payment orders. I regret, however, that this procedure is very little applied in a number of Member States. Member States should also allow applicants to submit their requests in other languages, as is the case in France, where applications are accepted in five different languages.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — This European Parliament own-initiative report relates to the evaluation of the implementation of the European Order for Payment Procedure (EUFMH) Directive. The EUFMH aims to allow easier recovery of amounts in cross-border proceedings. The procedure is optional, which means it is available as an alternative to a number of equivalent national procedures in cross-border cases. The procedure allows creditors to easily receive an order for payment to recover undisputed civil and commercial claims. An application for an order may be submitted by letter or by electronic means, without requiring the assistance of a lawyer and may be enforceable in another Member State without further formalities. A number of legal issues have been raised regarding the transposition of the directive. First of all, interest, automation of the procedure, forms and language use. Overall, it can be said that the directive has laid the appropriate procedural bases, and the experience gained in its implementation does not justify an urgent amendment. However, the Commission must pay due attention to the application of the directive in future. In agreement with the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)

Overall, it can be said that the directive has laid the appropriate procedural bases, and the experience gained in its implementation does not justify an urgent amendment. However, the Commission must pay due attention to the application of the directive in future. In agreement with the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. Regulation EC No 1896/2006 of 12 December 2006 established the European order for payment procedure. The procedure does not require recourse to a judge or lawyer, or no exequatur, and is effective at a low cost, even if its scope is limited to uncontested claims. However, the report highlights many shortcomings that hamper the effectiveness of the device, including lack of awareness and slow processing. We cannot support this project, which would impose new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, to the detriment of their sovereignty.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — The European order for payment procedure falls within the category of measures in the field of judicial cooperation in civil matters having cross-border consequences and which are necessary for the functioning of the internal market. The procedure applies to civil and commercial matters relating to uncontested claims, the main purpose of which is to simplify and accelerate the procedure for cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditor rights in the EU. The report underlines that no change to the existing legislative framework is necessary. Given the different types and length of procedures in the Member States, I believe that the European order for payment will be much faster and cheaper and will make it easier for Europeans. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The European order for payment is optional, which means that it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to different equivalent national procedures. An order for payment may be requested by mail or, often, electronically, does not require the assistance of a lawyer and is enforceable, without further formalities, in other Member States. The existence of two different legislative arrangements to deal with an unlawful act will create legal uncertainty, while it attempts to deforestation the Member States' forensic system of matters relating to their exclusive competence.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European payment procedure is intended to enable the simplest recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The process is optional, meaning that it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to the various equivalent national procedures. What is proposed in this report is that the Commission adopt new versions of some of the standard forms, in order to take into account the various changes that have occurred over the years, as well as to improve the clarity of the sections on interest payments. As regards the regulation itself, it is considered that some of the restrictions on the scope of the process could be lifted in view of the progress achieved under EU family law. It is also highlighted in the report that additional efforts are required with regard to requests for review of European payment requirements.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following proposal as it ensures a easier recovery of the sums of money in the context of cross-border proceedings. The application of the European order for payment is a more economical and quicker way to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The legislation in question has been in force since 2006 and its main objective was to speed up, simplify and reduce the costs associated with processes involving more than 1 European Union country and, inter alia, to allow the free circulation of European orders for payment, which are recognised and enforced throughout the European Union. After 10 years, the time has come to recapitulate and evaluate the results of the legislation in question. We can therefore jointly assess that legislation on European orders for payment has brought with it positives in the form of uniform functioning and application in all Member States, but the European Commission has something to work on in the future in the field of harmonisation and removal of various exceptions.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report because I consider the procedure to be a useful tool for the business world.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - The European order for payment is optional, which means that it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to different equivalent national procedures. An order for payment may be requested by mail or, often, electronically, does not require the assistance of a lawyer and is enforceable, without further formalities, in other Member States. The existence of two different legislative arrangements to deal with an unlawful act will create legal uncertainty, while it attempts to deforestation the Member States' forensic system of matters relating to their exclusive competence, which is why I am voting against the report on the use of the European order for payment procedure.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of 12 December 2006 creates a European order for payment procedure for claims not contested by the defendant. This simplifies, speeds up and reduces the costs of litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. It also permits the free circulation of European orders for payment which are recognised and enforced in all EU countries. It applies to all civil and commercial matters in cases where at least one of the parties lives in an EU country different from the one where the application for an order is made. It applies to all EU countries except Denmark. The report on the application of the European Order for Payment procedure is meant to give feedback on the almost 10 years of experience in applying this procedure throughout Europe. The main conclusions of the report were positive towards the successful operation of the procedure in all the Member States, but making the point that it should be made sure that it is more known and widely used, by informing and assisting citizens. The report also asks the Commission to produce an impact assessment and a future revision should focus on ensuring more harmonisation in the application of the procedure and on removing certain exceptions.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — This European Parliament own-initiative report relates to the evaluation of the implementation of the European Order for Payment Procedure (EUFMH) Directive.
