name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report, bearing in mind that the European payment procedure is intended to allow the simplest recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The process allows creditors to easily obtain an order to meet uncontested civil and commercial financial claims. According to the Commission, around 12 000 applications are submitted each year for the implementation of the European payment procedure. The EC should adopt new versions of some of the standard forms in order to take into account the various changes that have occurred over the years, as well as to improve the clarity of the sections on interest payments.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I vote in favour of the application of the European Order for Payments procedure. I welcome a procedure applicable in civil and commercial matters relating to the main objective of simplifying and speeding up the procedure for the cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditors’ rights in the EU.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it favours, however, without deleting the existing procedures in the Member States and therefore without creating legislative conflicts since the procedure is optional, the easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The latter are increasingly important in promoting economic recovery policies in order to take full advantage of the economic possibilities of the Union's internal market. Requests for an injunction for payment of this type are many, about 12,000 and more widespread where these types of applications are already made following national procedures. This confirms the goodness of the underlying principles of the report, but also a direction to be followed in informing companies and professionals of the law about the existence and benefits of the new procedure.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this report is to make an assessment of the implementation of the European Payment Order Procedure. The purpose of the European Payment Order Procedure is to enable easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims. I voted in favour of this report, as it calls on Member States to better implement the European Payment Order and to raise awareness among citizens, businesses, legal professionals and all other stakeholders about the availability, operation, application and advantages of this tool in cross-border cases.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of the report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure. Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of 12 December 2006 creates a European order for payment procedure for claims not contested by the defendant. This simplifies, speeds up and reduces the costs of litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. It also permits the free circulation of European orders for payment which are recognised and enforced in all EU countries. The report is meant to give feedback on the almost 10 years of experience in applying this procedure throughout Europe. The main conclusions of the report were positive towards the successful operation of the procedure in all the Member States, but making the point that it should be made sure that it is more known and widely used, by informing and assisting citizens.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — This European Parliament own-initiative report relates to the evaluation of the implementation of the European Order for Payment Procedure (EUFMH) Directive. The EUFMH aims to allow easier recovery of amounts in cross-border proceedings. The procedure is optional, which means it is available as an alternative to a number of equivalent national procedures in cross-border cases. The procedure allows creditors to easily receive an order for payment to recover undisputed civil and commercial claims. An application for an order may be submitted by letter or by electronic means, without requiring the assistance of a lawyer and may be enforceable in another Member State without further formalities. A number of legal issues have been raised regarding the transposition of the directive. First of all, interest, automation of the procedure, forms and language use. Overall, it can be said that the directive has laid the appropriate procedural bases, and the experience gained in its implementation does not justify an urgent amendment. However, the Commission must pay due attention to the application of this Directive in future.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Order for Payment Procedure. This procedure was created to enable the rapid, facilitated and inexpensive recovery of sums arising from debts that are certain, of a fixed amount and due, and uncontested by the defendant. Although the operation of this procedure seems largely satisfactory according to statistics, the procedure is working greatly below its full potential, as it is mainly used in Member States whose legislation includes a similar national procedure. The resolution stressed that late payments are a key cause of insolvency, which threatens the survival of businesses – and in particular of small and medium-sized enterprises. This, particularly, is of importance to me and therefore I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure because I believe that this procedure allows creditors to obtain an order to collect unchallenged civil and commercial claims in a simple way. An application for a procedure can be sent by mail, and often electronically, without the assistance of a lawyer, and the order is enforceable in other Member States without the need for additional formalities. I believe it is necessary to accelerate the current delays in payments, as they are a key cause of illiquidity, which is a threat to the survival of business entities, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and leads to the loss of many jobs.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — Although it has practical advantages, this project threatens the sovereignty of the Member States by increasing the Commission's control over them, in addition to reducing legal certainty under the guise of simplifying and facilitating the procedure. I voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the application of the European order for payment procedure. While welcoming the smooth functioning of this procedure in all States, the report deplores the significant delay of almost two years in sending the Commission's report and the lack of updated data on the situation of States with regard to the operation and application of the procedure. We therefore ask for an expanded, updated and detailed impact assessment. The first of all objectives is to better inform companies and professionals about the existence, operation, application and benefits of the European order for payment procedure in cross-border cases.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The rapporteur is committed to improving the European order for payment procedure. It also complains of the two-year delay in a Commission review report, which it also considers insufficient content. The Commission is invited to prepare an enhanced, updated and more detailed impact assessment.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — This European Parliament own-initiative report relates to the evaluation of the implementation of the European Order for Payment Procedure (EUFMH) Directive. The EUFMH aims to allow easier recovery of amounts in cross-border proceedings. The procedure is optional, which means it is available as an alternative to a number of equivalent national procedures in cross-border cases. The procedure allows creditors to easily receive an order for payment to recover undisputed civil and commercial claims. An application for an order may be submitted by letter or by electronic means, without requiring the assistance of a lawyer and may be enforceable in another Member State without further formalities. A number of legal issues have been raised regarding the transposition of the directive. First of all, interest, automation of the procedure, forms and language use. Overall, it can be said that the directive has laid the appropriate procedural bases, and the experience gained in its implementation does not justify an urgent amendment. However, the Commission must pay due attention to the application of the directive in future. In agreement with the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Order for Payment procedure is a procedure applicable in civil and commercial matters relating to uncontested claims whose main objective is to simplify and speed up the procedure for the cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditors’ rights in the EU. In this regard, there are several elements that should be taken into account in order for the European Order for Payment procedure to be more effective. First and foremost, Member States should accept applications in languages other than their own where possible. In most Member States, however, applications in foreign languages are not accepted. Second, digitalisation of the procedure is necessary, which means that forms should be submitted online. This will reduce the number of errors and omissions on forms and will speed up the whole procedure. Last but not least, Member States should issue the orders within 30 days, the maximum term according to the regulation, no longer because the procedure becomes very slow and ineffective.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it wishes to extend the Commission's scope of competence in this area and to promote the EU's interference in the field of criminal responsibility.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported this implementation report, which follows a communication from the European Commission assessing the application of Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 establishing a European order for payment procedure. It agrees with the conclusions of the European Commission that even if the procedure, a tool for judicial simplification in cross-border cases, could be used more in some countries, it works perfectly wherever it is practiced more widely.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European payment procedure because it aims to follow up on these almost 10 years of experience in implementing this procedure in Europe. The main findings of the report are positive with regard to the successful use of this instrument in all Member States, but points out that an information campaign among citizens should be promoted to increase its use. The report also emphasizes the need to improve harmonisation in the application of payment, for example by urging Member States to accept orders in different languages. In general, it is observed that the use of the European payment payment is higher in those states which, like Spain, have a similar instrument at national level.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. — The European Payment Order procedure allows for easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. It is an optional procedure that can be an alternative to domestic payment orders. Statistics show that the European payment order is cheaper and faster than national procedures. However, this tool is used below its potential because it is mainly used in Member States with similar national legislation. I am in favour of this procedure because it has great potential for the economic environment. Late payment is one of the main causes of insolvency, which threatens the survival of businesses, especially small and medium-sized ones. Ordinary citizens, businesses, but also legal professionals, should be more informed about the advantages of the procedure. The procedure can become more effective if it can be operated online. Updated impact studies need to be carried out. Consumption differs greatly from one Member State to another. Citizens are uninformed and this poses a risk of decreasing confidence in EU law.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The European Order for Payment is an optional procedure which, as an alternative to domestic payment orders, can be applied in cross-border court cases and has been introduced in order to allow for quick and inexpensive collection of amounts arising from secure and due debts of a fixed amount which the defendant is not challenged. A European order for payment is needed for the internal market to function. Isolquidity is caused by payment delays, and this poses a serious threat to small and medium-sized businesses, especially as there is a loss of a large number of jobs. This procedure enables creditors to obtain an order to collect undisputed civil and commercial claims in a simple way. It is important to conduct a campaign to awaken awareness and to keep citizens, business entities and legal experts informed about the functionality, availability, application and benefits of this procedure. The European Parliament commended the successful functioning of the European order for payment procedure in all Member States so far in order to simplify and speed up the process of cross-border recognition and exercise of creditor rights in the European Union. Because I agree with everything written in the report, I supported it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the functioning of the European order for payment demonstrates the need to raise awareness of the Institute and its benefits. At the same time, it also points out the need to adopt updated model forms, which will have practical implications for its increased use. Member States must provide the Commission with timely, true and complete data on the functioning of the Institute in their countries, so that these data can be the basis for the adoption of more effective measures in the application of the European order for payment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the use of the European order for payment procedure because it is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The purpose of this text is to amend the European order for payment procedure to replace national civil and commercial law proceedings in the context of cross-border disputes of uncontested claims. This procedure, which is no judge and lawyer, has several advantages (speed, efficiency and cost). Its limited reputation and some persistent slowness are the main reasons why the rapporteur wants to improve it. This procedure, rather positive in appearance, puts new constraints on France and allows the Commission to once again interfere in our sovereignty, which we are opposed to. Furthermore, we have strong doubts about the legal certainty of this procedure, which is simple, fast, but which no judge comes to review.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The report highlights the insufficient number of returns to accurately measure the effectiveness of the European order for payment procedure. Moreover, this procedure suffers from limited awareness that prevents it from reaching its full potential. This lack of awareness results in a significant proportion of requests returned despite the simplicity of the procedure. The report also raises delays in processing applications despite the diversion of the procedure. We cannot support this project, which would impose new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, causing them to lose even more sovereignty. Moreover, simplicity and speed must not be sufficient reasons for sacrificing the legal certainty offered by the judge. Thus, I voted against this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the European Order for Payment Procedure will allow for more efficient recovery of monetary assets in cross-border proceedings.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The European order for payment procedure for uncontested cross-border claims by the defendant makes it possible to simplify, accelerate and reduce the costs of settlement in disputes involving more than one EU country. This regulation has the merit of establishing a uniform procedure leading to an enforceable judicial decision in all Member States without prior recognition. However, the regulations deserved to be revised in order to improve its effectiveness, update certain data, adopt new versions of certain forms, and improve clarity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which simplifies, speeds up and reduces the costs of litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. It also permits the free circulation of European orders for payment, which are recognised and enforced in all EU countries. It applies to all civil and commercial matters in cases where at least one of the parties lives in an EU country different from the one where the application for an order is made. It applies to all EU countries except Denmark. The report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure is meant to give feedback on the almost 10 years of experience in applying this procedure throughout Europe.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European order for payment procedure is established by Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council adopted on 12 December 2006. It aims to facilitate the recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. It allows creditors to easily receive an order for payment to recover undisputed civil and commercial claims. An application for an order may be submitted by letter or by electronic means, without requiring the assistance of a lawyer and may be enforceable in another Member State without further formalities. The report of the Committee on Legal Affairs notes that while the main advantages of the procedure are, in principle, simplicity and speed, in some Member States, the issue of an order may take up to half a year. It takes stock of problems with completing and submitting the relevant forms online and the situation where applications cannot be made in a foreign language in a number of Member States. It refers to the decision of the European Court of Justice that the effectiveness of consumer protection law requires the court to examine at least whether the contract condition under which the undertaking demands payment is fair to the consumer. The report calls for the European Order for Payment Regulation to address these issues. I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am against this project, which will put new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, causing them to lose their sovereignty even more. Moreover, simplicity and speed must not be sufficient reasons for sacrificing the legal certainty offered by the judge.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Payment Order is a procedure that can be used in cross-border cases as an alternative to domestic payment orders. I have voted for this report that will provide easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the report, which, from the finding that the use of the European Payment Warrant procedure varies significantly between Member States, makes the need to adopt practical steps aimed at further informing citizens, businesses, lawyers and other relevant parties on the availability and application of the European Payment Order procedure in cross-border cases; and benefits. In addition, it would be desirable to provide assistance to citizens and, in particular, SMEs in the use of existing legal instruments for enforcing cross-border claims within the relevant EU legislation. Going forward, it would be appropriate to consider the possibility of electronic application for a European payment order. They appreciate the positive mention of the Czech Republic in the context of allowing applicants to submit their applications in languages other than only in the domestic official language of that State.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on a European Payment Order which will make it easier to claim payments due across borders. The report on the European Payment Order basically describes the results of an impact assessment done by the Commission and suggests some improvements. The EPO is an optional procedure, complementing (not replacing) similar national procedures.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. This report applies the objective of the European order for payment procedure, which is to simplify the recovery of cross-border procedures. Accordingly, creditors will be allowed a way to recover unpaid product debts.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I support the report submitted. First of all, the European order for payment procedure must be more widely applied at EU level, since it allows for a cheap and expeditious settlement of debts from persons established in the Member States of the European Union. It should be noted that the European order for payment procedure is currently applied differently in different Member States. This makes it difficult and lengthens the process of monetary claims cases of an international nature and creates additional financial and administrative burdens. The Commission plays a special role in ensuring the effective implementation of this procedure in the EU. It must provide timely detailed reports on implementation and take concrete steps to further inform all stakeholders. In addition, the European order for payment procedure should be faster and more flexible in order to apply it effectively.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report on the implementation of the European order for payment procedure aims to give feedback on nearly 10 years of experience in implementing this process across Europe. The main conclusions of the report were positive for the successful operation of the process in all Member States. The report also calls on the Commission to prepare an impact assessment and a future review which should focus on ensuring greater harmonisation in the implementation of the procedure.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that the application of the European procedure for injunction of payment should be fully implemented. This procedure aims to allow an optimal recovery of debts which are certain and defined in the amount, due and not contested by the defendant; this type of debts, if not recovered, lead to jeopardizes the survival of small and medium-sized enterprises by causing serious damage to the economic fabric; it is therefore necessary for the injunction procedure to be applied in accordance with the current Regulation, avoiding maluse and aiming to maximize its functioning as in France, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Cyprus and Sweden, which are working to issue injunctions within a period of thirty days and accept applications in foreign languages. I believe that we should aim at simplifying and accelerating the procedure for cross-border recognition and application of creditors' rights in the EU. Therefore, I voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 creating a European Order for Payment Procedure is intended to simplify, speed up and reduce costs of the litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. I supported this report as it supports the work being done to allow the electronic submission of applications. Furthermore, it calls on the Commission to adopt updated standard forms and encourages the Member States to strive to issue orders within the 30-day period provided by the regulation and to accept applications in certain foreign languages.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the assessment of the application of Regulation (EC) 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council to create a European order for payment. The purpose of the European order for payment procedure is to facilitate the collection of amounts in cross-border procedures. The procedure is optional, meaning it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to various equivalent national procedures. In other words, this procedure allows creditors to obtain an order to collect undisputed civil and commercial claims in a simple way. An application for a procedure can be sent by mail, and often electronically, without the assistance of a lawyer, and the order is enforceable in other Member States without the need for additional formalities. It also allows free circulation of European payment orders recognised and executed in all EU countries. The European Order for Payment applies to all EU countries except Denmark. The European order for payment procedure applies to all civil and commercial matters in cases where at least one of the parties lives in an EU country other than the one where the application for the order was made.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: This project will put new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, causing them to lose their sovereignty even further. Moreover, simplicity and speed must not be sufficient reasons for sacrificing the legal certainty offered by the judge. I am therefore voting against this draft.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The existing procedure allows you to collect amounts quickly and inexpensively, but it continues to function below the limits of its full potential, which is necessary for an even more successful functioning of the internal market. It is primarily necessary to take concrete measures to inform all relevant parties about the benefits of this procedure. Our main objective is to simplify and accelerate the process of cross-border recognition and the exercise of creditor rights in the EU. The long-awaited Commission report does not have an extended impact assessment for each Member State and the report does not contain updated information on the functioning and application of the European order for payment procedure. I call for an extended and updated impact assessment to be developed, while Member States should provide accurate and comprehensive data to the Commission. We need to remove differences in the application of the procedure between Member States, because otherwise European citizens cannot fully exercise their rights at cross-border level, which weakens confidence in EU legislation. Applicants should be allowed to submit applications in additional languages, without which payment delays often occur — a key cause of illiquidity and threatens the survival of business entities and the loss of numerous jobs. In any case, the 30-day period established by the regulations should be observed. We also need to enable our citizens to submit applications electronically in the future, so I welcome the work on the development of the e-Codex system.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: - The report deals with the monitoring of the implementation of the European order for payment procedure and allows creditors to more easily obtain an order for payment with a view to recovering uncontested claims in civil and commercial matters. This is an optional procedure that can be used in cross-border cases as an alternative to equivalent national procedures. Late payments are one of the main causes of insolvency, which threatens small and medium-sized enterprises in particular, often resulting in the loss of workplaces. The procedure was set up to enable the rapid recovery of amounts arising from certain debts, net and payable and not contested by the defendant. Although it operates widely satisfactorily, this procedure is far from exhausting its full potential, as it is mainly used in Member States whose legislation provides for a similar procedure. Despite the considerations set out in the report commending and improving the functioning of the single market, which is also responsible for the difficulties encountered by many micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, it is a technical procedure for judicial cooperation at European and civil level, which seeks to combat one of its main causes of insolvency.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The objective of the European order for payment is to facilitate the recovery of amounts in cross-border cases. The proceeding enables creditors to easily obtain an injunction for the return of uncontested civil and commercial claims. The issuance of such an order may be requested by letter or, often by electronic means, it does not require the assistance of a lawyer, and the order is enforceable in other Member States without the need for additional formalities. A European order for payment is issued automatically, only on the basis of a lawsuit, however the debtor may object within 30 days. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the evaluation of the European order for payment procedure. Its purpose is to facilitate the collection of debts in cross-border cases. It may be applied by mail or electronic means, it does not require the assistance of a lawyer and can be used in other Member States without additional formalities. The Commission argues that the studies and consultations carried out did not reveal any difficulties in the application of the procedure. However, it would be appropriate to update the application forms and facilitate the filing of proceedings online and in a foreign language. Europe must continue to act to simplify citizens' administrative procedures.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure. This report is calling for Member States to provide to the Commission accurate and up-to-date data for effective monitoring and evaluation purposes.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which assesses the implementation of the European payment procedure. The European payment procedure was created in 2006 for the payment of debts not rejected by a debtor, thereby simplifying, speeding up and reducing legal costs in cases where more than one European country is involved, in addition to allowing free movement, recognition and application of payment proceedings in all Member States. The same applies to all civil and commercial matters in which one of the parties lives in a European country other than the country in which the order for payment is placed. The report gives a positive assessment to the European payment process, although it emphasizes the need to improve harmonisation as regards implementation and the need to provide.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 1 December 2016 on the application of the European order for payment procedure. The European Parliament “welcomes the smooth functioning of the European order for payment procedure in all Member States, a procedure concerning uncontested claims, applicable in civil and commercial matters, mainly aimed at simplifying and expediting the cross-border procedure for the recognition and enforcement of creditors in the European Union”. However, I deplore a number of factors, including the significant delay of almost two years in sending the Commission's report reexamining the application of Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006, the fact that the Commission report does not include an expanded impact assessment for each Member State and that the use of the European Commission's order for payment varies greatly between Member States.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The European Payment Order is an important financial instrument, an attribute of a united EU financial area. Therefore, ensuring its functioning is a prerequisite for the functioning of the single market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report, which I voted for, concerns the European order for payment procedure, which is characterised by making creditors easier, faster and more effective recovery of their uncontested claims in civil and commercial matters in cases cross-border. This is an optional procedure, which does not require the intervention of a lawyer and can be carried out electronically in any Member State without additional formalities. Although there is greater recourse to this procedure by countries with similar systems, it is important to make efforts to disseminate this instrument to the companies and professionals involved in the field, making them aware of the advantages and benefits inherent in its application. I endorse the suggestions made by the rapporteur on the elements necessary for efficient use of the European injunction procedure, in particular as regards the deadline for issuing them, the submission of online forms and the acceptance of applications in other official languages of the Member States. I welcome the legal clarifications that have been made to the regulation, especially those concerning consumer protection and protection, although some aspects need to be harmonised at the level of the laws of each Member State.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to improve the implementation and knowledge of the European payment process, which simplifies the recovery of cross-border debts. As this process complements and streamlines national processes, without replacing them, I voted favourably.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure. Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of 12 December 2006 creates a European order for payment procedure for claims not contested by the defendant. This simplifies, speeds up and reduces the costs of litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. It also permits the free circulation of European orders for payment which are recognised and enforced in all EU countries. The report is meant to give feedback on the almost 10 years of experience in applying this procedure throughout Europe. The main conclusions of the report were positive towards the successful operation of the procedure in all the Member States, but making the point that it should be made sure that it is more known and widely used, by informing and assisting citizens.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although there has been a simplification and more modern application of the European order for payment procedure, I must point out that the implementation of Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 does not achieve the best possible results. I regret that the use of the European order for payment procedure varies considerably between Member States, which makes European citizens often unable to exercise their rights at a cross-border level. It is understandable that, in this context, there is a constant risk of diminishing confidence in EU legislation. That is why I expect that, thanks to the measures taken, we will be able to better inform citizens, businesses, legal experts and all other relevant parties about the availability, operation, application and benefits of the European order for payment procedure in cross-border cases. I also support the proposed measures because, on the basis of them, we can create options for electronic submission of proposals for the issuance of a European order for payment. I believe that in the next period, in order to better and more efficient recovery of cross-border claims under the relevant EU legislation, we will provide more assistance not only to European citizens, but especially to small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The European order for payment procedure is a measure in the field of judicial cooperation in civil matters with cross-border elements. It aims to make it easier for creditors to recover amounts in cross-border litigation by allowing them to easily obtain an order to recover undisputed civil and economic claims. Small and medium-sized businesses have been facing increased delays in payments recently, putting their livelihoods and the loss of many jobs at risk. According to the Commission, around 12,000 applications for European payment orders are expected to be made each year, with a wide range of applications between Member States. This shows that there is a need for enhanced notification of citizens, businesses and legal experts about the existence, functioning and advantages of this procedure. The Parliament's report welcomes the successful operation of the procedure to date and supports the Commission's future efforts to optimise it. As the report highlights, inter alia, certain essential facts, such as the practice of Member States to prefer to apply national legislation instead of the European order for payment procedure, which makes citizens unable to exercise their right at cross-border level, thereby reducing confidence in EU legislation, I supported it in the vote. This is a good report calling for simplification and acceleration of this process and to reduce the cost of cross-border matters.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European order for payment procedure facilitates the recovery of sums in cross-border procedures. In order to optimise this process, some aspects need to be improved, such as the awareness of subjects, the speed of issue, the online submission or the receipt of a form in a foreign language.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the application of the European order for payment procedure. I reject a single European order for payment procedure. We need competition between European legal systems and there is no reason to use the respective national order for payment procedures as foreigners.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the application of the European order for payment procedure allows for easier collection of amounts in cross-border procedures. The European Order for Payment is issued automatically on the basis of the request, but the debtor can lodge a complaint within 30 days. In case of objection, the execution of the order is suspended and court proceedings may be initiated.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the implementation of the European order for payment procedure. The main objective of the European Order for Payment applicable in civil and commercial matters relating to the enforcement of uncontested claims is to simplify and accelerate the process of cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditors' rights in the European Union. I support a report which considers that practical measures need to be taken to further inform citizens, businesses, legal experts and all other relevant parties about the existence, functioning, application and advantages of the European order for payment procedure in cross-border cases;

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The European order for payment is optional, which means that it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to different equivalent national procedures. An order for payment may be requested by mail or, often, electronically, does not require the assistance of a lawyer and is enforceable, without further formalities, in other Member States. The existence of two different legislative arrangements to deal with an unlawful act will create legal uncertainty, while it attempts to deforestation the Member States' forensic system of matters relating to their exclusive competence.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — This European Parliament own-initiative report relates to the evaluation of the implementation of the European Order for Payment Procedure (EUFMH) Directive. The EUFMH aims to allow easier recovery of amounts in cross-border proceedings. The procedure is optional, which means it is available as an alternative to a number of equivalent national procedures in cross-border cases. The procedure allows creditors to easily receive an order for payment to recover undisputed civil and commercial claims. An application for an order may be submitted by letter or by electronic means, without requiring the assistance of a lawyer and may be enforceable in another Member State without further formalities. A number of legal issues have been raised regarding the transposition of the directive. First of all, interest, automation of the procedure, forms and language use. Overall, it can be said that the directive has laid the appropriate procedural bases, and the experience gained in its implementation does not justify an urgent amendment. However, the Commission must pay due attention to the application of the directive in future. In agreement with the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European order for payment procedure, which welcomes the successful operation of the procedure. The procedure makes it easier to recover sums in cross-border procedures, which is why I find it regrettable that its use differs significantly in different Member States and that, despite the simplified modern procedure offered by EU legislation, in many places, the legislation is preferred. I agree with the report on the need to inform EU citizens, businesses and legal professionals about the availability, operation, application and benefits of the European order for payment procedure in cross-border cases. I also agree with the finding that, with improved knowledge, companies, in particular SMEs, would be more effective in enforcing cross-border claims under the relevant EU legislation. I also support the possibility of the electronic submission of requests for a European order for payment, in connection with which it would be useful to encourage the use of the e-Codex pilot project.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European order for payment procedure was designed to enable the rapid, facilitated and inexpensive recovery of debts which are certain, the amount of which is determined and which are due and unchallenged by the defendant. For it should be remembered that late payments are the main cause of bankruptcy. This threatens the existence of businesses, particularly small and medium-sized businesses, and leads to the loss of many jobs. However, my concern is that there are significant differences between the Member States in terms of the application of the European order of payment procedure. Difficulties also relate to the adoption of lawsuits in other European languages, which negatively affects the costs and timing of the case in the proceedings. In this context, it is therefore extremely important to take practical measures to further simplify the procedures in force, as well as to inform citizens and businesses about the availability, functioning, application and merits of the European order of payment procedure in cases cross-border.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Order for Payment procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims. It can be applied for by correspondence or electronically, does not require the assistance of a lawyer, and is enforceable in other Member States without any need for additional formalities. This system simplifies, speeds up and reduces the costs of litigation in cases involving more than one EU country. It also permits the free circulation of European orders for payment that are recognised and enforced in all EU countries. This report gives feedback on the almost 10 years of experience in applying this procedure throughout Europe and provides some recommendations for the future. I support this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European order for payment procedure, which aims to facilitate the recovery of sums owed in cross-border cases. The procedure is optional, which means that it can replace many equivalent national procedures in cross-border cases. In short, this procedure makes it easier for creditors to obtain an injunction to recover undisputed claims in civil and commercial matters. This procedure can be applied by mail or electronic means (which is more often the case), does not require the assistance of a lawyer and can be used in other Member States without additional formalities.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: and writing. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the application of the European Order for Payment Procedure. The dogmatic basis of the introduction of the Institute of Payment Order is facilitating a simpler and more efficient collection of due claims. Since the European Union is the single market, it is necessary to effectively codify and then apply adequate legal mechanisms to facilitate the functioning of the Union system. Since, to some extent, there are still bureaucratic obstacles to the collection of claims, it is necessary to provide and regulate a procedure that will simplify the collection of undisputed civil and commercial law claims. I certainly support the initiative of enforceability of orders in a Member State to which it does not belong under territorial jurisdiction, especially since in that case it will not be necessary to activate legal services which produce additional costs for citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The purpose of the European Payment Order is to facilitate the recovery of money in cross-border disputes. The procedure makes it easier for credit providers to return undisputed civil and commercial claims. The proposal significantly reduces the bureaucratic burden, since it also enables this to be applied in writing or electronic mail and does not require the involvement of lawyers or the fulfillment of other formalities. The order is issued automatically, and only on the basis of prior application, and the debtor has the right to manifest itself within 30 days. When taking into account the cost of cross-border procedures and the very long duration of procedures in certain Member States of the Union, the resolution of procedures through a European order for payment is clearly a much cheaper and faster solution. So I voted yes.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the implementation of the European order for payment procedure. The European order for payment procedure aims to facilitate the recovery of amounts in cross-border litigation. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover undisputed civil and economic claims. It is possible to apply for him by mail, and often by electronic means - no lawyer is required. Some countries have a low level of application, so more needs to be done when informing companies and legal experts about the existence of the procedure and its advantages. For the successful application of the procedure, rapid release (30days) is required, enabling the submission of relevant forms online and accepting applications in foreign languages. The Commission must adopt new versions of certain standard forms in order to take account of the various changes made in recent years and to improve the clarity of those parts of the text in which the payment of interest is concerned.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to make an assessment of the application of the European Payment Order Procedure. The purpose of the European Payment Order Procedure is to enable easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims. I voted in favour of this report, as it calls on Member States to better implement the European Payment Order and to raise awareness among citizens, businesses, legal professionals and all other stakeholders about the availability, operation, application and advantages of this tool in cross-border cases.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Regulation of 12 December 2006 established the European order for payment procedure. This procedure is a first in this matter. It is optional and is a substitute for national civil and commercial law proceedings in cross-border disputes. Practically, this European procedure does not require recourse to a judge or a lawyer; nor will the applicant bring evidence. It has certain advantages. I cannot support this project, which would impose new burdens and constraints dictated by the Commission on States, causing them to lose their sovereignty a little more. Moreover, simplicity and speed must not be sufficient reasons for sacrificing the legal certainty offered by the judge. I voted against this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The aim of the European order for payment procedure is to allow easier recovery of amounts in cross-border proceedings. The procedure is optional, which means it is available as an alternative to a number of equivalent national procedures in cross-border cases. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this report is to make an assessment of the implementation of the European Payment Order Procedure. The purpose of the European Payment Order Procedure is to enable easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims. I voted in favour of this report, as it calls on Member States to better implement the European Payment Order and to raise awareness among citizens, businesses, legal professionals and all other stakeholders about the availability, operation, application and advantages of this tool in cross-border cases.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the fact that the European order for payment procedure is a procedure in civil and commercial matters relating to undisputed claims, the main purpose of which is to simplify and accelerate the procedure for cross-border recognition and enforcement of creditors' rights in the EU — works successfully in all Member States.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the application of the European Order for Payment procedure. The purpose of the European Order for Payment procedure is to allow for the easier recovery of sums in cross-border proceedings. The procedure is optional, meaning that it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to the various equivalent national procedures. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order to recover uncontested civil and commercial claims. It can be applied for by correspondence or, often, electronically, does not require the assistance of a lawyer, and is enforceable in other Member States without any need for additional formalities. The Commission states that some 12 000 applications for European Orders for Payment are made each year. Where the defendant opposes the application, the procedure cannot continue. I voted in favour because I believe that the Commission should adopt new versions of the standard forms in order to take into account various changes that have occurred over the years.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation aims to simplify, speed up and reduce litigation costs in transnational cases in which more than one Member State is involved. We are therefore talking about a voluntary procedure, whereby European businesses and citizens are expected to be able to provide an effective tool to be used. Given the benefits that this new tool can bring, especially to citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises, I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to improve the implementation and knowledge of the European payment process, which simplifies the recovery of cross-border debts. As this process complements and streamlines national processes, without replacing them, I voted favourably.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: - The report addresses the monitoring of the implementation of the European order for payment procedure, which results from Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006. The procedure allows creditors to easily obtain an order for payment for the recovery of uncontested claims in civil and commercial matters. The application may be submitted by correspondence or often electronically, does not require the intervention of a lawyer and applies in other Member States without further formalities. The European order for payment shall be issued automatically, solely on the basis of the application, but the debtor may, however, submit a statement of objection within 30 days. In the event of opposition, the order for payment procedure shall be terminated and contradictory judicial proceedings may be initiated. This is an optional procedure that can be used in cross-border cases as an alternative to equivalent national procedures.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — The European order for payment procedure is an optional procedure that can be used in cross-border cases as an alternative to domestic procedures. This report does not deal with the introduction of the European order for payment procedure — as early as 2006 — but seeks to increase the use of the European order for payment procedure. Firstly, the processing time of different Member States when providing payment orders will be reduced (it currently requires Member States from 30 days to 6 months), and secondly, the forms concerned will also be able to be completed and submitted online. The rapporteur is addressing possible improvements in the application of the European order for payment procedure (updating of forms, accruing interest on the main requirement, use of foreign languages, deletion of exemptions from the scope, digitisation). In addition, the rapporteur complains of the two-year delay in a Commission review report, which he also considers to be insufficient in content. The Commission is invited to prepare an enhanced, updated and detailed impact assessment. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the motion for a resolution on the application of the European order for payment procedure. The resolution stated that the European order for payment procedure is essentially successful and no major changes are needed at the moment. However, I agree that the most problematic, when it is applied, is the ignorance of EU citizens of its existence and how it can facilitate and accelerate the cross-border application of claims. That is why I believe that it is really necessary to raise awareness of this instrument, not only among citizens but also among Member States' institutions, and to ensure duly informed court officials so that they can work with the European order for payment. It is also necessary to ensure that all standardised forms are regularly updated and that there is no problem with the acceptance of forms in a language other than that of the country. Last but not least, it is necessary to systematically require that the Commission's information and reports in this area be submitted to the European Parliament in a timely manner, unlike the last report presented by the Commission only with a two-year delay.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the assessment of the application of Regulation (EC) 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council to create a European order for payment. The purpose of the European order for payment procedure is to make it easier to collect amounts in cross-border procedures. The procedure is optional, meaning it is available in cross-border cases as an alternative to various equivalent national procedures. In other words, this procedure allows creditors to obtain an order to collect undisputed civil and commercial claims in a simple way. An application for a procedure can be sent by mail, and often electronically, without the assistance of a lawyer, and the order is enforceable in other Member States without the need for additional formalities. It also allows free circulation of European payment orders recognised and executed in all EU countries. The European Order for Payment applies to all EU countries except Denmark. The European order for payment procedure applies to all civil and commercial matters in cases where at least one of the parties lives in an EU country other than the one where the application for the order was made.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the implementation of the European order for payment procedure. The procedure was introduced to allow for the quick, simple and cheap recovery of amounts arising from debts set in a fixed amount and due, and the defendant does not challenge them. The data show that the procedure is mostly performed satisfactorily, but it works significantly below its full capabilities. As I believe that the report well represents the implementation of the European order for payment procedure, points out key shortcomings in implementation and makes reasoned proposals for improving the process, I supported it.
